HEADLINE: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;
Wheeling and Dealing in Taiwan's Backwaters

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
Several recent films have shown contemporary Taiwan in all its up-to-the-minute urbanized glory, but how many have poked their noses into the country's sprawling suburban backwater? Hou Hsiao-hsien's strikingly handsome film "Goodbye South, Goodbye" is set in what might be described as the Taiwanese equivalent of David Mamet territory. As its youthful characters scuttle around the country pursuing various shady money-making schemes, you could imagine their American equivalents wheeling and dealing in a dingier outskirt of Miami.
The director, who was born in China and grew up in southern Taiwan, photographs the landscape with such an intensely observant eye that even what's ugly carries a poetic visual resonance. At moments, the movie pointedly steps away from its characters to linger on the lush subtropical scenery viewed from the back of a moving train or a sleek highway vista seen from a car through brightly tinted lenses. 
 It is a world in which speed is of the essence. The film's peripatetic characters are so engrossed in their plans, they barely notice their surroundings as they jabber over their cellular phones and snap at one another in impatient staccato bursts.
The story follows the luckless entrepreneurial schemes of Kao (Jack Kao); his girlfriend, Ying (Hsu Kuie-ying); his best friend, Hsi (Hsi Hsiang), his younger brother, Flat Head (Lim Goong), and Flat Head's girlfriend, Pretzel (Anne Shizuka Inoh). In the movie's opening scene, Flat Head's volatile temper ruins a short-term gambling operation that Kao and Hsi have set up outside a small-town railroad station. Their master plan is to raise enough money to open a disco in Shanghai, but the telephone constantly brings bad news from the Chinese mainland. Apparently the local bureaucracy is so corrupt that establishing a club would require untold millions in kickbacks, and their debts are already mountainous.
After the disco dream evaporates, the next scheme involves collecting a kickback from the sale to a farmer's cooperative of several thousand pigs removed from land condemned by the Government. With the pittance they make from the deal, Kao and his friends have a drunken celebration. Then Flat Head impulsively decides to confront his uncle and demand his share of his family's recently sold ancestral plot. His request unearths a wasp's nest of complicity and double-dealing, and he finds himself beaten up and thrown in jail.
"Goodbye South, Goodbye" tells its difficult-to-follow story in a fractured elliptical style that mirrors the characters' rootless, jumpy lives. The movie, which the New York Film Festival is showing this evening at 9 at Alice Tully Hall, is really an impressionistic portrait of the dark side of a modern Wild West economy. In this big floating crap game, Kao and his cohorts, despite their frantic efforts, seem destined to be numbered among the losers left behind in a cloud of dust.
 
GOODBYE SOUTH, GOODBYE
 
Directed by Hou Hsiao-hsien; written in Taiwanese (with English subtitles) by Chu Tien-wen, based on a story by King Jieh-we and Jack Kao; photographed by Lee Ping-bin and Chen Hwai-en; edited by Liao Ching-song; music by Lim Giong; production designer, Hwang Wen-ying; produced by Katsuhiro Mizuno, Shozo Ichiyama, King Jieh-wen, Huang Chong and Ben Hsieh. At Alice Tully Hall tonight at 9 as part of the 34th New York Film Festival. Running time: 116 minutes. This film is not rated .
 
WITH: Jack Kao (Kao), Hsu Kuie-ying (Ying), Lim Goong (Flat Head), Anne Shizuka Inoh (Pretzel) and Hsi Hsiang (Hsi)

HEADLINE: Look at Tuition Costs As Shackles From Jail

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The rise in college tuition (news article, Sept. 26), at least in public universities, is attributable to more than the "tax revolt" that slashed local budgets in the 1980's. States are cutting the percentage of their budgets they devote to colleges and universities. California, which for decades has claimed the nation's premier public university system, offers a stark example: In 1967, when Ronald Reagan was Governor, higher education received 17 percent of the state budget. By 1994-95, that percentage had fallen nearly one-third, to 12 percent. 
 Virtually every area of the state budget benefited at higher education's expense, including the health, welfare, business, transportation and housing agencies, as well as the legislative, judicial and executive branches of government. But no area ate up more of the pie than prisons; from 1967 to 1995, the slice going to corrections more than doubled, rising from 4 percent under Mr. Reagan to 9 percent under Gov. Pete Wilson.
Among casualties of the past five years is California's 125-year tradition of providing residents with tuition-free education at the University of California, something the state maintained even through the Depression. For the first time in California's history, the cost of instruction is shifting from the current working generation to its children.
Amazingly, the atrophy of educational opportunity comes at the dawn of the "information age," when most agree that economic and social progress will depend more than ever on education and research. Public higher education, through such institutions as the University of California and the City University of New York, has done more to expand opportunity in the country than perhaps any other engine. What kind of social policy sees prisons as an investment in the future and education as a burden on the public treasury?
 
JESS BRAVIN
Regent, University of California
Berkeley, Calif., Sept. 27, 1996

HEADLINE: New Deal Had a Better Approach on Workfare

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Sept. 27 editorial supporting New York City's workfare program fails to address the real problem with such initiatives. Every survey of job vacancies in the United States in the past three decades has shown that the economy does not provide enough jobs to employ everyone who wants to work. When welfare recipients are put to work performing services that otherwise would be performed by other workers, job opportunities in the regular labor market shrink still faster. 
 This does not reduce joblessness. It merely moves it around. Since welfare recipients are paid less, this kind of workfare also puts downward pressure on wages. The result is the same whether the effects are immediate, as with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority plan, or occur over time, as under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's approach.
New Deal social welfare planners had a better grasp of labor-market realities and drafted their programs accordingly. Their model was a simple one: Provide dignified income support for people who either cannot work or whom society does not expect to work, thereby meeting their material needs while making it possible for them to withdraw from competition for scarce jobs.
For those expected to work, their strategy was to create jobs -- not because requiring people to work for their public assistance benefits was necessary to correct shortcomings in the recipient population, but to preserve their dignity. Harry Hopkins, who headed the New Deal's public relief effort, summed up their attitude: "Give a man a dole and you save his body and destroy his spirit; give him a job and pay him an assured wage, and you save both the body and the spirit."
We should learn from their example and undertake to create enough jobs to employ everyone who wants to work, at wages capable of supporting a dignified existence. If we are unable or unwilling to achieve that goal, because of concerns about what it would cost or fears of inflation, simple honesty should dictate that we stop complaining about welfare dependency and stop pretending that everyone can work in an economy that does not provide enough work.
 
PHILIP HARVEY
Camden, N.J., Sept. 27, 1996
 
The writer is an associate professor of law at Rutgers University.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
An Internet newcomer is making money by selling moving ads as part of screen savers.

BYLINE: By David Barboza 

 BODY:
ADVERTISING in cyberspace has not been a lucrative venture for many. But one Internet company thinks it has hit upon a formula that could work.
Pointcast Inc., a new company based in Cupertino, Calif., has begun what it calls "Internet broadcasting," delivering customized news, weather forecasts, stock quotes, sports scores -- and yes, even advertising -- directly into computers using an Internet connection. After just three months on line, its site is already challenging the Netscape Communications Corporation and Yahoo Inc. as one of the biggest earners of advertising dollars on the Web. 
 In fact, the site's prospects were so highly regarded that within months of its start in May, the company raised $36 million from outside investors, including the Compaq Computer Corporation, the Gannett Company and Knight-Ridder Inc.
"Pointcast is probably the most closely watched application in cyberspace," said Adam Schoenfeld, an analyst at Jupiter Communications Inc. in New York.
People are watching Pointcast because of its novel application called "off-line delivery," a technology that periodically logs onto the Internet and retrieves only the information that users have selected and stores it on the Pointcast "channel viewer," which also acts as a screen saver program.
Analysts say it's the difference between going down to a newsstand and having a newspaper thrown onto the front lawn. The news and information is provided by Reuters, Accu Weather and Time-Warner, with CNN, The New York Times and several Knight-Ridder newspapers coming soon.
"From the very beginning, we approached this with the promise not that it delivers traffic but that it delivers a message to a demographic that is hard to reach," said Anna Zornosa, vice president of sales at Pointcast. "We approached people and said, 'We're going to get you into an environment that you haven't been able to get into.' "
Thus far, Pointcast claims about 500,000 regular subscribers (a million people have registered by downloading the software free over the Internet at www.pointcast.com).
In addition to the news content, viewers see a rotation of animated, 30-second "commercials" on a frame in the upper right-hand corner of the screen, a new advertising tool that executives contend is a compelling alternative to the static banner ads that now dominate the Web.
"With banners, you're talking about very flat messages," Ms. Zornosa said. "If you want to tell a consumer your mint is best, you can't do that in a static banner. Contrast that with a 30-second animated commercial."
Although Pointcast's "smart ads" are not full-motion video, they do run up to 10 frames a second, giving the ads a near-television effect. And because they are downloaded directly into a hard drive, they will also run when a computer is off-line or in the screen saver mode.
Pointcast has about 50 commercials available and says it expects its fourth-quarter advertising revenue to top $3 million. That would make Pointcast one of the top ad-supported sites in cyberspace, according to Adspend, a web-tracking service owned by Jupiter Communications. Netscape tops the list with $9 million in the first half of the year.
Pointcast has successfully lured large consumer-oriented brands into advertising in cyberspace, such as Avis, Fidelity, General Motors, Johnston & Murphy shoes and Nationsbank.
"We're bringing new players to the Web," Ms. Zornosa said, noting that about 25 companies have agreed to pay the standard rate of $100,000 to advertise on Pointcast in the fourth quarter.
For that money, advertisers are guaranteed 20 million "impressions," or viewings, a month. Each time a 30-second spot plays, it registers in the user's computer. When the user logs back on to Pointcast, that information is delivered to the company. Pointcast says the data will be verified by the Audit Bureau of Circulation.
Meanwhile, Pointcast is beginning to face competition from companies including Freeloader Inc. in Washington, and V-Cast Inc. in New York. Yesterday, Berkeley Systems Inc., known for its After Dark screen saver program, introduced a news and information station in the form of a screen saver, with news and features provided by, among others, USA Today, The Wall Street Journal and Sports Illustrated.
Bill Bass, an analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., said the Microsoft Corporation, the "Magilla Gorilla" in the field, was already working on a customized application called Active Desktop, which will be built right into the Windows operating system.
"The problem is the more compelling your work, the more interested Microsoft is in doing something similar," Mr. Schoenfeld at Jupiter Communications said. But, he added, "Pointcast got out first and got out best, and that cannot be negated."

HEADLINE: Panama Still Wants Yankees to Go Home, but Not Right Away

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PANAMA, Sept. 28

 BODY:
Since World War I, Fort Amador has been the jewel of the American military presence here, dominating the Pacific Ocean entrance of the Panama Canal. But on Tuesday, the 207-acre site, which includes the residence of the United States Army commander, is to be transferred to Panamanian control.
The change is the beginning of a marked acceleration in the pace of the American withdrawal from Panama. Over the next year, the United States is also scheduled to hand over Albrook Air Force Station, Gorgas Hospital and the Arraijan fuel depot and reduce its strength here from 6,800 to 4,400 soldiers. 
 In addition, by the time the Federal Government's 1997 fiscal year ends next Sept. 30, the headquarters of the United States Southern Command, here on Quarry Heights in one form or another since 1916, plans to have left for its new billet in Miami.
Among Panamanians, that prospect has awakened as much apprehension as pride.
With barely three years remaining before the final American departure, this country of 2.5 million people finds itself rummaging for ways to put these newly reverting areas to use and gradually realizing that maintenance costs will be huge, especially if private investment projects fail to materialize.
With that in mind, President Ernesto Perez Balladares and his Government are urging Washington to retain some sort of military presence into the 21st century, or at least to contribute to a regional anti-narcotics center that they hope to see based here.
But the Clinton Administration is closing military bases in the United States and facing pressure to cut spending further, and the American response has been lukewarm.
Signed in 1977, the Panama Canal treaties require the United States to give up control of the canal and withdraw from its bases here by Dec. 31, 1999.
That process moved at a snail's pace for more than 15 years, a result first of tension between the countries during the dictatorship of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and then the abolition of the Panama Defense Forces after the American invasion of December 1989. General Noriega was ousted after the invasion.
"This is a subject that must be settled sometime late in 1996 or early in 1997," Panama's Foreign Minister, Ricardo Alberto Arias, said of the prospect of a continued American presence. "If there is going to be a presence, they should prepare for it, and if there is not, we should prepare for it."
Mr. Arias said Panama would insist on some form of "direct economic benefit" as the price of any United States military presence after 1999. Washington has repeatedly said it will not pay rent for the use of any bases, but Panamanian groups have suggested other forms of compensation, ranging from construction of a new bridge or tunnel across the canal to signing a free trade agreement.
In the meantime, the Panamanian Government faces a major test of stewardship with the transfer of Fort Amador. The site includes four small islands, a golf and country club and beaches and causeways that have become popular gathering spots since the Panama Canal Zone went out of existence in 1979.
The Panamanian Government hopes to turn Amador into a tourist attraction and has signed letters of intent for construction of hotels, restaurants and shopping centers on the installation once it leaves American hands. But many ordinary Panamanians are skeptical of those grandiose plans, noting that many existing hotels and time-share condominiums here are empty.

HEADLINE: Ulan Bator Journal;
Mongolia Is Throwing Out 75 Years of Rusty Ideas

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia

 BODY:
A small man sits in an enormous, wood-paneled office inside the austere and cavernous Government House here each morning, a tremendous amount of responsibility suddenly thrust in his hands.
The official, Enkbold, a 30-year-old lawyer, did not have a day of Government experience before this summer, when he assumed charge of an ambitious plan to privatize the bulk of Mongolia's industry, residential housing and land, all at once. His graduation from law school, Mr. Enkbold admits, was only a few months ago. 
 A remarkably young, inexperienced but determined group of politicians has set up the first non-Communist Government here in 75 years. After surprising the ruling party with an upset victory in a parliamentary election on June 30, the Democratic Union, as they call their group, has now begun to carry out a detailed plan for radical reform.
"By our contract with the voters, we have to privatize 60 percent of all state property," said Mr. Enkbold, who like many Mongolians uses only one name. "We have to move fast. The longer we wait, the harder it will be."
Contract?
Mr. Enkbold smiled. Yes, the idea was taken from the Republican Party in the United States. Like the Republican Contract With America, Mongolia's Contract With Voters promises a slashing of Government spending, a sharp reduction of aid to the needy and a top-to-bottom transformation of the Government.
The difference, Mr. Enkbold said, is obvious: America is as big and cash-rich as Mongolia is small and cash-poor, with just 2.4 million people and per capita income of $350 a year. With a Government built to survive on Soviet support, and no longer getting any, Mongolia is in the midst of a wrenching economic transition where inflation is raging and jobs are disappearing.
Although few politicians here predicted the election results, the consensus in hindsight seems as widespread as it is obvious: Voters were fed up with the ruling Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, whose formerly Communist leaders clung to power after democracy arrived in 1990, but failed to undertake serious changes.
In the election, where many herdsmen rode horseback for miles to vote, a clear majority chose the young and untested democratic opposition, which held just 6 of 76 seats in the previous legislature, and said publicly that they hoped to win 15 to 25 seats this year. Instead, they won 50 of 76 seats.
An important tool of the campaign, many politicians agree, was the Contract, which sets out more than 200 one-sentence promises. "To ease the burden on taxpayers by 20 to 30 percent" is one promise; "to support herders' rights to use non-cash payment methods" is another.
"It was an important tool to educate voters," said Hashbat Hulan, a newly elected legislator. "People needed to see that a government can be responsive and can be held accountable. In that sense, it worked."
Leaders of the defeated party, whose own pollsters said later that data predicting their loss had been disbelieved and suppressed, handed over the reins of power with little resistance. A 41-year-old man named Enkhsaikhan took office as Prime Minister in July and got to work.
In his first three months, Mr. Enkhsaikhan and his team have reduced the central Government from 13 ministries to 9, drastically raised the prices of many essential goods and begun fiscal reform to avert a collapse of the central bank.
They also dismissed the directors of several state-owned industries without notice one Saturday night in August, now referred to jokingly by young democrats, ever aware of American history, as the Saturday Night Massacre.
With all this sudden change, there is a palpable sense of excitement among young people in the new Government that they can move Mongolia toward a system characterized by initiative and self-determination, and gradually extinguish the inertia made so prevalent in Soviet times.
"In all of the state's plans, the underlying objective is to encourage people to take charge of their lives, to do something, to get out there and find a way to make money," said Batkhuyag, a senior economic adviser to the Prime Minister. "Otherwise there are simply no options. It's time to move people, to get them to move on their own and not just sit there and wait for instructions."
At the same time, many members of the new Government express amazement that they are in office at all. Mr. Enkbold, for one, confessed that he was as surprised as anyone by the election results, and daunted by the tasks that followed.
"I remember that night," he said. "I had been planning to go on a long vacation with my family, and when the results came in, I was stunned."
Instead of getting a day off, Mr. Enkbold got what he calls "the job no one else would accept."
As chairman of the State Committee on Property, Mr. Enkbold oversees the dismantling of empires that Communist bureaucrats have been building for years. He will also oversee the one-time collection of millions of dollars in revenue.
"It's a great amount of responsibility, but when I step down everyone will hate me," Mr. Enkbold said.
And what qualified him for this huge undertaking?
"I'm a millionaire," he said, having worked as a "suitcase trader," or independent businessman, for several years. "No one can bribe me."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mongolia, with a new government, is starting to untie a knotted bureaucracy after 75 years of Communism. In charge of turning industry over to private ownership is Enkbold, 30, a lawyer with his hands full. (Seth Faison/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Frances Lear, a Mercurial Figure of the Media and a Magazine Founder, Dead at 73

BYLINE: BY ENID NEMY 

 BODY:
Frances Lear, a mercurial figure in the media world who spent some $25 million she received in a divorce settlement to start a magazine named after herself, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 73.
She died of breast cancer, said Dr. Jonathan LaPook, her son-in-law. 
 Ms. Lear was married for 28 years to Norman Lear, the highly successful television producer of series like "All in the Family" and "Maude." Her divorce settlement from Mr. Lear, an amount variously estimated to be between $100 million and $112 million, was one of the largest ever recorded.
"I was very much a part of his thinking," she often said, justifying the amount of the settlement. "Norman could not have done his shows without me."
It is generally considered -- and she herself claimed -- that she was the inspiration for Maude, the feisty and opinionated title character played by Bea Arthur.
Ms. Lear made a name for herself among feminists, working in political campaigns, including Eugene McCarthy's Presidential campaign in 1968; with the National Organization for Women on behalf of the Equal Rights Amendment, which was not ratified; as a partner in an executive search firm specializing in placing women, and as a writer, producing articles for a number of national publications. But she believed that she had faded into the background as her husband's career took off in the 1970's. After Mr. Lear acquired his own movie studio and founded his own civil liberties group, People for the American Way, she discussed her frustrations in an Op-Ed piece in The New York Times in 1981.
A woman in Hollywood is a nonperson, she wrote, "unless she is under 21, powerful or a star." She noted, too, that an industry wife was looked through, never at. In a later interview, recalling her years as a Hollywood wife, she said she had felt constantly ignored and undervalued, had had little self-esteem and had often been depressed.
Ms. Lear, in her own words, "always aspired to something out of the ordinary," and she moved to New York after her divorce in 1985. She quickly set out to change the nonperson identity she had felt in Hollywood by creating Lear's, a magazine aimed at women like herself -- "the woman who wasn't born yesterday," as the magazine said on its cover.
Lear's began publication in 1988 and was a success. It began with a circulation base of 250,000 and grew to 350,000 in a year. But after two years, Ms. Lear abandoned her original concept and lowered the age of the theoretical Lear's woman to over 35. Abandoning the older-age niche put the magazine into competition with other women's magazines, and its advertising never recovered from the move.
Almost immediately after the magazine's debut, Ms. Lear developed a reputation for being unpredictable and hot-tempered. She held a series of intimate lunches in her apartment during which she sought, and then usually ignored, advice for her fledgling publication. She also frequently brought up more of her personal history than most of her guests were prepared for, revealing that she had a Dickensian childhood, that doctors had determined that she was manic-depressive and had prescribed lithium for her condition, that she was an alcoholic and that she had made several suicide attempts over the years.
There ensued a revolving door of editors and writers, many of whom complained of Ms. Lear's inexperience and capricious decisions. Numerous articles were accepted and not published, and layouts were changed at the last minute. In an article in The New York Times, a staff member recalled that when Ms. Lear had been told that she could not change a quotation, she had shouted, "It is my magazine, and I will do what I want."
A former associate once said of her, "She spent her life in Hollywood, where you go on your gut and you are prized for being slightly nuts." Ms. Lear did not deny the validity of the remark. She had lived with that behavior for many years, she said, and "very possibly some of it rubbed off."
Although circulation was more than 500,000 in its final months, Lear's ceased publication in March 1994. It had lost an estimated $25 million to $30 million in its six years of operation.
Ms. Lear then formed Lear Television, investing $500,000 in a video production company. The videos, which she referred to as "television books," were specifically for women and dealt with subjects like personal finances and relationships. She had also just completed a book, "Frances Lear's Guide to Work and Family in the 21st Century," which does not yet have a publisher.
Ms. Lear was born on July 14, 1923, at the Vanderheusen Home for Wayward Girls in Hudson, N.Y., the child of an unwed mother and an unknown father. "The odds were stacked high against me," she once said. She was given the name Evelyn, but she was renamed Frances when she was adopted after 14 months in an orphanage by Aline and Herbert Loeb of Larchmont, N.Y.
"Aline was outwardly affectionate with me for my father's sake, but she did not like me," Ms. Lear wrote in "The Second Seduction," (Alfred A. Knopf, 1992) an autobiography that pulled no punches. The slim volume laid out in harrowing detail her personal history and most intimate experiences.
The memoir related her years of sexual abuse, beginning at age 12, by the man whom her adoptive mother married after Mr. Loeb committed suicide during the Depression. She told, too, of being sent to a psychiatrist, to whom she revealed her stepfather's abuse, and of the psychiatrist's betrayal in repeating her confidences to her mother and stepfather. Her stepfather, she wrote, "met me at the door with a kitchen knife in his hand." Her mother "turned and left the room, went into her bedroom, closed the door and protected her economic hide." On her mother's death, her stepfather was left 90 percent of the $100,000 remaining from Mr. Loeb's insurance, Ms. Lear said.
Ms. Lear attended the Mary A. Burnham School for Girls in Northampton, Mass. In the 1940's and early 50's, she held a number of jobs, primarily in advertising and retailing in New York. She was, she never hesitated to say, dismissed from most of them for behavior like listening in on the boss's telephone conversations and drinking through lunch.
For a brief period, she was the camera girl at the Copacabana nightclub in New York. The job ended when she asked Frank Costello, the camera-shy gangster, whether he would like to have his picture taken. Her boss grabbed her under her armpits, lifted her into the air, carried her into the street, set her down, kissed her goodbye and advised her to try another line of work.
Ms. Lear had two short-lived marriages before she met Mr. Lear. Her first marriage, to Arnold Weiss, a traffic manager at the Navy Yard in Charleston, S.C., lasted less than two years. Her second marriage, to Morton Kaufman ("or Kauffman or Kaufmann -- I cannot remember how to spell my second husband's name," she wrote in the autobiography), was dissolved within a year. She said that he had been unfaithful, leading to her first suicide attempt and three weeks in the psychiatric ward at Bellevue Hospital.
"I tried to commit suicide three times seriously and three times with minimal interest in the outcome," she once said.
She was 33 and a buyer for better active sportswear at Lord & Taylor when she married Mr. Lear, who was then a television writer, and moved to California. She turned down a buyer's job with a Los Angeles store and concentrated on homemaking and rearing her two daughters.
One day, she recalled, she realized that "we had become he." She began to think seriously of leaving her marriage. It took her 15 years, she said, "to work up the courage."
"I believe the second half of one's life is meant to be better than the first half," she said in an interview last year. "It is certainly true of me."
Ms. Lear is survived by her two daughters, Maggie Beth Lear and Kate Breckir Lear (who is married to Dr. LaPook), both of Manhattan, and two grandsons.

In His Own Words

 BODY:

BOB DOLE
Speaking by telephone yesterday from Florida to employees of Netscape in Mountain View, Calif.:
"The American voters and certainly people there today face a clear choice this year. Our opponents are liberals who want the public sector to grow without limits. We want the private sector to grow without limits. Our liberal opponents have big ambitions for the Federal Government and we have big ambitions for the American people. These differences will become even more apparent in the remaining five weeks of this campaign. 
 "As we go into the home stretch, let me say again that we're pleased to have you on our side and we'll be on your side after the election. We need your help to spread the word about our vision for America.
"You're the ones creating the jobs and expanding the frontiers of industry and making America the most competitive productive country in the world. There are tens of thousands out there who want to follow in your footsteps and we want that next generation of Americans to be just as successful and to help transform the world just as dramatically as you have. That's why Jack and I are campaigning on our economic program."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Corn and Soybean Prices Off; Energy and Gold Also Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Corn and soybean futures prices fell yesterday amid expectations of good weather in the Midwest and a Government report that stockpiles were unexpectedly strong.
On other markets, energy and gold futures prices retreated. 
 The Agriculture Department said soybean inventories on Sept. 1 were 183 million bushels, 20 million above expectations and 13 million above its most recent estimate.
The Agriculture report also said the 1995 harvest was 25 million bushels higher than expected, and there was talk among investors on the Chicago Board of Trade that this year's yields would also surpass expectations.
The harvest begins this week, and warm, dry weather should allow farmers to make good progress as well as strengthen immature crops. Prospects for a damaging Midwest frost have also waned.
Corn futures fell to the lowest spot price in a year after the Agriculture Department said the final 1995-96 stocks would be greater than the current forecast.
Soybeans for November delivery plunged 25 1/4 cents, to $7.58 a bushel, the lowest price since mid-August. December corn fell 6 1/2 cents, to $2.96 3/4 a bushel.
Energy prices were mostly lower in light volume on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid expiring contracts and word that Iraq would soon be to resume oil sales.
The United Nations hopes to approve a deal to allow the Iraqi sales in a matter of weeks.
Crude oil for November fell 22 cents, to $24.38 a barrel; the expiring October heating oil contract rose 0.02 cent, to 71.51 cents a gallon, but all other contracts fell. The expiring October unleaded gasoline contract fell 1.89 cents, to 62.71, but other contracts fell as well. Natural gas for November delivery rose 3.3 cents, to $2.214 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Gold fell to a 18-month low after the International Monetary Fund said it did not see inflation accelerating in industrial countries. Gold for December delivery fell $2.30 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange, to $380.50, the lowest price since November 1995.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Rose Sharply in August

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Sales of new homes during August rose at the briskest pace in a decade, the Commerce Department reported today, while personal income and consumer spending both picked up during the month.
New-home sales rose 4.7 percent, propelled by strong sales in the Midwest, to a surprisingly strong seasonally adjusted annual rate of 832,000 in August. That was the fastest clip since sales hit a rate of 857,000 a year in April 1986. 
 Both June and July rates were revised upward, with July sales up 8.3 percent, to 795,000 a year, from 7.9 percent, or 783,000.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said that August incomes from wages, salaries and other sources rebounded six-tenths of 1 percent, in line with expectations, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $6.5 trillion. Incomes had risen one-tenth of 1 percent in July.
Personal consumption also rose six-tenths of 1 percent, above the projected gain of five-tenths of 1 percent. Consumption rose two-tenths of 1 percent in July.
Analysts said that the surge in August new-home sales underlined the resilience of the housing industry. But, they added, both reports remained consistent with an expected slowing in economic activity in the third quarter, which ended today.
"The basic reason that G.D.P. will slow so significantly in the third quarter is that personal consumption spending falls off from the second quarter," said David Orr, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C.
He predicted that after growing at a two-year high of 4.7 percent a year in the second quarter, the gross domestic product would be found to have slowed to a 2 percent rate in the third quarter.
The big surprise today was the climb in sales of new homes, which had been predicted to decline instead of advance to a 10-year peak.
The new-home sector "has nine lives; it refuses to plateau," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis.
The August jump in national sales was led by a 28.9 percent increase in the Midwest, where houses sold at a rate of 196,000 a year.
Otherwise, the only region where August sales rose was in the South, up a modest 2.6 percent, to 355,000 a year. That was the strongest rate since 381,000 in July 1995.
Sales in the Northeast fell sharply in August by 13.9 percent, to an annual rate of 62,000, and in the West they declined 2.7 percent, to 219,000.
A vibrant economy, in its sixth year of expansion from the last recession in 1990-91, is aiding the housing sector by making consumers more confident about taking on long-term mortgage commitments.
"There's hundreds of thousands of jobs being created every month, incomes are being generated and it's giving consumers the wherewithal to go out and purchase a home," said David Lereah, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association.
He said he expected the upward trend to hold: "Applications for mortgages are up, so this should continue."
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said that rates for a 30-year mortgage averaged 8 percent in August, down from 8.25 percent in July and 8.32 percent in June. But that was still much higher than the average 7.03 percent January rate.
Consumer spending rose in five of the six months through August, with the only decline coming in June, when it fell five-tenths of 1 percent.
The August spending rise was concentrated on durable goods, which surged 3.1 percent, to an annual rate of $644 billion, from $624.9 billion in July.
By contrast, spending on nondurable products was flat at $1.54 trillion, while spending for services gained just three-tenths of 1 percent in August to $2.99 trillion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Hits Highest Level In Two Years Against Yen

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The dollar jumped against the Japanese yen yesterday, rising to its highest level since the start of 1994. But while the dollar is now 38 percent above its record 1995 low, analysts are not yet convinced that its long-term turnaround is at hand.
The dollar was at 111.40 yen in late trading in New York, up from 110.83 Friday and its highest since Jan. 25, 1994, when it was 111.03. 
 Analysts said that the dollar could continue to move toward the 120 level in the short term as Japanese investors move more aggressively to invest abroad, which means selling yen to buy foreign currencies, especially the dollar.
But the longer-term outlook remains uncertain, in part because the big interest-rate differential that now exists between Japan and the United States -- which favors the dollar -- should narrow when the Japanese economy gets back on its feet. Meanwhile, the stronger dollar will hurt American exporters, leading to a wider trade deficit with Japan, which could send it down.
"Every dollar rally has all the health warnings attached to it," said Peter von Maydell, a currency economist at UBS Ltd. in London.
"I don't think it is going to run away," said Charles A. Spence, vice president for foreign exchange at Standard Chartered Bank in New York. "It is not a long-term change."
The dollar hit its postwar low of 80.63 yen on April 18, 1995. So far this year, it is up 7.6 percent against the yen, and 1.5 percent in the third quarter alone. That rally, and a 6 percent rally of the dollar against the German mark, could have a small negative impact on American companies that depend a lot on profits from abroad.
According to Thomas Doerflinger, an investment strategist at Paine Webber, the dollar's jump in the second quarter clipped from 2 percent to 5 percent off sales growth. But he said the hit this quarter should be less because the dollar was up less against all the currencies of the United States' major trading partners.
The immediate trigger for the jump in the dollar, according to traders, economists and analysts, is the end of the Japanese fiscal half-year, when a stronger dollar improves the valuation of Japanese companies' foreign assets. Additionally, comments over the weekend from American officials and their Group of Seven allies supported a stronger dollar.
Robert Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs who was in Washington for the meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, said that currency traders were looking for a sign that the Clinton Administration might be unhappy if the dollar moved beyond 110 yen, in part because American auto makers had been grumbling about a stronger dollar hurting exports.
"There were not signals to that effect and that gave the market confidence," Mr. Hormats said. Indeed, in statements over the weekend, officials led by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said they favored a strong dollar.
Less than two weeks ago, when the dollar was at 109.43 yen, Robert J. Eaton, chairman and chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation, said that the dollar was too high against the yen and that its recent strength partly explained Japanese auto makers' decisions this autumn to hold prices level or even cut them in the United States market.
"It's quite clear that the dollar is overvalued; there's no doubt about that," he said.
The longer-term support for the dollar has been a push by the Japanese Government for a weaker yen, been shown in part by an encouragement of investment abroad.
This policy has been especially apparent recently because a weaker yen and a stronger dollar is an important tool Japan uses to stimulate its economy by making its exports cost less when sold in other countries, especially the United States.
The Government's other tools -- lower interest rates and higher Government spending -- have been pretty much exhausted. Official interest rates in Japan are at a half of 1 percent, compared with 5.25 percent in the United States, which is one reason that investing in United States Government securities is so attractive for the Japanese. In addition, the Japanese Government has already poured billions of dollars of program money into the economy.
"This is a dollar held higher against the yen not on its own merits but by Japan," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y. "Fundamentals would prompt me to look for a cheaper dollar."
Michael Rosenberg, head of international fixed-income research at Merrill Lynch & Company, said that the dollar should also get a lift against the mark and other European currencies for the same reason -- Europe needs to keep interest rates low to stimulate growth and its currencies weaker to help exporters.
In fact, the recent cut in interest rates by the Bundesbank, the German central bank, was preceded by comments from its officials indicating that they thought the strength of the mark was impeding economic growth. Yesterday, the dollar was at 1.5245 marks in late New York trading, up from 1.5235 late on Friday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Lower On Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities turned lower yesterday for the second consecutive session, mostly on the strength of a housing report that surprised the market and again raised investors' concerns about inflation and higher interest rates.
The 30-year bond slipped 3/32, to a price of 97 28/32 to yield 6.92 percent, up from 6.90 percent on Friday. 
 A 4.7 percent jump in new-home sales for August surprised the market, and defied economists' predictions of a slowdown in that sector even as borrowing costs have risen over the last six months. The Chicago Purchasing Managers' September index, which was also released yesterday, showed a slight dip but did little to offset the market's negative reaction to the housing report.
Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said the economic momentum had slowed considerably from the hectic pace earlier this year, but the key question remained "whether the economy is slowing fast enough to allay inflation concerns."
New-home sales had been expected to decline to 744,000, from 783,000 in July, but instead surged to a 10- year high of 832,000 units on an annualized basis.
Overseas buying coming into the New York session did help lift prices early. A strong dollar, which surpassed recent highs against the Japanese yen and approached them against the German mark, also limited the downside to trading, since a strong dollar makes United States investments like Treasury securities attractive to foreign investors.
Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said that "the quarter-ending enthusiasm we saw Thursday and Friday has tempered," noting that volume was low even for a Monday.
"Data this morning came in surprisingly strong on the housing sector, to a decade high," Mr. Regan noted, adding, "This latest economic data are now giving the bond bulls some pause to reflect," he added
Analysts said the additional economic data due to be released this week could change the mood of the market. Due out are the National Association of Purchasing Management Report for September and the Conference Board's leading indicators for August, both to be released today, and on Friday, the Labor Department will release the closely watched employment figures for September. "By then many in the marketplace will perhaps have adjusted their buoyant feelings of last week," Mr. Regan said.
"We seem to be in a new trading band of 6.85 percent to a 6.95 percent yield on the long bond, or in the case of the December bond future, a price trading range of between 109 8/32 to 110 8/32," he said. Yesterday the December contract settled at a price of 109 6/32, down 9/32 on the day.
Elsewhere, as expected, rates were off in the Treasury's regular weekly bill auction. The average rate for a three-month bill was 5.01 percent, down 17 basis points from last week, while the six-month bill was 5.17 percent, down 13 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Underwriting Shrinks, and Thus Do Fees

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Stock and bond underwriting shriveled in the quarter that ended yesterday, a sure sign that chief financial officers of some of the big investment banks are going to have to perform some fancy accounting footwork to dress up results.
The securities industry underwrote $205.3 billion of domestic debt and equity issues in the third quarter, a drop of 13 percent from the second quarter. Executives attributed the decline to uncertainty concerning the direction of the stock market and interest rates. 
 Wall Street firms underwrote $20.6 billion of common stock, half the level of equity underwriting they did in the preceding quarter, according to the Securities Data Corporation, which tracks the investment banking business.
They underwrote $77.5 billion of straight and convertible debt issues, a decline of roughly 40 percent from the second quarter.
Jitters over corporate earnings, weakness in technology issues, and uncertainty as to whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates combined with the traditional end-of-summer slowdown to create a roller-coaster environment for underwriting, executives at several securities firms said yesterday.
"After six months of steadily rising interest rates, we had a lot of gyrations up and down," John C. Qua, co-head of global debt capital markets at Merrill Lynch & Company, said.
Fee income, which set a record last quarter of $2.91 billion, plunged to $1.62 billion in the third quarter, according to Securities Data. Part of the reason is that the underwriting of initial public offerings, which traditionally earns the fattest fees, plunged 59 percent to $7.6 billion after breaking records in the second quarter.
And though bond underwriting compared favorably with the third quarter of last year, and stock issuance declined only slightly, year-over-year, fees dropped 14.3 percent, another indication that competition from commercial banks is driving down profit margins.
Still, most capital-markets executives said that there were signs of improvement in the last three weeks of September, as initial public offerings that had been postponed when the stock market dropped in July were floated, and investors showed an appetite for more complex bond issues and junk bonds.
"If the election doesn't pose a big change -- and most people don't think it will -- you're going to see a second push to get business done before the Thanksgiving holidays," said Kelley Millet, the managing director in charge of debt capital markets at J. P. Morgan & Company.
While Merrill Lynch topped the combined debt and equity underwriting chart yet again, the rest of the ranks were scrambled.
J. P. Morgan & Company stunned its investment-banking rivals, who like to call it a commercial bank, by jumping to fourth place, leap-frogging even Goldman, Sachs & Company and Morgan Stanley & Company, which typically round out the top three.
They fell to sixth and seventh place, respectively, ceding their usual positions to Lehman Brothers and Salomon Brothers.
The ongoing boom in mergers and acquisitions continues to help drive the underwriting business, as companies that have made acquisitions scramble to refinance. Merrill, for instance, recently underwrote a $1.4 billion debt refinancing for Aetna's purchase of U.S. Healthcare.
And Mr. Qua noted that Merrill had underwritten an unusual amount of "put" bonds, which allow their holders to lock in interest rates. "People are more confused about the direction of interest rates," he said. "Sentiment is very day-to-day, and if you're a portfolio manager, you're looking to hedge against the uncertainty."
On the equities side of the business, the market for initial public offerings has started to show renewed signs of life lately, as several new issues that were postponed in the summer came to market in the last couple of weeks. Smith Barney, the Travelers Group's investment banking unit, brought RMH Teleservices public; Goldman, Sachs brought Houston Exploration and Applied Analytical, and a host of other issues came to market as well.
"That bodes well for the final quarter," said Kathleen S. Smith, a principal at the Renaissance Capital Corporation, a research firm based in Greenwich, Conn. "We are concerned, though, that should the market hit any negatives, there will be a lot of trouble because there are a record number of deals in the pipeline."
Brian Hehir, head of equity capital markets at Merrill, said stable interest rates, strong mutual-fund cash flows and solid earnings had helped stabilize the equity underwriting market.
Additionally, new issues are being priced more rationally to entice investors. "Valuations have improved from an investor's standpoint particularly in the i.p.o. market, and we're continuing to see good reception for quality companies," he said.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Finally, That Championship Season

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
As the front-office employees of the Texas Rangers celebrated at a party in the early hours last Saturday morning, one man approached the team's general manager.
"I want to congratulate the man with the plan," the employee told Doug Melvin. 
 In the team's 23 years in Texas before Melvin arrived, the Rangers' five general managers had plans, but the blueprints always faded and the Rangers with them. Until last Friday night, the Rangers had never won a championship, had never reached the post-season.
Except for the four-year-old expansion teams, the Rockies and the Marlins, every team in the major leagues had won division championships, even other expansion teams like the Blue Jays and the Mariners, who began life 16 years after baseball created the Washington Senators Part II and five years after the Senators moved to Arlington, Tex.
Melvin, who began his baseball career as a minor league pitcher the same year the Senators became the Rangers (1972), arrived in Arlington two years ago as a rookie general manager and set about trying to eradicate the stigma that stuck to the Rangers like Krazy Glue.
"The plan was to change the philosophy and the attitude of the organization, to bring in pitching and defense," said Melvin, a Canadian with links to the Yankees. "I had asked a lot of people to give me a description of the Texas Rangers, and most people said power hitting, a lot of hitting, a lot of injuries, no pitching and the defense wasn't very good."
The Rangers were indeed notorious for their poor defense, perennially finishing at or near the bottom of the defensive statistics. The most noted aspect of their pitching was the frequency with which their starters seemed to suffer injuries. Their hitting had been good, but not good enough to overcome the shortcomings in the other parts of their game.
First, Melvin hired a manager, Johnny Oates, for whom pitching and defense were just as important as they were to the general manager. The second step in his plan was to find a player who would epitomize the Rangers' new defensive philosophy. The player turned out to be center fielder Otis Nixon, and to get him, Melvin sent Jose Canseco to the Boston Red Sox.
"At the time I took a lot of heat for trading Canseco," Melvin said. "My wife and I were in a restaurant, and the waiter made some sarcastic remark about trading him. I wondered if I was in the right position. But that turned out to be a big plus. It changed the attitude of the organization."
The trade was symbolic because it sacrificed hitting for fielding. It also was economical because it freed money Melvin used to sign pitchers as free agents.
Nixon remained with the Rangers only for last season, then left as a free agent. But they signed Darryl Hamilton to replace him, and the new center fielder went through this season without an error, leading a team that committed the fewest errors in the major leagues, 87, or barely one every other game. In the not-long-ago season of 1992, the Rangers made 154 errors, or nearly one a game.
Melvin's change in philosophy resulted in a dramatic change in performance as well.
In gaining their first championship, the Rangers held first place in the American League West for all but six days of the season. But winning the title wasn't all that easy. A six-and-a-half-game lead in late June dwindled to one game in early August, and a nine-game lead on Sept. 11 virtually disappeared in the space of eight days.
A players' meeting in Toronto on Aug. 9, after a ninth-inning, 3-2 loss in Detroit the night before, became the catalyst for the stretch that catapulted the Rangers away from the Mariners over the next month. It was Dave Valle's meeting.
Valle, a Queens native, is a 35-year-old reserve catcher who plays infrequently because the Rangers have the best catcher in the league in Ivan Rodriguez. But this season he has served another role, and he played it to the hilt that night in Toronto. His words to his teammates were so inspiring that Dennis Cook, a relief pitcher, said afterward, "I was so pumped up I wanted to wear my uniform home to bed."
Valle explained yesterday that he requested the meeting because a post-game meeting after the loss to the Tigers left a bad taste.
"It was a pretty harsh one," he said. "Things were said. I felt the things left undone would cause scars and division among the guys. We were such a tight-knit group, but it was in the heat of the moment after a very difficult loss that things were said. On the plane that night I felt something needed to be done to right the wrongs. I kind of stepped out on a limb and called a meeting."
Valle's goal was to elicit from each player a commitment to the team, a promise to put aside all individual accomplishments and statistics. He went around the clubhouse, stopping before each player, pointing a finger at him and asking, "Are you willing to make a commitment?" Whenever a player hesitated before replying, Valle refused to move, waiting until he received an affirmative response.
"He got in everyone's face and made them say, 'Yes, I will,' " Melvin said. "We jelled even more as a team and took off from there."
But 9 losses in 10 games in mid-September sent their lead plummeting once again, from nine games over the Mariners to one, and gave the skeptics an opportunity to raise the past. "People were saying, 'Same old Rangers; they're not going to win again,' " Melvin said.
Even Oates, speaking of the Mariners' four-game sweep of the Rangers in Seattle, said: "It wasn't so much we were looking over our shoulder at Seattle. We were looking over our shoulder at our history -- 25 years of not being there, of never winning." And Melvin acknowledged, "Even I started thinking, 'Good gosh, is this going to be one of those years?' "
But the players and the fans held firm. The fans flooded the team's hotel on the road with supportive faxes, and Eddie Napoleon, one of the coaches, posted them on the clubhouse walls. The players recalled what they had promised Valle and responded.
In the early hours of the morning last Saturday, after Seattle had lost in Oakland to give the Rangers their first division championship and everyone was partied out, Doug and Ellen Melvin prepared to leave the Ballpark in Arlington. With them were their 12-year-old daughter, Ashley, and her friend.
"Everything reeks of alcohol," Ellen Melvin recalled thinking. "How do I take Ashley's friend home and explain to her parents?"
But that was one of those things that, under the circumstances, didn't need explaining.

HEADLINE: Philanthropist Pledges Help To Immigrants

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
George Soros, the Hungarian-born philanthropist and international financier, said today he would give $50 million to assist legal immigrants in the United States.
Mr. Soros said he was creating the new charity in response to the recently enacted welfare law that greatly restricts public benefits like food stamps and Supplemental Security Income for legal immigrants. 
 "I am appalled by Congress's recent action to deny vital public assistance to noncitizens who are lawfully resident in this country," Mr. Soros, a naturalized United States citizen, said at a news conference.
"This is a clear-cut case of injustice and is contrary to this country's proud tradition of welcoming immigrants," he said. Mr. Soros emigrated to England from Hungary in 1947, and to the United States in 1956.
The money will go largely to pay for the costs of immigrants applying to become naturalized United States citizens and to assist local and community organizations that provide English-language classes and other aid to immigrants.
More than 1.1 million immigrants have become naturalized citizens this year, and Federal officials expect the harsh provisions in the welfare bill to push equally large numbers of legal immigrants toward citizenship in the next few years.
The charity, called the Emma Lazarus Fund after the poet whose words are inscribed on the Statue of Liberty, will also support organizations conducting legal or educational efforts on the behalf of immigrants.
Immigrant-rights groups expressed astonishment today at Mr. Soros's new project.
"We're thrilled," said Donald Kerwin, chief operating officer for Catholic Legal Immigration Network, a public-interest organization based in Washington. "This is probably more money in a given year than all the foundations and state bar associations give out. It's really shocking."
The new charity is an offshoot of the Open Society Institute and other Soros philanthropies, which spent $350 million in 1995 mostly in countries undergoing the transition to democratic regimes.
In addition, Mr. Soros was one of the early proponents of lifting the siege of Sarajevo during the Bosnian war. He proposed a $50 million aid plan to Bosnia in 1993, but suspended the offer when logistical details bogged down in bickering.
More recently, Mr. Soros has given out or pledged nearly $15 million to help change the nation's drug policy. For example, Mr. Soros has advocated legalizing the medical use of marijuana, and has been critical of efforts to treat drug use as a crime rather than a medical problem.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "THE DETAILS: Restricting Immigrants"
Through changes in welfare legislation and in the immigration law, Congress has imposed new restrictions on illegal immigrants and on the use of public money for illegal immigrants and in some cases, legal immigrants.
 
PUBLIC ASSISTANCE Illegal immigrants will be ineligible for most public assistance programs financed by the Federal Government or the states.
 
They cannot receive grants, Federal contracts or loans, and will not be eligible for benefits under programs like the Earned Income Tax Credit, Supplemental Security Income, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, social service block grants, Medicaid or food stamps, housing, unemployment or financial aid for college.
 
Medical emergencies will be covered. Children who are illegal immigrants could attend Head Start or receive immunizations.
 
Under the welfare legislation President Clinton signed in August, most legal immigrants will be ineligible for many public assistance programs.
 
EMPLOYEE VERIFICATION PROGRAMS Pilot programs will be established in five states with high populations of illegal immigrants so that employers could voluntarily check the legal status of prospective workers through a Justice Department program.
 
Verification documents will be restricted so that employers must require prospective employees to produce a United States passport, alien registration card or other authorization issued by the Justice Department. Under the agreement, various other forms, like a certificate of citizenship or naturalization, an unexpired foreign passport or a birth certificate will not be acceptable.
 
EMPLOYER SANCTIONS The new immigration financing will allow for 300 more employees a year for three years to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. They are to be deployed to investigate the unlawful hiring of illegal immigrants and the smuggling of illegal immigrants.
 
DISCRIMINATION The burden of proof will be raised for prospective employees who claim hiring discrimination on the basis of immigration status, so that a job applicant will have to prove that rejection is a result of intentional discrimination.
 
BORDER CONTROL The number of border patrol agents will be doubled to 10,000 by 2001 and 2,700 detention cells will be added.
 
SMUGGLING Penalties for smuggling people into the United States will be increased for a prison term of up to 10 years.
 
FRAUDULENT DOCUMENTS Criminal penalties for fraud or misuse of government-issued identification documents will increase from 5 years imprisonment to 15 years.
 
REMOVAL OF ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS Anyone trying to enter the country without the proper documents will be subject to deportation. If someone seeking asylum is found to have no credible fear of persecution after an initial meeting with an officer, the person will be subject to removal after a hearing before an immigration judge. Such a hearing will have to take place within seven days, and there would be no additional appeals. Anyone suspected of terrorism will be immediately rejected.
 
Only one hearing will be held and notices of removal proceedings no longer will be given in Spanish.
 
Mandatory detention will be imposed on those ordered to leave the country.
 
EXCLUSION AND DEPORTATION Anyone who represents a terrorist organization will be deported or denied entry. Any former United States citizen who officially renounces citizenship to avoid paying taxes will not be permitted to re-enter the country. And any student who violated a special nonimmigrant status visa will be banned for five years.
 
SPONSORING LEGAL IMMIGRANTS For those who sponsor legal immigrants for citizenship, the income guidelines will be altered so that sponsors would have to earn more than 125 percent of the poverty level. (The poverty level, according to 1995 figures, was less than $15,455 for a family of four.)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE WEST;
Democratic Tide Is Eroding G.O.P.'s Stronghold in West

SERIES: The Race For President: The West

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30

 BODY:
George Bush fared poorly against Bill Clinton in the West in the 1992 Presidential campaign, and four years later, Bob Dole is struggling to head off a similar debacle, especially in California.
With Election Day a little more than five weeks away, most voters living in the great swath of America that stretches from the high Rockies to the surf of Hawaii seem reasonably satisfied with their lot at this point, particularly with the way the Western economy has recovered. Because of that, pollsters and analysts say, voters appear to be poised, unless the political situation changes, to give Mr. Clinton most of the region's 119 electoral college votes, 44 percent of the 270 he needs to win a second term. 
 If that happens, the 13 states of the West, a mostly Republican, conservative stronghold in Presidential elections until 1992, could be on their way to becoming a solid part of the Democratic base in election years to come.
The latest round of polls show that only voters living in sparsely populated Alaska, Wyoming, Idaho and Utah now seem firmly committed to Mr. Dole. And those states, less homogenized and less affected by outside forces than many other Western states, account for just 15 electoral votes. Nevada, with 5 electoral votes, is rated a toss-up.
But pollsters report that Mr. Clinton leads Mr. Dole in California, with its 54 electoral votes, as well as in Montana, Colorado, New Mexico, Washington, Oregon, Hawaii and, most surprising of all, Arizona, which last voted for a Democratic President in 1948. In many of those states, including California, the President's lead is in the comfortable range of a dozen or more points.
Mr. Clinton carried 8 Western states in 1992, an early sign that the growing and urbanizing region -- 9 out of 10 Coloradans now live in cities -- was beginning to loose itself somewhat from its traditional conservative moorings. Analysts say Mr. Clinton could win in the West by much larger margins this year.
Ross Perot, who ran strongly as an independent in many Western states in 1992, is hardly showing any poll strength this year. In Utah, where he captured almost 30 percent of the vote four years ago, helping to put Mr. Clinton into a politically embarrassing third-place finish, he is now running third, supported by only 5 percent of those polled.
"We feel especially confident about the West this year," said Douglas Sosnik, the White House director of political affairs. "It's now a major part of our base, particularly California and the Pacific Northwest. We're also more than competitive now in the Rockies. As with the rest of the country, people in the West just can't see much reason to vote for Bob Dole, not when Bill Clinton has both the economy and his legislative agenda on the move."
The evidence of the President's strength and Mr. Dole's weakness in the West can perhaps best be seen in the weekly compilations of polls from around the country put together by The Hotline, a national political newsletter. Most of the polls cited are done by independent survey organizations for news outlets.
The Clinton campaign managers, viewing the California polls, are so confident of victory that they have scaled back on buying television time in the state. Mr. Clinton has already put much time into California, visiting it 27 times in the last four years, and he has always said he must win here to be re-elected, given Republican inroads in the once solidly Democratic South.
"We don't see Dole closing in any of our polls, so we're not going to spend money we don't have to spend," said Bill Carrick, a top Clinton strategist from Los Angeles. "If Dole begins to move, then we'll begin to spend and counter. But we don't think a candidate who is pro-tobacco, anti-abortion, loves assault rifles and really doesn't spend any time in the region is ever going to move very much, not in California and not in much of the rest of the West as it exists today. There's a lot of talk about Dole getting out of California. Well, we're wondering when he'll get in."
Mr. Dole's running mate, Jack Kemp, kicking off a four-day swing through California on Friday, insisted that the race was narrowing. Then he sought to put aside the persistent rumors that Mr. Dole, like Mr. Bush before him, would shortly abandon California. The speculation has been that Mr. Dole would be forced to conclude that his campaign here was a hopeless, money-depleting quest in a state whose sun-worshiping, kicked-back voters seem unwilling so far to embrace an oft-dour septuagenarian from inside the Beltway.
"Rumor aside," Mr. Kemp said, his voice rising earnestly, "we are going to spend a lot of time in California, a lot of money. It is critical to our victory effort."
A more pointed, if less sweeping, argument for a continued Dole presence in the state came from Steven A. Merksamer, a Dole strategist and adviser from Sacramento, Calif., and a close Kemp friend.
"Bob Dole may be trailing now, but he isn't going to pull out of California because California history is on his side," Mr. Merksamer said. "Any number of Republican candidates down through the years -- Deukmejian, Bush, Wilson -- have come from more than a dozen points back to win at the wire, or finish even better. It's history you can't ignore. And it can happen again in 1996 because Bob Dole's solid message of fiscal and social responsibility eventually will cut with Californians."
But another veteran Republican analyst and consultant from Sacramento, Tony Quinn, is less sanguine.
"The problem is, ultimately, that Bob Dole just can't seem to connect with people out here in the West, particularly Californians," Mr. Quinn said. "He's just not one of us, not of us. He's a product of Washington, D.C., running in a region that tends to see Washington as the enemy. And on top of that, he's competing with a guy who not only has a good economy going for him but who's been out here in this state two dozen times or more, dumping Federal largesse everywhere there's been an earthquake or fire or closed defense plant.'
Mr. Quinn sees a strong possibility that Mr. Dole will not only lose in California and much of the West but that he will truncate his campaign in some states, leaving other Republican candidates on their own.
"There very well could be a big voter turnout problem for the party before this is all over," he said.
One measure of Mr. Dole's weakness and Mr. Clinton's strength in California can be found in Orange County, just south of Los Angeles.
The county has long been as hard-core Republican as any in America, and any Republican running statewide has traditionally relied on a solid vote there to offset the usually big Democratic vote in Los Angeles and San Francisco. But recent Orange County polls show Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole running neck and neck there. One pollster, Richard H. Hertz, of Bodega Bay, Calif., found that the strongly recovering California economy was the main reason for that.
"While voters are still concerned," he said, "they are considerably more optimistic about the nation's future and their own personal economics."
Elsewhere in much of the West, analysts and poll takers, both independent and partisan, say Mr. Clinton's strength has similar underpinnings -- and then some.
"Bill Clinton is more popular in the Northwest -- Washington and Oregon -- than he was 2 years ago, 12 months ago, or even 6 months ago," said Tim Hibbitts, a Portland pollster. "He's helped a lot by the lack of a strong opponent in Bob Dole and also by Dole's ties to Congressional Republicans who are viewed as too extreme."
In Arizona, which was last in the Democratic column when Harry S. Truman won the Presidency, Mr. Clinton's surprising lead over Mr. Dole is largely attributed to deep angst among retirees about whether overly zealous Republicans on Capitol Hill might try to cut Social Security and Medicare benefits.
Still, there are states where Mr. Dole has good things going for him politically, places where the Old West, not the New West, still dominates. Mr. Dole leads in Wyoming by perhaps 10 points or better.
"My feeling is that Dole will quite easily take the state," said Larry Hubbell, chairman of the University of Wyoming political science department. "This has got to be one of the most Republican states in the country, and there's a lot of anti-Washington and anti-Federal feeling."
But it is the New West, especially California, that has the most electoral-college clout now.
Ken Khachigian, Mr. Dole's chief California strategist and a veteran of numerous Presidential campaigns, argues that the former Kansas Senator is politically nimble enough to bridge the gap between new and old. "He can do it; he can do it," he insisted.
But Bob Mulholland, the chief political strategist for the California Democratic Party, says he sees the winner as Mr. Clinton, going away.
"Bob Dole doesn't surf," Mr. Mulholland said.

LENGTH: 513 words

HEADLINE: Mexican Justice

 BODY:
President Ernesto Zedillo has promised to enforce the laws of Mexico fully and impartially, even with top officials of his Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI. The future of political and economic reform requires the fair administration of justice. But Mr. Zedillo and his party have repeatedly delivered a good deal less than that.
The latest example came last week when a PRI majority prematurely terminated a congressional investigation into possible crimes or misconduct by Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. 
 The Zedillo administration can undo some of the damage by insisting that its attorney general vigorously prosecute the charges against Raul Salinas in the courts. But the administration's own record in prosecuting other politically sensitive cases is not encouraging. Unless Mr. Zedillo acts more boldly the culture of impunity will prevail, and continue to thwart efforts at reform.
Raul Salinas is now in jail facing charges of murder and illegal enrichment. But since his arrest on the murder charges 19 months ago, his case has moved slowly. The Government's attempt to prove that he masterminded the assassination of a top ruling party official has stalled. The corruption charges were brought later, largely as a result of Swiss and American investigations of Mr. Salinas's large offshore bank accounts. Mexican efforts to uncover the sources of his enrichment have lagged.
These investigations are highly sensitive, since they could involve some of the country's most prominent businessmen and politicians. The congressional inquiry into Raul Salinas's conduct as a top official of the Government's food distribution company was seen by many Mexicans as an attempt to force the pace of the wider investigation.
Mexicans now wonder if the multi-party congressional inquiry was shifted offstage to the closed world of the attorney general's office and the courts because it was drawing so much public attention to currently powerful figures.
By appointing an opposition party member as his attorney general, Mr. Zedillo initially raised hopes that his administration would aggressively prosecute politically sensitive cases like that of Raul Salinas. But that optimism has been dashed by the Government's repeated prosecutorial failures and omissions.
The Zedillo administration rejects its predecessor's conclusion that a lone gunmen murdered the former presidential candidate Luis Donaldo Colosio, but has yet to convict anyone else of the crime. It has failed to pursue high-profile criminal cases involving the governors of two Mexican states. That record creates little confidence it will take on the powerful ruling party interests involved in the Raul Salinas corruption case.
Unless the rule of law is applied equally to all Mexicans, neither democracy nor free and transparent markets can take root. That is the powerful lesson of the unraveling of Carlos Salinas's presidency. If Mr. Zedillo fails to apply it consistently, his own hopes for reform could falter as well.
