HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Arafat's War Option

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Palestinians can choose between war against Israel or peace talks with Israel. They no longer can have both. Unless they learn that at the Washington conference called by President Clinton, the meeting will be simply a step toward one more Mideast disaster.
For the Palestinians, the use of the war option was a great success -- this time. They got immediate international support for their attacks on Israelis plus instant international condemnation of Israel for being in the way of Palestinian police bullets. 
 The Clinton Administration did not lead the pack but sent signals of displeasure with Israel. Mr. Clinton has called an Arab-Israeli conference in Washington for this week. Now it is his chance and responsibility to make the meeting worthwhile by clarifying reality for Palestinians: Their war option has expired.
If the United States allows the Palestinians to leave Washington still believing that they can play the war card again, it will be encouraging them to move along a road that is likely to end in another full-scale war between Arab and Israeli.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been doing his underreported best to negotiate with the Palestinians on building up their own economy and reaching an agreement on Hebron that would give control to them but significant protection to the Jews living there.
The previous Labor Government just let Hebron slide for months, afraid to deal with it before the elections, as promised at Oslo. But at least former Prime Minister Shimon Peres can pleasurably denounce the elected Government of his country and praise Yasir Arafat, the commander of the Palestinians who fired on Israeli soldiers. So be it.
No amount of domestic or international pressure will persuade Mr. Netanyahu's Government to permit Palestinian gunmen to push Israel step by step toward any agreement he considers a threat to its ability to survive as a free nation. The danger is that the Palestinians will again prove their talent for historic miscalculation.
War is the word for what happened last week. This was not intifada, one more furious uprising of unarmed Palestinian civilians against the Israeli forces that they used to see on their streets. Ninety percent of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza now live in cities controlled by the Palestinian Authority set up by the Oslo agreement and financed largely by international grants.
This time the stone-throwers were not only backed up by police using automatic weapons but had to go looking for Israeli soldiers at checkpoints outside of town, or search out Jews living among them where they might congregate -- like a synagogue or yeshiva.
It was a script. Mr. Arafat took 36 hours to organize police-backed riots against the opening of a new door to an ancient archeological tunnel, Then he turned the armed riots on. When he was good and ready, he turned them off.
If Mr. Clinton puts Palestinians on notice that the war option has been used for the last time, he will have bipartisan support for the meeting, which he certainly does not have now.
Bob Dole, House Speaker Newt Gingrich and the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, have told him not to use the meeting to pressure Israel still further. In a letter to Mr. Clinton, the Speaker and the Senator said that last week's attacks did not exist in isolation:
"We urge that the roles of Iran, Syria, Hamas and Hezbollah in destabilizing the region be a key part of the agenda for this meeting. The U.S. must lead in forcing a multinational strategy to combat these sponsors of terrorism and enemies of peace. Without such a strategy any attempt to bring peace to the region is destined to fail."
Exactly. Mr. Netanyahu got serious advice from some of his cabinet members that the Palestinian armed force of about 40,000 would become larger, better armed and get more support from Arab dictatorships, Arab militants, Western appeasers, the whole nest of those who cannot forgive Israel for existing.
Mr. Netanyahu refused. But if Mr. Arafat again orders Israeli soldiers used as rifle targets, Mr. Netanyahu will not be able to refuse again for long, or maybe at all. So the Washington meeting will have meaning only if Mr. Clinton tells Palestinians that their war option is now a deadly mirage.

HEADLINE: TENSION IN THE MIDDLE EAST: THE ISRAELIS;
Netanyahu Seeks New Talks On 3 Major Palestinian Issues

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is convinced, he and his aides say, that the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, has already won an undeserved advantage in the battle for world opinion, but that Mr. Netanyahu is determined that world opinion would not dictate Israeli positions.
Mr. Netanyahu and his advisers laid out for reporters today an opening proposal intended to demonstrate that his Likud party Government has been unfairly cast as obstructionist in peace talks with the Palestinian Authority. 
He said he would call for high-level Israeli and Palestinian delegations to meet in continuous closed-door negotiations until they resolved three contentious issues: differences over Israel's agreement to withdraw its security forces from most of the West Bank city of Hebron, provisions to allow Palestinians to travel more freely from the West Bank and Gaza Strip to jobs in Israel, and a range of specific security issues including the fate of a proposed Palestinian-controlled airport in the Gaza Strip.
These three subjects were already identified as the main items on the negotiating agenda at Mr. Netanyahu's first meeting with Mr. Arafat earlier this month.
The talks, at a secluded location like the Egyptian resort of Taba on the Red Sea, "will continue until there is white smoke," Mr. Netanyahu told reporters, adding that he and Mr. Arafat should be prepared to attend periodically to prod their negotiators along.
But the offer was coupled with a demand for Palestinian restraint that advisers said was essential to hold the support of religious nationalists and security hawks who are part of Israel's governing alliance.
Israeli officials said Mr. Arafat would have to forswear further violence against Israeli forces and formally accept that continued attacks would give Israel license to retaliate strongly. The officials said they wanted the United States to declare that it also recognized this Israeli right.
"What I'd like to see is two things," Mr. Netanyahu said before he left for Washington, where he arrived this evening. "First a cessation of violence, and second a speedy resumption of negotiations to their conclusion, and to that effect I am proposing that the two sides meet right after the meeting in Washington in a locale to be determined and engage in continual negotiations until agreement is reached. This is the way to proceed."
At the same time, Mr. Netanyahu rejected making any concessions or gestures that would be perceived as a surrender to violence.
Specifically, they said, there would be no talk of closing the tunnel in Jerusalem that Palestinians cite as the immediate spark of the recent conflict.
Among the Israelis who flew to Washington with the Prime Minister, the recurring theme was that Mr. Arafat had deliberately provoked the confrontations that left scores dead to bring pressure on Israel.
The violence of the last three days, Mr. Netanyahu said, was "a fundamental violation of the agreements."
"Even Chairman Arafat knows he's pushed the rope to the end," Mr. Netanyahu said.
Dore Gold, the Prime Minister's senior foreign affairs adviser, said Mr. Arafat had used the opening of the tunnel to foment rioting. The Israelis contend that Mr. Arafat's strategy paid off, in that the West and Arab governments generally blamed Israeli stubbornness for the conflict. The United Nations Security Council condemned Israel for opening the tunnel -- and the United States pointedly abstained, declining to use its veto power in Israel's defense.
Mr. Gold said the Palestinian leader deserved to reap "no political fruit" from the Israelis at the Washington meeting.
"He already has his fruit," Mr. Gold said. "He'll be wined and dined in Washington. He has the U.N. vote and the U.S. abstention."
Mr. Gold described the Israeli position as a dilemma. On the one hand, he said, Mr. Netanyahu is under intense pressure from Western and Arab governments to make a gesture of conciliation. On the other hand, the violence has energized the religious and nationalist wing of his Government, for whom the sight of Palestinians shooting at Israelis was anathema.
Natan Sharansky, a Cabinet member traveling with the Prime Minister, said the right wing of the Government had pushed insistently for Mr. Netanyahu to use all available force against the Palestinian uprising and to use the occasion to halt peace negotiations.
In general, Mr. Netanyahu and his aides argued that they had been unfairly accused of stalling on the Palestinian front.
They said that the previous Labor Government had operated with what Mr. Gold called "a long line of credit" -- that Labor had been praised for incremental results -- while the Likud Government was under constant pressure to show quick results.
The aides said the West and the Palestinians and their Arab allies did not appreciate how difficult it had been for Mr. Netanyahu, given his dependence on hard-liners in his coalition, to do what he had already done, including meeting with Mr. Arafat, renewing negotiations and agreeing in principle to carry out the withdrawal from Hebron.
Mr. Sharansky said the Government had been nearing a decision on the timing of a withdrawal from Hebron, which was overdue under an agreement reached by the previous Government. Israelis say the withdrawal has become far more difficult because of fears fanned by last week's clashes.
The presence of Mr. Sharansky, the Minister of Industry and Labor, in the delegation was intended to bolster Israel's case that accusations of drift were unfair.
Mr. Sharansky said one of his tasks would be to point out to critics of the Likud Government that Israel had taken various steps to improve the economic plight of the Palestinians, including an increase in the number of work permits issued to them from 15,000 to 50,000 and negotiations on creating job-rich industrial zones abutting the Gaza Strip.
As a well-known former Soviet dissident, Mr. Sharansky was also on hand to argue to the Americans, as he had in the Israeli Cabinet, that giving in to force would only lead to disaster and a renewal of violence.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dollar Hits 111.40 Yen, Highest Level Since 1994
The dollar jumped against the Japanese yen, rising to its highest level since the start of 1994. But while the dollar is now 38 percent above its record 1995 low, analysts are not yet convinced that a long-term turnaround of the dollar is at hand.
The dollar reached 111.40 yen, up from 110.83 Friday and its highest since Jan. 25, 1994, when it was at 111.03 yen. [Page D6.]

Stocks Rise Modestly
A late burst of profit-taking and other quarter-ending portfolio shifts cut into a broad advance, but some measures rose enough to set records. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.25 points, to 5,882.17. [D10.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities fell for the second consecutive session. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.92 percent. [D17.]
 
Connecticut Blue Cross Merger Deal
Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut has agreed to merge with Anthem Inc., a big Midwestern insurance company, people with knowledge of the deal said. [D8.]
 
German Workers Face Benefit Cuts
Taking advantage of a new law that goes into effect today, big German companies plan to cut back some of the most generous employee benefits in the world. [A1.]
 
Arizona County Accused of Fraud
The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Maricopa County, Ariz., of securities fraud in connection with a 1993 bond sale. [D2.]
 
Pension Funds Criticize Archer
Two pension funds criticized Archer Daniels Midland's steps toward creating a more independent board as "shallow." [D8.]
 
New Home Sales Rise Strongly
Sales of new homes during August rose 4.7 percent, the briskest pace in a decade, the Commerce Department reported. Both personal income and consumption rose six-tenths of 1 percent in August. [D5.]
 
Circulation Down in Detroit
Circulation at the two striking Detroit newspapers has declined by more than 30 percent since workers walked out. [D7.]
 
Shuttle Program Goes Private
NASA will turn over much of the operation of the space shuttle program to a joint venture of Lockheed Martin and Boeing, in a deal worth about $7 billion over six years. [A18.]
 
Kiwi Air Files For Bankruptcy
Kiwi International Air Lines, a low-cost carrier beset by problems inside and outside the company since it started in 1992, has filed for bankruptcy protection. As a result of the filing, Kiwi, based in Newark, will shrink its route structure to three cities -- Newark, Atlanta and Chicago. [D2.]
 
Generic Drug Shown Effective
Sangstat Medical said clinical trials had shown that its immune-suppressant drug worked as well as cyclosporine, Sandoz A.G.'s branded equivalent. [D4.]
 
N.A.S.D. Fines Alex. Brown
The N.A.S.D. fined Alex. Brown & Sons and one of its brokers for violations related to the sale of certain foreign securities. [D20.]

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Pride of Puerto Rico Visible in Post-Season

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

 BODY:
For a whole summer, the sounds of salsa underscored the growing influence of Latin America on the Mets and Yankees. That flavor will be even more palpable -- and distinctly Puerto Rican -- tonight when the American League West champion Texas Rangers and the A.L. East-winning Yankees begin their playoff series at Yankee Stadium.
The Yankees' Bernie Williams and the Rangers' Juan Gonzalez and Ivan Rodriguez, who grew up playing with and against each other in the boys' leagues around the baseball-hungry island, will be prominently displayed. 
 And their presence, along with that of Sandy Alomar Jr. of the Indians and Roberto Alomar of the Orioles in the league's other first-round series, will show that the contributions of this tiny island only 100 miles long and 35 miles wide did not end with Roberto Clemente, nor has it been totally eclipsed by the Dominican Republic.
And the contributions this season have been immense.
Williams, whose graceful approach to the game led his manager, Joe Torre, to liken him to Arthur Ashe, used a .305 average, 29 home runs and 102 runs batted in to help the Yankees win a division for the first time since 1981.
Rodriguez is the Rangers' 24-year-old catcher, whose skills and bat have allowed him to inherit the nickname Pudge from the former All-Star catcher Carlton Fisk. He and Gonzalez, the powerful right fielder who muscled 47 home runs and 144 r.b.i., were primary ingredients in taking the franchise to its first post-season appearance.
When they are introduced, when their images are beamed to Puerto Rico, "it will be huge," Rodriguez said with a smile as large as the uproar he predicts. Williams, flashing an equally big grin, said, "It'll probably be the most-watched playoff series in Puerto Rico in a long, long time."
Perhaps since Clemente last played a World Series game and launched a rich tradition these three players merely seek to extend. "In Puerto Rico, the No. 1 sport is baseball -- nothing is bigger, and a lot of kids are watching us," said Rodriguez, who hit .300 with 19 homers and 86 r.b.i. "They want to be like us."
"And that means a lot to me," said Williams, who played in Little League against the younger Rodriguez and teamed with Gonzalez at Vega Baja in a league named for Mickey Mantle -- the Hall of Famer who ruled the same center field ground Williams now patrols.
"Taking into consideration the size of the island and the fact that there have been a lot of good players to come out of Puerto Rico, it's certainly a great honor to be a part of the tradition of Puerto Rican players in the post-season," the 28-year-old Williams said.
Now, these players are not suggesting that Puerto Rico reigns supreme when it comes to sending major leaguers to the States. "Baseball in the Dominican is huge," Williams said. "It's big in Puerto Rico, also, but in Puerto Rico, the average kid will have so many more options."
Yes, Puerto Rican kids are still easily plucked by scouts; Gonzalez and Rodriguez both signed at age 16. But their hunger may not match that of Cubans, Dominicans and Mexicans, many of whom view baseball as the only avenue away from lands locked in poverty. As United States citizens, Puerto Rican children, by contrast, have access to economies and standards of living that are decidedly more American.
"That's a big point," said Williams, a pre-med college student before signing with the Yankees.
Still, the tradition exists in Puerto Rico, perhaps not as feverish, but as cherished. In listening to these three players, it is obvious why.
"I never saw Clemente in person, but I remember seeing him on tape, in the World Series, and what a great feeling it was," said Gonzalez, the 26-year-old whose popularity at home -- and penchant for charitable deeds -- are said to mirror those of Clemente, the Hall of Famer. Clemente died in a plane crash on Dec. 31, 1972, while attempting to fly supplies to Nicaraguan earthquake victims.
"Roberto Clemente was a very good player, but he also loved children and he died trying to help people," the 24-year-old Rodriguez said. "And that's what I want to do, to help people. That's why I have foundations, in Puerto Rico and Texas, for children with cancer."
Thus, Clemente lives, on the field, in these players' hearts. "We have to make that our job to make the kids growing up now remember what he was about, about the legacy he tried to make," Williams said.
Tonight, Rodriguez, Gonzalez and Williams will not only rivet the attention of an entire commonwealth. They will also make their mission all the more easy merely by stepping onto the field.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
State Jobs, but Not on Paper

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
As one of the economy measures in Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's current budget, the state has stopped publishing a list of vacant Civil Service jobs. The list is available over the Internet, but two Democratic legislators say that is no help to many job-seekers who do not have access to a computer. Only 15 of the state's 400 libraries offer Internet access, the New Jersey Library Association said. 
 Dropping the printed job bulletins saved the state $100,000. But two Assembly members, Shirley K. Turner of Ewing Township and W. Reed Gusciora of Princeton, urged yesterday that the bulletins be restored.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Soup Kitchen Feels the Heat Of a New Law

BYLINE: By Clyde Haberman 

 BODY:
HOW to explain the sudden change? The Rev. William Greenlaw says that he can't, not really. All he knows is that for about the last six weeks, coincidentally or not, the period since President Clinton signed the welfare-overhaul law, lines have grown a lot longer at the soup kitchen he runs out of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Apostles, at Ninth Avenue and West 28th Street.
Before, Father Greenlaw says, he could expect a typical weekday to bring 900 to 1,000 "guests" to lunch at Holy Apostles, a huge soup kitchen, if not New York's biggest. Suddenly in mid-summer, the numbers jumped to between 1,100 and 1,300, reaching 1,475 one particularly taxing day in late August. Yesterday's head count was typical of this harsh new reality: 1,208, mostly single men, standing on a line that curled around the corner toward Eighth Avenue. 
 "It's clear that there are a whole lot of people who are coming to us for the first time," Father Greenlaw said. "Something is clearly going on. And the fear is that if this is happening before everything kicks in with this new law, what's going to happen when it all kicks in?"
What, indeed? It is a question that soup kitchens and pantries are asking all around the city, and winter still lies ahead. Even before the ballyhooed end to welfare as we knew it, they had been struggling to keep pace with a sharp rise in demand, the result of cuts in social programs at all levels -- Federal, state and local.
A YEAR ago, the New York City Coalition Against Hunger put the number of pantries and kitchens at about 800. Now, it counts 907. Food for Survival, the kitchens' central supplier, operating out of Hunts Point in the Bronx, says that it distributed 27 million pounds of food from July 1995 to June 1996. That was 35 percent more than in the previous 12 months.
"It's been one thing on top of another, like the Mayor's policy of forcing people off welfare," said Judith Walker, executive director of the Coalition Against Hunger. "The decline in the welfare rolls doesn't mean there's less poverty."
We will have to wait and see if the longer lines at Holy Apostles is a statistical blip or a disturbing early glimpse into the future, citywide. Other food programs around town do not report the same increase in demand over the last month or so. It is "awfully soon," Ms. Walker said, to be feeling such a heavy impact from a law signed by President Clinton only on Aug. 22.
Still, some of its provisions have already gone into effect, like denying food stamps to certain legal immigrants. And Holy Apostles is not that unusual. Kitchens like St. John's Bread and Life in Bedford-Stuyvesant and POTS (as in Part of the Solution) in the Bronx, are also suddenly seeing more down-and-outers showing up at their doors. The increases are just not as sharp as those at Father Greenlaw's church -- more on the order of 9 percent since mid-summer, Hossein Saadat, the executive director at St. John's, said.
"People fear to go to apply for entitlements," Mr. Saadat said by way of explanation. "The feeling with this new law now is, Why bother? So they're starting not to go, and they're coming to soup kitchens."
TOMMY McEWEN, the soup kitchen director at POTS, said the new law has reinforced a sense among the desperately poor that they had better tuck away whatever little money they have. "Most of my clients say they're trying to hold onto their dollars and take advantage of what's available for free," he said.
In the simple sanctuary of Holy Apostles, many who came yesterday for a lunch of tuna casserole and green beans recognized that much of America has grown tired of them. There would be no welfare law if that were not so. "A lot of society has pretty much written off certain people, like so much dirt under the rug," Edward Perry, an unemployed 45-year-old, said, adding that it was his first visit to a soup kitchen in three years.
As it happened, the soup kitchen served yesterday what it believed to be its three millionth meal since opening in October 1982. It took Holy Apostles six years to reach the one million mark, then roughly four years for each of the next two millionth-meal milestones. Common sense suggests, Father Greenlaw said, that he will get to four million in considerably less time.
It fell to Mr. Perry, more or less arbitrarily, to be designated Meal No. 3 million, a distinction that earned him nothing in the way of a special reward. "This is not a celebration," Father Greenlaw said. "It's an indictment."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Despite a Selloff, a Good Quarter for Stocks

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The 104th Congress will be remembered for overhauling the welfare laws, a higher minimum wage and two shutdowns of the Government. But to a select few investors who paid attention to minor legislation, it will also be remembered for creating a great investment opportunity.
That opportunity was in legislation that greatly expanded the powers of a lesser known semipublic agency, the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Association, otherwise known as Farmer Mac. That expansion, passed in February, led to a lot more activity for the organization, and to its first profits ever. And in the third quarter, it also produced the best stock in America: Farmer Mac's class A stock, traded on Nasdaq, leaped 292 percent. 
 For the rest of the market, the quarter's gains were less spectacular, but they were welcome just the same. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks ended the period at a record 687.33 points, after enduring in July its worst correction since the 1990 recession.
The Dow Jones industrial average flirted with a record yesterday, but closed a dozen points below the high it set last week. And there was strength in markets throughout much of the world. The Dutch market was the only European one to set a record close yesterday, but those in Britain and Germany set peaks earlier in September. Even France, whose economy is struggling with high unemployment, rose nicely, though prices there remain below their 1994 peaks.
The general good news for shareowners has its exceptions, such as a small decline in Japan, but over all much of the world seems to be moving more or less in tandem, paced by expectations that gradual growth in the industrialized world will continue and a belief that few acceptable alternative investments are available.
Still, the July selloff that decimated many technology stocks in this country, and produced the largest correction for blue chips in more than five years, has not been totally forgotten. The Nasdaq composite index is up 17.7 percent from the low it hit then, but remains 1.8 percent below the peak it had reached in early June.
And while the Dow industrials ended the quarter with a quite respectable gain of 3.9 percent, the Dow transports were off 4.7 percent and the Dow utilities were down 1.6 percent. Weak airline stocks, beset by traders' worries about higher fuel prices, were the leading culprits in the transport weakness; worries about competition hurt some electric utilities as well.
As for the bond market, the net movement in the quarter was almost imperceptible. The 30-year Treasury bond ended the quarter yielding 6.92 percent, up from 6.89 percent at the end of June. And the change in the three-month Treasury bill rate was even less. Yesterday's figure of 5.01 percent was down from 5.02 percent three months earlier. When stock prices were plunging in July, a fear of higher interest rates was cited as a factor; that fear failed to materialize.
Financial stocks, in fact, were among the best performers, though many would be vulnerable to a sharp rise in interest rates. The S.& P. index of financial stocks climbed 7.5 percent in the quarter to a record.
The lists of best and worst performing individual shares, as is often the case, showed investor actions at their best and worst. Farmer Mac may be a classic case of a small stock -- only 1.2 million shares are available to the public -- that slipped below the radar of most analysts.
Farmer Mac's best performing shares, the class A shares, are available only to financial institutions. But anyone can buy the class C shares, which, incidentally, will also be in line for a higher dividend, should the company ever pay one. The class C shares jumped 191 percent in Nasdaq trading.
The bank that wins the award for spotting -- and acting on -- Farmer Mac is Zions Bancorp, which in March agreed to buy 320,000 newly issued class A shares, at $8 each, from Farmer Mac. The price was then a 60 percent premium over the market price, but now it looks cheap. The shares ended yesterday at $23.50. Zion's shares didn't do badly either, rising 22 percent, to $88.50, in the quarter.
By contrast, two of the quarter's worst performers among stocks that began the quarter at or above $5 a share provide an example of how fast a small stock can go down if its chief sponsor walks away.
U.S. Bridge had barely celebrated its first year as a public company in August when the State Street Capital Markets Corporation said it could no longer make a market in its favorite stocks, of which U.S. Bridge was one. U.S. Bridge was down 88.6 percent, to $1.28 a share during the quarter.
Not far behind was Cable & Company Worldwide, another stock whose chief supporter was State Street Capital. It was off 75.6 percent. State Street blamed short-sellers, who had bet heavily that the companies were overvalued.
On the Big Board, the best performer, the Providence Journal Company. was up 91.1 percent and got there the old-fashioned way, via a takeover offer from A. H. Belo at a big premium to market.
But it is the second-best performer, Applied Magnetics, a maker of magnetic recording heads used in computer drives, that in some ways best sums up the quarter. Shares of Applied Magnetics leaped 72.6 percent, to $18.125 in the quarter. But they had been pounded in the July selloff of technology stocks, and are still less than their May 1 high of $21.75.

It is independent; it is not a unit of Metropolitan Life Insurance.

HEADLINE: Minimum Wage, Minimum Effect;
Politics Aside, Economy Is Shrugging Off Rise to $4.75

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 30

 BODY:
When Gloria W. Robinson, the top economic development official for the City of Detroit, was asked for the names of local companies that paid the minimum wage, she had to stop and think.
Finally, she suggested Ace-Tex Enterprises, which sells rags for wiping up grease and other gunk from factory floors. But even in Detroit, one of the nation's poorest cities, just 26 of the 200 workers at Ace-Tex will get a raise in the next 24 hours, when the minimum wage increases to $4.75 an hour from $4.25. The rest earn more now, having graduated from such jobs as stuffing boxes with rags to the more skilled work of making specially coated sterilized cloths. 
 While many members of Congress have trumpeted the minimum-wage increase enacted into law in August as a boon to American workers, it is, in fact, a non-event for most. The number of wage earners who will get an immediate raise will be minuscule -- just 4.2 million, or 3.3 percent of all workers. Their lives may improve, but the impact on the overall economy will be negligible. Many economists predict small job losses -- 100,000 to 200,000 at most over two years in a work force of 126 million. Because so few earn the minimum wage, the inflationary jolt will amount to one-tenth or two-tenths of 1 percent this year, economists agree.
"The whole issue is overblown," said Barry P. Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, who said the higher minimum wage was just as unlikely to lead to layoffs as it was to move families out of poverty. Mr. Bosworth said a second increase mandated by the new law, to $5.15 next September, would not change the equation much, either, though it will mean raises for 5.4 million additional workers.
In past years, when more people were paid the minimum wage -- and when that level of pay went further toward meeting a family's needs -- the economic ripple effects of an increase were greater. Now, though, even in Detroit, where unemployment at 9.4 percent is nearly twice the national rate, much of the economy has moved beyond minimum-wage levels. McDonald's pays its hamburger flippers here at least $5.25 to start.
In Detroit, as elsewhere, small businesses will bear the brunt of the new law -- and, if the comments of the managers of a strip of shops along Woodward Avenue are any guide, these people are taking it very much in stride. Many say they will bump up their employees' wages even if they don't have to in order to keep them ahead of the lowest-paid workers.
Some of the merchants on the decaying strip that was once the retail heart of Detroit grumble that prices will have to go up, and others worry that customers will complain. But none of the managers interviewed plans to lay workers off, or even cut back their hours.
Emily J. Webster, co-owner of Detroit Hardware, said she would give each of her six part-time workers a 50 cent raise, to $6.50 an hour, by January. She predicted the same would be true of the companies that supply her store with brooms and nails, and that higher prices would inevitably result. "It is just a chain of events," Ms. Webster said. "The manufacturers will raise their prices, the distributors will raise their prices, then the retailers will raise their prices."
But Alex F. Martin, manager of Sibleys Shoes across the street, shrugged off the wage increase as unimportant. "Business just has to go on," he said.
Rather than eliminate jobs, employers said they would adjust other aspects of their business equation to compensate for higher labor costs. "It will probably just cut out into the profits a little bit," said Tony C. Collins, manager of nearby Value Village, which sells secondhand clothes, books and toys and most of the 35 employees earn the minimum wage. "I don't think it will affect the business at all."
George Randall, manager of the Turkey Grill, where a smoked turkey sandwich sells for $3.89, said he would have to raise prices to offset the raises five of his nine workers will get as the result of the new law. He fears that some customers will be upset because his company's reputation is built in part on its reasonable prices. "I would just hope that they would accept it," Mr. Randall said.
If local businesses are figuring on small price increases but planning to keep their work forces intact, they are following the script laid down by economists. David L. Littmann, a senior economist at Comerica Bank, predicted a decline of only about 600 jobs in Detroit over the next two years as the result of the increase. "That's because times are about as good as they can be," he said.
For the workers on the bottom rungs of the economic ladder, however, the new law makes a real difference, even if it won't be enough to lift them up from poverty. At Ace-Tex, Sherry Wells, 32, a single mother whose $4.40 an hour will rise to $4.75, said that for her, it means that "you can look forward to your next paycheck."
"Things now are a lot higher," Ms. Wells said. "If you want to pay your phone bill, you just budget." As she used a machine to cut white cloth into two-foot-square strips, Ms. Wells explained that she planned to spend part of her raise on $8 haircuts for Darius, her 6-year-old son.
Ms. Wells, a high school graduate who had a year of college, is one of the lowest-paid workers at Ace-Tex's high-ceiling, brown brick building, which was designed early in this century by Albert Kahn, a famed Detroit architect. The building, surrounded by a chain-link fence topped with barbed wire, sits near a boarded-up factory and across the street from an abandoned house. In such dismal surroundings, it seems almost incongruous that Ace-Tex pays so many of its workers well over the minimum wage.
In the Detroit suburbs, it is even harder to find workers earning just $4.25. At McDonald's in Madison Heights, Mich., the manager, Michelle M. Zweng, said she had given no thought to the minimum-wage increase because her lowest-paid workers earn $5.25 an hour.
Nearby, at the Oakland Mall, clerks at the Kay-Bee toy store start at $6 an hour. Lisa D. Rytlewski, assistant manager at the Loop, a jewelry and ear-piercing store in the mall, said it was hard to find even part-timers willing to accept jobs that pay only 75 cents an hour more than the minimum wage. When told that jobs at the Loop start at $5 an hour -- the older college students just laugh, Ms. Rytlewski said.
In Washington, proposals to increase the minimum wage typically foster fierce debate, with business groups and many economists warning of the danger of mass layoffs and liberals arguing that the poor need more money to make ends meet. Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich, defending the latest increase, bristles at the notion that it would not make much difference to workers making the lowest wages.
"It is easy for commentators to pooh-pooh the significance of an $1,800-a-year raise," Mr. Reich said. "But when you are earning $8,500, that raise is far from insignificant."
While many members of Congress seemed eager to vote for the popular proposal in an election year, that is not the only reason the fight over the minimum wage was less vicious in this time.
The minimum wage in inflation-adjusted dollars has fallen over the decades, and with it, the fraction of all workers who earn it. "It used to be that every McDonald's worker was paid the minimum wage," said Diane C. Swonk, an economist at First Chicago NBD Bank in Chicago. Labor Department data show that the percentage of workers earning the minimum wage has fallen from 8.9 percent in 1980 to a fraction of that today.
But by the same token, the falling value of the minimum wage has kept those who earn it mired in poverty. The minimum wage would have to jump to $7.80 an hour to lift workers to the poverty level of $15,600 for a family of four.
"It was much more difficult to pass when the minimum wage meant something," Ms. Swonk said. This year, "everyone kind of sat back and yawned."
The Rev. Bill Cunningham, who runs Focus Hope, a nonprofit organization dedicated to helping the poor in Detroit, said that society should pay more attention to training workers than to setting a wage floor. "The poor are really people without training and skills," he said. "They are not just people without jobs."
Indeed, at the low end of the wage scale, even full-time workers earning more than the minimum wage struggle to get by. Melonise T. Williams, 22, earned the minimum wage when she started work at Ace-Tex two years ago. The high school graduate now earns $5.03 an hour to stuff 50 pounds of finished rags into cardboard boxes and label them for shipping to factories.
Ms. Williams has managed to support her two young daughters -- 7-month-old Diamond and 3-year-old Sharae -- by living with her mother and eagerly working overtime. But even with the extra few thousand dollars provided by the Federal earned-income tax credit, ends don't quite meet for many of the working poor like her.
For baby formula, for instance, she relies on a Federal food program. The assistance "comes in handy because that stuff is high," Ms. Williams said. The brand she uses costs $6 for a 13-ounce can. Without the aid, Ms. Williams would work an hour and 12 minutes for a single can.
Whatever the debate in Washington, some Detroit-area executives and managers said they are actually glad the minimum wage is going up.
"The minimum wage is too low for employees," said Vinnie Johnson, chief executive of Piston Packaging, a Detroit company that makes cardboard boxes, and sorts and sequences parts for auto makers. "You can't survive on that." Mr. Johnson, a retired Detroit Pistons basketball player, said he starts all his employees at $6 an hour and moves them quickly up to $8.
"You want your employees to be happy," he said, "and if they put in a good day's work, they should be paid fairly for it."
Many workers earning the minimum wage have already learned that education is their ticket to the middle class.
Wanda L. Mitchell, 20, who serves frozen yogurt and soft drinks at Harry's, a soda stand in Oakland Mall, is one of the few workers at the mall who is paid the minimum wage. Her weekly check will rise by $14, to $131, starting Tuesday. It doesn't sound like much, but the extra $728 a year will help pay her tuition at Wayne State University in Detroit, where she is studying full time toward a radiology degree.
"I want to keep trying to go full time so I can get out," she said -- "so I can make more money."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 2, 1996, Wednesday

Graph: "Diminishing Returns"
 The economic impact of increases in the minimum wage has diminished with the shrinking purchasing power of the base wage and the steady decline -- outside of recessions -- in the ranks of those who earn it. Still, large numbers of some subgroups in the labor force are paid the minimum, or less.
 Graphs track the minimum wage in nominal dollars and adjusted for inflation, since 1955. Also tracked is the percentage of hourly workers at or below the minimum wage, as a percentage of the total number of wage and salary workers. The latter graph runs from the late-1970's to the present. Other percentage figures are supplied for various subgroups in the workforce. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

CORRECTION-DATE: October 3, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about the financier George Soros's pledge of $50 million to help legal immigrants in the United States referred incorrectly to his humanitarian assistance in Bosnia. He offered $50 million in aid in December 1992, suspended it in May 1993 in protest over Western inaction and resumed it in July 1993.

HEADLINE: New York Wines: Bigger and Better

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
AS New York winegrowers harvest their grapes, they are benefiting from political and agricultural revolutions that have turned the state into a source of wines that often rival those from France and Germany.
In 1976, New York State had 19 wineries; today, it has more than 100. Its best wines are now based on Old World grapes rather than the native American grapes and French-American hybrids that once predominated. And sales, although still largely concentrated inside the state, are booming, many producers say. 
 In the two most important grape-growing regions, the Finger Lakes and Long Island, new wineries are opening, old ones are expanding their vineyards with European grapes, and owners are buying costly agricultural and cellar equipment. Change has been slower in the two other areas, the Hudson River region and the Lake Erie district, where fewer highly regarded wines are being produced.
There are no statistics on sales, and because most wineries are privately owned, the owners are reluctant to be specific. But judging from new plantings and beehive-like business activity in tasting rooms, many of the wineries appear to be profitable.
C. J. Britt, the senior vice president for agricultural lending at the National Bank of Geneva in Geneva, N.Y., verifies this observation. "The Finger Lakes wineries have become a potential source of new business for commercial lenders in the area," he said. "They are a tremendous growth opportunity for everyone here."
In 1995, the Yates County Chamber of Commerce found that nine producers in the Finger Lakes had total wine sales in their tasting rooms of $1.13 million in 1992, $1.65 million in 1993 and $2.24 million in 1994. In New York's wine regions, increased tourism has led to a surge in orders in recent years, producers say. The New York Wine and Grape Foundation, based in Penn Yan in the Finger Lakes, estimates that 900,000 tourists visit yearly.
On Long Island, wine estates are expanding. Most recently, Bidwell, in Cutchogue, invested $700,000 in upgrading its property, including $530,000 for a new tasting house that opened last summer, said Bob Bidwell, an owner. Sagpond, in Sagaponack, is building a new $2.5 million winery that is to open next year.
Are New York State's wines popular? It depends on who is asked. Morrell & Company on Madison Avenue in Manhattan, carries just three New York brands -- "an adequate supply for the demand I encounter," said Peter Morrell, the chairman. Sherry-Lehmann, a few blocks away, also has three. "Customers prefer to pay $7 for a Macon or St. Veran than $15 for a New York chardonnay," said Michael Aaron, the president.
But that's not so at McAdam Liquors, an East Side discounter that specializes in Long Island wines and promotes them aggressively. "We started selling a small number in September 1994, and now we offer everything we can get our hands on," said Bill Rudowski, the manager. The wines range from $7 to $35; the average price is $12.
Statewide, the biggest cluster of wineries, 52, is found on the shores of the principal Finger Lakes -- Cayuga, Seneca, Keuka and Canandaigua -- in a serene farm and vacation belt of awesome vistas and 1940's Americana. Long Island has 17; the Hudson Valley, 23, and the Lake Erie district, 7. The rest are spread across the state. Most offer tastings.
Prof. Richard P. Vine, who teaches enology at Purdue University and buys all the wines served on American Airlines, has judged New York wines in six contests run by the Wine and Grape Foundation, which was established in 1985 and sponsors the "Uncork New York" campaign. "In competitions nationwide, New York vintners are being judged by their peers to be among the best in this country," he said.
Wines like those of 10-year-old Palmer on Long Island, 11-year-old Millbrook in Dutchess County in the Hudson Valley and 5-year-old Lamoreux Landing on Seneca Lake are increasingly taking gold and silver medals in national competitions.
"The Finger Lakes are a good source of cool-climate whites," Professor Vine said. "Long Island merlot is competitive with better labels in Northern California and eastern Washington."
Lake Erie, in a sea of Concord grapes, is mainly grape juice country. In the Hudson Valley, the wide dispersal of the wineries has worked against forging a collective identity.
In the valley, Millbrook's chardonnay and cabernet franc are getting high marks, and the crisp seyval blanc still and sparkling wines at Clinton Vineyards (made from a hybrid grape) have been best sellers for years. In the Lake Erie district, consumers cannot get enough of the Johnson Vineyards Liebestropfchen, a late-harvest dessert wine made from the Delaware grape.
Taken together, a string of deregulatory laws, a cooperative State Liquor Authority and competition from California, Oregon, Washington and foreign producers have motivated New York growers to strive for world-class wines.
The vineyard revolution began in the mid-1950's in the Finger Lakes. It reoriented the industry toward wines made from European vinifera grapes like chardonnay and merlot and de-emphasized wines made from American juice-and-jelly fruit like Niagara and Concord and from French-American hybrids like seyval blanc and baco noir.
Other gains are due partly to the Farm Winery Act signed by Gov. Hugh L. Carey in 1976, which drove a wedge into the legacy of Prohibitionism and enabled farmers to set up their own wineries.
The fortunes of the state's wine industry, which dates to the mid-1800's, had plummeted because of an anti-alcohol mindset in Albany that, after Prohibition ended in 1933, discouraged production and consumption, and because of consumers' notion that New York wines were primarily sweet, heavy and simple at a time when dry and complex wines were coming into vogue.
John S. Dyson, Governor Carey's Secretary of Agriculture and Markets, helped engineer passage of the Farm Winery Act. He had not planned a career in wine, but in 1985 he founded Millbrook in a dairy barn; it is now the Hudson Valley's flagship winery. Armed with a degree in agricultural economics from Cornell University, Mr. Dyson became a disciple of Dr. Konstantin Frank, an iconoclastic viticulturist.
Defying the conventional wisdom that only native grapes and hardy French-American hybrids could survive the Finger Lakes winters, Dr. Frank proved that European grapes could flourish. Vinifera Wine Cellars, which Dr. Frank established in 1962 on Rhine-like heights over Keuka Lake in Hammondsport, is now run by his son, Willy, and has become one of the state's, and the East's, top wineries. Chateau Frank, on the same grounds, makes three sparkling wines that can rival prestigious ones from Champagne. A big Manhattan distributor, Paramount, recently took on Frank wines as well as Glenora, a 19-year-old Seneca Lake house specializing in sparkling wine.
Finger Lakes wineries are at a competitive disadvantage. Because of limited inventories and the six-hour trip to Manhattan, they cannot easily supply stores and restaurants that insist on next-day deliveries. Anthony Road and Hunt Country, estates run by Finger Lakes families, have jointly sold their wines in the Union Square Greenmarket for years. But most Finger Lakes wineries sell in their tasting rooms and in nearby markets like Buffalo, Corning, Rochester and Syracuse.
Since 1979, the sophisticated dry, semidry and sweet rieslings made by the German-born Hermann J. Wiemer have shown that Finger Lakes rieslings can equal those from Germany, Alsace and Austria. And critics are comparing the light-bodied chardonnays from the Finger Lakes to those from Macon and Chablis in France.
Other promising producers in the Finger Lakes include Standing Stone, a tiny three-year-old house, where David B. Whiting, 33, is turning out remarkable dry and semidry whites. His austere and elegant rieslings, chardonnays and gewurztraminers are sold in a plain white tasting room that was upgraded from a chicken coop.
Dr. Frank's Rkatsiteli, Fox Run's Ruby Vixen, Hunt Country's Vidal ice wine, Knapp's Pasta Red, Lakewood's White Catawba and Wagner's Delaware, Melody and Niagara can be treats. They are cash cows that subsidize the costly production of vinifera wines.
The Canandaigua Wine Company, the nation's second-biggest producer after Gallo, is a major player in the Finger Lakes as a grape buyer, but its Manischewitz kosher and Taylor Lake Country lines are not usually perceived as premium New York wines. The same is true of the Brooklyn-based Royal Wine Corporation, whose Kedem kosher wines are made in the Hudson Valley.
Bully Hill, with a 220,000-case capacity, is the biggest Finger Lakes producer of hybrid wines. Its high-end competitors deplore the low-end impression it makes, but they take seriously the under-$8 prices its 53 labels fetch.
Long Island was pioneered as a wine region in 1973 when Louisa and Alex Hargrave, ardent Francophiles, put vines into potato fields at their Hargrave Vineyard in Cutchogue on the North Fork. Today, Suffolk County's 17 producers and 1,600-plus acres of vines yield 150,000 to 200,000 cases a year.
The biggest, Pindar, a mini-Gallo on the North Fork, will produce 82,000 cases from the 1995 vintage.
On the East End, wine lovers can find not only Bordeaux-like merlots and cabernet sauvignons, but also barrel-fermented Burgundian chardonnays, charming pinot blancs and a few top-notch pinot noirs.
Although such outstanding North Fork producers as Bedell, Hargrave, Lenz, Palmer, Paumanok and Pellegrini have cajoled their way into some stores and restaurants in Manhattan, most still sell 75 percent or more of their wines out the front door. Although their wines have gained fans, most New York producers lack nationwide recognition, and few are willing to invest to distribute nationally. (A handful of premium wineries have customers outside the state, and the Wine and Grape Foundation's four-year-old export program has helped create niches in Canada, Sweden and Britain.)
"We don't yet have sufficient demand for distributors to justify the costs of adding our labels to their already heavy portfolios," said James Trezise, the foundation's president. "It's a chicken-and-egg situation."

Tastings, From Cayuga Lake to Cutchogue
FOLLOWING is a list of wineries whose products are among the best in New York State, along with a comment about what visitors will see at each. Prices are approximate. Local merchants are usually willing to order a half or full case from any winery. And most producers will fill credit-card orders for in-state buyers. Shipping to many states is illegal.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Finishes Mostly Higher Despite Monetary Union Spat

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher yesterday, overcoming a French-Italian spat over Europe's single-currency plan, which briefly bolstered the mark.
Traders attributed the dollar's strength to underlying demand for the currency, as well as a boost it received from a weekend meeting of the Group of Seven finance ministers from the richest industrial countries, who called for a strong dollar. 
 "I think everyone seems fairly happy with the dollar," said Roger Chapin, foreign exchange manager at Bank One in Columbus, Ohio.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.5260 marks, from 1.5245 marks on Monday. The British pound weakened to $1.5645 from $1.5650.
The dollar slipped against the yen, from 111.40 to 111.33, as traders sold dollars to lock in profits from the currency's rally above the 111-yen barrier on Monday. Nonetheless, the dollar remains at its highest level against the yen since January 1994.
"The dollar's made a reasonable move up, and it's understandable that we'll do some consolidating at current levels," said Tom Hoge, vice president of corporate trading at the Bank of New York. "The dollar remains well bid and probably should go higher."
The dollar traded at its lows of the day during European dealings, when the mark strengthened after President Jacques Chirac of France publicly questioned whether Italy could meet the stringent requirements for joining the European Union's planned single currency in 1999.
While countries like France and Germany are trying to improve their financial conditions, he told reporters, "It may take a bit longer for those who are behind, like Italy."
Italian officials reacted furiously in what appeared to be the most serious instance of high-level bickering among key participants in the currency plan. Although the mark retreated later in the day, the French-Italian argument reflected "a potential bump in the road toward European monetary union," said Robert Katz of the MTB Bank Corporation in New York.
Others said the dollar's gains were tempered by National Association of Purchasing Management's report showing a manufacturing slowdown last month. Traders were awaiting the report on September unemployment Friday for more insights into the economy's direction.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Higher On 2 Reports

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, as weaker-than-expected manufacturing and retail sales reports helped ease the concerns of investors that the economy might be growing fast enough to accelerate inflation, which would lead the Federal Reserve to push up interest rates.
The 30-year bond gained 18/32 , to a price of 9815/32 to yield 6.87 percent, down from 6.92 percent on Monday. 
 Larry Berman, a senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said that he had expected yesterday's National Association of Purchasing Management index of manufacturing activity to come in at 53; instead, the index fell to 51.7 in September, from 52.6 in August. A reading above 50 often signals an expanding economy, while a reading below 50 signals a contraction.
Adding to the day's positive trend for the credit markets was the weekly Redbook retail sales report for the period ended Sept. 28. It fell four-tenths of 1 percent, after declining three-tenths of 1 percent the week before. The slower sales renewed the confidence of market participants that inflation was not about to accelerate.
Elsewhere, traders said the market received a psychological lift in the afternoon after a report in the Australian Financial Review quoted Australia's Treasurer, Peter Costello, as having said that based on a recent conversation with the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, he had the impression that Mr. Greenspan did not see inflation as a near-term problem. Some traders may have taken that to mean that the Fed may not consider raising rates in November.
"I'm excited about how things are happening," Mr. Berman said. "Technically the market is reacting great. On a longer term we are seeing a strong base in the market, with the yield level on the long bond at 7.25 percent.
"So unless we see signs of inflation soon," Mr. Berman said, "I would say between now and the December Federal Open Market Committee meeting, we may be looking at the beginning of another bull market."
Maury Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., discussing the purchasing managers' report, noted that while the overall index of industrial sector business conditions slipped, there was a decline in the vendor delivery lead times -- a favorite of Mr. Greenspan -- and a modest rise in the prices paid component. "On balance," Mr. Harris said, "the mixed September N.A.P.M. report did not portray an overheated economy badly in need of a dose of Federal Reserve tightening of short-term interest rates."
In the municipal market, Denver led yesterday's $1.3 billion sale of municipal bonds with a $279.6 million offering through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.
The offering, which is insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, is rated AAA, and because of good investor demand underwriters were able to sell the securities at a higher price and lower yields. Series C bonds were priced to yield from 4.65 percent in 1998 to 5.85 percent in 2013, while the series D securities, which consist of two maturities, were priced to yield 5.875 percent for a bond due in 2016 and 5.83 percent for a maturity in 2025.

HEADLINE: Elderly and Poor Do Worse Under H.M.O. Plans' Care

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Elderly people and poor people who are chronically ill tend to fare worse in health maintenance organizations, which pay a flat rate for each patient, than in conventional insurance plans, which pay doctors for each service, researchers reported today.
The researchers, led by John E. Ware Jr. of the New England Medical Center in Boston, said that for average patients there was no particular difference between the outcomes of treatment by H.M.O.'s and fee-for-service plans. 
 But in today's Journal of the American Medical Association, they wrote, "Patients who were elderly and poor were more than twice as likely to decline in health in an H.M.O." as in a fee-for-service plan.
The researchers said their findings, based on observation of 2,235 patients in Boston, Chicago and Los Angeles, should send "a cautionary note to policy makers."
In the last few years many Federal and state officials and members of Congress have decided to direct poor people into H.M.O.'s to help save money for Medicaid. Members of Congress from both parties have also suggested that greater use of H.M.O.'s is necessary to shore up the finances of Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled. Until last year, costs in the two programs were rising about 10 percent a year.
Over all, more than 60 million Americans are in H.M.O.'s. Nationwide, enrollment grew by an average of nearly 500,000 a month in the last three years.
The American Association of Health Plans, which represents H.M.O.'s, took issue with Dr. Ware's study. Karen M. Ignagni, president of the association, said the findings were at odds with recent research showing that chronically ill people who were elderly or poor had received excellent care in H.M.O.'s. The quality of care in such prepaid health plans is at least as good as that in fee-for-service plans, she said.
But Prof. Sara Rosenbaum, director of the Center for Health Policy Research at George Washington University, said: "The new findings are consistent with a long line of research showing that poor people with health problems tend to do worse in prepaid health plans. The results tell me that we are going much too fast in converting Medicaid to a managed-care program. We are going faster than H.M.O.'s can accommodate. Whether it's good policy is not the issue. The market may not be ready for these patients -- sick low-income and elderly populations."
Dr. Ware and his colleagues studied adults with chronic illnesses, including high blood pressure, diabetes and congestive heart failure. Patients ranged in age from 18 to 97, with an average just under 58. Slightly more than half were women. The researchers classified patients according to whether there was a change for the better or the worse in their "health status": what they were able to do in everyday life and how they felt physically or mentally.
The researchers followed patients for at least four years. Collection of data began in 1986 and ended in the early 1990's. Some H.M.O.'s say they have stepped up efforts to improve the quality of care in recent years.
The authors noted that chronically ill patients who are elderly or poor "account for a disproportionate share of health care expenditures and are therefore prime targets of cost containment."
Fifty-four percent of the elderly H.M.O. patients and 28 percent of the elderly fee-for-service patients experienced some decline in physical health, the researchers reported.
Low-income patients also fared worse in H.M.O.'s than in fee-for-service health plans, the researchers said. For poor patients who initially had some type of illness, 22 percent of those in H.M.O.'s and 57 percent of those in fee-for-service plans showed improvements in physical health.
For years, H.M.O.'s have emphasized preventive and routine care to keep people healthy. In recent years H.M.O.'s have asserted that they are just as good as fee-for-service insurance for patients who need specialty services like cancer care, neurosurgery and orthopedic surgery. Moreover, H.M.O.'s say they attract a true cross-section of the elderly, not a healthier group of patients, as Medicare officials contend.
Dr. Ware said that "patients who were younger, relatively healthy and relatively well off financially did at least as well in H.M.O.'s as in the fee-for-service plans."
Dr. Paul M. Ellwood Jr., the health policy analyst who coined the term "health maintenance organization" in the early 1970's, and Dr. George D. Lundberg, editor of the A.M.A. journal, assessed recent trends in an editorial accompanying the report.
"There is good reason to be hopeful" about these trends, which let consumers choose from many health plans, the editorial said. But it added, "We have no assurances that the competition of such plans in the current market will reward those who deliver higher quality care."
Indeed, the editorial said: "We have no evidence that the economic success of these plans is being affected by their clinical performance. Purchasers and consumers have not, so far, rewarded or punished plans based on quality."

HEADLINE: Apple Officer Sees Return to Profitability

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif. Oct. 1

 BODY:
The chief financial officer of Apple Computer Inc. said today that the company could return to profitability as soon as December as a turnaround plan improves Apple's gross margin.
"We are still confident we can return to profitability no later than March," the executive, Fred Anderson, said in an interview. "Could it happen sooner than that? Yes." Apple had previously said it would be profitable by the end of March. 
 Shares of Apple rose $2.44, to $24.625, in Nasdaq trading.
Apple has had three consecutive quarters of losses, its worst financial performance ever. It is struggling to recover from forecasting mistakes, manufacturing problems, weak demand and crippling management turmoil that scared off customers earlier this year.
But the company has already shown signs of a recovery. In the third quarter, Apple reported a narrower-than-expected third-quarter loss of $32 million, or 26 cents a share. The loss was reduced by a gain of $39 million, or 31 cents, on the sale of Apple's investment in America Online Inc.
Mr. Anderson also said today that more people were leaving the company on their own, and that Apple might not need to spend as much money on severance. Apple took a charge of $207 million to cover the costs of getting rid of 2,800 workers.
Apple started the fiscal year with 17,500 workers, Mr. Anderson said, and the company now has about 13,500.
The company is losing employees in some of the areas that needed to be cut, including manufacturing, he said. The losses are not indicative of a "brain drain" that would rob Apple of its most valuable workers, he said.

HEADLINE: Economic Signs Are Mixed As Manufacturing Slows

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
There were more mixed economic signs yesterday as a closely watched manufacturing report showed slower momentum but a forecasting tool reached another high.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's index fell to 51.7 percent in September from 52.6 percent in August. A reading above 50 percent is a sign of an expanding industrial economy. 
 The Conference Board said its Index of leading economic indicators rose two-tenths of 1 percent in August, its seventh consecutive gain, but on par with analysts' expectations.
Wall Street took the reports as positive, sending stock and bond prices higher.
On Monday, reports showed August had the highest level of new- home sales in more than 10 years and solid gains in personal income and consumer spending. Those surveys rekindled concerns the economy might not be slowing enough to avoid an interest rate increase when the Federal Reserve holds its next policy-making meeting on Nov. 13, after the Presidential election.
"I think the market has been kind of seesawing back and forth between a strong economy and a soft economy," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "I think this pattern will continue until probably after the election."
Last week, the Fed decided not to raise interest rates to head off inflation, apparently believing that the economy was slowing on its own and not threatening a resurgence of higher inflation.
The purchasing managers' report said prices paid by manufacturers increased for the first time in four months, with its price index rising from 47.4 percent in August to 51.2 percent in September.
The decline in the overall N.A.P.M. index was unexpected. Wall Street had been looking for a slight gain to about 53 percent.
The purchasing managers' figures are closely watched on Wall Street because its survey is one of the first key indicators of September economic performance. The leading index, in contrast, relies on August data.
Elliott Platt, director of economic research at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation , said the purchasing managers' report tended to confirm the economy was advancing at a moderate pace. Inflation is generated by a fast-growing economy.
In addition to its reading on the manufacturing sector, the N.A.P.M. index indicated the overall economy had expanded for the eighth straight month. An index reading above 44.5 percent suggests overall growth.
Other components of the N.A.P.M. report, based on responses to survey questions of purchasing executives at more than 300 industrial companies: The production index fell to 54.1 percent, from 57.0 percent in August, and the new orders index rose to 56.3 percent from 55.6 percent.
"The increases in the price and new orders indexes and the decreases in the supplier deliveries, employment and production indexes give a mixed indication of the direction of manufacturing activity in September," said Ralph G. Kauffman, chairman of the N.A.P.M.'s business survey committee.
In addition to the rise in the index of leading economic indicators' August reading to 103.3, two sister indexes, the coincident and lagging indexes, also gained in August.
The index is designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance. It is seen by economists, however, as most useful in forecasting the economy's direction rather than its pace.

HEADLINE: At Work, Injuries and Bitterness;
Labor Strife and Amputations Roil a Plastics Factory

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: SOLVAY, N.Y.

 BODY:
Valerie Yerdon talks in a flat voice with no hint of emotion, describing how she lost the middle finger and index finger of her right hand.
She was cleaning the side of a printing press with a rag when the press's high-speed rollers pulled in the rag, and her fingers along with it. 
 "They were so mangled there was no way they could be reattached," said Ms. Yerdon, a printing press technician at Landis Plastics, which makes containers for Cool Whip, Breyer's yogurt and Philadelphia cream cheese.
Thankful that she is back on the job, Ms. Yerdon, 32, declines to fault her employer. But many of her co-workers, along with some clergymen and safety experts, have harsh words for Landis's safety record and other unpleasant aspects of work there, like managers inspecting workers' mouths to check whether they are chewing gum.
In the last 15 months, police reports show, three other employees at the 200-worker factory have lost fingers on the job. According to factory records, during the last year, a fourth of the plant's predominantly female work force has missed work because of job-related injuries, including fractures and back sprains.
Not only that, the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration is investigating Landis for failing to report many injuries in its safety logs, as required by law.
"A lot of girls are scared to work there," said Kathy Saumier, who trains workers at the plant in this gritty village of 6,718 just west of Syracuse.
This is not at all what Solvay residents expected when three years ago, village officials and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced plans to build a plastics plant in Solvay. The factory provided hope for a village whose economy had been on life support since 1986, when Allied Chemical's huge, century-old soda ash plant, which paid 47 percent of Solvay's taxes, closed, and dismissed 1,400 workers.
According to state safety figures, the amputation rate at Landis is almost 100 times higher than at a typical New York factory. The most recent amputation occurred in August, when, on her fourth day of work, Wendy Bibbs lost her left pinky as she reached into a printing press to remove some trapped container lids. In June, Craig Roberts lost the tip of a finger while cleaning the drum of a printing press that unexpectedly started operating at full speed.
Lynn Golash, executive director of the Central New York Council on Occupational Safety and Health, said: "The accident rate is very high. There's no way it should be happening."
Stephen Ellis, the mechanical engineer who runs the plant, insists that Landis is continually taking steps to improve safety.
In a written response, approved by Landis's lawyers, to a reporter's questions, Mr. Ellis said, "The company made every effort possible during the design of its equipment, and the development of the guarding equipment, to insure a safe operation."
Discussing the amputations, he added, "In light of the variety of circumstances under which these four incidents occurred, and the different causal factors, the company does not believe its safety program is subpar. In a perfect world, we would not expect a single accident, and given our choice, none would have occurred."
The company announced yesterday that it has hired a consultant, Oshex Associates, to improve its safety performance.
Though Landis's factory floor is spotless, brightly lighted and full of shiny new injection molding machines, many workers call it a modern-day sweatshop, and safety problems are just part of it. Landis, a family-owned, Chicago-based company, has developed such a reputation as a renegade employer that every Thursday members of Syracuse's labor-clergy coalition pray outside the one-story ribbed-concrete factory, prompting company supporters to stage their own demonstration.
Landis gives demerits to workers, many of them single mothers, when they leave work to go to emergency rooms when their children are injured. To keep workers from chewing gum, which they fear might fall into yogurt containers, supervisors pat down workers' pockets and order them to open their mouths.
Ms. Saumier and several other workers said managers have told them that the entry-level jobs packing plastic cups into crates are for women and higher-paying technical jobs are reserved for men. Lorraine Baker, a packer, and other workers complained that their health insurance was canceled days after they were put on disability leave.
The National Labor Relations Board has charged Landis with breaking the law by dismissing and punishing workers who asked the steelworkers' union to organize the plant.
James Valenti, the steelworkers' official heading the unionization drive, said: "In my 20 years of doing this, I have never seen an employer that holds its workers in such contempt in so many areas: in safety, workers comp, sick leave, hiring, sex discrimination. It's total contempt across the board."
On nonsafety matters like discrimination, Mr. Ellis says union supporters are lying and distorting the facts. He also says Landis is a better employer than most, paying more than many nearby companies and offering an array of benefits, including a 401(k) plan and health and dental benefits. In addition, the company denies improperly terminating workers' health insurance or dismissing workers because they support unionization.
While giving a visitor a tour, Mr. Ellis said: "When people tell me I don't care when my employees get hurt, I take offense. I care about being part of the community. If all that these people say is true, I wouldn't be here."
Although Landis pays far less than what it promised local officials it would pay, which was -- $13 an hour plus $7 to $12 in benefits, Mrs. Baker happily gave up her $5-an-hour waitress job to work as an inspector-packer at Landis. The lure: an hourly wage of $6.50, rising to more than $8 after two years.
"They made it sound like paradise in there," Mrs. Baker said. "Boy, was I wrong."
She has been out out of work for 16 weeks, awaiting an operation for carpal tunnel syndrome. Ten-inch-long braces cover her wrists, which are often numb. Her injury, she says, was caused by turning thousands of stacks of plastic containers around each day to inspect for defects.
Her job, the most common at the plant, is at once high pressure and monotonous. She would remove plastic containers from the molding machines, twirl them around to inspect them, stack them into cardboard boxes and carry the boxes, weighing 25 to 44 pounds, to a conveyor belt 15 feet away.
The lifting takes a toll. Marcella Mauro has been out of work since she sprained her back two months ago when the top of a crate she was carrying popped open, and something popped in her back as she sought to stabilize the box.
As evidence of how Landis filled out its OSHA safety logs improperly, Mrs. Mauro noted that the logs said she missed no days of work because of her back injury. Photocopies of the logs, provided by a lawyer for the union, show that when Landis listed Valerie Yerdon's amputation in January, officials merely wrote "right hand," even though Federal rules specify that the word "amputation" should be used to describe such an injury.
The photocopies show that six months after Ms. Yerdon's accident, and only after a steelworkers' lawyer sought copies of the logs, Landis officials altered them to describe Ms. Yerdon's injury as "right hand mangled." Copies of the logs show that more than a dozen accidents last winter and spring had been omitted for months before being listed this summer.
"There was a deliberate effort to hide things from Federal regulators," said Mairead Connor, a lawyer for the steelworkers' union, which played a major role in bringing Landis's safety problems to light. State officials say the State Attorney General is investigating charges that Landis repeatedly failed to inform the Workers Compensation Board within 10 days of employee injuries, as state law requires. With government regulators beginning to look into Landis, its lawyers filed about 60 injury notices in August, some going back two years.
Mr. Ellis said, "While the union has accused the company of not submitting forms to the State of New York in a timely manner, the fact is every employee injured on the job received first-class medical care and lost-time compensation -- all at the company's expense."
Some employees blame the amputations on inadequate training and inadequate guard mechanisms in the printing presses to keep fingers out. Others say the machines operate so fast that the workers can not think straight, especially toward the end of a 12-hour shift.
Management's supporters have a different explanation. Terri Komuda, an administrative assistant, pointed to carelessness by workers who have little experience with machinery.
"At home, you know not to stick your fingers in a running blender," she said. "But sometimes you have freak accidents."
Rabbi Daniel Jezer, co-chairman of the labor-religion coalition, said such an explanation was blaming the victim. "The plant needs to be constructed in such a way," he said, "and training has to be done in such a way so that if you know you have a population vulnerable to accidents, management will build in safeguards to minimize the risks."
Auxiliary Bishop Thomas J. Costello of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Syracuse said what particularly disturbed him was Landis's demerit system, which penalizes workers who face family emergencies.
That happened to Linda Murphy, who received a phone call in May telling her that her 3-year-old, Charlie, had scalded himself when a pot of soup spilled off the stove.
She said: "I told my supervisor, 'I got to go to the emergency room. My son's burned.' " She said, 'This is going to put you in the danger zone.' "
Mrs. Murphy entered the "danger zone" because she had accumulated three demerits in April for missing three days of work with a kidney infection. At Landis, workers receive a demerit for each day they miss work, no matter what the reason. Workers who receive 10 demerits are docked 50 cents an hour for three months; those who accumulate 15 can be dismissed.
Bishop Costello called this system arbitrary and inhumane, but Mr. Ellis defended it as a no-fault attendance policy that allows workers nine absences a year.
Mr. Ellis said, "We believe fairness to our employees requires us to tell employees in advance the number of absences we consider satisfactory."
Assemblywoman Catherine T. Nolan, a Queens Democrat who heads the Labor Committee, has scheduled a hearing for Oct. 2 about the Landis situation.
"The kind of exploitation that people associated with the underground economy has moved into the mainstream," she said. "Government is cutting back on the number of people who enforce workers' comp and job safety, and if you don't put resources there, it can produce problems like this. We're in a climate that says, 'We have to do everything we can to free up business,' but there has to be a balance between that climate and protecting workers."
