HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole Stages a Dress Rehearsal for the Debates

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: KIRTLAND, Ohio, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Bob Dole turned his attention today to next Sunday's Presidential debate, staging his first full-run practice session in Washington and using a speech here to test themes for the coming encounter.
Mr. Dole's speech, at a rally in a Cleveland suburb, along with a 15-minute kaffeeklatsch with a local family before a small pool of reporters and photographers, marked his first public campaign appearance in three days, a reflection of the importance he has attached to preparing for the debates. Aides said Mr. Dole would maintain the unusually light public campaign schedule through most of the week before retiring to his Florida condominium for two days of full-time debate preparation. 
 After five days of studying briefing books and videotapes of President Clinton's debate performances, Mr. Dole participated in his first mock debate today. The setting, a 10th-floor conference room at his campaign headquarters in Washington, was equipped with television lights and lecterns. Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee, a former actor, played Mr. Clinton, while Nelson Warfield, the campaign's press secretary, played the questioner, who will be Jim Lehrer of PBS.
Mr. Dole's speech here, to an audience of mostly college students, marked the beginning of an effort to set the stage for the debate on Sunday in Hartford, testing themes he would like to use against his opponent while continuing the customary pre-debate effort to play down his own debating abilities.
To that end, Mr. Dole used remarks and props -- including what he called a "Consumers Guide to the Debate" and a floor-to-ceiling chart of numbers spelling out the benefits of his tax cut -- to remind his listeners of promises Mr. Clinton made in the 1992 debates and did not keep as President. Those included pledges to cut taxes for the middle class and to balance the budget.
"Those were the promises he made the last time he debated before a national audience. You know the story from there. Did anybody get that tax cut in this audience? No! Are you going to believe him next time he promises a tax cut? No!"
In both cases, Mr. Dole led the audience in answering his question.
"I just want to say, if you're listening to these debates, ask yourself this question," Mr. Dole said, reaching his conclusion. "Would you buy a used election promise from this man?" The young crowd roared back with a full-throated: "No!"
And Mr. Dole suggested, again, that his debating skills paled compared with Mr. Clinton's, notwithstanding his 35 years in Congress, and that the public should thus not hold high hopes for his performance. "We're going to have a little debate on Sunday night," Mr. Dole said. "I'm going to show up, and he is so good, if I show up, I think I will win."
In praising Mr. Clinton's debating strengths, Mr. Dole, who in recent days has argued that Mr. Clinton was a politically consistent liberal, returned to his earlier criticism that the President is politically pliant, which, he said, made him that much more difficult an opponent.
"He doesn't care what he says," Mr. Dole said. " He'll say it today and he'll believe it. He'll say something else tomorrow and he'll believe that."
Mr. Dole spoke at the Lakeland Community College here, in a gymnasium whose walls were plastered with "Trust Dole" signs. The lectern was decorated with a slogan evocative of his tax cut: "You earned it. You can keep it."
It was not one of Mr. Dole's easier rallies. From the start, it was disrupted by scuffles in the crowd as supporters of Mr. Clinton hoisted up Clinton-Gore signs, only to have them ripped out of their hands by Mr. Dole's aides and supporters before they were escorted out by security officers. As they were walked past bleachers filled with Mr. Dole's fans, a corner of the gym was swept by boos, which Mr. Clinton's supporters encouraged by hoisting their ripped Clinton-Gore signs. The heckling was directed at Mr. Clinton's operatives, but it competed with Mr. Dole's speech.
And as Mr. Dole delivered his remarks, confetti guns that were supposed to fire at the end of the speech were set off inadvertently by Mr. Dole's advance workers, filling the air with confetti and colored streamers. Mr Dole, who has seen his campaign speeches interrupted by miscues before, continued speaking.
Mr. Dole also stopped by the home of a local family for what had been advertised as a coffee discussion. It lasted about 15 minutes, and it was marked by a number of silences. Mr. Dole attempted briefly to explain his economic plan and then, gesturing to a coffee pot on a picnic table near an above-ground swimming pool, sought to change the subject. "Is there coffee in that pot?" he asked. There was, and Mr. Dole requested some.
 "Plain, half a cup," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bob Dole took his Presidential campaign to the home of Don DiSantis, second from left, yesterday in the Cleveland suburb of Willoughby, where he chatted in the backyard about economics and coffee. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
Court Review for Suicide Laws
The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether the Constitution gives terminally ill patients a right to a doctor's assistance in hastening death. The Justices accepted appeals filed by the States of New York and Washington of lower court rulings that said people who were mentally competent and terminally ill had a constitutional right to doctor-assisted suicide. [Page A1.]
 
Con Edison Proposes a Freeze
Consolidated Edison has offered to freeze electric rates for five years as part of a proposal to radically change its operations, allowing all its customers by 2003 to buy their power from alternate suppliers. [B1.]
 
Safety Questions at Factory
The opening of a Landis Plastics factory in Solvay provided hope for the village near Syracuse whose economy had been on life support. But safety experts have harsh words for the company. In the last 15 months, 4 of the 200 employees there have lost fingers on the job. [B1.]
 
New Media Mogul?
Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the investment banker who is married to New York's Lieutenant Governor, is expected to announce today that he is purchasing a controlling interest in a chain of weekly newspapers that extends from Manhattan to Eastern Long Island to Washington. [B1.]
Don Forst, a veteran newsman who was editor of New York Newsday, has been named editor of The Village Voice. [B6.]
 
A Film Maker's Protest
Leon Ichaso handed out protest fliers to the opening-night crowd at the New York Film Festival, which rejected his movie "Bitter Sugar" on artistic grounds. But Mr. Ichaso thinks the film, which ends with a disillusioned Cuban youth striking out against the Socialist state that betrayed him, was rejected for going against the liberal grain. About New York by David Gonzalez. [B1.]
 
Brooklyn Primary, Part 2
Seeking to remedy polling-place foul-ups that prevented or discouraged voting in last month's primary, a Federal judge ordered that scores of voting sites in Brooklyn be reopened on Oct. 10. [B3.]
 
Government's Unanswered Mail
A City Council survey suggests that many city agencies are failing to follow a basic tenet of public office: Always answer the mail. Mayor Giuliani described the survey as partisan sniping. [B3.]
 
Serious Crime Falls Again
Police Department statistics suggest that the city's falling crime rate shows no sign of bottoming out and that the decline in most major crimes has accelerated. Reported serious crime has tumbled by more than 12 percent compared with 1995, with only one Bronx police precinct experiencing a modest increase in crime. [B3.]
 
Arrests in Mafia-Run Drug Ring
Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn announced the arrest of 40 people believed to be members of a crack cocaine ring operated by the Lucchese crime family. [B6.]
 
Redefining Domestic Violence
Governor Pataki signaled his support of a broad definition of domestic violence, and in the process defied his conservative allies who have defined a household strictly as a married heterosexual couple. [B7.]
 
A Friendly Rivalry Turns
Mayor Giuliani, New York's chief executive Yankee fan, is always ready to establish a bantering sports rivalry with another mayor or governor whose team challenges his own. But the rivalry turned chilly when an out-of-town official appeared to challenge the city's reduction in crime. Sports Wednesday. [B12.]

New Stage for Crash Inquiry
With the last concentrated field of wreckage from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 largely cleared, dozens of divers donned scuba gear and fanned out to join the hunt for the last scattered fragments of the jet. [B7.]

Militia Leader's Arrest
For years, Bo Gritz, a former Green Beret commando and an unofficial leader of the far-right militia movement, has warned of Government conspiracies to restrict freedoms and called for upright citizens to arm themselves and move to the Idaho hills. He is now facing charges that he tried to kidnap two young boys who he believed had been unjustly taken from their mother. [A1.]
 
Lawyer Outlines Rape Defense
On the first day of jury selection, Alex Kelly's lawyer began to outline a defense suggesting that a woman who accused him of rape had been drinking excessively before engaging in consensual sex with Mr. Kelly a decade ago. [B6.]

Indictment in Unabomber Case
A Federal grand jury in Newark indicted Theodore J. Kaczynski, suspected of carrying out deadly mail-bomb attacks as the Unabomber, on charges that one of his devices killed an advertising executive in North Caldwell. [B7.]

HEADLINE: Speaking Up for Immigrants

 BODY:
At a time of rising attacks on immigrants as a blight on American life, it is certainly fitting for the Mayor of New York City to stand up for the values symbolized by the Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor. But Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's recent criticism of the new Federal welfare law, which cruelly cuts off basic social services even to legal immigrants, is welcome because it springs from much more than tradition and a spirit of charity. Mr. Giuliani rightly argues that punishing immigrants is self-defeating. It violates basic constitutional principles and overlooks the valuable economic and social contribution that immigrants make every day.
Recent waves of immigrants have rescued neighborhoods throughout New York City, brought an entrepreneurial spirit that has spawned new enterprises and provided a pool of labor that has let established businesses grow and thrive. Since large portions of the white middle class have fled to the suburbs or elsewhere in the last 20 years, the major reason the city has not declined in population is an influx of new arrivals from the Caribbean, Asia and the former Soviet Union. For the most part, contrary to popular conception, these immigrant groups are not on welfare any more than the native-born portion of the population. 
 Much of the attention paid to the recently enacted welfare legislation focused on the work requirements and time limits imposed on poor families. But the $54 billion in savings required by the new law over the next five years entails cuts in the food-stamp program for all recipients and a denial of food stamps and other benefits to legal immigrants, except those who become citizens or have worked in the United States for 10 years. Since those very same immigrants pay taxes and contribute their work and energy to their communities, it is morally repugnant to change the rules after they have come to the United States and leave them no recourse if they become disabled or their families break apart.
Since neither the city nor the state can afford to spend the hundreds of millions of dollars it might take to make up for the losses in Federal support, Mr. Giuliani will have to follow up his criticism by pushing the next Congress to reverse the parts of the new welfare legislation that punish immigrants. Gov. George Pataki has also spoken out against the provisions that hurt immigrants. If he joins with Mr. Giuliani and other Republicans, they could be especially effective because they also enthusiastically support the work-requirement part of the law.
Until now, Mr. Giuliani has avoided the role that some of his predecessors staked out as national urban spokesmen. Voters in New York City have not always looked kindly to mayors who spend much time tending to politics outside the city's borders. But it is in the city's interest for Mr. Giuliani to address these issues nationally. With his record of lowering crime and putting welfare recipients to work, he has the standing to speak up for the immigrant tradition.
No doubt the Mayor is playing this role knowing that it might help him in the election next year. The City Planning Department estimates that there are about 2.3 million foreign-born people in New York City. Many are voters, and many more are likely to become voters because of the boom in naturalization that has been spurred by new laws affecting immigrants. But like many children and grandchildren of immigrants, Mr. Giuliani is obviously also speaking from the heart on the subject. As the Mayor of a city that has always thrived on each new wave of immigrants and through them renewed itself as a place of energy, competition and cultural variety, Mr. Giuliani may well be able to tip the balance against the self-destructive and xenophobic attitudes that other politicians have courted in the last few years.

HEADLINE: British Labor's New Model

 BODY:
Only a few years ago, Britain's Labor Party seemed locked into a decline as inexorable as that of the coal mines and smokestack factories whose workers built its ranks. Now it has rebounded to a healthy lead in the polls based on a modernized, middle-class platform far removed from the old Socialist themes of nationalization, union power and unilateral nuclear disarmament.
Having lost four consecutive national elections since 1979, Labor is determined to win the next one, due no later than next spring. Tony Blair, a telegenic, media-savvy 43-year-old who became the party's leader two years ago, has modeled himself on Bill Clinton and tried to capture the broad center ground on social, economic and defense issues. 
 Labor's recovery is welcome. Strong competition is invigorating to democracy, just as it is in the marketplace. Labor's updated positions calling for a flexible mix of public and private ownership and more democratic decision-making serve Britain better than those they replaced. Other Labor views are vague but appealing campaign slogans whose real meaning will become clear only if the party takes power.
British politics was transformed in the 1980's by Margaret Thatcher. Breaking sharply from the aristocratic traditions of the Conservative Party, she won over much of the upwardly mobile urban middle class with an emphasis on markets, deregulation and self-reliance. But under her chosen successor, John Major, the Tories have stumbled and been riven by internal conflicts over Britain's proper role in the developing European Union.
Americans would find Labor's campaign platform, which has been on display at this week's party conference, familiar ground. In place of the old Socialist slogans are calls for combating crime, cutting taxes and assuring business profits. Mr. Blair urged his union allies to "forget the past. No more bosses versus workers. You are on the same side."
He made a direct bid for the middle-class voters Mrs. Thatcher wooed away from Labor, reaching out to small business and the self-employed with promises of tax relief, reduced bureaucracy and tight fiscal discipline. He identified Labor as "the party of law and order" and pledged to sustain a strong national defense.
Labor's clearest difference with the Conservatives is its more positive approach to the European Union. But even here the party is cautious, stressing Labor's commitment to national independence and opposition to joining a "European superstate."
Throughout the developed world, the center-left parties that regularly elected governments in the 1960's and 1970's saw voters defect in large numbers during the 1980's and early 1990's. Most have tried to rebuild their strength by modernizing their appeal, and it makes sense for British Labor to seek lessons from Bill Clinton's campaign successes.
Mr. Blair's success in broadening Labor's appeal seems real. The test now is whether he can hold this new base together in an election, and if Labor wins, in a new British government.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Earlier, and Better, Education

 BODY:
A task force of the Carnegie Corporation has recommended that virtually all children in the United States be enrolled in a preschool program at age 3 to improve their prospects for success in school and, ultimately, in life. Unfortunately, the task force did not estimate the total cost of such a program or suggest who should pay the bill, so its proposal is less a call for immediate action than a sensible long-term goal that deserves serious attention from policy makers and parents.
Currently, about half of all 3- to 5-year-olds are enrolled in preschool programs, including Head Start, school-based prekindergarten programs, nursery schools and child care. The most recognizable model of a high-quality early-childhood development program is probably Head Start, which serves low-income children. The program helps inculcate educational and social skills in its young participants that can carry into elementary school. The children also receive health and nutritional services. At the same time, the program encourages parents' involvement and offers social services to families. 
 Most quality programs for preschool-age kids, whether run by private child-care givers or public entities, incorporate many of these elements. A report released earlier this year by the David and Lucile Packard Foundation's Center for the Future of Children emphasized the long-term educational and economic gains of good early-childhood programs. The report concluded that low-income children exposed to these programs have higher reading scores, are less likely to be held back a grade or put into expensive special-education classes and are more likely to graduate from high school than those who do not participate in them.
While such outcomes have been documented for low-income children, the Carnegie task force makes clear that all children would benefit from a good-quality preschool experience. The panel finds that the educational demands of a more competitive global society are higher than most American children are currently achieving. American youngsters are already falling behind students in many foreign countries by the fourth grade. With stronger skills coming into elementary school, they would probably do better.
The Carnegie task force recommends universal early-childhood development, but it has no universal prescription for how that should be achieved. What makes the most sense is to build on the range of programs that already exist, from Head Start to family day care, and simply expand them to cover the 47 percent of children who now have no preschool experience. That would allow each community to tailor programs to its own needs.
The task force estimates that 75 percent of the funding for existing early-education services is provided by families, but it leaves open for further analysis how much it would cost to cover all 3- to 5-year-olds and who should foot the bill. Even without a fixed number, this will undoubtedly be a multibillion-dollar, multi-year effort that should be shared among families and Federal, state and local governments. The task force has made a valuable contribution by highlighting the need for a firmer educational foundation for all the nation's children.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE RUNNING MATE;
Kemp Seeks To Narrow Gap With Women

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 1

 BODY:
From school choice to extra tax breaks to lower crime, Jack Kemp proffered a luxurious bouquet of pledges today in pursuit of the votes of women, who have tended to spurn the Dole-Kemp Republican Presidential ticket.
Speaking to more than 200 women at a Jewish community center in Tucson, Mr. Kemp promised that a Dole Administration would so reduce taxes that families could get by on one income, allowing mothers to stay home if they wished. He said that the capital gains tax would eventually be eliminated altogether and that the new tax code he and Bob Dole want to see written would help foster the new businesses that American women are increasingly founding. 
 "We will double the number of women-owned businesses," he told the receptive crowd.
Mr. Kemp even attempted to cast foreign policy in a feminine light, saying that a Dole Administration would apply the type of diplomacy that a mother would choose and not "bomb Baghdad without talking to someone," a reference to Mr. Clinton's decisions recently to bomb sites in northern Iraq.
With polls showing that American women -- even suburban housewives who traditionally vote Republican -- feel a lack of enthusiasm toward Mr. Dole, Mr. Kemp is scheduled to appear at a similar women's event in Connecticut on Thursday.
A Kemp campaign spokeswoman, Alixe Glen, said Mr. Kemp's courtship of women's votes was not a dramatic shift in policy, but added, "We do need to get our message out to the soccer moms and the suburban women."
Mr. Kemp painted the Republican Party as one of inclusion and compassion that wanted to help the poor by expanding the economy and moving social programs from Federal to local control.
He won applause by deriding he Department of Education as "the department of no education" and more when he declared, "We think the tax code stinks." He also won loud approval when he reassured a local woman who asked him whether a Dole Administration, in pursuit of lower, simpler taxes, would do away with the rule that allows homeowners to deduct the interest they pay on their mortgages.
"You can bank on it," he said in pledging that the mortgage deduction would be "absolutely sacrosanct" and that he would "personally tackle" any Treasury Secretary who tried to do away with it.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Rise to Records, With Dow Topping 5,900
Stocks rose to records, led by bank and financial shares, as the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 5,900 points for the first time, rising 22.73, to 5,904.90, on optimism that interest rates would not rise and harm profits. The S.& P. 500 stock index climbed 1.77 points to 689.08, its second consecutive closing high. 
 However, the Nasdaq composite index, home to a host of computer and technology shares, fell 5.41, to 1,221.51, about 28 points shy of the record it set in June. [Page D10.]
 
Treasury securities also rallied, with the 30-year bond gaining 18/32 to a price of 98 15/32 to yield 6.87 percent. [D20.]
 
Purchasing Managers' Index Off
Behind the market rallies was a report by the National Association of Purchasing Management that led traders to conclude the Fed would not need to push up interest rates. The group's index fell to 51.7 percent in September from 52.6 percent in August. [D2.]
 
European Union Plans Trade Suit
The European Union, in a rebuff of the Clinton Administration, said it would challenge in a new court of world trade the American law that has imposed sanctions on foreign companies doing business with Cuba. [A9.]
 
Anthem Confirms Connecticut Deal
Anthem, a big Midwestern insurer, confirmed it intended to add Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Connecticut to its Anthem East unit. [D9.]
 
Chrysler Sales Pace Tops Industry
Chrysler continued to outpace the rest of the auto industry last month, as sales of its cars and trucks rose 22 percent. In contrast, G.M. posted a 2.1 percent drop. [D2.]
 
G.M. and Unions Progress in Talks
General Motors and its main American and Canadian unions are said to be moving toward new national labor contracts and resolving disputes over selling parts factories. [D2.]
 
Con Ed to Freeze Electric Rates
Con Ed said it would freeze electric rates for five years as part of a proposal to change operations radically, allowing all its customers to buy power from alternate suppliers by 2003. [B1.]
 
Senate Passes Securities Bill
The Senate approved legislation to streamline the regulation of mutual funds, investment advisers and stockbrokers. The House passed the bill on Saturday, and President Clinton is expected to sign it. [D4.]
 
Micron's Coming of Age
Micron Technology appears to be growing up, having announced that three top managers were leaving its board -- which is still dominated by Idaho agribusiness magnates -- to make way for outside directors. News Analysis. [D6.]
 
HCIA's Stock Is Pummeled
HCIA Inc. said late Monday that its earnings would be 10 to 15 cents a share, in contrast to the 29 cents expected. Wall Street's reaction was brutal. Shares fell $27.125, to $32.875, in extraordinarily heavy trading. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D10.]
 
F.D.A. Approves New Lilly Drug
The F.D.A. approved a new drug for treating schizophrenia that is expected to have fewer side effects than existing medications. The drug, olanzapine, is to be sold under the brand name Zyprexa by Eli Lilly & Company. [A21.]

HEADLINE: Con Ed Offers To Hold Rates For Five Years

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday proposed a five-year freeze on electric rates and radical changes in operations that would allow all customers to purchase power from other suppliers by 2003.
Con Edison is one of five utilities in New York State that were ordered by the State Public Service Commission on May 20 to file comprehensive plans by yesterday on how they would reduce electric rates and give customers more choice in buying power. 
 Although the commission urged the utilities to allow customers to begin buying from alternate suppliers by early 1998, the proposal by Con Edison would give only a small number, 5,600 of its three million customers, a choice by then.
The proposal for a rate freeze appeared to be an effort by Con Ed to show regulators that it had a plan to control costs, without following the state's timetable on offering a plan to give customers a choice of electrical suppliers. Regulators say that more choices will provide more pressure to keep costs in line, much as competition among long-distance companies has helped hold down telephone rates.
Eugene R. McGrath, the chairman of Con Ed, defended the utility's proposals, saying the company needed more time to explore the choice issue.
"A lot has to be learned," Mr. McGrath said. "We have to find out what kind of problems we're going to have with this."
Some customers, particularly larger commercial and industrial users, have been pressing the state to reduce electric rates quickly. The state has some of the highest rates in the nation, and some companies have threatened to move out of the state.
Con Edison's rates are exceeded by several utilities in Hawaii and by the Long Island Lighting Company. Lilco, which may be taken over by the state, was not required to file a plan yesterday for reducing rates.
The freeze proposed by Con Edison would lock in rates of about 13.5 cents a kilowatt hour. The national average rate last year was 7.2 cents a kilowatt hour.
Mr. McGrath said one reason rates were so high in the New York area was high local and state taxes on the utility, accounting for about 3.2 cents of Con Edison's costs.
Con Ed's proposal comes against a backdrop of across-the-board deregulation in the utility industry. Electric companies across the country are making plans to sell cheaper power as states like California open their markets to competition. And with New York and New Jersey having opened their markets for natural gas, the Brooklyn Union Gas Company agreed last month to lower its rates and then freeze them for three years to make itself more competitive.
The Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation, the New York State Electric and Gas Company, Orange and Rockland Utilities Inc. and the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Company have also filed proposals similar to Con Edison's for dealing with a competitive electricity market.
Niagara Mohawk Power, which has threatened to file for bankruptcy protection, was also exempted from the filing.
Under Con Edison's plan, customers would be able to buy electricity from competing suppliers. Con Edison, for a fee, would deliver the power to their businesses or homes over its transmission lines.
While the competition among power suppliers is expected to reduce electric rates for some customers, there are widespread concerns about reliability, about whether all customers would benefit equally and about whether outside suppliers could provide enough power during peak periods of demand.
In this competitive marketplace, most utilities are expected to sell or close many of their power plants, since customers would be buying power from suppliers that in turn would acquire it from the lowest-cost producers in many states.
Most utilities would retain their transmission systems and remain primarily responsible for delivering the power.
As a result, keeping the power flowing reliably will be a complex process, since many big changes have to made in tandem with others.
To show the complexity, Mr. McGrath displayed charts with more than 350 continuous steps that the utility would have to take over the next seven years to make the transition.
"We know how vital, how life-and-death critical, energy is to New York City, and we have to be very careful that we don't impact reliability." he said.
Mr. McGrath also said that Con Edison wanted to insure that one group of customers, like larger industrial and commercial users, would not be favored at the expense of others. In some states, like Michigan, utilities have given big rate reductions to industrial customers while increasing rates for smaller residential customers.
Currently, the average monthly bill for a residential customer of Con Edison is about $54.
To absorb the cost of flat rates, Mr. McGrath said, the utility would continue to reduce its work force of 16,100 by attrition. About 3,200 jobs have been cut in the last decade.
The proposals will be used as a guide by the Public Service Commission in its drive to deregulate the industry. As other states have moved ahead, the pressure has grown on New York to move faster.
California has moved the furthest, with the Governor having recently signed a law that will set up an elaborate system under which some customers will be able to buy electricity through a power pool by 1998.
The proposal by Con Edison would also enable the utility to form a holding company that could diversify into other power-related businesses.
Con Edison's proposal was praised yesterday by the Natural Resource Defense Council, an environmental group. Ashok Gupta, the energy economist for the group, noted that under its proposal Con Ed would continue to spend $50 million to $60 million a year on rebates and financing help for those who invest in lighting and appliances that use less energy. Many utilities, he said, have phased out such programs when cutting costs.
Larry Shapiro , senior lawyer for the New York Interest Research Group, said that his consumer group agreed with Con Edison that a gradual approach to more competition was the best course because of the uncertainty on how deregulation would affect consumers.
Among the issues, he said, is whether consumers who deal with outside marketers in the future would retain the protections they now have before a utility can cut off power in disputes over payment of bills.

HEADLINE: Chrysler Sets Sales Pace While G.M. Lags

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 1

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation's cars and trucks continued to outsell the rest of the auto industry while the General Motors Corporation reported another month of lackluster sales today.
Sales of Chrysler cars and trucks rose 22 percent in September, while sales at General Motors fell 2.1 percent from the period a year ago. Among the 10 auto makers reporting September results today, sales rose an average 4.9 percent over the period a year ago. 
 "Chrysler has gone through the roof," said Scott F. Merlis, the president of Merlis Automotive International, an independent automotive research firm based in Westport, Conn.
One reason, he said, is that Chrysler has had such success with its mini-vans and its Dodge Ram pickup trucks that those models have drawn customers into Chrysler showrooms, increasing sales of other car and truck lines as well. "When you get products this successful, there tends to be a halo over all products," Mr. Merlis said.
Robert J. Eaton, the chairman and chief executive of Chrysler, said, "The market continues to look very, very good for us."
Chrysler's car sales rose 17 percent last month, while sales of light trucks rose 24 percent. Analysts said the results were higher than expected. The company increased car sales slightly by offering rebates and discounted lease deals on certain models. Percentage calculations are based on a daily selling rate because there were 24 selling days last month but 25 selling days in September 1995.
At General Motors, car sales plunged 10 percent while truck sales rose 13 percent. Ronald L. Zarrella, the G.M. vice president in charge of sales, service and marketing, said sales should improve later this year when a number of redesigned 1997 midsize cars start appearing on showroom floors.
"Midsize models debuting in the coming months -- Pontiac Grand Prix, Buick Century and Regal, Oldsmobile Cutlass and Intrigue and Chevrolet Malibu -- give G.M. six all-new entries in this important segment," Mr. Zarrella said.
Three redesigned mini-vans will go on sale by the end of the year -- the Chevrolet Venture, Pontiac Trans Sport and the Oldsmobile Silhouette -- and those, along with a new model of the Cadillac, called the Catera, should further improve sales, Mr. Zarrella said.
Other auto makers reporting sales today were: Nissan, up 2.6 percent; Mitsubishi, up 18.5 percent; Subaru, up 15.8 percent; Isuzu, down 21.1 percent; Volvo, up 5.4 percent; Suzuki, up 70.6 percent; Kia, up 44.3 percent, and Land Rover, up 60.3.
The auto sales numbers provide one of the first glances at the performance of the nation's economy in September. Several auto executives and Wall Street analysts said that while the numbers showed some strength, they still suggested that Federal Reserve officials were correct in leaving short-term interest rates unchanged after their meeting on Sept. 24.
"From our vantage point, the economy looks very good -- we do not see any inflationary pressures," Mr. Eaton said. "We think the Fed did exactly the right thing," he said.
Auto analysts agreed. Mr. Merlis said, "There is no reason to believe there was any overheating."
Jeff K. Thredgold, chief business economist at Keycorp bank, said that the auto sales figures, taken with reports of modest declines in retail sales and slower spending plans by corporate purchasing managers, showed that the economy might have slowed enough so that an interest rate increase was not necessary. "The Fed probably made a good choice," he said.
Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., predicted that for the industry as a whole, the September sales rate would not pick up much from the sales pace earlier this summer. July and August combined turned in a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 15.1 million cars and light trucks, he said. He expects that by Thursday, when the Toyota Motor Corporation, the Honda Motor Company and the Ford Motor Company are scheduled to report their sales, the industry will turn in a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 15.3 million light vehicles.
"September sales certainly indicate that the economy isn't particularly vigorous," Mr. Glantz said. "Chrysler was stronger than I anticipated and G.M. was weaker."
Some auto dealers said sales were sluggish. Lou N. Kairys, president of Lustine Automotive Group in Hyattsville, Md., said sales at his chain of car dealerships were "significantly slower" in September.
"There's a real softening," said Mr. Kairys, who sells cars and trucks made by G.M., Nissan and Toyota. "You're starting to see some fallout from the people who have garnered all the credit they can possibly garner and now are facing the piper and paying for it."

HEADLINE: McCaughey Ross's Husband Is Expected to Buy Weekly Newspapers

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the investment banker who is married to New York's Lieutenant Governor, is expected to announce today that he is purchasing a controlling interest in a chain of weekly newspapers that extends from Manhattan to the East End of Long Island to Washington.
By the standards of high finance it is a tiny transaction, but it would give Mr. Ross control of a newspaper chain that each week reaches 650,000 people. Mr. Ross heads a group that will pour $2 million into News Communications Inc., a publicly traded company that owns 23 weeklies, many of them free, including Our Town on the East Side of Manhattan, Dan's Paper in the Hamptons, and The Hill, a scrappy newspaper devoted to covering Congress. 
 Mr. Ross said that he would become chief executive of News Communications and that his group would control about 22 percent of the company's stock, while Jerry Finkelstein, the founder of the company, would remain as chairman.
"I believe there is a real niche, indeed a real need, for papers like these that fill in the blanks left by the big daily papers, the electronic media and Internet," said Mr. Ross, who is senior managing director of the Rothschild Inc. investment bank. "It started out as a cottage industry and I believe it'll end up with big chains and a high degree of professionalism. At a certain point, most of the additional revenue generated by these papers will be profit."
Although Mr. Ross said the deal was a strong business transaction, one political consultant said it ultimately could benefit the political career of Mr. Ross's wife, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross.
The consultant, Norman Adler, noted that Mrs. McCaughey Ross has been at odds with state Republican leaders, who have warned that she may not be on Gov. George E. Pataki's re-election ticket in two years. Mrs. McCaughey Ross, her friends say, has no intention of retiring from political life and may mount a challenge in 1998 to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. Coincidentally, News Communications owns The Independent Voice in Island Park, Mr. D'Amato's hometown.
"If you want to be in politics, it's very comforting to have an affluent husband with an imagination," Mr. Adler said. "It's at least one rung up, if not two, on the ladder of political visibility. Those papers are in a lot of middle- and upper-income communities, and that's where the voters are. If I were running in a primary I'd want my spouse to own a string of widely read newspapers."
But Mr. Ross denied there was a political aspect to the investment. He said that he and his group of investors, which includes Robert Nederlander, president of the Nederlander Organization, the Broadway producers, and Sy Syms, chief executive of the Syms Corporation, a clothing retailer, are in it only for the money.
"This is a business transaction," Mr. Ross said. "That's why Bob Nederlander and Sy Syms are in it. They believe we can make a very good economic transaction out of this. What's driving the deal is business. I don't think the owner is going to be writing the editorials."
According to the latest annual report filed by News Communications, revenues rose 33 percent to $18.1 million for the year ending Nov. 30, 1995. But the company suffered a net loss of $1.7 million, due to a jump in the price of newsprint and the high costs associated with starting several publications.
Mr. Ross said that he hoped the infusion of cash would allow the company to computerize its operations and create a joint advertising program for all the company's weeklies.
Mr. Finkelstein said: "I hope to conclude this deal with Wilbur, but I haven't had a board meeting. He's an excellent banker and he's going to do us a lot of good. I'm trying to get him to do a lot of work."
The newspaper chain was widely believed to have been borne of Mr. Finkelstein's political ambitions for his son Andrew Stein, though he has consistently denied it. In 1968, he contributed tens of thousands of dollars to his son's successful campaign for the State Assembly. By the mid-1980's Mr. Stein was the City Council President and a potential mayoral candidate.
During the same period, Mr. Finkelstein, the longtime publisher of The New York Law Journal, began piecing together his media empire. In 1985, he started The West Side Spirit, a weekly now known as Manhattan Spirit, and three years later he bought the first two papers -- Dan's Papers and the Montauk Pioneer -- in what would become a string of weeklies based in upper-middle-class communities.
Mr. Stein jumped into the 1992 mayoral race along with Rudolph W. Giuliani, who promptly accused Mr. Finkelstein of using the string of weeklies to tout his son's candidacy and lambast his opponents. Mr. Stein ultimately dropped out of the mayoral race and politics altogether. Mr. Finkelstein, however, continued his empire building, purchasing a string of eight weeklies in Nassau County in 1993 and starting up a glossy monthly magazine, Manhattan File, the following year. Both Mr. Finkelstein and Mr. Ross say they are still in an expansion mode.

HEADLINE: OPERA REVIEW;
For a First Night at the Met, Pavarotti in 'Andrea Chenier'

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Opera's fashionable first-night audience was a blessing to be counted on Monday. The house's production of "Andrea Chenier" is scarcely six months old, but what an unhappy affair it is. The three long intermissions provided the evening's principal satisfactions, I am afraid to say. One's heart sank every time the house lights went down.
The Met has given us some powerful productions in the past few seasons, so it is hard to understand its settling for something like this. Nicolas Joel and Hubert Monloup offer a "Chenier" that is pretentious, ugly and confused. Clubfooted symbolism prevails: an oversize mirror that tilts ominously toward doomed French aristocrats, wrecked timbers in the Revolution's aftermath, an economy-size guillotine projected in silhouette at the end. 
 To get a picture of Act I's chateau setting, imagine yourself entering a Howard Johnson motel while dead drunk. There is the looming, fractured mirror, the geometric lobby carpeting, the ghastly blue-and-gold drapery and a hideous sofa to stoke the fantasies of any upwardly mobile suburban housewife. Act III's courtroom is like the entrance to an American city hall. There is more, but enough.
Mr. Joel's staging takes confusion as its watchword. Large numbers of people are crowded toward the front of the stage, where they mill aimlessly. If a metaphor for the chaos of the times is intended, it is a clumsy one. Secondary principals are egged on toward caricature, Paul Plishka's Matthieu being particularly egregious. If one was seeking good taste on Monday, the audience was perhaps the best place to look for it.
Giordano's sweetly lyrical music aims to please and almost always does. It is a little fragile to be supporting momentous doings like the Terror, but there are such powerful moments as Gerard's "Nemico della patria"; Juan Pons sang it with a flat-out ardor that brought down the house.
As a story, "Andrea Chenier" is muddied by all the minor characters necessary to prod along the plot, but it enjoys the built-in symmetry of master-servant relationships reversed. Chenier is the poet caught between higher and lower orders. Maddalena is the frivolous aristocrat who finds dignity and love in the final execution scene.
This is an opera that can be celebrated more for its parts than its whole. Luciano Pavarotti has the principal one. Six decades have drained a lot of the color from his voice, but in the title role he holds up admirably well. The points of vocal stress are handled gingerly but they are handled. A 61-year-old tenor must by nature be a master of disguise; and so Mr. Pavarotti directs most of our attention to his powers of articulation, almost to the point of excess.
As Maddalena, Maria Guleghina lives for the moments when she can fill the Met with deafening soprano sound. Elsewhere she has little idea what to do with herself: the phrasing is confused, the sustained piano passages unsteady.
There were small pleasures. I was particularly taken by Stephanie Blythe's brief appearance as Madelon, a bereft mother of the Revolution. This is a dark voice of quiet authority. James Levine and his Met orchestra performed with relish. The brass playing at the final curtain provided a sliver of happiness to take home with us.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Luciano Pavarotti in the title role of the Metropolitan Opera's six-month-old production of "Andrea Chenier," a tale of chaos in revolutionary France. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The states aren't examplars of how to balance budgets.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
'Most states are required to balance their books," proclaims "Plan for Economic Growth," the Dole-Kemp campaign document. "Bob Dole believes the Federal Government should be required to do so as well."
If Mr. Dole is elected, the Constitution may well be changed to restrict deficit finance to national emergencies. The House passed a balanced budget amendment in 1995. A parallel initiative failed in the Senate by just two votes, and there is strong support for the amendment at the state level. 
 But anyone who relies on the states' experience to project the impact on Federal budget-making is in for some surprises, argues Richard Briffault of the Columbia University Law School. His report, "Balancing Acts: The Reality Behind State Balanced Budget Requirements," to be published later this month by the Twentieth Century Fund, is a sobering analysis of the limited impact of seemingly tough legal restraints on Government borrowing.
"Most states balance their operating budgets most of the time," Mr. Briffault acknowledges. And most states -- the number varies from a few dozen to 49, depending on how the laws are read -- officially bar deficit spending. The closer one looks, though, the less binding these strictures appear.
Unlike Washington, states make a distinction between "operating" and "capital" budgets. Almost all permit the sale of bonds to finance long-term improvements -- schools, airports and the like.
That makes sense. Just as no one expects successful businesses to finance their growth entirely from internal cash flow, few expect states to pay for new roads the year the asphalt is laid. Trouble is, it's hard to nail down what constitutes a capital improvement.
In practice most states use special authorities, whose debts are not formally backed by the state's credit, to underwrite a mix of capital and operating outlays. The extent to which operating expenses are hidden in capital budgets is, in practical terms, impossible to figure out. But Mr. Briffault reports that slightly more than half of state spending came from authorities unconstrained by deficit spending limits in 1993 -- far more than even the most generous estimates of capital spending.
Moreover, when pressed, states resort to cruder gimmicks. Michigan altered its fiscal year to pick up an additional three months of revenue over the summer, when it was not obligated to make aid payments to school districts. West Virginia, New Jersey and several other states have fudged pension accounting, shifting more of the obligation to pay for retirement of civil servants to future taxpayers. New York sold the Attica prison to a public authority, leasing it back and using the cash to cover the operating budget. All told, the General Accounting Office found that about one-third of the state budget gap that emerged in the 1990 recession was covered with dubious fund shuffles.
Another widely used tactic to reduce budget woes, Mr. Briffault suggests, is to pass them on to local governments. It is no coincidence, he argues, that local taxes have risen faster than state taxes since the mid-1980's. In California, for example, localities were forced to make up some $7 billion in aid cuts between 1990 and 1994 as the state struggled with stagnant revenues.
On balance, the states do have a far better fiscal record than Washington. But Robert Reishchauer, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office, is not inclined to assign much of the credit to constitutional borrowing limits. After all, when it has been expedient, state legislatures played games with capital budgets, pushed obligations into future years or simply dumped fiscal responsibilities on local taxpayers.
Moreover, state budgets are fundamentally different beasts. Mr. Reischauer notes that state budgets are less sensitive to the business cycle than the Federal budget. Washington's tax receipts fall more and its obligations to maintain the safety net rise more during recessions, making the task of keeping the Federal budget in balance that much harder.
More important, states are unable to print money, making them fiscal prisoners of the private capital markets. When Washington runs a deficit, it can always make up the difference by selling bonds backed, ultimately, by the power to create money. When Albany and Sacramento run deficits, they must find private investors to lend them the cash.
Of course, states do have the power to tax to cover debt obligations. But this power is indirectly limited by competition among the states. Faced with higher taxes, businesses and high-income individuals have the option to go elsewhere.
The irony here, Mr. Reischauer suggests, is that all things considered the state experience with constitutional limitations on deficit finance may be no better than Congress's efforts to discipline itself. The Federal deficit, after all, has fallen from $300 billion a few years ago to around $100 billion now. Not many states can match that gain.

HEADLINE: Commercial Building Outlays Give Construction Slight Lift

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Record outlays for commercial buildings raised construction spending in August, but the increase was offset by a third straight decline in government projects and flat residential expenditures, the Commerce Department said today.
Spending on residential, nonresidential and public projects rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, to $562.1 billion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, the fourth increase in six months, the Commerce Department said. 
 Still, the advance, which was in line with analysts' expectations, failed to erase the 1.1 percent decline in July even though the July figure was revised from its initial 1.4 percent estimate.
And despite the August performance, many analysts believe construction spending in the third quarter will fall below the average during the previous three months.
"This is an important piece of the economy and appears to be swinging from a strong second quarter to a much weaker third quarter," said David F. Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders.
"Unless July and August are revised up and September comes in strong, it certainly will contribute to a slowdown in growth in the third quarter," he added.
The Federal Reserve has been expecting economic growth to moderate. Officials decided last week they did not need to slow growth with higher interest rates to keep inflation under control.
Paced by a 12.3 percent jump in construction of hotels and motels, nonresidential spending rose 3 percent, to an annual rate of $139.5 billion, the highest on record. Outlays in the category, which includes shopping centers, were up 6.1 percent.
But residential spending, 40 percent of the total, was virtually unchanged at a $244 billion rate in August.
Spending on single-family houses edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent, same as the July increase, as 30-year mortgage rates averaged 8 percent or more for the third straight month.
The single-family market is particularly interest-sensitive since a one- percentage-point increase in mortgage rates would add more than $100 to many monthly payments. Mortgages averaged about 7 percent last January.
Outlays for often-volatile multifamily projects such as apartments and condominiums rose 3.4 percent but failed to recoup the 14.4 percent loss a month earlier.
Government spending continued to feel the effects of budget cuts. It fell two-tenths of 1 percent, to an annualized rate of $138.7 billion, the third straight decline.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Reaches 2 1/2-Year High Vs. Yen and Gains on Mark

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose to a two-and-a-half-year high against the yen yesterday as Japanese investors expressed their preference for American investments over the low interest rates on Japanese financial instruments.
With the start in Japan yesterday of the second half of the fiscal year, traders said, more investors there are looking to buy foreign securities. To do that, they must generally sell yen for other currencies. 
 "The dollar is going to continue going higher," said Jack Griffin, currency-sales manager at Fuji Bank. "With the start of the new fiscal term, a reallocation of assets is being made. There will be continued Japanese investment into the U.S."
Fuji has seen substantial dollar purchases from Japanese life insurers, pension funds and investment houses this week, Mr. Griffin said.
The dollar also jumped to a three-month high against the German mark after the chairman of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, John C. Whitehead, said in an interview with NBC Desktop, a multimedia news service, that it could gain further against European currencies.
The dollar rose as high as 112.04 yen yesterday, its strongest since Jan. 24, 1994, and 1.5336 marks, its highest since June 25. In New York trading late in the afternoon, it was quoted at 111.90 yen, up from 111.33 on Tuesday, and at 1.5315 marks, up from 1.5260. The British pound rose to $1.5650, from $1.5645 on Tuesday.
Japanese monetary officials have held the discount rate at a record low, one-half of 1 percent, since September 1995, and no increase is expected by analysts any time soon.
Given that, Japanese investors "need to risk buying foreign assets to better manage their money," said Norihiko Nishino, manager for foreign exchange at the Nomura Trust and Banking Company in Tokyo.
The dollar increased against the mark after Mr. Whitehead said it could rise 5 to 10 percent more against European currencies.
Mr. Whitehead's Federal Reserve bank post is largely honorary. A former Deputy Secretary of State in the Reagan Administration, he is chairman of AEA Investors, a money management firm. The New York Fed's president, William J. McDonough, has influence over monetary policy.

HEADLINE: A Fragile Redwood Deal

 BODY:
A promising deal has been struck that could resolve a 10-year struggle to save part of what is left of northwestern California's ancient redwood groves. Some environmental activists argue that the deal gives away too much and can never be made to work, and in recent days they have stepped up their protests. Proving them wrong will require a lot more effort by Federal and state negotiators who have already invested heavily of their time. It will also require good faith by a company that is not known for environmental virtue.
At issue is the Headwaters Forest in Humboldt County, which contains thousands of acres of old-growth redwoods that provide habitat for at least three endangered or threatened species -- coho salmon, a seabird known as the marbled murrelet and the spotted owl. The forest is owned by the Pacific Lumber Company, acquired in a leveraged buyout in 1986 by Charles Hurwitz, a prominent Texas financier and savings-and-loan operator. To pay down his debt, Mr. Hurwitz has been cutting redwoods and other trees, but in recent years a series of lawsuits and demonstrations have slowed his operations and caused him no end of public embarrassment. 
 There are two parts to the plan. First, the state and Federal governments will pay Pacific Lumber $380 million in cash and government property in exchange for 5,600 acres of the company's most sensitive land, including about 3,500 acres of virgin, old-growth redwoods. This looks like a steep price but is, in fact, less than the value placed on the property by a Forest Service survey four years ago. These acres would then become a public preserve.
Second, Pacific Lumber has agreed to join with Federal and state officials to devise a "habitat conservation" and "sustainable logging" plan to protect endangered species on the rest of the land it owns, amounting to more than 200,000 acres, predominantly second- and third-growth redwood and Douglas fir. This plan would be the most ambitious public-private effort so far to protect an entire ecosystem, instead of protecting individual species within that system on a case-by-case basis under the Endangered Species Act.
There are powerful incentives here for Mr. Hurwitz to conclude the deal. He will receive fair compensation for the 5,600 acres of virgin redwoods. Further, if all sides can agree on a conservation plan governing the rest of Pacific Lumber's property, the company will effectively be relieved of species-by-species lawsuits, which can lead to injunctions that bring logging to a halt. That will give Mr. Hurwitz a level of economic certainty he does not now have.
Local environmentalists would like the state and Federal governments to buy 60,000 more acres, but Senator Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat who helped broker the deal, says that is financially absurd. They also worry that any overall conservation plan, no matter how tightly drawn, will not provide nearly as much protection for endangered species and their habitat as the present system that allows for species-by-species lawsuits. In short, they do not trust the company.
That is a plausible concern, and it places powerful obligations on Federal and state negotiators in the months ahead. They will need to recruit the best scientific minds, independent of company or political pressure, to devise the protection plan. They must also insist on the right to revisit the plan at regular intervals to see whether Pacific Lumber's logging practices are in fact protecting valuable habitat -- and to tighten the plan if they are not.
On paper, this is a bold and imaginative initiative. But turning it into a real victory for those who value what is left of the redwoods will take careful attention to detail and continuing pressure.

HEADLINE: Japanese Voters, Too, Get a Big Tax-Cut Promise

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Borrowing a leaf from Bob Dole's briefing book, a Japanese opposition leader tried today to stimulate his sagging campaign by calling for big tax cuts.
The opposition leader, Ichiro Ozawa, is desperately trying to win support in general elections to be held on Oct. 20. 
 Mr. Ozawa, who has had a reputation as a wizard at election strategy, called for a 50 percent cut in both the national income tax and the local tax, abolition of a property tax and a more modest cut in the corporate income tax. He also said the national sales tax should be left where it is at 3 percent, instead of being raised as scheduled next April to 5 percent.
"Japan's economy is now in a state of stagnation, of recession, and if we leave things as they are it will only get worse," Mr. Ozawa, leader of the New Frontier Party, said at a news conference this evening. "Therefore, we must change the structure of the economy, and to do that we must enliven the economy as a whole."
Promises of tax cuts are old hat in American electoral politics, but Mr. Ozawa's approach is unusual in Japan. Japanese grumble about high taxes as much as Americans do, but Mr. Ozawa already has a reputation among many voters for being tricky, and so it is not clear how voters will view his latest promises.
The written platform that Mr. Ozawa issued today gave few details of how the tax cut plan would work or how it would be financed. The platform was called "five covenants with the people," and it appeared to be modeled in part on the Republicans' Contract With America.
Mr. Ozawa is an admirer of many aspects of the United States and has long shown an interest in American politics. Similarly, he has often seemed to have more support in America than in Japan, for while many Americans hail him as a true reformer he is regarded by many Japanese as an untrustworthy titan of machine politics.
The Government of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, which is widely expected to win re-election, is taking the opposite approach of Mr. Ozawa: it is promising a tax increase. Mr. Hashimoto insists that the increase in the sales tax is necessary and will go ahead as planned.
The sales tax increase is unpopular with voters, and it is expected to be the major issue in the campaign, which formally begins next Tuesday and lasts only 12 days. But Mr. Ozawa's proposal for tax cuts may set off a broader debate about tax policy. Japan's ratio of all taxes to national income is 38 percent, 3 points higher than America's.
Mr. Ozawa sounded a bit like a supply-sider at this evening's news conference, saying that lower taxes would stimulate economic growth and in turn increase tax revenue. As a result, he said, Japan's budget deficit will not drastically increase.
"By enlivening the economy, we will increase tax revenues and partially pay for the cost of the cuts," Mr. Ozawa said. "And with administrative reform, we will reduce expenses."
Even Mr. Ozawa acknowledged that in the long run Japan needs to address its budget deficit, which in percentage terms is far greater than America's. As a result, he said that it would eventually be necessary to consider an increase in the sales tax.
Mr. Hashimoto and other members of the governing coalition had no immediate comment on Mr. Ozawa's tax-cut proposal. But Nihon Keizai, a newspaper that often reflects the views of business, suggested this evening that the plan was unrealistic.
"How is the party intending to reconstruct the already deficit-ridden public finances?" the newspaper asked. "The answer is uncertain."

HEADLINE: Central Europe Learns About Sex Harassment

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
When Iwona, a 21-year-old computer operator, landed a coveted job with a multinational company whose presence in Poland she considered a hallmark of growing economic success, she hoped to rise through the ranks.
But her hopes were crushed. She says she was sexually harassed by one of the company's salesmen, who is also a Pole. She filed a complaint with her employer, the consumer product company Unilever. But the hearing she got was described by her lawyer as unfair, and when her contract came due in August, it was not renewed. 
 Women's rights advocates say such cases illustrate that sexual harassment is finally being raised as an issue in the former Communist countries of Central Europe.
The woman's case stood out not because of the harassment she says she suffered but because she stood up to it in a culture where women have long endured sexual harassment, accepting it as the norm.
In many Polish workplaces, the tone is set by a Playboy centerfold hanging on the wall behind the secretary's desk -- a practice that began under the Communists. The centerfolds have remained because male bosses want them there. Many women in those offices say even now that they see nothing demeaning about sitting in front of the centerfolds.
But increasing attention to sexual harassment in news reports is beginning to encourage some women to speak out. Poland's main Government television channel recently ran a prime-time docudrama about sexual harassment, followed by a discussion with a studio audience and telephone calls from viewers. The message to women workers was: if you take your case to court, you can win.
In fact, though, the region has weak labor and civil-rights laws, and they have been largely untested because so few sexual harassment cases have been filed.
But there are signs that some companies are taking notice. In a high-profile recent case in the Czech Republic, a manager at Komercni Banka, a major state bank, was dismissed after a secretary filed a sexual harassment complaint against him. In a case last year involving the same man, the bank refused to act.
And a case in Hungary drew the attention of the top executive of International American Products Ltd., a contracting company based in Columbia, S.C. After allegations by local women of sexual harassment against the company's American construction workers at a United States Army base in Taszar, the executive traveled there to investigate.
The executive, Doyle E. McBride, said after his investigation that the allegations were unfounded; the women withdrew their accusations, but women said they had been pressed into changing their story.
But for the most part, the average Central European woman, pressed by today's harsh economic circumstances and inured by decades of Communism when she had little recourse, remains unaware that there may be a way to fight sexual harassment, or even that she should.
An official of the Polish Government's office for women and family, Aleksandra Smejda, said she had not received any grievances "because unfortunately Polish women do not protest against such treatment."
Only 5 percent of those responding to a recent Polish newspaper poll said they had ever encountered cases of sexual harassment at work, a result that showed the women's resignation rather than lack of incidents, sociologists say. Similar results have been found in the Czech Republic and Hungary, where even the term "sexual harassment" is a new addition to the lexicon.
"We have a long way to go in raising the consciousness of women and men and making them realize what is not appropriate," said Urszula Nowakowska, director of the Women's Rights Center in Warsaw, a pro-bono group of lawyers that has taken up Iwona's case.
At a discussion during a visit to Warsaw last summer by Hillary Rodham Clinton, Ms. Nowakowska appealed to her to help by urging large Western corporations to drop what Ms. Nowakowska called their "double standard."
The corporations have failed to adopt here the policies against sexual harassment that they have established in Western Europe and the United States, Ms. Nowakowska said. In some companies, the text of a harassment policy set by the global headquarters is sent as a gesture to the Central European office, but it is rarely translated into the local language and rarely reaches the work force.
Even as awareness among women grows, Western companies are likely to be slow in introducing Western-style sensitivity training, a personnel expert said.
"Polish employees are much more afraid of making claims against their employer," said Jerzy Warman, a former human-resources manager at Price Waterhouse in Warsaw who now works in New York City's personnel department. "They are more afraid of losing their job or of slowing the speed with which they are progressing."
Mr. Warman said that given the high level of domestic violence in Central Europe, it would take time for women to feel comfortable about bringing suits. "If a woman is being beaten by her husband at home, it is unlikely that she would consider her boss making some bawdy remarks or slapping her back as inappropriate," he said.
Another barrier is the weak legal framework in Eastern European countries. Even so, with the idea of bringing the issue to public attention, Ms. Nowakowska is searching for a case to pursue under either civil law or labor law. A victory would galvanize women, she said.
A possible case involving an American company emerged earlier this year, but the woman bringing the complaint, a deputy director of an office, decided to settle out of court after seeking the center's advice, Ms. Nowakowska said. The woman, a Pole, had received excellent job ratings from her director, who was also Polish. Then the man insisted that she have sexual intercourse with him and threatened to dismiss her if she refused, Ms. Nowakowska said. The woman refused, and her job evaluations dropped and her company car was taken away.
The American company sent an executive to investigate the case, Ms. Nowakowska said. The company agreed to pay the woman a year's salary if she left, but stipulated that the company's name could not be disclosed, the lawyer said.
In Iwona's case, Ms. Nowakowska said, the young woman says the last straw came when the male supervisor came upon her in the office kitchen, pressed his body against her and groped her. In a letter to Unilever's personnel manager at the company's headquarters in the Netherlands, Ms. Nowakowska said her client had been explicitly told by a Unilever manager in Poland that her contract would not be renewed. Many Polish workers are hired on a contract for the first three months and then almost automatically given permanent employment.
The reason given by the Unilever manager was the filing of the complaint, Ms. Nowakowska told the company in her letter.
Ms. Nowakowska said she was gathering evidence for a possible court case against Unilever.
The chairman of Unilever in Poland, Tjalling Tiemstra, denied that the woman was unfairly dismissed. He said the case was handled according to Unilever's global guidelines. Thus, he said, all parties were given a "fair hearing," the facts were checked and a ruling was issued.

HEADLINE: On Second Thought, U.S. Decides Shipyard Subsidies Aren't So Bad

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
It took six years and endless arm-twisting for American trade negotiators to persuade Japan, South Korea and nearly every European nation to end one of the biggest forms of corporate welfare in the world: billions of dollars in government subsidies for shipbuilders.
The subsidies, American shipbuilders said, were making it impossible for them to compete and could cost thousands of jobs in shipyards from Maine to California. 
 But nearly two years after the deal was struck and ratifed by all but one of the signatories, and just as most subsidies were supposed to be cut off, the whole agreement unraveled in Washington. Both Democrats and Republicans in Congress, only weeks from the election, realized that the United States would also have to cut off its subsidies to American shipbuilders.
Even the Clinton Administration, which was pressing Congress to ratify the accord until a few weeks ago, has played both sides of the issue. Last weekend, at a campaign appearance in Boston, President Clinton boasted that the budget agreement reached late last week included millions to "revitalize the Quincy Shipyard" in Massachusetts.
In fact, the revival effort in Quincy would have been greatly hampered if the agreement had passed Congress and gone into effect.
With no agreement in force, European nations have decided to continue subsidizing their industry, to the tune of more than $1 billion annually, 20 times what the United States spends guaranteeing loans for the sale of American ships. But the beneficiaries of those loans say they would rather continue the subsidy wars than live with the changes the agreements would force at home.
The collapse of the shipbuilding agreement is an example of how easy it is for Democrats and Republicans alike to talk about ending "corporate welfare," and how hard it is actually to do it. And it illustrates how an accord that would save taxpayers millions of dollars and level the playing field -- an objective both Mr. Clinton and Bob Dole say is at the core of their economic foreign policies -- can fall apart as soon as companies and workers discover that other nations expect the United States to make concessions as well.
It also raises serious questions about whether American allies can believe that the United States will put into effect the trade accords that its negotiators initial.
"In the past month the Congress has walked away from three international accords," said Senator John Breaux, the Louisiana Democrat who fought unsuccessfully to win passage of the shipbuilding accord. "We ditched the chemical weapons treaty, the agreement on tuna and porpoise fishing, and now this one. It sends a disturbing message to international trading partners that the U.S. will get you to sign a treaty, but there is no guarantee that Congress will get it done."
What killed the accord in the end was opposition from the same big shipyards that pushed the Bush Administration to negotiate it in the first place. Almost all of them are big military contractors who now fear that the same deal they once said was vital to their survival could now end any hope of Government subsidies as they struggle to become bigger players in commercial shipbuilding. And several of them are in politically volatile states.
The six biggest yards opposed to the agreement are Avondale Shipyards near New Orleans, the largest industrial employer in Louisiana; Bath Iron Works, the largest employer in Maine, and Electric Boat in Connecticut, both part of the General Dynamics Corporation; Ingalls Shipbuilding in Pascagoula, Miss., a division of Litton Industries and the largest private employer in the state; National Steel and Shipbuilding in San Diego, and Newport News Shipbuilding in Virginia, part of Tenneco Inc. and the largest nongovernment shipyard in the country.
"These are big yards that got caught by the end of the cold war and suddenly they think they can get subsidies out of the Defense Department to stay in business," a senior Administration official said. "And so suddenly, they did an about-face."
The shipbuilders tell a different story. "This was a bad trade agreement," said Tom Bowler, who once ran the Navy's largest shipbuilding operation and is now the president of the American Shipbuilding Association, the lobbyist for the large shipyards.
The accord did not prevent South Korean shipbuilders from continuing to add capacity, he complained, and that has sent ship prices down sharply. And he contended that the accord did not end all forms of subsidies.
But the agreement went a long, long way in that direction, so far that the American shipbuilding industry was clearly divided. Smaller shipyards, which tend to be more efficient and far less dependent on military work, fought for the agreement's passage. Labor unions sided with the big shipyards, which employ roughly 90 percent of the 110,000 shipbuilders in the United States.
The idea behind the agreement was to get the United States into a market where it is currently a nonplayer: international shipbuilding, which the Government estimates will be a $250 billion business in the next decade. But with European governments paying upward of 9 percent of the cost of building every ship, American shipbuilders had no chance of becoming competitive.
Under the agreement all those subsidies would end, except for a few existing programs that would be permitted to run their course. Big government payments to revamp shipyards, like the $3 billion program in Germany to refurbish shipyards in the former East Germany, would be prohibited.
In short, America's competitors would have to give up far more than the United States would. The biggest Federal subsidies to American shipbuilders ended a decade ago, though the Transportation Department still offers 25-year loan guarantees for the purchase of American-made vessels. That program would be scaled back, but not wiped out.
The agreement would also have provided a way to fight the "dumping" of ships, or selling them below the cost of manufacturing them.
And somewhat remarkably, America's trading partners agreed to allow the United States to retain legislation that stipulates that all smaller ships, which ply the inland waterways, must be built in the United States. Such "home build" rules elsewhere are vigorously protested by the United States.
In return for allowing that rule to continue, the other nations were permitted to impose penalties against American shipbuilders under some limited circumstances. The big shipyards said that this was another reason the accord had to be defeated.
They got a lot of bipartisan help, including support from many in Congress who view themselves as internationalists and free-trade advocates. The accord's opponents included Republicans like Senators William S. Cohen of Maine, John Warner of Virginia and Thad Cochran of Mississippi. Democratic opponents included Edward M. Kennedy and John Kerry of Massachusetts, Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Dianne Feinstein and Barbara Boxer of California.
The acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said the odd life and apparent death of the shipbuilding accord were not a huge surprise. "In the past two years," she said, "the Hill has had no appetite for controversial trade legislation." Cambodia and Bulgaria have received upgraded trade status and there have been agreements linked to the Middle East peace accords, but, she noted, there has been nothing involving industries at the core of American competitiveness.
Then again, it is an election year. And so in Massachusetts this week, Democrats and Republicans are arguing about shipbuilding -- not the agreement, but who can take credit for saving the Quincy shipyard.

A Record Bull Market, Any Way You Slice It
With the latest rise in the Dow Jones industrial average of 29.07, to 5,933.97, the current bull market has become the biggest ever without a decline of at least 10 percent. Since the last such decline ended, almost six years ago, the Dow is up 150.9 percent. [Page D8.]
