HEADLINE: Market Place;
Fed's Hard-Won Credibility Allows It to Take Small Risks

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer 

 BODY:
What is credibility worth? For the Federal Reserve, it's worth all the economic pain from nearly two decades of hard work -- and more. And the proof is in the way the market has reacted to the central bank's decision last week not to raise short-term interest rates.
Based on polls before the Sept. 24 meeting of the Fed's policy-making committee, more than half of Wall Street's forecasters expected a quarter of a percentage point increase in the target rate for Federal funds. 
 Yet when the Fed left the target at 5.25 percent, bond prices did not fall as they probably would have in the past, making borrowers pay extra in higher interest payments. Instead, they rose and long-term rates fell. Since then, the yield on the inflation-sensitive 30-year bond has dropped to 6.84 percent from 7.02 percent.
Part of the drop was a reaction to new data since the Fed meeting indicating that the pace of economic growth was slowing even without the Fed lifting a finger. But a much larger part of the reason is that investors, speculators and analysts seem to have confidence that the central bank will not let inflation get out of the bag again.
"Nobody really believes that the Fed is always behind the curve anymore," said Louis Crandall, the chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates.
This credibility has been hard won by the Fed's last two chairmen. Paul A. Volcker served two four-year terms as chairman and started the crackdown on double-digit inflation in 1979. He was followed by Alan Greenspan, who is now in his third term and has presided over a five-year stretch -- the longest period since the 1960's -- of inflation under 3 percent.
Still, some analysts say that the Fed showed a willingness to shift its tolerance for inflation by not moving last week when faced with unemployment as low as 5.1 percent and signs that wage increases are finally creeping up.
Instead of risking a sharper economic slowdown to be sure that inflation does not bounce higher, they say the Fed is apparently willing to risk a little jump in prices to insure the economy continues to cruise ahead.
"If Greenspan had been as vigilant as he was in 1994, he would have raised interest rates in July," said David Jones, the chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "I think he is showing a much greater willingness to accommodate growth."
John R. Williams, the chief global markets economist at Bankers Trust Company, agreed, "To a degree I haven't seen in the past, the Fed seems willing to roll the dice on inflation going up." He said, though, that bond investors did not appear to share his concern.
Mr. Crandall said, "The advantage of having credibility is that it lets you cheat when you want to."
In fact, growing Fed credibility has influenced Mr. Crandall, who said he thought the Fed should have raised the Federal funds rate, the interest charged on overnight loans between banks, in July. But he is still "confident that the current group is committed to containing inflation." He is sure, he said, that the Fed will move aggressively if new data, including the September jobs report due on Friday, raise the specter of higher inflation.
There are other reasons for the calm exhibited by the so-called bond vigilantes -- those speculators and traders, so feared in Washington, who once sold their bonds quickly on any hint of inflation or a whiff of weakness at the Fed.
One is that the risk the Fed is taking is not particularly great. The economy is not booming; the question is simply whether it is slowing quickly enough from the fast pace earlier this year. Worker compensation is rising, but just barely. Inflation is still in check and anecdotal evidence shows that companies are having trouble pushing their prices higher.
At the same time, interest rates today are nothing like they were in February 1994, when the Fed began a yearlong ratcheting up of interest rates. The Federal funds target is 5.25 percent now, not 3 percent, and the yield on the long bond is 6.84 percent, not 6.30.
John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said that investors and others had "bought the Fed's logic that the economic data is ambiguous enough that the Fed should hold off."
But Mr. Lipsky thinks the current slowdown is just temporary.
The most probable outcome, he said, "is a bounce-back in the fourth quarter that will bring the Fed back to the fore and an eventual snugging of interest rates."
Two longtime Wall Street commentators, Albert M. Wojnilower, senior economic adviser at the Clipper Group, and Henry Kaufman, the head of his own firm, said they believed there was less of a will to fight inflation today.
"It's the passage of time and lower inflation," Mr. Wojnilower said.
But even Mr. Kaufman, long known for his bearish views on inflation, is not particularly worried. "The Fed is somewhat behind the curve now," Mr. Kaufman said, "but it is not much more behind the curve than it was in the second quarter and in July."
Finally, there are a number of economists who are not worried because they were already convinced the economy was slowing on its own.
"There is no risk here in waiting," said Bruce Steinberg, manager of macroeconomic analysis at Merrill Lynch & Company. "The economy is slowing already and there is no inflation out there."
But even with its hard-won credibility, the Fed cannot simply rest on its laurels. The next hurdle will come when the September jobs report is released tomorrow morning. In July, the economy added 228,000 jobs; the figure for August was 250,000. Indeed, so far this year, the monthly gain in nonfarm payroll jobs has averaged 237,000.
To keep the contented content, the number is probably going to have to come in lower than that. Otherwise, the confidence in the Fed will get another -- tougher -- test.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Jersey City Gains Jobs

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
Of New Jersey's major cities, only Jersey City has shown substantial economic growth in the last three years, Rutgers University professors said yesterday. Their study found that jobs in Jersey City rose 17.6 percent between 1992 and 1995, said James W. Hughes, dean of the university's planning school, and Joseph J. Seneca, a professor of economics. Paterson and Trenton showed modest gains, with Newark and Elizabeth flat. Mr. Hughes attributed Jersey City's growth to the relocation of Wall Street back-office jobs.

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
D.C. Ends MetroStars' Inaugural Season

BYLINE: By ALEX YANNIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
The MetroStars' inaugural season in Major League Soccer is over.
Just when it appeared that their third and deciding playoff game with D.C. United would go into a shootout, United scored on a penalty kick with 64 seconds left for a 2-1 victory and a trip to the Eastern Conference finals. 
 Raul Diaz Arce converted the penalty kick to the delight of the Robert F. Kennedy Stadium crowd of 20,434. The fans had fallen almost silent three minutes earlier after Antony De Avila's goal tied the score at 1-1. Steve Rammel's goal in the 65th minute had given United a 1-0 lead.
Despite being eliminated, no one from the MetroStars had any complaints afterward. Rob Johnson had brought Marco Etcheverry down inside the penalty area, and the referee, Brian Hall, had no choice but to make the call. Unfortunately for the MetroStars, it came at the most inopportune time.
"There was no question about the penalty," said Carlos Queiroz, who coached the MetroStars for the last time. "Soccer is not a fair game. It's not fair to lose like that in the last minute."
Queiroz will leave for Japan in the next few days to take over Grampus Eight, which gave him a three-year contract for $6 million.
While the MetroStars did not question the penalty kick, they raised some doubts about Rammel's goal, thinking it might have come from an offside position.
Rammel scored from about a foot away. He just reached out with his right leg as he was standing virtually on the goal line to deposit the ball in the back of the net after it had bounced away from the MetroStars' Miles Joseph.
With United trying to protect its lead, the MetroStars pushed forward and tied the score when De Avila converted Roberto Donadoni's pass from 8 yards away.
"All in all, United deserved to win," said Charlie Stillitano, the vice president and general manager of the MetroStars.
Before he signs a new coach, Stillitano will have to secure the contracts of five players -- Peter Vermes, Tony Meola, Roberto Donadoni, Tab Ramos and De Avila, who are the bulk of the team's foundation.
Stillitano said he would soon interview prospective candidates to replace Queiroz.
"I'm going to Spain, Italy, Holland and Germany," he said. "All I'm going to say is that I have four people in mind. Two are employed and two are unemployed."

HEADLINE: In a Well-Kept Part of Brooklyn, Crack Arrests Are Met With Concern

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
The Gold Star Pizzeria at Avenue O and West Third Street in Brooklyn sits on a corner virtually indistinguishable from those of dozens of family-owned cafes that dot the mostly middle-class landscape of Bensonhurst.
Its neighborhood is one of well-kept apartment buildings and two-family houses with yards and porches surrounded by plaster flower pots. Across the street yesterday, the smell of bread drifted from the Boccia Bakery and men talked outside Monte's Heros delicatessen. 
 On its surface, the corner might seem an unlikely nexus for the crack-cocaine trade, which has largely been a scourge endured by the city's poorer neighborhoods.
But in February alone, Federal drug investigators say, undercover agents went there four times to buy cocaine from young dealers, all of whom lived in the neighborhood and who had made the corner a common meeting place for transactions.
The dealers were working under the watchful eye of the Lucchese crime family, many of whose members also call the neighborhood home and who have long been believed to protect their streets from many kinds of crimes. But over the last five years, the young dealers had turned a handful of other unlikely street corners, building lobbies and cafes in Bensonhurst and Bay Ridge to the same purpose.
Their customers, officials said, were nearly always their own neighbors, young men also in their 20's, some of whom had even gone to the same high schools as the dealers.
As the news spread through close-knit blocks of Bensonhurst and Bay Ridge yesterday that more than 30 residents had been arrested on Tuesday and accused of selling cocaine for years, it was received with almost equal measures of shock and grim resignation.
While many said they found it hard to believe crack was being sold and smoked on their streets, they also said that their neighborhoods were in the midst of a sea change.
"The new generation here is different," said Gus Arena, 66, a retired corrections captain who has lived in Bensonhurst all his life. "This was always a working-class Italian neighborhood, never rich people. But people here used to work. They used to break their neck. Now, kids will defile their own neighborhood with drugs to make money."
Mr. Arena, whose father immigrated from Italy and worked as a bricklayer in Brooklyn, spoke on the corner of 21st Avenue and 74th Street, where mothers pushed baby carriages and elderly women sat on lawn chairs. In January, drug investigators said, drug dealers in a Ford Escort sold undercover agents $200 worth of cocaine on the same corner.
Like Bay Ridge, Bensonhurst has long been home largely to middle-class families, mostly of Italian ancestry, with a smaller population of Jews and a recent influx of Russians and Asians.
But like Bay Ridge, in which 10 percent of residents now live below the poverty line, it has seen its economy erode over the last decade, opening the door, some say, to the kinds of crime more common in poorer neighborhoods, like drug sales and petty thefts and muggings to finance drug habits.
Some officials involved in the investigation maintain, however, that the weak economy has little to do with the crack trade's migration to the neighborhoods. "We know many of the sellers came from stable middle-class homes and had no good excuse to do this, if there is a good excuse," one Federal agent said. At least some of the dealers came from families with some history of organized crime involvement, he added.
Benny Bonello, a 14-year-old Bensonhurst resident who waited out the rain with a friend at the Gold Star Pizzeria yesterday, told of the temptation to enter a life of organized crime and drugs when he commonly saw acquaintances only a few years older flashing wads of hundred-dollar bills and driving expensive cars.
"You see it and you know all the guys, but you just try to mind your own business if you know what's good for you," he said.
Behind him, the elderly woman who owns the pizzeria, who would not give her name because she said she feared the Mafia, cursed in Italian when she read the list of suspects, many of whose nicknames -- Jimmy Frogs, Mikey Flattop and Rags -- are well known in the neighborhood. When told they had been arrested, she she clapped her hands and said, "Good! Good! Troublemakers!"
The situation in Bensonhurst and Bay Ridge is also the result, law enforcement officials said, of the weakening of traditional kinds of protection that organized crime once provided to neighborhoods where its members are believed to live, like Bensonhurst and Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and Belmont in the Bronx.
"They're really being forced into the drug trade to raise revenues that were once raised by gambling, prostitution and other rackets that have been cracked down on," said an agent of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration who was involved in the yearlong cocaine investigation. "Their greed pushes them to the point where they are willing to peddle in their own neighborhoods."
The agent, who insisted that his name not be used, said that the investigation had developed "hard, fast evidence that this was an activity sanctioned all the way up the line by the Lucchese leaders, if not explicitly, then tacitly."
And Robin Waugh, a spokeswoman for the Drug Enforcement Administration, said that the investigation also suggested that the lure of fast money from selling drugs, especially crack, cuts easily across social and economic lines.
"When someone can make $2,500 in one night by doing this," Ms. Waugh said, "I don't think it matters whether it is a poor or a middle-class, working-class neighborhood, or what kind of family you came from."

According to the Medical Examiner's office, the man, John Joseph Vite, died of natural causes; his death was not related to drugs. The Times regrets the error.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
Single-Family Homes in a Mix, All Maintenance-Free

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Started a decade ago as a development that was to have more than 500 condominiums, Sterling Woods in Danbury, Conn., had progressed as far as 87 residences before the savings and loan debacle and a real estate recession shut down construction and sales in 1990.
Now the incomplete portion of the project, on Nabby Road in the northeast of the city, is being revived with new owners and a different concept. The plan, made possible by a change in Danbury's zoning, is to create a smaller mixed residential community of 77 single-family homes, 38 duplex houses -- two-family homes sharing a common wall -- and 239 condominiums. All will offer maintenance-free living. And while the residences of two to four bedrooms will be clustered in as many as 10 neighborhoods spread over 128 wooded hillside acres, 40 percent of the site will remain undisturbed. 
 The Building and Land Technology Corporation of Wilton, an active developer in the area, will build the $70 million project in partnership with the Spinnaker Companies of Stamford. The partners hope the revamped project will appeal to a broad range of house hunters, from first-time and move-up buyers to older couples.
It will rise in phases over the next five years, with the first 67-unit phase now under way. Prices are $150,000 to $280,000, said Carl R. Kuehner 3d, president of Building and Land Technology, which is returning to the project after selling its interest four years ago. Financing is coming from the partners' own equity and banks.
The partners bought the project with an already approved site plan last month for $4.5 million. The seller was Parcliff Associates in Manhattan, which had purchased it at an auction in 1992 by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency created to dispose of failed savings and loan assets. Before that sale the corporation -- which had seized the property when it took over the failed Danbury Savings and Loan -- reached an agreement with existing owners that the old and new residences would be in independent enclaves. They will be separated from one another by buffers and each will have its own homeowners association and recreational amenities.
Danbury supported the development concept for the remaining portion of Sterling Woods from the start. Dennis I. Elpern, the city's director of planning, said the result was a project that would have less impact on municipal services and would preserve more of the hillside and woodlands. He said it would also provide an alternative type of housing that was not yet available in Danbury. He said he also thought the idea of having single-family detached homes in a community where someone else takes care of the maintenance "had promise." The idea "is slowly being accepted" throughout Connecticut, said Donald A. Hull, executive vice president at Consolidated Multiple Listing Service Inc. in Norwalk. "It gives buyers the best of two worlds."
Sterling Woods is moving forward as the sales picture in Danbury, as in other parts of Fairfield County, is showing signs of improvement. Condominiums, which were overbuilt during the boom days of the 1980's, have bounced back as the lack of new construction in the last few years helped whittle down available inventory, real estate agents said.
According to William Pitt Real Estate, based in Stamford, the average price of the 125 condominiums sold in Danbury this year was $105,000, up from $96,000 for the 103 sold during the same time in 1995. The average price for the 400 single-family homes was $219,000.
The rebounding market has rekindled developer interest in reviving stalled projects and starting new ones. Mr. Elpern, Danbury's director of planning, said projects under way, approved or planned, if realized, could produce 1,000 new residences in the city in the next few years. Much of it is attached housing, including two other projects together totaling 132 residences planned by Building and Land Technology.
The largest is Sterling Woods. Mr. Kuehner said the project's diversity of housing types in a natural setting and a prime location would attract buyers. The site is off Federal Road, a main retail corridor and close to Interstate 84. It also backs up to undeveloped land, part of the single-family neighborhoods that border the site on three sides.
"There is no other condominium project like this planned in the area," providing a ready market, Mr. Kuehner said.
Construction on the first 67 residences, designed in colonial style by E.D.I Architects of Dallas, began last month. The attached residences range in size from 1,400 to 1,600 square feet, with the duplex homes as large as 1,900 square feet. Prices are $150,000 to $190,000. The single-family detached homes, with 1,800 to 2,200 square feet, cost $230,000 to $280,000. All of the units have garages for one or two cars.
Among the amenities planned are a clubhouse, pool and jogging trails. The monthly maintenance fee is expected to be approximately $200, Mr. Kuehner said. He said sales were expected to start next week.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Takes a Breather Ahead of Today's Jobs Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar's rally paused yesterday for the first time in more than a week, reflecting in part a reluctance to bid the currency higher before a report today on United States employment in September.
"We're kind of on the sidelines, just on the off-chance there's something really unusual about this number," said John Beerling, chief currency dealer at the Norwest Bank Corporation in Minneapolis. 
 The dollar ended steady to slightly lower against most leading currencies, at least stalling a trend that has pushed the dollar to two-and-a-half-year highs against the yen and three-month highs against the mark over the last few days.
In late trading in New York, the dollar fell to 111.45 Japanese yen from 111.90 yen on Wednesday. The dollar also fell to 1.5313 marks from 1.5315 marks, the first time the dollar has ended lower against the mark since Sept. 24. The British pound was unchanged at $1.5650.
A Commerce Department report that showed factory orders tumbled in August tempered the demand for dollars, as did a Labor Department report that showed weekly unemployment claims remained at the highest level in three months. Both reports suggested the economy was decelerating, which diminishes the prospect that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates at its next policy-making meeting Nov. 13. Forecasts for higher United States rates have been an underlying element in the dollar's strength.
More clues to the economy's direction are expected today with the Labor Department's report on employment last month. While many currency traders expect the report to show a slowdown in job growth, which would suggest rates would remain unchanged, many were reluctant to speculate ahead of the report.
"We just don't know what to expect," said Debra Larsen at the New York branch of Commerzbank. "You don't know how the market is going to react."
Traders have attributed the dollar's strength partly to the prognosis for continued low interest rates in Japan and Germany, which have been struggling with economic sluggishness. Relatively high interest rates in the United States and the outlook for low inflation are seen as increasingly alluring to investors.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Analysts cheer the new direction at Hilton Hotels.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
LONG regarded as well managed but overly cautious, the Hilton Hotels Corporation has recently dispelled most doubts about its ability to react to opportunities with a whirlwind of acquisitions, buyouts and marketing alliances. And Hilton is hinting of more deals to come.
Financial analysts are already signaling their approval for what Hilton's new chief executive, Stephen F. Bollenbach, has done so far to rejuvenate the company since he signed on in February. 
 So far this year, Hilton has agreed to acquire the Bally Entertainment Corporation for more than $2 billion, a deal that when completed will make Hilton the world's biggest casino gambling organization. It agreed to buy most of the Prudential Insurance Company's interest in hotels that Hilton jointly owns with the insurance company in New York City, Washington, Chicago, San Francisco and Rye, N.Y. And it forged a strategic alliance with Ladbroke Group P.L.C., which owns Hilton Hotels International.
In addition to allowing each company to buy a fifth of the other, the alliance unites the ownership of the Hilton name in the United States and abroad, thus giving the Hilton Hotels Corporation a renewed presence in the international market.
"This has been a complete metamorphosis -- Hilton is changing right before our eyes," said W. Bruce Turner, an analyst for Salomon Brothers. "And they still aren't anywhere close to peaking, in either lodging or gaming."
While most of the publicity has centered on the Bally agreement, which will finally gain Hilton entree into the lucrative Atlantic City market, analysts say the payoff from the recent Prudential acquisitions is also likely to help Hilton's balance sheet.
Almost no big city hotels are under construction, those analysts say, therefore rates and occupancy should grow for at least the next several years. "Hilton should be able to grow cash flow by 25 percent a year," Mr. Turner said, "primarily because a lot of time there's not going to be any room at the inn."
Late last month Hilton carried out a 4-for-1 stock split, as part of its agreement to acquire Bally.
Joseph V. Coccimiglio, the gaming and lodging analyst for Prudential Securities, said he foresaw Hilton stock outperforming the market over the next 12 months.
Most analysts expect Hilton to earn about 24 cents a share after the split, and company officials said they expected earnings to meet expectations. Hilton's chief financial officer, Matthew Hart, said he expected the company to generate $1 billion in cash flow this year.
Hilton stock closed at $28.25, unchanged, yesterday.
Michael G. Mueller, the hotel analyst at Montgomery Securities, said he thought Hilton's acquisition of hotels in "downtown trophy markets" bode well for the company. "Those properties should appreciate significantly over the next decade, assuming even moderate economic growth," he said. "So now is a good time to be owning those hotels, while they have the wind at their back."
Mr. Mueller foresees Hilton growing at a 20 percent annual rate over the next five years. "Essentially," he said, "the company is raising capital at attractive rates at a time when financing costs are close to a historical low level, and reinvesting that capital in gaming and lodging businesses that generate high current returns and have attractive longer-term growth outlooks."
All three analysts said they were reassured by the appointment of Arthur M. Goldberg, chairman and chief executive of Bally, as president of the Hilton-Bally gambling operations. To Mr. Mueller, the appointment will make it easier for Hilton to exploit opportunities in markets other than Atlantic City. "He understands the gambling market, and is very entrepreneurial," the analyst said.
Mr. Coccimiglio of Prudential Securities said he thought Mr. Goldberg, who cut costs at both the corporate and casino level after joining Bally in 1990, would also be helpful in identifying areas where Hilton could realize its target of $60 million in operating cost savings.

HEADLINE: In America;
The Cities Climb Back

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
As Henry Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, sees it, the long and devastating "free fall" of American cities is over, and the difficult climb back has begun.
He may be right. 
 New York City has a good chance of ending the year with 1,000 murders or less, a terrifying statistic in most venues but a reason to celebrate in the Big Apple, which suffered through a record 2,245 homicides in 1990.
In Detroit, which came up with the quaint custom of burning itself down every Halloween, a genuine rehabilitation seems to be under way. There has been some modest job creation, an increase in home ownership, a commitment of $2 billion in private investments in the city's empowerment zone and a resurgence of the downtown area, which was in pitiful shape (especially at night) just a few years ago. A symbol of the renewed action in Detroit is the serious effort by the football Lions to arrange a return to the city. The Lions have been holed up for years in suburban Pontiac.
Chicago, Philadelphia, Kansas City, Cleveland -- all are making headway in the areas of employment, public safety, neighborhood revitalization and civic pride. Even Newark, N.J., comatose since the riots of 1967, appears to be waking up. Among other things, Newark's rancid high-rise public housing complexes are being demolished and housing more suitable to the human species is being built.
"Unemployment is down in the cities, crime rates are down, and some job creation is up," said Mr. Cisneros. "I'm not saying the cities have recovered, but they are recovering."
Slowly.
It's not that the Clinton Administration has been a champion of the cities; far from it. But since Bill Clinton became President cities have at least been able to get a hearing in Washington. And some members of the Administration, most notably Mr. Cisneros and Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin, have been passionate and eloquent advocates for cities.
This is a vast change from the approach of the Reagan and Bush Administrations. The idea then was to go Gerald Ford one better and tell all of urban America to drop dead.
Without some Federal support local efforts are doomed. In making the case for the Clinton Administration, Mr. Cisneros points to several things: to Federal support for anti-crime initiatives, including money to put additional police officers on city streets; to changes in public housing policies away from high-rises filled with the poorest of the poor to lower density, mixed-income dwellings; and to the creation of urban empowerment zones, which carry with them a whole load of Federal subsidies and tax benefits.
It is too early to gauge the impact of the empowerment zones, but the other efforts have been helpful. And cities have unquestionably benefited from the continued push to make credit more readily available through programs like the Community Reinvestment Act and the low-income housing tax credit. The Administration has steadfastly defended these programs from assaults by conservative legislators.
"What we've really seen is a credit revolution in the inner city," said Paul Grogan, president of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a nonprofit outfit that helps in the rebuilding of deteriorated neighborhoods. "There have been large rises in home ownership rates for African-Americans and Hispanics, and the availability of bank credit for all manner of activity has risen."
Most important, the cities have benefited from the overall improvements in the economy. The top 50 cities have seen their official unemployment rate decline by 2.5 percent over the past four years. In Detroit the decline was nearly 7 percent. In Cleveland, 4 percent.
More people working means more people buying and furnishing homes and paying taxes.
The flip side of the good news is that the burden of Federal budget-cutting continues to fall disproportionately on the shoulders of the cities. And the narrow, unfair and remarkably uncreative ways in which spending is being cut is sapping the nation's ability to invest in education, additional job creation, the infrastructure and the environment -- all areas that would benefit cities and the nation as a whole.
Nevertheless, good news is good news. It's heartening to see flowers emerging from the rubble.

HEADLINE: New Orders To Factories Fall Sharply

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
New orders to factories tumbled at the sharpest rate in three and a half years in August, the Commerce Department said today, as the economy's industrial sector lost some of its vigor.
Orders were down a surprisingly steep 1.9 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $311.1 billion -- the largest monthly decline since a 2.2 percent decrease in January 1993. Backlogs of unfilled orders weakened and inventories mounted. 
 The August decline more than erased a 1.7 percent July orders gain.
Another report today pointed to moderate growth. The Labor Department said new applications for jobless pay were steady last week at 340,000, the same as in the previous week, though a four-week moving average picked up for a seventh straight week.
"Both of these numbers support the view that the economy will be moderating for the balance of the year," said Lynn Reaser, an economist with Barnett Banks Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla.
Last week, a four-week moving average of jobless claims rose to 334,500 from 328,750 the week before, the highest reading since an average of 312,500 claims for the week ended June 10, 1996.
The August falloff in factory orders followed a revised 1.7 percent July increase that was previously reported as a stronger, 1.8 percent gain. Orders have fallen in two of the last three months, including a 0.7 percent June decrease.
Demand faded for both expensive durable goods like cars and airplanes and goods like food and paper products.
Durables orders dropped a revised 3.2 percent, to $166.8 billion in August, after a 1.4 percent July rise, while nondurables orders were down four-tenths of 1 percent following a 1.9 percent jump in July.
Previously, the department said durables orders had fallen 3.1 percent in August but it revised that fractionally.
"For the most part, these are relatively soft numbers which are more in line with an economy that is growing at a moderate, sustainable pace," said Joel Naroff, an economist for the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C.
Mr. Naroff said a fall of three-tenths of 1 percent in August order backlogs and a second consecutive monthly rise in stocks of unsold goods "imply that manufacturers are not being overburdened by too much demand and will therefore not be pressed to raise prices."
The biggest factor in the durables orders decline was transportation equipment, as orders plunged 7.9 percent, to $37.9 billion, after declines of 1.5 percent in July and 1.3 percent in June.
The department said aircraft and parts were the major cause for the transportation slump in August, although new-car orders were also down from July.
Excluding transportation, August factory orders were still down 1.1 percent, the largest decline since a 1.5 percent drop in May 1993, after a 2.1 percent rise in July.
Weaker factory orders were anticipated in view of other recent signs of continued cooling in manufacturing activity.
On Tuesday, the National Association of Manufacturers said its September index of activity slipped from August.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Factory Orders" shows manufacturers' total new orders from March 1995 to Aug. 1996. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Dip Ahead Of Job Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mostly lower yesterday, with the only increase coming in the longest maturity.
The report of a larger-than-expected drop in factory orders, which would usually tend to lead prices higher, was largely ignored as the market focused on today's monthly employment report. Few investors seemed willing to make large commitments ahead of the jobs number. 
 The 30-year bond gained 2/32 in price, to 9831/32 , for a yield of 6.83 percent, down from 6.84 percent on Wednesday, and setting another six-week low. But investors in most government securities apparently chose to take profits yesterday after the recent run-up in prices.
Yesterday's weekly report on jobless claims showed that the number of Americans applying for unemployment benefits last week was unchanged from the previous week. The report covered the final week of the third quarter and set the stage for today's employment numbers, which analysts expect will show that 175,000 jobs were created in September as the unemployment rate rose to 5.3 percent from 5.1 percent.
However, the bond market is probably looking for the job-growth number to be weaker than the consensus of analysts. And the market will again pay particular attention to the hourly earnings figures. Analysts are predicting an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent in that figure, but some estimates are as high as six-tenths.
The market was also hurt yesterday by the dollar, which had provided support for bonds Wednesday but turned lower yesterday. Overseas buying did help support bonds early in the day.
Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International, said: "The resiliency in Treasury securities seen so far continues to suggest the market will trade higher on as-expected data. The 30-year bond could challenge the August highs on friendly data, but will meet stiff resistance there. However, with so much talk of a friendly report, the market is very vulnerable to strong figures. A payroll number in the 240,000 to 250,000 range could be disastrous, alongside a rise in earnings and little change in the unemployment rate."
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that while factory orders slipped 1.9 percent in August, that was not surprising in light of the 3.2 percent decline reported last week in orders for durable goods. Orders for nondurables also fell in August, but the dip of four-tenths of 1 percent only partly offset the 1.9 percent rise in July.
Mr. Fine said that while the growth rate in factory orders may be slowing, "the strong performance of housing-sector data in August implies sustainable economic growth in the months ahead, as housing is considered to be the leading edge of future economic activity and has yet to show any signs of significant decline."
He said that several factors were contributing to a healthy environment for the market with little threat of inflation in the near term. The index of leading indicators has risen for seven consecutive months and the industrial sector is showing steady growth with only modest price pressures.

Critics' choices of some Manhattan art shows:
 
FRITZ WELCH, AC Project Room, 15 Renwick Street, near Canal Street, South Village (through Oct. 12). Hallucinatory, sometimes funny large-scale wall drawings in which beautiful, obsessively rendered textures seem half the point expand upon the persistent tradition of high school notebook-cover doodlings (Roberta Smith).
 
SAL SCARPITTA, Trisha Collins Grand Salon, 83 Grand Street, SoHo (through Oct. 12). Although sculptures involving a sled piece and a wrapped car frame occupy center stage, this show's strengths lie in less characteristic works: a series of bronze wall pieces, out of Africa by way of Picasso, made from shoe trees, lasts and horns; some ink drawings of gyrating race car drivers, and the economical "Tub Leg Elk," from 1970, which testifies elegantly to hislong dedication to assemblage (Smith).
 
ANNIE LEIBOVITZ, James Danziger Gallery, 130 Prince Street, SoHo (through Oct. 12). The photographer's crisp sharp-focus style, which makes everything sit in three-dimensional space with uncanny perfection, if not glamour, remains almost frighteningly consistent across subjects from Olympians and movie stars to battered wives. (Smith).

HEADLINE: Kohlberg Kravis Will Buy Kindercare for $467 Million

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Kindercare Learning Centers Inc., the nation's largest preschool and child care company, for approximately $467 million, or $20.25 a share.
Kohlberg Kravis made the announcement along with Kindercare and Oaktree Capital Management L.L.C., a Los Angeles-based company that manages a 52 percent stake in Kindercare that is owned by TCW Special Credits, a unit of Trust Company of the West. 
 The announcement was made after the close of financial markets. Kindercare's shares closed at $16.25 on Nasdaq yesterday, up 12.5 cents.
Under the terms of the agreement, Kindercare shareholders can either choose to receive $20.25 in cash for each of their shares or retain existing Kindercare stock. However, retained stock is subject to proration, and Kohlberg Kravis said that about 93 percent of Kindercare shares outstanding would be exchanged for cash, with the remaining 7 percent held by existing shareholders.
As manager of the TCW investment, Oaktree has agreed to retain a sufficient number of shares so that all other shareholders wishing to cash out will be able to do so.
After the merger, an entity controlled by Kohlberg Kravis will own about 85 percent of Kindercare, and the company's pre-merger shareholders will own about 15 percent.
In addition to the cash portion, Kohlberg Kravis will assume about $130 million of Kindercare debt.
Kohlberg Kravis said that after the merger Kindercare would be capitalized with $175 million in equity, of which $148.75 million would be invested by a Kohlberg Kravis affiliate.
All of the financing for the transaction is being arranged by Kindercare, Kohlberg Kravis and the Chase Manhattan Corporation. Kindercare also received a commitment from Chase that $300 million in bank debt would be available for future growth and acquisitions.
Kindercare, which was founded in 1969, operates nearly 1,150 preschool and child care centers in 38 states and Britain. It was taken private through a leveraged buyout arranged by Drexel Burnham Lambert in 1987. Saddled with large amounts of debt, the company struggled, and filed for bankruptcy protection in November 1992. It emerged from Chapter 11 the following March.
TCW Special Credits bought a 37 percent equity stake when Kindercare came out of bankruptcy. In April that interest was increased to the current 52 percent.
In its most recently completed fiscal year ended May 31, Kindercare, which is based in Montgomery, Ala., earned $21.7 million on revenues of $541.3 million.
Kohlberg Kravis said that TCW Special Credits, Oaktree and certain of their affiliates had agreed to vote in favor of the merger. The deal, which is subject to shareholder and regulatory approval, is expected to close by January at the latest.
Analysts said the deal was attractive for both sides.
"It's a win/win situation for both K.K.R. and shareholders," said David Mann, an analyst at Johnson Rice & Company in New Orleans. "For shareholders to get more than $20 a share is more than I would have expected the stock to move in the near term."
Mr. Mann said that Kohlberg Kravis was getting a company whose future was "clearly looking brighter."
The decision to move into child care represents something of a shift for Kohlberg Kravis, which in recent years has made big investments in insurance companies.
Of its current holdings, the only company that is remotely related is the Merit Behavioral Care Corporation, formerly a subsidiary of Medco. Merit is the nation's largest managed behavioral health care company.
Clifton S. Robbins, a Kohlberg Kravis general partner, said in a statement that "we believe the child care industry is an important and growing sector of the economy fueled by strong demographic trends." He added, "K.K.R. intends to support the expansion of Kindercare through internal growth and acquisitions while continuing to promote industry-leading education and quality standards."
CS First Boston acted as financial adviser for Kindercare. Salomon Brothers Inc. advised Kohlberg Kravis.

HEADLINE: Peter Brennan, 78, Union Head and Nixon's Labor Chief

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Peter J. Brennan, a Depression-era house painter who rose through the construction trades, became one of New York's most prominent labor leaders for three decades and was Secretary of Labor from 1973 to 1975 in the Nixon and Ford administrations, died on Wednesday at the home of a daughter in Massapequa, L.I. He was 78.
Mr. Brennan died of lymphatic cancer, according to his daughter Joan Tetro, with whom he had lived since he became ill last July. 
 Ruddy-faced and white-haired, he was a blunt, colorful man whose Hell's Kitchen accent echoed his origins on the West Side of Manhattan. Mr. Brennan was a submariner in the Pacific in World War II. After the war, he fought his way to the top of the painters' union and then the unionized building trades in New York.
Except for his two years as Labor Secretary, Mr. Brennan was president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York, an umbrella organization of unions with 250,000 members at its peak, from 1957 to 1992, when he retired.
He was also president of the council's 386,000-member New York State counterpart and was vice president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the New York City Central Labor Council. He enjoyed wide popularity in all the craft unions and was a major voice in city and state political and legislative circles.
In 1970, with the nation in turmoil over the Vietnam War, Mr. Brennan leaped to national prominence by organizing a rally of thousands of construction workers near City Hall to show support for President Richard M. Nixon's policies and American soldiers fighting in Southeast Asia. A counterdemonstration by antiwar protesters led to a clash with the workers, and many of the antiwar protesters were beaten.
Mr. Brennan and other New York labor leaders who supported Mr. Nixon were invited to the White House. Mr. Brennan said he was gravely concerned about any concessions or show of weaknesses by the United States toward the Communists in North Vietnam.
In the months that followed, friendship between Mr. Nixon and Mr. Brennan flourished. In the 1972 election, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. proclaimed its neutrality, but Mr. Brennan, a longtime Democrat who had supported Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, organized labor leaders and unions in support of Mr. Nixon, who was re-elected.
Yesterday, Representative Peter T. King, Republican of Seaford, L.I., called Mr. Brennan a "man of courage" for "standing up to the antiwar protesters who tried to take over our streets."
He added: "More than any other individual, he was responsible for bringing the blue-collar labor Democrats into the coalition that elected Presidents Nixon and Reagan. The concept of 'Reagan Democrats' would not have existed if not for Peter Brennan."
A few weeks after his re-election, Mr. Nixon nominated Mr. Brennan as Secretary of Labor, and after Senate confirmation he assumed office on Feb. 2, 1973. Organized labor was delighted, for Mr. Brennan had often spoken out for raising the minimum wage and expanding its coverage, increasing unemployment benefits, creating more jobs and training and enhancing workplace safety.
But when Mr. Brennan presented the Administration's proposal for minimum wages that would rise in small increments over four years and would not be extended to state and local employees and domestic workers, George Meany, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and other labor leaders were outraged. A defensive Mr. Brennan called it a compromise that might have been worse, given the lengthening shadows of inflation, recession and unemployment.
As the current Labor Secretary, Robert B. Reich noted yesterday, new laws were adopted during Mr. Brennan's tenure to protect the pensions of millions of workers, and the employment rights of disabled people were greatly expanded. He was also credited with strict enforcement of occupational safety and health laws and improving benefits for workers displaced by import competition.
But Mr. Meany virtually ignored Mr. Brennan for the rest of his tenure. After Mr. Nixon resigned in the Watergate scandals and Gerald R. Ford became President, Mr. Ford decided to replace several of Mr. Nixon's Cabinet appointees early in 1975. He offered Mr. Brennan the post of ambassador to Ireland. Mr. Brennan declined the offer.
He returned to New York and resumed the presidency of the construction trades council, a post he held until 1992. Over the years, he was credited with helping to raise wages and to expand job and training opportunities in the construction trades.
But he was also criticized by some civil rights advocates, who accused the building trades of discriminating against members of minority groups and said Mr. Brennan had not moved swiftly enough to open training and apprenticeship jobs to black and Hispanic workers. Mr. Brennan insisted that he had moved as fast as possible in trades that were traditionally white and resistant to change.
Peter Joseph Brennan was born in New York on May 24, 1918, one of seven children of a unionized ironworker, who died in an influenza epidemic in 1921, leaving his widow to raise the family. Peter Brennan graduated from Commerce High School and went to work as an apprentice painter, becoming a journeyman with a coveted membership in Local 1456 of the Painters Union.
During World War II, he was in the Navy as a chief petty officer aboard a submarine in the Pacific, operating mostly out of Guam. After the war, he returned to the paint pots, but became increasingly involved in his union's activities. In 1947, he was elected business manager of the local.
Regarded as a tough negotiator and a rising young star in the construction trades, he became a protege of Howard McSpedon, president of the city Building and Construction Trades Council. In 1951, he was appointed as director of the council's maintenance division.
In 1957, when Mr. McSpedon resigned, Mr. Brennan was elected president of the building trades groups. For several months each year thereafter, he was in Albany, lobbying for pending legislative measures favored by the council.
Colleagues said he was respected by legislators for his directness and grasp of complex laws and political nuances. They said he often worked 12-hour days, meeting with building company managers to solve workplace problems, mediating quarrels among council affiliates, addressing public forums and maintaining relations with the council's allies in labor and politics.
Mr. Brennan also held a wide range of appointed positions, including memberships on New York State Urban Development Corporation, the state's Job Development Authority and its Workmen's Compensation Advisory Committee. He was also an official of the Police Athletic League and the United Fund of Greater New York, and was active in the Youth Council and the Boy Scouts.
His wife, the former Josephine Brickel, died in 1987. In addition to Mrs. Tetro, he is survived by a son, Peter Jr., of Massapequa; a daughter, Peggy Tritto of San Jose, Calif.; a brother, John of Westbury, L.I.; eight grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Pressures Time Warner to Transmit a Fox Channel

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration has thrust itself into the middle of a rancorous dispute between Time Warner and Rupert Murdoch by asking for permission to carry Mr. Murdoch's new 24-hour news channel on a public-access cable channel the city controls.
Time Warner immediately rejected the request. But city officials said they were not ready to give up, raising the prospect of a showdown between City Hall and New York's dominant cable television provider, whose franchise agreement with the city is up for renewal in 1998. 
 The city's unusual request came in a letter and several phone calls this week from Fran Reiter, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Planning and Development, to the president of Time Warner, Richard D. Parsons. City officials said they were supporting Mr. Murdoch's efforts to promote his fledgling news channel because it would mean jobs for the city, but experts said the city's involvement raised a host of legal questions.
Time Warner recently refused to carry the Fox channel, which is to debut on Monday, on its 1.1-million-subscriber New York City cable system, instead backing a rival service owned by NBC, a unit of General Electric, and the Microsoft Corporation. The News Corporation has threatened to retaliate by refusing to carry some Time Warner programming services on its television networks.
After a reporter inquired yesterday about the city's request, Time Warner issued a terse reply, saying in a letter to Ms. Reiter that such an arrangement would violate both Federal law and the terms of the company's agreement with the city. "It is therefore a request we cannot and will not consider," said the letter, which was signed by Peter R. Haje, the company's general counsel.
But city officials insisted last night that their request was legitimate and said they would meet today to consider their next move. The dispute between the News Corporation and Time Warner puts the Giuliani administration in a delicate political situation since both Mr. Murdoch and Mr. Parsons have been strong supporters of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
In her letter, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, Ms. Reiter said the city felt obliged to act because the News Corporation recently agreed to maintain its United States headquarters and base its news channel in New York, which would generate 1,475 new jobs.
But she said the company had informed the city that it "could no longer guarantee the creation of these new jobs" if the Fox News Channel was not carried by Time Warner.
Several communications lawyers said yesterday that the city's request could run afoul of Federal law. The Cable Act of 1984 prohibits city governments from using public-access channels for commercial programming and also forbids municipalities from imposing any programming requirements on cable operators.
"I would tend to think this won't fly," said one prominent communications lawyer, who declined to be identified. "It looks odd to have a government channel being used for openly commercial purposes."
Ms. Reiter was on vacation in Scotland yesterday and could not reached for comment. But her chief of staff, David Klasfeld, said, "In a city as large as this, it's important there be as many major sources of news coverage as possible."
Howard Rubinstein, a spokesman for Mr. Murdoch, said Mr. Murdoch would have no comment.
Mr. Klasfeld said the city could not order Time Warner to grant its request. But the company clearly would prefer to avoid a battle with the city over the issue, especially given that its franchise agreements are up for renewal in 1998.
As part of its franchise agreement with Time Warner, New York City has access to five channels in the upper range of the television dial, which are known collectively as Crosswalks. The channels show a mix of educational programs from the City University of New York, City Hall news conferences and information about public events. There are no ads.
In her letter, Ms. Reiter proposed placing the Fox News Channel on one of those channels. The News Corporation would pay the city for access to the channel and give unspecific support to other Crosswalks channels. In return, it would be allowed to carry commercials.
The News Corporation has said that gaining cable distribution in New York City was vital to the future of the Fox News Channel. The city's other big cable operator, Cablevision, which has about 400,000 subscribers in Brooklyn and the Bronx, will carry the channel.
The two other national news services -- CNN and MSNBC -- are both distributed in New York City on Time Warner's system.
Executives at the News Corporation said the company had enlisted the city's help in persuading Time Warner to reverse its decision. These people, who declined to be identified, said the company had pointed out to city officials that CNN was based in Atlanta and MSNBC was in Secaucus, N.J. Mr. Murdoch, on the other hand, has built a large studio for the Fox News Channel on the ground floor of an office tower in midtown Manhattan.
"Rupert could very well pull this network out of Manhattan, and put it in Secaucus, where MSNBC is," one executive said
In the same week that Time Warner rebuffed Mr. Murdoch's channel, it agreed to double MSNBC's distribution. MSNBC is jointly owned by NBC and Microsoft.
That decision angered Mr. Murdoch, who had reportedly offered to pay Time Warner $110 million for access to the company's 1.1 million subscribers.
Executives at the News Corporation noted that Time Warner was about to take control of Turner Broadcasting System, which owns CNN. And they have suggested that Time Warner was trying to diminish the challenge to CNN by favoring the weaker of the two competing all-news channels.
But people at Time Warner said that the company was simply honoring a pre-existing contract with NBC to carry a predecessor channel to MSNBC, America's Talking.
Privately, they have accused Mr. Murdoch of attacking Time Warner and its chairman, Gerald M. Levin, in the pages of The New York Post, which is also owned by News Corporation.

HEADLINE: Court Halts Sandblasting on Bridges Until Studies Are Completed

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
A state court has blocked sandblasting on all New York City bridges, pending environmental studies and public hearings, in a ruling that deepens a controversy arising from lead-paint removal on the Williamsburg Bridge.
The ruling by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court expands an earlier order halting sandblasting only on the Williamsburg Bridge, and addresses again the well-known health hazards of lead-paint residue. 
 While only a few words in the latest ruling by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court differ from the court's earlier ruling, the new decree has far-reaching effects. It is likely to stop sandblasting for weeks or even months, until the city complies with the environmental-review process or tries to fight the ruling before the Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal.
It is by no means certain that the city will get permission to go to the high court, or win there if it does, because this week's Appellate Division decree and the June decision that it modified were unanimous 5-to-0 rulings, from which there is no automatic right of appeal.
Nor was it clear yesterday how many of the 838 city-owned bridges were undergoing lead-paint removal as part of their maintenance. The Department of Transportation said it did not immediately know how many bridges were involved. Matthew J. Chachere, a lawyer for people who have been battling the sandblasting for several years, said he thought 20 or more spans might be affected.
Leonard Koerner, the chief of the corporation counsel's appeals unit, said yesterday that "obviously, the city is concerned," and that the city had 30 days to decide whether to agree to the environmental-review steps or to try an appeal.
The paint at the heart of a legal, political and social controversy was applied years ago, before the health hazards of dust and chips from lead paint became widely known. Doctors and environmental experts now agree that even tiny traces of lead paint can cause permanent harm, especially in children.
When the sandblasting on the Williamsburg Bridge began in the summer of 1992, it touched off an uproar. Residents on both the Brooklyn and Manhattan sides of the span complained that paint chips were raining on their yards, sidewalks and playgrounds.
City officials maintained that the sandblasting, part of an extensive refurbishing, was as necessary on the turn-of-the-century Williamsburg Bridge as it is on other spans. But neighborhood residents heard their worries validated by health experts, and they were not appeased by precautions that included a protective tent meant to keep paint chips from flying into the air.
The Appellate Division, in June, declared that the city had paid too little heed to community feelings, and it borrowed from the wording of a lower court ruling that "by all accounts, the project was a public relations and public health fiasco."
The latest court decision, issued with little fanfare this week, closes what Mr. Chachere called "an enormous loophole" that he said the city had used to its advantage.
In its June ruling, the Appellate Division had ordered the city to either conduct environmental studies or to issue a "negative declaration": that is, an assertion that the paint-removal work had no environmental significance.
While Mr. Chachere would not say so yesterday, it seemed clear from the text of arguments before the Appellate Division in early July that he was surprised, perhaps even baffled, by the court's wording in June.
Mr. Chachere argued in July that the court's invitation to the city to issue a "negative declaration" was contrary to the overall rationale of its ruling, in which the justices agreed with a lower court finding that the city had failed to adequately study the sandblasting's possible effects on the environment.
The city actually resumed sandblasting on the Williamsburg Bridge for a short time in July, while the Appellate Division was considering a change in its original language, said Mr. Chachere, who represents the Northern Manhattan Improvement Corporation. But the appellate court said it wanted the work stopped while it reconsidered its own ruling.
The lawyer said that this week's development -- in which the appellate court removed precisely the ambiguous language the plaintiffs had complained about -- vindicated their position.
Mr. Chachere and other critics of the sandblasting were quick to criticize the city anew yesterday. Conceding that getting rid of the hazardous paint chips "is an admirable thing to do," the lawyer said that "our position has always been that we want it done safely."
Assemblyman Joseph R. Lentol, a Brooklyn Democrat who is one of the plaintiffs against the city, said, "Not only has the city reneged on its promise to protect public health, but through outright refusal to abide by the law has also caused the unemployment of more than 100 bridge painters."
Asked why the Williamsburg Bridge blasting had caused such controversy when similar work has been done on other spans, Mr. Chachere said that in the neighborhoods on both sides of the Williamsburg, "the people were vigilant enough to see what was going on."

HEADLINE: Big Retailer Is Said to Bid For Barney's

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Dickson Concepts Ltd., a retail giant based in Hong Kong, has made an initial offer to buy Barney's Inc., several people close to the situation said yesterday.
While it is unclear how much Dickson Concepts is offering for Barney's, which filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act last January, the offer is said to be between $300 million and $400 million. The Hong Kong retailer has made its intentions known to Blackstone Group, the investment bank that is advising Barney's. 
 It is also unclear whether the price includes the company's Asian license, which has often been valued at $200 million, and is considered the tastiest and most useful chunk of the retail company. Also in question is whether the offer includes buildings owned by Barney's.
Left out of the loop has been Isetan Inc., the American retailer's Japanese partner with which Barney's has been fighting since the Chapter 11 filing.
Isetan's absence from any role in the deal appears to be the latest sign of a growing gap between that company and others on the creditors committee.
When Barney's filed for bankruptcy protection, it was under pressure because of a cash crunch and a dispute with Isetan, which paid for the construction of the three flagship Barney's stores -- in Chicago, Beverly Hills and New York -- and now says it is owed millions of dollars in rent for those buildings.
Bob and Gene Pressman, who own Barney's, have long argued that Isetan's bore the building costs in exchange for an equity stake in the business, and they sued their partner when they filed for Chapter 11 protection. Dickson's original offer apparently included alternate plans, both excluding and including a future role for Isetan.
Earlier this week, the creditors committee filed papers in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, seeking to become a co-plaintiff with Barney's in its claim against Isetan. The committee agreed with Barney's that the Japanese company should be considered an equity partner -- rather than a creditor -- and therefore not entitled to rent or $177 million from building loans.
"The litigation is about recasting the leases," said Lawrence M. Handelsman, the lawyer for the creditors committee. "The committee wants to intervene and participate." Bankruptcy Judge James L. Garrity is to decide this month whether to make a summary judgment on the rent issue.
A rift between Isetan and other committee members has deepened since July, when Isetan announced, without having consulted the rest of the concerned parties, that it was working with Saks Fifth Avenue to find a way to take over Barney's. Furious that Isetan would put its interest before those of the others, the creditors committee has formed an odd alliance with the very company that owes its members millions of dollars.
The greatest manifestation of this alliance is the co-plantiff position on the rent issue, but it has also resulted in shutting Isetan out of talks, not letting Isetan know the progress of Dickson's courting efforts and occasionally sending Isetan representatives out of the room during negotiations.
"Isetan tends to make life difficult because their attitude is that if you take the position that these are not leases, then you are their mortal enemy," said a person close to the talks who insisted on anonymity. "But at the end of the day, it will all get settled because the economics require that."
Barney's executives declined to comment, and lawyers for Isetan did not return phone calls yesterday.
The motives of the creditors committee are clear enough. Should Isetan be proclaimed an equity partner rather than a wronged landlord, Isetan could suddenly find itself in the same position as Barney's; when the cash is divided, creditors get preference, and those with equity interests collect only if there is money left over after the creditors are paid.
Further, the creditors committee obviously wants the richest acquisition offer available. That is not likely to be Saks's, given that the debt-ridden retailer would like to pay for Barney's with stock. Also, Saks may not want to battle with the rest of the creditors committee, which has hired the investment bank Peter J. Solomon Company to advise it.
"It seems that the battle lines have shifted," said Lisa Stern, an analyst at M. J. Whitman, which specializes in distressed securities. "Before, it was Barney's verses the creditors committee. Now, Isetan has angered everyone by appearing to be self- dealing."
Dickson Poon, chief executive of Dickson Concepts, has been looking into Barney's for several months, and his interests appear to make sense.
Dickson Concepts owns stores in Hong Kong, as well as Harvey Nichols, a London retailer whose upscale merchandise and sensibilities are similar to those of Barney's. It also has retailing rights across Asia, with a number of high-end brands. It recently agreed to pay $23.2 million for a controlling stake in the Hong Kong and Chinese arm of Seibu Department Stores, a big Japanese retailer that competes with Isetan. Barney's would give the company a foothold in the United States, where it currently has no presence.
"It makes a lot of sense for Dickson in many ways," Ms. Stern said. "Poon is a go-go young guy who would get along with Gene Pressman. And given what is going on in Hong Kong, he likely wants to get a big investment out of there and into U.S. dollars."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEBATE;
CLINTON IN NORTH, AND DOLE IN SOUTH, STUDY FOR DEBATE

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Oct. 3

 BODY:
President Clinton and Bob Dole today headed into three days of secluded preparation for Sunday's Presidential debate, using their final campaign appearances to preview themes for the encounter: Mr. Clinton flaunted his domestic record, while Mr. Dole offered his toughest assessment yet of the President's foreign policy. 
 Mr. Dole, who has seen his campaign overshadowed by a week of Middle East fighting and peace efforts, sought to take back the spotlight in a swing through the South. Less than 24 hours after the disappointing end of the Middle East summit talks, Mr. Dole belittled the President's foreign policy record as a "string of failures dressed up for television as victories." He also suggested that Mr. Clinton had staged the summit talks with an eye to the November election.
The President moved in the opposite direction. Seeking to leave his troubled week of peacemaking behind him, he turned to domestic concerns. He was the host at a Rose Garden ceremony in which he signed into law bills to fight illegal drugs, keep track of sex offenders and provide college funds for the children of slain police officers. Then he flew to an airport rally in Buffalo, where he was greeted by shivering supporters gathered to hear him in the autumn chill. "This is a better country now," Mr. Clinton told them, rattling off statistics to support his point.
By nightfall, both candidates had settled into what will be their respective debate seminaries for the next three days. With a small army of aides and advisers, Mr. Clinton headed to the Chautauqua Institution, a 750-acre lake front vacation retreat, to study briefing books, stage practice sessions and, he hopes, play golf.
Mr. Dole flew to this South Florida resort community and went to his condominium on the 12th floor of the Seaview Hotel, where a first-floor ballroom had been set up to replicate the theater setting he will face this Sunday in Hartford.
Simultaneously, the Dole and Clinton campaigns began a new series of television advertisements, again geared to framing the debate. Mr. Dole's advertisement begins with an announcer saying, "How to speak liberal," and goes on to discuss Mr. Clinton's record of raising taxes.
Mr. Clinton's advertisement portrays the President as a social conservative as it links the former Senate majority leader to House Speaker Newt Gingrich and asserts that they were responsible for unpopular cuts in social spending.
Of the two candidates, Mr. Dole had a far more visible day on the campaign trail, intent on making up for attention lost as the President served as host for the Middle East discussions.
With the political stage finally clear, Mr. Dole offered his strongest and most encompassing critique of Mr. Clinton's foreign policy record to date. The speech was partly intended to raise doubts about Mr. Clinton's record and credibility heading into the debate. It also reflected increasing sentiment among Mr. Dole's advisers that he elevate foreign policy to the front of his campaign, even if it means taking the politically unconventional step of assailing American policy amid a crisis.
"Unfortunately, the Clinton Administration's foreign policy is, in my view, rudderless and illusory," Mr. Dole said at a luncheon at the Eastern Tennessee State University in Johnson City. "My concern today is not with the crisis of the moment -- it is not what is happening over in the Middle East -- but for the record of this Administration.
"In the last three years, you and I have seen a series of photo opportunities, treaty signing, staged handshakes and even military theatrics -- all designed to create the impression of foreign policy progress."
Mr. Dole argued that Mr. Clinton had inherited from President George Bush a powerful presence on the world stage, but had then "squandered American power."
"Let's face it: if President Bush had any strength, it was in foreign policy," Mr. Dole said. "The fact is that President Clinton inherited a strong, secure country at peace, and nearly four years later our friends no longer respect us, and our enemies no longer fear us, and no Administration in memory has so frequently deployed American forces to zones of conflict, and so casually undertaken the use of force."
Mr. Dole criticized Mr. Clinton's foreign policy effort around the globe and throughout the President's 45 months in office: from Bosnia to Northern Ireland, from North Korea to Cuba, from Somalia to Haiti. Mr. Dole was particularly harsh in his assessment of Mr. Clinton's most recent foreign policy endeavor, in Iraq, which he said has left the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, "better off today than he was a few weeks ago."
"For the first time in five years," Mr. Dole added, "Saddam is back in charge of northern Iraq."
Today's speech was keyed to Mr. Clinton's Middle East summit talks, which Mr. Dole suggested was politically motivated. "I was disappointed that President Clinton's statement did not include an unequivocal condemnation of recent violence," the former Senator said. "Frankly, it may be unclear to some what the President expected out of such a meeting, and some have suggested, I've seen, that he may have had on his mind Nov. 5," Election Day.
But Mr. Dole did not offer any suggestions on what Mr. Clinton might have done to affect the outcome. "Of course the Israelis and Palestinians will continue and must continue to negotiate, and as the summit demonstrated, the United States cannot impose a settlement," Mr. Dole said. "However, we can stand clearly in support of a peaceful resolution of differences between the Israelis and the Palestinians for a truly just peace."
Even with Mr. Dole's attempt to use the Middle East crisis as a springboard to discuss foreign policy, the attention of both campaigns was shifting to the Bushnell auditorium in Hartford this Sunday, where the debate will be held. And with these last public campaign appearances by the major party candidates -- Ross Perot, the Reform Party candidate, was excluded from the debates -- Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton used their speeches and television advertisements today to set public impressions and expectations for a debate that Mr. Dole's aides in particular view as vital.
The attack on Mr. Clinton's foreign policy was intended to reinforce Mr. Dole's position that the President is untrustworthy. Later today, in Atlanta, Mr. Dole returned to a refrain that he promised Mr. Clinton would hear this Sunday: that he is intellectually unprincipled and a political liberal.
"The American people have had too many years of double-speaking, and it's time for plain speaking, and Bob Dole is plain speaking," Mr. Dole said. "What I say, you can believe -- that's the big difference."
By contrast, Mr. Clinton, at his airport rally, offered the bouncy and happy rhetoric that has characterized his campaign stops, at least until this week's summit meeting.
"Compared to four years ago, there's a lot of good news," Mr. Clinton asserted. "Ten and a half million new jobs. Average family income is up $1,600 after inflation since we passed the economic plan that our opponents said would drive the country into the ditch."
The importance that Mr. Dole in particular attaches to Sunday's debate could be seen in where he chose to spend his day: in the South, a region where Republicans had expected by this point to be far ahead in the Presidential campaign. Polls in Georgia showed that in that state, as in much of the country, Mr. Clinton has a substantial lead over his Republican opponent.
Mr. Dole alluded to the debate several times today, telling a Hartford radio station at one point, "I haven't been this scared in a long time."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

New York City Enters Fray In Rancorous Cable Feud
New York City has thrust itself into the middle of a rancorous dispute between Time Warner and Rupert Murdoch by asking for permission to carry Mr. Murdoch's new 24-hour news channel on a public-access cable station the city controls. Time Warner immediately rejected the request, raising the prospect of a showdown between City Hall and New York's dominant cable television provider, whose franchise agreement with the city is up for renewal in 1998. City officials said they were supporting Mr. Murdoch's efforts because it would mean jobs for the city. [Page B1.]

Little Progress In G.M. Strike
Negotiations between General Motors and the Canadian Automobile Workers union showed little progress after 15,000 assembly workers began walking picket lines. Jane Armstrong, a union spokeswoman, said negotiators met twice during the day, but were accomplishing very little. "Talks are continuing, but absolutely no progress," she said. [D2.]

Markets Pause Before Jobs Data
The stock market's record-setting advance paused, pulling most indexes lower as investors waited to see if today's employment report justifies an optimistic outlook on inflation and interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average, which closed at new highs on Tuesday and Wednesday, slipped 1.12 points, to 5,932.85. [D6.]

The bond market also waited for today's employment data and few investors seemed willing to make large commitments. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.83 percent, from 6.84 percent on Wednesday. [D16.]

Factory Orders Down Sharply
New orders to factories tumbled 1.9 percent in August, the sharpest fall in three and a half years, the Commerce Department said. [D4.]
 
Kohlberg Kravis to Buy Kindercare
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. agreed to buy Kindercare Learning Centers, the nation's largest child care company, for $467 million, or $20.25 a share. Kohlberg Kravis will also assume $130 million of Kindercare debt. [D3.]
 
Kodak in Talks to Buy Wang Unit
Eastman Kodak is in negotiations to buy Wang's document imaging software business. Analysts said Kodak would pay between $300 and $400 million for the Wang unit. [D3.]

Authentic Fitness Takes Charges
Authentic Fitness, owner of the Speedo trademark in North America, said it was abandoning the skiwear business, closing its outlet stores and restating second- and third-quarter results to add $18.8 million in reserves to cover potential losses. [D3.]
 
U.S. to Rescue Pension Plan
The Government announced a rescue plan for the battered pension fund covering 70,000 unionized workers in the men's suit industry. The plan, the first of its type involving an entire industry, is supported by the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees and by the Clothing Manufacturers Association. [D6.]
 
Ratings Pressure at WCBS
The abrupt dismissal of seven anchors and reporters from WCBS-TV illuminated the intense pressure for ratings among television stations competing in the enormously lucrative local news market. [B4.]
