HEADLINE: TENSION IN THE MIDDLE EAST: THE PALESTINIANS;
A Shadow Over the Mideast: Arab Youths on a Short Fuse

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: AL AROUB, West Bank, Oct. 3

 BODY:
A group of teen-agers wearing old jeans and dirty sneakers clambered up to the rooftops early this morning to let the Israeli soldiers below know what they thought of the summit meeting that ended the night before in Washington.
Bottles filled with gasoline and topped with burning rags flew in graceful arcs toward the lonely ribbon of asphalt in this community, officially designated a refugee camp by the United Nations, in a zone still patrolled by Israelis. As the gasoline bombs rained down, a half-dozen Israeli paratroopers wearing helmets, hugging either side of the street, pointed their M-16 assault rifles, equipped with bulbous grenade launchers under the barrels, toward their attackers. 
 The young Palestinians, experienced street fighters, ducked, crouched and scampered to avoid detection until the troops let loose with a warning volley. The Palestinian youths melted away; no one was wounded and the confrontation ended as suddenly as it had begun.
Frightened families slammed their shutters tight. Children let out wails of fear. And the troops pulled back behind some trees, anxiously scanning the maze of concrete hovels for any movement. There was none. The refugee camp fell still and silent.
The mini-battle, recounted in detail by Israeli troops and camp residents minutes after it ended, could have been lifted from the six-year-long Palestinian uprising known as the intifada that started in late 1987. But, deep below the surface, the differences were profound and bode ill for any future conflict that might erupt if the faltering peace process sputters out.
The young men who carried out this assault have little schooling, no jobs, no hopes of getting any jobs and a future so bleak that confrontation has become a vocation. It would be easy to say they have become Islamic radicals; they all say they are believers. But in fact they seem to have little ideology, saying that they will back anyone, whether it is Yasir Arafat's 30,000-strong Palestinian police force, or the militant Islamic group Hamas, willing to kill Jews.
"The moment the Palestinian police opened fire on the Jewish troops last week they became our brothers," said Jamal Abu Mohammed, a teen-ager, as he stood at the edge of the camp. "Before that they had been Israeli rent-a-cops in Arab uniforms. But now they have proved that they are with us. We are all one now. We will together drive the Jewish occupiers from our land."
Al Aroub refugee camp, about seven miles outside of Hebron, is a squalid warren surrounded by a chain-link fence patrolled by Israeli paratroopers in red berets, several of whom said they did not particularly like their job. There are no trees, gardens, patches of grass or even flower boxes to offset the hard, dusty rocks and gray concrete blocks that make up the walls of houses that see six or eight people packed to a room. The camp, like the city of Hebron, remains under round-the-clock curfew, and the confrontation this morning ended any hopes of the 5,000 people trapped inside that they would get an hour to go buy food.
The six-year uprising of the late 1980's and 1990's, which finally drove the Israelis to negotiate a peace accord with Mr. Arafat, was carried out by young men whose parents had often proved docile and compliant under Israeli occupation. Many took to the streets in 1988 because they saw their parents, who had lost their homes and their businesses, humiliated day after day by the Israelis.
Those that began that uprising are now in their 20's. Some have joined the Palestinian police, others have started families and work at menial jobs. They can still recall, from before the previous uprising anyway, lives with stable homes, traditional ties, enough income to survive and the driving ambition that once made the Palestinians the best-educated Arabs in the Middle East.
All that has changed, especially with the loss of the hundreds of millions of dollars in remittances that once poured into the West Bank and Gaza from Palestinians who worked in the Persian Gulf before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
Now, a generation is growing up knowing curfews, shootings, closed borders with Israel and grinding poverty. Many had older brothers who were crippled or killed by Israeli gunfire and fathers who lost their jobs. Few spent much time in school.
"The old uprising was carried out to establish our own state," said Abu Ahmed. "But if the violence begins again, it will lead to a war where our goal will be to exterminate the Jews."
A year after self-rule was extended to parts of the West Bank and Gaza, nearly all Palestinians find themselves banned from Israeli territory, an edict that took force after a series of suicide bombings in Israel in February and March. The economy has ground to a halt. Palestinian cities lie ringed by Israeli tanks and armored vehicles, severing ties between 450 towns and communities. And Israeli troops have blocked off dozens of roads leading into Israel with concrete barricades.
Interviews here suggest that if Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel refuses to push ahead with the Oslo peace accords, he will face a different foe than the one Israel grew accustomed to in the past, one far readier to die.
Most Palestinians interviewed today said Mr. Netanyahu had one last chance to salvage the peace process when talks begin at the edge of the Gaza Strip on Sunday. If that fails, they said, there will be no holding back the volcanic rumblings of hatred and frustration that fuel many young and desperate Palestinians.
"There is a terrible fury brewing here," said Hama Abu Ghoush, 32. "It frightens even me. We are hanging by a thread. If the talks on Sunday fail, if we are convinced that the peace process is dead, then it will kill all our hope for a better life. Many people, already depressed, are too tired to fight. But there is a whole generation with nothing more to lose. They want only vengeance and blood. All they are waiting for is the signal to start."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: Campaign Trail;
THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

 BODY:

What Campaign?
More evidence that ignorance is bliss: with the general-election Presidential campaign now six weeks old, a new study indicates that citizens in nearly a third of the 50 states have yet to sit through a Bob Dole or Bill Clinton stump speech or zap their way through a Presidential attack commercial.
Indeed, for most campaign purposes save the final counting of electoral votes, the states might as well be in Paraguay. 
 The Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania, which tracks such matters, reports this week that the two campaigns effectively ignored 17 central and Southern states during September, neither sending their top candidate nor buying significant television advertisement there.
An independent check of the campaigns' activities since the August conventions draws a similar conclusion: in 15 states, neither campaign has scheduled a Presidential candidate's appearance nor bought much, if any, television time. The 15 include not just the expected states, like rock-ribbed Republican Alaska and solidly Democratic Hawaii, but those nominally up for grabs, like Oklahoma, Alabama and Indiana.
The explanation? "The general election in a Presidential campaign is run on the same principles as a battle in World War I: each side just rams at each other," Bill Knapp, a principal in the Clinton campaign's advertising team, said in an interview. "They're going to spend the bulk of their resources in a dozen states, and thus you're going to spend the bulk of your resources in a dozen states to blunt them." Nor will either campaign spend much time in states it has either locked up or conceded to the opposition.
That leaves a handful of mostly Southern states that both campaigns might claim in November but seem to have put aside for now. Mr. Dole holds a narrow lead in most of them and has more pressing uses for his money. The Clinton campaign, sitting on a hoard of electoral votes, has the luxury of addressing them later.
So to Idaho, North Dakota, Minnesota and most of the other 12 American Paraguays, hasta la vista until November, baby.
On the other hand, says John Buckley, the Dole campaign's communications director, "if you're a voter living in, say, Canton, Ohio, you're going to think you're being stalked by these two candidates."

Archeopolitics
The folks who run the White House political machine have long dismissed Whitewater as ancient history. Maybe they're right; the latest evidence from the campaign trail suggests that they have a doctoral degree in the field.
When Bob Dole trooped into Lancaster County, Pa., this week to speak at tiny Elizabethtown College, Mr. Clinton's opposition-research squad was already on the ground and firing live bullets. In telephone calls and press releases, both the Pennsylvania Democratic Party and the Clinton campaign charged that Mr. Dole had once voted against giving the school $387,750 to build classrooms and expand a library.
"Only in Bob Dole's world can he travel to Elizabethtown College -- the place where he voted against aid for its buildings -- and pose as a friend of students," the Clinton press release said.
Pennsylvania Democrats heaped scorn on Mr. Dole, quoting one of the school's students, Jennifer Shockley, in its release as saying, "Maybe Bob Dole thinks that because he voted against our school before we were born we wouldn't notice."
On closer inspection, it is doubtful that even Mr. Dole noticed. Mr. Dole cast his 'nay' vote almost 33 years ago, Nov. 6, 1963, on the Higher Education Facilities Act, an omnibus-consolidated-grab-bag-public-works bill loaded with what some critics might today call political pork.
Elizabethtown College's $387,750 was part of a $14 million allotment to the Keystone State. That, in turn, was but a sliver of the $1.2 billion that the bill allotted for various higher-education projects.
Bob Dole was a second-term Congressman in 1963, at the start of his political career. And Bill Clinton was in the Rose Garden that same year, shaking John F. Kennedy's hand.

Economists for Clinton
 Harry S. Truman used to joke that he wanted a one-armed economist, so he would never have to hear the word "on the other hand" from an economic adviser again.
Some jokes are timeless.
Bob Dole claimed the support of 100 prominent economists, including Nobel laureates, when he unwrapped his plan to slash income and investment taxes and Federal spending. Now The Economist, the British news magazine, has produced a survey indicating that a lot of other prominent economists do not agree.
The magazine polled 60 "randomly chosen" macroeconomists at major American universities last month, and most of the 41 who replied said they favored President Clinton's economic themes. Mr. Clinton's proposed tax cuts were endorsed by 46 percent of the economists, versus 22 percent for Mr. Dole ("neither" took second place with 32 percent). By a resounding 83 percent to 17 percent, the academics said they did not believe Mr. Dole's plan would produce a balanced budget without cutting Medicare and military spending.
Seventy-eight percent doubted Mr. Dole's assertion that he could pay for a fourth of his plan's tax cuts through swifter economic growth. And a mere 12 percent believed cutting income-tax rates and spending would give the economy a major boost. One Dole issue -- shifting from an income tax to a consumption tax -- did gain their favor, by 63 to 37 percent.
All told, the economists agreed 71 to 29 percent that a second Clinton term would benefit the economy more than a Dole Presidency. But there were strings attached: more than half said the best economic policies would emerge from a Democratic White House offset by a Congress at least partly in Republican hands.

Sound Bite
"You have to envy the astronaut Shannon Lucid. She missed six months of negative Democratic commercials." -- Bob Dole, who didn't, speaking earlier this week. MICHAEL WINES

HEADLINE: Daniel Ortega's Second Act

 BODY:
Few politicians seem less suited for a political comeback than Daniel Ortega. The dour leader of Nicaragua's Sandinista Front in the revolutionary 1980's, Mr. Ortega seemed allergic to charisma. His political judgment led him into such misadventures as visiting Moscow just before a Congressional vote on American aid to the contra rebels fighting his Government. The Reagan Administration's war on Nicaragua, compounded by Sandinista economic ineptitude, brought the country an inflation rate of 30,000 percent. Before he turned over the presidency to Violeta Chamorro in 1990, Mr. Ortega and other Sandinista leaders indulged in an ugly grab of property and houses. Yet despite all, he has pulled even with the front-runner in the current presidential race. Voting is later this month.
The leading candidates represent two extremes, and either winner would be destabilizing after Mrs. Chamorro's politics of reconciliation. No matter who wins, the election is proof that Nicaragua has come far. Mr. Ortega scheduled the country's first real elections, in 1990, when polls indicated he would win. When he lost, he surprised many by leaving office without a fight. Today few doubt that the elections will be free and the results respected. 
 Mr. Ortega's rival is Arnoldo Aleman, a conservative who boasts he is the favorite of the United States. As Mayor of Managua he received American aid for paving roads and other projects, and gained a reputation as a doer. He has authoritarian tendencies, and many poor people do not like the rich oligarchs who make up his circle of friends. His support has stalled at 40 percent.
Mr. Ortega has taken a sharp and not very credible turn to the center for this campaign. His vice-presidential candidate is a rancher whose land was expropriated by the Sandinistas. He has pledged support for a market economy. The Sandinista hymn, which contained the line "We fight the Yankee, enemy of humanity," has been dropped in favor of Beethoven's "Ode to Joy."
Most of his supporters are not nostalgic for the Sandinista years, merely desperate for change. The slums around Managua grow larger and bleaker daily. Crime is soaring. Former combatants still fight in parts of the countryside. The overwhelming problem is the economy. Mrs. Chamorro's Government conquered inflation, but its austerity program has led to extremely high unemployment.
Many Aleman backers hope that a victory by him will inspire investment back home by wealthy expatriate Nicaraguans in Miami. Many supporters of Mr. Ortega are hoping that he will put them in new government jobs if he wins. This hope of patronage on both sides reflects a widespread cynicism inspired by the frustrating divisions in Nicaraguan politics. There are 26 parties competing in the election, and the ballot is more than a yard long.
The ultimate rich outsider, of course, is the United States. This is Mr. Aleman's strong suit. Mr. Ortega says he wants good relations, but he will probably get no aid if Jesse Helms, who has blocked aid even to Mrs. Chamorro's Government, remains in the Senate. Regardless of who wins, Nicaraguans will continue to depend on remittances from relatives working in America. The Sandinistas told the Yankees to go home. Today, many Nicaraguans would add, "and take me with you."

HEADLINE: Protecting Farm Workers

 BODY:
A surprising aspect of American labor's new vigor is the resurgence of the United Farm Workers. After a two-decade slide from its heyday in the 1970's, a union made up of hard-to-organize transients -- many of them illegal immigrants -- grew at the fastest rate of any union last year. But the U.F.W. still claims only 26,000 members out of roughly 1.6 million farm workers. For those not in the union, conditions are as appalling as ever.
Until the minimum-wage increase this week, wages for workers harvesting some crops were at their lowest point in terms of purchasing power in decades. In direct violation of Federal and state laws, many workers do not have access to water or toilets in the field and are not paid benefits such as unemployment. Although they are supposed to make the minimum wage, farm workers' lawyers have documented numerous cases in which workers are paid only $2 or $3 an hour. 
 In the 1930's, farm workers, then largely black, were left out of the New Deal because President Roosevelt needed support from Southern senators. Only in 1963 did they get a minimum wage or Social Security, or coverage by health and safety laws.
Today farm work differs from most other labor in two important ways. Competition for jobs is fiercer. America already has too many farm workers, and with Mexico's economic crisis the flow of illegal immigrants rose, creating more competition for agricultural jobs. Most farm workers are Latino or Caribbean immigrants, many of whom are naturalized. About a third are illegal immigrants.
Farm workers' second big handicap is that belatedly won legal protections are often not enforced. Illegal immigrants seldom complain when mistreated. Only in California does the law permit farm workers to form unions. The few Legal Services lawyers who do farm workers' cases took a 33 percent budget cut last year.
One practice that allows many growers to get around the laws is the increasing use of labor contractors. Growers pay a crew leader a lump sum to hire workers at harvest time. They can then say that the crew leader is responsible for providing field water, toilets and all the payroll details.
The crew leader, however, is often merely a former farm worker who bought an old truck. He does not have the money or know-how to supply sanitation or handle Social Security. Often the grower does not pay the crew leader enough to give the workers minimum wage. Yet when farm workers have sued for wages owed them, the growers have successfully responded that they are not the employers, and pointed to the crew leader. Fortunately, a Federal court in Atlanta decided a case this July that may make it harder for growers to use this diversionary claim to escape payment.
Such abuse could be deterred by better law enforcement. The Labor Department's Wage and Hour Division has only three farm labor inspectors in Florida, and they also have to enforce dozens of other laws. In California, it would take the state's wage and health inspectors 150 years at current rates to visit every farm just once.
Farm workers should be able to unionize, consult effective lawyers and enjoy regular visits from a larger staff of inspectors. The only reason they were denied the legal protections other workers got in the 1930's is that they lacked clout. Today their powerlessness keeps the laws from being enforced.

HEADLINE: Sales by Ford Aid a Strong September for Auto Makers

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 3

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company reported today that sales of its cars and light trucks rose 7.3 percent in September, contributing to a stronger-than-expected gain for the auto industry last month.
Auto makers' sales in the United States over all rose 5.9 percent, bolstered in part by offers of cash-back discounts and subsidized leasing deals. 
 Sales of sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks led the way, rising 12.5 percent in September, compared with the comparable period a year ago. Car sales edged up 1.6 percent, helped by the discounts offered to customers.
Auto executives were optimistic about their prospects. "Inflation appears to be in check, consumer confidence is high, the economy continues to grow moderately and interest rates have stayed in a range that historically has supported good sales levels," said Bob Rewey, group vice president of marketing and sales at Ford. "All in all, the outlook for the new model year is a healthy one."
Still, some analysts said today that the strong sales this month signaled that sales would decline later this year. "We are starting to run on borrowed time," said Jack V. Kirnan, an auto analyst with Salomon Brothers. Sales have been strong so far this year, but the fact that auto makers must increasingly woo customers with discounts suggests that the market, left to its own devices, would be slowing.
"A lot of the pent-up demand has been exhausted," Mr. Kirnan said.
A slowdown would be consistent with other signs this week that the economy as a whole is growing moderately. On Tuesday, a September survey of corporate purchasing managers' spending plans showed declines from August levels. The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators was nearly flat in August, rising two-tenths of 1 percent. And there were modest declines in retail sales.
Today, Ford, the last of the Big Three auto makers to report results for September, said that its sales rose 7.3 percent in the month, compared with a year ago. Sales of Ford pickup trucks, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles rose 7 percent, while its car sales rose 7.7 percent in September. Percentage calculations are based on a daily selling rate because there were 24 selling days last month but 25 in September 1995.
Ford also won bragging rights to the nation's best-selling car for the model year, which ended Sept. 30, for its redesigned Taurus. Ford sold 378,144 of the 1996 model Taurus, while the Honda Motor Company sold 367,137 1996-model Accords and the Toyota Motor Corporation sold 354,035 Camrys.
For the 1996 calendar year the Ford Taurus is also ahead of the Accord and Camry. The Taurus has now held the title four consecutive years, both for model and calendar years.
 Ford's brand-new sport-utility vehicle, the Expedition, got off to a strong start in its first full month of sales. Ford sold more than 8,200 of the giant trucks, a company executive said.
Ford stock fell 50 cents a share, to $31.25, on the New York Stock Exchange today.
 Other auto makers said today that their sales increased. Honda said its sales rose 1 percent, while Toyota said its sales jumped 14.2 percent. Others reported results earlier this week.
The nation's largest auto maker, the General Motors Corporation, said Tuesday that its sales fell 2.1 percent while the Chrysler Corporation said its sales rose 21.9 percent from the corresponding period a year ago.
In September, auto makers sold cars and light trucks at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 15 million. That is down from August's rate of 15.73 million, but up from July's rate of 14.21 million. So far this year, the industry has run at a clip of 15.1 million annual sales, about the rate that the Big Three predicted early this year.
That suggested slowing to some economists. "I think there is a little bit of softening in the market," said Thomas C. Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association.
Such a slowing could be good news for those in the market for a new car or truck. Analysts agreed with Mr. Webb that auto makers would likely need to rely on cash rebates and discount leasing deals if they want strong sales to continue. "It is going to be a buyer's market," Mr. Webb said.
Indeed, Ford announced on Wednesday rebates and discount leases on a number of 1996 and 1997 models, including the Taurus, Aspire, Probe, Mustang, Contour, Thunderbird, Ranger and Windstar, along with Mercury's Tracer, Sable, Cougar, Grand Marquis and Villager. Most discounts are scheduled to last the rest of the year.
Auto dealers said their customers were responding to earlier rebates, and that the fresh rebates would likely prove popular.

HEADLINE: Senate Approves Bill to Preserve Parks, Including Sterling Forest

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
The Senate approved a broad package of legislation on parks and public lands today, including financing to preserve the Sterling Forest on the New York-New Jersey border, after the White House promised to let an Alaskan company continue to cut timber in the Tongass National Forest for a few more years.
The legislation, the Senate's last major act before it adjourned for the election, passed the Senate on a voice vote after Senator Frank Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, dropped his objection in return for the White House pledge involving logging in his state. 
 The bill provides financing for a grab bag of parks, memorials and public land deals nationwide, including the Presidio in San Francisco, a tallgrass prairie preserve in Kansas, a ski development in Utah for the Olympics in 2002 and scores of other projects that were avidly sought by lawmakers of both parties from all over the country.
Among the biggest of these, if not in acreage or dollars then in the political weight of the local delegation that pressed all year for its approval, was the public acquisition of the Sterling Forest, a 20,000-acre tract about 40 miles northwest of Manhattan. The bill authorizes $17.5 million to help buy the land from a private owner who otherwise might have developed it.
For months, it had seemed that provisions like these, which few opposed, would become victims of their own popularity, dragged down as the bill was loaded with other provisions that were far more controversial. Last week the White House said it would veto the bill unless several provisions, including a 15-year extension of logging in the Tongass, were dropped.
The House complied, stripping the bill of those provisions and then overwhelmingly passing it on Saturday. Now that the Senate has passed the bill, the President is certain to sign it.
"Though not perfect," Mr. Clinton said in a statement, "this bill represents a great victory for the American people and proves what we can accomplish if we work together."
Before the bill passed, in negotiations that dragged out all week, the White House had to satisfy a final demand from Mr. Murkowski, who had taken advantage of the Senate's deadlines and rules to block the bill single-handedly. It did so by negotiating a separate deal, outside the legislation, governing logging by Ketchikan Pulp Company.
The company, a subsidiary of Louisiana Pacific Corporation, was given special access to timber in the 1950's in exchange for building a pulp mill to create jobs in the region. The company has said it plans to close down the mill, which the Clinton Administration has asserted would breach its contract and end its guaranteed supply of timber.
Under the new deal, the White House has now agreed to negotiate terms under which the company could continue to log for two more years after closing the mill, sending the wood to sawmills that employ fewer people but make more profit.
The two-year continuation will probably allow logging of hundreds of millions of board-feet of timber (it takes about 15,000 board-feet to fill a lumber truck).
The deal between Mr. Murkowski and the Administration was in jeopardy until the very end as the two sides haggled over the wording of the Administration's promise, made in a letter to the Senator from White House chief of staff, Leon E. Panetta.
The letter emphasized that the Administration was not willing to revise the forest regulations for the Tongass or in any other way exempt the logging by Ketchikan Pulp Company from environmental controls.
Mr. Murkowski said he was disappointed by the deal, even though the two-year extension would save a few hundred jobs, at least for the time being. "For my state, and my constituents, and those who will face unemployment, they will have some hope -- not as much as I would have wished -- but some," he said.
Environmental groups who wanted logging stopped altogether said that the agreement gave Mr. Murkowski and his timber ally time to seek further changes later, but that it gave the Administration an opportunity to bring decades of logging to a close relatively soon.
"This is a great opportunity for the Administration to pursue its laudable goal of canceling the K.P.C. contract and bringing a balanced management to the Tongass National Forest," said Charles Clusen of the Natural Resources Defense Council, a leading environmental group.
Still, it was clear that Mr. Murkowski had lost more than he had gained. Several other provisions involving Alaska were also dropped from the bill, although others remained.
For the New York metropolitan region, the most significant part of the package was legislation to authorize Federal spending of $17.5 million to acquire the Sterling Forest along the border of the two states.
The forest is the last large, undeveloped tract of woodland in the area and the source of drinking water for millions of residents of northern New Jersey.
For a decade, environmentalists, residents, politicians and developers have disagreed over what to do with the Sterling Forest site.
The current owners, the Zurich Insurance Group of Switzerland, agreed in June to sell the land to the Trust for Public Land and the Open Space Institute, provided a $55 million deal could be worked out by the spring of 1988. Otherwise, the company planned to develop a community of 13,000 homes, commercial and industrial buildings and golf courses.
New York and New Jersey both pledged major contributions to the effort to acquire the land, and now nothing appears to stand in the way.
"We hit the last-second shot for Sterling Forest," said Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, using a basketball allusion from his previous career but plainly thinking of his last day in the Senate.
The White House did not win on every one of its objections to the parks bill, which retained one provision it opposed that would ease restrictions against development on some Florida barrier islands' beaches and coastal areas and allow those areas to get Federal flood insurance.

HEADLINE: Scores of House Candidates Dancing the Texas Shuffle

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Texas has had plenty of raucous free-for-alls in its electoral history, perhaps most famously in 1961, when 71 candidates jumped into a special election to fill the United States Senate seat vacated by Lyndon B. Johnson, who had become Vice President. Amid the ensuing fratricide among Democrats, John G. Tower became the state's first Republican Senator since Reconstruction.
But for sheer political chaos, it would be hard to match this year's races for the House of Representatives, with contests in 13 of the state's 30 Congressional districts thrown into turmoil by a fracas over redistricting. 
 A sweeping court-ordered change in this fall's electoral process in all 13 of those districts coincides with Republicans' hopes to achieve a historic shift in control of the Texas Congressional delegation, which now has 18 Democrats and 12 Republicans. But whether it will help them to do so remains unclear.
The commotion began when the United States Supreme Court ruled in June in favor of Republican plaintiffs who argued that in drawing the state's Congressional districts after the last census, the Democratic-controlled Legislature unconstitutionally gerrymandered three of them on racial lines. A Federal appeals court in Texas then redrew those three districts and 10 adjacent ones.
Beyond that, the appellate judges, in a ruling recently upheld by the Supreme Court, threw out the primary results in the 13 affected districts, all in the Houston and Dallas areas, and decreed that there would be open elections there on Nov. 5, any candidate free to enter them. Some of those races are now jammed with candidates -- 11 in one Houston district alone -- and the winners may not be clear until December runoffs, required in any districts where no one captures more than 50 percent of the vote on Election Day.
The judges' approach was in distinct contrast to that of courts elsewhere, which, in ruling on other states where the Supreme Court had found unconstitutional districts, including both Carolinas, chose to minimize disruption by allowing this year's elections to proceed along existing district lines.
The most immediate result here has been confusion, although of a kind in which many political consultants take delight and from which some may prosper. If the national battle for control of Congress is tight, it is now possible that it will be resolved not on Nov. 5 but instead a month later, with the runoffs in Texas.
Because of the appellate judges' ruling, some Congressional candidates defeated in primaries earlier this year have suddenly risen from the political dead. And some who looked like shoo-ins, including at least two Democratic incumbents, Ken Bentsen in Houston and Eddie Bernice Johnson in Dallas, could find themselves fighting for their political lives.
In east Texas, Representative Steve Stockman, widely seen as one of the most vulnerable freshman Republicans in Congress, seems to have been given a lift by the ruling, even though the judges made only the smallest of changes in his district's configuration. If Mr. Stockman winds up in a runoff, he may be able, by energizing his conservative base of loyalists, to do much better in it than he would have done in a one-on-one matchup against his prime Democratic opponent, Nick Lampson, on Election Day, when the turnout is typically larger than for a special election.
Behind all these individual battles is the fight for control of the Texas delegation, which has proved to be "the toughest Southern nut for the Republicans to crack," said Richard Murray, a political scientist at the University of Houston. To become the delegation's majority for the first time in this century, the Republicans need a net gain of four seats.
But although it was once widely agreed that Republicans as a whole would be the beneficiaries of the judges' ruling -- indeed, it was a coalition of Democratic incumbents who went to the Supreme Court in the unsuccessful effort to overturn it -- -- it is now not at all clear that they will be able to make major gains.
"There was an expectation of dramatic change," said Bill Miller, an Austin political consultant who has worked with candidates of both parties. "You felt like these judges, Republican appointees, were really going to change the map and the Democrats could kiss it goodbye. All that was at play."
But the redrawing that the judges actually did proved far less dramatic, Mr. Miller and several other analysts say, and, among a number of those seeking re-election, may be offset by the strengths of incumbency.
Moreover, even as they have a strong shot at capturing the Fort Worth seat being vacated by Representative Pete Geren, a conservative Democrat, the Republicans are in danger of losing a district of their own that curves along the state's central Gulf Coast.
That seat became theirs only after the incumbent, Greg Laughlin, made a highly publicized bolt from the Democratic Party after the 1994 elections. Mr. Laughlin lost his new party's primary this spring (the district is not affected by the redistricting ruling, and so that result stands), and the Republican nominee, Ron Paul, a former Congressman and Libertarian Party Presidential candidate, is facing a strong Democratic challenge from Charles Morris, an Austin lawyer.
And other Republican opportunities outside of the redistricting fray may not materialize: while two longtime Democratic Congressmen are retiring in east Texas, long thought to be ripe conservative ground, neither of the Republican candidates for those open seats is currently considered a favorite.
Of the 13 seats affected by the judges' redistricting ruling, 7 are now held by Republicans, 6 by Democrats. Six of the districts are in or near Dallas (the 3d, 5th, 6th, 24th, 26th and 30th), 7 in the Houston area (the 7th, 8th, 9th, 18th, 22d, 25th and 29th).
Of all the deck shuffling, the change that has probably drawn the most attention is in the 25th District, represented by Mr. Bentsen, a nephew of former Senator Lloyd Bentsen. The redrawing took many of Mr. Bentsen's reliably Democratic areas out of the 25th and gave him in return conservative-leaning suburban areas in west Houston.
As a result, the district could go Republican, especially if Mr. Bentsen faces a moderate Republican challenger in the runoff. But it is unclear who will prevail in what has effectively become a primary-within-an-election to establish a Republican candidate among no fewer than eight running in the new district. A second-place candidate could make the runoff with as little as 15 to 20 percent of the vote.
Several of those candidates have taken an anti-abortion stand, and one could emerge with strong support from the religious right. On the other end of the spectrum, Dolly Madison McKenna, a businesswoman and former Republican nominee in the old district, who supports abortion rights, said, "A centrist, economically conservative and socially moderate, is the perfect candidate for this new district."
Mr. Bentsen, despite disagreeing vehemently with the redistricting ruling, points out that 75 percent of the district remains the same, with new constituents having the same values as the old. "Fiscally conservative, socially more moderate," he said. "I think I fit that pretty well."
In other races, Ms. Johnson, the black Dallas Congresswoman whose district, the 30th, was one of the three found to have been unconstitutionally gerrymandered, is facing two other Democrats, two Republicans and three independents, including a former member of her staff. She ran virtually unopposed in her two previous campaigns but may now be vulnerable, although her district still has a heavy Democratic leaning.
In Houston, another black Congresswoman, Sheila Jackson Lee, also saw her district, the 18th, challenged and redrawn, but she remains heavily favored to win.
The third challenged district was Houston's 29th, initially drawn by the Legislature with an eye toward electing a Hispanic candidate. There, the non-Hispanic incumbent, Gene Green, a Democrat, may not find his political fortunes hurt at all by the redrawing. The district is now about 45 percent Hispanic, down from about 61 percent before, and still leans strongly Democratic.
Several other incumbents have been inconvenienced, but not exactly threatened, by the redistricting order.
For example, Representative Bill Archer of Houston, the Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, was unopposed before the judges acted and now has a challenge from two independents and a Democrat. But he is still considered the heavy favorite.

(F. Carter Smith for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Top Post at Rock-Bottom Wage;
Chief Executive Puts Stock-Only Pay to Ultimate Test

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Jerre L. Stead has every reason to wince when he sees headlines about the mega-dollar salaries paid to chief executives. He is, after all, a chief executive himself.
But when he signed on in August to take the top post at Ingram Micro Inc., a computer distributor, he positioned himself at the opposite end of the salary spectrum. He took a cash salary of exactly zero -- goose eggs. 
 In what may be the most daring pay package in corporate America, Mr. Stead will get nothing but stock options. His deal allows him to purchase 3.6 million shares of Ingram Micro's stock: 400,000 now, 1.6 million in four installments beginning in April 1998 and the rest on a schedule tied to goals for the stock price and company earnings. He could, in theory, own 2.8 percent of the Santa Ana, Calif., company in five years.
For years, shareholders and analysts have been preaching that corporate chieftains ought to put more of their pay at risk. Why should managers be rewarded so handsomely, they ask, if their performance is not up to par? The surest route to aligning the interests of chief executives with those of shareholders is to pay them heavily in stock options, pay experts say.
Although there are a few precedents -- most notably when Lee A. Iacocca joined the Chrysler Corporation and briefly took a pay package of $1 in cash and the rest in stock -- Mr. Stead will be the ultimate test.
"It's obviously very gutsy," said Graef Crystal, a San Diego-based critic of corporate pay practices whose annual lists of overpaid executives are a thorn in the side of the business elite. Under Mr. Stead's deal, "he makes zero unless the stock rises," Mr. Crystal said, adding, "If the C.E.O.'s of America would follow suit, I'd be back playing the piano."
Mr. Stead, 53, may well end up very rich, of course. But even now, his package, which was his idea, has one highly desirable byproduct. Ingram Micro, a $10 billion-plus division of the privately held Ingram Industries, is to go public this month, at an expected $14 to $16 a share.
"There's no question," said Robert Salwen, a compensation consultant in White Plains, that the pay package "will help the initial public offering."
"The first question Wall Street asks in I.P.O.'s is: 'What stake does management have?' " he said.
Even on this score, Mr. Stead's attention-grabbing deal stands out. Many companies going public pay managers little cash, loading them up instead with options that can often be exercised below the initial price. But "we like his package especially because his options are at the I.P.O. price," said Kathleen S. Smith, a principal at the Renaissance Capital Corporation, a new-issue research firm in Greenwich, Conn.
Still, Mr. Stead's rewards could be stunning. He and other Ingram managers would not comment because of regulatory restrictions on impending offerings. But John T. Thompson, vice chairman of Heidrick & Struggles, the recruiting firm that brought Mr. Stead and Ingram Micro together, pointed out that "if Jerre can triple the stock price in five years, he'll make over $100 million."
Mr. Stead's package is particularly striking when compared with some other recent deals. In August, for example, when Alex J. Mandl left the No. 2 post at AT&T to run Associated Communications, a tiny wireless telephone company with no revenues, he got a $1 million salary, a $20 million signing bonus, plus an 18 percent equity stake that may be worth more than $100 million if the company goes public.
Associated paid so much, analysts say, because Mr. Mandl brings both proven executive skills and credibility with investors, which will be crucial if the company goes public. But Matt Ward, a compensation expert at the Hay Group, a management consulting firm, called the deal "the ultimate no-risk package."
With some executives acting like free-agent athletes, "whether deals like Stead's will become more widespread is a tough question," said Donald B. York, managing director of Radford Associates, a Silicon Valley consultant. Everyone has daily expenses, so executives without big financial reserves will need paychecks.
Mr. Stead can gamble because he is worth about $20 million, including a nest egg from his most recent job, as chief executive of the Legent Corporation, a software company. There, his annual salary was $750,000 and he had options on 700,000 shares. When his tenure abruptly ended after six months last year, when Computer Associates International bought Legent, Mr. Stead cashed in his options for nearly $15 million.
Equally important, the future of deals like Mr. Stead's "depends on the risk profile of the individual," Mr. York said. "Are they a risk-taker or not" in their finances?
Risk-takers give up a lot of cash. William M. Mercer Inc., a consultant that has surveyed the 1996 pay packages of chief executives at 425 large companies, found that the average base salary was $450,000, while the average total pay, including bonus and options, was $609,300. Ingram Micro was willing to pay a new chief executive $1.5 million a year in salary and bonus, Mr. Thompson said.
Yet Mr. Thompson, for one, says Mr. Stead is blazing a trail. "The really savvy executives are looking for an opportunity to swing for the fences," he said. He sees it as a good sign when "an executive is open to this kind of package." Mr. Thompson is even now searching for a chief executive at one company, and "the two leading candidates are willing to take a no-cash deal."
So far, these newfangled deals generally occur at high-technology or entertainment companies, where the potential for growth, and big payoffs, is huge. But some pay experts say Mr. Stead's example might influence compensation elsewhere, too, simply because shareholders are agitating for changes in pay practices. Partly as a result, stock options and other pay-for-performance devices are spreading rapidly.
In 1995, the average stock option award to the chief executives of Fortune 500 companies jumped more than 35 percent, compared with 1993, while the average salary climbed 15 percent, said Judith Fisher, publisher of Executive Compensation Reports, a newsletter basedin Fairfax Station, Va. At the nation's largest 200 companies, she said, salary accounted for just 19 percent of the chief executive's total pay in 1994, down from 24 percent in 1992. The portion derived from options jumped to 44 percent from 37 percent.
In the last 10 years, use of options as compensation has jumped.
 Deals like Mr. Stead's might become more common if the evidence that they work grows convincing. But past results are mixed. Fifteen years ago, Mr. Iacocca did indeed revive Chrysler. But his token cash salary lasted just a year, too short to draw any conclusions.
More recently, since 1993 Nelson Peltz, chief executive of the Triarc Companies, has been taking $1 in salary. But his stock options from just 1994 and 1995 have a present value of more than $30 million, Mr. Crystal said.
Still, in a sense, Mr. Peltz has so far been working for nothing. Triarc, a diversified company with interests in food, chemicals and energy, has been outperformed by 93 percent of the 750 conglomerates that Mr. Crystal tracks. Its stock, now around $12, has not traded above Mr. Peltz's exercise prices, which range from $27.125 to $45. Nonetheless, said Brian L. Schorr, Triarc's general counsel, "we've not had any discussion about changing anything."
The best comparison with Mr. Stead may be Dennis R. Hendrix, who as chief executive of the Panenergy Corporation, a Houston natural gas company, from November 1990 through April 1995 took no salary or cash bonus. He was paid entirely in restricted stock: two grants of 300,000 shares each in 1990 and 1993, with the restrictions on selling being lifted on 25,000 shares each quarter. The stock, which traded at $11 in November 1990, is now around $35. Mr. Hendrix, who remains chairman, will by year-end own 600,000 shares, now worth $21 million.
Both Charles W. Duncan Jr., chairman of Panenergy's compensation committee, and Mr. Hendrix declined to comment. But in the past Mr. Hendrix has said that he asked for stock grants because they tied his fortunes to those of shareholders.
It seemed to work. According to Mr. Crystal's analysis, Mr. Hendrix has outshone rivals in the natural gas industry. One dollar invested in Panenergy in November 1990 would be worth $2.60 today, Mr. Crystal figured. By contrast, a dollar invested in Columbia Gas is worth 56 cents; in Consolidated Natural Gas, 96 cents, and in Pacific Enterprises, 83 cents. A similar investment in the S.& P. 500-stock index would be worth $1.89. Only one competitor, the Williams Companies, comes close; its value today is $2.58.
Despite that record, Panenergy has reverted to a traditional pay package for Mr. Hendrix's successor. Mr. Hendrix had asked for his stock deal -- "this was not something the board insisted on," a company spokesman said. In 1995, the new chief executive, Paul M. Anderson, got a salary of $455,417, a bonus of $333,540 and options.
Mr. Stead's package is riskier, though, for while Mr. Hendrix got stock grants, Mr. Stead must pay to exercise the options. Although Mr. Crystal estimated that Mr. Stead's options have a present value of about $24 million if the offering price is $14, they will be worthless if the stock does not rise.
If Mr. Stead does wind up wealthy, that could arouse the critics of lucrative executive pay. But at least his rewards will be related to performance. "The more the executive is willing to tie pay to performance, the better," said Robert H. Frank, co-author of "The Winner-Take-All Society" and an economics professor at Cornell University. "Tying pay to performance per se is not a bad thing, even though it has meant that pay has exploded at the top."
The design of Mr. Stead's package may also mollify critics who worry about corporate myopia. For a start, the options are parceled out over a five-year period, which should thwart any temptation to manage solely for short-term gains, said Mr. Thompson of Heidrick & Struggles.
The awards linked to performance goals will turn on accumulated earnings or the stock price over at least four months, not one-month or one-day pop-ups. Finally, Mr. Stead's option terms will be consistent with the options program used in paying other Ingram managers.
Mr. Stead's package has another attribute that should not be overlooked, Mr. Salwen, the consultant, noted, "It's very politically correct."
 The article misidentified the employer of Matt Ward, a compensation expert. He works for Watson Wyatt Worldwide, not the Hay Group.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 5, 1996, Saturday

A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about the compensation of Jerre L. Stead, chief executive of Ingram Micro Inc., referred incorrectly to terms of his stock options. An illustration with the article misstated the pay of a chief executive with a similar compensation package, Nelson Peltz of the Triarc Companies. As noted elsewhere in the chart grouping and the article, he is paid $1 a year in salary, not zero.

HEADLINE: HIGH ROLLING ON THE RIVER: A special report.;
An Oasis of Casinos Lifts A Poor Mississippi County

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

DATELINE: TUNICA, Miss., Sept. 28

 BODY:
Implausibly looming over the Mississippi Delta, the flat, black alluvial soil that brought forth cotton and the blues, are an Irish castle, a cowboy town, the Hollywood hills, a circus tent, a Tudor mansion and, biggest of all, something that its architects insist synthesizes Victorian-age San Francisco, the Wild West, New Orleans at Mardi Gras and a rain forest with a pagoda and some Greco-Roman columns thrown in, the whole tastefully outlined in pulsating purple neon.
For years, Tunica County had been the poorest place in the United States. Dead last by virtually every social and economic measure, Tunica was the worst-off county of the most poverty-stricken state in the nation. 
 But almost overnight, really by accident, a $1 billion-a-year industry plopped down in the isolated fields: gambling. The slot machine may well have more impact here than any device since the cotton gin.
Stretch limousines roll past the acres of white cotton bolls now in bloom, and there are more jobs in the county (about 13,000) than people (about 8,300). Three-quarters of the residents are black, many still living in sharecropper's tumbledown shotgun shacks. Welfare payments and unemployment rates have been cut in half, and the constantly repeated phrase here is that anyone who wants a job can get one.
The sheer numbers are staggering. The 10 casinos in the county, running 24 hours a day, are drawing 1.2 million visitors a month to these vast rural stretches. Four years ago there were 17 rooms in a rundown motel by the side of Route 61; by the end of this year there are expected to be 6,000 hotel rooms, most of them built by the casinos.
The newest, the Grand Casino, which opened to a crowd of about 45,000 people on June 24, represents an initial investment of nearly $500 million, spreading across 2,200 acres. With 140,000 square feet of "gaming" -- the term preferred in an industry where the word gambling is never used -- it is one of the biggest casinos in the country and the biggest between Las Vegas and Atlantic City.
Still, the Tunica casinos, which are all owned by major corporations with headquarters outside the state, are isolated enclaves that provide nearly every service, including free drinks and cheap buffets, to their patrons to keep them playing, and their impact on local life is still unclear. With a poorly educated and unskilled work force, only about 1 in 4 or 5 casino employees is from Tunica County, and there are so few commercial ventures that services like food and laundry, along with most of the employees, are from nearby Memphis and its suburbs.
Indeed, the town of Tunica (population 1,200) has been completely bypassed as the casinos leapfrogged north to the edge of the county ever closer to Memphis, 15 miles from where the new Grand is snuggled next to the Tunica border. The town is still a sleepy place, where the clock tower on the Planter's Bank shows the wrong time on all four faces and the part-time Mayor, Bobby E. Williams, a furniture dealer, locks up the brand-new brick town hall, built with gambling payments, before he goes to lunch.
"Tunica is just getting scraps," said Prof. Klaus J. Meyer-Arendt of Mississippi State University, who has been studying the casinos, which he compared to giant funnels sending money back to corporate headquarters. "But people there have never had even scraps, so they're grateful for anything."
Gambling taxes have swelled Tunica County's annual budget from $2.8 million before the casinos arrived to more than 10 times that amount. "Tunica wasn't smarter than anybody else," said County Administrator Kenneth M. Murphree. "Tunica was just more desperate."
The whole state was desperate in 1990 when the Mississippi Legislature met in special session to consider a state lottery, doomed in a state so socially conservative that it was the last to repeal prohibition, in 1966. Almost unnoticed, a legislator from threadbare Natchez offered a bill that would have allowed riverboat gambling in his district. Other counties bordering the river were added.
"Nobody ever took it seriously," said Charley Williams, the Republican chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. "It never would have passed a statewide vote."
People call the new casinos "the boats," though the river cannot be seen from most of them, the result of a creative method to make them legally seaworthy. They are really huge buildings, surrounded by moat-like ditches, in which gambling is done over water.
Sponsors of the bill, Mr. Williams said, hoped to produce about 3,000 jobs on six gambling boats docked on the Gulf Coast or along the Mississippi River and talked about a possible $10 million a year in tax revenue. Instead, the Mississippi Gaming Commission says the state, now the third-largest gambling market in the country, after Nevada and New Jersey, took in $213,713,855.43 in taxes this year from an industry that employed 32,273 people, with perhaps another 20,000 people working in other jobs created by the industry.
The state had latched on to one of the fastest growing businesses in the country, with well over $400 billion a year now being legally wagered. As the current annual report for Circus Circus, one of the casino concerns operating here, put it: "Casino gambling is more than three times the size of the cinema box office in the U.S., three times theme parks, and almost three times professional spectator sports. The stakes, all of a sudden, have gotten big."
 
The History
Going Forward, Moving Back
For a century, the Mississippi Delta was shaped by two interrelated institutions: sharecropping and segregation. A tiny class of white plantation owners held poor blacks in economic serfdom, chopping and picking cotton, nearly always in debt. But, toward the end of World War II, machines were developed to harvest cotton and chemicals to kill the weeds. Blacks here and throughout the Delta fled northward in a great migration that changed the country, and by the late 1960's, black labor was largely superfluous.
Tunica County's population in the 1950's was about 25,000, more than three times what it is today. Despite the widespread poverty, there are more than a score of planter millionaires, and about a dozen old-line white families pretty much run everything.
Much has changed in the 30-odd years since Mississippi fiercely resisted the civil rights movement. The county sheriff, John Pickett, is black, as are many of his deputies.
Other things have not. The public schools, which up to two years ago ranked consistently last among the state's 154 districts, are all black. White students go to the private Tunica Institute of Learning. The races still live separate lives, many of the blacks in a section known until recently as Sugar Ditch for the open sewer then running though it.
Tunica County was such an undesirable site that hardly anyone, least of all the big gambling operators, noticed when the County Board of Supervisors, headed for the last 34 years by a wealthy cotton planter and catfish farmer, Paul Battle, opened the way to casinos by getting a legal notice published in newspapers. There were no organized objections to the notice.
In DeSoto County, just north of Tunica and next to Memphis, church groups demanded a referendum on gambling and residents organized and voted down the proposal.
Then, on Oct. 19, 1992, down a country road at an old dock called Mhoon Landing, a little band of entrepreneurs, including Ronnie and Ricky Schilling, brothers from Kentucky who owned an old barge that had been a floating disco in Louisville, opened the county's first gambling riverboat. It was called Splash, and it made local history.
The owners charged $10 just to get in, and people stood in line for three hours, sometimes in a driving rain, to gamble. Splash cleared $25 million in its first five weeks and the gambling rush was on.
"It shocked the world," said Mr. Murphree, the County Administrator. "It opened a lot of people's eyes that there was this kind of market."
Splash is gone now, along with three other early casinos, squeezed out when the big operators moved in. The Schillings are living in Fort Lauderdale.
"Came here in an old black Lincoln with everything they had piled in the back and left millionaires," said Brooks Taylor, publisher, editor and the main reporter of the weekly Tunica Times.
Splash left another legacy -- a way to get the "boats" on land. The original plan had been to put a yacht at the dock. But the Mississippi's current is powerful, and the river can fluctuate by 40 feet. So the owners dug a slip for a barge and protected it from the river with a cofferdam.
The law called for gambling vessels to float on the Mississippi River or its navigable tributaries. What this has come to mean is the flood plain of the Mississippi. The casino operators dug trenches inland and created ponds, floated in barges, then filled the trenches. The gambling floors of the casinos now sit atop the barges, making them legal "gambling boats."
 
The Casinos
Fierce Fighting For Customers
The casinos themselves are "somewhere else" architecture, conjuring up cowboys, old movies or some other adventuresome theme. But inside, they are remarkably similar, dominated by rows and rows of slot machines emitting constant ear-splitting clangs, operated by grimly silent customers, many steadily puffing cigarettes, feeding in coins from paper cups. A nickel slot makes the house about $100 a day, a $1 slot $221 and a $5 slot about $471 a day, the gaming commission says. There are 14,650 slot machines in the county's 10 casinos. Even the bars with the free drinks have video card games implanted in the counters.
At the Grand Casino, bulldozers are clearing the way for three hotels, two golf courses, a 90-acre lake and water park, a convention center, a child care center, parking lots, a mall and more in hopes of turning the site into what the tourist industry calls a "destination."
Competition is cutthroat, with the casinos offering complementary food, drink and hotel rooms and giving away boats and cars as prizes, as well as claiming better odds and more winning slot machines.
The market is not just the Memphis area, but the whole center of the country, because Interstate 55, running from Chicago to New Orleans, and Interstate 40, connecting both coasts, intersect there. There are excursion buses from countless communities, especially for retirees, and a special $99 air package from Atlanta. The cars, vans and recreational vehicles have plates from Arkansas, Oklahoma, Missouri and beyond.
Like a blackjack player splitting his aces, the county is putting the lion's share of its new tax revenue -- the state gets 8 percent of casino profits, Tunica County 4 percent -- into new roads, turning country lanes into four-lane connectors to Interstate 55 to bring more gamblers straight to the casinos. "Who ever would have thought we'd need roads?" Mayor Williams mused.
The crowds are blue-collar, often graying. But in a place where color was once so important, green is all that counts. Blacks with gold chains stand shoulder to shoulder with grizzled whites in faded Harley Davidson T-shirts, throwing their money on the gaming tables. The big-name entertainment is carefully calibrated between blues and country -- for example, B. B. King and Patty Loveless.
"Maybe," said a black waiter, "the casinos will drag this place into the 20th century."
 
The Change
Lining Pockets, Filling Others
Calverta Jackson, a 36-year-old black woman wearing her Bally Casino T-shirt, who was shopping in the Piggly Wiggly supermarket, is one of the local people who have found jobs that put shiny late-model cars in the driveways and replaced some of the shacks with trailer homes.
"I think it's the best thing that happened here," she said. "Many things have changed. You see people buying cars, their own property. They weren't able to do that. The casinos made all that possible."
Before the casinos, 19.8 percent of the population was on some form of welfare, said Jacqueline Pickett, the county director of social services; the number today is 10.3 percent, mostly elderly people. Unemployment fluctuates seasonally. In 1991, before casinos, the January rate was 26.6 percent and the July rate 13 percent. This year, the figures were 8.8 percent and 6.2 percent.
"The choices have opened up," Mrs. Pickett said. "The adults at the Piggly Wiggly can go for higher pay at the boats. There's a job available for everyone who wants to work. They're able to buy trailers, things they weren't able to buy. People just have a better prospect of living."
It has not been entirely smooth. Many people in the county had never worked steadily, and the casinos have to run basic training programs. "Some didn't respond to the kind of requirements businesses have," said Bill Baker, vice president for human services at the Grand, "like coming to work on time."
The people who made the big money were those, already rich, who owned the land. Shea Leatherman, whose family settled in the county when the hardwood forests were cut in the mid-19th century, hoped to get a few million dollars, the story here goes, for land that had been worth less than a million. When the operators of Sam's Town Casino offered him $20 million in 1993, he kept a straight face and settled for $25 million. The casino took in $128 million in its first year.
But at the Blue and White Cafe, lounge and gas station, a truck-stop landmark serving catfish and homemade pie at the edge of town since 1937, Wiley Chambers, the owner, is so mad he once chased out the publisher of a gambling newspaper that had free casino meal coupons.
Anticipating a rush of business, Mr. Chambers concreted the grease pit of his gas station, burying the hydraulic rack, to create a new lounge, only to find the casinos were giving away drinks. Another roadhouse, the Hollywood, which claimed to have originated french-fried pickle slices, a local delicacy, has closed down. Directly across Route 61 from the Blue and White, the area's first McDonald's is under construction.
"Straight down, that's where the casinos should go!" Mr. Chambers was shouting angrily the other evening, over a country song on the jukebox and a hard-fought pool game. "Out of here! All the locals go just to eat the cheap food!"
Heck Wiley, with a Bud and meaty tattooed forearms on the bar, objected, saying, "Where else could an ole Mississippi boy go to hear Merle Haggard and Patty Loveless?"

CORRECTION-DATE: November 5, 1996, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 4 about Tunica County, Miss., reported its transformation by casino gambling, from the poorest county in America to the home of a billion-dollar-a-year industry. The 2,500-word article was fully based on The Times's reporting and interviewing at the scene, but some avenues for the reporting were suggested by an article by John Brans ton in the July-August issue of Memphis, a Tennessee magazine.
Three brief passages in The Times closely reflected the phrasing of Memphis's article. These were references to the parallel between the slot machine's impact and that of the cotton gin; to the profit statistics per slot machine, and to Shea Leatherman, a farmer who found a windfall in selling land for a casino. Those three passages should have been attributed to Memphis.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Recovers After Dropping On Weak Employment Report

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar was hurt initially by a surprisingly weak employment report yesterday but eventually rose as stocks and bonds surged in the belief that the Federal Reserve would hold off raising interest rates.
The jobs report, which also showed a large jump in wages, divided currency traders. 
 "The market is more sensitized to inflation than it is to growth right now," said John Nelson, senior vice president at ABN-AMRO Bank. "As a result the wage number was probably more important than the nonfarm payroll number."
After earlier declines, the dollar rose to 1.5321 German marks in late New York trading from 1.5313 marks late Thursday, and to 111.80 Japanese yen from 111.45 yen.
The dollar rose despite lower interest rates, which make United States assets worth relatively less. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.74 percent, its lowest level since Aug. 9.
The dollar has rallied for most of 1996 as investors load up on American stocks and bonds, believing that a strong economy will keep interest rates relatively high.
With interest rates across Europe falling and yields in Japan at record-low levels, foreigners may increasingly ignore economic data. Their appetite for dollar-denominated assets should continue to fuel the dollar's rise even if yields on Treasury bonds did fall yesterday, traders said.
"Lower interest rates are a product of assets improving in value not a lack of economic activity," said John Barlow, senior dealer at Bayerische Landesbank Girozentrale. "It's more of a product of supply and demand for U.S. assets."
"No matter what the numbers were it doesn't really change the market sentiment," said Dorit Ronnen, foreign exchange trader at Bank Leumi Trust Company.
"Typically, when you see a number like that, they say 'O.K., the Fed is going to ease,' and the dollar would come off, but it didn't. The bond and stock markets are well bid and the dollar followed that."
The British pound cost $1.5640, down from $1.5650. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, were: 1.2576 Swiss francs, up from 1.2559; 5.1843 French francs, up from 5.1815; 1,521 Italian lire, up from 1,517; 1.3543 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3598.

HEADLINE: About New York;
A Civic Heart Is Sold Off In 'Bake Sale'

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
SEVERAL hundred bargain hunters filed into the auditorium at Police Headquarters, where the city was selling vacant lots and buildings on Wednesday. As the pony-tailed auctioneer recited the rules, Anna Vincenty turned around and whispered some last-minute advice to her friend Yolanda Garcia.
"Don't scratch your head," Ms. Vincenty said, no doubt savvy from sitcoms. "They might think you're buying." 
 Ms. Garcia smiled weakly and kept her hands on her lap. But when the bidding stopped on Parcel No. 99, the Bronx Borough Courthouse, she had enough reasons to scratch her head. The new owner, Gus Kitkas, said he wasn't sure what he would do with the granite and marble Beaux-Arts landmark he had bought for $130,000.
Ms. Garcia had plans once. She is a co-founder of Nos Quedamos / We Stay, a Bronx grass-roots organization that raised $1 million to turn the building into a town center. Until 1995, the organization had been negotiating a lease with the city. The building was the centerpiece of a housing and economic development plan that her group and local officials had drafted for their Melrose neighborhood.
But the money they had raised from foundations and government agencies was for renovation, not acquisition. Besides, why should the people who volunteered to help redesign their corner of the South Bronx spend money they don't have for a courthouse built with public funds?
They thought they had paid enough dues just by hanging tough during decades of arson, abandonment and planned shrinkage.
"People's investment of time also has a dollar value," Ms. Garcia said. "We spent four years trying to make our neighborhood good again. All of a sudden the City of New York shuts down the little guy. How much more is our community going to bleed before the city protects it?"
NOT that long ago, the city even honored them. In 1994 the Landmarks Preservation Commission and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani awarded a citation to Richard Kahan, the Urban Assembly's president, specifically for his work on the courthouse plans. The Urban Assembly is a nonprofit planning agency that has helped Ms. Garcia's group.
Like many involved in the project, Mr. Kahan was astounded by the possibility of the building being used for business by Mr. Kitkas, an electrical contractor. "This was to be the civic heart of the community," he said. "You couldn't have a worse use."
Actually, you could. Previous auctions have resulted in vacant lots being turned into illegal garages and by-the-hour motels. The city's short-term financial gains were offset by increased spending on police patrols and a drop in the quality of life.
"We have no consistent land use plan for New York," said the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, whose borough had been beset by some of the newly privatized properties. "There's no way to figure out how to get the highest return and the best use for our resources."
City officials insist that they can stop the sale if they feel the buyer is not responsible. "In general, we don't sell to Vinnie Bag O'Donuts," said Paula Young, the spokeswoman for the Department of Citywide Administrative Services.
The issue might become moot later this month, when lawyers for Nos Quedamos go to court to try to overturn the sale. City officials are confident that they will win. They said the auction was necessary to raise money for the city, even though higher priced properties were taken off the auction list after community pressure.
WHY wasn't the courthouse spared? Ms. Garcia thinks it's about politics, since her project is part of a larger plan to redevelop a 300-block area known as the Bronx Center. Mr. Ferrer has been touting the plan for years, hoping it will show the rest of the city that he has helped the Bronx rebound. He is also said to have plans on some new housing for himself. In Gracie Mansion.
The only people hurt, Mr. Ferrer said, are in the community.
"This is part of the municipal bake sale?" he asked. "This is a complete betrayal of the community and of the history and heritage of this city."
Ms. Young denied any machinations.
"It's one of those strictly-business-nothing-personal things," she said.
But the personal should count for something.
"What is a city if not a collection of personal elements?" Mr. Ferrer said.
Still, the day after the auction, Mr. Ferrer was in the Times Square subway station helping register new voters. Nothing personal.

HEADLINE: Canada Strike Could Close G.M.'s Plants In U.S. Shortly

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation has been quietly stockpiling auto parts in preparation for this week's strike by the Canadian Automobile Workers union, but may still be forced to begin closing factories in the United States by the end of next week if the strike continues, G.M. and union officials said today.
Dean W. Munger, G.M. Canada's vice president for personnel, acknowledged today that the company had accumulated some extra parts in preparation for the current walkout in Canada, which began on Wednesday night. 
 Yet some analysts may be right, said Tom Klipstine, a G.M. spokesman, in saying that American assembly plants will begin closing if the strike lasts 10 to 14 days. "I wouldn't disagree with anyone using those numbers," he said, noting that "a majority" of G.M.'s North American assembly plants use Canadian parts.
Union officials from several G.M. Canada parts factories said in interviews here today that G.M. had been running assembly lines nearly 24 hours a day since July in an effort to meet not only current strong demand for car and truck sales but also to create a buffer for a possible strike. Trish A. McAuliffe, the strike marshal at a car seat and interior door panel factory in Windsor, Ontario, said that workers there had been on 12-hour shifts and 6- or 7-day weeks for three months.
There were several signs today that G.M. will need its stockpiles. Negotiators met only briefly this afternoon before the Canadian union's president, Basil E. Hargrove, left town to spend the weekend at a series of strike rallies across Ontario. Talks were scheduled to resume on Monday, though Mr. Hargrove said he left his cellular telephone number with Dean Munger, G.M. Canada's top labor negotiator, in case G.M. wanted to revise its offer.
Mr. Hargrove told a rally of local union officials today that he would not stop bargaining until G.M. had agreed to the same terms that its rival, the Chrysler Corporation, accepted on Sept. 17. Those terms include a provision that any jobs eliminated through the purchase of parts from outside vendors be replaced with new jobs in the same community. The union also wants to stop G.M. from selling factories.
Mr. Munger said in an interview here that the union's positions were unacceptable.
"The inability to outsource is a serious concern to us because our plans are to improve our competitiveness," Mr. Munger said.
About 15,000 workers went on strike Wednesday night at several assembly plants in Oshawa, Ontario, and Ste. Therese, Quebec. Car-seat makers and trucking companies began laying off workers almost immediately, with at least 1,000 workers furloughed in the first day of the strike, according to a tally published today by The Globe and Mail newspaper here.
Several thousand more workers were scheduled to go on strike on Sunday night at an engine and transmission factory in Ontario, followed by another 5,000 workers at G.M. Canada parts factories next Wednesday night.
With one-sixth of the private-sector jobs in Ontario depending directly or indirectly on the auto industry, and with G.M. accounting for half the auto production here, economists here warned that a prolonged strike could eventually hurt the already limping Canadian economy. The Globe and Mail ran an editorial cartoon today showing an irritated Canadian beaver wearing a T-shirt labeled "economic recovery" and struggling to pull its tail out from under a cobwebbed G.M. truck with an "on strike" license plate.
Sam Gindin, the Canadian Automobile Workers' research director, said that the economy's problems resulted from job insecurity and stagnant wages and that the strike would aid the economy in the long run if the concerns were addressed.
In Washington, the Federal Reserve Board has apparently begun following the strike and any eventual spillover effects on the American economy, with a Fed staff economist calling the Canadian union for information, James O. Stanford, an economist for the Canadian Automobile Workers, said. "They were just calling us to get what the impact would be on the U.S. operations," he said.
Several members of the American central bank's Federal Open Market Committee -- which sets interest-rate policy -- complained last spring that a 17-day strike at two G.M. factories in Dayton, Ohio, had made it temporarily difficult to gauge the health of the American economy.
That strike closed all but two of G.M.'s 29 North American assembly plants and trimmed two-tenths of a percentage point from the nation's economic output in the first quarter, but G.M. was able to make up two-thirds of the lost production in the second and third quarters.
