HEADLINE: U.S. Weighs Tougher Reaction to Burmese Crackdown

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is struggling to decide whether the intensified crackdown on political activity in Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, amounts to the "large-scale repression" of the democratic opposition that, according to a new law, would trigger a ban on all new American investment there.
Some officials and Congressional staff members say the law, signed on Monday, requires immediate sanctions. 
 They say that laws and sanctions established in support of human rights only have credibility when they are used in clear circumstances, and point out that the Chinese and Nigerian Governments are gauging the Administration's mettle as carefully as the Burmese. The United States is the fourth-largest investor in Myanmar, after France, Singapore and Thailand. Most French and American investment is in the oil sector, with the companies Unocal, Texaco and the French company Total most heavily engaged.
On Thursday, President Clinton banned Burmese Government leaders from entering the United States. The decision, which is largely symbolic, was the Administration's response to the arrest last week of as many as 800 members of the National League for Democracy led by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
The Burmese Government retaliated in kind today.
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi and her party won elections in 1988, but the results were thrown out by the military, which seized power and tried to persuade her to leave the country.
Last weekend, for the first time since she was released from six years of house arrest in July 1995, soldiers prevented Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, a winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, from making a regular weekend speech to supporters.
Senior Administration officials and human-rights organizations believe the military government is now "trying to decapitate" the League and is putting Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi back under de facto house arrest.
Senior Administration officials say that they will discuss the matter at a meeting at the White House early next week, after watching what happens in Myanmar this weekend.
Officials who argue for patience or a delay in imposing sanctions say they want to coordinate pressure on Myanmar with Japan; the European Union, which is discussing the elimination of trade benefits; and with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which has just indicated that it may delay Myanmar's application to join unless its Government permits a more open society.
They suggest giving Myanmar a deadline for changing its course or facing sanctions.
But other officials believe that the American law is clear in requiring action. The law signed by Mr. Clinton on Monday embodies an amendment offered by Senator William Cohen, Republican of Maine, and Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, which was accepted by the Administration in lieu of stronger language demanding immediate sanctions offered by Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky.
Even this weaker language would impose a ban on new investment if the Burmese Government "has physically harmed, rearrested for political acts, or exiled Daw Aung San Suu Kyi or has committed large-scale repression of or violence against the democratic opposition."
"The United States has the leverage, but does it have the political will to use it?" asked Mike Jendrzejczyk of Human Rights Watch/Asia. "A visa ban is useful symbolic action, but if the Administration does not impose economic sanctions, its credibility on human rights will be seriously damaged."
A senior Administration official expressed the quandary this way: "The law is designed as a deterrent, so ideally we don't want to use it. But if it is to be credible, we have to be willing to use it."

HEADLINE: Responding to Burmese Repression

 BODY:
A new law went into effect this week requiring President Clinton to impose an American investment ban on Myanmar if its already repressive military regime extends its crackdown against dissent and democracy. The timing was exquisite. Myanmar, as Burma was renamed by its current rulers, is currently being shaken by the worst repression of the last five years.
The country's governing State Law and Order Restoration Council says that in the last week it has arrested nearly 600 members of the opposition National League for Democracy who were planning to attend a party conference. The league's leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, says the figure is closer to 800. To reach foreign reporters, Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi had to sneak out of her house, which is now ringed by soldiers and barricades. The Government has also cut her telephone and stopped her regular weekend rallies. 
 The Burmese Government's actions have provoked an unexpected and welcome international reaction. The Philippines and Thailand, the two most democratic members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, persuaded that organization to delay Burmese entry indefinitely. Other nations, including Japan and Britain, are also considering limiting their trade with Myanmar.
Washington's sanctions bill prohibits all new American investment if the Burmese authorities harm or rearrest Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi or engage in widespread repression. These conditions have clearly been met. Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi is effectively under house arrest, and the new crackdown is extensive by any standards.
President Clinton this week condemned the Burmese conduct and banned travel to the United States by Burmese officials and their families. The Administration chose not to apply the new sanctions immediately, but promises to take a fresh look at the issue as early as Monday. Officials argued that sanctions would be more effective if Washington can persuade European and Asian nations to restrict their own trade with Myanmar, although they are unlikely to join in full sanctions.
Recruiting international support is wise, and a few days' delay is acceptable. But the Administration should not wait for long to impose the ban on new American investment. The Burmese leaders are not likely to care much about the travel restrictions. Sanctions on Myanmar are now called for under American law, and should be employed unless the Burmese leadership releases hundreds more prisoners and allows freedom of movement to Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi and her supporters.

HEADLINE: George Kubler, 84, Pioneer In Study of Pre-Columbian Art

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
George A. Kubler, a pioneering scholar of pre-Columbian and Spanish colonial art and one of the influential art historians of his generation, died on Thursday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 84.
Mr. Kubler looked for new and unstudied topics in art history and for ways to enhance and invigorate traditional art historical approaches by borrowing from social and economic history, among other disciplines. He was iconoclastic in studying the colonial architecture of Mexico and New Mexico in the 1930's when other American art historians mostly studied European art. 
Significantly, he became one of the first scholars to treat pre-Columbian artifacts not just as historical documents but also as works of Western art were treated, and as examples of a universal human engagement with form.
Although neither an archeologist nor an anthropologist, he recognized the functional aspect of the objects, which in some ways set them apart from Western art. To develop a means for interpreting what was expressive about their forms, he did not rely on specifically Western notions like genius and originality.
"The Religious Architecture of New Mexico" was his first book, published in 1940, and he later wrote a major survey on the art and architecture of Spain, Portugal and their American dominions. "The Kuchua in the Colonial World," his article on the persistence of indigenous culture in Peru during the years of Spanish rule, remains a basic text in ethnography. He also wrote on Mayan mythology, and his "Art and Architecture of Ancient America," a survey published in 1962, was one of the first attempts to tell the story of pre-Columbian culture through art.
The same year he published his most widely read book, "The Shape of Time: Remarks on the History of Things," a brief and elegantly written treatise that raised the still radical idea that art "can be expanded to embrace the whole range of man-made things." He studied the iconography of pre-Columbian art, treating its hieroglyphs and pictographs not just as linguistic signs but as creative visual forms as well.
He was born in Hollywood, Calif., in 1912, the son of an art historian, who died when he was 8. He moved with his mother to Europe. After she died, he was sent to a boarding school in Ohio, then went to Yale, where he received his Ph.D. in art history in 1940 as a student of the French art historian Henri Focillon. He joined the Yale faculty, became Sterling Professor of the History of Art, and except for occasional terms at Harvard and elsewhere, taught there until he retired in the mid-80's.
He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Bushnell Kubler; three daughters, Alexandra Kubler Merrill of St. George, Me.; Cornelia Kubler Kavanagh of Norwalk, Conn., and Elena Ann Kubler of Deer Isle, Me., and a son, Edward George Alexander Kubler of North Branford, Conn.

GRAPHIC: Photo: George A. Kubler (The New York Times, 1990)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE SPOUSE;
On the Trail, Dole's Wife Seeks Votes Of Women

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Elizabeth Dole is on a one-woman mission to exterminate the "gender gap" that is plaguing her husband.
Like Sigourney Weaver battling the Alien, Mrs. Dole is fighting her heart out against huge odds. With the clock ticking toward Nov. 5, female voters still vastly prefer President Clinton to Bob Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee, and they could determine the election. 
 That has launched the determined Mrs. Dole into overdrive. With her May Queen smile firmly in place, she makes 20 to 30 public appearances a week, delivering her 50-minute speech in three or four media markets a day. Plunging into her audiences, she talks about her husband's human side, casting him as a regular guy who likes to channel surf and eat pizza but is also sympathetic to today's harried women and protective of the social safety net that Mr. Clinton says Mr. Dole threatens to yank away.
As she told Midwestern audiences on a three-city visit on Thursday, Mr. Dole has raised millions of dollars for people with disabilities, he has planned Thanksgiving dinners for inner-city children in Washington, and he likes "reverse birthday parties" where he and Mrs. Dole give gifts on their birthdays to residents of a senior center. He is so trustworthy, she said, "you can take his word to the bank."
Earlier this week, the 60-year-old Mrs. Dole even shed her custom-tailored business suit and high heels for jeans, a black leather jacket and boots and roared onto the Jay Leno show on the back of Mr. Leno's motorcycle. If she could convince late-night viewers that she was hip, the theory went, they might take another look at her husband.
"Rev it, baby," the cotillion-going daughter of the South instructed her host. "I've come a long way from Harvard Law School to biker chick."
In an interview later, she explained what she had accomplished on the show. "I had a chance to talk about my husband as a person," she said. "People don't really know him as a person. And it was a fun thing to do."
Kellyanne Fitzpatrick, a Republican pollster, put it more bluntly: "Republicans have been on a long, bad blind date with women and need to convince them to look beyond what is at the front door. Elizabeth Dole reminds us that not every Republican has three heads and horns. She teaches us that she loves Bob Dole, so we can, too."
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows male voters about evenly split between Mr. Dole and President Clinton, with 44 percent for Mr. Clinton and 40 percent for Mr. Dole. But it shows women lopsidedly favoring the President, with 56 percent supporting him to 30 percent for Mr. Dole.
Miss Fitzpatrick suggested that while the gender gap was years in the making, Mr. Dole had perpetuated it. She cited his disparagement of the popular Family and Medical Leave Act, for example, as "a colossal error in judgment."
"I wish a better culture had been created in courting the women's vote," she lamented. "But that it wasn't makes it more imperative that Elizabeth go out on her own, speak to women and double the territory."
Mrs. Dole covers twice the ground her husband does, both substantively in her speeches and geographically, as she keeps a fuller schedule. If her crowds are smaller than his -- although she drew 2,500 recently in Cedar Rapids, Iowa -- they seem more attentive, in part because her performance is so listener-friendly.
She abandons the lectern ("a barrier," she calls it), and roams among the people, locking eyes and touching sleeves. Her speeches have beginnings, middles and ends. They conclude, in lawyerly fashion, with summations. She uses topic sentences to telegraph where she is headed. ("Now, let's talk about the values that drive the policy decisions that Bob Dole has made.") If she mentions something that seems abstract, she invariably says, "Now, why is this important?" and proceeds to explain.
At every turn, she seeks to connect her husband's policies with real life. His favorite prop is a dog-eared copy of the 10th Amendment, describing states' rights; she never mentions it. In a pre-arranged bit of campaign theater here, she had witnesses stand and tell their stories -- about things like economic hardship and the loss of a child to murder. Then, through a gentle back-and-forth that ended with hugs and hand-holding, Mrs. Dole explained that her husband's tax cut proposal would benefit women, and that his appointment of tough judges and his insistence that criminals serve their full sentences would keep violent offenders off the streets.
While not all of her events are aimed at attracting women, two of her three 50-minute speeches on Thursday were. But, whatever the audience, her performance always wins Mrs. Dole rave reviews; it is less clear that it wins her husband any new votes.
"I'm a registered Republican, but I'm very ambivalent," said Deborah M. Lewakowski, 33, an accountant from Troy who heard Mrs. Dole speak to about 1,200 people, most of them women, here at the Women's Economic Club. "I'm a C.P.A., so I have very conservative leanings. But I'm also a woman, so I have very humanitarian leanings."
She added that "personally, I haven't suffered so bad over the last four years," referring to Mrs. Dole's description of a sour economy and stagnant wages that would improve under her husband's tax cut plan.
After Mrs. Dole spoke in Indianapolis, Mike McDaniel, the chairman of the Indiana Republican Party, hailed her presentation but questioned whether it would move voters in his reliably Republican state, where Mr. Clinton is running even with Mr. Dole.
"It's tough because we're a full-employment state right now, and people are working," he said. Asked if Mrs. Dole's warm reception was transferrable to her husband, Mr. McDaniel added: "It helps, but you can't do it with one stop on one day. She's trying to cover as much turf as she can, but I wish they would figure out a way to get her more involved, either in some of their advertising or whatever, because she is a tremendous asset to Bob Dole. She's got her act together. She knows what the story is."
A Republican strategist in Washington said that while Mrs. Dole was "a great campaigner, she's not on the ballot," and that the Dole campaign had made "modest to no gains in cracking Bill Clinton's lead" among working women. "Ultimately, for Dole to put together a winning coalition, these women have to come home," he said.
Some of them might -- if Mrs. Dole were on the ballot.
"She articulates her position better than he does," said Judge Mary Waterstone, 56, a Detroit District Court judge who heard her speak here. "He has done a good job leading the Senate, but I think she could do a better job of pulling people together -- men and women, minorities."
Mrs. Dole insists that all of her hard work is strictly on behalf of her husband, that she is not tilling the fields for any future run for office herself.
"I happen to be dedicated to my husband," she said in the interview. "I believe in him; I love him dearly. It is a privilege to campaign for him. I didn't leave the Red Cross to do anything other than be fully supportive, and that's my nature."
"I have absolutely no plans" to run for office, she said. "I'm not tilling the fields."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Elizabeth Dole has made as many as 30 speeches a week to women, who have shown less enthusiasm than men for the candidacy of her husband, Bob Dole. Mrs. Dole appeared in Indianapolis yesterday. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: When Gambling Calls the Shots

BYLINE: By Theodore Kulongoski and Peter Bragdon; Theodore Kulongoski, the Attorney General of Oregon, directed the Governor's Task Force on Gaming in Oregon. Peter Bragdon, a Portland lawyer, is a former assistant attorney general.

DATELINE: SALEM, Ore.

 BODY:
Imagine the public outrage if state governments began to rely heavily on liquor sales to pay for vital programs, raising revenue by encouraging people to drink more and even advertising new alcoholic concoctions on billboards.
Yet the public is strangely quiet when it comes to the aggressive promotion of and fiscal reliance on gambling, which, like drinking, may be harmless for most but is a severe problem for others. 
 States are increasingly using gambling to raise revenue. Last year, nationwide lottery sales hit $31.9 billion, up from $9 billion in 1985, and from them the 37 states running the lottery games added $11 billion to their coffers.
In Oregon, we are paying a price for our heavy dependence on gambling. Our 12-year-old lottery has helped create a rapidly expanding betting market in which gambling drives public policy, not the other way around. There are social costs, too, but we haven't assessed them because we failed to conduct any studies. A state task force has now recommended that we create an independent gambling council to help us make better decisions than we did a dozen years ago. Until then, perhaps other states can learn from our mistakes.
Last year, Oregon ranked sixth in the world in per capita wagering on lottery games. Besides "scratch" tickets and biweekly drawings, we use keno, sports betting and, most lucrative of all, video poker, introduced in 1992 and now in 1,800 bars and taverns.
Together, these games are expected to provide nearly $753.5 million, or about 9 percent, of our current $8.5 billion general budget. Only the personal income tax brings in more money. Last year, when officials realized that gambling revenues might be short by about $80 million, there was much hand-wringing about how to entice more Oregonians into betting on state games.
By now, Oregon officials know they can raise a lot of money simply by making their gambling operations more attractive or easier to use: by improving the visual appeal of a video poker game, for example, or speeding up the turnaround time of a video game to accommodate more bets in a shorter period.
The state's success in gambling has, in turn, spurred growing competition from the private sector. Oregon now has more forms of legalized gambling, state and private, than almost any other state.
Under the law, Oregon's nine federally recognized Indian tribes can offer forms of gambling already permitted by state law. In other words, when Oregon began to run video lottery games in taverns, it meant that Indian tribes could build casinos with hundreds of these machines. With six such casinos operating, Oregon now has a bad case of what is being called "level playing field syndrome," something akin to an arms race.
The state lottery and its retailers say that to compete with the private Indian-run casinos they must create better video gambling games. The race tracks, already annoyed by state lottery competition, complain that the lottery's new games will kill parimutuel wagering unless tracks are allowed to have card rooms and more than just a few of the state lottery machines.
Indian officials counter that if race tracks get the video betting games, it will cut into their operations and spur some tribes to add even more betting games. Bingo operators, in turn, insist that they need higher prize ceilings to compete with all of this.
Oregonians now joke that the Legislature should establish a Level Playing Field Committee to get ready for an endless stream of bills aimed at satisfying each segment of the gambling market. The truth is, any state that depends heavily on gambling for revenue will find itself under pressure to increase gambling.
Meanwhile, we have learned almost nothing about the social impact of all this. Oregon's video lottery games are thought to be particularly addictive, but until now the state has never tried to find out how many people are hooked. The Attorney General's office has heard from people who have squandered family resources, gone bankrupt or robbed their employers to get money to play. And the number of Gamblers Anonymous meetings in Oregon has grown to 34 per week, up from 3 a week before the gambling explosion.
The lack of information on these kinds of problems allows those who oppose gambling altogether to predict that parts of Oregon will soon resemble Atlantic City or be overrun by criminals and casinos preying on citizens. At the same time, proponents of even more gambling are able to dismiss any social concerns as unfounded. They look at the gambling revenues and point to the beneficiaries: schools, the environment, economic development. Gambling, they say, is good for schools. (Imagine if we said that liquor is "good," because we used it to finance kindergartens.)
Right now, we in Oregon do not know if we have created a monster. Nor do we know the real cost of state-run gambling, social and economic.
But we know we are going to pay the price. States that rush to raise revenues from gambling without thinking more than we did are playing a potentially addictive game of chance.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Surge as Drop in Payrolls Indicates No Rate Rises

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices surged yesterday after the September employment report bolstered expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates this year.
For many in the market, the employment report was more evidence that the economy was slowing slightly and that the Fed's policy of keeping interest rates steady was working. Traders focused on a surprising 40,000 drop in the nation's payrolls and were not discouraged by another element of the report that showed a strong rise in wages. 
 "We knew the bond market had been expecting a market-friendly jobs number today, and felt a negative surprise would probably be more harmful than a positive number would be beneficial," said Jack Ablin, director of fixed income at the Private Bank, a unit of the Bank of Boston. "We were a little cautious going in ahead of the number, but now feel good about the market and are looking for the long bond to lower its yield by 5 to 10 basis points each month."
The price of the 30-year bond rose 11/32 , to 1002/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.74 percent, from 6.83 percent on Thursday.
The yield on the long bond -- a benchmark for mortgages and other consumer and corporate rates -- is now at its lowest level since Aug. 9, when it was 6.69 percent.
The monthly employment report is the most important single indicator of the economy's performance, and previous reports this year have roiled the bond market with evidence of surprising strength. So traders were heartened by the unexpected fall in the payroll number.
Still, the gain in average hourly earnings -- up 6 cents, to $11.92 -- is likely to keep inflation concerns alive. But David A. Levy, director of forecasting at the Jerome Levy Economics Institute, Mount Kisco, N.Y., said the market's concerns over wage pressures and inflation were overblown. He said the yield on the 30-year bond could drop to as low as 6.25 percent by the end of the year and to 6 percent by the first half.
"There are only a few months out of the year that the monthly numbers are not skewed for one reason or another," he said. "When you take the last three months you see a trend. The average number of jobs added to the economy over the last three months has been 140,000 a month, compared to well in excess of 250,000 a month in the second quarter of this year. From quarter to quarter it is a marked deceleration. When you see a drop of that magnitude there has to be something to it."
Mr. Ablin of the Private Bank said he was not surprised that employment had continued in a slowing trend. At this rate, he said the yield on the long bond could be as low as 6.50 percent by Dec. 31. "You have to commend the Fed for keeping a steady hand on interest rates," he said, "or better, no hands."
The market now shifts its attention to a round of new inflation data, with the Producer Price Index and retail sales reports on Friday and the Consumer Price Index the following week on Wednesday.
Traders will also be concerned with the market's ability to absorb new supply. The Treasury auctions $26 billion of new three- and six-month Treasury bills on Monday, followed by a $10 billion auction of 10-year notes on Tuesday, and a $19.25 billion auction of one-year bills on Thursday.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the 10-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.47 percent.

HEADLINE: Wall Street Bears Lose 2 More Voices

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Uncle.
That was the word out of Morgan Stanley & Company yesterday morning as two of Wall Street's most visible bears doffed their painfully uncomfortable furs and donned bullish horns. 
 Since April, Byron R. Wien, the firm's United States investment strategist, has been predicting a 1,000-point decline in the Dow Jones industrial average. For even longer, Stephen S. Roach, its chief economist, forecast a rise in long-term interest rates to 7.5 percent this year. But in the face yesterday of economic news that prompted yet another stock market closing high and a bond market rally, both finally did an about-face.
"The economy is fine, but our interest rate call isn't," Mr. Roach said in a memorandum to clients.
Mr. Roach said that he now thought that long-term rates would fall to 6.5 percent this year. That is a quarter of a percentage point below where they ended yesterday after a surprisingly weak September jobs report helped solidify a view that the economy was soft and inflation was in check.
Mr. Wien said that with the forecast of declining interest rates, his near-term outlook had flipped. "There is a 10 percent upside in the market," he said, "if interest rates go to 6.5 percent."
The switch by these prominent analysts could add to the very market sentiment that Mr. Roach said forced him to reverse his interest rate outlook. And it leaves very few bears -- those who think markets will drop -- still active as winter approaches. But it is also possible, as has been the case in the past, that when just about everybody thinks stocks can't fall, that is when the market reaches its top.
Economic fundamentals have not changed, Mr. Roach argued. The economy is stronger than current data indicate and eventually interest rates and inflation will move higher. But now, Mr. Roach said, he thinks that will not happen until next year.
Even so, Mr. Roach conceded that most investors were seeing things differently, choosing to focus on the current slowdown in growth, the fact that inflation is still in check, and economic news that could persuade the Federal Reserve to leave short-term interest rates unchanged at least through the end of the year.
Mr. Roach disagrees with that view, but said he could no longer resist the tide. "My job is to try to call the market," he said. "Markets are determined by fundamentals and sentiment and right now sentiment is overwhelming the fundamentals."
The decline in Mr. Roach's interest rate forecast, which Mr. Wien endorsed, moved Mr. Wien to throw in the towel on stocks, too. Instead of the risk of an overvalued market that would push stocks sharply down, lower long-term rates leave the stock market undervalued with the opportunity for a strong rally.
For all the force of their about- face, it was a bit grudging. "I am still worried about a major selloff," Mr. Wien said, "but not until sometime after the first quarter of next year."
And Mr. Roach is forecasting that interest rates will move higher next year, hitting 7 percent to 7.5 percent in the first half. But that is lower than the 8 percent he once thought.
"In my gut, I still think we've got the fundamental call on the economy right, with both growth and inflation likely to play out on the upside of market expectations," he concluded in his memo. "What we missed was the burst of investor euphoria."
So does this mean that the investors who have bet on lower interest rates and higher stocks are wrong?
"No," Mr. Roach said. "They have money to put to work and they want to believe in the perfect path of slow growth and no inflation."

HEADLINE: JOB MARKET WEAK AS ECONOMY EASES, BUT WAGES ARE UP

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The job market weakened in September, confirming a slowing of the economy, as payrolls unexpectedly fell by 40,000 and the unemployment rate inched up, the Labor Department reported today.
But wages rose substantially for the second consecutive month, which is likely to prevent inflation concerns from fading. 
 Financial markets, shrugging off a 6-cent-an-hour rise in hourly earnings, rallied after the figures were issued, relieved that slackening growth would help keep borrowing costs from rising. Indeed, interest rates tumbled across the board and the Dow Jones industrial average vaulted 60 points to yet another record as it approached the 6,000 mark. [Page 41.]
Just a month before the election, the Clinton Administration attempted to put the disappointing drop in jobs in the best light. It focused on the higher wage figure as demonstrating that average workers were finally beginning to benefit from the economic upturn that has been under way since 1991.
"All recent indicators suggest that the economy will continue on a healthy and balanced course of low unemployment, low inflation and solid economic growth, with all Americans increasingly sharing in the benefits of that growth," the President's chief economic adviser, Joseph E. Stiglitz, said.
Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, boasted that "we couldn't have a better overall picture going into an election."
The Dole campaign reacted by pointing to the drop in employment last month and deploring what it called subpar economic growth since the end of the 1990-91 recession.
"This Administration has a policy of low economic growth -- and there doesn't seem to be any plan for raising it," said Martin Anderson, an adviser to Mr. Dole who was a senior White House policy official in the first two years of the Reagan Administration. "That is unacceptable."
He said the Dole proposal for a 15 percent tax cut would generate more growth in the next few years than the Clinton Administration expects, and that even a modest improvement would make "an enormous difference."
Unemployment, which in August hit a low point for the 1990's, rose slightly to 5.2 percent in September from 5.1 percent in August.
The monthly job report -- the September figures are the next-to-last ones to be issued before Election Day -- provides the most important single indicator of economic performance.
After a period of confounding mixed readings, various gauges now clearly show that the economy's growth rate has slackened from the rapid 4.7 percent annual pace in the second quarter. Most analysts are estimating that the economy will advance at only half that pace or less for the quarter ended Sept. 30.
"Businesses are responding quicker and quicker to changes," said Mickey D. Levy, economist at Nationsbank Capital Markets in New York, noting that retail sales have been flat lately and factory orders down. "Production is now responding to the slowdown in demand."
The latest figures seemed to confirm the judgment of monetary policy makers at the Federal Reserve, who decided not to raise short-term interest rates last week because of the belief that the economy was slowing enough on its own.
Yet some analysts remained doubtful. "The extent of the slowdown seems very overstated," said John E. Silvia, chief economist at Zurich Kemper Investments, a Chicago mutual-fund group. "The Fed has to be concerned about the wage number."
Payrolls, which had been expected to expand moderately last month, contracted by 40,000 instead, the first decline since January. This figure, the item that usually gets more professional scrutiny than any other in the employment report, was marked by an unnerving and widespread drop of 57,000 factory jobs, and by a 67,000 drop in local education that was almost pure statistical aberration.
The drop in education jobs, part of an 81,000 shrinkage for all levels of government, reflected a failure of the department's adjustment process to keep up with the twin trends of starting the school year earlier and operating schools year-round.
As a result, many jobs held by bus drivers, cafeteria workers, sports referees and the like were captured in the statistical net during August instead of September, when the adjustment -- based on typical patterns from the past -- assumes they will appear. Unlike these support personnel, however, teachers are assumed to be employed while on summer vacation and do not distort the figures except as they may take more or fewer temporary jobs than normal.
The biggest factory declines were in industrial machinery and automotive and other transportation equipment, with factories now employing 331,000 fewer people than at the most recent peak in March 1995.
Job growth continued to slow in services, which expanded by just 54,000 despite a pickup in health services, where a 30,000 gain followed three small ones. Retail trade and construction both showed sluggish growth while finance and real estate were both virtually unchanged.
In all, the expansion of private-sector payrolls, averaging 126,000 a month for July, August and September, was exactly half as large as in the preceding three months.
"We're well off where we were in the second quarter," Thomas J. Plewes, an associate commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said after an agency briefing.
The Government's survey of households, on which the unemployment rate is based, showed a 313,000 increase in the number of people holding one or more jobs last month. But this fell short of a 455,000 expansion of the overall labor force, which includes everyone working or looking for a job. That is why the unemployment rate inched up, although the rise was too small to be statistically significant, the bureau said.
Current jobless rates, some analysts argue, are effectively at the lowest level since 1973 because of a change two years ago in the way the bureau calculates the figures.
The unemployment rate for adult men, which dropped a half-point in August, climbed three-tenths of a point last month to 4.5 percent, the same as for adult women, today's report also showed. The rate for blacks was unchanged at 10.5 percent while that for Hispanic people fell a half-point, to 8.2 percent.
Geographically, the Northeast, South and Midwest all registered jobless rates one-tenth of a point higher than in August -- to 5.2, 5 and 4.5 percent, respectively -- while the rate in the West was unchanged at 6.3 percent.
The department said it had identified what it called a "fairly minor" coding error involving seasonal adjustment that would require recalculation of the series from March through July, with revisions to be published Oct. 18.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ORATORY;
Clintonian Speeches: A Guide for Listeners

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
In nearly four years as President, Bill Clinton has made thousands of speeches: short ones, long ones, big ones, little ones, good ones, bad ones. But in a way, he has made just one speech -- over and over and over again.
To be sure, the words change, and so do the ideas. Four years ago, Mr. Clinton spoke of providing health insurance to all Americans and expanding education and training to equip workers for a global economy. Now he talks of 48-hour hospital stays for mothers and newborns and uniforms for schoolchildren. 
 Yet in their architecture and their oratorical rhythms, in the topics they cover and the techniques they employ, the President's speeches are remarkably predictable. He seldom hews to any text but the one unspooling in his head, and the outlines of his arguments defy tidy diagramming, because he makes so many subpoints and ambles down whatever cul-de-sac may catch his fancy. He rearranges sections, and repeats some if the spirit strikes him.
Still, a survey of his recent stump speeches makes some patterns clear enough to construct a listener's guide and gazetteer to the spaces and places Mr. Clinton visits when he stands behind the bulletproof lectern that the Secret Service calls the blue goose, for the color of its top and its goose-neck microphone.
 
Glad to Be Here
Like all politicians, Mr. Clinton has his preferred preparatory rituals of greeting and gratitude. He thanks the local politicians on the platform. He thanks the band. "The colder it gets, the harder it is to play one of those instruments, I know," he told students in Buffalo on Thursday.
And he thanks the person who introduced him -- often a citizen chosen to exemplify the point he is trying to make that day -- in effusive and unvarying terms.
"Most of all I'd like to thank Sally and her mother, her daughter, and her granddaughter," he said of one woman who introduced him at an appearance with senior citizens in Sunrise, Fla., last month. "Didn't she do a good job? Let's give her another hand. I thought she was great."
If the introducer is particularly special, or has won particular applause from the crowd, Mr. Clinton will say the he is glad she is not running for any office against him.
In a world of endless airport rallies and undifferentiated photo opportunities, Mr. Clinton also goes out of his way to localize each speech, recalling a snippet of local history, praising the hometown sports team's latest triumph or mourning its defeat, celebrating the scenery or the weather and, in the South especially, larding his speech with regionalisms like "might oughta."
This is also the section in which Mr. Clinton plays off anything funny or diverting that has been said by previous speakers, as he did at a rock-concert rally for Senator John Kerry, who is locked in a tight race for re-election against Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts.
"Whoever said he didn't have a sense of humor?" Mr. Clinton asked the crowd at the Fleet Center in Boston. "Do you believe that Governor Weld would have the guts to stand up here and say he couldn't believe that we had all those people from the '60's play and everybody kept their clothes on? Next thing you know, John Kerry will be doing the macarena with Al Gore."
 
Why Me
Mr. Clinton gets down to business with a passage that begins, "Four years ago, I ran for President because . . ." The reasons vary slightly, but they usually include his desire to rebuild the American economy, restore the American Dream and bring together a country that is too often divided. Mr. Clinton does not claim to have accomplished these goals, but he quickly makes clear that he thinks he's made a good stab at them.
"I come here to tell you today we're in better shape than we were four years ago," he told a crowd in Houston. "And we're on the right track to the 21st century.
The President tries to prove his point with a battery of statistics: 10.5 million new jobs, record numbers of small businesses, record exports, the highest rates of home ownership in 15 years, welfare rolls down by nearly 2 million, child support collections up 50 percent, and his current favorite: the Census Bureau's recent report that median household income increased on average nearly $900 after inflation last year, the biggest increase in 10 years.
"I almost wept when I read it," he said in Fall River, Mass.
Naturally, Mr. Clinton takes credit for much of this good news, and recites his record on issues including cutting the deficit, signing the family and medical leave law, increasing Federal funds to help cities hire police officers and protecting the environment. And he puts flesh on the statistics by citing the stories of people he has met -- sometimes months or years ago, often that day.
In Houston last week, he told the tales of three people he had met shaking hands in Longview, Tex., that morning. The first was a Vietnam veteran with a child who suffers from spina bifida, who thanked Mr. Clinton for expanding Federal benefits to veterans to cover that illness. The second was a 34-year-old single mother of two who is paying her way through college by having served in the President's national service program, Americorps.
"And then I went on down a little more, and I met a lady who was really crying," Mr. Clinton said. "I didn't know what was the matter, she was obviously disturbed. And she said, 'I'm sorry that I'm so emotional, but because of the family and medical leave law, I was able to take a little time off from work when my husband was so sick with cancer, and I didn't lose my job.' "
 
The Best Is Yet to Come
After talking about what he has done, Mr. Clinton moves on to talk about all that he still wants to do. His goals range widely, from offering new tax credits for college education to having the private sector supply cellular telephones to neighborhood watch groups.
He wants to connect every classroom in the country to the Internet. He wants to balance the budget and "still protect our investments in education, in the environment, in Medicare and Medicaid." He wants to "mobilize an army of volunteers to work with parents and teachers to make sure that by the year 2000, every third grader in America can pick up a book and say, 'I can read this all by myself.' "
It is in this part of his typical speech, near the very end, that Mr. Clinton drops in whatever he wants to be the news of the day, outlining his latest proposal for inflation-proof Government bonds or drug testing for prison inmates.
But it is also here that Mr. Clinton sometimes gets lost in the underbrush of his own enthusiasms, veering wildly into meditations on the latest book he has read, musing on the wisdom of the Founding Fathers, the future of science.
If he is tired, his tongue may slip, as it did in Providence, R.I., when he bragged about having signed a bill to guarantee 48-hour hospital stays to end what he likes to call "drive-through deliveries," by saying he had signed a bill to stop "drive-by pregnancies."
In Houston, in a hymn to the nation's diversity that seemed unintentionally salacious, he said, "When I looked at the American Olympic team, it occurred to me that if they took their uniforms off, we wouldn't know where they were from."
Nothing ever seems more difficult for the President than wrapping it all up. Another clause always beckons. At a community college in Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., last month, Mr. Clinton three times began sentences saying "Finally . . ." and twice promised to make just one last point before finally sitting down.
On occasion, however, he simply runs out of steam. "Well," he told a crowd in an Iowa farm field at a fund-raiser for Senator Tom Harkin last month, "that's it."

HEADLINE: Presenting the IgNobels, UnPrizes Satirizing Weak Science

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 4

 BODY:
What was surprising about the IgNobel Prizes this year was that the winners of two of them actually accepted them. Usually winners ignore the prizes completely.
The sixth annual spoof of science and the Nobel Prize, sponsored by the Annals of Improbable Research and held on Thursday night at Harvard University's grand Memorial Hall, has become a sort of scientists' Halloween, attended by hundreds of students and faculty members. 
 This year the event was broadcast on National Public Radio and on the Internet.
Ten prizes were awarded in fields ranging from physics and medicine to art and literature for achievements "that cannot or should not be reproduced."
Among the recipients who chose the traditional path of not acknowledging the award was Jacques Chirac, President of France, who was given the IgNobel Peace Prize for a series of atomic bomb tests in the Pacific Ocean while the world was observing the 50th anniversary of Hiroshima.
Nor did any representative of the major American tobacco companies show up to receive the IgNobel in medicine for their discovery, announced in 1994 before Congress, that nicotine is not addictive.
And the editors of the journal Social Text did not retrieve the award in literature, given for publishing a paper entitled, "Transgressing the Boundaries: Toward a Transformative Hermeneutics of Quantum Gravity."
The author of the paper, a physicist at New York University, caused a furor after he announced that it was a hoax. The paper argued that reality does not exist.
But the award in public health was different. It went to Ellen Kleinst from Nuuk, Greenland, and Harald Moi of Oslo, Norway, for a report published in Genitourinary Medicine, a scientific journal. The paper was entitled, "Transmission of Gonorrhea Through an Inflatable Doll." One of the authors of the paper, Dr. Moi, showed up to receive the award.
The biology prize was also accepted by the winners, who sent a videotape from Norway. Anders Baerheim and Hogne Sandvik of the University of Bergen, Norway, were cited for their paper in the British Medical Journal and entitled "Effect of Ale, Garlic and Soured Cream on the Appetite of Leeches."
The authors said in their videotape that they were accepting on behalf of their research subjects, who were "in no position to accept for themselves." The Norwegian consul in Boston picked up the award.
The ceremony this year included not only the awards presentations but also an auction of plaster casts of the left feet of four real Nobelists in New England who cooperated in the casting: Sheldon Glashow, physics, 1979; Dudley Herschbach, chemistry, 1986; William Lipscomb, chemistry, 1976, and Richard Roberts, medicine, 1993.
The ceremonies also included a brief three-act opera about cockroaches and the destruction of the Earth, and a series of papers presented on biodiversity, including one essay defending bacteria and suggesting that hand-washing is a form of interspecies ethnic cleansing.
Other winners of IgNobel Prizes were:
Physics: Robert Matthews of Aston University, England, for his studies of Murphy's Law, which holds that if things can go wrong they will, and the fact that toast frequently falls buttered-side down. His paper "Tumbling Toast, Murphy's Law and the Fundamental Constants," was published in the European Journal of Physics.
Economics: Robert J. Genco of the University of Buffalo for his discovery that "financial strain is a risk indicator for destructive periodontal disease."
Chemistry: George Goble of Purdue University for setting the world-record time for igniting a barbecue -- three seconds. He used charcoal and liquid oxygen.
Art: Don Featherstone of Fitchburg, Mass., for being the first to create a plastic version of pink flamingos for the lawn. The award was given for the "ornamentally evolutionary invention," which the inventor said would "keep the archeologists guessing" when discovered at homesites in centuries to come.
Biodiversity: Chenosuke Okamura of Okamura Fossil Laboratory in Nagoya, Japan, for discovering fossils of an entire array of "mini-species" -- from dinosaurs to humans -- that were each less than one-hundredth of an inch in length. No monetary award comes with the IgNobel prize, but a statue and a few small gifts are included.
The chief sponsor of the prize, the Annals of Improbable Research, is a successor to a periodical that satirized scientific publications, The Journal of Irreproducible Results, which was published between 1955 and 1990. Cosponsors were the Harvard-Radcliffe Science Fiction Association, the Harvard Computer Society, and Tangents, a student mathematics bulletin.

HEADLINE: Campaign Debate Gives Hartford An Opportunity to Promote Itself

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 4

 BODY:
In the minds of city leaders here, when Bob Dole and Bill Clinton square off in their debate on Sunday, there will be one clear winner: Hartford.
For at least a few seconds, this city of 124,000 will be the focus of the world, as millions tune in and hear the magic words, "The Presidential debate, from Hartford, Conn." On that day, about 2,500 reporters will be in town for what may be the largest press event ever to take place here. 
 Many say it is a pivotal moment for this once wealthy city, which has fallen upon hard times. While neither Presidential candidate has seized upon the fate of America's cities as a campaign issue, the debate has become an opportunity for Hartford boosters to tout this city, despite its problems, as a beautiful New England town with a promising future.
Of course, the doubters who ask what the fuss is all about are many. The decline of the insurance industry and the loss of major banks that were based here still loom larger than any one-day event, and besides, some critics grumble, Clinton and Dole are not even addressing the core problems of declining urban centers.
"I think that both parties are getting away from cities to attract those angry white suburban men," said Steven Harris, a firefighter a lifelong Hartford resident. "No one talks about the cities anymore."
Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Mayor of New York, shares that view. "So far, neither one of them has spent a great deal of time on urban issues," he said. "Hopefully, the substantive part of the campaign is about to begin, and we will hear a lot more about what they intend to do about cities."
And Hartford's problems are substantial. One of the nation's poorest cities, based on the percentage of people living below the poverty line, it shrank early in this decade faster than any other city in the nation, losing 11 percent of its population in the first four years.
Still, Hartford's triumph in being chosen for the debate over 40 other cites is being hailed as one of many signs that the city's fortunes may be turning around.
"What happens on Sunday could be critical to the success of Hartford," said Dan Papermaster, the 32-year-old lawyer who a year ago had the idea of bringing the debate here. "This is a chance to show that tremendous things are going on in Hartford."
Crime has dropped to its lowest level in a decade, tourist events over the last two years have drawn thousands of suburbanites back into the city, and the unemployment rate has declined slighlty.
Yet in some respects, this is an unlikely place for the debate. Over the last five years, the city has lost two of its largest hotels, leaving it with only 1,000 rooms in the downtown area. Many visiting reporters -- and even Bob Dole -- will be staying in hotels in surrounding towns, with some as far away as Springfield, Mass, 25 miles north.
But the Hartford region has responded to the coming event with an enthusiasm that harkens back to a time when Presidential candidates were routinely greeted by huge crowds and ticker-tape parades.
Banners on the highways welcome people to "the home of the Presidential debate." Planters holding chrysanthemums have been placed on downtown streets, and suburban towns have sent cleaning crews to help city workers, who are laboring overtime. Graffiti is being washed away, the windows of abandoned buildings are being boarded up, and volunteers are pulling weeds from little-used parking lots.
The staff at the Bushnell, the 1930 Art Deco-style theater where the debate will be held, has been working around the clock for 10 days, repainting doors, sweeping steps and appointing a "glass and brass" team to polish brass and clean windows. "The brass is shining like it never has in 66 years," Deidre M. Tavera, the Bushnell's associate managing director, said today.
Although some dismiss the attention as merely Hartford's 15 minutes of fame -- "Who remembers where the 1992 debates were held?" one city worker grumbled (St. Louis; Richmond, Va., and Lansing, Mich.) -- city leaders gush about the benefits of every brief mention of the city on network television.
The city's Congresswoman, Barbara B. Kennelly, called it "the most important event" in Hartford's 300-year history. An editorial in The Hartford Courant maintained that the debate "should put Hartford on the map."
The Deputy Mayor, Frances Sanchez, said: "People always claim nothing happens in Hartford. Now with this international and national attention, people will wake up. The problems in Hartford are not going to be solved in a weekend, but people are excited; our neighbors are excited."
The debate is emblematic of a new civic pride, and it was brought here through a concerted effort by citizens, business leaders and elected officials.
It was the brainchild of Mr. Papermaster, a former aide to Senator Christopher Dodd, who along with Evan S. Dobelle, the president of Trinity College, sold the idea to business leaders, ultimately raising $1 million. When officials from the nonpartisan Presidential Debate Commission visited here last October, they received a gala welcome replete with a bus tour, a lunch catered by one of the city's best restaurants and a meeting with Gov. John G. Rowland, Mayor Mike Peters and Mrs. Kennelly.
The promoters even had a Mark Twain impersonator on hand. Twain, a Hartford resident for 17 years, has become something of a city symbol.
In January, the commission awarded the city the Vice-Presidential debate, but all plans changed last month when the two candidates reduced the number of debates from four to three. At that point, Senator Dodd, the general chairman of the Democratic National Committee, let it be known that he would not tolerate Hartford being dropped.
In a television interview on Sunday, Mr. Dodd said, "I weighed in very heavily with the Commission, with Paul Kirk, with Mickey Cantor on the Democratic side, to see to it that Hartford would be in the mix."
Mr. Kirk, a former Democratic Party chairman, is an official of the commission; Mr. Cantor, the Commerce Secretary, was representing President Clinton in debate negotiations.
As to whether Hartford's problems will be addressed in the debate, most politicians are not expecting much.
"They will go to one of the nation's most depressed cities and are likely to have a debate in front of the nation where they don't say a word about cities," said David Rusk, a former mayor of Albuquerque, N.Mex., and an urban policy consultant in Washington.
Urban experts say the negligible discussion of cities during the campaign stems from the declining role of the Federal Government in urban affairs as a result of budget cuts and from the candidates' electoral strategies, which emphasize the suburban vote and make urban policy a risky topic.
Mayor Giuliani pointed out that Mr. Clinton has yet to explain what he intends to do about the new welfare law, which Mr. Giuliani said is creating "real terrible problems" for cities. And Mr. Dole still must explain how he plans to take his philosophy of opportunity and empowerment and make it relevant to cities, Mr. Giuliani added.
"I think both of them have the opportunity to do that, but neither one has done it yet," he said.
Supporters of each candidate deny that they have ignored urban problems.
While the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, Jack Kemp, told a crowd in New Haven on Thursday that Mr. Clinton had no plan to help urban residents escape poverty, he insisted that Mr. Dole's economic plan, with its tax cuts and tax credits, would do that. Republicans also note that Mr. Kemp's long-held advocacy of enterprise zones -- designated urban areas that would receive special tax credits -- is proof of Mr. Dole's commitment.
In turn, William E. Curry Jr., a domestic policy adviser to Mr. Clinton and a former candidate for governor of Connecticut, remarked, "Just because it's not a radioactive campaign issue doesn't mean we don't have a program." While accusing the Republicans of lacking any specifics in their urban proposal, he said Mr. Clinton had sent Federal aid and personnel to cities to fight crime and had established empowerment zones that channeled millions of dollars to urban areas, among other initiatives.
There are examples of Mr. Clinton's work in Hartford that he may point to in the debate, Mr. Curry said.
Still, some in this city, dissatisfied by the lack of attention so far to urban policy, have mobilized to pressure the candidates to talk about cities.
On Monday, a community group, Hartford Area Rallies Together, gave Mr. Curry a list of issues they hoped Mr. Clinton would examine. And on Sunday, they are holding a rally to draw attention to the need to create jobs here.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks and Bonds Rally On Weak Employment Data
The Dow Jones industrial average shot toward the 6,000-mark as a weakening job market confirmed a slowing of the economy -- convincing traders that the Federal Reserve will not need to raise interest rates to contain inflation. Broader stock market barometers jumped to record levels as well, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index surpassing the 700-mark for the first time. 
 The Dow rose 60.01 to finish at 5,992.86, having come within 5 points of 6,000 in the last hour of trading. The blue-chip average has now rocketed back about 800 points, or more than 15 percent, from July's bruising selloff. For the week, the Dow was up 119.94 points. [Page 41.]
 
Treasury prices surged after the employment report bolstered expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates this year. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.74 percent, from 6.83 percent on Thursday. [38.]
 
The dollar followed the markets higher despite the expectation of lower interest rates. [40]
 
Wages Rise for 2d Straight Month
Despite an unexpected 40,000 drop in payrolls and a slight rise in the unemployment rate, wages rose substantially for the second straight month, which is likely to prevent inflation concerns from fading from the picture. Unemployment, which in August hit a low point for the 1990's, rose slightly, to 5.2 percent, in September from 5.1 percent in the previous month. Financial markets, though, shrugged off a 6-cent rise in hourly earnings, relieved that slackening growth would help keep borrowing costs from rising. [1.]
 
Shift on Air Crash Liability Limits
The Transportation Department has given tentative approval to a rule that would eliminate the limit on liability for damages in international air crashes unless the airline could prove it was not negligent. The current rule, specified by the Warsaw Convention since 1966, limits damages to $75,000 unless a victim's family can show that an airline was guilty of willful misconduct. [39.]
 
Pressure Increased on Time Warner
New York City has stepped up the pressure in its effort to persuade Time Warner to carry Rupert Murdoch's new 24-hour news channel, suggesting that a refusal by Time Warner could affect whether the city renews the company's lucrative cable franchises. [25.]
 
The Guiliani Administration has waded into a corporate grudge match that sounds like it was dreamed up in Hollywood. [26.]
 
S.E.C. Closes Denver Case
The S.E.C., as expected, closed its two-year investigation of Denver's sale of $3.9 billion in airport bonds without filing any charges. [39.]
 
I.R.S. Ruling Worries Airlines
The airline industry says an I.R.S. ruling could cost it more than $1 billion by 2004, if applied nationally. The agency ruled that a regional airline's costs for periodic engine inspections were capital investments to be depreciated over seven years, not an ordinary business expense that is deductible immediately. [38.]
 
Alcoa Earnings Fall 70 Percent
Alcoa reported a 70 percent drop in third- quarter profits, citing lower prices, higher materials costs and the cost of early retirements and layoffs. [38.]

HEADLINE: Dow in Surge Near 6,000 Spurred by Report on Jobs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average shot toward the 6,000-mark yesterday as a weakening job market confirmed a slowing of the economy, convincing traders that the Federal Reserve will not need to raise interest rates to contain inflation.
Broader stock market barometers jumped to record levels as well, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index surpassing the 700-mark for the first time. 
 The Dow rose 60.01 points, to 5,992.86, having come within 5 points of 6,000 in the last hour of trading. The blue-chip average has now rocketed back about 800 points, or more than 15 percent, from July's bruising selloff. For the week, the Dow was up 119.94 points, or 2 percent.
That summer tailspin was instigated largely by worries that rising production costs would force the inflation-wary Federal Reserve to raise its key lending rates, slowing consumer spending and, perhaps, corporate profits.
Now those worries have abated. Indeed, the inspiration for yesterday's rally was a Labor Department report that payrolls fell by 40,000 and unemployment moved up to 5.2 percent in September from 5.1 percent in August, a seven-year low. Last week, the Fed heartened investors by leaving interest rates unchanged.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners, 1,803 to 726, on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume was heavy at 463.9 million shares.
The S.& P. 500 rose 8.68, to 701.46, ending up 15.27 from last Friday, and the Big Board composite index rose 4.02, to 374.16 -- the fourth record finish for both indexes this week.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 14.47, to 1,247.56,, just a point and a half shy of its high set on June 5. The index was up 19.58 on the week. The Nasdaq market, where more volatile technology and speculative companies are traded, had lagged behind the blue-chip rebound from July's selloff, which dragged the Nasdaq composite as low as 1,008.
The American Stock Exchange's market value index, which is also dominated by more speculative shares, rose 7.29, to 579.89, but is still about 35 points from its May peak.
Among the Dow industrials, Bethlehem Steel fell 1, to 8 5/8; Union Carbide lost 3/4, to 45 1/4; Alcoa dipped3/8, to 60, and Caterpillar gave up 3/8, to 73 1/2.
Dow components that contributed to the average's surge included I.B.M., up 1 5/8, to 126 5/8; Du Pont, 3, to 93 3/8; General Electric, 1 5/8, to 93 1/2; Procter & Gamble, 1 3/4, to 99 7/8, and Exxon, 1 7/8, to 87 7/8.
Bellwether technology shares continued their recent resurgence on optimism about improving demand in the computer industry. Intel jumped 23/16 , to 10111/16 ; Microsoft rose 2 3/8, to 136 3/8, and Dell Computer rose 2 7/8, to 84 7/8.
Overseas, before the American jobs report was released, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index slid 183.47 points, or nearly nine-tenths of a percent, to 21,148.03 but rose 35.79 on the week.

HEADLINE: Journal;
How Dole Fell

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
To understand why Bob Dole's Presidential quest is D.O.A. at the first debate, don't listen to pundits or White House spin artists but to a conservative Republican strategist in his party's trenches. A 103-page campaign document commissioned by Americans for a Republican Majority -- the political action committee headed by Tom DeLay, the House majority whip -- tells everything you need to know about why the Dole-Kemp campaign has failed.
The document, first uncovered by David Corn of The Nation and now gaining wider circulation among journalists, was written by Frank Luntz, the pollster who helped Newt Gingrich mastermind the Contract With America that heralded the G.O.P. Congressional sweep of '94. Based on 2,000 hours of focus groups and other voter research in the two years since, the report is an in-house guidebook instructing state and local Republican candidates nationwide on how to run best in the less hospitable climate of '96. The national ticket is never mentioned, but Mr. Luntz's advice can also be read retroactively as an unintended yet devastating commentary on the Dole political game plan. In almost every instance, the Presidential campaign is marching in the exact opposite direction of the often commonsensical Luntz prescriptions. 
 Rightly obsessed with the gender gap, Mr. Luntz prefaces his advice by noting that "the average American" is "a 32.7-year-old white woman." Such an electorate, he argues, is "harshly anti-partisan" in the aftermath of the Gingrich Congress's revolutionary bombast. "Voters don't want to hear candidates call each other ideological names," he writes, adding that "the angry, indignant, inflammatory approach" is a turn-off. Yet what is the latest Dole-Kemp tactic? Try to find a Dole sound bite or TV spot this week that doesn't feature the angry, indignant, inflammatory cry of "Liberal! Liberal! Liberal!"
Similarly, Mr. Luntz argues that G.O.P. candidates must talk about the future, should not talk about abortion ("a lose-lose situation"), should distance themselves from corporations that voters consider "special interests," and should play to Americans' hunger "for a sense of community" in "the world beyond their families." Mr. Dole, by contrast, has focused on his (and the country's) past, has repeatedly stumbled into abortion, has flaunted his connection to tobacco money and has trashed the communitarian rhetoric of "It Takes a Village."
But the most telling insights into Mr. Dole's travails can be found in the many pages the document devotes to any campaign's topic A -- the economy. It was Mr. Luntz's '94 polling that persuaded the G.O.P. to list the balanced-budget amendment as the No. 1 item in the Contract With America -- reflecting its pre-eminent popularity -- and, unsurprisingly, the appeal of a balanced budget remains undimmed today. In his recommendations for '96, Mr. Luntz urges that candidates talk about tax cuts by linking them to fiscally responsible spending cuts. Indeed, he writes that candidates shouldn't even use the phrase "tax cuts" but substitute "tax relief" instead -- given voter cynicism in the wake of broken Bush and Clinton pie-in-the-sky tax-cut promises.
What Mr. Luntz proposes is entirely consistent with Bob Dole's own career-long record as a deficit hawk. Or former record. This summer Mr. Dole reversed course, choosing to build his candidacy instead around exactly the kind of tax-cut promise that Mr. Luntz predicted would leave voters incredulous. Worse, Mr. Dole is vague about what spending cuts would pay for it. "Trusting the People," the book in which he and Jack Kemp outline their economic plan, is far more specific about what spending is exempt from cutting (Social Security, Medicare, defense -- half the Federal budget) than it is about wielding an ax. The free lunch of supply-side economics, we're asked to believe, will cover any shortfall.
If Bob Dole had been true to his own economic convictions, he wouldn't now be trying to sell a 15 percent tax-cut plan few Americans are buying, and he wouldn't have enabled a Democratic President, however preposterously and disingenuously, to steal the balanced-budget banner from the Republicans. Frank Luntz's playbook for a G.O.P. victory this year, tellingly enough, more often reads like a description of Bill Clinton's campaign than it does of Bob Dole's.
