HEADLINE: RITE OF ANGUISH: A special report.;
Genital Ritual Is Unyielding in Africa

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: MAN, Ivory Coast

 BODY:
Marthe Bleu is 12 years old, a shy, pretty girl with a heart-shaped face, dressed in flip-flops and a lacy white pinafore trimmed in pink satin. But already her body is taking on the soft, rounded shape of womanhood. And these days she wants more than anything to do what she believes stands between her and being grown up. She wants to have her genitals cut off.
In the lament of pubescent girls everywhere, she says that all her friends are getting ahead of her. Their parents have sent them into the woods where village women "cut what is down there," she said, gesturing to her lap. 
 After the rite, the girls are showered with gifts of money, jewelry and cloth. Their families honor them with celebrations where hundreds of relatives and friends feast on goat, cow and chicken.
"It is the custom, and I want to respect it," she said.
The tradition of female genital cutting is woven into the everyday life of the Yacouba people here, just as it is for hundreds of ethnic groups in a wide band of 28 countries across Africa. In Man, it is part of a girl's dreams of womanhood, a father's desire to show off with a big party and a family's way of proving its conformity to social convention.
The rising chorus of international condemnation of this age-old practice, voiced in recent years from the podiums of United Nations assemblies in Vienna, Cairo and Beijing, echoes only faintly in places like Man, a tourist town deep in the interior, surrounded by the craggy, cloud-shrouded Toura mountains.
On the coast, in the cosmopolitan hubbub of Abidjan, and in other parts of Africa, the debate about female genital cutting is slowly moving into the public arena. Only in the last few years have African nations even begun measuring the prevalence of genital cutting as part of national health surveys or in other research.
In the Ivory Coast and the Central African Republic, two out of five women have been cut. In Togo, it is one in eight. In the Sudan -- the only country that already had reliable national estimates -- it is 9 out of 10. In Mali, it is 93 percent.
"It looks like women in most countries are nearly as likely to undergo these procedures as their mothers and grandmothers," said Dara Carr, a researcher at Macro International Inc., the Maryland-based company that is assisting the countries in conducting the health surveys. "But there are some seeds of change."
In the Sudan, the prevalence of the practice has dropped from 96 percent to 89 percent over the course of a decade. And there has been a shift toward a less severe form of genital cutting. In Togo, a survey found that half of the mothers who had been cut wanted to spare their daughters. And while three-quarters of the women in Mali favor continuing the practice, a majority in the Central African Republic want to end it.
But what women want and what they have the power to accomplish are very different things. In most of the countries where tens of millions of girls and women have been cut, organizations have sprung up to combat the practice.
Like mosquitoes attacking an elephant, the small, ill-financed groups are struggling within societies where men rule women's lives, and old people, including old women, rule the young. There are, for example, Ivoirian laws against physical violence that could be used to stop the cutting, said Idrissa Fofana, a high-ranking official in the Justice Ministry.
But the Government has no interest in imposing them on unwilling families, antagonizing village chiefs and family elders who are pillars of society and guardians of tradition.
"If there was a complaint from parents that their child had been excised against their wishes, the Justice Ministry could pursue the case," Mr. Fofana said. "But if there is no complaint, we cannot disturb the peace of the family and the village."
Like most Yacouba girls in Man, Marthe Bleu is an eager initiate. But even if she resisted, her father, Jean-Baptiste Bleu, a trim, genial, neatly dressed waiter at a local hotel, would insist on her cutting.
"If your daughter has not been excised, the father is not allowed to speak at village meetings," he said. "No man in the village will marry her. It is an obligation. We have done it, we do it and we will continue to do it."
"She has no choice. I decide. Her viewpoint is not important."
The Bleus have not yet chosen who will cut Marthe, but not far from their home, through a maze of dirt pathways, lives Madeleine Douan, 47, one of the local excisers.
The tall, sinewy woman refused to show the ceremonial knife she uses, but brought out other accouterments of her calling: a long strand of metal bells and cloth sacks filled with bottle caps. While she cuts a group of 10 to 15 girls on the ground of the forest, other women shake the noisemakers, covering the cries of pain. Mrs. Douan herself sings traditional songs.
She introduced several of the girls she had recently cut. Natalie Sahi, 15, sat on the side of her thigh outside Mrs. Douan's windowless mud hut to avoid putting direct pressure on the wound. "I wanted it to happen," she said. "It's natural."
Patricia Vehgolou, 13, her hair neatly braided in corn rows, buried her face in her hands and would only giggle when asked if the cutting hurt. Mrs. Douan explained that the girls must swear before leaving the forest that they will not share the secrets of the rite with the uninitiated.
The purpose of the cutting, Mrs. Douan said, is to help insure a woman's fidelity to her husband and her family. "It's a tradition from antiquity," she said. A woman's role in life is to care for her children, keep house and cook. If she has not been cut, Mrs. Douan said, a woman might think instead about her own sexual pleasure.
 
The Origins
Pride, Tradition And Ignored Risks
It is not known when, where or why the practice of female genital cutting originated. Scholars believe that it started in Egypt or the Horn of Africa more than 2,000 years ago, before the advent of Christianity or Islam. It then spread west across the continent, all the way to the Atlantic Ocean, with the migration of dominant tribes and civilizations.
The practice knows no class or religious boundaries. Most prevalent among Muslims, it is also performed by Christians and followers of traditional African religions. The practice is more widespread among the illiterate, but it is also common among the educated.
The nature of the cutting, the reasons for it and the age at which it is done vary greatly by region and ethnic group.
The practice involves amputating some or all of the external genitalia -- the clitoris, the small genital lips and the large ones -- diminishing a woman's ability to experience sexual pleasure. It can also cause serious health problems, including hemorrhaging and infection.
Typically, the cutting is done by traditional village women without anything to dull the pain. But sometimes, when midwives or nurses are brought in to do the job, they apply a local anesthetic.
Many believe that cutting helps insure a girl's virginity before marriage and fidelity afterward by reducing sex to a marital obligation. Often, people follow the custom simply because it has always been done.
"Children are born and the parents do it," said Awa Kone, a Malian washerwoman in Abidjan, who plans to take her baby daughter, Kadia, to an exciser in the near future.
In the Horn of Africa -- Djibouti, Somalia, the Sudan and parts of Ethiopia -- the most severe and harmful form of cutting, infibulation, is practiced.
In this procedure, the clitoris and some or all of the small genital lips are cut away. Then an incision is made in the large lips so the raw surfaces can be stitched together, covering the urethra and most of the vagina. Only a small opening, as tiny as a matchstick or as large as a small fingertip, is left to pass urine and menstrual blood, said Nahid Toubia, a Sudanese surgeon who is an associate professor at Columbia University.
Infibulation comes with its own set of rationales. Some men say the artificial tightness heightens their sexual enjoyment. The smoothness of the scar is found esthetically beautiful. And the stitching itself forms a chastity belt of flesh.
There is a common thread to all forms of cutting. Economic realities underlie the practice. Women typically have no way to survive without a husband. Parents insist on the rite so their daughters are marriageable.
"People do know the health risks," said Ellen Gruenbaum, a medical anthropologist at California State University, San Bernardino. "They have seen people get sick. On rare occasions, a girl might die. But you will not change people's minds by preaching to them or telling them they're primitive. They undertake the risks for reasons important to them."
After the cutting, more pain lies ahead. Women who have endured the more extreme forms of the practice have particularly agonizing and complicated deliveries. The scarring narrows the vaginal opening and makes the flesh inelastic, doctors and midwives say. The pressure of a baby's emerging head often causes grave tearing of the vagina.
Women who bear a child in their villages without a doctor to widen the vagina surgically sometimes arrive torn and bleeding at the Maternal Health Center in Man. On occasion, the tearing goes up into the urethra and bladder, down into the anus, as well as side to side. The women must then be sent to a hospital in Abidjan for surgery.
Clautilde Yenon, a midwife at the health center, tried to think of a way to convey the excruciating damage. Finally, she had an idea. She picked up a sheet of paper and ripped it into jagged pieces.
 
The Policy
Official Reluctance To Oppose Custom
Ivoirian officials, working in skyscrapers that form Abidjan's sawtoothed profile, talked a good deal in interviews about the evils of genital cutting, but then conceded that their ministries have done little to put words into action.
The Ministry of Public Health is planning a campaign to educate people about the health consequences of the practice, often referred to here as excision and sometimes as female circumcision, but there is as yet no budget or staff to carry it out.
Narcisse Ehoussou, an obstetrician who heads the ministry's reproductive health program, told this story to explain the slow pace of change:
"A French doctor of public health once went to western Ivory Coast. He was horrified by what he saw, people with goiters on their necks. When he returned, he asked, 'Why don't you study this?' He was told, 'We don't study it because it is normal.' For women, excision is normal.
"You have to be patient in Africa. Just as it was difficult to convince people to accept family planning, so it is with excision."
It is not surprising that the Ivoirian Government is loath to take on genital cutting, despite the existence of laws that could be used to stop it. Like most African countries, the Ivory Coast is composed of many ethnic groups. Some practice it. Others, including that of President Henri Konan Bedie, the Baule, do not. There is generally great tolerance for differing traditions, and a reluctance to disturb the sometimes uneasy political balance.
"A judge's role is to maintain public order, but by combating excision, he would disturb public order," said Mr. Fofana, of the Justice Ministry. "We cannot impose the law suddenly. The law we have was inspired by the French colonizers. It does not take account of customs."
Such views aggravate Tomam Constance Yai, a speech therapist for deaf children and the Ivory Coast's leading crusader against genital cutting. "For our Government, violence against women is not a public disturbance," she said ironically.
Ms. Yai, whose grandmother was an exciser, founded the Ivoirian Association for the Defense of Women's Rights four years ago. It is a grand name for a small group of volunteers who fight ingrained cultural practices like forced marriage, polygamy and genital cutting.
With wily charm, Ms. Yai is pushing the Government to act, careful not to favor the aggressive prosecution of excisers or offending parents. Such tactics, she says, would only drive the practice underground. Rather, she wants to bring an educational campaign to the Government-controlled television stations, as well as schools, hospitals and clinics.
International pressure gives her group what little strength it has, she said: "If it were only our association, our Government would ignore us. They would say we're just a small group of foolish women."
So far, the pressure has mainly taken the form of verbal denunciations at United Nations gatherings. In Beijing, at the Fourth World Conference on Women, Hillary Rodham Clinton called it a human rights violation "when young girls are brutalized by the painful and degrading practice of genital mutilation."
Some human rights groups maintain that Western governments should link foreign aid negotiations with progress on the issue. But in the Ivory Coast, diplomats from the United States, which provides no direct aid to the Ivoirian Government, though it is supporting an AIDS research project, and France, the country's former colonial ruler and biggest aid donor, are reluctant to press the Ivoirian Government on the issue.
"It's a matter principally for local society to determine the extent to which these practices are to be tolerated," said Thomas G. Hart, a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Abidjan.
Emmanuel Gagniarre, a spokesman for the French Embassy in Abidjan, said: "This is a marginal problem. It's important, but to feed people is probably more important. I don't think it can be an issue when negotiations take place on aid provided to African countries."
 
The Ceremony
Sudden Agony, Then Celebration
In Man, a girl's rite of passage culminates in a day of joyous, enveloping pageantry. But the powerful pull of belonging to the group does not always overwhelm private doubts about the intimate consequences of the practice.
Jean-Baptiste Bleu, the waiter who plans to have his daughter cut, said he has slept with women who have not been cut and married one who has. A woman who has been cut is difficult to arouse, the sex often dry, he said. Yacouba men talk among themselves about how to excite their wives -- what places to caress, what words to whisper.
Without equivocation, he said, sex with an uncut woman is much better. "She is happy, joyous," said Mr. Bleu, who is 39.
Still, he believes the cutting is a duty. His daughters must endure the rite courageously, without showing their pain or fear, he said.
His wife, Yvonne, 31, said she will defer to his wishes, but she despises the practice because it deprives women of sexual sensitivity. "It is up to my husband," she said. "We live in Africa. The man makes the decisions about the children."
Several other women whose families rent rooms around the same courtyard as the Bleus pulled up a chair to join the talk. Not all were as emotionally torn.
Margarite Lou, 31, fondly remembered the celebration that followed the rite -- the lavish gifts, the applause of the villagers, the feast. And she lustily asserted that she very much enjoys sex, despite having undergone one of the more extreme forms of cutting. Even her scar is sensitive, she said.
Mrs. Lou dismissed notions that the cutting is harmful to a woman's health, passing on an old wives' tale. "It's easier to give birth if you're excised," she said. "There are no lips to close the opening of the vagina."
Twelve-year-old Marthe Bleu was then playing across the courtyard, as innocent of the bawdy talk that day as she is of sex itself. For her, womanhood beckons. And genital cutting is the portal she must walk through to enter it.
"I feel my friends are better than me because they have been cut down there," she had said earlier, her hands twisting in her lap. "It's very difficult, but I want to do it."

HEADLINE: U.S. REPORTS DROP IN RATE OF BIRTHS TO UNWED WOMEN

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
For the first time in nearly two decades, the rate of births among unmarried women declined in 1995, and for the fourth year in a row the teen-age birth rate dropped, the National Center for Health Statistics said today.
The out-of-wedlock birth rate dropped to 44.9 live births per 1,000 unmarried women last year, down from 46.9 births in 1994, a decline of 4 percent, according to a report by the agency, a division of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. 
 At the same time, the birth rate for teen-agers declined to 56.9 births per 1,000 girls in 1995, from 58.9 births the year before, for girls 15 to 19.
Both the rates for out-of-wedlock births and for teen-age births are part of a general decline in the nation's birth rate. For the fifth consecutive year, the total number of births decreased and the birth rate of 14.8 births per 1,000 population was the lowest level in 20 years.
Analysts say about half of the decline in the out-of-wedlock birth rate stemmed from changes in reporting births in California, so that children whose parents had different surnames were no longer automatically considered to have been born out of wedlock. The analysts noted that 37 percent of the country's Hispanic babies were born to California residents last year, and so the reporting change resulted in fewer Hispanic infants' being counted erroneously as out-of-wedlock births.
Even with the change in reporting, the one-year drop in out-of-wedlock births and some related statistical markers is significant, analysts said.
"There is still a real decline," said Stephanie Ventura, a demographer with the National Center for Health Statistics and the author of its report.
While the drop in both the out-of-wedlock rate and the rate in teen-age births are its most eye-catching features, the report, "Births and Deaths: United States, 1995," included a wealth of data indicating that some of the nation's most troubling social trends appear to be abating, although only slightly in some areas:
*Homicide rates fell by 15 percent, when adjusted to factor in the aging of the general population. It was the largest decline among the leading causes of deaths in 1995, and the decrease was double that of the decline of 1994 against 1993, and continued the nationwide trend in lower homicide rates.
*Infant mortality rates reached a record low of 7.5 babies per 1,000 live births, a 6 percent drop from 1994.
*For the first time since 1987, when AIDS began to be listed separately as a cause of death and became the leading killer in certain age groups, the rate of death stayed steady. Still, the total number of deaths from AIDS reached a record high last year, 42,506.
*Overall life expectancy reached 75.8 years last year, tying the previous record high reached in 1992. Life expectancy for black males also rose, to 65.4 years, the highest level since 1985, when AIDS deaths and sharp increases in homicides began to afflict inner-city neighborhoods.
Today's report is another set of favorable figures coming from a Federal agency in recent days. Last week, the Census Bureau reported that for the first time in six years, inflation-adjusted family incomes increased, and that poverty rates registered their largest decline in more than 10 years.
As he did last week with regard to the income figures, President Clinton quickly seized upon today's report as evidence that his policies were beginning to bear fruit, even though the statistical report is based on 1995 data and some of the policies he cited were not in effect until this year.
In an advance copy of his weekly Saturday radio address, Mr. Clinton declared that stepped-up enforcement of child support laws, and a 1996 executive order requiring young mothers to stay in school or live with their parents in order to keep welfare assistance, have helped produce "progress" in turning around the epidemic of teen-age pregnancy and out-of-wedlock births.
"The American family is getting stronger and we are making responsibility a way of life," Mr. Clinton said. "Our economy and our society are on the right track."
But Bob Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee, said that if Mr. Clinton was going to take credit for the drop in out-of-wedlock births and teen-age pregnancy, then he should also take responsibility for the marked increase in drug use among teen-agers that has occurred in recent years.
"If Clinton admits that a strong voice from the White House can make a difference in changing teen behavior, then why has he been silent as a million new young people have started using drugs?" the Dole campaign said in a statement.
But others who have studied the issue insist that no one can say with certainty why the birth rates for teen-agers and single women are falling. The last drop was in 1976, when the out-of-wedlock rate was 24.3 per 1,000, down from 24.5 in 1975.
Demographers are awaiting the results of "The National Survey of Family Growth," a major study that will be produced this year by the Government for the first time since 1988. The study will include data on sexual activity, contraceptive use and other issues that could shed light on declining birth rates.
There is evidence from previous reports by the National Center for Health Statistics that sexual activity among teen-agers has waned, analysts say.
"While we don't have firm data yet for the middle of the 1990's, it seems that the big increase we had in the proportion of girls and guys who were sexually active as teens seems to have leveled off," said Jacqueline Darroch Forrest, vice president for research at the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a nonprofit organization that does research on sexual issues and favors abortion rights.
And there is also evidence of an increased use of longer-lasting birth control methods, like Norplant, which is implanted under the skin and lasts for five years, and Depo-Provera, an injectable hormone that is effective for several months. Experts say condom use is also growing, primarily because of AIDS.
Yet conservative analysts do not attribute part of the decline in teen-age sexual activity to increased use of contraceptives. Instead, they say, the drop is influenced by increased abstinence among teen-agers.
"There is a new wave of virgins," said Gracie Hsu, a policy analyst with the Family Research Council, a conservative organization. "They are proud to be pure. They are boldly claiming their purity."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;
For Philadelphia Blacks, Clinton Is 'the Lesser of Two Evils'

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Derrick Rhamad is the kind of voter the Republicans say they have been dreaming about to help them retake the White House next month. He is a 32-year-old black bank investigator, who advocates boot-strap capitalism and a strong military. He denounces "welfare dependency," high taxes and soft-on-crime liberals.
He is a volunteer coach for his 9-year-old son's Little League football team in Philadelphia's integrated, middle-class Mount Airy neighborhood, and he admires Jack Kemp, the former professional quarterback and current Republican Vice-Presidential candidate who has been aggressively reaching out to black voters on behalf of the party and its Presidential nominee, Bob Dole. 
 "I'm a Republican," Mr. Rhamad said proudly the other evening as dusk fell fast and cool over the practice field. "I like Jack Kemp a lot, but I don't like Bob Dole. I'm voting for Clinton this year."
Yet Mr. Rhamad, and more than a dozen other black voters interviewed on the streets of Philadelphia who said they intended to vote for Mr. Clinton, showed little enthusiasm for their choice. Many said Mr. Clinton was their pick by default and through fear of what a Republican in the White House might do to the social safety net at which even the Democratic President has been hacking away. One called Mr. Clinton "a Reagan Democrat." And the phrase on the lips of almost everyone comparing him to Mr. Dole was "the lesser of two evils."
Camille Edwards, a 27-year-old social worker, said she was especially upset with Mr. Clinton for signing the welfare legislation because it will lead to more crime. "People will be robbing left and right just to eat," she said. "Nobody is going to allow their children to starve." Nevertheless, she said, she would vote for Mr. Clinton hoping he "will act more like a Democrat" in a second term.
"I don't think Clinton is the black man's friend by any means," Ms. Edwards said as she shopped along Germantown Avenue with her friend, Vanessa Walker, a 31-year-old nurse's aid. "He's kind of like Abe Lincoln who freed the slaves almost by accident."
Ms. Walker was much more enthusiastic about the President. "Clinton. Clinton. Clinton," she said. "A lot of people are registering to vote because if Bob Dole gets in, we are going to catch hell."
Still, most of the voters interviewed said they thought that the welfare system needed reform, and that too many people had turned welfare into "a way of life." But although most had jobs, from college professors to a laundromat manager, all expressed concern for the millions of Americans who were homeless and hungry, and the millions more who were just slightly better off.
"Dole wants to cut, cut, cut," Mr. Rhamad said, his coach's whistle dangling around his neck. "He's too much like Reagan. We need more programs for the kids, more places for them to go to get off the streets. But Dole wants to cut too much out."
Not one voter said they would support Mr. Dole, certainly not 70-year-old Ozell Liggett, who, like Mr. Dole, is a veteran of World War II. Mr. Liggett said he thought the former Senator was living too much in the past, reaching back with his proposed 15 percent tax cut to revive the "voodoo economics of Reagan."
"Dole also talks too damn much about his war wounds," Mr. Liggett added. "I have war wounds too. I got hurt at Guadalcanal but I don't talk about it all the time. That was 50 years ago."
As for Mr. Kemp and his overtures to black voters, Mr. Liggett, who has voted in every election since he got out of the Army in 1946, said he was not impressed. Politicians, he said, will say almost anything to win.
"They always talk black around election time," he said.
Oscar Pettigrew, 23, said he would vote for the first time in November but would not be happy about it.
"I don't like any of the candidates," said Mr. Pettigrew, who works at his mother's day-care center in the Germantown section of Philadelphia. "But I'm going to vote for Clinton. At least he tries to do a little something, even though he really hasn't done anything for the black community."
Mr. Pettigrew, who said he knew he was lucky to have a job when so many people his age were out of work and desperate, said he could not think of a political leader on the scene that he admired or would vote for without reluctance. He said he did not trust the Government, especially after recent news reports, based on articles in the San Jose Mercury News, alleging that the C.I.A. might have been involved in supplying crack in Los Angeles in the early 1980's to help pay for the United States-backed contra war in Central America.
"The best leader I ever saw," he said, "is my father. He says we can't wait for the Government. We have got to do it ourselves."
Philbert Young, 38, who owns a landscaping business, agreed with Mr. Clinton's decision to sign the welfare legislation "because a lot of people want to make welfare a way of life." But he said he would vote for the President holding his nose.
"Politicians are all talk," he said.
Anthony Monteiro, a professor of sociology at the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science, said in a telephone interview that he is tired of voting for the lesser of two evils.
Mr. Monteiro said he will not vote for President this year but will vote in his Congressional race. He said he has been leery of Mr. Clinton for years because of the President's rightward shifts. But it was Mr. Clinton's signing of the welfare legislation "that pushed me over the edge."
"That bill will throw one million children into poverty," he said, his voice raising on the other end of the telephone. "Clinton has literally become a Reagan Democrat. And Dole is a Reagan Republican. I don't think there is a lesser of two evils in this race. There's just evil."
For Linn Washington Jr., a journalism professor at Temple University, the choice between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole boils down to which man "am I going to oppose."
"I'm going to oppose the conservative movement in the country as symbolized by Bob Dole," Mr. Washington said. "Don't get me wrong, Clinton has not excited me at all, either."
With two children in college, Mr. Washington, 45, said he thought Mr. Clinton was more sympathetic than Mr. Dole about his major concerns -- education and taxes.
"The man has a good heart," Mr. Washington said of Mr. Clinton. "But his head is too focused on being re-elected instead of leading the country. He has pandered much too much."
Back at the park in Mount Airy, where the football players were practicing in the falling night, the sound of colliding shoulder pads floating over the damp field, Pat McBride leaned on a green fence to watch her son, Michael.
Mrs. McBride, 44, is a welfare case worker. She was tired, but her husband, Keith, a firefighter, was at work, so she had to come with her son to practice. She said many more children, especially in cities, desperately needed sports and other programs to keep them from the street and its many temptations and dangers.
"I think Clinton cares more about the little people," she said. "But it's still a question for me of the lesser of two evils. I don't like that he signed the welfare bill. A lot of my clients don't want to be on welfare. They have no choice. With all the downsizing going on, jobs are hard to find."
"That's what the election should be all about," she said, gesturing to the field. "Making the future better for our children. I just hope the politicians understand that."

HEADLINE: A Dominican Leader Receives an Official Embrace

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
As he rushed between appointments yesterday, Leonel Fernandez Reyna took a moment to reminisce about his days as a grocery delivery boy on the Upper West Side. He even managed to come up with a name: Mr. Meyers, the owner of the store where he worked on Amsterdam Avenue, between 95th and 96th Streets.
There was no need for him to say how far he had come. This soft-spoken Dominican immigrant came to the United States with his parents at age 7, returned to his native country as a teen-ager, became a lawyer and politician, and returned to New York City this week for his first visit as President of the Dominican Republic. "It's coming home," Mr. Fernandez, who is 42 and a divorced father of two young children, said on a sidewalk in midtown Manhattan. New York City, he said, "has always been part of me." 
 He has returned, though, on very different terms, with a reception by the city's political and economic elite that he said has astonished him. In the last three days, he addressed the United Nations, hobnobbed with business people, was lauded by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and was courted by three potential candidates for mayor, receiving attention that reflects the growing clout of the half million or so Dominican immigrants in the city.
Unlike other visits, this has been much more a tour of the halls of power than a reunion on the city streets, where he is popular among Dominicans because he shares the experience of being an immigrant here. As of last night, he had not visited his old elementary school, Public School 75, or popped into Coogan's Pub in Washington Heights, which he said this week was his usual first stop from the airport.
"I haven't had the time," Mr. Fernandez said, in his perfect English. "It's very much official business, what I have been doing."
But then, like a good politician remembering the source of his power, he halted for a second and said he did, in fact, expect to visit with ordinary Dominicans sometime before he leaves tomorrow.
"I definitely will do that -- today or tomorrow," said Mr. Fernandez, who took office in August. (His aides said later that he expected to make a trip to the headquarters of his party, the Dominican Liberation Party, in Washington Heights today.)
Most Dominicans interviewed said they would not be too concerned if Mr. Fernandez attended more to affairs of state on this trip. He is, after all, still very much in his honeymoon period, a youthful politician with a boyish face and mustache who has begun to reinvigorate his nation's politics after replacing Joaquin Balaguer, who is 89 and now blind. Despite a furor over his raising his salary to $6,000 a month from the $150 a month his predecessor earned, he is seen as a vibrant, charismatic leader.
He has also made specific efforts to reach out to the estimated one million Dominicans who live in the United States. Last month, after Congress passed legislation aimed at depriving legal immigrants of various public benefits, Mr. Fernandez urged Dominicans who are eligible to become United States citizens -- reminding them that they would not lose their Dominican citizenship.
"It will be an opportunity for them to actively participate in politics," he said. "There will also be more concerns for Dominican interests." He added another reason: One-third of the income in the Dominican Republic is provided by the roughly $1 billion that Dominicans abroad ship annually to relatives at home.
The move was popular among local Dominicans, who have been signing up for citizenship in record numbers, according to city officials. That was part of the reason that Ligia Guzman, who works for the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service, pushed her way in to shake Mr. Fernandez's hand after a ceremony at City Hall.
"Dominicans here were considered people who were not worthy," said Ms. Guzman, who moved to the United States 35 years ago. "We were treated like money machines. This President is not like that. He's willing to fix the problems."
Even though Mr. Fernandez has not spent much time in Dominican communities on this trip, he has run into Dominicans everywhere. At a press breakfast at the St. Regis Hotel on Thursday, one of the waiters was Fausto Franco, a 35-year-old native Dominican who is now a United States citizen. At the City Hall reception, Imelda Rodriguez, 27, carried plates of smoked salmon on rye.
"He's young and we need someone with new ideas," said Ms. Rodriguez.
Mr. Fernandez arrived in New York on Wednesday afternoon, as part of an annual celebration of Dominican culture at events around the nation. He promoted his agenda on several fronts. He has met with business groups to spur investment in tourism and in state-owned businesses he is trying to privatize. He became the first Dominican President in more than a decade to address the United Nations.
He had meetings with Mayor Giuliani and John Cardinal O'Connor. At a ceremony with members of the City Council, he received three proclamations as two potential Democratic rivals in next year's mayoral race, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi and the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth Messinger, praised him.
"I just didn't know I was going to be the object of so much honor here," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In his first visit to New York City as President of the Dominican Republic, Leonel Ferenandez Reyna, center, mingled with members of the city's Dominican community and political and business leaders this week. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New York Legislature Needs Reform, Not Raises

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Although the title of your editorial "Sneaky Pay Raises" is right on, the premise that New York state legislators, the second-highest-paid state legislators in the country after California's, deserve a pay raise is highly questionable. 
 If merit is the basis for a pay increase, this group would be in line for a pay cut. This year's state budget was the latest in history. The population of the state continues to stagnate, while our economic base and national political clout decline. Our taxes are among the highest in the nation, yet our basic services and funds for education are shrinking. Add to their accomplishments the creation of a state work force demoralized by several years of wage freezes and heavy layoffs, and the proposal that these legislators deserve a raise indicates the depth of their contempt for the views of the citizenry they supposedly serve.
As you note, the Legislature hasconsistently opposed opening up the political process (only reluctantly passing reforms for the primaries this year). If one reform in particular, the right to citizens' initiatives, were in effect, no doubt one of the first initiatives would be to submit to voter approval any legislative pay raises and the questionable practice of representatives paying themselves extra for committee assignments.
One can reasonably venture that the vast majority of New Yorkers strongly oppose the raises as well as the underhanded manner in which they are being advanced. Only Gov. George E. Pataki stands in the way of the Senate and Assembly's avarice and cowardly tactics.
Let's hope that rather than supporting their sneaky money grab, he will assert the will of the people and restore some semblance of government integrity by vetoing the pay raise.
 
DAVID POLAND
Ithaca, N.Y., Sept. 30, 1996

HEADLINE: PLAYOFFS;
Rogers Is the Enemy In His Own Backyard

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Tex., Oct. 4

 BODY:
Kenny Rogers lives two minutes from the Ballpark in Arlington, close enough to see dozens of tents snaked around the stadium for fans waiting to purchase possible Rangers World Series tickets.
It is close enough to hear the chilling sound of Juan Gonzalez's batting practice and to hear the whispers: The Rangers do not like him anymore. They want to punish him. 
 As a Yankee, Rogers knows he is the enemy in the town that was his baseball home for the first seven years of his career. He knows he will be booed and expects it.
Players shuffle from team to team like rental cars these days, so allegiances fizzle faster than an economy car on empty, even for a pitcher who is fifth in Rangers history with 70 victories.
"Sometimes, I still have to catch myself when I'm talking about the Yankees and the Rangers," Rogers said before Game 3 on Friday. "I'll say 'us' for Texas and 'we' for New York. It's weird."
While Rogers rocked on a chair in the visiting clubhouse, sweating after a workout, it was obvious he felt confusion about facing his former teammates in Game 4 Saturday.
"I'd like to prove something to them," said Rogers, who is 16-6 with a 3.32 earned run average in his career at the Ballpark. "I'm sure it's the same thing with them. They want to beat me worse than other pitchers. I was with them, so I'd like to prove something. You want to prove you're a capable player like you know you are. Hey, I know I did a good job for them."
It would be ironic if Rogers -- who signed a four-year, $20 million free agent contract with the Yankees last Nov. 21 and said, "I wanted to play for a winner" -- is the obstacle between the Rangers and the A.L.C.S. on Saturday.
The Rangers offered Rogers $17.5 million and then read Rogers's comments; they even taped them on the wall in spring training for motivation, and they went on to win their division title.
Saturday will be a day in which someone gets redemption. "I've thought about it," Rogers said.
In a season in which Rogers once threatened to tear up his $20 million deal after he was temporarily moved to the bullpen, a season in which he has labored with inflammation in his left shoulder since April and has constantly incurred Torre's wrath, Rogers's next hurdle involves foiling the players who used to sit next to him in the clubhouse.
Or else.
"I've got to block it out," Rogers said. "To say I don't think about that would not be honest. It's a different feeling. It's something you had. Those guys were behind me and I know them so well. It should be a little easier to get more comfortable."
A broad smile spread across Rogers's face as he talked about being happy about the Rangers' success. For now, the Rangers are more popular than the Dallas Cowboys, which never happened when he played in Arlington.
Even though he is part of the post-season spectacle in his hometown, Rogers feels odd.
"It's weird, a weird feeling," Rogers said. "When it's the organization that you grew up with, it becomes you. I felt comfortable with everything about the Rangers. This is the way I always thought it was going to be for the Rangers."
Except Rogers is wearing a different uniform.

HEADLINE: The Ups and Downs Of U.S. Capitalism

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Harvey Mallement (letter, Sept. 27) needlessly castigates Russell Baker for a colorful comment about those who "convert human misfortune into good numbers for Wall Street." Contrary to Mr. Mallement, this comment does not disserve the nation and its history. Capitalism and Wall Street are not identical. 
 Mr. Mallement is correct that many great achievements can be attributed to capitalism, but many bad things are part of it, too: child labor, unemployment, poverty. That is why we have a "mixed economy," with legislation and other factors placing limits on "pure" capitalism. In fact, no country anywhere has ever had unrestricted capitalism.
 
MARGARET DRAY
Corvallis, Ore., Sept. 27, 1996
 
The writer is a retired economist.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: STATE BY STATE -- New Jersey;
Dole Hopes Whitman's Magic Works for Him

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 3

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman is the Republicans' good-luck charm. In Michigan, in Florida, almost everywhere, party operatives inoculate themselves against discouraging polls and apathetic voters by recalling the New Jersey Governor's stirring last-minute escape from what seemed sure defeat in 1993, largely on the strength of a pledge to slash taxes.
If it worked for her, Republicans say, bravely whistling their happy tune, it can work for Bob Dole -- at least in New Jersey, a swing state with an aversion to high taxes. 
 "You can't transpose it 100 percent," the Governor said cautiously one afternoon this week in her Newark office. "There are parallels. Jim Florio, whom I beat, had said he wouldn't raise taxes and did it anyway. Bill Clinton promised a middle-class tax cut and raised taxes instead. Like Dole, I ran way behind for weeks. I think I was 10 percent behind on the final weekend."
Mrs. Whitman chose not to enumerate them, but there are important differences as well. She was fresh, upbeat, winning on television; Mr. Dole says he is "the most optimistic man in America," but he neither sounds it nor looks it. He carries more political baggage than she did. More important, perhaps, Governor Florio, a flawed campaigner, was very unpopular; President Clinton, a campaign virtuoso, is better liked.
"This tax-cut gambit was just as desperate a ploy for her as it is for Dole, maybe more so," said Michael Aaron, the political correspondent for New Jersey public television. "But it was so much nicer and more persuasive, coming out of her mouth. She hadn't spent years saying spending cuts first, tax cuts later, the way he has. Remember, too, the whole idea has been discounted a bit in New Jersey; we've had our tax cut, and it hasn't transformed our lives."
The biggest problem for Mr. Dole, Mrs. Whitman conceded, is the unpopularity of his (and his party's) stand against abortion, which is hurting him with Republican and independent women in suburbs across America.
Just as Republican Presidential candidates persuaded blue-collar suburban men to abandon their party loyalties and become Nixon or Reagan Democrats, Mr. Dole is driving away middle-class suburban women, turning "soccer moms" into Clinton Republicans.
For electoral purposes, New Jersey consists largely of two conglomerations of suburbs, one adjacent to New York City and one adjacent to Philadelphia, connected by a turnpike and a railroad. So the problem is acute here.
"Dole is talking about issues that matter to women, issues like the economy, education, crime," said the Governor, herself an advocate of abortion rights. "But they don't hear him. If you're a Republican and you're not pro-choice, you tend to get filtered out."
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, 45, an ambitious, intensely partisan Democrat who is seeking the Senate seat being vacated by Bill Bradley, also a Democrat, agrees with that.
"Christie Whitman won because of taxes, yes, but first she had to cross the threshold test that applies in New Jersey," he said. "She had to show she was a social moderate on issues like gun control, abortion and the environment. I don't see any way that Senator Dole can possibly cross that threshold."
His own polls, Mr. Torricelli said, show him with a slight lead over his Republican rival, Representative Dick Zimmer. The margin, he added, results entirely from disproportionate support by middle-income suburban women.
There is a threshold test for Democrats, too, showing that they are not big-spending liberals. "It was no accident," Mr. Torricelli conceded, that he was one of 22 House Democrats who voted for the Republican tax-cut bill this year, or that he pressed a cut in capital-gains taxes on the White House. He also brags that some of his speeches have been drafted by Jude Wanniski, a New Jersey Republican, supply-side economic theorist and supporter of Jack Kemp.
But Mr. Torricelli voted, as Republican television commercials note, for the tax increase of 1993.
With 15 electoral votes, the nation's ninth-largest bloc, New Jersey is important for Mr. Dole, especially because big states like California, New York and Illinois seem beyond his reach, and he trails in battlegrounds like Ohio, Michigan and Florida. But here, too, Mr. Clinton is leading in polls by 10 to 15 percentage points.
Television, the underdog's friend, is of limited use in New Jersey, because reaching the bulk of the state's voters that way means buying time on New York and Philadelphia stations, only a fraction of whose viewers live in New Jersey. Much of the cost is "wasted." So Mr. Dole will tour the state on Monday and Tuesday by bus, hoping to stir up some enthusiasm and to generate a substantial turnout, in Republican strongholds like Bergen and Morris counties.
"We think it is a competitive state for us," said Dean R. Armandroff, the director of Mr. Dole's campaign in New Jersey.
An unspoken reason that a vigorous Dole campaign is needed here is the races for the Senate and the House, several of which are competitive.
Mr. Zimmer, who is running even or close to it in public polls, might win even if Mr. Dole loses. The state has a long history of ticket-splitting, with Senator Frank Lautenberg, a Democrat, winning in 1988 when George Bush carried the state; Mr. Bradley winning in 1984, when Ronald Reagan scored here, and Clifford Case, the state's last Republican Senator, winning in 1960 despite John F. Kennedy's victory here and nationwide.
But if he is to buck a Clinton tide, Mr. Zimmer will need to turn out Republican voters. Stephen Falmore, a professor at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, who advises Republican candidates, warned that "the public, including Republicans, is not really engaged in this campaign yet, and we don't know whether they ever will be, which makes it hard to predict."
Not that Mr. Torricelli and Mr. Zimmer have not given the voters a show, or tried to. Politics is never ballroom dancing in New Jersey, but this year's Senate campaign is particularly nasty. This week Mr. Zimmer embraced charges that Mr. Torricelli had improperly aided the daughter of a Korean fugitive from United States courts, a former legal client. Mr. Torricelli has attacked the sources of Mr. Zimmer's campaign contributions, especially the tobacco industry, charging that the Republican "has chosen cigarette money over children's health."
If Mr. Torricelli fits uncomfortably into a liberal pigeonhole on some issues, Mr. Zimmer is an unconventional conservative. A hard-liner on fiscal questions, he chose as his campaign consultant Arthur Finkelstein, who specializes in branding opponents as too liberal. (Shortly after Mr. Dole hired two Finkelstein proteges, he began denouncing Mr. Clinton as "liberal, liberal, liberal!")
A graying, understated 52-year-old, Mr. Zimmer is nonetheless highly rated by some environmental groups, he supports abortion rights and he once ran the New Jersey office of Common Cause, the leftish advocacy group. Little-known statewide, he said his big problem was "letting people know that I'm the greener candidate and that I'm a Republican who has always been solidly pro-choice."
In their drive to retain control of the House, the Republicans hope to hang on to the district Mr. Zimmer represents, which cuts across the state from Princeton to the Atlantic. But two abortion-rights supporters split the primary vote, allowing a little-known foe of abortion, Mike Pappas, to snatch the nomination. Mayor David M. Delvecchio of Lambertville, the Democratic nominee, has mounted a vigorous challenge, but he is no more familiar to voters than Mr. Pappas.
The Republicans are also struggling to avoid a loss by Representative Bill Martini, one of their 1994 freshmen. His main difficulty, local politicians say, is not his opponent, Mayor William J. Pascrell of Paterson, but a voting record, shaped in part by the Contract With America, that is considerably more conservative than his district. This race is rated one of the closest in the country by Congressional Quarterly, and it could be tipped one way or the other by the Presidential race in the state.
So could the contest for Mr. Torricelli's seat. Centered on Hackensack in Bergen County, it includes a significant part of heavily Democratic Hudson County. Nevertheless, the Republican nominee, Kathleen A Donovan, a former Bergen County Clerk, has been holding her own in the polls against the Democratic candidate, Steve Rothman, a surrogate.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 10, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Presidential politics in New Jersey misspelled the surnames of the political correspondent for New Jersey public television and a professor at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University who advises Republican candidates. The reporter is Michael Aron, not Aaron; the professor is Stephen Salmore, not Falmore.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
A Little More Room At the Inn? Yes and No.

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
AFTER 56 consecutive months in which the hotel occupancy rate exceeded that of the same month in the previous year, the United States lodging industry finally experienced a downturn -- dropping to 73.9 percent this July from 74.1 percent in July 1995. Those are the latest figures available from Smith Travel Research, which tracks U.S. lodging industry performance.
But before anyone supposes that the hotel industry is about to return to the red ink of the late 1980's through 1990, when a glut of hotels and a weak economy resulted in rooms routinely being sold at deep discounts, keep in mind that the 0.2 percent drop from last July to this is statistically insignificant. And despite that modest dip, average room rates this July rose by 7.4 percent over July 1995, to $71.44, the biggest monthly increase since the early 1980's, an era of double digit inflation. 
 What's more, there has been no falloff in occupancy or room rates in such major tourist destinations as Orlando, Las Vegas, New York, San Francisco, Boston, Philadelphia, Los Angeles or San Diego. As many travelers learned to their regret, for much of this year most of the desirable hotels in those cities have been at or near capacity. Orlando occupancy, for example, has been up almost 6 percent this year through July and room rates have been up 5 percent. New York occupancy has risen 4.9 percent through 1996 despite a 9.4 percent increase in room rates, to an average of $140.82 -- far higher than runner-up Oahu Island, at $107.92, and third place San Francisco, at $103.83.
"Our four New York properties have been very, very busy almost the entire year," said Gordon Lambourne, a spokesman for Marriott. "Even the Marriott Marquis, which has almost 2,000 rooms, has had high occupancies throughout the year, especially on weekends and most holidays."
Not all Hawaiian properties have fared well, but many in tourist-rich Oahu have had a much stronger 1996 than expected. ITT Sheraton's four properties on Waikiki Beach were fully booked in January, February, June and August. John C. Brogan Sr., a senior vice president in charge of operations at Sheraton's seven Hawaiian hotels, said that the surge in business over the first three quarters of this year, specifically in Waikiki, had boosted Sheraton's overall Hawaiian revenues 8 percent over the same period last year.
Atlanta's performance, by contrast, appears to have been mixed. While people descended on the city for the Summer Olympics in August, many of them apparently stayed with friends or relatives -- even in hotels in surrounding states. Although many visitors began arriving in July, Smith Travel reported that occupancies in the city fell 0.3 percent that month.
While lodging figures are not yet available for August -- a month in which Delta boarded 2.1 million passengers in Atlanta, the most any airline has boarded during any one month at any airport -- many Atlanta hoteliers have already complained that occupancy fell below expectations. The saving grace for the city's hotel industry is that room rates soared 72.6 percent in July, to $116.46 -- an increase, tourism officials say, that probably accounts for much of the drop in occupancy.
In addition, occupancies this year in New Orleans, Minneapolis and Phoenix have fallen between 6 and 7 percent, although all three cities boosted room rates -- 11.1 percent in the case of Phoenix, whose average room rate inched past the $100 a night mark (to $100.59). Greater Washington occupancy was also off slightly through July, down 0.6 percent. Hotel officials attribute most of that to fallout from the Federal Government shutdown late last year, as well as from snowstorms that paralyzed the region early this year.
Although Smith Travel Research has warned of a gradual decline in occupancies beginning this fall, as demand catches up with the recent modest growth in room supply, others foresee continued strength for the U.S. hotel industry.
PKF Consulting, a San Francisco-based international firm specializing in the hospitality industry, forecasts that from now through 1977, United States hotels "will achieve the strongest combination of growth in occupancy, revenues and profits since the 1940's." Not only that, but if its projected $102.28 average daily room rate in major cities next year holds up, it will be the first time that rate will have surpassed $100.
As for New York, visitors without hotel reservations this fall, especially around the holidays, and much of next year, will probably do well to fuhgeddaboutit. The occupancy rate in the city is expected to surpass 80 percent this year, Mr. Fox said, and continue to climb in 1997 -- a performance he attributes to a limited number of new hotel rooms over the next few years, a cheap U.S. dollar that keeps domestic travelers in the United States and attracts foreign visitors, and an improved image reflected in the city's lower crime rate.
In addition, New York is becoming a more desirable destination for conventions. "Meeting planners are beginning to respond to the reduction of the rooms tax," Mr. Fox said.

HEADLINE: The View From: The New Haven Green;
A Short, Fresh Take on Topics of the Day, and Free, Too

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS 

 BODY:
BREVITY and clarity have been raised to an art form in the half-sheet flyers passed out on the southeast corner of the New Haven Green every Thursday at noon.
Every week a handful of dedicated activists produces 300 leaflets on a timely topic and gives them to all takers. The tracts are not religious, nor are they the rhetorical screed so often encountered in publications of both the political right and left. 
 They are, simply, information and opinion offered on various issues of peace and justice, usually ending with an invitation for the reader to do something -- write or call an elected official, communicate with a company accused of abusing its workers, attend a rally. Every week at the bottom of the flyer is the name of the tiny band responsible for the effort: Peace & Justice News & Views.
With few exceptions, they've been out on the four corners of Church and Chapel streets every week for six years. There have been other groups who have leafleted their fellow citizens on the green previously -- often including many of these same individuals -- notably during the Vietnam War. But this particular effort, says Sally Joughin, a member, began in August 1990 during the buildup to the Persian Gulf war. It was then called Coalition Against War in the Gulf, and it retained its name until 1995, long after the troops came home and the yellow ribbons faded.
They kept the name for so long, she says, to demonstrate their belief that the war was not in fact over -- either in Iraq, where a tight United Nations trade embargo was depriving millions of food and medicine or at home, where American taxpayers are still paying military-related costs and G.I.s who served in the war are suffering from mysterious illnesses.
"One thing that's unique about this group," says Marge Van Cleef, another member, "is that we have a new leaflet every week."
And they are timely. Ms. Joughin said she stayed up half the night in order to hit the streets with the group's views on the Connecticut Supreme Court's historic desegregation decision in Sheff v. O'Neill right after it was released in July. The headline called the decision "an opportunity" to put backing behind regional schools open to all students, wherever they might live and whatever transportation might be involved.
They've written lots of flyers about military spending. A recent one criticized their Congressional representative, Rosa DeLauro, for voting for more money in the defense budget than even the Pentagon had requested. "Already," they wrote, "the U.S. spends 20 percent more on the military than the next nine countries in the world combined -- and six of them are our allies. . . . Clearly the threat to our security is not military, but social and economic: our social services and infrastructure are crumbling while excessive contracts are being handed out to military contractors."
They've also written about the ongoing danger to civilians of millions of unexploded landmines around the world; condemned the United States embargo of Cuba, and supported Yale University's striking workers.
They've handed out pie charts explaining where Federal budget money goes; called for a new trial for Mumia Abu-Jamal, who is on death row, and agitated against the dumping of toxic sludge in Long Island Sound.
Sometimes they localize a leaflet being promoted by a national organization on a peace and justice topic. Sometimes they pass out other local groups' leaflets if the issue is urgent. Other times, people write from their own experience, as when one member attended the Labor Party's founding convention last spring in Cleveland.
Each flyer is laid out with attractive headlines and graphics, and it is neither printed in tiny type nor run out to the margins of the paper in order to fit in more words. Over the years, the group, of necessity, has become expert at expressing itself succinctly.
"We used to hand out a full sheet," says Ms. Joughin, "but we were low on money once and we started making it a half-sheet. Then we noticed that people read it on the spot."
"We've also learned," she adds, "not to try to say everything in one leaflet."
A rotating committee of one takes responsibility for writing each week's flyer, getting input from other members before making copies. Copying costs were covered for awhile by a small grant from a private foundation; when that ran out, Ms. Joughin, a piano teacher, held a fund-raising concert at her New Haven home.
Most members of the group are retired, work part-time or have flexible work schedules, enabling them to spend many hours a week on their avocation.
They used to put a phone number on the flyers, but no one called, so they took it off. They say they have no idea if anyone follows up on their suggestions, and they don't even have extended conversations with passersby when they do the leafleting. So what keeps them writing, producing and distributing their flyers week, week after week?
"As far as a gauge of our effectiveness," says Paula Panzarella, "during the Gulf War, New Haven did not look like Hamden or North Haven" -- two adjoining towns where pro-war sentiment often turned ugly and sometimes violent. "There were not as many yellow ribbons and not so much venom. I think that was partly due to the role of the activist community. We put the idea out there that it's okay not to go along with the chauvinism."
Or, as Ms. Van Cleef put it, "We provide an alternative analysis to fill in some of the gaps in what people are not getting in the popular media. Many facts are left out of the mainstream news media."
Ms. Joughin feels that, "If people read our flyers, the next time they hear something on the news they will say, 'Oh, yeah, that's what those people were leafleting about,' and maybe they will see the news in a new light."
That was exactly the reaction of one regular, Robbie Potter of New Haven, who takes a flyer whenever she spots the group. It is, he says, "stuff I don't see elsewhere. It gives me food for thought."
A downtown office worker who usually takes a flyer on her lunch hour said, "The group serves as a public conscience on these issues. It's really encouraging that there are still committed people out there."
Ms. Joughin says the two questions they get asked the most about their leafleting are, "Is it religious?" and "Who pays you?"
"People can't believe we would do this week after week just because we believe in it," she said.

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Lawrence Waldman;
Giving Recognition to the Entrepreneurial Spirit on the Island

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
AS a managing partner of Long Island's largest accounting concern, KPMG Peat Marwick, Lawrence Waldman founded the Entrepreneurial Spirit Awards. The awards, created to foster business development on Long Island, recognize the 50 largest privately held companies on Long Island, based upon total revenue, and the 25 fastest growing privately held companies, based upon revenue growth over the prior year. They will be presented tomorrow for the 10th year by KPMG Peat Marwick and Hofstra University.
A graduate of Hofstra with a master's degree in business administration, Mr. Waldman was president of both the East Williston Board of Education and the Nassau County chapter of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants. He serves on the boards of the Sid Jacobson North Shore Jewish Community Center, the Long Island Philharmonic, the Jewish National Fund and the Long Island United Way. 
 Mr. Waldman, 49, was honored last year by the Family Service Association. He lives with his wife, Joan, and their two children,-- Daniel, 20, and Craig, 17, in Roslyn Heights.
Q. How have compiling these lists helped you to promote Long Island as a place for business opportunity?
A. When we talk about economic development on Long Island and bringing companies here, what is the best thing we can tell them? That we have companies here that grow and prosper and do well. It's not to tell them that we have high electric rates or traffic. Everybody has that. But what do we have? We have a highly educated work force, a very industrious work force. We are sitting in the middle of the largest marketplace of the whole world. This is the financial and cultural capital of the world, and there's no better place to vacation than on Long Island.
Q. How did this program come about?
A. It was in 1984-85 that we were seeing growth in our practice here and economic growth all over Long Island. Yet we daily get bombarded in the local press and everywhere you look about how difficult it is to do business here. So I sat down and said why don't we come up with something that shows what Long Island is really all about.
Q. And you decided to concentrate on only the private companies?
A. Yes. Everybody knows about public companies. You hear about them every day; they put out press releases. So we went to the private companies, which are really the majority of companies out here and employ the majority of people. And we then asked Hofstra University to co-sponsor it and do some academic research as to why these companies have been successful, considering that you do have high electric costs and difficult transportation. It's tough to attract people sometimes because of the costs that are around here.
Q. How many companies were nominated the first year?
A. About 200 companies.
Q. And which company led the list of 500?
A. King Kullen. And No. 50 that year was Austin Productions. From 1 to 50 there were lots of names you knew and lots you didn't. What's really surprising is that there were a lot of big companies out here that were very successful and nobody knew they were here.
Q. What did Hofstra do with the winning list?
A. It interviewed about three-quarters of the C.E.O.'s to find out the common ingredient. Why, in the face of all the high costs and negatives, were these companies becoming successful? And Hofstra coined the term in its first research paper, entrepreneurial spirit. It said there are a lot of people here who are highly educated, highly motivated. We sit in the biggest marketplace in the whole world and there are lots of ideas going back and forth and they are willing to take risks. And that's why we named the lunch the Entrepreneurial Spirit Awards Luncheon.
Q. What has Hofstra's role been over the years?
A. To continue to do research every year on those companies to determine how many new jobs came about, how much revenue growth there was and how productive the companies were to Long Island. They found that given the whole composition of companies, these companies tended to be higher performancers, which you would tend to expect.
Q. Has the program changed over the years?
A. As companies found out about it, the bar kept going up. And more and more companies said it was a good program that they would like to be involved in. Some companies have put on their letterhead and on their stationery, "Long Island top 50 company" or "Twenty-five fastest growing company."
Q. How many companies participated this year?
A. Well over 300. In the beginning, some people used to call up and say, "Why should I do this? What does this do for me?" I'd say I didn't know if it did anything for them today but that it does something for the business community and the community that you live in, so why wouldn't you want to show it off?
Q. What was the reaction of some of the small, rapidly growing companies to your list?
A. In the second and third years they decided not to go in. They looked at the list from the first two years and saw that the smallest company had revenues of $30 million, so they thought they would never get in. But there are companies that are fast growing and also prove the point about Long Island. So in 1988 we started the list of the 25 fastest growing companies based upon percentage growth. So now we have a new group that comes in and says its revenues last year were $1 million and this year they are $3 million, or $10 million and now $20 million.
Q. Have you had companies move from the fastest growing list to the top 50 list?
A. Yes, in fact we have had some companies make both lists at the same time. A notable example is 800-Flowers. When they started out in this program, they were at the bottom of the top 50 list. In 1991, they were 45th. That same year they were No. 1 on the list of the 25 fastest growing companies. Now, 800-Flowers is No. 10 on the top 50 list.
Q. What do you find in terms of a common thread among the fastest growing companies?
A. That list seems to change year in and year out, based on what's going on. We had several years in the late 80's in which eight or nine of the companies were involved in environmental services. If you remember at that time the state and Federal governments were passing laws about what you had to do environmentally. So companies like Tyree were on the fastest growing list and then made it to the top 50 list. That's a local company that is now expanding internationally with environmental services.
Q. What has Hofstra found in examining the top 50 companies over the years?
A. It found that they had C.E.O.'s who started companies and were willing to take a risk to become very successful. Risk taking was one of the important factors in starting a company and growing because people who don't take risks don't get to throw the dice and come up with some big idea.
Q. Is there a field that is now particularly attractive?
A. We have found that software companies over the last few years, what you might call high-technology companies, have emerged on the fastest growing 25 list because that's what's happening.
You have Computer Associates out here. It's not on the list because it's a public company, but there are many companies that are doing this, such as Sheridan Software. A few years ago, you didn't find software companies on the list. They were out there but probably not as productive. I guess there's a big push to make Long Island a biotech center and sooner or later I think we'll start to see those type of companies. he fastest growing list tends to reflect the economic cycles and the economic ideas of what's going on. There's no one industry that is better than any other. If you're in business, you do a good job, know what you're doing and adapt to the world as it is, you're successful.
Q. What other companies are on the fastest growing 25 list?
A. Financial service companies. Long Island sits outside of New York City, the big financial capital, and we find that there have been a lot of financial service companies here.
Q. Are any of these companies likely to go public?
A. Many who make the fastest growing list and to the top of the top 50 list end up going public. You know what happens, you start a company, you need more capital, you get bank loans and then you say you have to go public. Snapple was the most famous that was ever on our top 50 list. In 1992 it was No. 18 and the following year it went public.
Q. Any other companies you can recall?
A. Career Horizons, a temporary service firm in Woodbury. It was growing and on the list for many years because temporary services were rapidly growing. Then they went public.
Another company is the Quantum Restaurant Group. They went public and changed their name to Morton's because one of their major subsidiaries is Morton's of Chicago, a very good steakhouse. They started in the top 50 companies in 1990 or so and it's founder, Allan Bernstein, has always been a very strong supporter of this program.
Q. Any companies that were a flash in the pan?
A. Lots of them. There are lots of companies that have a rapid growth spurt and then either don't adapt to the marketplace or positioned well enough to continue growth. Nothing can kill a young company more than growth.
If they don't plan for it and they expand and their capital runs out or their management team is turns out to be too short, it's very quick. The marketplace is very deadly when it works against you. It's very favorable when it works for you. We had lots of companies on the fastest growing list that never made it; we have more that made it.
Q. What's the key to success besides the willingness to take risks?
A. The ability to manage and to understand that you have a good idea and can make it work. And that always comes down to management, always comes down to people and being able to put the right elements in place so that you can continue to grow, so that you'll have enough capital to grow and let your idea adapt to the marketplace.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lawrence Waldman, of KPMG Peat Marwick, founded the Entrepreneurial Spirit Awards. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)
