HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
Kansas City Is Rediscovering Its Downtown Area

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH Utilicorp United was a loser in its recent fight to merge with Kansas City Power and Light, it should find some consolation come mid-November when it moves into a new corporate headquarters that is the latest crown jewel in the rebirth of this city's downtown.
The 10-story, 200,000-square-foot building at 20 West Ninth Street features state-of-the-art energy, communications and environmental capabilities appropriate for an international energy company with interests stretching from the heartland to New Zealand and Australia. 
But the $35 million renovation/restoration project also features, and preserves, the brick and brownstone exterior, the two-ton bronze eagle over the entry and the Italian granite atrium flooring of a Neo-Italianate building designed by McKim, Mead and White and built 108 years ago.
Always known as the New York Life Building (it was one of six buildings put up by the insurance company as speculative office space in the region late in the last century), it was considered the first "skyscraper" here and had the city's first elevators.
Bringing the New York Life Building back in all its glory as Class A office space has added glitter to the spectacular turnaround in downtown Kansas City, which along with its smaller sister across the river, Kansas City, Kan., has suffered more than most cities from the effects of suburban sprawl.
It is not an isolated phenomenon. For while there is no sign of slowing in the suburban growth, a combination of committed business people and an incentive program called Tax Increment Financing is transforming this city's downtown into an inviting cityscape where Post-Modern and Neo-Classical skyscrapers blend with restored and renovated Victorian low- and mid-rise buildings.
Almost every downtown block has construction under way, and the biggest headache is creating enough new parking space for employees of the businesses that are expanding or moving in to fill the new or renovated office space.
In addition to the New York Life Building, the projects completed or in construction since the transformation started gathering momentum four years ago include a 97,000-square-foot, five-story corporate headquarters for DST Systems Inc., a fast-growing processor of mutual fund accounts, and a 300,000-square-foot building across the street used by some DST personnel and office tenants; more than one million square feet of renovated and restored space in turn-of-the-century buildings and Victorian mansions; a 158,000-square-foot headquarters for Investor's Fiduciary Trust Company, which is expected to be followed by a second building the same size; the renovation and addition of 51,000 square feet of new space to the 50-year-old 162,000-square-foot Centennial Building and the renovation and addition of 30,000 square feet to the 43-year-old, 50,000-square-foot Hereford Building.
ON the drawing boards, but well along, is a plan by UMB Financial Corporation to build a 130,000-square-foot technology and operations center and 600-space parking garage on the east side of downtown near its Grand Avenue headquarters and the three-block Civic Mall now under construction, which will include a new Federal Court complex and a park stretching from the courthouse to the existing City Hall.
Stan Durwood, chairman of AMC Entertainment Inc., has saved for his hometown his most ambitious plan yet -- an entertainment complex with a 30-screen movie theater, live performance theaters, restaurants and stores. He has received approval from the Tax Increment Financing Commission -- but not yet the City Council -- for $185 million in public financing for the $400 million project.
All of these projects have used, or contemplate using, the incentive program known as Tax Increment Financing. Under Missouri law, the program permits the rebate of up to 100 percent of the increase in property taxes resulting from construction or renovation, and up to 50 percent from an increase in economic activities taxes -- sales, utility, corporate profit, food and beverage and individual-earnings levies.
While the restoration and renovation of the New York Life Building by Hugh Zimmer of Kansas City, a longtime developer of office parks and other commercial real estate here and elsewhere in the Midwest as well as in the South, is the single most glittering element in the rejuvenated downtown, DST is responsible for the overwhelming majority of the new construction and renovation completed since 1992.
DST, a spin-off from an old-line local company, Kansas City Southern Industries, and its affiliate firms now have about 5,000 employees spread out in eight buildings in addition to its new corporate headquarters. And it has effectively turned part of downtown into the kind of campus setting many companies enjoy in new suburban complexes.
J. Philip Kirk Jr., chairman of DST Realty, which DST created to oversee the fulfillment of its real estate needs, said that until tax-increment financing came along it had been difficult to amass a number of properties and to create the common environment that developers seek to protect their investments.
Much of the redevelopment work was done in what Mr. Kirk termed a "strategic" alliance made up of DST, a group of not-for-profit organizations needing new office space, and Bob Graham, real estate adviser to Joe Jack and Michael Merriman, members of a local family involved in insurance and investments. The effort took off after they obtained approval from the city in 1992 for a tax-increment-financing plan covering buildings in about 20 square blocks on the west side of the 150-square block downtown area.
MUCH of the area was along Broadway, once the heart of Kansas City's garment industry, where many empty buildings stood as silent witness to the offshore flight of clothing manufacturing. Immediately west of Broadway was the Quality Hill district of decaying Queen Anne mansions and once-fashionable apartment houses. A number of buildings were of architectural or historic significance. The oldest building in the DST project area was built in 1874, the newest in 1951.
The old garment-district buildings, most of them four or five stories tall with huge windows, have been converted to office space, and the new DST corporate headquarters sits among them. Some of the old mansions and hotels on Quality Hill have been turned into a campus for 16 not-for-profit agencies -- among them, the American Cancer Society's Western Division headquarters -- which now share meeting rooms and other facilities.
While the degree to which architectural history has been preserved pleases most local residents, the project has not been without its battles over historic preservation. Mostly they centered on the efforts of DST Realty and other developers to create enough parking space. .
"In an urban setting," Mr. Kirk said, "you have to figure out how some of these buildings that have become obsolete can be adapted and saved. Too rigid a historic preservation agenda becomes like hardening of the arteries.
"To make things work you have to have parking downtown -- that's the only way businesses will locate here. So it becomes a question of whether you take down some buildings to create parking or leave them all empty. I'm happy if I can save two out of three."
The Tax Increment Financing Commission estimates the cost of the DST projects at nearly $81 million, of which $37.6 million is eligible for reimbursement over a 23-year period as taxes are collected. Mr. Kirk, apparently including some planned renovations that are not yet formally in the city's documents, estimates that investment will eventually reach $125 million, with $45 million of it reimbursable.

GRAPHIC: Photos: DST Systems headquarters, left, 97,000-square-foot building put up in Kansas City. Right, New York Life Building and its two-ton bronze eagle; 108-year-old McKim, Mead and White building has received a $35 million restoration. (Photographs by Don Ipok for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 4; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1572 words

HEADLINE: Region's Economic Mood Turns a Corner

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
THE list of Long Island woes has become familiar: High taxes, high electric costs, traffic congestion and the loss of military jobs and contracts have combined to sap the vitality of one of the country's richest regions.
If something wasn't done soon, the cry went, Long Island risked becoming a ghostly place of failed businesses, shuttered downtowns and desperate home sellers yearning for lower living costs in North Carolina. 
 But in the fall of a Presidential election year, a time for taking stock, a far different picture is emerging, of a regional economy that has always benefited from residents' vast personal wealth, where the median family income towers over the national average.
Indicators that times are good for the rich and the fully employed are apparent, if not always applauded, from western Nassau to the Hamptons.
After shedding nearly 90,000 jobs at the start of the decade, Long Island has recouped nearly two-thirds of those jobs and is producing new ones at a moderate rate, said Dr. Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association. She said 12,000 jobs, including 9,200 in services and 5,200 in retailing, were added in the year that ended in August.
When the former Grumman Corporation and other military contractors that accounted for most of the job losses faltered in the late 1980's, many experts said that the expansion of lower-paid service jobs would not offset the damage.
Now, despite only partial diversification of the military contractors into civilian markets, experts voice a consensus that the Island has survived those losses.
"We not only survived that," Dr. Kamer said. "We are now doing very well."
She said the less cyclical economy was now based on small businesses, high technology and sophisticated services.
The president and chairman of the North Fork Bank, John A. Kanas, said the end of the reliance on military industries was "the best thing that ever happened to Long Island."
Mr. Kanas estimated that of 110,000 jobs lost in layoffs in the industry, 85,000 had been regained elsewhere.
"The difference is we lost those jobs 5,000 to 10,000 at a time, but they came back 5 to 10 at a time at a much wider array of smaller businesses," he said. "Lots of little businesses replaced a lot of huge ones, and that forms a more stable foundation for a Long Island economy that is gong forward."
Record gains on Wall Street have been creating new wealth for investors and bolstering companies like Computer Associates of Islandia, a leader in technology. The company's stock sold for about $14 a share at the end of September 1993. Last week it was above $50.
Stock profits, low interest and inflation rates and a guarded sense that corporate shrinkage among banks and other businesses has run its course have produced a spending mood for items large and small, economists said.
Residential real estate is no longer in the doldrums, particularly for upper-end new and existing houses, agents say. In locales like Manhasset agents report strong sales helped by a surge of young families that can pay prices that rarely dip below $400,000.
In Southampton an explosion in construction of highly priced second homes alarms advocates of farm and open-space preservation. They said the threat to the town's rural character had never been greater.
Islandwide, residential building permits by year's end will total 44 percent higher than in 1995, according to Dr. Kamer.
County governments, flush with sales-tax revenues that reflect a shopping culture, appear to have moved beyond annual budget crises and fiscal strains. Public schools, spared deep cuts in Albany, survived the budget votes with few casualties.
Even the widely disdained Long Island Lighting Company found allies in its effort to stop the Public Service Commission from immediately reducing rates by 5.2 percent. The cuts, the Long Island Association and others agreed, imperiled service that although costly was at least reliable.
As the dust settles from setbacks of the late 80's and early 90's, it becomes apparent that traditional bastions of wealth remained unaltered.
In the summer Worth Magazine listed the 300 wealthiest towns in the country, giving a reminder of the depth of that affluence. Villages in the five towns area of western Nassau and on the North Shore crowded the top 50. Four villages -- Hewlett Bay Park, Hewlett Harbor, Kings Point and Oyster Bay Cove -- were in the top 10.
But in a regional economy where only the rich, the professionals, the highly skilled and hard-working two-income families seem to prosper, relative affluence is widespread.
The race for disposable income continues to spur retailers. Across the Island, predictions of a strong holiday shopping season have large retailers in a bullish mood.
"So far the signs are terrific," a vice president at Fortunoff in Westbury, Arlene Futterman, said. "We have more people coming in early this year than ever before."
"Long Island is really picking up," a vice president of the store, Louis Fortunoff, said, adding that sales were particularly strong for high-priced jewelry.
At Roosevelt Field in Garden City, with 2.2 million square feet the largest regional mall in the eastern United States, ceremonies last week helped open 50 new stores.
Significantly, the owner of the mall, Corporate Property Investors of Manhattan, eschewed discounters in favor of retailers like F.A.O. Schwarz, A/X Armani, Polo Ralph Lauren, Laura Ashley, Kenneth Cole and Nordstrom.
"These are stores that are new to Long Island or this area," said Deborah A. Flattery, the mall marketing director, who suggested that no luxury retailer had ever gone broke counting on "the desire of women to shop in malls on Long Island."
"We have always tried to supply these avid shoppers with something unique," Ms. Flattery said.
To the east, at one end of the Long Island Expressway in Riverhead, the Tanger outlet center continues to exert a magnetic pull on bargain hunters. The success of the center has led to a groundbreaking for Tanger II nearby.
The residents of an adjoining apartment complex and other neighbors said they were overwhelmed by the obliteration of the woods to make room for the stores.
More open space is vanishing in Southampton, where permits for new building have been surpassing the pace in neighboring Brookhaven, which is large than Nassau County.
Edwin M. Schwenkof Southampton, said he had left his position as executive director of the Long Island Builders Institute in dismay over rapid development in his hometown.
"What's happening here is a reflection of what's happening on Wall Street," Mr. Schwenk said. "Wall Street is as hot as a firecracker, and these people who are making a killing are coming out here, and money is no problem for them."
Mr. Schwenk advocates a transfer tax on expensive houses and properties to finance the preservation of open space.
To the west, congestion on major roads continues, frequently because of major work like adding a fourth lane to Exit 57 on the Long Island Expressway. Only people who are out of touch with the tempo of late-20th-century Long Island are shocked by the gouging of swards that once buffered the roadway.
Road work, other large construction projects and the explosion of second-home building east of the Shinnecock Canal have revived the construction trades, where high jobless rates of five years ago have given way to almost full employment.
"We haven't seen it like this in a long time," said John M. Kennedy, the president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
Mr. Kennedy said construction workers who left in leaner times "to tramp all over the country looking for work" were returning. He said a $212 million Federal courthouse being built in Central Islip was "like plasma for us."
The 23-courtroom building, with plans to add 39 courtrooms in future years, is a major advance for the growing legal establishment. At the Suffolk County Bar Association, membership has risen, from 1,000 to 3,400 since 1980, according to Jane LaCova, an executive assistant at the association.
Sales of luxury cars, which plunged in harsh weather in January, are another sign. "New- and used-car sales have been strong, and there is considerable interest in new Jaguar and Porsche products," said Thomas G. Lederer, a vice president at Sportique Motors Ltd. of Huntington. "I can't necessarily attribute these trends solely to a healthier economy. But we do sense more confidence in Long Island's business future."
But the picture is not upbeat for everyone. The executive director of the Community Programs Center of Long Island, Paul Arfin, said he was seeing signs of growing distress among middle- and low-income families with children.
Mr. Arfin said calls that asked about day-care programs were increasing, with many callers who were looking for work or had found a job, but who were discouraged by child-care costs that could run from $100 to $200 a week.
He said the problem was compounded in Suffolk because of a waiting list of 1,500 for child-care subsidies. The county suspended the program when state aid ran out in May, 1995, and it has been unwilling to "put local tax dollars into the mix," Mr. Arfin said.
"If the working poor who now receive some assistance lose it and have to go on public assistance," he asked, "what have we achieved?"

HEADLINE: Rentals Thrive in a College Town With Big-City Airs

BYLINE: By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
IN a dusty industrial corner in this small city on the Charles River, two 22-story rental buildings are rising in what is Cambridges's largest market-rate apartment project and the largest residential development under way in metropolitan Boston.
The 435-apartment development is in an area of East Cambridge that saw a burst of building in the 1980's, followed by a sharp downturn as the real-estate market sagged in the early 90's. Now, on the last rag-tag strip of riverfront available for development, Congress Group Ventures Inc., based in Cambridge, has undertaken a $70 million project called Museum Towers. The developer is also building a 159,000-square-foot office building on the site for a single tenant, E. F. Group Inc., a Swedish company that operates language schools and student travel agencies. 
 The land is in a 70-acre industrial section of the waterfront called North Point, served by Interstate 93 and the McGrath Highway and within sight of Boston's Museum of Science, for which the apartments are named. Not far off is Kendall Square, the home of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the scores of technology-based companies it has spawned.
Dean F. Stratouly, the chief executive of Congress Group Ventures, which will provide $15 million to develop Museum Towers and finance $55 million with a construction loan from the Fleet Bank, explained that several factors had coalesced to make this a propitious time to build rental housing.
For one, government agencies will spend $80 million to install roads, utility lines and a riverfront park in North Point. Moreover, in comparison with the hot housing market of the late 1980's, it now costs less to buy land, go through the permit process and design and build a project because of reduced fees for professional and construction services. Lower interest rates, meanwhile, make it less expensive to borrow money.
A Museum Towers apartment that will now cost $150 a square foot to develop would have cost 20 percent more 10 years ago, Mr. Stratouly said.
Furthermore, the development comes at a time when, as a result of a statewide referendum held in 1994, Cambridge, Boston and Brookline have been ordered to end their 25-year-old rent-control system. The referendum has led to the decontrol of many apartments already, with a formal end of control for all apartments to take place by Dec. 31.
Since the referendum, residential rents have risen substantially, as has investor interest in Cambridge. "The removal of rent control has been a huge factor in encouraging the development of Museum Towers," Mr. Stratouly said.
With no limit on gross revenues from residential property, values and rent rates throughout the city have increased by 30 percent to as much as 200 percent since the two-year phase-out of rent control began in January 1995, according to Sally Powers, the city assessor.
WHILE rent control applied only to certain housing built before 1976, its abolition has engendered a more favorable financial climate.
"The financial markets were concerned that rent control might someday be extended to include new buildings," Mr. Stratouly said.
About two miles south of the Museum Towers site and a few blocks west of the river, another large rental project has received initial city approval. What will be called Worthington Place is now a complex of five historic industrial buildings near Kendall Square.
They will be renovated into 186 apartments at a cost of about $23 million.
The developer, MB Associates of Boston, signed an agreement to buy the property early this year, according to Steven J. Rioff, chief executive of the company. Construction is to start in February and be completed by June 1998, he said.
Both Museum Towers and Worthington Place will cater to the roommate market by featuring two-bedroom, two-bathroom apartments that will rent for about $2,000 at Museum Towers and $1,600 at Worthington Place.
In the Central Square area, Cambridge Designs is developing small projects that are more typical of the kind of new housing that has been available here since the late 1970's.
That company is renovating a carriage house on Elm Street in a transitional neighborhood behind Central Square. It is dividing the building into four 3,000-square-foot lofts that will be marketed for about $400,000 each and one apartment to be sold for about $100,000.
Recently, Cambridge Designs completed the renovation of a four-unit rental building on Blackstone Street between Harvard and Central Squares. The three-bedroom, 1,400-square-foot apartments have rented for approximately $2,300 each, about twice the price they would have fetched before 1994, said David Aposhian, chief executive of Cambridge Designs.
He easily leased the rental units during the 1996 rental season, which runs through the summer here. Demand for apartments outstripped supply despite rising rents.
"Cambridge is a perfect place to live," Mr. Aposhian said. "It's a small town with big-city comforts but the market has become wildly unstable."
JUST an eight-minute subway ride from Boston, this 6.5-square-mile city with 92,000 residents and a charming historic district is traversed by all of the metropolitan area's major highways. It has recreation, restaurants, nightclubs, museums and theaters for films and live performances.
Every academic year, its population doubles with students from M.I.T., Harvard, Lesley College and other schools and research institutes. It has long been a popular location for young professionals and in recent years, suburban empty-nesters have been moving into luxury apartments and buying condominiums here.
"It's almost scary," said John M. Angier, manager of the Cambridge office of the real estate company Hunnemen/Coldwell Banker. The amount of rental commissions his office has taken in so far this year is up 200 percent from a year ago. "Always a good rental market," Mr. Angier said, "Cambridge just keeps improving."
Even the values of condominiums and single-family homes have risen beyond the peak level of 1988, according to Allan N. Weiss, president of Case Shiller Weiss Inc. which analyzes market data.
The prices of single-family homes sold through the first half of the year are up 9.5 percent from 1988 and 29.5 percent from the low of 1991. Condominium sale prices are up 11 percent and 19.5 percent respectively, based on prices adjusted through time using a repeat sales index, Mr. Weiss said.
Walter F. Loughlin, vice president of Leeder Management, which owns and operates 117 rental apartments near Harvard Square, said the appraised values of its two apartment buildings had risen 35 percent. That mirrors the increase in their rental rates.
In such a market, it is no wonder that Mr. Stratouly of Congress Group Ventures persevered through an approval process of almost three years to develop the five-acre North Point parcel he bought in 1987. Moreover, he recently agreed to pay more than $15 million to buy what he called a "significant portion" of the remaining 65 acres of North Point for mixed-use development.
The desirability of the Cambridge rental market minimizes the financial risk of his investment. As Mr. Stratouly said, this city sells itself to potential renters. "Cambridge offers a cosmopolitan air and all the advantages of living in Boston, with less density and less expense," he said.

HEADLINE: A Huntington's Mohegan Mission

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
NEXT Saturday the Mohegan Indians of eastern Connecticut will open a big and opulent casino in Montville, near the banks of the Thames River, hoping to emulate the success of the Mashantucket Pequot casino in Ledyard, on the other side of the Thames, that has become the most successful one in the world.
Like the Pequots, who were once nearly obliterated in a massacre in Colonial times, the Mohegans also faced extinction in Connecticut, but at a later date and not by being slaughtered by white settlers. They faced the very real possibility of being shipped out of the state to the Far West by the Federal Government. 
 The story of the Mohegan survival is also the story of Sarah Lanman Huntington, a young white woman. What she did for the Mohegans has never been forgotten by them and in the past few months, they have been able to pay her back a little by a gift that might be entitled "To Sarah with love."
The bond between Miss Huntington and the Mohegans goes back to the early part of the last century, to the city of Norwich where she lived, and early displayed that she was a most unusual person.
Young ladies of prominent families of the time -- and she certainly fit that description -- were expected to be content with learning about needlepoint and motherhood. Not Miss Huntington. She became a social activist for an impoverished and declining tribe of Indians.
These were the Mohegans, the people of the mighty Uncas of Colonial times, now reduced to about 100 people living in the woods in Montville, only six miles from Miss Huntington's family home in Norwich. Despite the relatively small distance, the Indian reservation was a frontier. The woods were so deep that Miss Huntington could only find the Indians by following the sound of their axes biting into trees.
But once she had discovered them, they became her cause. Miss Huntington, the granddaughter of a Revolutionary War general who was also an original trustee of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, had entertained thoughts of becoming a missionary. The Mohegans became her unofficial mission, close to home.
She was not, however, the stern, uncompromising missionary of popular conception. In one of many letters she left behind she described herself as a "missionary in heart" to the Indians. And she did give her heart to them. She found Indian children to be delightful and anxious to learn. She found older people receptive to her, although sometimes suspicious that she might be just one more white person working a scheme to take more of their land, and dignity.
It just wasn't so in her case. She identified with the sufferings and successes of the Indians. In one letter she described the delight of being with the Mohegan children -- "a little Indian girl behind me on the horse and half a dozen other children following on foot, talking as fast as their tongues would do. I was perfectly delighted with my situation . . ."
Another time, she described sitting with an older man who was dying. She rejoiced with the friends she had found and she mourned when one of them was sick or had died.
For her work with the Indians, she received less than concerted acclaim from the Yankees of Norwich. In one letter to a friend, obviously answering the criticism of a citizen of Norwich who felt she was acting below her station in life, Miss Huntington wrote that she would like to ask her detractor, "If the Savior had any regard to his 'station,' when he left his throne for a dwelling among our wretched race?"
Criticisms only seemed to make her more enthusiastic about her mission. She started a school for children and adults on the Mohegan reservation. Then, when Eastern Indian tribes were threatened by the Federal Government with removal to the West, allegedly because they were "uncivilized and un-Christianized" and therefore a continuing menace to white settlers, Miss Huntington acted quickly.
She sponsored the building of the Mohegan Congregational Church on land donated by three Mohegan women and paid for by money she solicited. The church, to show conclusively that the Mohegans were Christians and therefore presumably civilized, was dedicated in 1831.
The Mohegans were never again threatened with being taken from the land that had been theirs long before white settlers came. And the church is still there, tucked into the woods, a monument to Sarah Huntington.
Miss Huntington's connection with the Indians came to a halt soon after the church became a reality. She married a missionary, Eli Smith, and went with him to Syria. In September of 1836, she was in a shipwreck in the Mediterranean Sea near Cyprus. Five days later she was dead from exposure. She was 32 years old.
All she left as tangibles after her short life were a bundle of letters, assembled and published in 1845 by the American Tract Society as "Memoir of Mrs. Sarah L. Huntington Smith," and an oil painting, believed to be her wedding portrait. The intangible she left was the affection and respect of the imperiled Mohegans.
And this year, in a manner of speaking, Sarah Huntington returned to Connecticut for one more good deed. It was in connection with the Samuel Huntington house.
Since Colonial times, the Huntington name has been one of the best known and most respected in Connecticut, dating to 1633 when Simon Huntington left Norwich, England, to take his family to America to start a new life. He died of smallpox during the voyage. When the ship landed at Boston his widow, Margaret, disembarked with their five children, four boys and a girl. From this difficult beginning the Huntington family grew and prospered. In 1852 a Huntington family association was formed. Today, it has some 2,000 members spread across the country, all tracing their roots to the five children of Simon and Margaret Huntington.
The most famous Huntington has always been Samuel, a leader in the Revolutionary War era. He was one of four Connecticut men to sign the Declaration of Independence. He was also President of the Continental Congress when the Articles of Confederation were ratified and the Colonies officially became the United States, making him, so some maintain, the real first President of the United States. When he died 200 years ago, in 1796, he was serving his 10th one-year term as Governor of the new state of Connecticut.
The home where Samuel Huntington was born in the town of Scotland in 1731, basically unchanged since then, was acquired by a trust sponsored by Huntington family members two years ago with the provision that the trust raise $160,000 to repay the town government, which had acquired it.
Until recently, with the deadline approaching, the trust was far short of its goal and the Huntington house was listed as the most endangered historical building in the state by the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation.
Then something rather marvelous happened.
Channing M. Huntington 2d, who had established the trust to save the house, appealed for help to Senator Christopher J. Dodd, and Senator Dodd and his staff started to get in touch with others who had the means to insure the home would be saved for the trust, and for the public as a museum.
The Norwich Savings Society agreed to give the trust a mortgage on the property and also forget the first year's interest. The Hartford developer David T. Chase, whose daughter-in-law has roots in the Huntington family, contributed $25,000.
But the biggest commitment was made by the Mohegan Indians -- an initial $25,000 to insure that the trust would receive a matching grant of $50,000 from the Connecticut Historical Commission, and then $25,000 each year for the next three years, in effect guaranteeing the mortgage.
Senator Dodd described the response as a "little miracle."
"I felt we owed it to the Huntington family," said Jayne Fawcett, vice chairwoman of the Mohegan Tribal Council. "Sarah Huntington saved us."
Mrs. Fawcett acknowledges that the "enforced Christianity" of the time, represented by the church that Sarah Huntington built, has always been a sore point with some Mohegans. "But we will always be grateful to Sarah." Besides, she said, the church has been from the start a mixture of Christianity and traditional Indian worship.
It was also the church that proved to be a vital factor for the tribe late in this century, Mrs. Fawcett said. Without the church, establishing that the tribe had a continuing presence in Connecticut to the present day, the tribe would have been unsuccessful in its petition to operate a gambling casino in the state, she believes.
With that casino, the Mohegans, now about 1,200 strong, are expected to become a major factor in the economic life of the area, able to support non-gambling enterprises and to sponsor all sorts of social benefits for the tribe. And, said Mrs. Fawcett, she is convinced all this would never have happened without Sarah Huntington. "The difference one person can make," she said.
One recent day, Mrs. Fawcett finally got to meet Sarah Huntington, or at least her portrait, close up. She had been unaware that a portrait existed, or that it was at Park Congregational Church in Norwich.
But there, indeed, was Sarah Huntington, a young woman, strong-featured but plain, with not a hint of decoration on her black dress. "She's not a beautiful woman but she's a handsome woman and there's a warmth in her face," said Jayne Fawcett.
Senator Dodd's "little miracle" reference might well apply to the portrait itself.
Its location had been mentioned casually in a book published in the last century, but when the Rev. H. Donald Smith became minister of the church a decade ago, the picture was not there.
Then late in the summer of 1995, he said, he received a letter from a woman in New Haven, saying she had something that belonged in his church. He drove to her home and was given the painting of Sarah Huntington, along with a copy of her memoir. She offered no explanation, he said, outside the fact that she was closing up her house. He did not press the issue.
As he later pieced it together, the Huntington portrait was one of many oil paintings discarded years ago because the Norwich building inspector considered them a fire hazard. Sarah Huntington's painting became the property of an art dealer in Mystic and eventually of the woman in New Haven.
It was she who decided the painting should go back to where it belonged, to a Congregational church in a city where Sarah Huntington was born and raised, and from which she walked out to the woods one day and found her mission in life.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
A Home Development Is Under Way, 14 Years Later

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
AFTER 14 years of negotiation and litigation, earthmovers are preparing to turn 200 wooded hillside acres in Roxbury Township into a large residential community.
The $100 million project, Poet's Peak, is to be built over the next five years on Mooney Mountain in western Morris County by the Bukiet Building and Management Company of Clifton. It will use its own equity and bank financing to build 315 single-family homes, not the 700 town houses originally planned. 
 The project underscores the state's slowly improving housing picture and the changes developers must make to stay ahead of consumer preferences. But the time it took to reach this point also shows how complex the development process in the state can be.
In an attempt to distance it from projects of the past, the 15 neighborhoods that will be carved from the woodlands off Mooney and Mountain Roads will be linked by pedestrian walkways and have access to public open space. The homes will have 2,000 to 3,300 square feet of space, sit on lots of from 7,500 square feet to 1.5 acres and have varied architectural designs -- from Victorian to Norman and colonial -- to recall a community that evolved over time, said Joseph J. Bukiet, the president of the company. Prices are expected to be $239,000 to $363,000.
Among the issues involved in the Roxbury project were the adequacy of water and sewage lines and the time-consuming state and local approval and regulatory processes -- the latter long a lament among builders.
Bukiet acquired the project, subject to approvals for the 700 town houses, for $3.5 million. But the town was slow in providing water and sewer to the project and development was further complicated when Roxbury came under a state-imposed moratorium on sewer hookups until it upgraded its sewage treatment plant. That work was completed in 1990 and the ban was lifted. The project, however, did not get the sewage hookups needed to move ahead, so Bukiet sued the township. Under a 1993 settlement, Roxbury agreed to amend its waste water treatment plan and to construct water lines and a pumping station to service the project.
Over the last two years, the plan was amended and the construction of the services is to begin soon and be completed in May. In turn, Bukiet lowered the density of the project to its current scale and switched to single-family homes, which Mr. Bukiet said were more marketable.
Gary A. Webb, the township manager, said the lower-density project would have much less of an impact on the community, its municipal services and narrow roads.
IT is also one of several projects that will help Roxbury meet its obligation under the state's Mount Laurel doctrines, which require municipalities to provide housing opportunities for people of all incomes. In response to a suit filed against Roxbury and other Morris County towns by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which ended in a settlement in 1984, the township rezoned for 375 low- and moderate-income units, much of it in high-density town houses, including Bukiet's town house project. Bukiet, rather than build its share of the affordable units, contributed $1.6 million to Roxbury's Affordable Housing Trust Fund, used to finance the construction of such housing.
Despite the delays Mr. Bukiet said his company continued to invest in the Roxbury site -- with, among other expenses, carrying costs and legal fees -- because its natural setting and location make it ideal for housing. It is accessible to Routes 46 and 206 and Interstates 80 and 287 and to the corporate offices alongside them.
The project is proceeding at a time when sales activity in the county, as in the state, has increased as buyers respond to higher but still reasonable mortgage interest rates, stable prices and a strengthening economy. Figures from the Morris County Board of Realtors show that 1,069 existing single-family homes were sold in the second quarter of this year, up from 954 the same time in 1995.
"Morris County has also seen a surge in new construction, which has been slow in the past few years," said Karen N. Smith, manager at the Roxbury office of Weichert Realtors. New homes in western Morris County, which includes Roxbury, cost $209,000 to over $350,000, Mrs. Smith said. Single-family homes remain the housing of choice with those priced to $250,000 drawing the most buyers, she added. "But it all depends on what they are looking for," she said.
According to a recent survey of 3,800 home shoppers by the National Association of Home Builders, today's buyers demand that new homes have at least 2,200 square feet. The survey shows that buyers also want a large kitchen open to a family room and features like nine-foot ceilings and two-car garages -- all of which are incorporated in the homes at Poet's Peak. Burton Appel, based in Union, is the architect.
Gopal Ahluwalia, director of research at the Washington-based builder group, said, "consumers refuse to accept the cookie-cutter designs of the past." They want homes in developments with walking trails, park areas and community centers, he said, adding that builders must respond to remain competitive.
"Everyone understands that it is time to move beyond the simplicity of the 1950's big subdivisions to something more interesting," added Barry Poskanzer, a Ridgewood-based architect. That could mean arranging streets in various patterns to create housing clusters and preserve open space, or blending houses with other uses.
ARCHITECTURALLY, developers are using housing styles like Victorians and design features like porches and shutters to evoke a sense of community. That is the case in Toms River, where Continental Properties of Brick Township is building 28 Victorian-style homes off Route 166 to fit in with those in the surrounding neighborhood and in the historic downtown, a half-mile away. The homes, from 1,640 to 1,803 square feet, cost $125,000 to $181,000.
Baker Residential of Pleasantville, N.Y., is constructing 115 houses at the edge of Cranbury's historic village that are designed to blend with the area's 19th-century character. The homes range from 2,708 to 4,573 square feet and sell from $355,000 to $440,000. In Raritan, the Kalian Companies of Red Bank is building a community of 243 Victorian-style town houses meant to echo the look and character of neighboring Flemington's historic Main Street. The town houses, with 1,700 to 2,100 square feet, sell for $149,000 to $189,000.
As for Poet's Peak, it has been designed to foster a sense of community and to respect the environment, said Thaddeus S. Dudek, a principal at the Parsippany office of Schoor DePalma, an engineering and design firm. It developed the land plan for the project, which last year won awards from the New Jersey Planning Officials and the American Society of Landscape Architects.
The site features open fields, mature woods and rolling hills and is bordered by hundreds of acres of undeveloped land owned by the township. Bukiet has donated 58 acres of its site, including wetlands, which under state law cannot be developed, to the township land. Clusters of woodlands will be left around and between the rest of the site.
The 15 neighborhoods will each have 5 to 20 homes designed to follow the contours of the land.
They will sit on different size lots and will be placed at varying setbacks from the streets, which will bear literary names. The place itself has no literary relationships; the name was chosen by the builder.
Eight different models -- each with three elevations -- including some with porches will be offered.
As a result, Mr. Bukiet said he expected the project to draw a broad group of buyers. He said pre-construction sales would start in the next four weeks.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 3021 words

HEADLINE: Pioneers Wanted; East River Views

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:

2BR, HI FLR, AC, OVRSZ WNDWS, SPECTAC RV VU, INDOR PRKNG, HLTH CLB, TENNIS, ADJ TO PARK, 5 MIN TO GRND CENTRL. $25,000.
NO, that's not a misprint: $25,000, give or take a few thousand, will be the asking price for the well-appointed two-bedroom apartments going on sale this December in a mixed residential-commercial development inspired by Battery Park City. Smaller apartments in this unsubsidized 42-story co-op will go for much less -- under $10,000 for a studio lacking a gonzo view of the East River.
What's the catch? One risk for buyers is that if Queens West doesn't take off they may be stuck with apartments they cannot sell. The site, a largely abandoned industrial swath of the Hunters Point neighborhood of Queens directly opposite the United Nations, is plainly a reach for prospective buyers accustomed to a Starbucks on every corner. And the commercial developers -- a group headed by the Mellon Bank Corporation -- want to break through qualms about living in Queens West by transferring much of the initial risk of ownership from co-op purchasers to the Federal Housing Administration. 
 The developers have arranged for F.H.A. insurance on a mortgage for the co-op building, the first such deal by the Federal agency, which allowed them to obtain the long-term financing to go forward. In order to entice buyers to move into the first building the developers have set prices low, deferring, in effect, the bulk of their hoped-for profits to the buildings that they intend to put up subsequently. Apartment buyers will own their homes after their first payment, but will be responsible for paying down the building's mortgage -- for that apartment purchased for $25,000, the share is estimated at $140,000 -- as part of their monthly maintenance. The bargain-basement prices for buyers is their reward for being pioneers as well as the savings developers are passing along from their innovative financial arrangement.
Indeed, the developers are gambling that the financing, which will make it possible to buy apartments for less than the down payment on comparable space in Manhattan (but leave the co-op with a giant mortgage to service), will more than compensate for the psychic perils of being a pioneer.
If it works as well as the sponsors hope, the "low-equity" financing strategy could influence national housing policy. For it neatly dovetails with the wishes of liberals, who look for the most housing bang from a Government buck, as well as those of conservatives, who emphasize the virtues of owning over renting. Low-equity finance could "create the bridge to homeownership" for cash-poor families in high-cost markets, said Nick Retsinas, the head of the Federal Housing Administration.
The development of Hunters Point, which Queens Borough President Claire Shulman calls "the best site in the City of New York," has been in the works for a decade. In the mid-1980's a group of developers bought or optioned some five and a half acres of land along the East River, with the idea of building condominium apartments with conventional private financing. The city and the Port Authority as well as the state, now represented by the Empire State Development Corporation, had bigger ideas. They planned a mini-city with 2.4 million square feet of office space and 225,000 square feet of commercial space along with 6.4 million square feet of mixed-income housing. But what seemed a no-brainer in the go-go real estate market of the mid-1980's looked like an impossible task as the decade ended in recession.
The city and state hung in, approving a master plan in 1990 that includes 28 acres of open space with a Battery Park-like esplanade by the river. The master plan guiding the development along more than a mile of East River waterfront includes 20 sections, 16 of which have been earmarked for residential development and four for commercial projects, including office buildings and a hotel. New York City is currently investing $30 million in roads, sewers and parks, along with renovating two huge abandoned cargo gantries, as "industrial sculpture."
And the Board of Education has committed to having an early learning center -- kindergarten through second grade for 300 children located in the first residential building -- ready in September 1997. "Everybody is on board," notes Fran Reiter, the deputy mayor for economic planning and development: "Projects this exciting and of this scale only come along a handful of times each century."
Perhaps most important, private development efforts maintained momentum. The developers of the residential building that is now going up raised additional seed capital by expanding the equity partnership to include the Dreyfus Corporation (now part of the Mellon Bank Corporation) and two Japanese corporations.
But something had to be done to make the apartments attractive to potential buyers in a market that had left banks, insurance companies and pension funds wary of all but the safest projects. The developers -- whose partners include Trotwood Corporation, a subsidiary of Mellon, real-estate pros such as Worldwide Holdings and William Zeckendorf Jr., James Wolfenson and two Japanese companies -- toyed with asking the state to approve tax-exempt bonds to finance the first building. But use of this indirect subsidy would have put strict limits on who would be eligible to buy apartments, as well as how much individuals could profit from their resale. And it would undermine the effort to transform Hunters Point into a neighborhood as desirable as choice locales in Manhattan.
THIS left only Washington as a possible source of financial guarantees that would reduce private lenders' risks to acceptable levels and allow the developers to obtain the long-term funding they needed. Ordinarily, the Federal Housing Administration only insures multimillion dollar mortgages for big rental buildings. But the developers noted a way around the convention: there is no law against using Government insurance to obtain private financing, and then quickly convert the finished structure to a co-op. After dealing with the initial shock of being asked to do something for the first time, the F.H.A. became an enthusiastic supporter.
The mortgage insurance for the building, approved in 1995, permitted the building's developers, M.O. Associates (the initials stand for Manhattan Overlook) to borrow $85.6 million from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Housing Investment Trust at attractive rates. The initial two-year construction loan -- a loan which carries little risk, in any case, because it is formally backed by the very deep pockets of the building contractor, Lehrer McGovern Bovis -- is at 8 percent. Thereafter, it becomes a 40-year, self-liquidating mortgage at 7.75 percent.
Now comes the juicy part. Rather than reduce the size of the mortgage with the proceeds from sales of the finished co-ops, M.O. Associates will sell the apartments for what amounts to a developer's fee and leave the co-op with the full F.H.A.-insured mortgage. In effect, the developer is using "wholesale" financing as a substitute for "retail" bank mortgages obtained by individual apartment buyers.
There is no magic here. With most co-ops, shares in the building largely represent equity, and purchasers usually go to banks to raise large sums to purchase them. Here, apartment ownership will require little cash up front, but it will saddle owners with proportionately more debt. However, the arrangement does generate an obvious marketing advantage for the developers -- think of the astoundingly low asking prices -- as well as some genuine financial advantages to apartment buyers.
For one thing, it eliminates the fees and red tape associated with obtaining an individual co-op loan from a bank. For another, it permits greater financial leverage than many middle-income families could otherwise obtain. For example, the co-op shares in an average apartment -- a $25,000 two-bedroom, one-bath unit -- will carry roughly $140,000 of the co-op's mortgage debt. Buyers will be free to reduce their cash outlay still more by borrowing any or all of the purchase price from other sources, including banks.
And while the co-op will have the discretion to reject applicants who lack adequate financial means to cover the monthly maintenance, the developers say they intend to bend over backward to attract New Yorkers now priced out of the Manhattan co-op market.
In the case of that average two-bedroom apartment, an annual income of $52,000 is deemed adequate. "We believe the apartments should be accessible to the firefighters, schoolteachers and cops who work in the city," explained Herbert J. Sturz, president of the Trotwood Corporation, which oversees the investment for Mellon.
Another selling point is that it will cost far less to own an apartment in Queens West than to rent comparable space at market prices in middle-class Manhattan neighborhoods. Consider again the average (two-bedroom, one-bath) 765-square-foot apartment. Monthly maintenance charges, including the paydown of the building's mortgage, are estimated to be $1,295. Because so much of the maintenance will be for mortgage service, that maintenance will be 75 percent tax-deductible. So for a middle-income New Yorker in a combined Federal-state-city 35 percent tax bracket, the after-tax maintenance will run to $955. Figure the after-tax interest income lost on the money that goes into the $25,000 purchase price at, say, 5 percent annually, which comes to $104 a month. Grand total: $1,059 a month.
The developers have also attempted to head off potential buyers' fears of the possibility of sharp rises in projected maintenance charges. At Queens West, the unusually high financial leverage that necessitates high maintenance charges from day one also guarantees that costs will rise far less rapidly than the rate of inflation.
Payments on the self-liquidating mortgage, which initially represent three-quarters of the monthly charge, are based on a fixed interest rate for 40 years and thus do not grow over time. So even if other costs -- energy, repairs, building services -- rose at a distressing 8 percent annually, total maintenance would rise by just 2 percent a year.
The co-op will eventually have to pay New York City real estate taxes when its as-of-right exemption begins to phase out in 20 years and disappears entirely in 25 years. But here, too, the developers have devised a way to shield apartment owners from future shock. For the first 20 years the mortgage payments will be greater than the amount needed to liquidate the principal in 40 years, making it possible to reduce mortgage payments thereafter by the estimated real estate taxes.
Arguably the biggest selling point for buyers, though, is the asymmetry between the potential risks and potential gains of ownership. In the worst-case scenario -- say, a nasty recession that knocked the stuffing out of the New York housing market -- the big building could become an orphan. While the city is committed to providing the riverside promenade as well as crucial infrastructure and the early learning center under any circumstance, development of a residential neighborhood with shops and a vibrant street life -- the master plan eventually envisions more than 6,000 apartments -- might be postponed indefinitely.
WHAT'S more, co-op owners would lose their entire initial investment in the (improbable) event the cost of competitive apartments elsewhere in the city fell below the after-tax maintenance costs at Queens West. And if some apartment owners default and their apartments are left standing vacant, the remaining owners would be left with proportionately larger maintenance costs. In the worst-case scenario, the co-op itself could stop mortgage payments, leaving ownership in the hands of the F.H.A., without any additional liability to individual apartment owners.
But the potential capital losses are more limited than in, say, a mature neighborhood of Manhattan, where a real estate bust that cut apartment values by 20 or 30 percent would cost owners of comparable two-bedroom apartments a lot more than $25,000. By contrast, if New York housing prices and rents remain reasonably strong and the Hunters Point development is completed as planned, pioneer owners could see their equity rise many-fold. It would hardly be unreasonable to find that, once Queens West has achieved critical mass with thousands of middle-class residents, an apartment purchased for $25,000 would sell for $150,000. Comparable units in Chelsea and the northern fringes of the Upper East and West Sides of Manhattan currently sell for more.
To limit absentee ownership that could undermine the fragile sense of community in the big building, a minimum of 70 percent of the initial owners will be required to designate it as their primary residence. To deter speculation that would increase turnover, Queens West will exact a stiff penalty of 50 percent of any profit from secondary sales in the first two years. This "flip tax" will be phased out thereafter, disappearing entirely after 10 years when the neighborhood will presumably have matured.
In the end, of course, this intricate financial package will not induce potential buyers to put down roots if the apartments don't mesh with their tastes. And here, the developers have walked the line between amenity and cost containment.
Location is plainly Queens West's best and worst feature. The river views -- 90 percent of the apartments have them -- range for good to jaw-dropping. And transportation could hardly be more convenient. The Vernon-Jackson station on the Number 7 subway line is two blocks away, and just one stop to Grand Central. Private ferry service to 36th Street in Manhattan is now available three blocks to the south at rush hour, and should become more frequent once Queens West is open for business. There will be secure indoor parking available (at market price -- perhaps $150 a month) to every resident.
Along with the early learning center the building will have a health club for residents, complete with two tennis courts on the deck of the garage (but no swimming pool, since a large public pool is planned for the Queens West complex). Some 13,000 square feet has also been set aside for commerce -- a restaurant, perhaps, or a few convenience stores. However, until more buildings go up, residents will have to leave the neighborhood for much of their shopping.
This first building, designed by Cesar Pelli, the architect of the World Financial Center, is more distinctive than the postwar slabs lining Manhattan's residential avenues. The interior space, designed by Peter Claman, will also have some flair. Windows are considerably bigger and ceilings, at 8 feet 4 inches, a bit higher than is typical in new construction. Room sizes are generous by current ungenerous standards with standard one-bedrooms between 620 and 697 square feet, two-bedrooms between 734 and 849 square feet and three-bedroom apartments with terraces between 1,037 and 1,115. And, of course, few apartment buildings can boast of a riverside esplanade outside the front door.
No matter how attractive the apartments may be, pioneer living isn't for everyone. Meredith Kane, a lawyer at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison and a former director of the home ownership program in the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, notes that Queens West "is certainly not for people who want to live in a place that looks like the neighborhood they grew up in." The best candidates, she suggests, are "young families in search of more space" and "those in New York with their first job who want an easy commute to Manhattan."
Richard Kahan, the former chairman of the Battery Park City Authority and president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, warns that, in the early stages of development "this won't be a great neighborhood for the elderly." The big winners, he says, are likely to be "the bargain hunters -- the people for whom ownership outweighs the inconveniences of being first."
WHILE the developers are not eager to share specifics, they acknowledge that the first building has, by default, become a loss leader. They don't expect a profit even if the first building sells out completely.
However if the apartments sell briskly, M.O. Associates will move quickly to obtain conventional financing for three additional buildings on the land they control in Queens West, selling as many as another 978 units -- the maximum allowed in the master plan -- at more generous profit margins.
If the development succeeds and the low-equity purchase financing being used in the first building is judged to have made the breakthrough possible, its boosters say, it may well be imitated by developers in other neighborhoods and other cities.
That would certainly please Mr. Retsinas at the Federal Housing Administration. "One of F.H.A.'s primary roles is to help the pioneers," he explains.
Mr. Sturz, a former chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, would like to see the low-equity finance formula applied to low-to-moderate income housing. He envisions co-ops built on abandoned or donated inner-city land, with financing subsidized with tax-exempt bonds. This, he calculates, would make it possible to sell multibedroom units for less than $10,000 and to service the mortgage for substantially less than market-rate rents. "I'm thinking about housing that would be affordable for a family making $30,000," he said.
For the moment, though, the name of the game is selling the first 522 apartments at Hunters Point -- and selling them rapidly, once the formal offering plan is accepted by the New York State Attorney General's office, which is expected to happen in December. A quick sell-out would probably allow Hunters Point to shed the stigma "pioneer neighborhood," a prospect pleasing to boosters of the city's boroughs beyond Manhattan.
"Why," asks Gov. George E. Pataki, "should people in New Jersey get the best views of Manhattan?"

HEADLINE: Once Upon a Time, When High Schools Were Palaces

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
NINETY years ago, an enormous Beaux Arts building went up on a hill overlooking the Hudson River. It had Corinthian columns, terrazzo floors and a vestibule lined with English marble. It could have passed for a palace, or at least a palatial estate.
But it was neither. It was, in fact, William L. Dickinson High School, the first public secondary school in Jersey City. It was the pet project of Mayor Mark Fagan, a "New Idea" Republican who was elected in 1901 and wanted a "handsome, substantial" school building that would be "a good advertisement for the city." 
 He also wanted the high school, named after the city's first Superintendent of Schools, to be open to the communityidea is catching on again today.
"Cities were building these massive public buildings, democratic in design, to show how egalitarian Americans were," said Barbara Petrick, a social studies teacher at Dickinson who is the school's unofficial historian. "They wanted to make the point that whether you were destined to be a workman or a professional, everyone was entitled to this kind of education."
When it opened in 1906, Dickinson had a 2,000-seat auditorium used not just for school functions but for political debates, plays and concerts. Helen Keller lectured there, and Presidents Taft, Wilson and Roosevelt all held political rallies under the stained-glass ceiling. A branch of the Jersey City Public Library opened in Dickinson, which also housed one of the state's first night schools.
Enrollment climbed quickly after Dickinson opened, and by 1910, it had more than doubled to more than 2,000. The city was also becoming an industrial hub, so in 1912, an addition was built that doubled the school's size. The new section had industrial and vocational classrooms, a foundry and a print shop.
Ms. Petrick said the school cost $1.5 million --an exorbitant sum for a school in those days -- most of which came from railroad and business-tax revenues, which increased under Mayor Fagan.
"The money was available because the city's business economy was at its most prosperous," she said.
The architect was John T. Rowland, a Jersey City native who also designed Jersey City Medical Center, the Jersey Journal building, the Labor Bank building and more than two dozen other schools. In 1933, he designed a $630,000 annex to Dickinson that housed a swimming pool, gymnasium and cafeteria.
In the 1980's, Ms. Petrick said, the overcrowded school was covered with graffiti and crumbling. But a $30 million renovation is under way, and so far the roof and facade have been repaired, the graffiti and several smokestacks removed and a sprinkler system added. Ms. Petrick said the school, with 2,700 students, is in better shape than many newer ones.
"It's built like the Rock of Gibraltar," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Part of the concrete and iron gate that guards William L. Dickinson High School. (Julio A. Ibarra Jr. for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 2322 words

HEADLINE: To Build a School

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: LEMINGTON

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY'S newest elementary school crouches among the fields here, barely visible from the road. It is long and low, with wide hallways and classrooms around a grassy courtyard. But the things that set the Copper Hill School apart from older schools -- a geothermal heating system, for example, and 40 miles of wiring to support a sophisticated computer network -- are invisible to residents of this town, who are footing the $14 million bill.
The design of Copper Hill contrasts sharply with those of schools built in the past, when educators, architects and New Jersey taxpayers -- who have the power to defeat school construction plans in bond referendums -- had different priorities. It is subtle and practical, from the earth-colored concrete facade to the heating system that does not use fossil fuels to the extra rooms for adult education and day care. The fanciest feature is the computer network, which will connect every room to the Internet and allow students to communicate with others around the state and the world. 
 In comparison, schools built in the first half of the century were more interesting to look at, with pillars, gabled roofs and stone carvings that created an aura of grandeur. In the 1950's the postwar baby boom caused an explosion in school construction, with little thought given to design or curriculum needs. In the 1970's the oil crisis made efficient heating a priority, and many schools were built with no windows.
These days, everyone involved in school design agrees that programming needs, not just for students but for the community as a whole, should be the top priority. But since school budgets in New Jersey are always tight, tough choices must be made. Through numerous public meetings, school officials eliminate possibilities that might be seen as excessive. Stages are often vetoed, for example, as are swimming pools and most kinds of ornamentation.
"You have to stay on a flexible, functional design, or it's probably not going to be accepted," said Scott R. Spiezle, whose Trenton architectural firm designed Copper Hill. "In other states, I have seen schools with waterfalls, huge aquariums, gorgeous design elements. But I don't believe the public in New Jersey is willing to pay for these things."
What the public is willing to pay for these days, architects and school officials say, are spaces that will accommodate residents of all ages, at all hours of the day. In cities and suburbs, school buildings are becoming community hubs where the elderly can use the library, middle-aged adults can take evening classes and children of working parents can stay for after-school programs. If a new school offers perks for the whole community, they say, it might appeal to childless residents who would otherwise fight it.
"We are undergoing tremendous changes in the nature of family and community life," said Roy Strickland, director of the New American School Design Project at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "Schools should be thinking about providing services for everyone from very young children to older adults, from early morning into evening."
With enrollments climbing fast in much of the state -- Flemington and the rest of Hunterdon County, in particular, are experiencing a population boom -- school designers are making buildings flexible enough to accommodate growing class sizes and untraditional schedules. For the many school districts that are considering year-round classes, air-conditioning is no longer optional. Some new schools have folding walls between classrooms, and others have separate cafeterias and gymnasiums, to accommodate lunch periods that start as early as 9:45 A.M.
Meanwhile, technology is changing the most basic elements of school design. Fluorescent lights, which cause glare on computer screens, are being replaced with softer, indirect lighting. Libraries are becoming "media centers," with less space allotted for shelves and more for computers, which can store every reference book and periodical on CD-ROM. Teacher lounges are now known as "work spaces," and along with sagging couches, they have computers, conference tables and phones with voice mail.
To complicate the planning process, new schools must comply with dozens of state and Federal mandates, a fire code and energy-efficiency ratios. Ceiling height, space between desks and wall thickness are strictly regulated, and plans must go through several stages of approval. All of these requirements, along with the directive to spend frugally, make it easy to overlook what is perhaps the most important question of all: What kind of impression will a new school make on the people who will spend their formative years there?
Certain details will linger in their minds long after they move on: the feel of the brick facade when they lean against it; the color of the classroom walls; the way sunlight filters through the windows and sounds echo through the halls. Mr. Strickland of M.I.T. says architects need to make schools more comfortable for the children who spend long hours there.
"If you look at the plan of a nicely designed house, there are large spaces for shared activities, as well as more private alcoves for people to be alone," he said. "Schools need to become more homelike."
 
ORIGINS
Wood and Spitoons
Historians say the first school in New Jersey was built in 1662, in a Dutch settlement that is now part of Jersey City. By the early 1800's, dozens of one-room schoolhouses were scattered around the state.
But towns did not start using tax dollars to build free public schools until the 1840's, when special acts of the State Legislature allowed some localities to raise money for school construction. Newark, Camden, Jersey City and Bridgeton were among the first to have graded public schools, which were typically made of brick and shaped like boxes.
The first public high school opened in Newark in 1855, and others followed in Paterson, Plainfield, Orange and New Brunswick. In 1876, the State Constitution guaranteed a free public education for every child, with a State School Fund to help with the cost. But until the turn of the century, tiny schoolhouses were the norm, and many were in poor condition.
"The floors are broken through, and the children cluster in the corner during rain storms, and shiver as wintry blasts whistle through," wrote Charles Morrow, the schools superintendent in Wantage, Sussex County, in 1864. "Floors answer for spitoons and they are well used by teachers and pupils; furniture rude and sadly cut up."
Such problems were so widespread that in 1865, the State Superintendent of Schools circulated designs to help towns build more durable schools. By 1874, the Superintendent's annual report included suggestions for 23 types of school buildings, with simple square classrooms, desks bolted to floors,and bell towers that held ventilation shafts.
By the turn of the century, schools were being modeled after other public buildings, like city halls and post offices, with facades in Greek Revival, Queen Anne and other traditional styles. The top floor was usually an assembly hall, and the others held only classrooms. Gymnasiums did not become common until the 1920's, and libraries and cafeterias came even later.
In 1996, 64 of New Jersey's 2,300 school buildings are more than a century old, which means that thousands of children are making do with archaic floor plans, outdoor gym classes and lunch hours held in basements or wherever they will fit. But it also means, school officials say, that the older buildings are much more durable than their midcentury counterparts.
In Fairview, Bergen County, 250 elementary school students still attend Public School No. 3, built in 1908. The district recently spent $1 million to replace the windows, heating system and lighting, and the third-floor assembly hall has been converted to classrooms. The basement serves as a cafeteria and rainy-day gym, but the rest of the school remains untouched.
"That place is built like a fort," said Patrick Caufield, the business administrator, adding that the inside walls are two feet thick and the brick facade has never needed a facelift. "It's not going anywhere."
 
BABY BOOM
Sprawling Conformity
By the 1950's, suburban school districts were in dire need of extra space, and they were building dozens of new schools every year. These Baby Boom schools were built quickly and inexpensively to accommodate new neighborhoods in counties like Middlesex, Monmouth and Somerset. Unlike their predecessors, they were usually sprawling, one-story buildings, with flat roofs, painted cinder block walls, and wings that could fit dozens of classrooms.
Fifty percent of the nation's public schools were built in the 1950's and 60's, including hundreds of New Jersey's suburban schools. More than 400 elementary schools were built in New Jersey from 1953 to 1962. Instead of brick, facades were often made of glass and metal panels, and windows were trimmed with flimsy aluminum. Roofs were flat, and layouts were often so confusing that it was (and still is) hard to find the main entrance.
"The suburbs back then were homogeneous environments with homogeneous families," said Mr. Strickland, the M.I.T. professor. "Boards of education were responding to that with homogeneous schools, plunked down smack in the middle of the community."
Inside the schools, though, some of the innovations of the 1950's and 60's were important. Desks were no longer fixed to the floors, and many elementary classrooms had library nooks and art corners. School libraries were more common, as were classrooms equipped for industrial arts and home economics.
Many postwar schools had classrooms painted in colors that many students now consider mind-numbing; washed-out greens and yellows seem to have been especially popular. But at the time, they caused mild excitement. A 1958 article in a New Jersey newspaper praised the "color engineers" who designed Watchung Hills Regional and Millburn High Schools. In the former, one classroom had typewriters in "sea-foam green," "desert sand" and "sapphire gray." In the latter, even the administrative offices were painted in ever-so-subtle pastels.
When the principal and his assistant inspected their new offices, the article said, "they found the walls a dreamy blue, the sample swatches labeled 'Wedgwood.' "
Pablo L. Jordan, a Raritan architect who has designed schools for 30 years, said many schools built in the 1970's "took color too far in the other direction," with walls painted orange and red. Now, he said, the trend is toward muted colors again, although sleepy yellows and greens remain unthinkable, Mr. Jordan said. Schools that have kept those colors have higher vandalism rates than those with taupes, beiges and grays, he said.
Starting in the late 1960's, when forward-thinking educators were calling for open classrooms and team teaching, some school designs verged on wacky. Some New Jersey schools built in that period were circular, with wide-open spaces instead of separate classrooms. Architects say those schools are partitioning up their inside space now, but the oddly shaped classrooms that result can cause problems. Today's taxpayers do not suffer such eccentric designs gladly, and for good reason, Mr. Strickland said.
"A lot of it," he said, "comes down to common sense."
 
NEW AGE
Community Clubhouse
James Gamble, the principal at the Copper Hill School, could not agree more. He offered suggestions for the building several years ago, with input from parents, teachers and other administrators. Technology was the top priority, he said, followed by rooms for community use.
As for the building itself, the school district wanted what Mr. Spiezle, the architect, calls "basic finishes": concrete-block walls, drop ceilings and vinyl floor tiles. The building looks nice, Mr. Gamble said, but he was more eager to talk about the front hallway, which is wide enough to drive a school bus through.
"We had a carnival in the hall a few weeks ago," he said. "There were a few hundred people milling around. In the hallway!"
Mr. Pease, the Raritan architect, says wide halls provide an extra common space, which is crucial when enrollment is up and space is tight. It also makes a school more comfortable, he said, as do courtyards with benches, and alcoves where students can relax.
"We're doing more areas for students to enjoy themselves," he said.
Although many educators are calling for smaller, more intimate schools, the numerous New Jersey towns that face enrollment booms do not have that option. Copper Hill has room for 900 students, and it is already up to 650. In Warren County, the tiny town of Pohatcong is building an elementary school big enough for 1,000 students, because its population is expected to triple over the next decade.
But large schools can be subdivided into smaller "pods" that feel more intimate, architects say. At Copper Hill, the kindergarten classrooms are isolated in an octagonal wing, with a separate playground and a common area in the middle. The gymnasium has a folding wall that can create smaller spaces, as do several classrooms.
The school has some distinctive touches, but each serves its purpose. Skylights in the hallway allow natural light to filter in, and pillars out front support a pavilion that shields students from rain.
But if school buildings are going to serve as second homes and community clubhouses, perhaps the most meaningful details will be contributed by the people who spend time there. At Copper Hill, some classrooms have soft throw rugs, rocking chairs and couches. Already, the concrete walls are replete with essays that reveal students' hopes, dreams and favorite foods.
And the other day, when a noisy group of budding athletes did jumping jacks in that wide front hallway, the echo was just about right.
