HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;
New Signals in Cable Deal

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
Since 1993, Chinese immigrants who have Time Warner cable television service in Queens and Brooklyn have enjoyed access to Chinese-language programs provided 24 hours a day by the Chinese Communication Channel. But a dispute between the company and Time Warner may jeopardize some of their favorite shows.
Barry Rosenblum, president of Time Warner Cable of New York City, said the company had decided to replace Chinese Communication, which is seen on Channel 78, with Sino Television of Manhattan after it failed to honor contractual and financial obligations, a charge Chinese Communication disputes. 
 "They owed us $480,000 for over a year and we just don't feel they have the financial strength to continue," Mr. Rosenblum said.
But for many Chinese, the decision is seen as part of a never-ending power struggle between factions sympathetic to China or Taiwan. Although the owners of both companies are from Taiwan and say they maintain neutrality, Arthur Liu, of Sino Television, is seen by many as more sympathetic to China, and Chinese Communication, a corporation with headquarters in Flushing, more sympathetic to Taiwan.
Those who support Chinese Communication fear that Sino will increase the amount of mainland programming on Channel 78. Its current fare includes Taiwanese opera, a Chinese-produced soap opera, movies from Hong Kong and CNN Headline News, tramslated into Chinese. Mr. Liu, who still does not have a contract with Time Warner, says a programming schedule has not yet been set. Sino is entitled to buy the rights to most of the shows that have been offered by Chinese Communication, but Mr. Liu has said that mainland programming would cost him only about a third of what he would pay for Taiwanese or Hong Kong programs.
Mr. Rosenblum said his company's decision was purely economic. In 1993, the Chinese Communication Channel leased the station for $60,000 a month. But several months into the operation, the company asked Time Warner to reduce the rate, citing the lack of advertising revenue. When Time Warner refused, Chinese Communication began withholding payments.
Under an agreement reached last fall, Chinese Communication was to become a premium channel by January 1996, and would share a subscription fee with Time Warner. The agreement also stipulated that if Chinese Communication paid its debt by last December, Time Warner would forgive its obligations from January 1996 to August. But the channel never went premium.
Raymond Wang, executive vice president of the Chinese Communication Channel, blamed Time Warner for the dispute and said his company had sued it to remain on Channel 78.
A spokeswoman for Time Warner, Harriet Novet, said she would not comment on specific charges before the case went to court. It is to go to trial in mid-October. JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: So English. So Stylish. And, Yes, So Expensive.;
From the Looks Of It, It's the Year of the Cat

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
FEW of the many cars that I test-drive each year, except for some oddities like the AM General Hummer and the Oscar Mayer Weinermobile, actually stop traffic. But the 1997 Jaguar XK8 created such a stir wherever we went that I feared it might literally result in bloodshed.
As I waited to turn onto a busy street, drivers of three cars in a row stomped on the brakes and stared. This happened on my first day with the stunning new Jaguar, and the scene was repeated often during a weeklong test drive. Once, after meeting a lovely British roadster of the same royal blue as my XK8 coupe, I watched in the rear-view mirror as the passing driver twisted his head for a second glance. I was afraid he was going to rear-end the car in front of him. 
 The XK8, available as a coupe or convertible, replaces the recently retired XJS, the British company's longest-running and best-selling sports car. But the XK8 is far more modern, benefiting greatly from the deep pockets and the manufacturing and technical expertise of its parent, the Ford Motor Company. Indeed, the XK8 would not exist were it not for Ford's purchase of Jaguar in 1989. Likewise, another venerable British sports car maker in dire straits, Aston Martin, has regrouped under Ford and developed a rarefied cousin of the XK8, the DB7.
Jaguar's adoption had raised fears that its new models would be thinly disguised Fords, with another grand old name turned into little more than a marketing tool. But my week with the XK8 left me convinced that this sporting, sophisticated automobile is supremely worthy of the snarling-cat emblem on its hood.
In designing this beauty, Jaguar designers set out to link the XK8 to past Jaguars but not to build a nostalgic replica. "The heritage of good design is like DNA," Jaguar's styling director, Geoff Lawson, has said. "It must be traceable through history, but not necessarily an exact duplicate."
During my fling with the XK8 coupe, Jaguar aficionados scrutinized its styling cues the way people examine the family traits of newborns. "She has her mother's nose, but her father's eyes," they seemed to say.
The oval grille opening, the prominent headlamps, the styled wheels and the manner in which the fenders swell to meet the hood recall Jaguar race cars of the past, like those that won the 24 Hours of Le Mans each year from 1954 to 1957. The XK8's long, lean body -- at 187 inches, a full 10 inches longer than a Mercedes-Benz SL -- along with its low-to-the-ground profile and extended hood, invite comparisons with many classic Jaguars. The front and rear are reminiscent of the E-type, the work-of-art sports car that first appeared at the Geneva Motor Show in 1961; a convertible version was added this year to the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, only the third automobile to be so honored.
As sexy as its lines may be, my favorite part of the XK8 is the interior. This is surely the most sumptuous cabin of any car I have driven. I reveled in its rich, warm ambiance. Words like "exquisite" and "sensuous" come to mind. A slab of highly polished burled walnut stretches across the instrument panel from door to door. The same lustrous wood alternates on the steering wheel with the creamy Connolly leather used for the upholstery. The shift knob on the familiar Jaguar J-shaped gear selector also is polished wood. The XK8's gauges, including an analog clock, are deeply recessed into the instrument panel.
The seats look splendid, and they are splendidly comfortable. Simple in design, they narrow toward the top, providing excellent lateral support but giving the shoulders free movement. The steering wheel tilts and telescopes electrically, and multiple power seat adjustments make it easy to find a comfortable seating position.
Driving the XK8, I envisioned myself behind the wheel of a two-seater, even though there is a rear seat -- with absolutely no legroom -- and a trunk far larger than those of any roadster, or any of its coupe competitors, for that matter.
Looking out across the elongated hood, I had a commanding sense of the road, yet a safe separateness from the harsh outside world. The XK8 has the safety equipment one expects in a luxury automobile, including pre-tensioners that tighten the slack of the lap and shoulder belts in a crash.
Just as significant as the car's style is what's under its long hood: Jaguar's first V8 engine, replacing the XJS's in-line 6 and V12. The 4.0-liter engine -- developed by Jaguar, not Ford -- is rated at 290 horsepower and is paired with a five-speed electronic automatic transmission. The fifth-gear overdrive helps to raise the fuel economy to 17 city and 25 highway, and indeed the Jaguar's mileage is high enough to avoid the Federal gas-guzzler tax.
Standard are anti-lock brakes and an "automatic stability control" that adjusts power to slipping wheels. Traction control, which adds automatic braking when wheels spin, is optional.
The powertrain produces the powerful performance of a sports car with the refinement of a luxury car. And the XK8 is on par in every way -- acceleration, top speed and braking -- with the very competent competitors in its class. Yet it is substantially lighter than its counterparts from Mercedes and BMW, making it feel more nimble.
With a base price for the coupe of $65,480, including shipping, and about $5,000 more for the convertible, the XK8 is indeed costly, but it does seem worth every penny. Its chief competitors cost tens of thousands of dollars more.
For all its greatness, the new Jag has its quirks and flaws. The ignition switch is so low that the key fob dangles against the knee. The steering seemed slightly off-center. The front and rear defrosters leave much to be desired. With four occupants, the windows remained cloudy for the entire early-morning drive to and from pre-school.
And the quality of the fit and finish could have been better on the early-production test car. The anchor for the rear seat belt broke, revealing an ugly tear in the upholstery underneath, and the lid covering the front dual cup holders, in the shape of a heart, didn't fit as it should have.
But I'm willing to overlook the XK8's minor flaws. It stole my heart.
On the last day I had possession of the Jaguar, I longed for a few more hours. The open road beckoned. I closed the door -- the windows automatically raised the last quarter-inch to lock into the top seal and shut out the madding world. Speeding across twisty country roads in midday with the XK8 enticing me to push it harder, I felt as if I were skipping school. The day was glorious; the Jaguar was divine.
 
INSIDE TRACK: A sleek feline worthy of its impressive pedigree.

LENGTH: 841 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
How Much To Pay for Security?

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to auto insurance, one of the more perplexing decisions is whether to buy coverage against theft and vandalism.
Unlike liability insurance, protection against theft and vandalism is not mandatory. So the key question becomes: Does it make economic sense? 
 Especially in urban areas, like New York, plenty of car owners have decided it doesn't because of the high cost. But they know they are at risk of losing a valuable asset. And people who do pay for the coverage lament the costly premiums.
Now Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is up for re-election as New York Mayor next year, has taken up the cudgels on behalf of car owners, exclaiming that since his police force has driven down auto theft by 51 percent, the cost of comprehensive coverage, which includes theft and vandalism protection, should take a similar dive. State insurance officials say premiums have declined somewhat, but not as much as thefts because most New Yorkers don't carry comprehensive insurance in the first place and the benefits are thus not accruing to insurers.
But the Mayor is unrelenting. Last Thursday, he told a State Senate hearing in Manhattan that the cost of comprehensive simply must become more affordable. Right now, it can cost 10 times more in New York than in rural America.
Whether or not the Mayor succeeds in his insurance campaign, car owners debating the usefulness of theft coverage will find they fall into one of three categories. If they have new, expensive cars, they can hardly think of doing without comprehensive coverage. If the car is financed, as is usually the case, the lender requires such coverage to protect his investment. Meanwhile, owners of real clunkers routinely skip comprehensive coverage because the car's value is so little.
The decision becomes tricky for the owners of cars that have been on the road for a few years. As a rule of thumb, Consumer's Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports, recommends that car owners consider dropping comprehensive coverage on cars that are four or five years old and that have a replacement value of, say, less than $10,000.
"Often you'd do better with an older car by setting up a kind of self-insurance fund," said Bill Ahern, an analyst for Consumer's Union, "just putting into a money market the money you'd be paying in annual premiums. In places where comprehensive is expensive, you might end up setting aside the value of the car in four or five years. If you'd bought insurance and nothing happened to your car, the money would just be gone."
Across the country, three-quarters of car owners buy comprehensive coverage. Mr. Ahern says many probably could do without it. Car owners usually go over their insurance needs with an agent when they take out a policy, he said, and automatically renew every year without making adjustments.
"As the car ages, people should be asking, 'Do I really need the comprehensive?' " he said. "But they don't look at the policy again."
Only 38 percent of motorists in New York buy comprehensive coverage. In the cities of New Jersey the rate is even lower: 20 percent.
A big reason that urbanites don't buy comprehensive coverage, said Sean Mooney, an economist at the Insurance Information Institute, is that after paying the high cost of the required insurance, they don't want to dig further into their pockets. New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and most other states require car owners to buy liability insurance, which pays for injuries or damages to other drivers and their cars. Drivers in the three-state area are also required to have insurance that pays for injuries to themselves or people in their vehicles.
New York ranks among the most expensive areas in the country for both the required and the optional comprehensive insurance, Mr. Mooney said.
"It's the bumper-car factor, the density of traffic," he said. "The more cars you have, the more accidents you have. That means more damage to people and cars and, therefore, higher insurance rates."
Furthermore, medical care and auto repairs cost more in urban areas, while city people tend to sue more than others. Some city people simply opt to drive old clunkers that they consider unlikely to be stolen.
In Brooklyn, a 35-year-old man might pay more than $1,400 a year for the mandated auto insurance for a five-year-old Ford Taurus, valued at about $8,000. To buy comprehensive coverage, he would pay as much as $2.000 more a year, gaining protection against theft and vandalism, as well as fire and damage from falling trees and hail.
John Calagna, a spokesman for the New York State Insurance Department, and Mr. Ahern advise against buying comprehensive in such cases because the premium represents such a high percentage of the car's value.
In rural California, where auto theft is much less common, the comprehensive portion of an auto policy may seem a steal at a cost of as little as $200 a year. "But you may actually be throwing your money away," Mr. Ahern said, "because the odds of having your car stolen there are so low."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%);

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE

 BODY:
A State Supreme Court judge has rejected the rent increase Metropolitan Life imposed last year for the 147,000 defective windows the company installed three years ago at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the sprawling middle-income projects it owns on First Avenue between 14th to 23d Streets. Justice Herman Cahn last week ordered the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal to re-examine Met Life's application for a rent hike based on the $30 million it spent on new double-paned windows, which began to implode shortly after their installation in the two complexes, which together have 110 buildings. "This victory bolsters the notion that people shouldn't have to pay for broken and defective merchandise," said Jack Lester, an attorney representing the tenants. Metropolitan Life says it plans to appeal the decision. In the meantime, residents will not have to pay the estimated 6 percent rent increase. 
 Two Lower East Side cultural centers won a reprieve last week when the city-owned buildings they occupy were taken off the auction block. The city had planned to sell the abandoned Gothic schoolhouse at 107 Suffolk Street, which houses the Clemente Soto Velez Cultural and Educational Center, and a building at 605 East Ninth Street occupied by El Bohio Cultural Center. The centers rent the spaces from the city. "There was a tremedous outpouring of support by the community and elected officials," said Jack Deacy, a spokesman for City Hall.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
From Beer to Prozac, Perks Abound

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

 BODY:
SURE, there is a health plan for employees at Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc., but it probably doesn't make anyone feel better on the way out the door at night. That is what the ice cream is for: three pints, fresh from the freezer, free, for everyone, every day.
That's a lot of ice cream. Some employees just can't eat it all, but have found another way to tap its value. They barter their pints around town, in South Burlington, Vt., for haircuts or baby-sitting. 
 This kind of perk, tantalizing to 12-year-olds, works well with adults, too. Everyone knows about the serious, obvious perks -- airlines let employees fly for next to nothing, department stores give minimum-wage clerks a discount on clothing and such. But it is often the small displays of company largess that make employees feel as if they are getting something for nothing. Depending on whom they work for, employees may receive everything from free hamburgers to free Prozac.
For starters, there's free beer. Anheuser-Busch employees receive vouchers for two cases a month. It's the same at Pete's Wicked Brewing Company in Palo Alto, Calif., brewers of Pete's Wicked Ale, and at the Boston Beer Company, which makes Samuel Adams. But these two also show some small-company flexibility: at Boston Beer, said Lucy Sholley, a spokeswoman, "if someone has a party they can get a few extra cases."
Pete's encourages employees to go to what a spokeswoman, calls "local beer events"; they can be reimbursed for a taxi home, too.
Robert Mondavi, the Napa Valley winemaker, gives each employee a case of wine at the end of every quarter, and the wine tastings at work "are so regular I don't even consider them perks," said Susanne Bergstrom, a spokeswoman. Workers with desk jobs can go out at harvest time to learn about picking and crushing, and, Ms. Bergstrom said, "some employees have gone on group trips to Europe, to visit Bordeaux and stuff."
Rubbermaid Inc. gives employees "rubber bucks" for a job well done. The bucks can be redeemed for goods at company stores. ("You can never have enough Servin' Savers," said Lorrie Crum, a spokeswoman for the company.)
At the Gap, employees who have babies receive a package of items from Baby Gap stores. Workers at Benjamin Moore & Company get paint at wholesale prices, and starting next year the company will select two employees and send crews to paint their houses for free.
"I think paint is one of the great things in life," said Eileen McComb, a spokeswoman for Benjamin Moore.
At Eli Lilly & Company, employees can get free Prozac: The health plan covers 100 percent of prescription drugs made by Lilly, while requiring a 20 percent co-payment on others.
And in this service economy, free stuff isn't everything. At the Great American Backrub stores in New York, the company's product, a massage, is free to the employees.
Rodale Press, publisher of Runner's World, Prevention, Organic Gardening and other health-related magazines and books, dispenses free health and fitness. At the gym on the company's campus in Emmaus, Pa., employees can choose from 25 classes, including aerobics, ballroom dancing and yoga. The company charters buses to take its runner-employees to races, pays their entry fees and puts them up in hotels if necessary.
For one big race in Manhattan, Rodale provides carbohydrates in the form of a seven-course dinner at the Supreme Macaroni Company. Workers can also rent bikes, fly-fishing equipment, snowshoes, scuba gear and in-line skates at $2 to $5 for a weekend.
THEN there's food. Domino's workers can order pizza at 35 percent off and receive a discount in the cafeteria at the company's headquarters in Ann Arbor, Mich.
Out in the franchises of McDonald's, most operators allow workers one small sandwich for a short shift, one big sandwich for a full shift. But McDonald's employees at the company headquarters don't get to eat free. They have to pay retail at the on-site outlet at the company campus in Oak Brook, Ill.
At the headquarters of Subway sandwich shops in Milford, Conn., employees eat free, getting, well, Subway fare, for both breakfast and lunch in the cafeteria.
"We don't just eat all day, so here's another thing," said Michele Klotzer, a spokeswoman. "Fred DeLuca, our owner, is a big movie fan, and once a month we go to a local movie theater, each employee and a guest, and see a recent film." This month, she said, it will be the new Tom Hanks movie, "That Thing You Do!"
Not all company perks can be easily shared with a friend.
Along with all the fitness-related perks, Rodale Press employees receive compost. The company sends wastepaper from its cafeteria to the town's leaf-composting facility, which allows Rodale employees to pick up the product free.
"I know it sounds funny, talking about compost as a perk," said Bob Martin, a company spokesman. "But if you're doing your yard, you know, you need tons of that stuff, and it adds up."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
First-Rate Returns on Third-World Bond Funds

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON

 BODY:
CAN emerging-markets debt stage a three-peat?
Fixed-income mutual funds that specialize in Brady bonds and other debt of third-world nations were top performers in this year's second quarter, and they led the taxable fixed-income category again in the third, with double-digit advances. The reasons for that success, though, make it increasingly unlikely they can continue to outperform. 
 "These are bonds, not stocks," said Barton M. Biggs, global market strategist for Morgan Stanley. "It's statistically impossible for this asset class to do in the future what it's done in the recent past."
A torrid rally in third-world debt has seen the interest-rate premium that investors have demanded over United States Treasury bonds shrink to about 6 percentage points, on average, from 19 points at the market's nadir in March 1995, according to Mr. Biggs. With bond prices varying inversely to yields, values have doubled since the low, with 40 percent of those gains coming in the last 12 months.
To have them double again, investors would have to decide that third-world bonds were more secure than United States Government debt. That likelihood is zero.
But many experts say further advances are more than just possible.
"I wouldn't expect that the party's over," said Jim Forest, associate editor of the Bond Fund Report in Ashland, Mass. The devaluation of the Mexican peso, which precipitated the market's collapse in December 1994, was so unexpected that it sent investors reeling, and the result was a selling panic. But subsequent events have demonstrated resiliency in a number of underdeveloped nations, making their debt seem much less risky than it appeared a year ago, he said.
"It's a bit too early to give up on emerging-markets debt," said Simon Treacher, who manages $850 million of such securities for Morgan Grenfell Investment Services Ltd. in London. "The demand side is increasing. I see more and more interest in investing in emerging-markets debt as an asset class."
Emerging-market debt occupies a small and little-known corner of the fixed-income market, with a total market capitalization of about $180 billion, according to Morgan Stanley. Issuers are clustered primarily in Eastern Europe and Latin America. To overcome concerns about credit quality, currency translations and political risk, nations like Mexico and Argentina typically offer high long-term yields, on the order of 8 percent to 11 percent, according to Salomon Brothers Emerging Markets Research.
About $140 billion of this market, or more than three-quarters, is in Brady bonds, the United States-backed debt securities created at the end of the 1980's as part of the restructuring of Mexico's overwhelming foreign debt load. Mounting concerns about Mexico's debt problems prompted the Treasury, under then-Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, to step in to offer United States guarantees.
This assurance that principal would be repaid provided the foundation that led to the market's recovery, and Brady bonds have been used in other emerging markets since then. The bonds now represent, for instance, 83 percent of the portfolio of Bear Stearns Emerging Markets Debt Portfolio.
Unlike the bank loans they replaced, Brady bonds are "legal securities, which means liquidity goes up dramatically," said Ed Vaimberg, who manages a total of $60 million in two Bear Stearns emerging-market debt funds.
"They've become a very effective way for a broader array of investors to enter these countries," he said.
But liquidity isn't the only positive this market has enjoyed in the last year. Mexico itself has begun retiring Brady issues early with lower-yielding, uncollateralized debt of its own.
"We're seeing improving fundamentals in many of the countries, most of which have strengthened their economic reforms," said John Carlson, who manages a total of $670 million in seven emerging-market fixed-income funds at Fidelity Investments.
The return of confidence to the market is nowhere more obvious than in Russia. Its Vnesh series of restructured debts -- named for the Vnesh Ekonom Bank -- have doubled in the last year, despite the political uncertainty of the Russian elections earlier this year and, now, the health of President Boris Yeltsin.
Venezuela and Panama have also been leaders in price appreciation, leaving many larger nations, like Mexico and Argentina, with room to catch up, Mr. Carlson said. The two smaller economies have benefited from successful local financial reforms, said Mr. Vaimberg, and the movement of funds into these smaller markets has also had an outsized impact.
The state of the global economy is also favorable to emerging-market debt. With interest rates low in the United States, Germany and Japan, "typically money flows down the credit spectrum and out the yield curve" to the highest yields, Mr. Carlson noted.
For domestic investors, emerging-market debt also has an advantage in portfolio diversification over junk bonds, which are its rival for high yields. Corporate junk is closely linked to the business cycle, but the fortunes of emerging-market bonds are tied more directly to interest rates. In a recession, junk bonds can drop along with their issuers, whereas government bonds tend to rise in price as interest rates fall.
The debt of emerging-market countries can even diversify an equity portfolio, having performed quite differently recently than third-world equities. Much of the debt is denominated in United States dollars, so there is no foreign currency risk, Mr. Vaimberg noted, and many of these nations have policies intended to bring down inflation, which push up interest rates and hurt corporate earnings in the short run.
Emerging-market debt, Mr. Biggs said, "is disconnected from everything."
FINALLY, many emerging-markets specialists say the sector's small size will be a big plus as more investors discover it. "What we like about Brady bonds is that they are limited in size," Mr. Treacher said. "As more money chases the dragon, there isn't going to be any more supply." Indeed, if Europe achieves monetary union, the effect will be even fewer choices for fixed-income investors, as distinctions among the bonds of Germany, Italy and Spain are erased.
Volatility is likely to remain the signature characteristic of this market, however. "If you can't stand the heat, you shouldn't be in this kitchen," said Mr. Forest of Bond Fund Adviser. "But if your goal is to hold a diversified portfolio, having an allocation to these markets can reduce your overall risk."

HEADLINE: Too Loose? Or the Way to Go?

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
IN the last few years, New York City has become a hub of school reform, with the addition of more than 60 new public schools, the largest expansion of the system in half a century.
The vast majority are small high schools that in the words of the pioneers have "dropped the bucket." The bucket is full of educational conventions: 40-minute classes, standardized tests and an age-old curriculum that would have them teach "The Scarlet Letter" in 10th grade and "The Red Badge of Courage" in the 11th and race through thousands of years of history in a few semesters. 
 Now, with all the talk -- in Albany and elsewhere -- about more rigorous standards and a national curriculum, the political climate is decidedly unfriendly for unconventional schools.
"There's something eerie in the air," said Deborah Meier, who founded a movement that spawned dozens of alternative high schools. "There are more kids in poverty, fewer services to back them up, more difficult conditions in the schools, and we've decided we'll make them all take the 'tougher' curriculum. If that is going to produce more learning, somebody has a theory of human nature I haven't bumped into before."
It is still unclear exactly how the new push for higher standards will affect the alternative schools, but many progressive educators are nervous. Ms. Meier, who said she was frustrated by the slow pace of reform in the city, announced last week that she wanted to start a school in Boston.
Alternative schools still give basic state examinations in reading, writing and mathematics, but are exempt from giving examinations in subject areas like social studies and science. Now Albany has decided that starting in 2000 all public high school students must pass the more rigorous Regents examinations to earn a diploma. Unless the alternative schools can prove their alternative assessment techniques are as rigorous, they may be forced to join the Regents-dominated culture of the traditional schools.
The Regents exams themselves are changing to reflect a more open-ended style of testing that in some cases mirrors what some alternative schools are already doing to evaluate their students. For example, some of the Regents exams being phased in slowly over the next few years will assess collections of student work, or portfolios, and require students to perform tasks rather than answer multiple-choice questions.
The largest crop of small high schools emerged under the former Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, who, in an attempt to make high schools safer and smaller, turned to an alliance of city educators and secured financing from City Hall and the Board of Education. In September 1993, the Annenberg Foundation donated $25 million to the new schools.
Despite that support, progressive educators say they have always been at odds with the educational establishment.
"New York State is a top-down, examination-driven system, more than any other," said Stephen E. Phillips, superintendent of alternative high schools and programs. "There's an inherent clash in this state, and progressive education has never really been supported. Everybody will say, 'It's wonderful what you are doing with this new curriculum, but where are your Regents results?' "
He added: "One of the big myths in terms of curriculum is that if the teacher covered it, the kid got it. There's an assumption that if I had a lesson on Pearl Harbor, that something beneficial happened."
Among the new high schools, even those that belong to the same reform networks, there are stark differences in how they approach education. For example, included in the 38 city elementary and high schools that belong to the Coalition of Essential Schools, a national reform network based at Brown University, there is the Manhattan Village Academy, which follows a fairly traditional curriculum, and University Heights High School in the Bronx, which utterly rejects it.
City education officials have said that attendance has improved at the smaller schools, many of which were carved out of troubled larger high schools, and that they are substantially safer. They often attract students who struggled in traditional schools and who might have otherwise dropped out.
Because the schools are so new and typically shun the types of tests that traditional schools use to measure performance,
the academic results are still sketchy.
"There has to be some way to gauge the effectiveness of these schools," said Diane Ravich, a senior research scholar at New York University who supports a common curriculum for all schools. "I believe in small schools. But they have to have standards, and they have to be prepared to say, 'This is what we're doing' and then be prepared to be judged as to whether or not they have done it. You can't just give them public money and say, 'We'll trust you, here's the money and goodbye.' "
 
Take the Regents
Here are 10 of the 48 multiple choice questions from the June 1996 United States History and Government Regents Exam. The Regents exams set the academic standards for high schools and drive what is taught in traditional schools. Alternative schools can give the exams, and some do, but many reformers view them as obstacles to the learning process. The exams also have essay questions.

 1. "The only representatives of the people of these colonies are persons chosen therein by themselves; and that no taxes ever have been, or can be constitutionally imposed on them but by their respective legislatures."
-- Statement by the Stamp Act Congress, 1765
What is a valid conclusion that can be drawn from this quotation?
1. The colonial legislatures should be appointed by the English King with the consent of Parliament
2. Only the colonists' elected representatives should have the power to levy taxes
3. The English King should have the right to tax the colonists
4. The colonists should be opposed to all taxation

 6. "The privilege of writ of habeus corpus shall not be suspended, unless when in cases of rebellion or invasion the public safety may require it."
This provision is evidence that the writers of the United States Constitution. . .
1. Wanted the President to have unlimited power during wartime
2. Wanted to balance the individual liberty with the needs of the nation
3. Did not trust the common people to obey the laws
4. Expected the American people to oppose most government policies

 11. Early in his Presidency, Abraham Lincoln declared that his primary goal as President was to. . .
1. Enforce the Emancipation Proclamation
2. Preserve the union
3. End slavery throughout the entire country
4. Encourage sectionalism

 13. The poll tax, the literacy test, and the actions of the Ku Klux Klan were all attempts to limit the effectiveness of. . .
1. The 14th and 15th amendments
2. The Supreme Court's decision in Brown v. Board of Education
3. Civil rights legislation passed in all states after the Civil War
4. Immigration laws such as the Gentlemen's Agreement and the Chinese Exclusion Act

 20. W.E.B. Du Bois believed that African Americans should attempt to gain equality in the United States by. . .
1. Setting up a separate nation within the United States
2. Entering vocational training programs in separate schools
3. Demanding full and immediate participation in American society
4. Taking over the leadership of the two major political parties

 29. The popularity of escapist novels and movies during the Great Depression is evidence that. . .
1. The Great Depression was not really a time of economic distress
2. Popular culture is shaped by economic and social conditions
3. American society did not try to solve the problems of the Great Depression
4. The greatest employment opportunities for the average person in the 1930's were in the field of entertainment

 34. In the United States during World War II, the role of women changed as they. . .
1. Were drafted and assigned military roles equal to those held by men
2. Continued to work outside the home only in jobs traditionally performed by women
3. Made major contributions to the war effort by taking jobs in factories
4. Achieved positions of leadership in most major industries

 41. A major long-term effect of the Vietnam War has been. . .
1. An end to communist governments in Asia
2. A change in United States foreign policy from containment to imperialism
3. A reluctance to commit United States troops for extended military action abroad
4. A continued boycott of trade with Asia

 43. According to the supply-side economics principles promoted by President Ronald Reagan, economic growth would occur when. . .
1. Corporate business taxes were reduced
2. Business was regulated by antitrust legislation
3. Unemployment benefits were increased
4. Investment in capital goods was decreased

 44. The rulings of the Supreme Court in Dred Scott v. Sanford (1857), Plessy v. Ferguson (1896), and Korematsu v. United States (1944) all demonstrate that the Supreme Court has. . .
1. Continued to extend voting rights to minorities
2. Protected itself from internal dissent
3. Sometimes failed to protect the rights of minorities
4. Often imposed restrictions on free speech during wartime
 
Answers (in parentheses)
 
1 (2); 6 (2); 11 (2); 13 (1); 20 (3); 29 (2); 34 (3); 41 (3); 43 (1); 44 (3);

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Will Fund Investors Prove to Be Faithful or Fickle?

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
WHEN Raymond DeVoe, market strategist for Legg Mason Wood Walker, visited Japan in 1989, he heard the same story at least two dozen times. "Everyone talked about how different Japanese investors were," he recalled last week. "They were in for the long term, and nothing would be likely to make them sell their stock investments."
Seven years later, the Japanese stock market is down 40 percent, and the amount of money in the Japanese version of mutual funds has fallen more than 90 percent. Instead of holding onto their stock funds, Japanese investors have cashed out, even as the Nikkei index rallied nearly 20 percent in the last year. 
 Now, with billions of dollars flowing each month into American mutual funds, United States fund investors are being characterized as the Japanese were several years ago. Americans will not flee their stock funds, the argument goes, because they know their historical performance and because they are investing for the long term.
As fresh evidence, some Wall Street analysts point to the most recent quarter, when cash poured in despite a downturn in stock prices in July.
But such a conclusion ignores several recent cases of investors' fleeing individual funds -- among them Fidelity Magellan, Strong Discovery and Van Wagoner Emerging Growth -- when performance did not live up to expectations. In addition, investors in Charles Schwab & Company's mutual fund marketplace quickly pulled money out of funds in July when the market's long bull run appeared threatened.
A longer view, too, shows that American fund investors, like their Japanese counterparts, have abandoned an entire asset class when performance lagged. Equity investors in the late 1970's and government bond investors in the last two years have continued to sell even after those investments returned to decent returns.
To be sure, there is little in the performance of equity funds in the third quarter to give investors much reason to flee. According to the fund trackers at Morningstar Inc., in Chicago, the average United States stock fund gained 2.55 percent in the quarter and 12.5 percent in the first nine months of 1996. International funds, by contrast, lost an average of a half of a percent in the quarter, lowering the year's returns to 9.6 percent.
Few on Wall Street expect the performance of the stock market to waver substantially the rest of the year, which means that fund companies are likely to continue to reap strong cash flows. But there is plenty of evidence that a significant portion of the people now flocking to mutual funds are an untested, if not unstable, group.
According to the Federal Reserve's quarterly "Flow of Funds" report, released last month, mutual funds held $1.25 trillion of equities at the end of June, up from $233 billion at the end of 1990. That means 80 percent of the money now invested in stock funds was not there during any significant downturn -- like the crash of 1987.
"That's really kind of mind-boggling," said Melissa Brown, quantitative analyst at Prudential Securities. "Most of the money invested in mutual funds has not gone through a bear market, so we really don't have a historical framework to determine whether individuals will stay put if we see a prolonged correction in the market. My guess is that they won't -- that they will be much more likely to pull their money out than the common wisdom would suggest."
David Kim says he will not be one headed for the exits. A 30-year-old investor who makes his living reading scripts for movie studios in Los Angeles, Mr. Kim made his first stock fund investments in July, moving about $7,000 from a Schwab money market account into three funds.
Looking at how his funds have performed so far, as well as at their one-year performance, Mr. Kim wants to invest more, particularly in Stein Roe Capital Opportunities, which has gained 49.6 percent in the last 12 months. He plans to do so by taking a cash advance of $1,500 on a credit card and using it to buy more fund shares.
Once he has the money in hand, Mr. Kim plans to transfer his card balance to a new credit card, which offers a low introductory interest rate of 5.9 percent for the first year. After a year, when the introductory rate expires, he intends to cash out of the fund or, if possible, roll over the loan to another card with a low rate.
Mr. Kim said he recognized that he could lose money, but the risk does not bother him. "I think that given the general upward trend of the market, the idea makes sense," he said. "I will give it three to six months, and if the fund is consistently going down over that time, I will cash out and pay off the principal." Thus, while he thinks the long-term prospects for stocks remain bright, Mr. Kim might jump in and out of the market at times.
Certainly, Mr. Kim does not fit the profile of the "average" mutual fund investor as compiled by the Investment Company Institute, a fund trade group. In July, the institute reported that, based on a random survey of 1,165 households, the average fund investor is middle class, 44 years old, has financial assets of $50,000 and bought his first fund shares before 1990 -- none of which would suggest that fund companies need to worry about the willingness of shareholders to move in and out of positions.
But fund companies could be fooling themselves if they do not recognize that they have an increasing number of shareholders like Mr. Kim. Investors certainly have demonstrated a growing interest in the ability to move assets quickly between traditional long-term investments -- stock and bond funds -- and cash accounts. So much so, in fact, that last year Charles Schwab instituted rules to discourage fund shareholders from making short-term trades.
Still, Schwab investors, who make up 8 percent of all mutual fund assets and 18 percent of those in funds sold without brokers, made net withdrawals of $754 million from domestic funds in July, part of a selloff that caused some concern. But nearly as much went back into those funds in August, which some analysts say is a credit to the great stabilizing factor among fund investors -- the retirement plan.
With a greater portion of today's fund investors putting money in tax-deferred plans, they probably will not cash out their investments entirely and buy consumer goods because of tax penalties. And investors love stock funds because equities have been the best long-term investment, said Avi Nachmany, an analyst at Strategic Insight, a New York consulting firm.
"There will have to be a great change in the societal climate to convince people that not only are there short-term risks in stocks, but long-term investment does not resolve those risks," he said. Mr. Nachmany does not foresee that happening anytime soon.
If it does happen, even 401(k) investors will find it easy to turn on a dime and move their money to what they see as the safest haven. In previous downturns, corporate pension managers oversaw the retirement money of millions of Americans; today the investors make the decisions.
Companies like Fidelity Investments, the largest provider of 401(k) retirement plans, allow investors to switch investments 24 hours a day, by telephone. In the case of one high-profile Fidelity fund, plenty of investors have made use of that service this year.
Roughly half of the $51.7 billion in the Fidelity Magellan fund, the country's largest mutual fund, comes through 401(k) plans -- presumably making those assets more stable than those of the average fund. But in the five months ended in August, as the fund fell 1.25 percent in value, investors withdrew $3.7 billion.
Numerous smaller funds have also suffered cash outflows, according to AMG Data Services, which reported a $4 billion outflow from equity funds in one week in mid-July. From mid-June through late September, the Wasatch Aggressive Growth fund suffered 15 consecutive weeks of net outflows, measuring $34.8 million, or 10 percent of assets. The Founders Special fund lost $38 million, or 9 percent of assets, to outflows, and the Strong Discovery fund saw $45.5 million, or about 7 percent of assets, leave the fund.
In each case, the withdrawals were on top of losses caused by the July market downturn. Even at the popular Van Wagoner Emerging Growth fund, which was flooded with money when it started last spring, more money flowed out than came in from mid-June through mid-September.
Using bad performance as an excuse to cash out is a basic element of investor psychology, said Kenneth Safian, an economist and investment analyst in White Plains. The same rules that governed behavior when individuals did most of their investing through individual stocks drive the actions of fund investors, he says.
The crash of 1987 was neither the first nor the worst period of redemptions by shareholders of American mutual funds. In the 96 months from November 1971 through October 1979, investors made net withdrawals from equity funds in every month but one, according to data from the Investment Company Institute. Not until November 1981 did investors put together two consecutive months of net inflows to stock funds -- even though the Standard & Poor's 500 rose in five of the six years from 1975 through 1980.
That experience parallels the cascade of withdrawals from Japanese mutual funds in recent years, said Steven Leuthold, president of the Leuthold Group, a market analysis and money management firm in Minneapolis. "The fact that the redemptions continued after the Japanese market started back up shows how human nature responds," he said.
American investors reacted the same way to a downturn in the bond market that started in early 1994, when the Federal Reserve embarked on a series of interest-rate increases. Since then, government bond funds have seen withdrawals in each month, despite a strong bond rally in 1995.
When it comes to stock funds, investors have not made net monthly withdrawals since September 1990. "When that much money comes into the market, any subsequent outflow will cause a big jolt to the market," Mr. Safian said. "It doesn't mean that all individuals will liquidate their fund holdings, but enough will to put a shock in the system."
SOME fund analysts do not buy the Japanese example. Mr. Nachmany, of Strategic Insight, said that, unlike stock funds here, Japanese investment trusts were marketed as trading vehicles with time horizons of a year or less. And he dismisses the notion that Americans' withdrawals from bond funds the last two years would be repeated at stock funds, pointing out that bond funds were not as widely held in retirement accounts.
If investors follow the course described by Mr. Nachmany, equity funds are not likely to suffer, and history will not be repeated. One investor who will not throw money blindly at stock funds, however, is Mr. Nachmany, who has a conservative penchant. "I always find reason to be in a money fund or in a balanced fund," which invests in both stocks and bonds, he said. "But I'm a terrible investor."

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Kim, a 30-year-old script reader in Los Angeles, bought his first stock funds in July and now wants to buy more -- using a cash advance on a credit card. Investing with borrowed money carries risk, and if the market turns south, Mr. Kim concedes he would sell to cut his losses. (Kim Kulish for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: AT THE GATE;
For Sabre Group, Some Long-Term Reservations

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
THE AMR Corporation, the parent company of American Airlines, will soon offer stock in Sabre Group, its successful airline-reservation business. But while the offering may be a good short-term buy, the prospects are less clear for the long-haul investor.
AMR expects to raise about $434 million with the issue, offering 20.2 million shares at an expected price of $20 to $23 a share. The proceeds will be used to repay debt to AMR and to finance Sabre's operations and expansion. AMR will retain an 84 percent interest in the company, along with 98 percent of the voting power. 
 Sabre's main attraction is a rare one among initial public offerings: the company dominates its market. More than 40 percent of all airline bookings through travel agents in the United States last year went through Sabre, making it by far the largest domestic distributor of travel arrangements, according to travel industry analysts and the offering documents.
Domestic and foreign airlines have formed several competing consortiums to try to imitate Sabre's success. Amadeus/System One is a joint effort of Air France, Continental Airlines, Iberia and Lufthansa, for example. But neither it nor any of the other ventures do nearly the volume of AMR's operation, analysts say.
Through Sabre, travelers can book reservations with more than 350 airlines, 55 car-rental agencies and 190 hotel companies. The company's pioneering system, which was founded as an in-house operation in 1960 and went commercial in 1976, includes more than 29,000 travel agency locations in more than 70 countries. The network's scope is so large, said Mark Basham, who analyzes new issues for Standard & Poor's, that Sabre is "a very important part of the transportation system in the U.S."
The company's dominance shows up on the bottom line, and that's why Mr. Basham -- who often favors companies with the largest share of their markets -- recommends the stock. In 1995, the company's earnings increased to $225.9 million on revenues of $1.53 billion, compared with earnings of $197.2 million on revenues of $1.41 billion the previous year. That's 15 percent annual earnings growth.
Sabre's size should also be a big advantage as it embarks on its ambitious growth plans. It hopes to push into Asia and to increase its European and Latin American presence. It has a business-consulting operation, too, and wants to expand that service into railroads, financial services and other industries that -- like airlines -- require the tracking and updating of large amounts of data. Sabre also plans to commit more than $100 million during the next five years to upgrading its technology and making other operating improvements.
Sabre stock seems reasonably priced, too. At its expected offering price, the company would be selling at 15.5 times its estimated earnings for the current fiscal year. Since there are no other stand-alone airline-reservations companies, Mr. Basham suggests that Sabre be compared with concerns like First Data, a $4 billion company that processes credit-card transactions. At Friday's close, First Data's stock was trading at 32 times earnings. The comparison is rough because the companies are in different industries, but Sabre's price level does not look unduly high.
There are factors, though, that could bring Sabre some turbulence.
For one, Sabre's market dominance is not assured. "Competition to attract and retain travel-agent subscribers is particularly intense," the company says in its S.E.C. filing; Sabre would be "materially adversely affected" if a large number defected to competitors. And even without such losses, competition might compel Sabre to lower the fees it charges agents, also hurting the bottom line.
Airlines can now sell tickets on the Internet without travel agents, and it is unclear whether Sabre will dominate the new turf of on-line reservations the way it dominates its traditional business. Although Sabre recently introduced an on-line system, it faces formidable competitors like American Express and Microsoft, which announced an alliance in July to provide an on-line corporate reservations service.
Another challenge for Sabre -- and a threat to travel agents -- is ticketless purchasing, said Robert Mescal, an analyst with New Issues, a newsletter of the Institute for Econometric Research in Deerfield, Fla. In this fare system, travelers make telephone reservations directly with the airline and present an identification card at the gate. The procedure never requires a paper transaction.
And while Sabre generates lots of cash, unlike many new issues it cannot count on the money raised in the initial offering to help it fight these battles. That is because about 85 percent of the $434 million raised will be used to pay off Sabre's debts to AMR.
Sabre still dominates its field, and Mr. Mescal knows it. But he is less certain that the company will, in the long run, remain profitable enough to make the big investments necessary to prevail against all this competition. "I am limiting my interest to five years," he said.

HEADLINE: Forget Pearl Harbor

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
THE eight teachers walked into a hot and stuffy classroom on the fourth floor of University Heights High School in the Bronx and, as always, they were in for a pressure-cooker afternoon. They took their seats at a round brown table, arranged their favorite books, videos and photocopied packets in a stack in front of them and began to wrestle with the question: What should the students know?
"This is our chance to grab them, entice them and seduce them," said Evelyn Birnbaum, one of the teachers. "If we lose this one, it's going to be hard to get it back." 
 Time was running out for the humanities team, in charge of devising a plan to teach English and social studies to 300 students. They had two hours to decide what to cover during the first six weeks of the school year, but it was already the second day of classes. They knew they would spend the year teaching a course called "Is Power Good or Bad?" But the plan was vague, the nitty-gritty still to come.
There was tension at the table. It started with the reading list -- one teacher had written out her selections, calling it a bibliography of revolutionary writers. The list contained some urban high school staples -- Richard Wright's "Black Boy," "The Autobiography of Malcolm X." But another teacher wanted more classics, less ideology. Machiavelli made it -- something from "The Prince," but what about Locke? Hobbes? A new teacher was a little jarred by some of the violence in the readings; one began with a rape, another with a gang rape.
Then there was Theodore Daniel, a social studies teacher by training, who was quiet during the meeting but said later that he thought it was ridiculous to study power without looking at the American Revolution. As a matter of fact, so far the team's curriculum included no history at all.
"I'm struggling," said Mr. Daniel, who just began his second year at University Heights. "I don't want to shortchange anybody's kid."
Mr. Daniel and his colleagues teach at an alternative high school because they share a belief that the old way of doing things is not working. They teach at University Heights, one of the growing number of alternative schools in the city, because they believe that the thousands of students who flounder at traditional high schools struggle because the schools fail them. They joined the ranks of the reformers because they wanted to be free of a rigid educational bureaucracy that would force them to cover Pearl Harbor, the periodic table, Shakespeare and other staples of the traditional American high school curriculum.
But, as a month with the humanities team at University Heights revealed, the frontier of reform is frazzled. It is a high-stakes journey of clashing agendas, compromise, exhilaration and frustration. What was perhaps most striking about the discussions in Room 425, was that the teachers at one of the city's most radical alternative schools, in the University Heights section of the Bronx, are as divided over what to teach as the warring factions in the raging national debate over academic standards.
Sometimes the teachers struggle within themselves. Mr. Daniel, for one, lives with a constant internal conflict about how to engage the teen-agers while making sure they know certain things, like spelling and American history.
"We've turned the bucket over," said Mr. Daniel, who is 34 and lives a kind of double life: he also teaches night courses in economics -- traditional style -- at Park West High School in Manhattan. "We're talking about a radical departure. We went really far. At one point, I wondered if we had gone too far, and I argued that we should come back."
One day Mr. Daniel and a colleague, who teach a course together, handed back essays their students had been asked to write on the power of guns. Mr. Daniel had circled grammatical errors in red ink on the papers he graded, but his partner had simply written "revise" on his. Mr. Daniel is adamant that mistakes should be corrected, but his partner was practicing a theory shared by other teachers that focusing on grammar would stifle the students' creativity.
"Some teachers don't like to hear the word 'grammar,' " he said. "Some teachers have completely swallowed whatever this new vision is. But we can correct grammar, we can put a little more emphasis on content and we can still call ourselves alternative. I don't think that sits well with everyone."
Over the last month, as the humanities team planned and improvised, struggled and debated, each member took on a specific role in the group. Some pushed ideology; others wanted to talk logistics. Mr. Daniel, who is from St. Kitts and Nevis in the Caribbean, was never confrontational during the meetings, but he would consistently mumble a mantra: "What about economic, social and political power?"
No one questioned that the school's theme this year, "Power: What it is good for," was a good one -- meaty, controversial, political. It seemed an ideal way to weave together the different subjects. The math and science team could develop a unit on solar power, the services and health team would look at the question "can the power of one make a difference?" and planned to link the high school students with elementary school children they could tutor and mentor. For the humanities team, there were Presidential elections to study and a widely publicized police brutality case to investigate, and the students had shown a strong interest in the plight of Mumia Abu-Jamal, a black radio journalist on death row for the 1981 killing of a Philadelphia police officer.
For all the teachers, there was also the obvious hook of a curriculum on power, which some teachers refer to as the "objective reality" of the school: the students, black and Hispanic youths from some of the city's poorest neighborhoods, are often powerless in the system.
 
 
 
A Freedom in Approach; What the Critics Say
 At the core of the school's philosophy is the belief that the way to engage students who were turned off by traditional schools -- many had a history of poor attendance and low grades -- is to make the curriculum relevant to their lives. They might look at the history of the Bronx and skip much of American history, or teach the novels of Sandra Cisneros and Toni Morrison and ignore the literary canon. They teach one subject, or theme, in depth, rather than covering many, and often choose controversial topics.
"We want our kids to be able to pose questions, as well as solve problems," said Kiran Chaudhuri, who has taught at the school for five years, "so we frame things as provocatively as possible. You need to start where the kids are. One of our primary purposes is to help them make sense of their own lives."
But critics of that approach say that it deprives students of the opportunities provided at traditional schools. Teaching current events at the expense of history, for example, is shortsighted, they say.
"I know that people say history is one damn fact after another, but the world didn't begin yesterday," said Diane Ravitch, a senior research scholar at New York University. "It sounds to me like this is something that's good enough for the ghetto kids, but not for the middle class kids. Some of these schools are experimenting with the children of the poor. The real challenge to the alternative school is to take the traditional content and make it exciting."
Some alternative schools continue to teach a traditional high school curriculum, but University Heights, which opened 10 years ago on the campus of Bronx Community College, took a decidedly radical route. At University Heights, there are no individual subjects. The teachers are generalists: a math teacher can give a class on history, an English teacher might instruct a lesson on physics. There are no bells, no clocks, no tests and no grading, although sometimes students request grades. Students in the high school, ages 16 to 21, are not separated into grade levels. The school also has a middle school that enrolls about 60 students.
Students graduate when they have demonstrated mastery of five "domains," or measurements of achievement that students and staff have agreed on. The domains are communicating, crafting and reflecting; working together and resolving conflicts; recognizing patterns and making connections; taking responsibility for myself and my community, and critical thinking and ethical decision making.
Often, it seems that teaching at University Heights is a constant experiment, educational improvisation in which the response of the audience -- the students -- is crucial to how the curriculum writers proceed. That, too, is part of the philosophy.
"Curriculum, at its best in our school, gets made in the classroom, through teachers and students collaborating," said Ms. Chaudhuri.
 
HB>From Scribbled Notes To the Classroom
 The humanities curriculum, a plan that will guide the teaching of English and social studies for the year, began to take shape in late August. The team got together and scrawled some notes on a white sheet of paper that included these potential lessons: "How powerful am I?", "Oct. 22 police brutality protest" and "news story -- analyze power." They met several more times before school started to brainstorm and, in keeping with the commitment to "start with the student," agreed to begin with a unit on personal power.
But by Sept. 5, the second day of school, the students were back and, several teachers were still unsure exactly what they were supposed to be teaching. "I feel like I'm flying by the seat of my pants," Miguel A. Garcia, a humanities teacher, said that day as he walked down the fourth-floor corridor between classes.
Later that day, at the curriculum planning session in room 425, the team met to plan the unit on personal power, which they had decided would focus on the role of the individual in the family and in society but would also include a look at violence. Not everyone was happy with the violence section. While some felt it had plenty of relevance to students living in tough neighborhoods, others thought that was exactly why they should not study it. Give the students a break from all that, they thought.
Hazel Joseph-Roseboro, a soft-spoken 24-year-old English teacher who grew up a few blocks from the school and graduated from University Heights, had decided Toni Morrison's "The Bluest Eye," was ideal for the unit because it touched on the family power structure. Ron White, the new teacher in the group who used to be a stockbroker, said he saw the literary merits of the Morrison book but was troubled by the rape scene at the beginning of the story. "It concerns me that we're grabbing attention in this way," he said. "Is this the only way we get students involved?"
Ms. Chaudhuri, the English teacher who had written up the reading list, was interested in getting the students to write personal memoirs. "Let's get the kids to find the politicizing moments of their childhood," she said.
Mr. Garcia, who wears his long gray hair tied back in a ponytail, was slightly uncomfortable with the reading list because there were no classical works on power, and he was frustrated because his eyeglasses were broken. He had to leave the session early, and rushing out of the classroom, he turned to the group, squinted and said half jokingly, "Put Homer on there."
They laughed, and he did not say then that the absence of classics on the reading list was bothering him. When Ms. Chaudhuri learned later that he was concerned about it, she sounded annoyed and said, "He used the word 'classics'?"
Mr. Garcia was not the only one who sometimes found himself yearning to teach something that might make more dogmatic colleagues bristle. Mr. White, a former stockbroker who later went to work in a homeless shelter before going into teaching, had never taught in an alternative school before. Mr. White, 54, said that when he discovered his students did not know what a contraction was, he had the urge to teach a basic grammar lesson.
"You know -- nouns, verbs, adjectives -- I was reluctant to say it," he said. "And I'm almost apologetic for saying this, but I feel that I'm a product of a really great traditional education. When you say that, though, you better be pretty thick-skinned."
He continued: "I think these kids will graduate from high school without really knowing about the Civil War or World War II or the Berlin Wall or the Vietnam War, about how government works -- the Senate, the House of Representatives, who becomes Speaker of the House.
"When I graduated high school, I had this general information so I could play 'Jeopardy.' But after all is said and done, what is the purpose of an education? To help us cope in an increasingly sophisticated world. It's about relationships, and we'll talk about that and maybe they'll be able to relate better in their families. Maybe they'll be more responsible citizens. Maybe they will see the importance of voting," he said.
Mr. Garcia, who has a background in business and acting and a master's degree in Spanish from N.Y.U., described his brief stint at a traditional high school as "horrendous" because it was so large.
In his five years at University Heights, he said he has been "satisfied, even through the ups and downs," but lately, he said he has begun to worry that the curriculum has veered too far from the mainstream. "I would like to see some things that do not subordinate everything to an ideology. I'd like them to read classics, I'd like them to have classes," he said, emphasizing the word as if it were a foreign concept.
"We are certainly taking a different road," he said. "And we'll see where we go with it. I hope that we can iron a lot of these things out and come up with something good. It's exhausting and frustrating to be constantly racing toward something new."
 
 
 
Doubts, Confusion And Working It Out
 Mr. Garcia could often be heard during the curriculum planning sessions over the past month asking the group, "What is our purpose?" And often, that question was never answered clearly. What was called collaboration among teachers often seemed more like group therapy and, like counseling, sometimes the sessions did more to open wounds than to heal. Often, teachers left the meetings confused and frustrated about a lack of direction, or over having to give up subjects they wanted to cover.
"I'm feeling a little down," Mr. Daniel said on Sept. 3, after the team had met. "I don't know exactly where this is going."
On Sept. 11, Alan Hilliard, the teacher who was leading the planning meetings, began the session by saying: "I've been hearing some concerns that people are feeling out there, by themselves. We don't seem to have a firm thing going on. And I think Ron needs some support."
A few minutes later, Mr. Garcia, still struggling with the broken eyeglasses said, "Can I ask the purpose? Is it that we gather here to come up with a unified curriculum for all of us to share?"
Paul Allison, the school's director of curriculum and assessment who was sitting in on the meeting, said, "You can do your own thing, but if you do, it's got to be better than what we've come up with."
Mr. Hilliard said, "Of course, individuals can put a twist on this."
Mr. White said, "I was doing my own thing."
Mr. Daniel said, "I really want us to look at economic, political and social power."
Ms. Birnbaum said, "I'm not sure what social power is."
Ms. Joseph-Roseboro said, "I thought we were talking about social justice."
Mr. Farnham said, "Don't forget our essential question, 'Is power good or bad?' "
Mr. Daniel said: "I feel I'm being robbed. This is overwhelmingly an English curriculum."
Over the first several weeks of school, the teachers generally followed the topic of personal power, hammering out the details in the teams of three that teach two-hour seminars. Mr. White did teach his grammar lesson and reported that it was well received -- by students and colleagues. Ms. Joseph-Roseboro did not get a chance to teach "The Bluest Eye" but felt satisfied with her lessons on essay writing.
As for Mr. Daniel, he twice approached the humanities team with a complete social studies lesson, one he had worked up on the United States Constitution and another that would have the students investigate "powerful people," like Nelson Mandela, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. or George Washington. The team wanted to postpone those topics and stick to the focus on personal power and writing, but they promised to add more social studies later, he said.
"I decided to play nice boy and go along with them," Mr. Daniel said. "But if I need to, I'll rock the boat."
When the trial of a police officer accused of murdering a Bronx man began -- a seemingly perfect opportunity to teach the students about the judicial system and the city -- Mr. Daniel reluctantly organized a trip to the court. He feared that without a lesson on the law, the activity would seem out of context.
"It didn't go very well," he said. "They just didn't have a grounding in the legality of the courtroom. They kept saying the judge was being rude and I kept trying to get them to identify the symbols of power in the courtroom. It was a dilemma because I was mindful that this was a case they were interested in, but they weren't ready."
Did Mr. Daniel give up on the American Revolution? "Not one bit," he said. "I'll get to it, and this is where I may have to depart from the team."
The other week, the team members met to decide what to teach for the rest of the semester. First, they debated whether the next unit would focus on the Presidential elections (some argued over whether voting makes enough of a difference to use it in the curriculum), more police brutality or, as Mr. Daniel suggested, the power struggles of other nations. But right up until the final moments of the one-and-a-half-hour meeting, they still did not know.
Then, with 10 minutes to go, Ms. Birnbaum said, "I don't know if this will work, but what about New York City?"
There was a silence. Then teachers started to nod. New York City seemed to be able to satisfy all the agendas at the table. They could teach history, immigration, economics, religion, cultural institutions and New York writers. The students, the teachers hoped, would be interested in their own city. Then there are the sweatshops, the workfare debate and, as one teacher pointed out, October is the "month of resistance," and there were nonviolent protests coming up.
"I'll go for it," Mr. Daniel said. "New York is the mecca of history."
He paused and added: "So I guess there's some method to the madness. New York gave us everything we wanted."
Ms. Birnbaum said: "I love New York. Let's end this meeting."

 University Heights High School, the Bronx.

Shown and read aloud to teachers, parents, friends, other students and "critical friends" (outsiders invited to school to help assess student work.)

HEADLINE: No Time for Fashion;
As the Way of All Flesh Goes South

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE C. R. WHITE 

 BODY:
WOMEN, particularly baby boomers whose acquisitiveness in the last two decades brought boom times to the fashion industry, are revising their values: they're not cutting them to fit this year's fashions.
This attitudinal shift is related largely to the changing bodies and psyches of baby boomers, who have been a significant part of the market. Women are investing less in clothes and more in the real fabric of their lives -- children, health care, careers, vacations and financial security. The trend is also in part a reaction against a fashion industry that, in recent years, has become its own worst enemy, casting about with peculiar trends like grunge, transparent shirts and an endless parade of styles from decades past. Pants, a kind of white flag sent up by designers unable to fathom customers, are ubiquitous in fall catalogues and store advertising. 
 "The reason fashion missed the boat is that everything was too tight," said Carol Farmer, president of C. F. Associates, a trend research company in Boca Raton, Fla. "It was body-shaping fashion that was not respectful of a boomer body. What does the baby boomer want? Certainly not polyester doubleknit, the stuff we grew up in."

 
 
Comfort Over Style
 As boomers have aged, spending on apparel has decreased and more goes to services, said economist Carl Steidtmann, in his recent report for Management Horizons, the research arm of Price Waterhouse L.L.P. Apparel spending peaked in 1978 with baby boomers between the ages of 15 and 24, he said. Those consumers are now 33 to 42.
In a 1994 survey by Management Horizons, which tracks buying patterns and shopping attitudes, consumers said they cared less about fashion and more about value than in the past. The study also found that consumer spending on apparel has fallen steadily for the last 16 years. Though some designers are adjusting by offering more relaxed, inexpensive clothes, and there has been a slight but uneven increase in sales since last year's dismal Christmas, demand overall is sluggish.
Giorgio Armani, profiled in New York magazine last month, declared fashion finished. The system, he said, had broken down. Mr. Armani is correct: Women no longer follow the dictates of designers or fashion editors, the traditional disseminators of the message.
But fashion magazines, bent on pushing never-too-rich, never-too-thin fantasy while readers have moved toward a relaxed reality, share some responsibility for women's lack of interest in fashion. The disconnect between editorial content and advertising, flights of fancy and the real world, is evident in most of the magazines.
What message was to be gleaned from the cover of the September issue of Vogue, with two models draped in semi-transparent, mustard-colored slip dresses? Inside editorial pages displayed expensive, overwrought concepts like matadors and bullfighting. Even when allowing for magazine-speak about playing to readers' aspirations, the images looked out of touch next to advertising showing the new, uncomplicated and moderately priced clothes available in stores.
Vogue's biggest September advertisers were fragrance and cosmetic companies like Revlon and casual, less expensive clothing retailers like Lee Jeans and Tommy Hilfiger, which bought a record 22 pages. As for the top-of-the-line retailers, most put their money on accessories.
While fashion falters, other industries are capitalizing on women's mature shapes as well as their new mood. The travel business offers more adventure trips and family-oriented vacations. Women's participation in adventure travel rose from 54 percent in 1985 to 63 percent in 1995, according to Kathryn Cooney, president of Overseas Adventure Travel, a trade group based in Cambridge, Mass. At Woods Women Inc., a travel society in Minneapolis specializing in women's travel, participants have jumped from 400 in 1986 to 1,100 so far this year, said Denise Mitten, executive director.
Spas are marketing themselves as stress relievers rather than the weight-loss centers of a decade ago. Women's use of commercial gyms jumped 108 percent, to 3.6 million, between 1987 and 1995, according to the International Health, Racquet and Sportsclub Association.
Publishers are churning out "The Celestine Prophecy," "The Tenth Insight" and other books meant to help boomers plumb their spiritual depths. Car companies have introduced dozens of sport utility vehicles in the last three years, the better for boomers to express their rugged individualism.
Even the number of nail salons nationwide has shot upward. Seven years ago 900 nail technicians were registered with the Korean Nail Salon Association in the New York, Westchester and Long Island area; today 6,000 are.
 
 
 
Dividing a Smaller Pie
 As the many baby boomers turn 50 this year, biology is shaping women's response to fashion. Clothes that promote sexual attraction and reproduction are, it seems, fundamentally different from those suited to cocooning and reaching maturity in a career or relationship.
A decade hence, a new wave of young people 15 to 24 years old -- today's baby boomlet -- may spark a surge of interest in fashion again, said Mr. Steidtmann of Management Horizons. Meanwhile, women's complacency, if not inertia, about fashion is likely to continue.
Women have not stopped buying clothes, but the industry will have to adjust to dividing a smaller pie as fashion moves to the outer nebulae of its customers' lives.
