HEADLINE: Word for Word/U.S. Army Training Manuals;
Be All That You Can Be: Your Future as an Extortionist

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
THROUGH the 1980's, the United States Army trained Latin American police and military officers in techniques that the Pentagon now acknowledges were "clearly objectionable and possibly illegal": torture, extortion, censorship, false arrest, execution and the "neutralizing" of enemies.
These lessons appeared in some of the Army's training manuals, manuals that were used at the School of the Americas, a military academy at Fort Benning, Ga., and that were distributed in Colombia, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala and Peru to help governments threatened by leftist rebellions. 
 The Army compiled the manuals in 1987 using lesson plans used since 1982. Those lessons, in turn, were based on what the Pentagon called "old material" from the 1960's.
The Pentagon pulled the manuals from circulation in 1991 after an internal investigation turned up at least two dozen objectionable passages in six manuals. It has since destroyed the manuals on hand, except for one copy of each for its records, but an internal report noted that it was doubtful the Army could retrieve all of "as many as 1,000 copies" distributed over the years.
The disclosure has reignited a debate over the School of the Americas, whose students have included military leaders implicated in human rights abuses. The critics of the school, like Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d of Massachusetts, are now intensifying their demands that it close.
With titles like "Revolutionary War and Communist Ideology" and "Terrorism and the Urban Guerrilla," the manuals, which the Pentagon has made available for public scrutiny, have a dry, almost antiseptic style. But they recall the roiling political divisions of the cold war, when the United States willingly overlooked some abuses in Latin America.
The following excerpts come from a manual called "Handling of Sources," translated from Spanish by the Pentagon. The passages in italics are those the Pentagon identified as violations of American policies or principles. The spelling mistakes have been corrected. The term "employee" means "informant." The abbreviation "C.I." stands for counterintelligence. STEVEN LEE MYERS
 
Obtaining and Utilization of Employee We can define the "employee" as that person who renders his services in exchange of remuneration or compensation. Since the insurrection movements could emerge in different zones of economic, political and geographic influence, the Government is not able to depend only on the information provided voluntarily by faithful citizens or information obtained involuntarily from insurgents who have been captured.
A deserter . . . could be more or less certain that there will be no reprisals against him if all other members of his cell (who are the only ones who know that he was part of this cell) are eliminated by the government security forces. This circumstance could be used to persuade insurgent deserters to provide information to the Government.

Locating the Employee The C.I. agent must not discard the possibility of employing women. Women should be employed in some situations, while in others, they could be used with greater effectiveness than men. Remember that women are, as a rule, more emotional than men, but there [is] no difference in their intelligence.

Experience has shown that information obtained on the basis of fear is unreliable. . . . In addition, if an individual has been recruited using fear as a weapon, the CI agent must be in a position of maintain[ing] the threat.

The possibilities of finding persons willing to collaborate with the Government, in the place where an insurrection movement is developing, are immense. Specific individuals, organizations and commercial companies must be the object of infiltration by government employees, in order to obtain information about the guerrillas.

The C.I. agent must offer presents and compensation for information leading to the arrest, capture or death of guerrillas.

Placement of Employees A vital part of this program is the educational system tending to indoctrinate and recompense government employees who inform when a guerrilla element approaches them and tries to recruit them. The C.I. agent could cause the arrest or detention of the employee's parents, imprison the employee or give him a beating as part of the placement plan of said employee in the guerrilla organization.

The C.I. agent could increase the employee's value [in] destroying the structure of the guerrilla organization around said employee. This could be done by means or arrests, executions or pacification taking care not to expose the employee as the information source. If the employee is one of the few survivors, he could be a key member in a new or different guerrilla organization. Also the employee's reputation could be strengthened in this occasion by means of story fabrication, documents and witnesses, who are not only credible but also difficult to refute, since there will be very few guerrillas that have survived.
There are other methods of providing external assistance in order to assure the promotion of an employee. A method of achieving this promotion is by influencing an employee who has a much higher position in the guerrilla organization, another is to eliminate a potential rival among the guerrillas.

Scrutiny of Employees The ancient Romans had a saying "in vino veritas," there is truth in wine -- with that they wanted to say that a drunk man reveals his true thoughts and his real reactions. If we observe our employee drinking or in a drunken state, we could learn much about him.

I am going to mention some of the mechanical methods to test, which could be used under certain extenuating circumstances. Sodium pentathol compound, which is an anesthetic and hypnotic drug . . . could be intravenously injected and would have results of a "truth serum." . . . Another method that can be used is hypnotism.

Separation of Employees If the agent suspects he could have difficulty in separating an employee, it will be necessary to fabricate a reason to convince the employee that the separation is to his advantage. That could convince the employee that he has been compromised by the guerrillas. That continuing working for the Government could result in serious consequences for the employee and his family. If the employee does not believe this story, other measures could be taken to convince him, placing anonymous telegrams or sending anonymous letters. Many other techniques could be used which are only limited by the agent's imagination.

In the majority of cases, the purpose of the informal separation technique will be to have the employee "placed on the black list" by all government agencies, or threaten to expose himself or admit his activities, or bring about his removal by means of imprisonment, threat of imprisonment or voluntary or forced re-establishment. The methods that have to be used in informal separations must be carefully planned and approved by higher authority before being applied. . . . Threats should not be made unless they can be carried out and the employee realizes that such threats could be carried out. There are many disadvantages in the use of threats of physical violence or true physical abuse.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1268 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

UNEMPLOYMENT
Made-to-Order Statistics
Are the gods of statistics all Democrats? It certainly seems that way this year, for any President trying to be re-elected could not ask for better economic numbers. Even before Friday, all systems were humming, with the only possible flaw being that the economy might be heating up a bit too fast. But the jobs data took care of that with a stroke: unemployment up slightly, to 5.2 percent, and payroll jobs falling for the first time in eight months. To economists -- if not to people who lost jobs -- those are dream numbers. ("There is something for everyone in today's report," said Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich -- but not for Republicans.) The stock market duly did a little jig, with the Dow industrials heading tantalizingly close to (yawn) yet another barrier: 6,000. If things keep going this way, it won't be worth commenting on until it hits a round 10,000. But in case you've forgotten, it is possible for stocks to fall, too.
 
WIRELESS PHONES
P.C.S. Is Here, Sort Of
What? More high-tech lingo to cram into your overstuffed brain? Yes, like it or not, you'll have to get used to a new set of initials: P.C.S. That stands for "personal communications services," and it's the latest thing in wireless phones -- lighter phones, longer-lasting batteries, better sound quality. P.C.S. isn't exactly here yet, though it's coming soon. But last week AT&T decided to simply act as if it were here, introducing -- with trumpets blaring -- its new Digital PCS. True, the service is digital -- the signal is in computer code. But it's not true P.C.S. As one rival put it, "It's the same old AT&T in a new kimono."
 
HEALTH CARE
Poor? Old? Don't Get Sick
Many things in life are better if you're not too poor and not too old. Now you can add H.M.O. care to that list. A report out last week in the Journal of the American Medical Association said that while average patients did fine in managed-care plans, the poor and the elderly fared markedly worse. Maybe "we are going much too fast," one health expert said. "The market may not be ready for these patients." Of course, "average" people have few health problems; it's the ones on the margin who matter. People skeptical about H.M.O.'s could find a little solace in another bit of news last week: The stock of HCIA lost nearly half its value in a day on a poor earnings forecast. HCIA, among other things, advises H.M.O.'s about how long someone with a given ailment should stay in a hospital.
 
SHIPBUILDING
Subsidies That Won't Die
America, poor America, just loves to wail about unfair trade practices -- about how those other guys always do nasty, underhanded things to try to steal our quite ample lunch. The playing field must be level, we say. Just look at shipbuilding: Foreign countries pour billions into subsidizing this industry, so Americans don't stand a chance. So for six long, arm-twisting years American negotiators hammered away at this supposed inequity, and a deal was within a whisker of being ratified. But then some people suddenly said, "Oh, you mean it applies to us, too?" A level playing field is one thing, but not being able to help your local shipbuilding friends was just not acceptable, and the deal unraveled. So while human welfare is being cut back, corporate welfare is alive and grinning. (And surely election-year politics has nothing to do with it.)
 
AUTO SALES
Ovals and All, It's No. 1
Reports of the Taurus's death were premature. Ford came out with that wild redesign last year, with so many ovals -- from windows to dashboard -- that it's a wonder the wheels were round. But the car didn't sell too well at first, and Ford fretted that -- horrors! -- the Taurus wouldn't be the top-selling car any more. So it offered all sorts of incentives and rebates, everything except stopping people on the street and handing them wads of bills to take a test drive. Well, it worked, for when the model year ended on Sept. 30, Ford had sold some 378,000 Tauruses, edging out the Honda Accord. (Does that mean there's more bull than harmony this year?) But is the Taurus the No. 1 vehicle? Of course not. Ford's full-size pickup always wins that race, though provincial New Yorkers can never quite figure out who buys them.
 
GERMANY
Promised Land No More?
Americans straggling back from two- or three-week vacations sometimes think longingly of places like Germany. Now that, they say, is a civilized country: everyone, by law, gets six weeks off. And that's just part of a package that also features generous sick pay -- full salary for up to six weeks a year. But that haven may be about to vanish: last week corporate Germany started scaling back those benefits by trimming sick pay by 20 percent. With a single European currency due to arrive in 1999, the previous generosity may be an unaffordable luxury. But German workers are not giving up these goodies lightly, taking to the barricades in mass protests.
 
WCBS SHAKEUP
Don't Touch That Remote!
Well, the truth is out -- and a sad truth it is. TV executives, with no illusion that they'll always come up with scintillating programs, know that America's couches are chock-full of stupefied viewers who are not entirely sure where their TV's "off" button is. So the goal, as a CBS executive put it, is merely "to try to stop giving people a reason not to watch." But in New York, WCBS's happy-talk news -- actually, "local news" is the formal term -- has not even been able to meet that rather depressing goal, at least not enough to satisfy the bean counters. The station's response: kill the messengers. Last week it shocked viewers and people in the industry by dismissing seven top anchors and reporters, including high-profile types like Michelle Marsh and John Johnson. Since "Seinfeld" reruns usually beat the 11 o'clock news, maybe it should hire Kramer to read the weather.
 
TAKING MANHATTAN
Kmart Shrinks to Fit
Kmart came to Manhattan last week, but it wasn't easy. Its tractor-trailers, you see, are 13 feet high, but Manhattan -- in bridge and tunnel terms, anyway -- is a 10-foot-6 city. Not to worry: Kmart was so determined to take Manhattan that it lopped two and a half feet off some of its trucks. So it's really here, going "where no Kmart has gone before," in the words of the manager of the new store next to Penn Station. The questions now: Can it sell enough to pay sky-high Manhattan rents? Will jaded Manhattanites turn their noses up at this symbol of plain-vanilla suburbia? Or are New Yorkers people, too -- as enamored of warehouse bargains as their mini-vanned cousins? Take note, though: if you want guns (even toy ones) or huge bags of fertilizer, don't go to 34th Street.
 
POVERTY WAGES
A Bit Less Minimal
In terms of the overall economy, the minimum wage has become nearly irrelevant -- mainly because it got so low that few employers could pay it and still sleep at night. In all the Reagan years, the wage was unchanged, which means, of course, that it was drastically eroded by inflation. So when the latest increase finally took effect last week, from $4.25 an hour to $4.75, the experts barely blinked -- even after all the dire warnings of bankruptcies and mass layoffs. But was it a nonevent? Certainly not for the 4.2 million people who received automatic raises. Few people would scoff at a 12 percent raise, but if you're subsisting well below the poverty level, it could be a godsend. (The minimum wage would have to rise to $7.80 for a worker to lift a family of four to the poverty threshold of $15,600 a year.)

HEADLINE: The World;
Negative Ads Don't Work Here

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: ULAAN BAATAR, Mongolia

 BODY:
DEMOCRACY is still relatively new here in the land of grassy plains and animal herders, so it's full of surprises.
Like the results of this year's election. Virtually everyone here predicted an easy victory for the ruling party, a bunch of still-in-office Communists, when election day came on June 30. They were running against a young and disorganized batch of newcomers who, describing themselves as democrats, had little government experience and less expectation of getting any. The opposite happened. 
 The reason everyone was so off-base is another nice surprise, at least to anyone jaded by the over-analyzed Presidential contest going on now in the United States: Little polling was done, and the few polls that were conducted got little attention.
"Why look at a poll?" asked Delgermaa, a young woman who won a seat in Parliament (and who like many Mongolians uses only one name). "We all knew who was going to win. We were just wrong."
A larger surprise is that the transition has gone so smoothly. The ruling People's Revolutionary Party stepped aside gracefully, making way for the newly elected Democratic Union. The new Government has now drawn up a sweeping reform program, which was introduced to the new legislature last week.
Negative campaigning was a new blemish, but Americans sick of attack ads may be happy to know that here the technique mostly backfired. Delgermaa believes that a big reason she won was that her opponent accused her of giving away free flour and rice to voters. Never mind that Delgermaa admitted it was true. "Mongolians hate negative campaigning," she said. "They think it shows a weak spirit."
It is tempting to romanticize the democratic change under way. The new ministers and legislators, led by a 41-year-old Prime Minister, are young and idealistic and just plain enthusiastic about taking power. Their sense of excitement is as infectious as their plans are ambitious, and their political lingo sounds genuine and concerned with real problems.

 
 
Hard Realities
 But that is mostly because Mongolia's problems are so very real: The old socialist way has collapsed and the new market system still lacks capital and skills. Unemployment has hit nearly half the urban work force, inflation has eaten away at salaries and pensions, and packs of street children roam the streets to scavenge for food, even in the winter when the temperature gets stuck below zero.
Even in such economic straits, the transition to democracy that began in 1990 has gone remarkably well, as the easy transfer of power last summer suggests.
Effecting change is doubtless easier in a country as modest as Mongolia -- just 2.4 million people live here, roughly the population of Brooklyn -- than in a larger nation with a more complex society. "It's a small place," said Werner Prohl, a German who works in Ulaan Baatar for the Konrad Adenauer Foundation, a nonprofit group supporting research and democratic change. "It's really a few hundred people who matter in this country. If there is any scheming, everyone knows about it right away."
Yet Mongolia's experience plainly counters the argument, often voiced in the Far East, that democracy has no place in a developing country or in an Asian nation with "values" based on centuries of autocratic rule. Mongolian adults seemed fully capable of deciding who should govern them, and many rode by horseback for miles to vote. A full 98 percent of those registered to vote got to the polls.
"Asian people want democracy just like everyone else," Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for Asia, said during a recent visit to the region. "What's happened in Mongolia shows that talk about how Asian values don't fit with democracy is simply untrue."
The Mongolian Government now attaches great importance to winning sympathy from, and improved relations with, the United States. Cut loose from Russia after decades of political subjugation and economic support, Mongolians worry about their portly neighbor to the south, China.
Living squeezed between two giants, Mongolians have often felt as though they had to side with one or the other. The Soviet Union may have dominated Mongolia, a common refrain here goes, but China would simply consume it.
It is an understandable fear. In the broad swath of southern Mongolian plain that China has controlled since the 1940's, and renamed the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, there are now twice as many ethnic Chinese as Mongolians. Buddhist temples were demolished and monks purged for years before a semi-tolerant religious policy was adopted in 1979. Chinese is the language of instruction in schools.
It seems unlikely that Mongolia's new-found democracy will irritate China's leadership, which is careful to limit any discussion of democracy among its own people. Few people in China seem to be aware of the recent changes here, and the leaders in Beijing have not voiced any territorial claim to Mongolia.

 
 
China's Shadow
 Yet there is always a danger of trouble along the long border between China and Mongolia, because Chinese authorities are highly sensitive about any nationalist or religious activism that might stir up unrest among ethnic Mongolians within China.
While Mongolia's Government will be careful to avoid offending China in any way, it is eager to have American friends.
"American support is critical, because we live between these two giants," said Batkhuyag, a senior economic adviser to the Prime Minister. "We're very sensitive to that. We think that Americans can handle these guys better than anyone else."

HEADLINE: About Face;
Suddenly, a Mood of Danger in the Mideast

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL

DATELINE: CAIRO

 BODY:
THE grim expressions at the Middle East summit meeting in Washington last week were born not just of despair at the violence in the West Bank and Gaza that has intercepted the trajectory toward peace between Israel and the Palestinians.
A broader uncertainty lurks this autumn -- a sense that a region that a year ago seemed headed toward ineluctable peace might be on a track back toward war. 
 For King Hussein of Jordan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, the feeling is particularly stark. As champions of peace, they have tried to dampen Arab skepticism about Israel, assuring their citizens and their neighbors that it can be trusted.
But the clashes and their aftermath have so inflamed older hatreds that even Mr. Mubarak found it prudent to stay away from Washington. To many Arab ears, leaders like President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, who has scorned what he calls others' imperfect peace, sound now like they have been speaking with wisdom.
The shift in sentiment is not all that is worrisome. With the path toward peace apparently in stasis, at best, the build-up of elite Syrian troops near an Israeli post on Mount Hermon, in the Golan Heights, has multiplied the potential for trouble. The indecipherable motives of Iraq's Saddam Hussein have freshened the angst since the Iraqi leader baited the United States into launching cruise missile strikes that only Kuwait, among America's Arab allies, found it palatable to support.
And now Turkey, whose Ottoman forebears occupied so much of this region, has become a new source of puzzlement and fury with its schizophrenic wobbles from a military agreement with Israel to closer ties with Iran and other Islamic states. Even before the latest plunge into violence, Richard N. Haass, the director of foreign policy studies at the Brookings Institution, wrote in the current issue of Foreign Affairs that peace in the Middle East could be thought of as "a stock whose price has soared: a correction is inevitable."
After the failure of the meeting in Washington to produce more than the new round of talks between Israel and the Palestinians that was scheduled to start today, there remain worries that this could turn into Black October. King Hussein, who was sanguine even after the election of Israel's conservative new Government last May, was plainly gloomy after he and President Clinton failed to persuade Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to offer a clearer concession than hints that he might become more conciliatory.
"The psychological moment when people begin to lose hope is close by," the King said in a television interview.
For three years now, both the King and Mr. Mubarak, along with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, have relied on hope to prop up faith in peace agreements with Israel that have yet to produce many clear economic benefits. During the accord-a-year run from 1993 to 1995, spirits soared along with the rhetoric of signing ceremonies each autumn. But for all the peace partners' proclamations, the darker suspicion lurking in many minds and articulated most forcefully by Mr. Assad is that haste has already led to historic mistakes.
And since the suicide bombings in Israel last February and March, followed by clashes between Israeli forces and Hezbollah guerrillas in southern Lebanon in April and then Mr. Netanyahu's election in May, the path toward peace has been left without momentum, opening the way to broader uneasiness.
One fear that haunts Arab leaders is that Turkey, despite recent overtures to the Islamic world, has decided to align itself with Israel, having signed a military cooperation agreement last spring. On Friday, the country's Prime Minister, Necmettin Erbakan, head of an Islamic party, joined Mr. Mubarak in urging that Israel close the archaeological tunnel in Jerusalem whose opening ignited the recent violence, but there remains deep Arab concern that the pro-Western half of Turkey's divided Government would cast its lot with Israel in a crisis. Under the military agreement, Israel and Turkey can train in each others' airspace, and Syria in particular is worried that Israeli planes in Turkey could presage a pincer attack.
 
 
 
Remembering 1973
 That and other uneasiness has been reflected in Arab troop movements. Most alarming has been a shift of elite Syrian forces in Lebanon to positions that threaten an Israeli outpost on Mount Hermon, the strategic peak southwest of Damascus. Diplomats think it less likely that this is an intentional step toward conflict than a reminder to Israel by Syria of the danger of remaining in a no-war, no-peace situation. But along with massive military exercises by Egypt that included a simulated crossing of the Suez Canal, the provocative gesture has rekindled anxious memories of the October of 23 years ago, when Arabs and Israelis last waged all-out war.
It was the Persian Gulf war of 1991, of course, that appeared to transform the troubled region by establishing the partnership between the United States and key Arab states that drove Iraq from Kuwait. But five years on, with Arabs growing weary of policies aimed at crippling the tenacious Iraqi regime, the latest flare-up between Washington and Baghdad exposed a widening rift. Forced to choose between pressure from the United States and public opinion at home, every Arab country except Kuwait showed its distaste for President Clinton's decision to resort to military action.
Urged last week by Mr. Clinton to attend the summit meeting in Washington, Mr. Mubarak faced a similar choice, and the fact that he said no underscores a widening Arab sense that this may be a season for new tactics. "One of our most potent weapons in confronting Israel is the weapon of rejection," the Egyptian commentator Assayed Zahra wrote, "and that is one that the Arab states have regrettably squandered."

Lopez/The New York Times) (pg. 1); In Washington: President Clinton; Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader; Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, and King Hussein of Jordan. HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE RUNNING MATE;
Many See Election as Warm-Up for Kemp

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 4

 BODY:
The candidate bounded forth, mis-introduced as "Bob Kemp" but well enough known by the skeptical black audience to be greeted with a smattering of decidedly wary applause.
Jack Kemp, Republican candidate for Vice President, beamed nevertheless, barely flustered and determined to cherish each and every stop along his personal political revival circuit. 
 Beyond his sheer loquacious energy at any open microphone, there is a serenity to Mr. Kemp as he conducts a campaign that begs thoughts not so much of the coming Presidential election as the one in the year 2000.
"You just cannot get me to say what I hypothetically would do," the resurrected Republican politician firmly declared in an interview even as a sense of felicitous premonition, of being in a no-lose position regardless of the Nov. 5 result, quietly suffuses the Kemp campaign.
It remains unstated, especially by the candidate himself. Inured to most of the football metaphors that endlessly afflict his appearances, the former quarterback does dwell on one, his repeated promise of a come-from-behind fourth-quarter victory next month.
"By picking me, Bob Dole brought me back into the arena," Mr. Kemp acknowledged gratefully. He answered a few questions before going forth to "the lion's den," as he put it, to present the New Jersey Black Issues Convention with his relentless message that the Republican Party can be more inclusive. "I am at peace with my role."
Professional politicians studying his mellow mood along the trail sense a happy warrior retrieved from electoral oblivion, whose selection by Mr. Dole for the ticket may even hold the promise of the inside track on the future Republican Presidential nomination.
That track looks increasingly valuable as President Clinton's lead in the opinion polls keeps dogging Republican hopes. While swearing off all thought of new-millennium politics, Mr. Kemp seems to fortify his ebullience at every little-noticed whistle-stop. Party officials, fund-raisers and local journalists are on hand, a fund of future contacts grateful for his energetic performances.
"Advantage Kemp," contended Representative Bill McCollum, the Florida Republican, preferring a tennis metaphor in evaluating Mr. Kemp's perch, even should the ticket lose. "He'll be in a very good position for the year 2000, a wonderful opportunity," Mr. McCollum said on Wednesday at a rally in Orlando, Fla., hardly conceding defeat this year after hearing Mr. Kemp's rousing speech. The candidate delivered a typically booming address in which he grandly enlisted the biblical Good Shepherd into the cause of supply-side economics.
Off the campaign stage, he stayed busy denouncing any talk of being the leading edge of a trailing ticket. "That's just ludicrous," Mr. Kemp commented on speculation about being a front-runner in the 2000 election. "I do not view myself that way."
The speculation reached the point this week that Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, was asked about Mr. Kemp and pointedly omitted his name in estimating that the nation's Republican governors were the party's "vanguard" in any speculation about candidates beyond Mr. Dole. "That diminishes the prospect that there's any one person who you would think of as the party leader," Mr. Barbour said.
Mr. Kemp, paying careful attention to this news between campaign stops, said he was "disappointed, not angry" that Mr. Barbour even took a question on the subject. "It's not a good signal to be talking about the year 2000 when we have five weeks left in the campaign," he said, while agreeing that the future was wide open and insisting that his main goal was to stay on what he optimistically referred to as the Dole re-election ticket.
As a candidate, Mr. Kemp may have reined in his more ad-hoc riffs of oratory lately, with no further compliments to be heard for Louis Farrakhan, the firebrand black Muslim leader. But his pleasure in loyally bending his back to the ticket's secondary role seems undiminished at stop after stop as flashing security cars and a large retinue of campaign factotums announce the re-entry of Jack Kemp into competitive politics.
The candidate's rat-a-tat revivalist's performance in public is matched in private by Mr. Kemp's own lighthearted references and allusions to how the wintry years out of power of one of his political heroes, Winston Churchill, prepared the British politician for leadership.
As a performer, Mr. Kemp is always on, a political whirligig pointing and waving to people in the passing scene as he tours America, even shouting "Hey, how are you?" across an empty hotel lobby floor at a stranger who was mopping it in Jacksonville, Fla. The single word "entrepreneur" on his Thursday morning agenda rendered him evangelistic for a solid hour at the University of New Haven.
"I really believe he really believes in what he says," said Bob Burkett, a real estate dealer after intently studying the ever-moving, ever-talking Mr. Kemp on Wednesday at a Florida stop.
In contrast, the resentment was palpable among the black audience here when Mr. Kemp, relying on his progressive reputation as a former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, sought to address one woman amiably as "girl" and referred to an earlier campaign stop as being with "the folks in Harlem."
The wary reception seemed to put Mr. Kemp off a bit, at least to the extent of his uttering what lightly struck some listeners as a Dole-ism: "This is the most exciting world in history." But he maintained his whirlwind speaking style -- he claims 275 words a minute as his oratorical velocity --- and kept his promise to bring his message to a wide variety of American scenes and to not concede the black vote to Democrats. "Listening to polls is stupid," he told an autumnal rally on Thursday evening in Stamford, Conn., as he urged a full hearing of the candidates' debates. "Mr. Lincoln never took a poll."
Mr. Kemp volunteered in the interview that he was not entirely satisfied with the way the ticket is performing. "I am not convinced that we've done as good a job as we must do to get across to the American people the positive nature of this agenda, the growth side of it, the tax reform ideas," he said. "It would be no secret that I do not see politics as tearing someone else down," he added on the Republican strategy of focusing criticism on Mr. Clinton at the expense of issue discussions.
As he happily heads from stop to stop on the national scene, Mr. Kemp declares the ticket's current situation is no worse than being down 7 or 10 points in the third quarter of a contest he considers eminently winnable.
"We have yet to do the salesmanship and marketing and advertising necessary to advance our brand of politics," the candidate complained. "But we will in the last five weeks."

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
THE STATES AND THE ISSUES

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

 BODY:

Idaho
A Democratic Threat In G.O.P. Country
It has been said that in politics these days there are some issues, like Social Security, that are radioactive. The Senate race in Idaho indicates that there are no issues more radioactive than radioactivity. 
 In recent weeks Walt Minnick, the Democratic challenger, has pulled within striking distance of the incumbent, Larry Craig, a Republican in one of the country's most staunchly Republican states. Polls by the Minnick campaign show that the Democrat has closed to within two points of Mr. Craig. Mr. Craig's campaign officials scoff at those polls and cite an independent poll showing their candidate with a comfortable lead.
Nonpartisan observers, like Jennifer Duffy, an analyst with The Cook Political Report, a Washington newsletter, say Mr. Craig does have a race on his hands. They attribute Mr. Minnick's surge mainly to Mr. Craig's support for a deal reached between Gov. Phil Batt and the Clinton Administration to allow the Navy and the Department of Energy to store highly enriched uranium at the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory. In return, the Federal Government has promised to remove the waste by the year 2035.
"All this has to do with this one issue," Ms. Duffy said.
At a recent 90-minute debate among Mr. Craig, Mr. Minnick and two independent candidates, a third of the time was spent on the nuclear-waste issue. Mr. Minnick has trumpeted his support for a ballot initiative that would void the agreement and require that any future agreements to store nuclear waste be approved by the State Legislature. Mr. Craig opposes the measure.
Ms. Duffy said Mr. Craig could pull through, given the state's high percentage of Republican voters. Still, the fact that some people are even talking about a Democratic upset in Idaho is surprising.
"It is a Republican state, and in the end that may pull Craig across," Ms. Duffy said. "But right now, he looks like an incumbent who is in trouble and who probably didn't anticipate being in trouble. This one is sort of coming out of the blue."

Oregon
Senate Race Hinges On Portland Suburbs
According to Tip O'Neill's famous saying, all politics is local. In the Oregon Senate race, all politics is Clackamas and Washington Counties.
Like the Ron Wyden-Gordon Smith senatorial race in January -- won by Mr. Wyden -- the contest this fall between Mr. Smith, a Republican, and Tom Bruggere, a Democrat, is coming down to who can capture the two counties that are suburban bedroom communities of Portland.
Mr. Smith has a solid lead in the historically Republican areas in the eastern and southern parts of Oregon, whereas Mr. Bruggere is way ahead in Portland, a traditionally Democratic city. The two are running even in the Portland suburbs.
"We certainly need to have stable numbers in the metro area," said John Easton, a spokesman for Mr. Smith's campaign, referring to the suburbs that ring Portland. "They can't go lower."
Indeed, Mr. Smith's razor-thin loss to Mr. Wyden in January came as a result of being defeated among moderate voters in the Portland suburbs, mainly women who did not like his anti-abortion stand. This time around, Mr. Smith is trying to soften his image and is stressing economic themes.
But Mr. Smith appears to be hampered by a lack of money. In the next two weeks, state officials will mail out the first round of absentee ballots in Oregon's vote-by-mail system, but Mr. Smith has not run any television advertisements in a week.
"We're just making a determination on where we're going," Mr. Easton said.
 
Minnesota
Candidate, 41, Seeks Votes and a Wife
People may or may not agree with Michael Gubash's positions on social issues. But you have to admit that the guy knows how to hold down spending.
Mr. Gubash, 41, is running a shoestring campaign for the State Senate in Minnesota. Seeking to contain costs and hoping to take care of two very basic needs, he recently placed an advertisement in the September/ October issue of "Meet People," a Minneapolis-St. Paul singles sheet.
"My name is Michael and I am running for state senator, Senate District 65," the ad said. "I am a God-fearing, moral, pro-life Republican. I am also seeking a faithful, devoted, obedient, God-fearing woman to be my wife, to share my life, and to bear my children."
Mr. Gubash, who ran unopposed in the Republican primary, explained that he had placed the ad because he needed to jump-start his campaign against incumbent Sandra Pappas, a Democrat, and because he had not "been successful meeting people." Since his campaign, like his love life, is running on empty, it seemed fiscally wise to combine his personal and professional desires.
"It's cost-effective," he said in a telephone interview.
The ad asked people to contribute to his campaign and asked interested women to send pictures. "Either one or the other," he said, "or both."
So far, he hasn't had much luck. No pictures have come in, though he has received some telephone calls that have not panned out. And his ad has generated only enough contributions to bring his campaign war chest up to $100, and his donors' list up to three.
"Four, if you count myself," he said.
Mr. Gubash, a pipe fitter, is facing a tough political battle in an overwhelmingly Democratic district. A staunch conservative, he has vowed, if elected, to make abortion illegal, to shut down gay bars and to "teach children the value of marriage."
To accomplish the latter, of course, it would help if he found a wife -- and some votes. Either one.
Or both. STEVEN A. HOLMES

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;
Clinton Finds the Northeast Just as Cozy as Home Turf

SERIES: THE RACE FOR PRESIDENT: The Northeast

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
There is no better gauge of President Clinton's political potency in Pennsylvania, or in the entire Northeast, than in the changed behavior of this city's Democratic Mayor, Ed Rendell.
Only 14 months ago, when Republicans were still savoring their triumph in the 1994 elections, Mayor Rendell was so eager to cozy up to Republicans who had gathered here for their national summer meeting that he startled many in the audience when he declared with enthusiasm: "We are a solid Republican state. We have a Republican Governor and Lieutenant Governor. We have two Republican Senators." 
 But when Mr. Clinton came calling here the other day, the Mayor was back to being a loyal Democrat, clinging to the Chief Executive at every stop. "C'mon, I'll buy," he said as he treated Mr. Clinton to a cheese steak.
While Mr. Clinton is enjoying an immense lead over Bob Dole in polls around the country, nowhere is it more manifest than in the dozen states in the Northeast. Although large states in the region, like New York and Massachusetts, have long been safely Democratic, what is particularly surprising is Mr. Clinton's strength in states that have been Republican bastions in Presidential races, like New Hampshire, Maine, Vermont and Connecticut. In addition, the region's traditional battlegrounds of Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware, which usually roil with political swells, today look like still ponds.
The Northeast has essentially emerged as Mr. Clinton's electoral base. In contrast with other sections of the country, polls show that the President has completely shut Mr. Dole out of the Northeast, to the point that many Republicans say they fear that his unpopularity could drag down candidates for Congress and local offices. The third-party candidacy of Ross Perot, who did particularly well four years ago in Maine, is mired in the low single digits in every Northeastern state.
"If we weren't strong in the Northeast, we'd be in trouble," said Harold M. Ickes, a deputy chief of staff who oversees the political operation from the White House.
Even Mr. Ickes acknowledges that the President has been stronger in the region than many Democrats expected, in part because of the sturdy economy and also because Speaker Newt Gingrich and the Congressional Republicans seem particularly noxious to many voters here.
"If you didn't know any better, you'd think Bill Clinton was a New England governor," said J. Bradford Coker, president of Mason-Dixon Political/Media Research, a nationwide polling concern based in Columbia, Md. "He runs much better in New England than even in his home territory. It's rooted in traditional Yankee politics, which is a social liberalism and a rejection of Gingrich."
In an outburst of overstatement or, perhaps, overconfidence, Gary Hindes, chairman of the Democratic Party in Delaware, was so enthusiastic about Mr. Clinton's prospects in his state and beyond that he declared, "There's a possibility this guy could carry 50 states, which has never been done in history."
Scott Reed, Mr. Dole's campaign manager, insists that the outlook for his candidate is not as bleak as polls suggest. "Don't believe the polls," he said. "Pennsylvania is a key battleground state where Bob Dole's message of cutting taxes and being tough on crime and drugs will resonate. It has a large Catholic population where Clinton is extremely vulnerable on the partial-birth abortion issue. And we have a very popular Republican Governor who has cut taxes who is running our campaign."
While Mr. Dole's aides always expected Pennsylvania to be a battle, the fact that they are struggling in New Hampshire is a telling measure of what the campaign is up against across the entire region. Although Mr. Clinton carried the state in 1992, he was the first Democrat to win there since 1964, and it was by only one percentage point. The latest Mason-Dixon survey shows that Mr. Clinton is leading by 11 points.
Mr. Dole's advisers explain that there is still residual anger toward Mr. Dole from the New Hampshire primary, where he finished second behind Patrick J. Buchanan. To get that far, Mr. Dole had to survive millions of dollars' worth of attack commercials from the campaigns of Steve Forbes and Lamar Alexander.
Gov. Stephen Merrill of New Hampshire, general chairman of the national Dole campaign, tried to put the best face on Mr. Dole's prospects in his state. "I wouldn't say this is the dream scenario I wrote in my mind," he said. "But I'm not running scared."
After a slow start, the Dole campaign is now geared up in the state and has begun advertising on television, Mr. Merrill said. He surmised that the effort had not begun earlier because campaign officials had hoped that Mr. Clinton would not pose any threat in New Hampshire.
Mr. Dole's troubles in the Northeast are reflected in his travel schedule. Although he has campaigned and advertised heavily in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, he seems to have all but given up on campaigning in other states in the region. Mr. Dole stumped in heavily Republican central Pennsylvania last week, in the wake of a visit to the state by the President.
In an appearance at a fund raiser here, Mr. Clinton made special note of the affluent Main Line communities around Philadelphia that are full of swing voters who backed him four years ago. "The normally Republican suburban areas near here were unusually good to the Clinton-Gore ticket in 1992," he said, "and I hope they will be in 1996."
David Buffington, editor of The Pennsylvania Report, a political newsletter in Harrisburg, said Mr. Dole represented a hard-edged Republicanism that was too conservative for this state. "Voters here want Jack Kemp, but Jack Kemp ain't at the top of the ticket," Mr. Buffington said. "They want a kinder, gentler Republican Party that will still keep the I.R.S. out of their stock funds." He said Democratic appeals about protecting Medicare had also played well with the sizable elderly population in this state.
But Kieran Mahoney, the Dole campaign's senior consultant for the Northeast, noted that there was a recent tradition of Republicans in the region coming from behind and scoring upsets. He cited the elections of three Governors: George Pataki of New York, Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey and Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania. "These states are highly sensitive to taxes -- and outraged at the levels of government spending," he said. "Talk to Mario Cuomo. Talk to Jim Florio. The political graveyard is littered with people like that. And Clinton's still the poster child of tax increases."
Tony Podesta, who is helping to run the Clinton campaign in the state, said Mr. Clinton was doing so well that he had the luxury of limiting his appearances in Pennsylvania while campaigning more heavily in usually Republican territory, like Arizona.
"Who would have dreamed that in the month of September in this election year, the President would be in Arizona twice and Pennsylvania once?" Mr. Podesta said. "It speaks of Clinton's strength and Dole's vulnerability."
It also explains Mayor Rendell's change of heart. "I want the President to be responsive to the needs of the city of Philadelphia," Mr. Rendell said. "And he has."

HEADLINE: POLITICS -- Political Battle of the Sexes Is Tougher Than Ever;
Suburbs' Soccer Moms, Fleeing the G.O.P., Are Much Sought

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 3

 BODY:
If the catch phrase that emerged from the Republican sweep in the 1994 elections was "angry white men," then what will it be this election season?
"Anxious white women," suggested Karen Hasse Ball, a mother of two who lives with her husband, children, dog and two cats on a leafy street in this Los Angeles suburb and casts her vote based on concerns about her children's future. 
 In fact, the white suburban women like Ms. Hasse Ball who are fast becoming the most sought-after voters of the campaign season are already known in campaign circles by a different name that is only now gaining currency: soccer moms.
But she was right that she and her comrades in the minivan brigades are politically hot. By breaking with their traditional Republican leanings and spurning Bob Dole in striking numbers, according to early polls, they have become a central focus of campaigners and pollsters who consider them part of the swing vote, without which Mr. Dole cannot win the Presidency.
"The campaigns are both trying to target and appeal to this group," said Susan Carroll, a senior research associate at the Center for the American Woman and Politics at Rutgers University. "And what's making it very tough for the Dole campaign is that the Clinton campaign seems to be going after these women equally aggressively."
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, conducted in early September, found that support for President Clinton among married white suburban women appeared to have jumped dramatically since 1992. In a comparable poll in September 1992, 48 percent of them preferred Mr. Bush while 27 percent preferred Mr. Clinton. This year, only 39 percent favor Mr. Dole while 49 percent prefer Mr. Clinton, for a shift of 22 percentage points in Mr. Clinton's favor.
In interviews around the country this week, white suburban married women who plan to vote for Mr. Clinton gave many reasons for their choice, but they all seemed to boil down to a perception that Mr. Dole is from Mars and Mr. Clinton is from Venus.
Mr. Clinton and the social welfare programs he supports appealed more to the women voters' compassion for the unfortunate and feelings of "there but for the grace of God," they said, while Mr. Dole's arguments that the tax cut he is proposing would benefit all families struck less of a chord.
"Men tend to vote with their pocketbooks," said Robin Smith, an insurance executive and father of three stopping in to the La Salle High School here for a parent-teacher conference, "and women. . . . "
" . . . vote with their hearts," finished his wife, Leslie.
But it is far from that simple.
At an evening mah-jongg game in a suburb of Lincoln, Neb., the five players -- all married white women -- listed an array of issues that concerned them most and that President Clinton seemed better on, like abortion, health care reform, gun control, improved public education and paid leave for family caregivers. But Michelle Carr, 38 and a Democrat who voted for George Bush in 1992, said she would nonetheless vote for Mr. Dole -- reluctantly -- because she could not trust Mr. Clinton. Like several other women interviewed, she said that neither candidate seemed right but that she would vote for Mr. Dole because "we need some tax relief in this household."
In Richmond, Mary W. Alexander, a mother of two from the suburb of Mechanicsville who teaches learning-disabled children, expressed a similar lack of enthusiasm for both candidates but leaned the other way.
"I was really for Bush, so there was a reason to vote for him," she said as she sat on a folding lawn chair and -- a literal soccer mom -- watched her son play for the Chickahominy Chargers. "Dole is not a very appealing candidate. A lot of women I teach with feel the same way: Clinton is the lesser of two evils."
Mr. Clinton, she added, "does seem to care."
That sense of caring appears to count tremendously for women who say their political approaches have altered since they had children.
"You think where the country's going to be in 10 years," Ms. Alexander said. "You aren't so me-centered. Before, I thought how it was for me -- taxes, Social Security, balancing the budget. Now I'm thinking about them -- drugs, education, medical reform. You get that mom focus."
Their husbands, many women said, tend to remain more concerned about economic issues, pushing for lower taxes and trusting in their own earning ability rather than supporting more of a social safety net in case they should fail.
When they discuss politics, the men in their lives also tend to see things more in black and white, they said, whereas they, like President Clinton, have a more consensus-building style.
"Dollars and cents," said Gay Koty, a school nurse, mother of four and typical Bush-to-Clinton shifter from Somerville, Mass., of her husband's way of thinking about politics. "Nuts and bolts. Meat and potatoes."
Those differences are longstanding, but some pollsters and analysts say the shift in the soccer moms' vote is accentuated because of women's reaction to the cuts effected by the Republican Congress.
The breakaway moms also reflect the mounting political independence of women who have been out in the workplace for many years now, said Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster. Her suggestion for the 1996 catch phrase was "energized white women" because "they're not particularly angry but they are empowered."
The Republican assessment of the importance of the soccer moms shows in the campaign's open wooing of them recently; campaigners say Mr. Dole's message does jibe with the moms' concerns, but it has not been effectively communicated yet.
"We just need to do a better job of talking their language," said Linda DiVall, a Republican pollster.
Another Republican pollster, Charles F. Rund, cautioned that there had often been a radical, last-minute change in voting gaps between the sexes with the approach of Election Day.
For the soccer mom contingent, 11th-hour changes would be for one obvious reason: their lives are so hectic many barely have time to think about eating, let alone voting.
"Moms will listen at the last minute," said Linda C. Baber, who was in Richmond this week planning a slumber party for 10 9-year-old girls for the eldest of her three children. "I need a quick summary."

HEADLINE: Baby May Make 3, but in Japan That's Not Enough

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: KYOKUSHI, Japan

 BODY:
It is not that the young women strolling the meandering alleys of this sun-dappled farming village in southern Japan are lazy or dishonest or impolite. No, the problem, at least as old folks and local officials see it, is just that they have almost stopped having babies.
The latest statistics, released recently, show that Japan's birth rate hit a new low last year, and a Government projection now suggests that the population will fall by more than half over the next century. It is forecast to tumble to 55 million in 2100, from 125 million today. 
 Reflecting the unease, a weekly magazine went even further and calculated that in the year 3000, if trends continue, the population will dwindle to 45,000. No one has worked out just when Japan will be down to a final, childless couple, a reverse Adam and Eve, post-genitors of the race, but there is agreement that such a trend would not be reassuring for housing prices.
Tumbling birth rates are a concern in much of the industrialized world -- indeed, the United States is one of the few major countries with a rough balance. Fertility rates in most of Europe are well below the replacement level needed to sustain a population.
By contrast, in much of the third world, the rates are causing population explosions.
"My husband doesn't want kids at all, and I don't particularly want them either," said Naomi Hamada, a 28-year-old Tokyo housewife.
"My husband just doesn't like them," she said. "He doesn't like annoying things. And since he wouldn't help out raising them, I don't want kids either."
Because of people like the Hamadas, the average Japanese woman is now expected to have just 1.4 babies. It takes just over 2 babies per woman, roughly the level in the United States, to maintain a population in the long run.
This figure, called the total fertility rate, is even lower in a few other places: 1.2 in Germany, Spain and Hong Kong, and 1.3 in Italy.
So officials here in Kyokushi -- and around the world -- have been debating how to make people make more babies.
"There are several ways to encourage people to have more babies," said the Mayor, Masahide Iwane, a lean and dour man with gray hair, 4 children and 12 grandchildren. "For starters we thought we would offer a congratulatory reward to mothers of a fourth child, to show our community's desire for more babies."
So any woman in town will get a gift of almost $5,000 upon the birth of a fourth or subsequent child. To lure fecund types to Kyokushi, which is on the southern island of Kyushu, the town will pay the same sum to newly arrived couples who have a fourth child -- but only after they have stayed in town for a year.
Many other Japanese towns also offer cash for births, but Kyokushi's rewards are among the highest. Mr. Iwane said the town had also considered other financial incentives: cash for marriages, cut-rate land for child-bearing couples, and cash grants to parents when their children turn 3, 5 and 7, which are all auspicious birthdays in Japan.
The problem is that the potential procreators, like Noriko Hirayama, are unimpressed. Mrs. Hirayama, 25, lives in a farm family on the edge of Kyokushi with two children, 5 and 3, and is resisting pleas to have more.
"I tell her all the time to have more kids," said her mother-in-law, Atsuko, who lives with them. "I'm young and I was once a nursery teacher, so I tell them the sooner the better. But kids these days seem to think about all kinds of things."
What are these things? The younger Mrs. Hirayama said that she doubted she had the time or money to raise four children properly, and that she relishes what free time she has.
"People in my generation feel we want kids," she said, "but we also want to enjoy our own lives."
Since Kyokushi introduced the reward in April, no woman with three or more children has become pregnant. Women interviewed around town all suggested that the amount was far too small.
"It costs far more than that to raise a child," noted Emi Nagata, a 34-year-old mother of two who was shopping in the main grocery store in Kyokushi. If the reward were paid "not once but every year," she said, people might find it more tempting.
One might think, after enduring the Tokyo subway during rush hour, that a reduced population would not be such a bad idea. After all, Japan's projected 55 million inhabitants in 2100 still represent the same population that the country had back in 1920, and they would still create a population density five times that of the United States today.
Yet there seems little enthusiasm for a tumbling population. One reason is apprehension about the destabilizing effects of a smaller work force, declining land prices and a shrinking economy. Another is worry that Japan will become a less important country, as its population drops to just one-quarter of America's soon after 2050, from two-thirds of America's a century ago.
Fertility rates have risen in some industrialized countries in recent years. But just why is unclear; it could be a statistical discrepancy, or the result of cash payments and maternity benefits that some Governments have offered, or a function of social changes that make it easier for a woman to combine motherhood with a career -- or the result of an influx of immigrants whose higher birth rates have driven up the total.
Whatever the reason, Sweden has bolstered its fertility rate to 1.9, from 1.7 in 1980. Similarly, the fertility rate in the United States has risen to about 2.0, from less than 1.8 in 1975. Even when the American fertility rate falls below the replacement level, the population is expected to increase steadily because of immigration.
Japan is considering substantial increases in child and maternity benefits, which are now minimal. These seem critical in the calculations of some women, like Michiko Kawamura, a strong-willed, angular housewife who is a bit of a local heroine in Kyokushi because she has had four children.
"Our fourth child was on condition that my husband help more," Mrs. Kawamura, 37, said. "But then after I had the baby, he kept saying that he was too busy. So I ended up doing all the work by myself."
Japan is in many ways a difficult place to be a mother. While an excellent national system of day-care centers is available for working mothers, women sometimes feel pressure to care for children entirely by themselves. Mothers are often expected to spend huge amounts of time taking their children to cram schools, special classes and other activities, with almost no help from fathers.
Tokyo, with its tiny homes, sandbox-size parks and obsession with getting into the right schools, is probably the most child-unfriendly place in all of Japan. Not surprisingly, it has the lowest fertility rate: just 1.1 children per woman.
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, when he was Finance Minister, suggested what seemed a novel way to increase fertility: discourage women from going to college. In 1990, Mr. Hashimoto told the Cabinet the reason for the decline was that the Government was encouraging women to seek higher education.
Mr. Hashimoto's comments provoked a furor; he has not been heard from on this issue since.
Another reason for the dropping rates is the growing pool of women who marry late or who feel no burning compulsion to marry at all.
"My child absolutely doesn't want to get married," said Atusko Tanaka, 52, an Osaka housewife. "She's already 26 years old, but she never had high hopes or dreamed of marriage at all. She looks at the way I live, which I think is the way most women my age live, and tells me she doesn't want to end up like me."
The average woman marries at 27, and about 17 percent of women in their early 30's are unmarried.
"The reason for women marrying later, I think, is that men are wimps," said Makiko Kobayashi, 24, a Tokyo student researching motherhood. "I know that might sound a bit exaggerated. But it's hard to find the men of our dreams."
Some experts echo Miss Kobayashi, saying the decline has less to do with women's not wanting babies than with their difficulty finding the right fathers.
In an attempt to boost marriage rates and fertility levels, some local governments are helping arrange for the immigration of marriageable women from the Philippines. Still, some demographers doubt much can be done.
"I'm very pessimistic about a restoration of fertility," said Makoto Atoh, director general of the official Institute of Population Problems in Tokyo. "The main reason for the decline in fertility is that women have advanced. They want to get ahead in the world, but they're also asked to care for children and do all the housework. Men never do that stuff."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Officials like Mayor Masahide Iwane of Kyokushi worry about Japan's low birth rate. He spoke with Noriko Hirayama and her 3-year-old. Mrs. Hirayama has two children and is resisting pleas to have more. (Nicholas D. Kristof/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: It's a Lonely Way to Pay the Bills;
For Unauthorized Biographers, the World Is Very Hostile

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
There is a living purgatory inhabited by biographers who dare to write about famous people who are neither consenting nor dead, and that is where Carole Klein found herself one night several years ago at the New York Public Library.
The occasion was a reading by Doris Lessing, the novelist whose biography Ms. Klein was preparing to write -- over the objections of Mrs. Lessing, who had actively discouraged others from helping Ms. Klein. 
 The auditorium was packed. In the crowd sat Ms. Klein, feeling the duplicity that is the unauthorized biographer's burden -- unrecognizable yet conspicuous, sheepish yet righteous, professional writer turned amateur spy.
Then a strange thing happened. Mrs. Lessing, formidable in her 70's, finished reading, and no one rose to ask a question. It occurred to Ms. Klein that the audience was afraid of looking stupid. The silence grew awkward.
Suddenly, she found herself feeling, of all things, protective of Mrs. Lessing. "I thought to myself: Should I ask a question?" Ms. Klein recalled recently. "Then I thought: No, I'll ask the question and she'll think I'm stupid."
These may be boom years in the biography business, but the economics of publishing and popular tastes have put pressure on writers to select living subjects instead of the kind one biographer calls "nice and dead."
The problem is that the living ones tend to say no. Some even encourage their friends to do the same. Which can make spending three or four years reconstructing a hostile subject's life a lonely, dispiriting way of paying the bills.
Letters go unanswered, calls unreturned. Sources hang up when the biographer introduces himself over the phone. One potential source let Ms. Klein fly all the way to London before canceling their lunch date.
And when Carl Rollyson wrote to a former husband of one of his subjects asking why their marriage had failed, the man shooed him away by quoting Macbeth's dismissal of Banquo's ghost: "Hence, horrible shadow!/Unreal mockery, hence!"
Then he signed the letter: "Insincerely yours."
It gets painful.
"I will never, never do another living person," said Ann Waldron, who is completing a biography of Eudora Welty. "I have a pretty thick skin but not that thick to undergo this for the rest of my life."
And in a city where virtually every definable group has its corresponding support group, and where biographers are abundant enough to have two, one small subset of biographers working on living subjects hangs loosely together, mostly by phone, to share war stories, lick their wounds and offer moral support.
They are all experienced biographers with multiple books to their names. They consider themselves serious, responsible writers -- who just happen to have chosen subjects who are less than ecstatic about their plans.
The group includes Ms. Klein, writing her book on Doris Lessing; Marion Meade, researching a biography of Woody Allen; Mrs. Waldron, doing a book on Eudora Welty, and Mr. Rollyson and his wife, Lisa Paddock, who are researching a biography of Susan Sontag.
The writers met through the New York University Biography Seminar, a larger group of published biographers, many of them academics writing on figures long dead, who gather monthly at N.Y.U. to do the biographer's equivalent of talking shop.
But the writers with living subjects are almost a breed apart.
"Let me put it this way: I don't think I could do that," said Brenda Wineapple, a biographer and professor at Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., who is a co-director of the N.Y.U. group. "It can be very demoralizing, very difficult. You need a certain kind of personality to confront that.
"Plus, you really need to believe in what you're doing," she said. "Which is not being a literary paparazzo, it's not being a scandal monger. It's really, in some sense, excavating history. And that's difficult when your subject is alive."
None of them started out looking for trouble. They describe themselves, mostly, as admirers of their subjects. Ms. Klein was "a tremendous fan" of Mrs. Lessing's books, interested in the social and cultural context of her life. As she puts it: "I had this feeling that we would connect."
Ms. Meade's previous subjects had all been dead -- Eleanor of Aquitaine, Dorothy Parker, Buster Keaton and others. But when she proposed another "dead person" last year, she found editors said things like: "I'm only going to be able to ship 3,000 copies of a subject like that. What else do you have?"
So she suggested Woody Allen.
Neither Ms. Meade nor Mr. Rollyson sought their subject's cooperation first; they believe they are more objective biographers without it. Instead, each wrote a letter informing the subject that they had signed a contract to write a biography. Neither received a letter back.
Mrs. Waldron and Ms. Klein, on the other hand, each approached their subjects before making a book proposal. They had known them, at least slightly, before. Mrs. Waldron had visited Miss Welty in Jackson, Miss., on several occasions. Ms. Klein had had earlier telephone conversations with Mrs. Lessing about receiving an award from a group of which Ms. Klein is a member.
But Miss Welty and Mrs. Lessing said no, repeatedly. They were not interested in having biographies done, they said. They gave reasons subjects often give: Miss Welty said she wanted her writing to stand on its own; Mrs. Lessing said she was writing a memoir.
"I was a fool," Mrs. Waldron said in retrospect. "I rushed in where angels would have feared to tread." She said she allowed herself to believe Miss Welty was not adamantly opposed. And being from the South, like Miss Welty, she figured she would be able to get Southerners to talk.
One of the first people she called was a man she had interviewed for an earlier book. "I'll have to call Eudora," she remembers him saying. When he called back, he said he had been asked not to cooperate. He said Miss Welty had said: "Ask Ann to call me."
Mrs. Waldron didn't.
"She'd just talk me out of it," she explained.
Mrs. Waldron went to Memphis and tracked down a retired college administrator who had known Miss Welty years before. Does Eudora know you're working on this book? The woman asked over the phone. Mrs. Waldron said yes. Do you have her permission? No. The woman hung up.
Mrs. Waldron wrote to another man; he never answered, then declined to talk when she reached him by phone. Still another agreed to see her as soon as he returned from Europe. When he got back, he called her. "Don't come," he said. "I've talked to Eudora."
Mrs. Waldron drafted and redrafted a letter to him, explaining how much she wanted and needed the interview. She offered not to quote him, if that would help. To try to convince him she was a serious literary biographer, she sent along a copy of one of her earlier books.
"He sent the book back unopened and a one-line letter saying: 'The last thing Eudora needs at this stage in her life is an unauthorized biography,' " Mrs. Waldron said. She called her colleague Carl Rollyson from the N.Y.U. biography group and said, "I can't stand this!"
"Nobody ever told you it was going to be easy," he said coolly.
Ms. Klein ran into similar problems. When she published an author's query in The New York Times Book Review, looking for correspondence and personal recollections about Mrs. Lessing, Mrs. Lessing's agent sent a frosty letter to the editor that was then published in the Book Review.
"I am writing on behalf of Mrs. Lessing to say that this biography is totally unauthorized, that no permissions will be granted for extracts from the author's work and that her letters are also copyrighted and cannot be used without her permission," the two-paragraph letter said.
Ms. Klein was stunned.
"If you were an unsophisticated person reading this, you would have thought it was illegal to answer," she said. "I did think that was out of bounds. This was cutting off the most valuable research tool a biographer has. It was such an extreme step, particularly for a writer to do to another writer."
There are other difficulties, too. When Mr. Rollyson proposed an unauthorized biography of Lillian Hellman, he knew her papers were stored at the University of Texas. Only after he had signed a book contract did he learn that the only biographer with access to the papers was her authorized one.
After an initial panic, he says he ordered copies of every Ph.D. dissertation that had been written using the archive, knowing that graduate students did not need permission from Miss Hellman's estate to use it. He says he was able to reconstruct much of the Texas archive through the dissertations.
For his unauthorized biography of Martha Gellhorn, the writer and third wife of Ernest Hemingway, Mr. Rollyson found that copyright laws severely limited his ability to quote from her unpublished letters. The lawyer for his publishing company ended up allowing him to quote just three words.
According to Mr. Rollyson, the three words had appeared in a letter from Miss Gellhorn to Bernard Berenson, responding to his teasing suggestion that Mr. Hemingway, from whom she was then divorced, might be visiting him in Italy at the same time as Miss Gellhorn had planned to come.
"She said, 'Don't you dare. I don't want to feel his hot jungle breath on my neck,' " Mr. Rollyson recalled in an interview. "I said to the lawyer: 'Come on! I'm going to come up with a paraphrase for 'hot jungle breath'?' So she said, 'O.K., O.K., O.K.' So 'hot jungle breath' is in the book."
Ms. Meade said she believes biographers' feelings often follow a predictable course: They adore the subject, then despise the subject, then wonder whatever possessed them to choose that subject at all. Eventually, biographers "work through that hostility and come out in the proper place," she said.
Ms. Meade herself had a hard time adjusting to a living subject. "The very idea that my subject was alive and living across the park freaked me out," she said. For months, she would wake up in her Upper West Side apartment "feeling just horribly depressed."
But as time passes, she said, "the subject recedes to a place which is like a twilight zone." Much of the research is the same, whether the subject is living or dead. "Now, I don't feel as terrified," she said. "Besides, I do keep telling myself: This is my job."
There are signs above Ms. Meade's desk. One that appeals to her sense of humor reads: "The less said about this person the better."
Of everyone in the group, Mr. Rollyson appears to have achieved the deepest state of emotional detachment. He professes, persuasively, to take a clinical view of his work. He and Ms. Paddock describe his attitude as a product of temperament and long experience.
The son of a bartender and a discount-store sales clerk, Mr. Rollyson was an actor in his adolescence, then got a Ph.D. in English literature and became an academic. He writes in small spurts -- "two, three hours, tops" -- while also working as a professor at Baruch College of the City University of New York.
He gets his legal advice on copyright matters from Ms. Paddock, a lawyer, former stock broker and now a freelance writer. Their home is an apartment in what was once an Ex-Lax factory in downtown Brooklyn. Together, they have also written a couple of how-to books about genealogy.
Biography, as Mr. Rollyson sees it, is all about exposure.
"I seem to fasten on subjects who have created these images of themselves and who seem to feel entitled to project this as history," he said. He believes the public is entitled to understand how that is done. If his subjects reject him, Mr. Rollyson doesn't mind. After a half a dozen biographies, mostly of writers, he understands.
"I feel my subject is entitled to their anger," he said. "I can certainly understand why someone would be nervous that there's someone around inquiring into their life. They have no control over this person. Who is this person?
"You know, you're dealing with someone with a very significant literary reputation. And the biographer, compared to that person, could easily be called a second- or third-rater. So I can see all sorts of reasons why they might be upset and worried."
How would he feel? he was asked.
"I've left instructions to everybody: Talk, talk, talk," Mr. Rollyson said, laughing. "I want it to be a good book, colorful stories. Everybody talk. I want to be famous."
And Ms. Paddock?
"I wouldn't like it at all," she said. "It would make me very angry and upset."

 ANN WALDRON, who is writing an unauthorized biography of Eudora Welty, gave this account of her efforts to land an interview. Without success.
 
1. In a published interview with Eudora Welty, Mrs. Waldron notices a reference to a family named Miat with whom Miss Welty had spent May Day, 1950, in France.
 
2. Mrs. Waldron runs the name through various library indexes and finds Mary Miat, a writer who had married a French sculptor, Aristide Miat.
 
3. From a guest list for a celebration of Miss Welty's birthday, Mrs. Waldron finds that Mrs. Miat had lived at one time in Santa Fe, N.M.
 
4. Mrs. Waldron calls galleries and museums in Santa Fe. In one museum, an employee finds a catalogue with a single reference to Aristide Miat.
 
5. Mrs. Waldron writes to thank the museum employee, who then voluntarily tracks down a daughter of Mrs. Miat still living in Santa Fe.
 
6. The daughter tells Mrs. Waldron that her mother is 90 years old and living in Bethesda, Md. with another daughter. She gives Mrs. Waldron the address.
 
7. Mrs. Waldron writes to Mrs. Miat, asking to interview her about Miss Welty.
 
8. Mrs. Miat writes back. She says she has spoken to Miss Welty and she would rather not talk. JANNY SCOTT
