HEADLINE: POLITICS -- Political Battle of the Sexes Is Tougher Than Ever;
For Many White Men, Clinton's the Reason To Vote for Dole

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 3

 BODY:
Ask Republican men in this stronghold of conservatism why they are voting for Bob Dole in November, and the odds are they will tell you first that Bill Clinton is a promise-breaking, policy-shifting politician whose charm and sweet talk have cast a dangerous spell on much of America.
It is not that they think Mr. Dole would not be a good President. They think he would be. It is just that the same passion they feel in explaining why they do not like and do not trust Mr. Clinton eludes them in explaining why they prefer his opponent. 
 As the 1996 Presidential campaign has unfolded, President Clinton's persistent lead over Mr. Dole in public opinion surveys has been defined, in part, by a growing number of women who say they prefer the President over Mr. Dole. Poll after poll shows Mr. Clinton has gained significant strength with female voters in the four years since he defeated President George Bush.
But on the other side of the gender gap, many of the same polls measure something else: a strong preference for Mr. Dole over Mr. Clinton among certain groups of men, like white men who are married and live in the suburbs. In many cases, the polls show, Mr. Dole is doing even better among these groups of men than Mr. Bush did in 1992.
With the Presidential campaign lumbering into its final weeks, many men, particularly in a state like Texas, are angry that Mr. Clinton is doing so well in the polls, frustrated that Mr. Dole has failed to catch fire with voters and baffled that so many Americans do not seem to care about character.
These men may profoundly respect Mr. Dole, but they do not seem to like him very much. While it troubles them to admit it, they wish he could be a lot more exciting, like Mr. Clinton, or better still, like Ronald Reagan.
In the family room of a house in an upper-middle-class Dallas suburb, seven white men stayed behind after a weekly 7 A.M. Bible study group with their sixth-grade sons to vent. Their lack of enthusiasm for Mr. Dole is so great that it took 20 minutes before his name came up.
"I wish you could put Ronald Reagan's head, when he was President, into Bob Dole's body," said Gil Sheehan, a 39-year-old father of three who runs a small gift-manufacturing business. "Ronald Reagan said, 'Hey, America, this is what I believe.' I don't know if it's his handlers or what, but Bob Dole comes off as wishy-washy."
Phil Mabry, a 42-year-old stockbroker and father of four, agreed, saying: "Ronald Reagan had vision. Jack Kemp has vision. Hillary Clinton has vision, although it's one I don't agree with. I don't sense that from Bob Dole. He's very qualified, but he has trouble articulating his message. And that's what elects Presidents."
While none of the men said his wife was supporting Mr. Clinton, they are painfully aware that the polls show Mr. Clinton has a 2-to-1 lead nationwide over Mr. Dole among female voters.
Even in Texas, where the most recent Democratic Presidential candidate to carry the state was Jimmy Carter in 1976, men and women are straining in opposite directions. While 50 percent of Texas men prefer Mr. Dole, only 39 percent of the women do, according to a poll of 1,007 registered voters taken by Blum & Weprin Associates in September. By contrast, 36 percent of Texas men who were surveyed prefer Mr. Clinton, while 46 percent of the women do. The margin of sampling error for each sex was plus or minus 4 percentage points.
The men have little trouble explaining why some women do not find Mr. Dole an attractive candidate. "Grumpy old man," said Frank Bullock, a 41-year-old real estate broker.
"It's a Nixon-Kennedy thing," Mr. Mabry said.
The only time the group got excited about the Republicans was when Joseph P. Garrett, a 41-year-old real estate developer and father of two, asked: "Would you vote for Elizabeth Dole for President?"
"I'd love it!" Mr. Sheehan said. "She's one of the reasons I'm excited about Bob Dole."
"I'd love a Kemp-Elizabeth Dole ticket," Mr. Mabry said.
"That's my ticket," Mr. Bullock said.
Even when Mr. Sheehan tried to stop the group from fantasizing too much about a possible female President Dole, he still could not stir much enthusiasm for her husband. "Please don't think Bob Dole doesn't have a lot of vision, that we'd rather have a woman," he said. "But you know, he doesn't have a lot of vision."
The men -- and dozens of other middle- and upper-middle-class men interviewed throughout Dallas -- acknowledge that the explanation for the male-female gap is more complicated.
They cite the Republican Party's rigid opposition to abortion, which has polarized the party establishment in Texas and alienated a large segment of Republican female voters.
They say that Mr. Clinton has inaccurately -- but cleverly -- managed to portray Mr. Dole as a man who would rob old people of their medical benefits and take food away from poor children.
They think that some of the issues that Mr. Dole has stressed, like the need for a stronger defense and a stronger business environment, do not automatically carry as much weight with women.
And in a state like Texas, where the economy has thrived in the Clinton Presidency, Mr. Dole's pledge of a 15 percent tax cut comes off sounding to both men and women more like a political ploy.
But the way Mr. Dole looks and talks is what the men keep coming back to -- whether at an afternoon game of six-man football for sixth graders in the upper-middle-class enclave of University Park or in the hog house of the Texas State Fair.
"I wish Dole would come across as a more tough-minded person, a person with more vigor," said Grant Stephenson, 52, an executive recruiter, watching his son play football.
"I don't think it's the age thing. It's his style. Bill Clinton has so much charisma I don't even know if a Ronald Reagan could beat him this year," Mr. Stephenson said.
At the State Fair, men talked more bluntly about why Mr. Dole's inability to charm hurts his chances, particularly with women.
"Dole, well, he's old and ugly for one thing," said Scooter Brown, a 51-year-old veterinarian, horse-trader and Dole supporter.
As for Mr. Clinton, Mr. Brown added: "Some women know about his past, but they don't seem to care."
Mr. Clinton's past, in Republican circles here, is shorthand for accusations of marital infidelity that may not be much of a factor nationally but that are being used in Texas as part of a broader attack on the President's character.
"Bill Clinton is not a role model for our children or our nation," said David Slaughter, 38, the owner of a women's shoe company who was at the fair with his wife and children. "It's the immorality, it's Whitewater, it's sex."
That sentiment was echoed at the fathers' morning meeting. "I have friends who run around on their wives, and it's nice to go hunting and fishing with them," said Frank Fleming, a 44-year-old lawyer, "but I wouldn't want them running my country."
Recent polls in Texas showed Mr. Dole had a lead so slim over Mr. Clinton that the race is considered a dead heat.
But Mr. Dole's die-hard supporters remain convinced that Texans -- both male and female -- will not be swayed by the President's charm.
"Been there," said Will Ford Hartnett, a lawyer and conservative member of the Texas Legislature. "I was the nerd. My fiancee was always attracted to smooth talkers. But the good guys always win in the end. In the end I got her. What counts is stability, loyalty, devotion, integrity. Bob Dole's going to win Texas hands down."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;
DOLE CAMP LOOKS TO COMING DEBATES AS A LAST CHANCE

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Frustrated that their candidate is still bogged in second place, Bob Dole's advisers consider the nationally televised debates that begin Sunday night as his last best chance to reverse his electoral fortunes in a campaign that President Clinton has dominated from the start.
The Dole camp is placing such importance on the first debate that it has suspended decisions about its television advertising as well as which states to pump its remaining resources into in the last four weeks. "All strategic decisions have been put on hold," said one senior Dole aide, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "Everything is on hold until after the debate." 
 But as Mr. Dole shares the stage in Hartford with Mr. Clinton in the first of two 90-minute confrontations, he faces a titanic challenge: to break through to an unusually uninterested electorate and then take the next step of persuading voters to reconsider what polls show is their predisposition to support the President. Mr. Clinton has held a double-digit lead over Mr. Dole in most polls, the type of deficit from which no candidate in the last several decades has rebounded this late in the campaign.
Another complication for Mr. Dole is that historians contend that debates have never been consequential in how people make up their minds, and polls show that this year a particularly large proportion of voters has already decided.
While Mr. Clinton was spared a primary challenger, allowing him to coast through the campaign -- he has never even formally announced his candidacy -- Mr. Dole has had a particularly hard time capturing the nation's attention. Aides close to Mr. Dole said he had been toying with the idea of a dramatic gesture: announcing during the debate that Gen. Colin L. Powell would be his choice for Secretary of State. They met for breakfast on Thursday in Washington.
Despite such possible flourishes, the debates may not generate quite the usual enormous interest -- and not only because they are competing this year with the baseball playoffs. In a nationwide poll of 1,517 registered voters by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press, only 30 percent of those surveyed said the debates would matter to them, while 65 percent said their minds were already made up. In a departure from previous elections, only 43 percent of registered voters said they were "very likely" to watch the debates; that is down from 67 percent in 1992.
Even so, Mr. Dole's advisers emphasized that the debate, with an audience estimated at 90 million people, offered Mr. Dole the first opportunity of the race to appear on an equal footing with the President, particularly now that the commission sponsoring the debates has excluded Ross Perot, the Reform Party candidate. It will be followed by another face-off in San Diego and a Vice-Presidential debate in St. Petersburg, Fla.
"From the standpoint of being able to put Bob Dole in front of 90 million or 100 million sets of eyeballs, it's very important," said Tony Fabrizio, Mr. Dole's pollster. "This is an opportunity for Dole not to be drowned out by a bombing in Iraq or a Middle East summit."
Scott Reed, Mr. Dole's campaign manager, added, "The debate is a stepping stone to winning the election."
By contrast, a certain headiness now pervades the White House. Concluding that it was all but too late for Mr. Dole to win, George Stephanopoulos, a senior adviser to Mr. Clinton, said: "It's not enough for Senator Dole to win the debate on Sunday. It's not enough for him to beat expectations. He's got to fundamentally change the nature of the race."
Even Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, said debates were not known for turning campaigns around. "I'm not a believer that debates in and of themselves change a whole lot of votes," he said. Then, searching for some hope for Mr. Dole, he went on, "But in this case, I think they probably do focus people more on the campaign than they have been."
The Dole campaign is so intent on knocking Mr. Clinton off stride that aides said they were considering what one called the "psychological warfare" of putting in the front row one or two people who would make the President uncomfortable. One possibility, according to aides, is Billy R. Dale, whom Mr. Clinton dismissed as director of the White House travel office and who now works for the Dole campaign.
For Mr. Dole, the debates open the final phase of a campaign that has become famous for its multiple starts. For months, Mr. Dole's advisers pointed to markers in the campaign that would scramble the dynamic: First they said the polls would change once he won the nomination. Then after he quit the Senate. Then after he announced his economic plan. Then after he picked Jack Kemp as his running mate. Then after the convention in San Diego.
Despite those efforts to jump-start the Dole campaign, the race has been remarkably static. The President's lead has been unchallenged in most polls for at least six months, and state surveys also show that Mr. Dole is still struggling even in states that have long been Republican strongholds, like Florida, Arizona and New Hampshire.
Mr. Dole used his weekly radio address to set the stage for the debate as well, listing many of the goals he has laid out in this campaign so far. Mr. Dole said Mr. Clinton claimed that he shared many of the same goals but in fact could not be trusted to follow through.
"You'll hear President Clinton say he wants many of these same things for our future," Mr. Dole said. "But listen carefully. If it were a contract, you'd need to read the fine print." That Mr. Dole, whose favorable rating in the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll is lower than his unfavorable rating, faces a mountainous task can be measured by the list of things his aides want the debates to accomplish. They hope that Mr. Dole will change voters' image of him, sell his tax plan and undermine Mr. Clinton's character and his record -- and do it all with a smile.
The Clinton camp has a shorter agenda: Mr. Clinton must avoid any gaffe that could jeopardize his lead, should avoid picking fights and should look Presidential. Rather than cast the election as a referendum on his leadership, Mr. Clinton is expected to invoke the Republican Congress led by Speaker Newt Gingrich, subtly suggesting that Mr. Dole is an extremist in the Gingrich mold.
Although Dole aides have been dampening expectations by portraying Mr. Clinton as far more skilled on his feet, the President may have more to lose. "The risks are all Clinton's," said Nelson Polsby, a political scientist at the University of California at Berkeley, "because everyone expects him to do extremely well."
Mr. Dole has struggled to find an issue that can take hold -- raising character questions about Mr. Clinton, promising a tax cut, promising a war on drugs and even branding the President a liberal. Now he must try to convince voters not only that the economy is in trouble, but also that he, not Mr. Clinton, could best bring it back to life.
Yet the predicament for Republicans is that with the election only four weeks from Tuesday, some prominent party members are raising the prospect that Mr. Clinton could sail to Election Day without even a tightening in the polls. Many Republicans are most concerned that even if he loses, Mr. Dole does well enough to keep Republican control of the House and Senate.
Asked about the stakes in Sunday's debate, one top Dole aide said: "I think he'll do better than expected. But is that enough?"

HEADLINE: 2 Governors Plan Cleanup For Harbor

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
In a move that could end a threat to the regional economy and quell a longstanding environmental dispute, the Governors of New York and New Jersey have agreed to clear five million tons of silt from clogged shipping channels in New York Harbor over the next 12 months and to share the burden of disposing of harbor mud that is too contaminated to be dumped in the ocean.
In an agreement to be released tomorrow, Gov. George E. Pataki and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman outline how they intend to use dredged material on land, to dispose of it safely in waters close to shore, and to develop new techniques for decontaminating the most polluted mud so that it can be turned from an environmental problem into a commodity. New Jersey officials will focus on finding ways to use the dredged material as a resource for shoreside development projects while New York looks for ways to reduce the flow of pollutants that have created the contamination problem and complicated harbor dredging. 
 Over the last three years, dredging largely ground to a halt after strict new Federal environmental standards barred mud with traces of toxic chemicals from being dumped at sea off the New Jersey Shore, as had been the norm for most of the century.
The Governors say that the agreement -- to commit up to $130 million from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for dredging in the next 12 months -- sets the stage for a long-term solution to a problem that has dogged the region, and should prevent deep-draft ships -- along with almost 170,000 jobs and $20 billion in annual economic activity -- from moving to competing ports. Representatives of port industries and shipping firms said they were cautiously optimistic that the impending move -- the first concrete pledge by the states to resume dredging after three years of environmental discord -- could preserve New York Harbor's 150-year status as the dominant East Coast seaport. With new fleets of cargo ships cutting deeper into the water even as the channels were losing depth, port officials and shipping companies said that the region stood to lose not only existing trade and jobs but also the prospect of future growth. By the turn of the century, a new generation of deeper-draft ships is expected to bring goods from Asia to the East Coast. A key goal in the effort to carve channels even deeper is to best competitors like Norfolk, Va., and Halifax, Nova Scotia, and to make New York the hub for this new trade route.
"This bistate plan is a critical step in breaking the dredging deadlock," Governor Whitman said in a statement accompanying the plan. Copies of the plan were sent by the governors' offices to several newspapers, including The New York Times.
The agreement adds new detail to commitments made by the two Governors in May, when they pledged to spend $130 million in capital funds from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on dredging but offered no specific solutions.
It also builds on a Federal plan announced in July by Vice President Al Gore, which clarified environmental testing procedures, streamlined the process by which Federal permits are issued for harbor dredging, and set a deadline for ending dumping of contaminated mud at the traditional dumping grounds, east of Sandy Hook, N.J. The sea bottom there has been stained by contamination after a century of dumping.
A firm date -- Sept. 1, 1997 -- for halting the dumping of tainted mud offshore was considered essential by private environmental groups to spur the states to find alternatives.
In essence, the states' agreement says that New York and New Jersey will share the burden of finding new repositories or uses for the millions of tons of silt that washes down the Passaic, Hudson and Raritan rivers each year and settles in the harbor's 430 miles of berths and channels.
Until now, dredged mud from every corner of the sprawling port was barged to the old site off Sandy Hook, angering coastal communities, fishermen and environmentalists who felt unfairly saddled with New York City's waste.
The backlog of contaminated mud will be distributed in different places, depending on the level of pollutants. Federal environmental officials have agreed to allow a million additional tons of lightly tainted mud to be disposed of at the old dump site before next September. Thereafter, only mud with no significant levels of pollutants will be dumped there. Environmental officials hope that the continued spreading of clean dredged material over the dump site and a 30-square-mile area around it will slowly cover past contamination.
Under the two-state agreement, heavily contaminated mud will go into submerged pits in Newark Bay, to a foundation for a shopping mall parking lot in Elizabeth, and into shoreline restoration projects and other sites that will be identified in new programs initiated by each state. Once the backlog is cleared, however, the states must find ways to deal with the three million tons of contaminated mud that accumulates each year. Although a potential threat to marine life, the tainted mud is not considered a hazard to humans, and similar dredged material has been used successfully in other parts of the country to create waterfront parks and artificial islands and to cover garbage in landfills.
Altogether, New Jersey plans to spend $65 million on a variety of dredging and disposal programs through 1997. The plan calls for increasing the use of dredged material in highway projects, finding places where the material can be used to restore shorelines, and developing new disposal methods and decontamination processes.
New York has committed the same amount of money, and will dedicate some of its portion to studies looking at how to reduce the flow of pollution into the harbor. The plan draws heavily on work done by an ad hoc task force of state and Federal officials and representatives of environmental and business groups interested in the harbor, and so is likely to generate broad support, members of the ad hoc group said.
The states are also likely to lean heavily on a large study, scheduled to be released this week, by the United States Army Corps of Engineers, which lays out an exhaustive list of dredging and disposal options and their probable costs. The Corps is responsible for issuing dredging permits and for maintaining the central group of channels around the harbor.
In an indication that the new plan is unlikely to put an end to conflict over mud, when drafts of the Corps report were circulated to groups last week, community groups and state officials quickly challenged certain options, like an artificial island that could be built in the lower harbor.
Over all, though, tomorrow's announcement by the Governors and the recent moves by the Clinton Administration have cheered the owners of port-related businesses.
"For the first time in a long time, we're optimistic," said John Holtz, a spokesman for the New Jersey Petroleum Council.
The council represents the dozens of businesses that transport billions of gallons of petroleum products in and around New York Harbor each year. Channels leading to oil terminals tucked between Staten Island and New Jersey have grown steadily shallower year after year. But in the last eight days, Exxon and Chevron went through the initial phase of the new streamlined routine for simultaneously obtaining state and Federal dredging permits, Mr. Holtz said, and company officials were pleased by the speed of the process.
It was likely that channels that have remained undredged since 1989 will be clear by next spring, Mr. Holtz said, adding: "The states and Federal agencies are cooperating. They've really demonstrated to us that they're serious about making this happen."

HEADLINE: Labor and Academia In a Campus Meeting

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The buzz was undeniably there, although no one expected it to be.
It was a standing-room-only crowd. Another 500 people were packed into nearby rooms to watch on closed-circuit television. And outside stretched a 200-yard-long line of people who were turned away. 
 It was not a Mike Tyson fight. Nor was it the latest Pearl Jam concert. The crowd was there for a panel discussion with professors of philosophy, law and religion, a feminist author and a labor leader.
Far exceeding the organizers' expectations, some 1,700 people thronged to an auditorium at Columbia University on Thursday night for the Fight for America's Future, billed as "a teach-in with the labor movement." With an electricity that was rare for both labor and academic events, there were repeated standing ovations for the speakers, who included Cornel West, the Harvard professor of religion and Afro-American studies, and John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president.
Speaking under the rotunda of Low Library, Betty Friedan, the feminist author, said: "I have a pretty good historical Geiger counter. Thirty years ago, my Geiger counter was clicking about the beginning of the women's movement. My historic Geiger counter is clicking again."
The Columbia teach-in was the flagship of 10 such events scheduled around the nation this month, at sites including Eastern Illinois University, the University of Texas at El Paso, and Wayne State University in Detroit. The events -- modeled and named after antiwar conferences of the Vietnam War era -- are being organized by various groups of academics, not only to renew ties with unions but also to teach students more about the labor movement and to get more students and professors to devote their intellectual energies to helping working Americans.
The organizers are hoping to re-establish the labor-intellectual partnership that was a powerful force from the Progressive Era until the early 1960's. That alliance broke down as union leaders grew angry with liberal academics for opposing the Vietnam War, while left-leaning intellectuals soured on the A.F.L.-C.I.O., seeing it as tradition-bound and preoccupied with the cold war.
Academics now say it is time to renew the alliance because the labor movement is on the rebound and American workers are feeling squeezed.
Thursday night and again on Friday at Columbia, the labor leaders reveled in the unaccustomed glow of academic chic, while intellectuals appeared delighted to hold labor's muscled hand and feel relevant.
Nelson Lichtenstein, a University of Virginia historian and a co-chairman of the event, said: "We have hit a moment when class questions are back at the center of American social and political concerns. That's why all these people are here."
At the main panel discussion on Friday morning, held at Columbia's School of International Affairs, the crowd included undergraduates, professors, retired unionists and dozens of middle-level union officials.
Stirred by the crowd, Mr. Sweeney asked labor's new partners to use their brainpower -- to write books and articles, give speeches and do research for organizing drives -- to back union efforts to lift wages and give workers more say.
"We need your help in making basic economic education available and accessible to every American, so everyone can understand what is happening to their family budget and who is doing it to them," Mr. Sweeney said. "We need your help in telling millions of unrepresented workers that while it takes a village to raise a child, it takes a union to get a raise."
The teach-in did feature one obligatory nod to academic traditions: infighting. Orlando Patterson, a Harvard sociologist, was booed by many people in the audience when he said the left should support tougher immigration rules because immigrants were undercutting workers' wages.
Richard Rorty, a University of Virginia philosopher, was attacked for suggesting that New Left activists were responsible for creating the rift between intellectuals and labor when they spat at Vietnam veterans and burned flags.
And Katha Pollitt, the poet and essayist, angered some A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials by asserting that the labor movement did not oppose the new welfare law vigorously enough and had isolated itself by fighting primarily to help union members, instead of all workers.
Sarah Kendzior, a Sarah Lawrence freshman attending the conference, said, "I don't understand how these people can unify when they keep disagreeing among themselves."
But other students -- like Michelle Sieff, a graduate student in political science at Columbia -- found a heartwarming, if old-fashioned, sense of solidarity.
"It's been very inspiring to see labor back on American campuses," she said. "Students are reaching for something right now. There's a lot of apathy, as we all know, but there's a desire to find an alternative to the M.B.A.-law school track of life."

HEADLINE: For Poor, Life 'Trapped in a Cage'

SERIES: BARELY FOUR WALLS: Housing's Hidden Crisis -- First of six articles.

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG; Jane H. Lii contributed to this article.

 BODY:
On a corner of Clinton near Delancey, up a narrow stairway between a pawnshop and a Dominican restaurant, Ana Nunez and her three children live in a single, illegal room that suffocates their dreams of a future.
It is a $350-a-month rectangle, with no sink and no toilet, that throbs at night with the restaurant's merengue music. Ms. Nunez's teen-agers, Kenny and Wanda, split a bunk bed, while she squeezes onto a single bed with little Katarin, a pudgy 4-year-old with tight braids. Out the door and down the linoleum-lined hallway is the tiny bathroom they share with five strangers. 
 In this cramped room on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, the Nunezes suffer the consequences of their poverty in ways that eerily recall the pathologies of turn-of-the-century tenements. Last winter, tuberculosis traveled from Kenny to his mother and younger sisters in a chain of infection as inevitable as their bickering. Inevitable, too, is their fear of fire: life in 120 square feet means the gas stove must stand perilously close to their beds.
This so-called apartment, this life, preys on them all, but most of all on Kenny, who, at 18, is a restless young man in a female household. Ask him what bothers him most and he flatly states that he has only one way to get some privacy: "I close my eyes." Partly because he had nowhere to study, much less to think, Kenny dropped out of school last year, a fact that his mother found herself too depressed to lament. She changed the subject instead.
"At night," she said, "when the mice crawl over us in bed, it feels even more crowded."
Across the city, tens, perhaps hundreds of thousands of poor families like the Nunezes live in miserable, crowded conditions from which they can see no way out. But they suffer privately, captives of a hidden housing crisis that has been masked for years by the more public crisis of homelessness.
These families live in a growing network of illegal homes: stacked like firewood in Chinatown; wedged into coffin-sized cubicles in Washington Heights; even tucked away in the basements and attics of the leafier reaches of Queens, where private homes have been sliced and diced. They also live in perfectly legal rentals, crowded together in overextended families: in the aging brownstones of East Harlem and the decaying tenements of Bushwick, Brooklyn; under puckered ceilings in Mott Haven, the Bronx, and up sloping stairways in the Rockaways.
Compared with outright homelessness, even their bad housing has come to seem acceptable in a new urban calculus that finds something to be better than nothing. Well aware of the crisis, the Federal, state and city governments are nonetheless stepping away from it; their commitment to providing and maintaining housing for the poor slips by the year.
Emblematic, perhaps, of New York City's shifting priority is its deployment of municipal employees: for almost every housing inspector charged with keeping the city's 140,000 apartment buildings livable and safe, there is a city counselor devoted to the new task of "homeless diversion."
Despite city laws that explicitly outlaw crowding, homeless-diversion workers routinely urge the poor to double and triple up with other families -- if that is what it takes to keep them out of the homeless shelters, the only real gateway to the exhausted supply of public housing.
"Sometimes, you're talking three, four generations in a studio," said Beatrice Adams, who trains homeless-diversion workers for the city. "But it's better than in the shelter. That's our position."
It is a position that subverts the very premise of the housing reform movement begun more than 100 years ago by the Danish-immigrant photojournalist Jacob A. Riis. With haunting photos, Riis's crusade provoked a great outcry that led to a stringent system of codes to protect a poor tenant's claim to a safe and decent home.
Yet more than a century later, in a city that blatantly defies those very codes, the Nunezes inhabit just the kind of claustrophobic quarters that Riis sought to eliminate. Like so many others, they are the all-but-homeless, enduring their homes because they have nowhere else to go.
"We're trapped in a cage," said Ms. Nunez, a United States citizen born in the Dominican Republic.
Precisely how many such tenants there are cannot be known. But these poorest of the city's families are being squeezed between a powerful combination of changing demographics and economics: since the early 1980's, the city's stock of inexpensive apartments has withered away just as the demand has mushroomed with deepening poverty and a vast influx of immigrants.
An ambitious, decadelong program started by former Mayor Edward I. Koch created 40,000 apartments for the poor and working class, but it ultimately made only a dent, albeit a significant one, in the problem.
Almost inevitably, the growing demand spawned the network of illegal homes, and taxed the shrinking, already decaying supply of legal rentals. At the same time, the city all but abandoned strict enforcement of housing laws, allowing the illegal market to flourish and leaving legal tenants to fend for themselves.
"The reality is that if you are poor in a fast, cold city like this, they don't care how you live so long as you are not out on the streets worrying people," said Maria Pagan, 83, a retired school cafeteria worker who lived for a decade in a city-owned building in Bushwick that was crumbling around her, with a wooden brace supporting its foundation and outside walls so unsteady they could be shaken like loose teeth.
In a busy city that accepts hardships as a given, glimpses into Miss Pagan's world occur only rarely -- when smoke fills a lower Manhattan basement, rousting a dozen Chinese men; when a building collapses in Harlem, killing three; when fire fatally traps a young family in an illegal attic home in South Jamaica, Queens.
Except on these very worst of days, their crisis remains behind closed doors.
"It's our city's dirty little secret, because people don't have to face it," said Scott Sommer, chairman of the Metropolitan Council on Housing, a tenant-rights group.
Over the last 10 months, reporters for The New York Times visited at least 200 poor households in a sorry panoply of living spaces, from storage sheds and storefronts to basements, triple-decker bunkrooms and apartments that are simply falling apart.
As expected, the reporters found illegal immigrants in some of the makeshift homes. But many of the worst apartments were filled with considerably more established New Yorkers, foreign- and native-born Americans alike, people working menial jobs as well as those on welfare, young mothers and elderly widows and single men battling mental illness or addiction. And most have spent their adult lives -- lives increasingly without options, lives often without heat -- on stale waiting lists for government housing assistance.
And so they spend winters shivering, windows smothered in blankets, ovens on broil.
Or they bed down in illegal basements with nothing but plywood between their mattresses and the sibilance of boilers.
Or they share beds with their children, bedrooms with their in-laws and bathrooms with strangers.
They confront frightening dilapidation: leaks that eat at their ceilings and rot their floors, rusted fire escapes and rollercoaster stairways, sometimes with steps so corroded that tenants adopt idiosyncratic safety measures: Martinez Tyson in East Harlem, for one, keeps a rope under his bed, preparing for the day when he will have no way out but a window with no fire escape.
And they endure vile infestation -- rats gobble their garbage and nibble their slippers, and, in one horrifying case in Bushwick, cockroaches have laid eggs inside the noses of Wanda Carrero's children.
"When I see the density and conditions in which people live," said Richard Plunz, a Columbia University professor and author of the definitive "History of Housing in New York" (Columbia University Press), "I have to wonder just what Jacob Riis and the housing reformers would say if they wandered into the New York of today."
Since Riis's day, of course, there have been some very basic improvements, like plumbing and electrification -- although plenty of apartments still lack the rudimentary amenities, like fire escapes and hot running water, mandated by early-20th-century housing laws.
And compared with just 25 years ago, the very worst conditions seem to have improved: far fewer people are known to live in buildings considered so unsafe and unfit for habitation that they endanger lives -- although, by the city's latest housing survey, more than 60,000 people still do.
"In aggregate, if you take a rock-bottom criterion, there has been some general improvement in the city's housing stock over the last 25 years," said Victor Bach, director of housing policy and research for the Community Service Society, an antipoverty organization. "But in the hardest-hit neighborhoods, by the city's own measure, there are increasing numbers of deficiencies. Conditions are not good."
In poor neighborhoods, tenants and landlords have always been locked in a tenuous relationship, dependent on the buildings that no one else wants to live in or own. But now, as expenses for landlords are rising and tenants' incomes are falling, the dynamic is particularly unhealthy. When rents cannot be met consistently, even the best-intentioned landlords cannot afford to maintain their properties. So they let them deteriorate, or simply walk away, leaving the tenants' fate in the hands of government.
But the government is pulling back. The Koch building program has no successor; fewer apartments are being created even for the homeless.
"We're at the point where we cannot afford to make a massive investment in a continuous way," said Lilliam Barrios-Paoli, the city's Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development since April. "Not that the need is not there. There are a substantial number of people living in sub-substandard housing. But we have to figure out how to motivate the private sector."
Private landlords of low-income housing, however, have always relied on government assistance. And there have already been and will continue to be cuts in the welfare payments and rental subsidies that keep poor buildings afloat.
Poor tenants have always depended on the city to regulate private landlords. But the city's housing regulatory system has shrunk into what can seem like a parody of its noble intentions; the slashed force of housing inspectors responds only to emergency complaints, and even then, does so little follow-up that many landlords feel free either to ignore their orders or to lie to the city about repairs never made.
"It seems that we have almost given up the concept of preserving the housing stock in this city through code enforcement," said Joseph M. Corso, president of Local 211 of the Allied Building Inspectors union. "Maybe that's because it's so easy to forget what's really happening inside private buildings until they fall down or burst into fire and somebody dies."
Yet, the city's own apartment buildings -- thousands of them, taken from deadbeat landlords -- are in the worst repair of all; many experts see this as emblematic of a failure of municipal will on the entire issue of low-income housing.
A basic tenet of Riis and the housing reformers was that insuring decent housing was a prerequisite for a humane society -- that the public conscience would not tolerate the kind of conditions he had documented.
But while this century began with the optimism that bad living conditions could be reformed out of existence, it is ending with a tacit official acceptance that any home is preferable to no home at all.
 
The Housing Ladder
On the Lowest Rungs, The Most Hope
Think of low-income housing as a ladder, with the meanest dwelling -- the cellar cubicle, the mattress on the dormitory floor -- at the bottom and public housing at the top. But it is a treacherous ladder, with a built-in paradox: it is often those on the lowest rung who feel the least trapped.
Take L. Ping, 21, whose small tenement apartment on Elizabeth Street resembles a beached submarine, lined with stacks of the hand-sawed bunk beds that many recent Chinese immigrants call home.
When he returns late at night from his job as a restaurant cashier, he eases off his shoes and climbs into his allotted space. He often takes out a knife and whittles flowers from potatoes, practicing to be a chef. Or he hunches over a small notebook, composing Chinese aphorisms that are a kind of mantra for survival: "As long as you are courageous and hold your head up high," he writes, "bitter juice will turn into sweet wine."
Like Mr. Ping or H.D. Zheng, who lives in yet another Lower East Side bunkroom, many of the worst-off tenants are recent immigrants. Eking out an existence on the absolute edge of society, confident that their only path can be up, they festoon their wretched spaces with plastic flowers or scrub them to a patina of decency.
Three years after arriving in this country from the coastal province of Fujian, Mr. Zheng, 35, is still working off a $30,000 debt to the smugglers who secured him passage on a series of ships. He can devote very little of his meager busboy's salary to rent, so he has 11 roommates. They share a studio bracketed by triple-tiered bunk beds, with a narrow passage like a gangplank between them. One bachelor household among two dozen others in a complex of three low-rise buildings on Allen Street, they split a rent of $650 a month, paying about $54 each.
Like the others, Mr. Zheng keeps his scant belongings in a plastic bag above his mattress, nailed beside the herbal-medicine pouches and girlie pictures that decorate his rectangle of wall. And like them, he curls into his allotted space without grumbling -- except, perhaps, for one small complaint.
"Fujianese girls in America are very materialistic," he says. "The first question they ask is, 'Do you have your own apartment?' and if you don't, they won't look at you."
Still, Mr. Zheng says, he knows from the example of more-established immigrants that he will not have to live forever in a communal home bereft of any grace or privacy. Now, he may have to share his nightly dinner of rice gruel and mustard greens with a pack of relative strangers, their tiny television tuned to an Italian soap opera as incomprehensible as anything on English-language television. But soon, he feels certain, he will have a room of his own, however small or dismal, in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, say, or Flushing, Queens.
Jose Moreno Reyes, a Harlem resident born in the Dominican Republic, once knew that kind of faith. But like other more-established immigrants, he took that first step toward a higher standard of living too long ago to appreciate it any more.
Now, he is an American citizen, with a long work history at a clothing factory in New Jersey. But that doesn't buy him any better than a rotten apartment at the top of a rickety stairway in an aging brownstone that lists to one side. "The building is bad," he said. "The building is broken."
When Mr. Reyes, who is 58, came to New York 13 years ago, he slept on his brother's couch until he found a good job packing clothes at a factory. Then he moved into the tiny two-room apartment in Harlem, expecting it to be a stepping stone.
Over the years, as three of his children joined him there, the building deteriorated, and by the time his wife and youngest son immigrated last spring, they were so ashamed of where they lived that they did not even throw a party to celebrate their reunion.
Not that there would have been room for one -- although, they point out, the place feels a lot roomier during the evening, when everyone is sitting up, than at night, when everyone is stretched out.
Mr. Reyes's oldest children -- Belta and Manuel, both 24, and Eduardo, 22 -- sleep head to toe in the bedroom, which measures 7 by 14 feet. Through a doorway covered only by a bedsheet, in a living room that is 9 by 10 feet, Mr. and Mrs. Reyes squeeze onto a cot that is flush against the sofa where their 20-year-old son, Carlos, spends the night.
A wire, draped with clothes, traverses the rooms -- a closet on a rope. The communal kitchen, which has no ceiling and a corroded linoleum floor, and bathroom are out in the hall. The apartment is infested with vermin and littered with sticky traps. "We live like animals," he said. "The rats crawl over us, and roaches fall in our cooking pots."
Mr. Reyes said he had repeatedly asked for the city to send a housing inspector to his building, but no one had ever come. It wasn't that he actually believed they might make repairs, he said, but he wanted a written report that might persuade the Housing Authority to give him some kind of priority for public housing.
"It is immoral for the city to ignore us," he said. "We've got one foot in the streets, and the other in this tinderbox."
Constantly looking for a new apartment, he never finds anything better at the same rent: $400 a month. Too many buildings have drug problems, which he will not tolerate, or demand security deposits he cannot afford. Dozens of times, he says, he has greased the palms of superintendents with an illegal $50 fee just to see apartments no bigger or better than his own -- and more expensive.
Jeanette Rowe thought she had taken a step up when she moved with her five young children, ages 2 to 13, from an illegal room to an illegal cellar apartment in Laurelton, Queens. Ms. Rowe, a native of Queens who depends on welfare but has a high school diploma and swears she will get a job once her youngest child is in school, had no idea there was such a thing as an illegal home. "So many folks live in basements around here," she said.
Even with the half-windows painted shut, her cellar home seemed spaciously luxurious -- until the leaks began and the appliances gave way. Then, because she withheld her $550-a-month rent when her demands for repairs went unmet, Ms. Rowe found herself facing eviction from a home that wasn't legal or fire-safe -- but was better than nothing. "My main concern is for the children to have somewhere to stay, if it's a cellar or an attic or what," said Ms. Rowe, who ended up voluntarily leaving the cellar at the end of June to double up with a friend's family as she figured out what to do next.
In Bushwick, Miss Pagan, who retired from the cafeteria at Public School 124 in the Bronx after 26 years as a school employee, was too old and infirm to search for another apartment herself. She just kept waiting for help from her landlord, because her landlord was the city, and the city kept promising to help, especially during the year and a half after her ceiling collapsed.
"I was doing the dishes when it fell like in an earthquake," she said. "I ran, and thanks to God I wasn't hurt."
The city did erect makeshift beams to hold up a temporary plywood ceiling in her kitchen, but left uncovered the gaping holes in her bathroom, with its exposed heating pipes and wires and a clear view of the rotting floorboards above. Because the bathroom sink did not work, Miss Pagan had to scoop water from her toilet to wash her hands and brush her teeth, bending slowly in her floral house dress and pink slippers.
As a sign, perhaps, of where she was placing her hopes, Miss Pagan had hung a plaque on her living-room wall. "God Bless This Home," it read.
"It's not so bad here," Miss Pagan said in February. "At least there is good steam." The next month, the boiler died, and there was no heat at all for the rest of the winter.
Occasionally, her upstairs neighbor, Carmen Torres, checked in on her. But Ms. Torres, a 46-year-old grandmother who lived with her mentally incapacitated daughter and five grandchildren, including a 9-month-old infant, had problems enough of her own.
In the spring, Mrs. Torres said: "Some days I wake up and wonder how exactly we'll all die. Will we fall to our deaths when the floor gives way, or be crushed when the ceiling falls, or die in a fire because we can't make it out our broken window?"
 
A New York Problem
Issues and Answers All Start in the City
Birthplace of both the American tenement and public housing, New York has always been home to the nation's most severe housing problems and to some of its most creative solutions. And while the shortage of affordable housing is a national problem, New York remains at the heart of the nation's housing story.
According to the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, more Americans -- 5.3 million -- have "severe housing crises" now than at any point in the last 20 years, when the Government began measuring. But the New York metropolitan area has the greatest number of households with what are known as worst-case needs -- that is, those paying more than half their incomes for rent or living in substandard conditions or both, according to HUD.
And those needs have been growing, largely because of rising rents, falling incomes, gentrification and the persistent abandonment of buildings in low-income neighborhoods, many of them overleveraged during the speculation of the 80's. Further, among old American cities with an aging housing stock, New York is one of the very few that is gaining population.
According to the most recent city housing survey, the number of apartments renting for $450 a month or less fell 40 percent between 1981 and 1993. And the vacancy rate was near zero for the very cheapest apartments -- those going for $300 a month, barely affordable to families dependent on menial jobs or on welfare, with its average monthly shelter allowance of $286.
Over that same decade, the 40,000 new apartments of Mr. Koch's more than $4 billion housing program revitalized patches of devastated neighborhoods throughout the city, especially in the South Bronx. But housing analysts say around 300,000 more low-income homes are needed.
And the poorest of New York's tenants are growing more impoverished as they struggle to pay the rent.
Anthony Blackburn, a consultant who analyzed data for the city in its most recent housing survey, found a crisis that had grown "more, not less, severe" over the previous decade for almost half the city's tenants. The poorest fifth, he found, now spend 80 percent of their incomes on rent, compared with 60 percent a decade ago.
For most of the city's poor people, public housing remains the hope -- the grail. But the waiting lists for housing assistance -- both public housing and rental vouchers -- are the longest in history, with 336,000 families. Late last year, for the first time ever, the Housing Authority closed the door on new applicants for Section 8 rent subsidies, the sole Government program to help poor people pay rent in private apartments, after calculating that it would take six years to interview all who had already applied.
All of which adds up to this startling statistic: While more than half of New York City's renters are poor enough to qualify for Federal housing assistance, most do not receive it; many do not even apply.
So for now their only option is to rent private housing in a famously expensive market where affluent people battle for the right to pay $3,500 a month for a two-bedroom flat with "original plumbing."
And that option is circumscribed.
"People who are poor are significantly poorer than a decade ago. So what do they do?" said Liz Krueger, associate director of Community Food Resources, a nonprofit group that helps poor people. "They punt, and one of the most obvious ways is to move down the food chain for housing."
 
One Building's Tale
Model Apartments Fall Into Squalor
Almost building by building, the city's current housing crisis echoes with history, with hopes dashed and lessons learned. On the Lower East Side, 211 Madison Street is a case in point.
In 1887, three years before Riis published his landmark book, "How the Other Half Lives," a picture framer named Henry Waters built a squat brick apartment house there and named it the Henrietta. Its five solid stories, a $19,000 investment, seemed a clear aspiration to a decent future amid the neighborhood's rookeries.
By 1905, Mr. Waters had filled his 22 apartments with 107 immigrants, mostly Russian Jews, according to the handwritten census taken then. Louis Becker, a painter, lived there with his wife and five children, and Sarah Horowitz, a bookkeeper, with her parents. With their neighbors -- a cigar maker, an ice cream maker, a presser, a folder, a milliner and a corset maker -- they made a portrait in miniature of the turn-of-the-century Lower East Side.
Today, 211 Madison Street is a rundown relic that long ago abandoned its role as a model of decent housing. Its residents are late-20th-century equivalents of those Russian Jews: Chinese immigrants who work in garment factories and return home, variously, to filth, broken windows, leaking ceilings, peeling lead paint, blocked fire exits and "hot" water of 52 degrees. The superintendent, Luis Gonzalez, collects and redeems cans to buy light bulbs for the hallways.
On the first floor of 211 Madison, an elderly couple -- Deng Peiwen, a retired garment worker, and her husband, Ting Dong Huang, a retired dishwasher -- taped garbage bags over their windows to keep out the winter cold, and hammered wooden planks over rat holes in their sinking floor. Tired of complaining without results and too old to consider moving, they finally asked their son to take on the landlord's responsibilities for repairs, glumly accepting an idea that many of their neighbors share: that an affordable apartment is in itself a kind of gift from the landlord, who can be asked for nothing more.
The owner of 211 Madison Street, Kai H. Lo, stands out as a landlord so negligent that the city has devoted scarce resources to pursuing him. But it has been a frustrating legal battle, never finished. The building has racked up 752 violations; Mr. Lo has paid the city $45,000 in fines over the last decade.
But he owes $47,000 for repairs the city has made on the building, and for unpaid taxes and water bills. And as he corrects some violations, Mr. Lo accumulates new ones.
In 1989, for instance, city officials ordered him to remove the tenants living illegally in cubicles in his basement; in 1991, they issued the same order; and in 1994, they cited him six more times for renting out basement space. Yet when a small fire broke out in the building last year, firefighters found 15 immigrants living in the basement.
Last spring, after many tenants had been on a rent strike for months, Mr. Lo made enough repairs that the city considered 86 violations corrected when it inspected in late June. But as of Friday, he had 157 violations outstanding, many new. Mr. Lo has not returned telephone calls seeking comment.
"He is a real problem," said Mari Carlesimo, an assistant housing commissioner. "Kai Lo needs the constant pressure of litigation to force him to tend to his buildings, but the problems never stop appearing.
"Sometimes you wonder, are you just going through an awful lot of effort to end up back in the same place?"
 
Revisiting History
Is Any Housing Better Than None?
Tenants in the Bushwick tenement of Miss Pagan say their landlord, the city, told them it would not fumigate their building because it was not worth even that expense. Still, that did not mean the city could provide them with anything better, the tenants say they were told. "We were supposed to feel lucky," Mrs. Torres said. "We weren't homeless."
That has become the official bottom line for city officials dealing with the poor: To eliminate crowded and illegal housing would ultimately mean condemning thousands to the streets or the filled shelters.
When Riis exposed the squalor of the slums, the dilemma was the same. In 1894, American Architect magazine wrote, "If the tenants are ordered out of houses unfit for habitation, they have no other place to go."
Riis and the housing reformers, though, saw that as a false choice. And so, even as their work displaced thousands, they gave birth to a movement that led to the demolition or improvement of tenements, to stringent codes that regulated everything from ventilation to space per person, and, eventually, to public and subsidized housing.
Over the next century, however, those gains were repeatedly lost during economic declines and political changes in a city that never made poor tenants a priority for long.
During and after World War I, for instance, the tenements boarded up in the heyday of the reform movement were reopened to ease a severe housing shortage. And they quickly became overcrowded. But while this time they were clearly illegal, the city considered it impractical to enforce the law. Besides, for fiscal reasons, the city had cut the number of inspectors by half.
Many political mood swings later, by the start of the 1990's, the city seemed again to have lost its sense of mission about insuring decent housing for all. Not only was the housing-inspection force a shadow of its former self, but Housing Court, created amid idealistic rhetoric in 1973 to enforce the housing maintenance code, had devolved into a kind of collection agency for rents.
By the time Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took office in 1994, even public housing was at least 25 percent above capacity, in violation of Federal regulations. And the city was too busy focusing on housing crises -- people already homeless and buildings already falling apart -- to think about preventing them.
"The way I see it our city's attitude toward housing boils down to this: Instead of doing primary care, we only do emergency-room stuff," said Ms. Krueger of Community Food Resources.
Some housing experts believe that government intervention has not worked, and that the real estate market should be left to regulate itself. Indeed, a battle to weaken, if not abolish, rent controls is expected when they expire next year. But most experts agree that decent low-income housing requires strong government involvement: a combination of direct investment, subsidies to landlords and stringent oversight.
In an era of fiscal restraint and retrenchment in social welfare policy, though, the government's goal is to minimize its role.
Starting last summer, for instance, the Giuliani administration decided that families living doubled up with other families would be ineligible for beds in city shelters.
And like its predecessors, the administration contends that it is not the city's role to act as landlord of last resort to the city's poorest tenants. So the city has not only stopped foreclosing on properties in tax arrears but has started trying to return its vast inventory of rundown buildings to the private sector. Although many tenant advocates criticize this move because they expect that a cycle of investment and abandonment cannot help but repeat itself, city officials discount their criticism, reminding them that the city has been a terrible landlord.
"It's inexcusable that, as a landlord of last resort, we run poor buildings," Ms. Barrios-Paoli, the Housing Commissioner, said. "That's why we shouldn't be in the business."
Back at the turn of the century, the health of the slums was seen to impinge directly on the health of the city; to regulate housing for the poor was to inoculate the city at large against the physical and social ills believed to breed in their homes.
"Preventing fire and contagion, that's what urban housing policies were all about, and I think we've forgotten that," said Dr. Ernest Drucker, a professor of epidemiology at Albert Einstein Medical College, who has studied the link between crowded living and childhood tuberculosis in the Bronx. There, he has found, both have returned to the peak levels of the Great Depression.
At 84, Jane Benedict is the doyenne of the housing reform movement, the retired chairwoman of the Metropolitan Council on Housing. She says it has always been "clear as bells" to her that housing reform was not just a liberal impulse but an investment in the common cause. But now, she wearily concludes that others either do not see this as clearly or do not care.
"I think this is the lowest point I've seen," she said. "The politicians don't even care about the homeless anymore, so how are they going to begin to care about the way people live?"
 
When Officials Act
Help Comes Slowly, If It Comes at All
City officials knew Ana Nunez was living in extremely overcrowded conditions; she was certified as a top priority for public housing four years ago. And they knew Maria Pagan was living in a dilapidated building with collapsed ceilings; the city owned it.
But each woman had a roof, if not a ceiling, over her head, and so neither was considered officially in crisis.
Weeks after a Times reporter described the condition of Miss Pagan's building to a spokeswoman for the Housing Preservation and Development Department, the tenants were moved. They were told, they said, that the move was urgent, that their 76-year-old building, with the wooden brace supporting its foundation, was unstable. "It was very confusing," Miss Pagan said. "They put me off for years, and suddenly they decided my situation was an emergency."
The housing agency did not grant interviews with the building's managers, who would not speak without approval. In a written response, the agency said the building was "temporarily closed in order to perform systems replacement work."
After a reporter described Miss Pagan's living conditions, however, Commissioner Barrios-Paoli said: "God knows no one should live in buildings like that. Her manager should have closed that building before you brought it to our attention."
Miss Pagan is now living in another city-owned building in Bushwick. "I can only thank God that I have a new home for my remaining years," she said.
On Clinton Street, above the pawnshop and the Dominican restaurant, Ms. Nunez's room is an illegal living space in a two-story building that was once solely commercial and is now certified to have two full apartments with complete bathrooms and kitchens. It is, effectively, an illegal single-room occupancy that violates the most basic size and occupancy rules for S.R.O.'s: children are not allowed and no more than two people should be housed in no less than 140 square feet.
Still, Ms. Nunez's home is not hidden from the authorities. School counselors have visited, lamenting quarters so close that they seemed to explain Wanda's troubles in school. When Kenny had tuberculosis, Ms. Nunez told his social worker that she thought their small room was a breeding ground for germs; the social worker said housing was not her responsibility. And welfare officials even send Ms. Nunez's shelter allowance -- $312 a month -- directly to her landlord.
Through the years, Ms. Nunez has felt indebted to her landlord, who first rented the room just to her. After she brought her older children from the Dominican Republic and gave birth to a third, he told her it was not legal or safe to stay, but he did not kick her out. He even installed the gas stove, and divided the room with a partition.
"I kept telling her the apartment was too small for all of them," the landlord, Henry Hallivis, said. "First there was one, then three, then four. Oh, my God, a baby in there. And then the tuberculosis! It was a disaster.
"But she kept saying she would get into the projects. The projects, the projects. Tomorrow, she'd say. Always tomorrow."
An inspector from the Buildings Department showed up in June, but the landlord need not have worried: The inspector's visit was indirectly prompted by a reporter's inquiry to the housing agency, which, believing the building to be simply a commercial one, filed a complaint with Buildings, urging an investigation of its illegal use as a residence.
Somehow, the housing agency's complaint was miscommunicated or misunderstood: the inspector was instructed to look for "an illegal commercial use." He found none.
And, not knowing there was any reason to search further, he never climbed the steps to the second floor, where Ms. Nunez, Kenny, Wanda and Katarin feel as if the walls are closing in on them.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Cyber-Retailers Hitting the Web For Wider Markets

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
THE doors of the Cyberian Outpost computer supply outlet in Kent have been locked for months now. The storefront scene is one all too familiar in Connecticut: Yellowing display posters, dusty windows, a floor strewn with boxes.
Yet the reasons for the store's closing are not the usual ones, like minuscule clientele or through-the-roof rents. Neither was competition; the Cyberian Outpost was the only computer store of its kind for miles around. Rather, Darryl Peck, the owner, shut it up because "it didn't make sense," he said. "If we did $400 of business a day down here, we'd do that in 12 seconds upstairs." 
 Upstairs, in a section of somewhat sparse-looking offices in the Kent Town Center's second floor, is where Cyberian Outpost has made its name. Mr. Peck says 7,000 people visit each day, though one wouldn't bump into any of them on the way to the water cooler. That's because all the shopping is done on-line, via the World Wide Web.
Cyberian Outpost began life only last year, in a 500-square-foot combination warehouse and office in Mr. Peck's hometown of Sharon. The idea of establishing a computer store accessible only via the Internet came to Mr. Peck, then an out-of-work software company executive, when he spent some of his new downtime surfing the World Wide Web, a multimedia avenue of the Internet.
"I immediately thought, 'This is what I must do with my life,' " he said. "Clearly there was a living to be made off the Web. The question is how to do that."
With Cyberian Outpost, he believes he has found the answer. After clicking onto its web-site address (http:// www.cybout.com), the viewer arrives at a brightly colored home page display menu. Viewers can select what kinds of computer products they want and whether they want them in Macintosh or IBM-PC format. There is even a parade of flags from almost a dozen different countries; click on one and the text will be re-rendered in that language.
Clicking a particular item will call up a description and often a photograph of a product. To order, tap a display with the cursor arrow. Because many customers are leery of giving credit card numbers over the Internet, a telephone number for that purpose is provided.
Mr. Peck says that Cyberian Outpost has been doubling its business every 90 days, and is within range of becoming a $20 million company by the end of the year. Also doubling will be the staff, with some 25 new employees anticipated in time for the holidays. That is a long way from Cyberian Outpost's beginnings in early 1995, when it was started with only $28,000 and two staffers: Mr. Peck and a sales director.
Because it is not a store, there is no need to hire clerks or rent prime commercial space. Because it is not a typical mail-order operation, there is no need to print or ship thousands of catalogues several times a year to potential customers. And the ability to change or update the Web site to account for new products or prices is instantaneous. Mr. Peck estimated that Cyberian Outpost makes 500 such changes each day.
"In all due modesty, we have been by far the most successful retail venture ever to open on the Internet," he said. "We know we're onto a good thing here."
When it comes to the advantages of getting on the Web, many Connecticut-based businesses would seem to agree. According to a Connecticut Business and Industry Association report released in September, a third of employees at small and mid-sized businesses in the state use the Internet regularly, up from 14 percent in 1995. And 15 percent of small businesses now have a Web site. "We pretty much had a doubling of use of the net by small business," said Kim Trumbore, a C.B.I.A. analyst. "The results also represent how quickly small and mid-sized businesses have been accessing technology. They need to adapt to change to stay competitive."
The Internet isn't just for computer people. Evelyn Siefert Kennedy owns a textile restoration and appraisal firm in Groton called Sew tique. Late last year, she decided to put up a home page, hiring an independent contractor to design it.
"We're averaging six hits a day," she said, meaning visitors to the Web site. If that translates into just one contract a month, it's no small thing. A single job of making a wedding dress or repairing a quilt is rewarding enough, and there is the ancillary benefit of getting the store's name out to a very wide audience indeed. Ms. Kennedy noted Sewtique has attracted clients from as far away as Australia by virtue of the site.
The Sewtique web site (http:// members.aol.com/sewtique) is not nearly as flashy as Cyberian Outpost, but it has its own charm. A photograph of the shop is displayed, and buttons below invite the browser to choose from a slew of possible services.
When it comes to wiring up small businesses to the Internet, Bryan Adams likes to think he has the market cornered. That is because Mr. Adams is owner of WebToad Advertising, a Hartford-based firm that produces, among other services, the Hartford Index. An on-line directory, the Hartford Index (http://webtoad.com) provides listings for some 200 businesses in the Hartford area. A key element is that it only lists companies within driving range of the city, in order to boost its local appeal.
So far, results are mixed. The Hartford Index lists addresses and telephone numbers free of charge, hoping to earn its revenue through specialized services like graphic displays and Web sites that can be accessed through Hypertext Multi-Link formatting.
Campus Pizza, for example, has a display window that includes a handy pull-out directional map. So far, only a few companies have opted to do this.
"We have built a good engine, but unless the word gets out, we're not going to be able to develop it," Mr. Adams said. "The problem is it's hard to explain just what on earth it is we're talking about."
Many note the concept of the Internet is still fairly young. "We're really still in the build-out or novelty phase," said Bob Allen, a managing partner at Modem Media LP in Westport. "The real growth is two to three, even five years ahead of us."
Modem Media, which was started the day the stock market crashed in 1987, a pioneer in setting up Web pages for corporate clients like AT&T and Delta Airlines, now employs 140 people.
New operations are sprouting up regularly in the state, like the Women's Global Business Alliance, LLC, a for-profit operation based in Westport that will offer a Web-based list of contacts and advice for female corporate executives when it makes its debut in November.
The Alliance web site will offer browsers free access "to a certain level," and then provide a members-only station, according to an Alliance founder, Deborah Polydys. "Globally, the women's market is ready to explode," she added.
While Ms. Polydys notes surveys that say men are more likely to surf the net than women are, Ms. Polydys takes heart in another survey result showing that women are more likely to linger at a particular site.
"Technology is a way to even the playing field," she said. "We're looking to be The Wall Street Journal for women."
Can the Internet be the mechanism by which Connecticut finally emerges from its economic doldrums? Can it be to the 21st century what the telephone has been to this one? There are skeptics who question some business applications, particularly Web stores like Cyberian Outpost.
"It's kind of come and gone," said Michael J. Walsh, president of Internet Info Inc. of Falls River, Va., about the cyber-store innovation. "The biggest problem is that they don't offer consumer price and selection."
Others agree the business is due for further shakeouts. Tristian Louis, development director at iWORLD, an on-line magazine of Internet news based in Westport, notes there are currently about a hundred on-line malls, and that "the offer is now greater than the demand."
"They are usually a glorified mail-order catalogue," Mr. Louis said.
He wasn't familiar with Cyberian Outpost, but agreed to take a look. He came away with some positive first impressions. Their telephone feature for credit card purchases was a good attempt to alleviate customer fears, he said, and a feature that suggested complementary items for a particular purchase was noteworthy. "It creates more impulse purchases," he said.
Not everyone is so impressed. Dale Dougherty, president of Songline Studios in Sebastopol, Calif., said he has a "casual acquaintance" with Cyberian Outpost from making price comparisons, and that the site did not provide enough information about some items. "It's like shopping in a warehouse," he said.
Guy Kawasaki, an executive with Apple Computer Inc. said Cyberian Outpost challenges the notion that cyber-stores have run their course. "They belong in the category of stores that belong on the net," he said.
Cyberian Outpost began as a forum exclusively for Apple products and prides itself today as a place for Mac owners to go in an increasingly personal computer-centered universe. "One of the great myths is that Macintosh has no software, or less software," Mr. Kawasaki said. "People like Cyberian Outpost challenge that."
Mr. Peck disputes claims that retail on the Web is a done thing. In fact, he says, it's only just begun.
"Every piece of research shows electronic commerce is going to grow in leaps and bounds," he said. "Some of the research shows it's going to be a $7 billion business. That's what's going to drive the Internet. Sure nine out of ten will fail. But that's because most create terrible Web sites."
As he sees it: "The World Wide Web is the world's first global consumer marketplace."
