HEADLINE: POP/JAZZ;
One Son Learns Lessons From a Father . . .

BYLINE: By TOURE 

 BODY:
NOT LONG AGO, Olu Dara, a 55-year old jazz and blues trumpeter who once played with Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers, lighted a pipe, turned on the CD player in his cozy Harlem apartment and put on "Illmatic," the debut album from a popular 23-year-old rapper named Nas. "My goodness," he recalled thinking at the time. "It sounds like something I would've done."
Nas is Mr. Dara's son, and Nas's latest album, "It Was Written," has sold more than two million copies. He and his father share a musical philosophy, even though their styles are as different as their upbringings. And for these reasons their relationship illuminates how a musical heritage can be passed down in a family. 
 Mr. Dara grew up in Natchez, Miss., during the 40's and 50's to become a jovial country gentleman who is charmingly young at heart. (He was born Charles Jones 3d and took his current name in the 60's.) His music, which he calls "creative rhythm music," draws from jazz, folk, blues and Caribbean roots.
His father was a well-known singer and his uncles were traveling minstrels. His great-uncles were performers in the historic Rabbit's Foot and Silas Green touring carnivals. And his grandfather, who traveled through the South as a W.P.A. foreman, had a reputation for bursting into song to entertain his workers.
At age 7, Mr. Dara began playing the trumpet professionally, and he spent much of his youth touring the South. In the 1960's and 70's he gained acclaim in the jazz world while playing with Blakey and recording with Taj Mahal, Bobby Womack, David Murray and many others. Mr. Dara recently wrote and performed music for a play by Rita Dove called "The Darker Face of the Earth." He also appears as a musician in Robert Altman's recent film "Kansas City."
"When I was a kid on Sundays, we'd lay back and listen to my father on the radio," Mr. Dara recalled. "So it's almost like I expected to hear Nas on the radio or see him in performance."
Nas's full name is Nasir Jones. (Nasir, which Mr. Dara chose, means helper and protector in Arabic.) He and his younger brother, Jungle, were raised by their mother, Fannie Ann Jones, in the tough Queensbridge Houses, a housing project in Long Island City, Queens. During his teens, Nas was a break dancer who used the name Kid Wave. Now he is quiet and pensive, an introspective old soul. His music is hard-core hip-hop with lyrics like tightly written street poetry.
"Music is in my blood," Nas said while sitting at a console at a Manhattan recording studio. "I could have chosen to do a lot of other things. I could have been a scientist, a lawyer. But this is where I'm comfortable at, right here."
When "Illmatic" was released in 1994, it was hailed as a classic. (Mr. Dara appears on it in one song playing a short and poignant trumpet solo.) Nas was compared favorably with Rakim, who is considered the best rapper ever. A few months ago Nas released "It Was Written," and it immediately leaped to the top of the Billboard charts.
Nas's music is characterized by a laid-back cool, with a penchant for medium-pace tempos and relatively sparse tracks, all of which are hallmarks of his father's music. "He has different genres of songs," Mr. Dara said of Nas, "but in each one, the chords he has going, the economy, the smoothness, the nonaggressiveness. . . . His aggressive is cool. Not like, 'I'm angry! I'm mad!' It's cool. And that's the way my music is."
Vernon Reid, the legendary guitarist who has played with Mr. Dara and is a fan of Nas's music, also noted similarities between the two. "Both have a finely tuned sense of irony, which I think is evident in Nas's lyrics and Olu's playing as well," Mr. Reid said. "There's a kind of cockeyed way of looking at the world. A raised eyebrow. Sly. They're seeing what's going on underneath the surface."
Nas agreed. Speaking of his father, he said, "The certain sound that he likes, that's the sound that I like."
HOW IS IT THAT TWO MEN WHO ARE SO different and who work within different genres make music that shares so much? "It's probably genetic," Nas said. "And just growing up with music being around, instruments being around. It's just inspirational."
Wynton Marsalis, the jazz trumpeter who is himself the product of a famous musical family, agreed with this theory. "I think you mainly learn music from hearing it, and also from seeing how musicians act, the way they talk to each other, their work ethic," he said. "Being in a musical family means you're always around music. You grow up with it. Musicians are always around other musicians. They're always having rehearsal at the house. They're listening to music. They're always talking about music."
In Nas's family, music is a central mode of communication. "When we get together, there's no words thrown away, no idle talk," Mr. Dara said. "We'll sit down, play drums and just conversate musically."
Jungle, who is not a rapper, remembers such moments. "Soon as I come in my father's house," he said, "he'll start talking about an instrument, and he'll teach me how to play something, and next thing you know we're playing our own song."
One recent afternoon Mr. Dara, Nas and Jungle were at the studio. Nas began sounding out a beat with is palms. A moment later, Mr. Dara tapped out a counter-rhythm with the tips of his fingers. It seemed a father-son collaboration was imminent. But as soon as it started, the beat fell away, and the room passed back into silence.
"In the future," Jungle said later that afternoon, "Nas and my father are probably going to get together and make some stuff. Maybe an album. They talk about that. That's probably why he had Nas."

HEADLINE: The Rough Rider and the Easy One

BYLINE: By Edmund Morris; Edmund Morris, the author of "The Rise of Theodore Roosevelt," is at work on a biography of Ronald Reagan.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Twenty years ago, during an out-of-town tryout of the musical "1600 Pennsylvania Avenue," I was intrigued by the actor Ken Howard's ability to transform himself from President to President with the aid of a quickly applied prop or two, and adroit changes of voice and gesture. Although he was big and blond, he needed only to clamp on some pince-nez, and snap his teeth at the audience to become a creditable Theodore Roosevelt. The audience burst into applause.
The current resident of the White House has recently pulled off a similar coup de theatre, inspired no doubt by the success of his Truman skit last year and his masterly impersonation of Ronald Reagan before both houses of Congress last January. One remembers, further, that in his youth he modeled himself on John F. Kennedy and vowed on entering the White House to become another Franklin D. Roosevelt. 
 Should the scholarly gravediggers who wish to exhume Lincoln ever succeed in their quest and parade the Emancipator's bones on the nightly news, we must brace for appearances by Mr. Clinton in a stovepipe hat. In the meantime, he's found his latest vein of mimicry in T.R.
Not coincidentally, the 26th President is hot at the moment. Tonight and tomorrow, PBS will broadcast a major documentary on his life and times. Mr. Clinton has a bust of him on his desk (along with busts of all the other Presidents mentioned above), and I'll bet that at times during the recent Netanyahu-Arafat summit he thought wistfully of T.R.'s Nobel Peace Prize, glistening like a chimera on the mantel of the Roosevelt Room.
It is natural, given the loneliness of supreme power, for a chief executive to identify with his more distant predecessors (consecutive Presidents hardly ever get along, as anyone studying photographs of them together can see). We all know about Richard Nixon's chats with Honest Abe, and Ronald Reagan told me, with entire lack of self-consciousness, that he and Thomas Jefferson liked to "look at each other" across the Mall.
Usually, however, such moments of self-identification are private. When Mr. Clinton evokes T.R. on horseback in Wyoming, or wearing cowboy boots and khakis at the edge of the Grand Canyon, he invites public comparison with the Rough Rider -- at his considerable peril.
There are many parallels between them as campaigners for their respective second terms in the White House. Overwhelming personal charm, youthfulness -- T.R. was 45 on this date in 1904, Mr. Clinton is just 50 -- acute political intelligence, garrulousness, love of applause, love of people, luck: the list could be extended right down to prowess at the lunch table and their common enjoyment of a hapless opponent.
If we compare them intellectually, however, such a void opens up as to isolate them from each other, on the north and south rims of our regard. Mr. Clinton's new book "Between Hope and History" happens to be exactly the same length as T.R.'s official letter accepting the Republican nomination in 1904, and since both documents were published in late summer for the same political purpose, a side-by-side reading is instructive.
To begin with, there is the question of gravitas. I allowed Mr. Clinton's book to fall open at page 57, and found that of its 191 words, only 31 had any particular meaning. The rest of the space was devoted to cliches (one every three lines), generalities like "investing in the capacity of our people," redundancies and extremely vague statistics, of which my favorite was his claim to have made "improvements in the bottom lines of average Americans."
Out of sympathy as well as fairness, I deliberately chose one of the least noun-dense, fact-packed paragraphs of T.R.'s own manifesto (interested readers may find it at the foot of page 937, Volume IV, of his collected letters). In 14 lines, there is not a single cliche, and only 10 unnecessary words. Every sentence states something concrete, and all the emotions -- contempt for governmental critics, impatience with naysayers, veneration for veterans, sympathy for farmers, excitement over the implications of his Reclamation Act -- are genuine and strong. One senses a passionately self-directed man whose mind moves like an oiled combine over every dry stalk of policy, neatly stacking and sorting.
In contrast, Mr. Clinton has what T.R. would call "a fatal lack of sequitur." He drives without steering, and he would as soon process weeds as wheat. "Between Hope and History" reads like a series of improvised speeches (incessantly punctured by the word "I"), although his publisher assures us that the text was "labored" over for many months, and his uncredited co-author says the final book is "80 percent Bill Clinton." T.R.'s enormous letter was dictated -- probably during the course of a morning -- but it is clearly the work of a disciplined writer.
Of course, we do not elect Presidents for their prose style. Mr. Clinton is unquestionably sincere -- for the moment -- in asking us to equate him with T.R. the mediator, the environmentalist, the bully-pulpit thumper, the legislative reformer. All these aims are noble, providing he closely examines T.R.'s actual record of achievement, which was a lot less progressive than he seems to think.
On the environment, for example, T.R. was by no means a tree-hugger. When it came to a choice between scenery and the homesteader desperate for firewood and aqueducts, he paid little heed to the protests of preservationists.
"It is a cardinal principle of the forest-reserve policy of this Administration that the reserves are for use," he said in his Fourth Annual Message. Similarly, the great Trust Buster prosecuted the Northern Securities Corporation more to make a moral point (that government maintained the right to regulate a free economy) than to declare any kind of war on Wall Street. His successor, William Howard Taft, whom he lambasted for being pro-business, in reality busted more trusts than he did.
There was, moreover, a lordly hauteur about T.R.'s foreign policy, and a hair-trigger willingness to deploy gunboats when crossed, that Mr. Clinton surely does not wish to emulate. (Watch him whip off those pince-nez at the slightest hint of trouble in Panama!) He rightly sees today's world as a flux of forces -- interactive, freewheeling, cyberspatial -- rather than power blocs separated by steel and saltwater.
It is tempting to speculate, in the manner of those old "Impossible Interviews" in Vanity Fair, how Teddy and Bill would get along today should they bump into each other on the campaign trail. One imagines that Mr. Clinton would avoid any discussion of the Vietnam War, not to mention his veto of the late-term abortion bill, which would undoubtedly result in an abrupt end to the conversation. (Of all Theodore Roosevelt's convictions, the deepest was his reverence for life.)
They would admire each other's power of memory, political skills and stage manner, and laugh at their shared habit of saying, "in closing" before 3,000 words of peroration. Mr. Roosevelt would notice that Mr. Clinton, behind his joviality, has no humor, while the latter would be dismayed by T.R.'s binary way of looking at things: Good vs. Evil, Strong vs. Weak, Duty vs. Dereliction.
Such speculations, though, are historically vain. For the moment, Mr. Clinton has as much right as Theodore Roosevelt to preen before a largely contented electorate. It is encouraging that he, too, wants to be remembered for effecting great changes in a time of peace. But he might bear in mind, as he almost certainly proceeds to emulate the landslide of 1904, that T.R. never felt the need to imitate anybody.

HEADLINE: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;
Nasty Little Gang of Boys In the Low Life of Taipei

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
"There are two types of people, crooks and dopes," sneers Red Fish (Congsheng Tang), a teen-aged Taipeian wheeler-dealer whose corrupt, formerly wealthy father has gone into hiding after declaring bankruptcy. Red Fish is the soul, if you can call it that, of "Mahjong," the Taiwanese film maker Edward Yang's frantically scribbled hate letter to the boom town in which he grew up.
This grubby little character is also the de facto leader of a gang of four avaricious youths who share apartment space and women and who collaborate in scamming and hustling everyone who crosses their paths. Hong Kong (Zheng Zhang) is a hairdresser and gigolo; Toothpaste, also known as Little Buddha (Qizan Wang), tells bogus fortunes, and the more contemplative Luen-Luen (Yuluen Ke) serves as his noisy roommates' chauffeur and translator. 
 In a typical scam, Hong Kong seduces a wealthy woman and arranges for Toothpaste to foretell an imminent vehicular mishap, which Red Fish and Luen-Luen then engineer. From here on, she is an easy mark. Along the way, more than one Mercedes gets mangled.
"Mahjong," like Mr. Yang's previous film, "A Confucian Confusion," is a comic portrait of a city gone haywire with greed. Where Mr. Yang's last movie ridiculed the obsession of Taipei's corrupt, soulless nouveau riche with maintaining a facade of respectability, virtually all the characters in "Mahjong" are shamelessly rapacious about money and sex. The queen of the Hard Rock Cafe, the characters' tacky social center, is Ginger (Diana Dupuis), a jolly American who has parlayed her escort service into a corporate giant.
Into this rat's nest stumbles Marthe (Virginie Ledoyen), a beautiful 18-year-old Frenchwoman in headlong pursuit of Markus (Nick Erickson), a fickle English entrepreneur she met in London. A snooty twit who derisively refers to all Taiwanese as "these people," Markus sees Taipei as the future economic capital of the world and intends to grab a huge chunk of it. Before it's over, the movie has followed its characters through a typical day of hustling, kidnapping, blackmail, suicide, murder and endless sexual double-dealing.
"Mahjong," which the New York Film Festival is screening this evening at 6 at Alice Tully Hall, doesn't even try to establish a basic credibility. As its outrageous characters slither and scuttle around the congested Taiwanese capital, the film has the feeling of a live-action cartoon. The stridently bad acting of much of the cast only adds to the hysteria.
For all its sloppiness, this satiric morality tale still has a sharp comic bite. It also sends the same message as the New York Film Festival's other Taiwanese selection, "Goodbye South, Goodbye." In Asia's Wild West, there is a gold rush going on.
 
MAHJONG
Written (in English, Taiwanese and Mandarin, with English subtitles) and directed by Edward Yang; director of photography, Yixu Li and Longyu Li; edited by Bowen Chen; music by Forward Records; produced by Wei-yen Yu. At Alice Tully Hall today at 6 P.M. as part of the 34th New York Film Festival. Running time: 120 minutes. This film is not rated.
 
WITH: Virginie Ledoyen (Marthe), Congsheng Tang (Red Fish), Yuluen Ke (Luen-Luen), Zhen Zhang (Hong Kong), Qizan Wang (Toothpaste), Diana Dupuis (Ginger) and Nick Erickson (Markus).

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Pie In The Sky

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Going into the first debate, Bob Dole was hobbled by one problem above all. What was meant to be the foundation of his campaign for President, the promise of a 15 percent cut in income taxes, had turned out to be a loser. Doubly so.
From the moment he unveiled the idea, at the San Diego convention, it damaged Senator Dole's reputation as a man of principle, of consistency. He had long ridiculed as puerile fantasy the supply-side doctrine -- theology, really -- that reducing rates would increase tax revenue. Now here he was embracing that very doctrine. 
 The second difficulty has developed in the weeks since San Diego. As Senator Dole has made more arguments on how he can cut taxes while still keeping his old commitment to balance the budget, he has quite failed to convince his listeners. And for good reason. His figures do not remotely add up.
Senator Dole's proposal for the 15 percent income tax rate reduction plus a 50 percent cut in the capital gains tax and the child tax credit would cost the Treasury $548 billion over six years. In order to meet that cost and also eliminate the budget deficit by the year 2002, he would have to cut a total of $867 billion in spending by the Federal Government. On the stump, Mr. Dole has been saying he can do that by reducing by just 5 percent all expenditure except on defense and entitlement programs. He holds up a nickel to show how little that would be. But the arithmetic he offers is embarrassingly phony.
The Dole plan starts with the premise that most of the $867 billion in spending cuts he needs are going to occur anyway under the budget resolution passed by the current Republican Congress. But Thomas Oliphant of The Boston Globe pointed out the other day that Congressional Republicans have already abandoned the harsh budget-cutting requirements of the resolution.
Before it adjourned, Congress dropped the idea of huge cuts in Medicare and Medicaid spending that were in the budget resolution. Republicans did not act, as they had said they would, to cut the earned-income tax credit for poor working families. And so on.
The reason Republican leaders in Congress shied away from the sharp reductions promised in the budget resolution is no secret. The public did not like them. It did not want to destroy the civilian side of the Federal Government. So Newt Gingrich & Co. dropped their radical plans and agreed to appropriations that preserved most government services.
The result is that the spending cuts needed to reach the Dole target by 2002 would make Dracon of Athens look like a pussycat. Mr. Dole ruled out touching some of the biggest items: defense, Social Security, Medicare, veterans' benefits. All other government activities would have to be cut not 5 but 37 percent. That figure comes from a study by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, and it is convincing.
What Federal programs would the public want to cut by 37 percent? Hurricane forecasting? Air traffic control? Prisons? The F.B.I.? Emergency relief for the victims of floods and other natural disasters? Border control?
No President could eliminate or drastically scale back those and numerous other programs. So remaining Federal activities would have to be slashed far more than 37 percent to reach the target.
The Concord Coalition, the spending watch-group headed by former Senators Paul Tsongas and Warren Rudman, said the Dole plan would reduce the Federal Government to the level of the Coolidge and Hoover era. It said: "Most public services to the young and the poor will have to be defunded entirely."
You do not have to be an economist to understand that Senator Dole's economic plan is humbug. But economists do not think much of it either.
A magazine that takes a rigorous view of government spending, The Economist of London, reports in its current issue a survey it made of 60 macroeconomists "at America's top universities," about half the total number of such economists. An astonishing 70 percent responded. Asked whether they believed that Mr. Dole could cut taxes and balance the budget as he promised, they voted: 17 percent yes, 83 percent no.
Campaign promises always tend to be rosy. Bob Dole's budget promises could have been written by Pollyanna.

HEADLINE: Advertising;
Advertisers gather for their 87th annual conference to proclaim that 'brands are back.'

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

DATELINE: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla.

 BODY:
THE nation's largest advertisers, taking a cue from a venerable name-brand cereal, are focusing their 87th annual conference on the branding of champions and the championing of brands.
The conference of the Association of National Advertisers, which began Friday with more than 500 people attending at the Ritz-Carlton here, has as its theme "Brand Champions." John J. Sarsen Jr., president and chief executive of the association, explained that choice by declaring, "brands are back in a very big way." 
 That resurgence, particularly evident among marketers of consumer packaged goods, is of course very good news to association members, whose companies expect to fuel growth with increased sales of brand-name products. Their ebullience was palpable as the conference opened, stronger even than the rain and gale-force winds that have so far forced virtually all scheduled outdoor events inside.
The silver lining in those clouds for conference organizers has been large audiences for the speeches and break-out session concentrating on ways to build, bolster and brighten brands.
For instance, the keynote speaker at the general session yesterday suggested that it took the collapse of Communism for America's biggest advertiser to revitalize the capitalistic practice of brand-building.
"We had to go halfway around the world" to "some of the world's newest markets" to relearn some old lessons, said Wolfgang C. Berndt, executive vice president of the Procter & Gamble Company and president of Procter & Gamble North America. His reference was to Eastern Europe, where P.& G. sales since 1991 have soared to $1 billion.
In more than 50,000 interviews, Mr. Berndt said, the company found the newcomers to market economies "responded to product-focused advertising and sampling" rather than to tactics like coupons and short-term price cuts that have become common in the United States in the last two decades.
"We'd become our own worst enemy," he added, in adopting those tactics. "We'd taken our eyes off the prize, the deep abiding loyalty of consumers."
Now that P.& G. has revamped its advertising and marketing efforts in this country, Mr. Berndt said, with "selling ideas that are focused on product benefits," that approach of "back to basics is paying off in a big way" in important product categories like diapers, generating "three consecutive years of share and volume growth."
Another challenge to the conventional wisdom came from Ed Winter, chief executive of the Channel One Network unit of the K-III Communications Corporation. In a session on Saturday, he asserted that advertisers "can build brand equity" if they "embrace controversy" rather than avoid it.
"If you're taking big bold steps to grow a brand," said Mr. Winter, whose efforts to expose students to sponsored newscasts still invoke contentious debate, there can be "a strategic role for controversy" -- not "controversy no matter what, to get attention," but controversy linked to brand attributes that play off consumer attitudes. Among the examples he offered were Nike Inc., Calvin Klein Inc. and the Dallas Cowboys.
Indeed, Jerry Jones, president of the Cowboys, was one of 13 executives honored at a dinner Friday, sponsored by the trade publication Brandweek, for their marketing achievements.
Other honorees included two related to the Summer Olympics: Dick Ebersol, president of NBC Sports, which broadcast the Games from Atlanta, and Jeff Bliss, president and chief executive of the Olympic Partnership at the Sara Lee Corporation.
A reminder of how difficult a task brand-building is came with the Brandweek selection for 1996 Marketer of the Year: Roger Enrico, chairman and chief executive of Pepsico Inc. That company recently disclosed financial problems related to difficulties in its soft-drink and fast- food operations.
In business matters, the association made its annual change in elected leaders. Ronald O. Cox, group vice president at the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company, was named the 1996-97 chairman. Mr. Cox, who was vice chairman for the last year, succeeded the 1995-96 chairman, Richard A. Costello, corporate marketing communications manager at the General Electric Company.
James J. Garrity, vice president for communications at the Compaq Computer Corporation, was elected the 1996-97 vice chairman.
Also, Bruce R. Wilson, corporate advertising director at the Eastman Kodak Company, received the Robert V. Goldstein Award, honoring his work on a public service campaign for the advertising council for the American Red Cross. The award is named for a former board member of the association and the council.
The conference continues through today.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Asian Connection

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
On April 12, 1993, Associate Attorney General Webster Hubbell received a call from the Indonesian businessman James Riady, a former client, and the Arkansas lawyer and Clinton golfing partner Mark Grobmyer. Both men had, a month before, been seen in Indonesia's East Timor, a human-rights hellhole.
Hubbell's log shows Riady called again the next day, this time from the Washington number 456-2684. That is the Office of Presidential Personnel, then supervised by Bruce Lindsey, Clinton confidential aide. 
 James Riady is the son of Mochtar Riady, the ethnic Chinese at the head of the Lippo Group, a $6 billion conglomerate with great commercial and political influence throughout Asia.
Both Hubbell and Clinton knew the Riadys well. During the 1980's, the Riadys held an interest with the Little Rock financier Jackson Stephens in the Clinton-friendly Worthen Bank, which retained lawyer Webster Hubbell.
During the 1992 race for President, James Riady and his wife overtly contributed close to $200,000 in "soft money" to the Democratic campaign. The Democratic finance chairman, Marvin Rosen, tells me he was informed that Riady employee John Huang "helped a lot in raising money in '92."
The Riadys were then able to boast of placing their man in a position of influence in the Clinton Administration. Mr. Huang, 46, was named Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce for International Economic Policy. Just before taking this job, Mr. Huang was paid almost a million dollars in salary, bonus and severance from the Lippo Group, $788,750 from Hip Hing Holdings, operator of a parking lot in Los Angeles owned by the Riadys.
Mr. Huang left the Commerce Department late last year to become a vice chairman of the Democratic Finance Committee. President Clinton praised "my longtime friend John Huang" on July 22, 1996, for "his aggressive efforts to help our cause."
Aggressive is putting it mildly. Three months before, the Riadys' man Huang introduced Mr. Clinton to a South Korean magnate who made a $250,000 contribution to the Democrats through a subsidiary of a South Korean corporation.
Such a contribution is clearly against the law, which finance chief Rosen admits; only when The Los Angeles Times began asking about it was the quarter million hastily given back. Thus, for the first time, a President of the U.S. was personally involved in the solicitation of a major illegal contribution, but the Democratic Finance Committee has not had one call on this from the Federal Election Commission.
If foreigners want to slip U.S. politicians "soft money," the best conduit is a U.S. citizen or a resident alien. One of the largest Democratic contributions -- $425,000 -- is from an Indonesian gardener named Arief Wiriandinata, a green-card holder no longer in the U.S., whose wife's father helped run several Lippo ventures for the Riadys.
The Riadys gained much face in Indonesia in 1993, helping the Clinton Administration lose interest in labor abuses in East Timor; in 1994, as an Asian conference was to be held in Indonesia's capital, they were eager to impress China's leaders with their American influence. Again they turned to Webster Hubbell.
By that time, the Associate Attorney General who had loyally kept Whitewater files hidden in his basement had quit Justice because he was about to be indicted for defrauding law clients. Who would hire a man facing ruination at a time when his silence was golden to the Clintons?
The Riadys did. I'm told that between resignation and indictment, a Lippo affiliate paid Hubbell over $250,000. He went to Indonesia for them in October 1994.
One month later, at a conference in Jakarta, Indonesia, that included China's Jiang Zemin, President Clinton surprised U.S. Embassy officials by holding a private meeting with James Riady. This duly impressed Asian leaders who put great weight on connections in high places.
Clinton's foreign contributors are coming through for him in this campaign. Does Hubbell, his lip zipped in jail, expect to be sprung before his time? Will he then be made financially whole by the Clinton Asian connection? "Nobody's promised me a damn thing," the felon insisted at a Senate hearing. We'll soon see.

HEADLINE: Trade vs. Cultural Identity in Canada

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
Canada knows that by charging excise taxes of 80 percent on Canadian editions of Sports Illustrated and other American magazines, it can keep those publications off the nation's newsstands and out of its advertising market.
Canada contends that it is only trying to protect the country's national identity and help support its own modest magazine industry. 
 But the United States contends that Canada's real goal is to stifle competition. After years of complaining to the Canadians without satisfactorily resolving the issue, the United States has finally taken its grievance to the World Trade Organization in Switzerland, where it filed a formal complaint in September.
The United States is asking the international organization, which represents the trading interests of nations that have signed the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, to determine whether Canada is using cultural identity to conceal unfair trading practices.
The United States also objects to postal rates in Canada that are much lower for Canadian magazines than those imported from the United States and to a 30-year-old ban on Canadian editions printed in the United States.
Canada's response, citing what it believes are GATT provisions allowing countries to protect cultural resources, was filed Sept. 26. A hearing will be held this Friday at the World Trade Organization in Geneva and a ruling is due by Feb. 21.
Whatever the organization decides, the issue has already raised hackles in a Canada increasingly apprehensive about the encroaching American culture.
"There is a very strong dominance in the cultural industries of the Canadian marketplace by the United States," Arthur C. Eggleton, Canada's Minister for International Trade, said. "We come at this from the point of preserving culture and identity, while the U.S. comes at it from the standpoint of wanting to do business in our country."
Mr. Eggleton said that 70 percent of the magazines sold in Canada already come from the United States, and that allowing Canadian editions -- cheap to produce and full of local advertising -- would further shrink the small pool of advertising open to Canadian publications.
Canadian magazine publishers insist that existing trade agreements do not guarantee the United States free access to Canadian advertising. They say that opening the market to Canadian editions of United States magazines would threaten the survival of Canadian magazines.
"American publishers have virtually unlimited access to Canadian readers," said Catherine Allman, acting president of the Canadian Magazine Publishers Association. "The question is, will Canadian readers have unlimited access to Canadian magazines" if the magazines cannot survive competition that the Canadians regard as unfair?
Canada's cultural concerns go far beyond magazines. The Government has not allowed the United States bookstore chain Borders to establish a Canadian branch because the company and its Canadian partners did not satisfy standards for substantial Canadian control of the enterprise. And Government action in 1994 effectively threw out the Country Music Television cable channel to make way for a Canadian competitor. Eventually, the two companies involved negotiated a joint venture.
A United States trade official, who spoke on condition he not be identified, said that the two nations had been jousting over the real meaning of cultural exemptions in trade for a long time, usually without filing any formal complaints.
"But when certain actions are taken like chasing a business out of the market, we have to weigh in and say 'You've gone too far,' " the official said.
The issue of cultural influences is one of the most sensitive in the modern global economy, and an especially important part of the trading strategy pursued by the United States. With the decline of traditional manufacturing, intellectual properties like movies, magazines and books are now considered to be among the most attractive exports of the United States.
Canada is not alone in restricting intellectual imports from the United States. Some European countries have limited the showing of movies and television programs from the United States.
Before Canada signed the North American Free Trade Agreement with the United States and Mexico in 1993, it fought hard to exempt sectors of the economy essential to its cultural identity. Because of the difference in language, Mexico did not fight as hard for such cultural safeguards, although representatives of Mexican media groups warned that there was no way Mexico could compete with Hollywood.
Canada's cultural exemptions in the North American accord meant that the United States complaint on magazines would have a better chance in front of the World Trade Organization, United States trade officials said.
Canada's protectionism goes back at least to the 1960's, when Canadian editions of United States magazines were not allowed across the border. Technological advances later made it possible to print these editions in Canada.
In 1993, Time Warner Inc. introduced a Canadian edition of Sports Illustrated. It included a small amount of material on Canadian sports but most of the magazine was identical to issues sold in the United States. It then sold advertising in the regional, or "split run" editions, to Canadian companies.
A Canadian Government task force estimated that 53 other United States magazines and 70 trade journals might also try to publish split- run editions. As a result, Canada last year imposed an excise tax of 80 percent on the total dollar value of the advertising in almost every split-run magazine sold in Canada, except for Reader's Digest and Time, which had longtime Canadian editions.
For example, an issue of Sports Illustrated that carried $100,000 in ads would be charged $80,000 in excise taxes.
On top of that, a 1976 law prohibited Canadian companies that advertise in the regional editions from deducting those costs from their taxes, as they would if the ads ran in a Canadian magazine. And postage rates were higher for Sports Illustrated.

HEADLINE: Candidates For Senate Use Truth, Of a Sort

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
Truth is to political campaigns what military music is to music: a distantly related phenomenon.
In the feisty campaign to fill the United States Senate seat from New Jersey being vacated by Bill Bradley, the two candidates have unleashed a dizzying array of charges and countercharges. Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat, has repeatedly accused his opponent, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, of voting to cut Federal spending on Medicare. Mr. Zimmer, a Republican, has delighted in saying that Mr. Torricelli voted for the largest tax increase in American history. 
 In their bare-knuckles television commercials and again in their first, somewhat testy debate on Saturday, Mr. Zimmer and Mr. Torricelli have repeated these and other assertions meant to paint the opponent as extremist and the accuser as the kind of middle-of-the-road statewide candidate that New Jersey voters historically favor.
On careful examination, none of their major claims prove patently false. Each possesses enough truth to meet the vague, unwritten standards for what is fair in political oratory. But many of the most frequently repeated broadsides also tend to slip into hyperbole.
Take, for instance, Mr. Zimmer's contention that Mr. Torricelli, a seven-term Congressman, voted for "the largest tax increase in history." The assertion is a centerpiece of Mr. Zimmer's attempt to brand Mr. Torricelli an old-fashioned tax-and-spend liberal, someone hopelessly out of step with the times.
The tax increase refers to President Clinton's five-year economic plan, approved by Congress in August 1993. By one measure, the plan did include the largest tax increase in American history: $241 billion over five years.
But in another way of counting, a 1982 bill sponsored by Senator Bob Dole and signed into law by President Ronald Reagan actually contained a larger tax increase. It raised taxes by $215 billion in 1982. But adjusting for inflation, the Reagan increase was worth $286 billion in 1993 dollars, making it the largest tax increase ever.
There are also important aspects of Mr. Clinton's 1993 economic package that Mr. Zimmer's debate zingers and 30-second television ads leave out. For example, the plan barely raised the average American's taxes at all.
What it did was increase substantially the Federal tax rates on the richest Americans. The top income tax rate, which was 31 percent, was increased to 36 percent for single taxpayers with taxable incomes of more than $115,000 and for couples with taxable incomes of more than $140,000. The rate for all taxpayers with taxable incomes of more than $250,000 was increased to 39.6 percent.
The plan also raised the Federal taxes on gasoline and corporate incomes modestly, but it also cut taxes for low-income workers by expanding the earned-income tax credit.
Moreover, labeling the Clinton package as a tax increase -- something Republicans from Mr. Dole to Mr. Zimmer have taken pleasure in doing since the campaign began -- ignores what Democrats view as its primary purpose: reducing the Federal deficit. The package reduced projected spending by more than $250 billion over five years.
Mr. Zimmer, a three-term Congressman, is not the only candidate who blurs complexities with political one-liners, of course. Mr. Torricelli often twits Mr. Zimmer for his support of House Speaker Newt Gingrich, trying to portray Mr. Zimmer as a conservative Gingrich acolyte.
In the debate, Mr. Torricelli recited a long list of Federal programs that Mr. Zimmer and other House Republicans had voted to cut, citing popular middle-class services like aid to college students and environmental protections. "It may be worst in Medicare," Mr. Torricelli said of the cuts, "the most vulnerable citizens of all, our senior citizens."
On closer scrutiny, though, Mr. Zimmer voted not for a reduction in Medicare, but for a cut in the program's rate of growth -- which was also an important element of President Clinton's 1993 economic plan to trim the Federal deficit, which Mr. Torricelli voted for.
In the debate, Mr. Torricelli also took Mr. Zimmer to task for having voted to cut American aid to Israel by $750 million. Well, he did and he did not. In 1992, Mr. Zimmer voted in favor of a bill that would have cut all American foreign aid by 25 percent. That would have translated as a cut of $750 million in aid to Israel. The bill did not pass.
So when is a cut not a cut? When it is a limitation on future spending increases, or a projection from a larger overall reduction in foreign aid. In politics, as in art, beauty and truth are in the eyes of the beholder.

HEADLINE: They Have No Passports! It's O.K. They're Runners.

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: EL PASO, Tex., Oct. 6

 BODY:
Today, just a month after Congress agreed to double the size of the Border Patrol and provide more helicopters, weapons and fortifications, one of the world's most closely guarded border crossings opened for a horde of more than a thousand dashing across from Mexico.
"My number is my passport," said Jesus Ramos, pointing to the black numerals pinned to his singlet for the El Paso-Juarez International Classic 15-kilometer road race. With about 20 other members of his Chamizal Runners Club from Ciudad Juarez, he was standing near the starting line just yards from the Rio Grande and the Mexican border. 
 This year's race, the 17th, came as a reminder that the two cities often identify more closely with each other than with national capitals 1,300 miles to the south and 2,000 miles to the northeast. Even as they quarrel over crime, pollution and dozens of other issues, they tend to think of themselves as a single city, with nearly 700,000 residents in the El Paso area and about 2 million in Juarez, which promotes itself as the largest metropolis on any international border.
"Despite Operation Hold the Line, there's a natural kind of bonding because of all the economic ties," said Lucinda Vargas, a United States Federal Reserve economist raised in Juarez and now based here, referring to tougher border enforcement.
The flow of shoppers, visitors and shipments of supplies and finished goods to and from the factories across the river makes this the Mexican border's busiest crossing. There are about 60 million legal crossings a year, while illegal crossings are down but far from eliminated.
The race has become emblematic of the Juarez-El Paso alliance as an adventure in cooperation with unforeseen calamaties.
Race organizers praise the flexibility of the Immigration and Naturalization Service even as they note the challenges of a 9.3-mile event that starts in the United States, soon crosses to Mexico for about four miles, then crosses back.
"People joke that we leave the U.S. with a thousand runners and come back from Mexico with 2,000," said Bill Barry, a race sponsor through his two local Athlete's Foot stores.
A clipped "heh, heh," was the only response when Albert Martinez, an immigration inspector with his hands clasped behind his back and a Smith & Wesson on his hip, heard this joke on the Good Neighbor Bridge as runners streamed past. While most runners had numbers, a few, as well as some bicyclists, did not.
The task of linking two cultures, nations and languages with a road race falls to a group used to enduring no matter what. Almost every year presents its own challenge.
"You're dealing with the city, the state because we're on a state highway, the county," said Ted Jablonski, the race course manager. "We're dealing with immigration, with border patrol, with customs. We're dealing with three different railroads and the bus people. Then you go to Mexico and you duplicate it."
About seven years ago, organizers carefully planned the race with officials in Juarez, arranging for a police escort to lead the runners from the crest of an international bridge through Juarez traffic. Then, days before the race, a newly elected government took office in Juarez. Come race day, the runners mounted the crest of the bridge only to find honking motorists but no police.
Three years ago, a guard at the bridge bringing the runners back to the United States first heard from the El Paso police minutes before they wanted him to let through more than a thousand people with no passports or permits. No wholesale border break on his watch, he said. A few frantic minutes later, the right immigration officials had been reached and beseeched to give him the official word, and the runners swept past undetained.
Last year, less than a mile from the finish, a train cut off runners at a rail crossing. This year, El Paso's Mayor threatened to block the bridges in a dispute with Washington over maintenance funds. In recent weeks, the bridges have been closed several times after anonymous bomb threats.
The major problem this time befell contestants in a smaller 2-mile race walk earlier this morning. From a course entirely in El Paso, they were misdirected by race volunteers and then immigration inspectors, they said. They ended up dodging trucks and other traffic in Juarez. It took a 10-year-old girl, Anne Magers, to react somewhat as Dorothy did after her unplanned excursion from Kansas to Oz. Anne, realizing they were no longer on track, led a confused band of walkers back across the bridge.
Steven R. Silver, the race director, said: "In the New York Marathon, the worst thing that can happen to you is you get lost in the Bronx. Here, you end up in another country."
Earlier, at the start of the race, Mr. Silver had to improvise when there was only a tape of the United States national anthem, but not one for Mexico's. A Mexican runner ended up singing his country's anthem into the race announcer's microphone.
Runners from both countries were elated to zip across a border where one to two-hour waits for inspectors and drug-sniffing dogs have only recently been reduced with the arrival of more agents.
"The only reason I do this is to go through customs unimpeded," one runner hollered at Mr. Martinez, the immigration inspector.
A majority of the other runners appeared to be from the United States, including more than 300 troops from nearby Fort Bliss, who were grouped by units and shouting their cadence. But hundreds of other runners came from Mexico.
An immigration agency spokesman sternly insisted that the organizers screened undesirables from a list they brought over the night before the race, but the organizers say the immigration service does it.
For the racers, officialdom is one domain they would rather run around.
"The politicians don't understand the border," said Jesus Zambrano, a coach for the Club Avanti team in Juarez. "The athletes do."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Runners from the United States and Mexico crossing back into El Paso on the Stanton Street Bridge yesterday from Ciudad Juarez. (Bruce Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Why European Computer Makers Flop

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: MILAN, Italy, Oct. 4

 BODY:
When Olivetti S.p.A. announced on Thursday that it was putting its personal computer division on the block, it joined a long line of European computer makers that had dropped out in the face of strong American competition.
The Europeans, unlike their counterparts in the United States or East Asia, held on to costly retail stores too long and failed to speed products to customers in a race against obsolescence that is crucial in a business where product cycles are measured in months, not years. Besides that, most European computer makers have failed to gain market share beyond their tight national boundaries, robbing themselves of economies of scale needed to be internationally competitive. 
 So it is perhaps not surprising that the field is littered with the corpses of the losers. This year, Compagnie des Machines Bull of France merged its personal computer division, Zenith Data Systems, with Packard Bell Electronics of the United States. Earlier, ICL P.L.C. of Britain sold most of its personal computer business to Fujitsu. This summer, Escom, No. 2 in Germany after Siemens Nixdorf, filed for bankruptcy.
"If history is a guide, it's not Olivetti -- it's European technology companies," said Daniel Mandresh of Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. "Getting beyond their state borders is a major problem."
As a result, the five leading personal computer companies in Europe, including the No. 1, Compaq Computer Corporation, as well as I.B.M., are American; of the top 10, only Siemens Nixdorf and Olivetti are European. And if Olivetti succeeds with its plans, that, too. will soon change.
The lure of Europe for the American companies is in many respects obvious. Price margins have been high in comparison with those in the American market, and until recently the pricing environment has been stable. Add to that a rich humus of small and medium-sized business customers, which in major markets like Germany and Italy form the backbone of local industry, and the opportunity for rapid growth and high profit becomes evident.
So what have European computer makers been doing wrong? For one thing, although the American computer industry stopped running its own retail stores a decade ago, many European companies still run expensive chains. Vobis Microcomputer, a small and aggressive German manufacturer, for example, operates 251 stores and 436 franchised outlets. Only recently have superstores in Britain and Germany come on the scene -- hastening a shakeout of the less competitive.
Moreover, unlike their nimble, highly specialized American competitors, many of Europe's personal computer makers are divisions of huge, diversified electronics corporations. Siemens Nixdorf, for instance, the European leader, is a unit of the giant Siemens A.G., which makes everything from power generating stations to toasters.
In a major turnaround, Siemens Nixdorf has had three years of profit, after running up $1.3 billion in losses. Norbert Strauch, a company spokesman, attributes the improvement, among other things, to "internal restructuring, breaking down from one big organization to a whole series of smaller ones."
David Winn, general manager of European PC operations for International Business Machines, , says that a strength of the Americans, and a European drawback, has been the ability to move equipment around, making quick sales and avoiding inventory pile-ups that translate into losses.
"Given the rapid technology change and short product cycles, logistics becomes an overwhelming differentiation," he said. Indeed, unsaleable inventories caused much of the red ink that has drowned Olivetti.
Oddly, too, on a Continent where many businesses regularly export two-thirds of their products, European computer companies have failed miserably to break out of national boundaries. Siemens Nixdorf does 65 percent of its business in Germany; Elonex, an innovative British company, rings up 89 percent of its sales in Britain. Tulip Computers N.V., No. 4 in the Netherlands, is No. 22 in all of Europe.
Graham Lisle, a Compaq executive in Munich, attributes this European failing to being "a hero in your own country, and to a lesser extent elsewhere."
"We're all over," he said of his own company. "If there's an economic downturn, you're less exposed, because it balances out."
Olivetti, which did a mere 29 percent of its personal computer business in its home Italian market, avoided that pitfall at least. But by most indications, it seems to have done everything else wrong.
Until early this year, when it began shutting down, Olivetti ran an expensive chain of computer stores throughout Italy and abroad. With production of only about 700,000 machines, Olivetti never achieved the economies of scale of competitors like Compaq and Hewlett-Packard, and slow-moving delivery systems meant inventory pileups that cost dearly. Like Siemens Nixdorf, Olivetti's personal computer unit was part of a much larger group that sold everything from fax machines and copiers to mobile phones and printers.
Nearly half of Olivetti's personal computers were delivered to the group's own systems and services unit for inclusion in large banking or business systems, with often unclear bookkeeping between various Olivetti units that led to heavy losses.
Oddly, too, on a Continent accustomed to a patchwork of languages and cultures, European computers are often shunned outside their home country. Germans buy Siemens Nixdorf, the Dutch buy Tulip. American computers, in contrast, are somehow neutral.
American companies have proved superior to their European counterparts at meeting varying local demands. Compaq, for example, sells smaller processors and slower modems in southern Europe, where technology tends to lag behind; ads by the American manufacturers are attuned to national taste.
"There is an art to getting the balance between your global business, and making just the right allowance for local markets," Mr. Winn of I.B.M. said.
"I think manufacturers from the United States have gotten good at that."

HEADLINE: Spurred by U.S., Two Sides Open New Talks to Save Mideast Peace

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: EREZ CROSSING, Gaza Strip, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Spurred on by Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Israelis and Palestinians sat down today to the urgent negotiations they agreed on at last week's summit meeting in Washington in an effort to salvage their peace after the recent gunbattles in the West Bank and Gaza.
The central focus was to reach agreement as soon as possible on turning over control of most of Hebron, on the West Bank, to the Palestinians. The long-delayed transfer has evolved into a litmus test of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's intentions toward the Palestinian peace. 
 But the fact that Palestinian police officers used their weapons against Israelis in the violence has made Mr. Netanyahu determined to strengthen the security arrangements for the Jewish enclaves in the heart of Hebron, the last of seven West Bank cities to come under Palestinian self-rule under a 1995 agreement. The transfer had originally been scheduled for March, but was suspended after a series of Palestinian bombings in Israel.
The talks that opened today were officially negotiations that had been agreed on last month and delayed by the shootings. But the prominent presence at the negotiating table of Mr. Christopher's chief Mideast coordinator, Dennis Ross, and Mr. Christopher's own meetings with Mr. Netanyahu and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat made clear that the United States was now determined to press for quick and tangible results.
"The recent violence has demonstrated the great urgency of reaching some concrete results just as soon as possible," Mr. Christopher told reporters after meeting with Mr. Netanyahu in Jerusalem. "The situation has eased somewhat, but it is still a dangerous situation," he said two hours later after meeting Mr. Arafat in the Gaza Strip.
Mr. Christopher, Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat did not attend the opening session of the negotiations, which was held at Erez on the Israeli-Gaza border.
The two-and-a-half-hour session was described as largely organizational, and the chief negotiators -- Said Erekat on the Palestinian side and Dan Shomron on the Israeli -- said they had agreed to set up three subcommittees: on Hebron, on security and on economic issues.
Israel also announced some easing of the security cordon thrown around Palestinian areas after the recent violence. They said 2,000 Gazan workers would be allowed into the Israeli-controlled Erez industrial zone on Monday, and the blockades around two West Bank towns, Tulkarem and Jenin, would be eased.
But the two sides could not decide where to continue the negotiations. The plan agreed to in Washington was to retire to a secluded spot for continual talks, but Israel was reportedly against the Palestinians' first choice, the Egyptian resort of Taba, near Eilat, the southernmost Israeli city.
Both the negotiators and senior American officials made clear that the major hurdle would be to find a way to satisfy the conservative Israeli Government's demands for more stringent security for Jewish settlers in Hebron while meeting the Palestinians' insistence that the existing agreements not be reopened or renegotiated.
Accordingly, at a news conference with Mr. Christopher, Mr. Netanyahu said: "We did not propose opening the agreement. We suggested that within the confines of the existing agreement, adjustments be made."
Mr. Christopher stressed the same point: "One of the things that has been clarified during my visit here is that the parties intend to negotiate within the four corners of the agreement. They do not seek to modify it."
The question was how much "adjusting" Mr. Arafat was prepared to accept, since the new Israeli plan, as reported in the Israeli press, demanded substantial changes, including the arming of Palestinian police in Hebron only with sidearms, new buffer zones around Jewish enclaves, and the right of Israeli soldiers to pursue Palestinians anywhere in the city.
Appearing later with Mr. Christopher, Mr. Arafat avoided commenting on the issues to be negotiated. But the chief Israeli negotiator, Mr. Erekat, firmly declared on going into the meeting, "We will not renegotiate the agreements signed, we will not reopen the agreement for any modifications or amendments." Only the "implementation" can be discussed, Mr. Erekat said.
Dore Gold, Mr. Netanyahu's foreign-policy adviser, was equally firm in declaring that "without reopening the agreement, a lot can be changed."
Senior American officials expressed satisfaction that Mr. Netanyahu had given a public assurance that existing agreements would not be renegotiated. They said one reason for Mr. Christopher's stopover was that the decision to open these talks was made at the very end of the Washington summit meeting last week, leaving no time to work out critical details.
Mr. Christopher said that Mr. Ross's role in the talks would be only as a "facilitator," and that whenever possible the Americans would leave the talks to the Palestinians and Israelis. It was not clear how long Mr. Ross would stay, nor was any deadline set for reaching agreement.
American officials said they believed their presence was necessary because the three days of violence across the West Bank and Gaza that erupted on Sept. 25 had deeply undermined an already shaky level of trust between the Palestinians and Mr. Netanyahu's Government.
Hebron, moreover, brought out all the mutual distrust -- the Israeli fear that Palestinian police might fire on the Jewish settlers, and the Palestinian suspicion that Mr. Netanyahu was trying to roll back the peace agreements.
The crisis erupted after Israel opened a new exit in a tunnel alongside the ancient plateau where the Dome of the Rock stands, raising suspicions among Muslims that the Israelis were seeking to change the delicate religious balance in Jerusalem's Old City.
The incident also proved to be the breaking point in mounting Palestinian frustrations with the lack of movement in carrying out the peace accords. Protest demonstrations escalated into firefights between Palestinian police and Israeli soldiers, in which 62 Palestinians, 1 Egyptian and 14 Israelis were killed.
That was followed by the emergency meeting arranged by President Clinton in Washington last week between Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat. After more than three hours of talks, the two leaders agreed to hold the talks on Hebron and other issues.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Gretzky's Home Debut Is Less Than Great

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
WAYNE GRETZKY would have been great even if his family name had never prompted the alliterative and literary nickname The Great Gretzky. No hockey player has ever maneuvered the puck like him.
But sports fans in the most chauvinistic town would insist that it never truly happened for Wayne Gretzky until he shucked off the garb of the hinterlands, St. Louis and Los Angeles and Edmonton, and played his first home game as a Ranger last night. 
 He skated onto the ice in the Garden -- you know very well which Garden -- in the familiar red, white and blue uniform and smiled shyly as the 18,200 fans (dozens of them wearing expensive new No. 99 Ranger jerseys) cheered for him.
"It even went up to another level for Mark," Gretzky noted later, referring to the ultimate introduction for his pal, Mark Messier.
Messier was ejected in the second period for mugging an opponent, and the Rangers went down to a 5-2 defeat that reminded everybody that the Florida Panthers were Stanley Cup finalists last season and the Rangers most emphatically were not.
Last night Gretzky made his first point as a Ranger, after not being involved in a goal in the 4-4 opening tie in Boston on Saturday night. In both games, Gretzky's intuitive and feathery passes showed his new teammates what they can expect, eventually.
"Communication is the whole game," Gretzky said. "You talk about it or you try to watch it in a video. It works both ways. It's a team game. No one player has ever won a championship by himself."
There have been few reunions like this in any sport because rarely have two teammates come along at the same time, on the same team, with the skills of superstars, with strong egos, yet remained loyal friends.
Messier came to New York a superstar and goaded the Rangers to their first Stanley Cup in 54 years in 1994. He showed his ultimate security by saying, yes, there was room for his friend on this team.
With all due respect to Messier, Gretzky has been a defining and transitional figure in his sport much the way Babe Ruth was in baseball and the triumvirate of Larry Bird, Magic Johnson and Michael Jordan was in basketball, raising the level of skill and fan awareness. Gretzky had McEnroe touch and Ashe diplomacy. And he still does.
Since Gretzky first skated from Ontario to the major leagues as a willowy teen-ager, he has flitted through defenses with otherworldly instincts, making time stand still on ice. From the 70's to the 90's, hockey progressed from a tight little Canadian passion to a world sport, and nobody came close to Gretzky in making hockey big time.
The surliest goons on other teams would refrain from trying to break his wispy body, the same way the beefed-up strongboys of the old American Football League sacked Joe Namath with tenderness, laying him down like a babe in a bassinet, because they respected him as superstar and savior.
For Gretzky to finally play as a homeboy in "the world's most famous arena," as the folks at Madison Square Garden call it, required considerable deliberation in corporate offices.
"The hockey part was easy," said Dave Checketts, the president and chief executive officer of the Garden. "Wayne scored 102 points last year for two different teams, one of them not going anywhere."
Neil Smith, the general manager, and Colin Campbell, the coach, thought Gretzky was still a superior player. But Checketts had to sell Gretzky's $5.047 million, one-year contract to the two corporations that jointly own the Garden.
"I went to the people at ITT and Cablevision and said, 'This is not in line with our plans, but these things don't often happen,' " Checketts said. "The people at ITT and Cablevision were very supportive."
Checketts had already approved a brutal increase in ticket prices for the second straight year -- "North of 15 percent, over all," he said -- which angered longtime fans, who fear being squeezed out by huge corporations who can afford $5,000 or more per season ticket.
"We didn't pull a Los Angeles Lakers," Checketts said. "They raised their lowest ticket from $9 to $21 the day they signed Shaquille O'Neal. We had already sent out our renewal forms."
Once Gretzky had signed in July, the demand was so strong the Garden even refused to sell season tickets to one longtime patron who had complained about the Garden's holding his money during the lockout two years ago. These people play hardball on ice, but it seems to pay off.
"All our suites and sponsorships are already sold," Checketts said. "So the economic benefit will be long term. But we will be selling a lot of No. 99 shirts."
Garden fans -- who tear the visiting team jersey off the back of any hapless fan who dares to wear it -- used to greet Gretzky the polite way Brooklyn Dodgers fans used to greet Stan (the Man) Musial, even while Musial was bashing the Dodgers' brains out with a smile. You can't hate Wayne Gretzky.
Checketts saw another dimension of Gretzky after the summer signing ceremony at the Garden: "Wayne and his wife, Janet, were flying home to California, and ITT offered its company plane," Checketts said. "I was eager to see my family, so I asked if I could fly west with them. We stopped in Utah and my kids came out to the plane to meet me. He and Janet got out of the plane and stopped to talk to the children.
"Afterward, my 17-year-old, Katie, said that he had held out his hand and said, 'Hi, I'm Wayne,' and he asked her what she thought of life in the East, and what she did in school. I realized that what sets him apart is more than his talent."
The talent was awesome and unique, and maybe it still is. Some New Yorkers truly believe they deserve whatever The Great Gretzky has left.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wayne Gretzky being introduced to the Madison Square Garden fans last night in his Rangers home debut. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Is That Glass Half Empty, or Half Full?

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

 BODY:
From the moment the red light went on last night, Bill Clinton played the optimist and Bob Dole, his Republican rival, played the pessimist.
For several months, Mr. Dole's strategists have urged him to project some of the sunniness, some of the confidence that happier days lie just ahead, that made Ronald Reagan one of the great motivators and vote-getters in American history. But Mr. Dole opened the first of his two planned debates with President Clinton by speaking of what he termed the anxieties and worries of the American people, and he said later, "There's a lot of things wrong with America." 
 President Clinton, on the other hand, took as his basic theme an incumbent's typically upbeat appraisal: "We are better off than we were four years ago. Let's keep it going." In his final answer, he commented pointedly, looking directly at Mr. Dole, "It is not midnight in America, Senator."
Perhaps the most noteworthy aspect of the debate was its temperate, civilized tone. The two men stuck carefully to major policy issues.
Neither with his economic thrusts nor with other barbs, directed at the President's records on drugs, foreign policy and health care, did Mr. Dole seek to transform the political argument with some dramatic new tactic or revelation. Indeed, his arguments restated those that he has presented on the campaign trail, to no great effect so far.
Whether Mr. Dole gave voters sufficient reason to take another look at him, as his managers said beforehand that he must, remains to be seen. But if this was his last best hope of cutting into Mr. Clinton's lead in the polls, as several of his aides said, he showed no signs of desperation or even urgency.
The President appeared thoroughly relaxed. He made his case calmly and with good humor, stating a credo that reflected his rediscovered centrism of the last year or so: "I believe the purpose of politics is to give people the tools to make the best of their own lives." Nothing that Mr. Dole said seemed to get under his skin, although he occasionally sounded the slightest bit defensive.
Mr. Clinton had little fresh to offer, returning several times to the metaphor he has ridden hard since the Democratic convention, the now-famous "bridge to the 21st century."
Neither man committed anything remotely resembling the kind of gaffe that could hurt him, such as George Bush's indiscreet glance at his wristwatch four years ago or Gerald R. Ford's stumble over Poland's political status in 1976.
Incumbents do not often lose when a nation is at peace and the economy healthy. No American troops are fighting abroad this fall. So Mr. Dole, looking for an opening in a race in which he has trailed for months, had little alternative but to suggest that the President's economic claims were bogus. And he did so, suggesting that while Mr. Clinton might be better off, many of the nation's "working families" had been left behind in what he called the slowest recovery of the century. Bankruptcies, he said, were at the highest rate in history.
But that is a hard sell when the Republican governors of pivotal states like Pennsylvania, Ohio and Michigan are bragging about record employment in their towns and cities and when the stock market stands at record levels.
Mr. Dole barely mentioned the economic boom that his supply-side running-mate, Jack Kemp, contends would be set off by the Republicans' 15 percent tax cut, and he said little about revolutionary change in the Federal tax code. Nor did he confront, head-on and in detail, the doubts expressed by many voters and economists that he could cut both taxes and the deficit.
"We're going to make the economic package work," he said without much passion about halfway through the 90-minute debate in Hartford.
He scored several times with his humor, teasing the President about his weight and his cholesterol and teasing himself about his fall from a campaign platform in California. Mr. Dole showed he was not just a grumpy old man, as some have said, and he sought to demonstrate that he had a compassionate side.
He demonstrated a mastery of the details of government that easily matched Mr. Clinton's. At times, he delivered a crisp line that seemed likely to find a receptive audience, as when he told the increasingly conservative electorate: "I trust the people, the President trusts the government." Or at another point: "I want the government to pinch pennies, not families."
Mr. Dole did not shrink from personal attacks, although he declined the invitation of the moderator, Jim Lehrer, to state how his character differed from Mr. Clinton's in ways relevant to the election. He raised the Whitewater issue while saying he would adhere to his policy of not raising Whitewater.
He said the President reminded him of his late brother Kenny, "a great talker" who exaggerated things -- a clear if subtle effort to reinforce doubts about Mr. Clinton's veracity. Borrowing one of Mr. Reagan's more successful lines, he said, "There he goes again," accusing Mr. Clinton of taking credit for things he had not accomplished.
Mr. Dole also stirred memories of his 1988 outburst after the New Hampshire primary, when he demanded that George Bush "stop lying about my record," telling the President to "stop scaring seniors and stop tearing me apart."
But he did avoid the bitterness of tone and dourness of visage that have landed him in trouble in the past -- what Eddie Mahe, a leading Republican campaign consultant, calls "this kind of 'black Bob Dole' vulnerability."
Over all, there was a notable lack of edge to the exchanges. Mr. Dole said repeatedly that he respected the President, and Mr. Clinton said, "I like Senator Dole. You can probably tell that we like each other." That no doubt pleased those Americans who tell pollsters and other interviewers that they dislike the endless bickering in Washington.
