Views of Their Opponent
 
MODERATOR Senator Dole, if you could single out one thing that you would like for the voters to have in their mind about President Clinton on a policy matter or a personal matter, what would it be? Something to know about him, understand it and appreciate it?

DOLE See, if I say anything, it's going to misconstrued. I don't think this is even a race between the -- it's about our vision for America. I happen to like President Clinton personally. I'm addressing him all evening as Mr. President. I said in 1992 he didn't extend that courtesy to President Bush.
But I respect the Presidency. I've served under a number of presidents. They all have their strengths and they all have their weaknesses. So I'd rather talk about my strengths. I think I have my strengths.
And I think the best thing going for Bob Dole is that Bob Dole keeps his word. It's a question between trust and fear. And I would say, I think, Mr. President, about all you've got going in this campaign is fear. You're spending millions and millions of dollars in negative ads, frightening senior citizens. I know this to be a fact, because I had one tell me last week, Senator, don't cut my Medicare.
I'm trying to save your Medicare, just as I rescued Social Security with a bipartisan commission. I have relatives on Medicare. I used to sign welfare checks for my grandparents. I know all about poverty and all about need and all about taking care of people. And that's been my career in the United States Senate.
And I'll keep my word on the economic package. If I couldn't cut taxes and balance the budget at the same time, I wouldn't look you in the eye tonight in your living room, wherever you may be, and say that this is good for America.
People will tell you who served with Bob Dole, agree or disagree, he kept his word. That's what this race is all about.
 
CLINTON I'd like the American people to know that I have worked very hard to be on their side and to move this country forward. And we're better off than we were four years ago. But the most important thing is my plan for the 21st century is a better plan.
A targeted tax cut; a real commitment to educational reform; a deep commitment to making welfare reform work, within incentives to the private sector to move people from welfare to work.
Now we've have to create those jobs now that we're requiring people to go to work. A commitment to continuing step by step health care reform with the next step helping people who are between jobs to access health care, not lose it just because they're out of work for a while. A commitment to grow the economy while protecting the environment.
That's what I'd like them to know about me, that I've gotten up everyday and worked for the American people and worked so that their children could have their dreams come true. And I believe we've got the results to show we're one the right track.
The most important thing is, I've believe we've got the right ideas for the future.
And like Senator Dole -- I like Senator Dole. You can probably tell we like each other. We just see the world in different ways and you folks out there are going to have to choose who you think is right.

DOLE Well I'd say, you know the first homeless bill in the Senate was the Dole-Byrd bill, part of the Dole-Byrd bill -- I can't remember who was in control then. I remember working with Senator Ribicoff from Connecticut on the hospice program, and now 2500 hospices. As I said, I remember -- I've worked all my life while I was in the Congress. I left on June the 11th because I wanted the American people to know that I was willing to give up something.
President Clinton ran for Governor in 1990 and said he's going to fill out his term but he didn't. He's president so I guess it's a little better deal. But I wanted the American people to know that I was willing to give up something. It wasn't just getting more power and more power.
So I rolled the dice. I put my career on the line because I really believe the future of America is on the line. We can give you all these numbers. They don't mean a thing if you're out of work, you have nothing to eat or you can't have medical care or you're holding a crack baby in your arms right now, and what do you do next?
 
DOLE You know, America's best days are ahead of us. I've seen the tough times. I know they can be better. And I'll lead America to a brighter future.
 
MODERATOR Mr. President, what do you say to Senator Dole's point that this election is about keeping one's word?
 
CLINTON Let's look at that. When I ran for president I said we'd cut the deficit in half in four years. We cut it by 60 percent. I said that our economic plan would produce eight million jobs. We have 10.5 million new jobs. We're number one in autos again, record numbers of new small businesses.
I said we'd pass a crime bill that would put 100,000 police on the street, ban assault weapons, and deal with the problems that ought to be dealt with with capital punishment, including capital punishment for drug kingpins. And we did that.
I said we would change the way welfare works, and even before the bill passed we'd moved nearly two million people from welfare to work, working with states and communities.
I said we'd get tougher on child support, and child support enforcement's up 50 percent. I said that I would work for tax relief for middle class Americans. The deficit was bigger than I thought it was going to be, and I think they're better off -- all of us are -- that we got those interest rates down and the deficit down.
The Republicans talk about it, but we're the first administration in anybody's lifetime looking at this program to bring that deficit down four years in a row.
We still gave tax cuts to 15 million working Americans, and now I've got a plan that's been out there for two years. It could have been passed already, but instead the Republicans shut the government down to try to force their budget and their plan on me, and I couldn't take that.
But we'll get the rest of that tax relief. And so, I think when you can look at those results, you know that the plan I've laid out for the future has a very good chance of being enacted if you'll give me a chance to build that bridge to the 21st century.

MODERATOR Senator.

DOLE Well, there he's goes again. I mean, it's a line that's been used before. But, exaggerating all the things that he did. He didn't do all these things.
Let's take all these four-debt years in a row. He came in with a high growth rate, the 1990 budget agreement -- which some didn't like -- had some very tough cost controls, put a lot of pressure on congress. The S & L crisis was over, they were starting to sell assets.
So, all that money was coming in. And he cut defense an extra $60 billion, threw a lot of people out of work. He talks about a smaller government. There are actually more people in government except for the people in defense-related jobs. They're gone.
The government's bigger than it was when President Kennedy was around. No, he says, it's not. In addition, the Republican congress cut $53 billion. So, let's just, you know, let's give credit where credit is due.
Governor Engler of Michigan cut taxes 21 times, created a lot of new jobs. So, did Governor Thompson, so did Governor Rowland. You know, a lot of people out there deserve credit, Mr. President.
When I'm President of the United States, we're going to have a Governor's Council. And we're going to work directly with the governors -- Republicans and Democrats -- to get power back to the people and back to the states.
 
CLINTON I think a lot of people deserve credit. And I've tried to give to them. But, I believe that my plan is better than Senator Dole's ill-advised $550 billion scheme which I'll say again will blow a hole in the deficit.
Our plan, will balance the budget, and grow the economy, preserve the environment and invest in education. We have the right approach for the future. And look at the results. It is not midnight in America, Senator, we are better off than we were four years ago.

Closing Statements
 
MODERATOR All right. That's the last question. The last answer. Let's go now to the closing statements. Mr. President, you're first. Two minutes.

CLINTON Well, first Jim, let me thank you and thank you, Senator Dole, and thank you ladies and gentlemen, all of you listening tonight, for the chance you've given us to appear.
I want to say in the beginning that I am profoundly grateful for the chance that you have given me to serve as president for the last four years. I never could have dreamed anything like this would come my way in life and I've done my best to be faithful to the charge you've given me.
I'm proud of the fact that America is stronger and more prosperous and more secure than we were four years ago. I'm glad we're going in the right direction. And I've done my best tonight to lay out my plans for going forward to an even better future in the next century.
I'd like to leave you with the thought that the things I do as president are basically driven by the people whose lives I have seen affected by what does or doesn't happen in this country. The auto worker in Toledo who was unemployed when I was elected and now has a great job, because we're number one in auto production again.
All the people I've met who used to be on welfare who are now working and raising their children and I think what others could do for our country and for themselves if we did the welfare reform thing in the proper way.
I think of the man who grabbed by the shoulder once with tears in his eyes and said his daughter was dying of cancer and he thanked me for giving him a chance to spend some time with her without losing his job, because of the Family and Medical Leave Act.
I think of all the people that I grew up with and went to school with whom I stay in touch with and who never let me forget how what we do in Washington affects all of you out there in America.
Folks, we can build that bridge to the 21st century big enough and strong enough for all of us to walk across. And I hope that you will help me build it.
 
MODERATOR Senator Dole, you're closing statement, sir.

DOLE Thank you, Jim. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank everyone for watching and listening. And I want to address my remarks to the young people of America because they're the ones that are going to spend most of their life in the 21st century. They're the ones who have the challenges and there are people out there making predictions that it's not going to be the same.
You're not going to have the opportunities. It's going to be more deficits, more drugs, more crime and less competence in the American people. And that's what you're faced with, the parents are faced with and the grandparents are faced with. It's important. It's their future.
And I would say to those -- I know there are more young people experimenting with drugs today than ever before. Drug use has gone up. And if you care about the future of America, if you care about your future, just don't do it. And I know that I'm someone older than you, but I've had my anxious moments in my life. I've learned to feed myself and to walk and to dress. I'm standing here as proof that in America the possibilities are unlimited. I knew who I am and I know where I'm from, and I know where I want to take America.
We are the greatest country on the face of the Earth. We do more good things for more people in our communities, our neighborhoods, than anywhere that I know of.
This is important business. This election is important. I ask for your support. I ask for your help.
If you really want to get involved, just tap into my home page: www.dolekemp96.org.
Thank you. God bless America.

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Yeltsin's Heart Surgeon in Action Performing a Coronary Bypass

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D. 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 7

 BODY:
In the same immaculately clean, high-technology operating room at the Cardiology Center here where Boris N. Yeltsin is expected to undergo heart bypass surgery in the next few weeks, his surgeon, Dr. Renat S. Akchurin, performed a similar operation on a 36-year-old man on Thursday.
Looking on, this reporter had a rare glimpse into heart surgery in Russia where surgeons said far fewer bypasses are done than are needed. Economic hardships limit the number of bypasses to about 3,000 each year, compared with more than 300,000 in the United States. 
 Draped in a two-tone blue and olive scrub suit, Dr. Akchurin peered at different times in the operation through either jeweler-type loupes strapped to his head or an operating microscope suspended overhead. The aim was to magnify by several times arteries and veins, some less than two twenty-fifths of an inch in width, that he cut and stitched to create new channels for blood to flow around the man's blocked coronary arteries and nourish the heart.
There was strict adherence to infection control practices, except for an assistant whose mask failed to cover his nose. The operating room was silent until Dr. Akchurin finished the most difficult part. The music that ordinarily plays in the background was inexplicably absent this day, Dr. Akchurin said, and he had to sew two extra stitches to adjust for the man's unusual anatomy. Otherwise, the operation went smoothly.
Efforts to reach Dr. Akchurin today for a report on the patient's condition, however, were unsuccessful.
During the surgery, Dr. Akchurin was polite and soft-spoken, unlike many other surgeons who have been known to yell and throw instruments in the operating room. He prefaced requests for instruments from his scrub nurse with a "please." But Dr. Akchurin changed his tone of voice to convey degrees of displeasure when assistants were not quick enough or a reporter asked too many questions about Mr. Yeltsin's case.
The circular operating room was more spacious than many in the United States. Its stainless steel walls make it easier to clean and avoid the repainting needed for most American operating rooms.
The Finnish-built and designed room contained standard items like a heart-lung bypass machine; monitors for vital functions like blood pressure, heart rate and electrocardiogram tracings; X-ray equipment, and television monitors connected to cameras placed in the overhead spotlights that brighten the operating field. The equipment was, for the most part, made in Germany or Britain. Store rooms appeared well stocked.
The cardiology center is in a larger institute named for its head, Dr. Yevgeny I. Chazov, a cardiologist who pioneered in the modern clot-dissolving techniques used to stop heart attacks in progress and was Minister of Health in the former Soviet Union. The center is clean and plush by Russian standards. The lobby and hallways are made of marble, the floors of granite and flagstone. The floors near Dr. Akchurin's office are wood parquet.
The heart center contrasts starkly to the grimy, aging hematology institute where Dr. Andrei I. Vorobyov works. He heads the Russian team of consultants in Mr. Yeltsin's case and his expertise has been tapped in studies of radiation damage from the Chernobyl nuclear accident. Doctors at the hematology center said they lacked essential drugs and equipment and that the building had not been repaired since it was built after World War II. People stumble in the hallways, which are dark to save the costs of electricity.
Over the weekend, Mr. Yeltsin moved from the Kremlin Hospital, where he had been a patient since Sept. 12, to a sanitarium, where he is expected to be freer to move around and increase his workload.
Dr. Akchurin is one of several consulting cardiac surgeons at the Kremlin Hospital. Yet the man whose hands control Mr. Yeltsin's fate and perhaps that of his vast country said he did not know why he was chosen to perform a triple or quadruple bypass operation on the 65-year-old Russian President.
Dr. Akchurin said he expected and preferred to perform Mr. Yeltsin's operation at his center instead of the Kremlin Hospital, particularly because of a disagreement between the two hospitals. Dr. Akchurin said he believed that the intensive-care practice at the Kremlin Hospital was inferior because anesthesiologists there stopped caring for a patient once the operation was completed and did not join the surgeons in monitoring a patient's course in the recovery room, as they did in his own hospital.
During his first years as a surgeon, from 1973 to 1984, Dr. Akchurin learned microsurgical techniques, largely for research purposes. In transplanting kidneys and hearts in rats, Dr. Akchurin came to depend on the 8- to 10-power magnification of an operating microscope. At the time, microsurgery was an underdeveloped field, Dr. Akchurin said. He applied the skills learned from animal surgery to the delicate repair of nerves and arteries in hands that had been mutilated in industrial accidents and in reimplanting arms and legs severed in automobile accidents.
Dr. Akchurin also worked with leaders in Russian cardiovascular surgery to perform heart transplants, create grafts to bypass clogged arteries in a leg and repair bulges in the aorta, the body's main artery. It was also a time when Dr. Chazov was scouring Russia for talented young doctors to upgrade the quality of medicine at the institute.
Dr. Chazov invited Dr. Akchurin to work at the cardiology center and sent him to work for several months with his friend Dr. Michael E. DeBakey, the heart surgery pioneer, at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston. Two weeks ago, Dr. DeBakey consulted on Mr. Yeltsin's case while attending a scientific meeting here.
After visiting heart surgeons at the Stanford University, New York University and New York Hospital-Cornell medical centers, Dr. Akchurin returned to Moscow and started a program in coronary artery surgery at the institute, relying on the operating microscope that only a few others like Dr. George Green at New York University were using for coronary bypasses. To do so, Dr. Akchurin said he had to solicit the aid of factories in Kazan to fashion a needle that is three times thinner than those used elsewhere as well as other lightweight surgical tools to let him sew with the extra thin sutures. He said he also helped modify to his needs scissors "made like a pencil so you just turn it and cut what you need" instead of spreading the handle as in a conventional pair.
Most surgeons use loupes while performing bypass operations. But Dr. Akchurin looks through them only while removing the internal mammary artery from beneath the rib cage. Then, while stitching the grafts made from the mammary artery and veins taken from the leg, Dr. Akchurin turns to the higher magnification afforded by operating microscopes. The reason, he said, is that he can make tiny slits in the blood vessels and then sew the arteries and veins to their new location on the surface of the heart with sutures that are finer than those used by surgeons wearing loupes.
All the surgeons on Dr. Akchurin's team use operating microscopes and microsurgical techniques. They said the skills take three to four years to learn but are worthwhile because the thinner needles and sutures help to keep the vessels stay open for many years and improve long-term results. But most heart surgeons elsewhere disagree, saying that they can do as well using the three or so power magnification afforded by loupes.
Dr. Akchurin said his team performed about 650 bypasses a year and had success and complication rates comparable to those in the United States and elsewhere. Such statistics cannot be independently checked.
Dr. Akchurin has performed surgery in other countries. This week he expects to leave to visit Dr. DeBakey's team in Houston to review the latest techniques and equipment. Dr. Akchurin plans to return with members of Dr. DeBakey's team and with newer equipment that he does not have, like a ventricular assist device that can aid patients with failing hearts, in the unlikely event that it is needed.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Renat S. Akchurin in his surgical mask working on the early part of a heart bypass operation he performed at the Cardiology Center in Moscow; inset, Dr. Akchurin before beginning the operation. (Photographs by James Hill for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Settles Mostly Lower On Hint of Japanese Rate Trim

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly lower yesterday, dropping sharply against the yen when a top Japanese political aide forecast a rise in domestic interest rates after elections are held in less than two weeks.
The remarks by Shizuka Kamei, chief spokesman for the Liberal Democratic Party, helped touch off a broad rally in the yen. Japan's rates have been at record lows for more than a year, helping depress the yen and causing the dollar's rise to two-and-a-half-year highs against the Japanese currency last week. 
 The dollar's decline in other foreign exchange dealings was softer. The dollar was underpinned by weakness in the mark, which continued to fall against other European currencies because of optimism about European monetary union.
In late trading in New York, the dollar fell to 111.12 yen, from 111.80 on Friday. The dollar also fell to 1.5312 German marks from 1.5321 marks. The British pound slipped to $1.5635 from $1.5640.
Traders said most of the action came in Asian trading after Mr. Kamei told a private conference in Tokyo that a monetary tightening was possible in Japan, including a rise in the Bank of Japan's discount rate, after the general elections on Oct. 20.
Mr. Kamei's remarks were widely quoted and confounded the prevailing view that rates were likely to remain low. Although Mr. Kamei is not a policy maker, his position as the Liberal Democrats' chief spokesman and the likelihood that the party will win the elections in less than two weeks carried some weight.
"The statement on the possibility of a rate rise after the election brought the dollar off its highs against the yen," John McCarthy, foreign exchange manager at ING Capital Markets in New York, said. Japan's low rates have weakened the yen by making yen-denominated holdings less attractive.
The mark's weakness against European currencies came after Hans Tietmeyer, president of the Bundesbank, said the selection of countries for participation in the 1999 currency union would be based on their ability to sustain strict financial criteria required for entry.
Mr. Tietmeyer's remarks were seen as soothing fears that some countries would use fiscal accounting tricks to qualify for participation in the plan and undermine it.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices Skeptically Review Law Requiring Cable Systems to Carry Broadcast Stations

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The Federal Government's defense of a law requiring cable-television systems to carry the signals of most broadcast stations found a skeptical audience at the Supreme Court today as the Justices, formally opening their new term, questioned whether the law violates the free-speech rights of cable systems.
Solicitor General Walter Dellinger, making his first appearance before the Court since President Clinton named him as the Government's top appellate lawyer over the summer, said it was "a matter of critical importance" to the Government to maintain a "robust array of quality programming" on broadcast stations. Mr. Dellinger said that with 60 percent of American households now wired for cable, broadcast stations that are cut off from cable subscribers would wither in the face of lost advertising. 
 "How many and to what extent?" Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist asked. The Chief Justice said the Court needed evidence rather than speculation before it could accept Congress's rationale for what are known as the must-carry rules.
Mr. Dellinger said that before the must-carry rules went into effect in 1992, cable systems were typically dropping as many as one-third of local broadcast stations in favor of other sources of programming.
Justice Antonin Scalia, for one, was not satisfied. It was "no big deal" to lose a broadcast station in a crowded market like New York City, Justice Scalia said. "Most communities have only one newspaper," he said before asking Mr. Dellinger: "Would you require newspapers to carry their competitors for the sake of diversity?"
"What cable operators have is the gate-keeping function" that controls what subscribers may watch, Mr. Dellinger replied, adding: "No newspaper has the authority to exclude others from entering the home."
If the argument at times had the quality of an interrupted conversation, there was a reason: this was the second time in three years that the case, Turner Broadcasting v. Federal Communications Commission, No. 95-992, was before the Court. In a 5-to-4 decision in 1994, the Court endorsed the general economic theory behind the Cable Television Consumer Protection Act of 1992, that cable's ability to exclude broadcast programming from a subscriber's home gives it the power to inflict economic harm on its broadcast rival.
But the Court, in an opinion by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, said the First Amendment would not permit the Government to turn cable operators into unwilling transmittors of others' speech without strong evidence of the damage that would occur without Government intervention. The Court sent the case back to a special three-judge Federal panel here, which reviewed tens of thousands of pages of evidence and upheld the must-carry rules on a 2-to-1 vote.
Many of the questions from the Justices today concerned how much and what type of harm would suffice to meet the Court's First Amendment standard. Mr. Dellinger said the public, particularly those without access to cable, would suffer if the broadcast stations that were shut out from cable became so weak economically that they could no longer provide high-quality programming.
Justice Stephen G. Breyer expressed doubt about that theory. Programming that is less expensive may nonetheless "be aimed more directly at the minority that doesn't have cable," he said, adding: "I see a theory, but no evidence that the minority has programming they find less desireable."
"Maybe people in the lower economic brackets don't necessarily want the History Channel," Chief Justice Rehnquist observed.
The Justices also had some tough questions for the lawyer representing the cable industry, H. Bartow Farr 3d. After Mr. Farr said that cable systems would voluntarily carry most broadcast signals, Justice Kennedy suggested that the industry was exaggerating the extent of the rules' burden.
"You can't have it both ways," Justice Kennedy said, adding that the cable industry was trying to argue that the requirement was both "terribly burdensome" and at the same time unnecessary, because cable systems would do what the law requires in any event.
Mr. Farr said the must-carry provisions were a burden because most cable systems are already at full capacity. To comply with the rules, he said, those systems have to eliminate programming they would prefer to carry in order to make room for the broadcast signals. He said the case posed the "fundamental question" of whether "Government can use the means of forcing access on private media to serve its goal of promoting broadcasting."
At one point in the argument, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor suggested that if the Government wanted to bolster broadcast television, it should do so with a direct subsidy. "Then you don't have to commandeer all these channels," she said.
Arguing for the broadcast industry, Bruce J. Ennis Jr. said it was "critical to the survival of broadcast television" to have access to cable. Several Justices questioned him about the fact that in the years before the must-carry rules took effect, only 31 broadcast stations failed out of some 8,000 that were denied a spot on their local cable systems.
Congress, in the 1992 law, was making a "predictive judgment" about the downward trend in the health of broadcast television, not simply looking at a "historical snapshot," Mr. Ennis replied.
Chief Justice Rehnquist was not satisfied. "How do you answer the fact that only 31 actually departed this world, so to speak," he asked.
As the Justices took their positions today for the opening of the term, many eyes in the courtroom were on Justice Scalia, who was known to have grown a beard over the summer recess. The question was whether he would keep the beard now that the recess was over. He did. The 60-year-old Justice, whose beard contains more than a hint of gray, became the first bearded member of the Court since Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes, who retired in 1941.
Clearing their calendar of the appeals that had piled up since the last term ended on July 1, the Justices denied review in more than 1,500 cases, including these:
 
Abortion Clinics
Without comment, the Court turned down a constitutional challenge to the 1994 Federal law that makes it a crime to use threats or force to block access to an abortion clinic or to harass or intimidate a clinic's patients and staff.
The law has now been upheld by all four Federal appeals courts to have reviewed it.
It was challenged in this case by six men who were arrested outside an abortion clinic in Milwaukee after they welded themselves to two automobiles they had used to block the entrance.
They argued that Congress lacked jurisdiction to pass the law because protests against abortion clinics were "wholly intrastate noncommercial activity" over which Congress had no authority.
The defendants had won an initial ruling from the Federal District Court in Milwaukee in 1995, in a decision that the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, overturned last December.
The appeals court held that Congress had the power to pass the law under its authority to regulate interstate commerce because the clinics "operate within the stream of interstate commerce" and patients travel across state lines for medical services.
The decision in this case, Skott v. U.S., No. 95-1523, was the third time the Court had turned down a challenge to the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act, and it is unlikely the Court would take such a case unless a split develops among the lower courts.
 
Judges' Taxes
The Court ordinarily turns down cases because not enough Justices are interested in hearing them. In one unusual case today, too many Justices were interested, in the sense of having a possible financial stake in the outcome. As a result, the Court lacked a quorum. The effect was to uphold a Federal appeals court's decision that a 1983 law subjecting Federal judges to Social Security and Medicare taxes for the first time had the unconstitutional effect of reducing their compensation.
The 1995 ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit came in a lawsuit by 16 Federal judges, all of whom were on the bench when the law took effect in 1984. They argued successfully that the new taxes violated the provision of Article III of the Constitution under which Federal judges' compensation "shall not be diminished during their continuance in office."
Steven Rosenthal, a lawyer for the judicial plaintiffs, said the judges who had joined this and other lawsuits -- about 80 judges -- might each receive as much as $75,000. There are several open issues in the case, however, including whether subsequent pay raises that all Federal judges have received could be deemed to have counteracted the effect of the taxes.
The Justices who took no part in the case, Justices O'Connor, Breyer, John Paul Stevens, and Ruth Bader Ginsburg, were all Federal judges in 1984, and theoretically could assert a similar claim. Chief Justice Rehnquist and Justices Scalia and Kennedy were also Federal judges in 1984, but the combination of subsequent promotions -- which entail resigning one judicial commission to accept another -- and the six-year statute of limitations has wiped out any claims they might have. Justices David H. Souter and Clarence Thomas were unaffected because they were not Federal judges in 1984.
Six Justices constituted the quorum necessary for the Court to act. The case was United States v. Hatter, No. 95-1733.
 
Sexual Harassment
Without comment, the Court denied review in a closely watched case on the question of whether Federal law makes a school district liable for failing to protect a student against sexual harassment by another student. In this case, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, ruled that the law, Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, which bars sex discrimination in education, did not apply to "peer sexual harassment."
The Clinton Administration joined an appeal by the mother of two teen-aged girls who were repeatedly harassed on the school bus by boys who received only light punishment from the Bryan, Tex., school district.
The Federal appeals court in Atlanta is currently considering the same issue, and the Justices may be awaiting the outcome of that review. This case was Rowinsky v. Bryan School District, No. 96-4.

HEADLINE: Saving New York Harbor

 BODY:
Yesterday's agreement between the Governors of New York and New Jersey to clear the shipping channels in New York Harbor is of great importance to the regional economy. The agreement is only a first step in a huge undertaking. But it starts a process that could preserve the local maritime industry, which provides the area with $20 billion in annual revenue and nearly 170,000 jobs.
Had nothing been done, the harbor could easily have closed down to major shipping within a decade. Three years ago new Federal regulations and an executive order by New Jersey's Governor, Christine Todd Whitman, halted ocean dumping of toxic silt that washes down the Hudson, Passaic and Raritan Rivers each year and settles in the harbor's 430 miles of berths and channels. Since there were few other places to put the silt, dredging stopped, the harbor clogged up and shippers began sending their deep-water container vessels to more accessible ports. 
 In July, the Clinton Administration came forward with a temporary fix. Vice President Gore announced that ocean dumping of lightly contaminated mud could resume off the New Jersey shore, but only for one year. The dump site would then be closed forever. Faced with this deadline, Mrs. Whitman and Gov. George Pataki of New York have now come forward with a plan that offers real hope.
In essence, the plan commits each state to provide $65 million to clear the channels of five million tons of silt over the next year and find new places to put it. Heavily contaminated silt will go into submerged pits in Newark Bay, which would then be capped; to a foundation for a shopping mall parking lot in Elizabeth, and possibly to highway projects. While tainted mud is a threat to marine life, it is not regarded as a hazard to humans if it is properly contained.
That should clear up the backlog. But it leaves untouched the larger problem of what to do with the three million tons of silt that will continue to accumulate each year. Dredged material has been used successfully in other parts of the country to create waterfront parks and artificial islands and to cover garbage in landfills. The plan calls for exploring these and other options, and also sets aside $20 million for research into "decontamination technologies" and ways to prevent pollution from occurring in the first place.
State and local funds will not be enough to keep the harbor open. For that reason the two Governors and local environmentalists are eagerly awaiting a report later this week from the Army Corps of Engineers, which is responsible for keeping many of the most important channels clear. The Corps will present its own menu of dredging and disposal options, perhaps laying the groundwork for increased Federal funding.
By the turn of the century, a new generation of even deeper-draft ships is expected to begin carrying goods directly from Asia to the East Coast. The prospect that the region could lose not only current business but also the hope of future growth lends added urgency to the need for comprehensive strategy. The agreement that both Governors have now signed on to is a solid beginning.

HEADLINE: U.S. Criticizes Turkish Leader For Libya Trip and Trade Deal

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The United States sharply criticized Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan of Turkey today for visiting Libya and signing a deal to triple trade with the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, which Washington accuses of sponsoring terrorism.
"We've got to stand together," the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, told reporters. 
 The Libyan media quoted Mr. Erbakan during his visit to Tripoli over the weekend as criticizing the United States and Israel and describing Libya itself as a victim of terrorism.
"I hope the Prime Minister didn't say those words," Mr. Burns said. "It would be highly surprising if the Prime Minister of an allied country, a NATO country, were to defend a terrorist like Muammar Qaddafi."
The United States has long led a campaign to isolate Libya politically and economically, and Libya is one of seven countries the State Department accuses of sponsoring international terrorism.
In 1992, the United Nations banned air travel and arms sales to Libya. The sanctions are aimed at pressing Libya to hand over two men suspected in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland.
Mr. Erbakan, Turkey's first Prime Minister from an Islamic party, came to power in June after promising to improve Turkey's relations with other Muslim countries.
In August, he visited Iran, which Washington also lists as a terrorist sponsor, and signed a multibillion-dollar natural gas deal. That visit drew similar criticism from the United States and other NATO allies.
"It's up to allies to be good allies and to understand you can't pick and choose places where you are going to support us or not support us," Mr. Burns said. "The United States remains troubled by any trip that could be seen as benefiting the Qaddafi regime."
The deal with Libya to triple trade was signed after 13 hours of talks between Mr. Erbakan and his Libyan counterpart, Abdel Majid el-Qaud. The agreement could raise trade between the two countries to nearly $2 billion a year.
Mr. Erbakan had threatened earlier to leave Libya without signing the agreement because Colonel Qaddafi had condemned a crackdown on ethnic Kurds in Turkey's southeast. He also previously said one goal of his trip was to get Libya to pay some $300 million owed to Turkish contractors, and reportedly made the deal contingent on payment of the debt.
In Tripoli, local media quoted the Turkish leader as describing Libya as being against terrorism and the victim of terrorism itself. He cited a United States air attack on Colonel Qaddafi's home in 1986.
Mr. Erbakan's visit was condemned by members of his own Cabinet. His coalition partner and Foreign Minister, Tansu Ciller, criticized the visit as ill timed and threatened to resign.

HEADLINE: Threat Seen to Catskills Trout;
Stream Repairs Worsened Flood Damage, Anglers Say

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: ROSCOE, N.Y.

 BODY:
The flood that swamped the western Catskills last January seemed insatiable, plucking trees out by their roots, plunging bridges into streams, wrecking homes and stores and leaving eight people dead.
 No one in this countryside famed for its two-foot wild trout could remember anything like it, and Federal officials declared the flood the state's worst calamity in 24 years. 
 Here and in the other mountain villages in Delaware and Sullivan Counties just beyond the Borscht Belt, people set to work, with the gritty resourcefulness that is a point of native pride and with $8.3 million in Federal and state emergency money. Throughout the winter and into summer, they launched an armada of bulldozers and tractor-driven shovels that reopened clogged roads and culverts under bridges and cleared the muck out of vital streams where brook, brown and rainbow trout spawn.
Now some people are saying that the flood relief was almost as harmful as the flood, that sloppy or excessive work had damaged two dozen glistening brooks and winding rivers, like the Beaverkill, that form the heart of this region's economy as the trout fishing capital of the East Coast.
With the spawning season just beginning, there is no evidence yet of a falloff in trout. But conservation groups like Trout Unlimited, a national organization of 95,000 members that strives to protect fish habitats, say that gravel and silt disturbed by excessive repair work ended up blocking tributaries that trout must enter to spawn. The work, these critics say, has also muddied or warmed cool-water pools in which the trout gather to rest or escape predators.
"The heavy equipment work represents a disaster for trout and the insects they feed on, one that will take years of careful work and lots of taxpayers' money to restore," said Jock Conyngham, a field biologist for Trout Unlimited. "Much of the critical habitat is now compromised."
Mr. Conyngham said much of the repair work was done carelessly and to excess as contractors tried to capitalize on the windfall of Federal aid. Enforcement of environmental regulations, he said, was lax. Though 1,000 permits were issued for stream repairs in Delaware County, the hardest hit of 41 counties affected by flooding, not a single summons for improper work was issued.
Environmental officials and local public works administrators conceded that some work had created as many problems as it cured, but they said those trouble spots were being repaired. Over all, the officials said, government workers and private contractors did the best they could, given the public outcry and pressure to free marooned families who needed to buy food and get to work.
"It was a natural disaster that tested all our resources," said Anthony F. Adamczyk, director of Region 4 of the State Department of Environmental Conservation. "In all honesty, it was not a time to get into a strong enforcement mode given the emotion that was there."
Strict supervision by an understaffed agency, he added, was not possible given the disaster's magnitude. Wayne D. Reynolds, public works commissioner of Delaware County, attributed most of the damage to the flood, which in some cases blanketed streams from bank to bank with rock and sand, leaving them impassable for trout.
Fishing this season has been better than in the drought-ridden previous two years, and state biologists suggested that Trout Unlimited was exaggerating the problem's gravity, since artificially raised fish outnumber wild fish in many local waterways.
But some of the men and women who fly fish the 87-mile-long Beaverkill and the linked east and west branches of the Delaware River say they have noticed more murkiness in the once vodka-clear water and a drop-off in the aquatic insects the trout feed on.
On a recent Monday, Bob LeDonne, a retired television news writer who has been fishing for 50 years, was wading hip-deep in the Beaverkill, flogging the air with his line until his fly landed in a spot he liked. He said he wondered whether the bulldozers working in nearby Horse Brook might have turned the river muddier and made it more difficult for fish to see his flies.
"Before, the river was so clear you were tempted to drink it on a hot day," he said. "It's tough enough fishing, but especially when the odds are against you like that."
Old Route 17 runs alongside Beaver Kill and crosses Horse Brook over a small bridge. Photographs taken for Mr. Reynolds show that debris seemed to fill a sizable stretch of the stream above the bridge, leaving only a small trickle into the Beaver Kill. The debris was cleaned out in the spring.
"The entire upstream channel was level bank to bank," Mr. Reynolds said. "I just put it back to what it was pre-existing."
But Mr. Conyngham said the workers widened the stream far beyond its original channel and churned up bank gravel that will be deposited downstream. He showed a reporter a three-foot rise of gravel that was now blocking much of the stream's mouth as it ran into Beaverkill. The channel, he said, was not deep enough to invite trout to spawn.
"They needed to clear the culvert, but they didn't need to do that," said Mr. Conyngham, a lean, intense man of 39 with a reddish-blond beard.
Mr. Adamczyk countered that much of the turbidity in the area's waterways was a result not of bulldozers but of the flood, which scoured away the banks and exposed underlying clay. One of his fisheries biologists, Kay Sanford, pointed out that gravel deltas were formed naturally whenever sloping brooks joined rivers.
Nevertheless, the state has asked the county's public works department to return to clear the gravel delta. At Read Creek, 10 miles north, it has also asked for work to reslope banks and reinforce them with rock walls, and to lay down boulders in midstream that can serve as fish sanctuaries.
Mr. Conyngham also showed a reporter Mountain Pool, a popular fishing spot in Beaverkill that he said had been muddied by work to shore up the Beaverkill banks. There he joined a landowner, Edward E. Eckel, 60, an expert fisherman and Trout Unlimited member, who said he had been told before the work started that two bulldozers and an excavator would shore up the banks by taking gravel from an island in the river. Less than half of the island should have been disturbed, but workers "scalped" it entirely of vegetation, he said.
Mr. Sanford, the fisheries biologist, said the work had been necessary. Sediment was coming not from the island, he said, but from an eroding bluff on one bank, which had to be resloped with dirt from the island.
The flood was generated by an untimely spell of warm weather. After heavy snows deposited a four-foot white pelt over the mountains, temperatures rose to the mid 50's and, along with a rainstorm, triggered a colossal meltdown. On Jan. 19 people awoke to find their roads and bridges impassable.
Gerald A. Barnhart, chief of fisheries for the environmental conservation department, said he grew up in Roscoe and "looked at streams I had played in all my life and I couldn't recognize them."
The Federal Emergency Management Agency described the disaster as the worst since Hurricane Agnes in 1972 and estimated the damage to 41 counties at $102 million. In the pandemonium, state officials issued permits for repairs on the spot, without demanding and reviewing construction sketches. Almost $50 million has already been spent on repairs.
Since Colonial days, roads have been built alongside the level ribbons of rivers and streams, but the required bridges and culverts -- tubes carrying water under roads -- create opportunities for bottlenecks. In the resulting flooding, streams leap out of their channels into the roads and deposit gravel in their beds or eat away at the manmade structures.
"Rivers and roads were not designed to go together," said Joe Rosa, a supervisor for Delhi Rock Drilling who was busy sloping banks on a recent Monday at a stream known as Fish Creek.
Floyd Franke, a fishing guide in the Roscoe area who has shepherded fishermen from as far away as Australia, saw the issue a little more skeptically, suggesting that highway contractors were not really meant to work in sensitive streams.
"If someone spends his life building roads, he ends up making the river look like a road," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Millions of dollars in government aid allowed work crews to repair flood damage to trout streams in the Catskills. An excavator reshaped the bed of Fish Creek. HEADLINE: High-Flying Quintiles to Buy Innovex in $747.5 Million Deal

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
The Quintiles Transnational Corporation, a rapidly growing drug research company that is a Wall Street favorite, said yesterday that it planned to buy Innovex Ltd. of Britain for $747.5 million in stock.
Quintiles said the deal would make it the world's biggest outside supplier of research and development to pharmaceutical, medical device and biotechnology companies. 
 Dennis Gillings, chairman and chief executive of Quintiles, said the combined client list included the 20 biggest American and European drug makers. Besides providing research, he said, Innovex rents out to drug makers a specialized sales force that includes people who had a part in the final development stages of new drugs.
Big drug companies are increasingly cutting fixed overhead costs by farming out part of their billion-dollar research pipelines to companies like Quintiles and Corning Pharmacueticals Services, a division that Corning Inc. plans to spin off this winter as a publicly traded company.
Under pressure from cost-conscious customers and profit-hungry investors, the drug makers have eliminated battalions of scientists, many of whom have moved to Quintiles headquarters in Research Triangle Park, N.C.
Quintiles stock jumped $5.031 yesterday, to $78.781 in Nasdaq trading, valuing the 10 million shares in the deal at $788 million. A year go, Quintiles traded at $26.25, adjusted for a stock split.
The current stock price exceeds 100 times 1995 earnings per share, reflecting Wall Street expectations for a continuation of the company's 74 percent surge in sales last year.
James S. Patricelli, a securities analyst with Adams Harkness & Hill in Boston, projects 61 percent growth in Quintiles earnings this year and 50 percent in 1997, which he said would be about 55 times the current stock price. Quintiles said Innovex would add 5 to 7 cents to earnings in 1997. Quintiles had $156.4 million in 1995 revenues. Innovex sales were $129.1 million for the year ended March 31.
"Quintiles is the best company in a tremendously fast-paced field, which is growing 20 to 25 percent a year," Mr. Patricelli said.
By keeping high-salaried scientists going full tilt and using electronic methods to analyze results, the independent research contractors say they can undercut the pharmaceutical giants' own costs. But Mr. Patricelli noted that "nobody can document the savings."
The pharmaceutical companies insist that huge research costs justify high prices for breakthrough drugs but they guard their numbers as trade secrets.
Under the deal, Quintiles will also assume $60 million in Innovex's debt. Mr. Gillings, the chief executive of Quintiles, will be chief of the combined company. A British-born statistician and former professor at the University of North Carolina, Mr. Gillings founded Quintiles in 1982.
In another deal last month, Quintiles agreed to buy BRI International Inc., a closely held research company, for about $134 million in Quintiles's high-flying stock.
"We are primarily an outsourcing and information company," Mr. Gillings said. "We sell a lot of information about pharmaceuticals and medical devices. We are beginning to move strongly into the health economics and outcomes research that determines whether large purchasers -- such as H.M.O.'s, insurance companies, large employers, the states and the World Health Organization -- regard the drugs as cost effective."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE THIRD PARTY;
Perot Demands That Clinton Unequivocally Rule Out Pardons

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7

 BODY:
After a month and half of sounding the alarm about the Federal debt and other issues, Ross Perot today sharply attacked President Clinton, asserting that he should unequivocally rule out Presidential pardons for associates who are in jail for Whitewater-related crimes.
"I guess a lot of you watched the debates last night," Mr. Perot said after pressing his case for high ethical standards during a speech to the American College of Surgeons here. "Can you believe that we have a President who has a number of associates who have gone to jail on financial issues that he was allegedly connected to, and he will not look the American people in the eye and say, 'If you re-elect me as President, I will not use that power to pardon my friends because if I don't, they are going to talk about me and do a plea bargain.' 
 "Now let me ask you, is it asking too much of the President to promise that he won't do that? I hope not."
After a burst of enthusiastic applause at the Moscone Center here, he repeated, "I hope not."
At the debate, held on Sunday night in Hartford, Mr. Clinton said that he had not considered any such pardons, adding, "I will not give anyone special treatment, and I will strictly adhere to the law."
Since he became the Reform Party's Presidential nominee in mid-August, Mr. Perot has criticized the Republican candidate, Bob Dole, especially after Mr. Dole's vigorous opposition to Mr. Perot's participation in the debates between the Presidential candidates. But today's attack on Mr. Clinton was a departure from his usual generic and even-handed appeals for change in a political system he contends is corrupt and dominated by special interests.
The Texas businessman's speech also included two indirect critiques of Mr. Clinton. But both were in keeping with his usual emphasis on issues.
Mr. Perot asserted that America's social programs started with "noble dreams" but have been broken for quite some time. He then criticized the White House study group that produced the Administration's health care bill in 1993, saying it could not solve the problems of the health care system, in particular, Medicare, because it had no doctors on it.
"The Medicare program is more complex than building the space shuttle," Mr. Perot said. "The space shuttle follows the laws of physics. Only in America would you have a task force with no doctors on it."
While the study group itself, headed by Hillary Rodham Clinton, did not have doctors among its members, there were doctors among the hundreds of advisers and consultants who helped the panel do its work.
After telling his audience that he would have been the preferred candidate in 1992 if Americans had voted their conscience, Mr. Perot referred to Mr. Clinton again indirectly and mildly, observing "You got what you voted for -- a winner."
Much of today's speech was full of statistics that Mr. Perot described as illustrating the grave threat that Federal debt posed to the nation's ability to remain an economic superpower. And when he got around to discussing the cause of the fiscal "mess," he distributed blame in equal amounts -- and with a pinch of sarcasm -- to Democrats and Republicans.
"The Democrats say they didn't do it," he said. "And the Republicans say they didn't do it. And each political party blames the other political party for doing it. But neither one says they did it. It's kind of like the O. J. trial. The facts are: there was nobody else around," he said, setting off a round of laughter and applause.
Mr. Perot also delivered mini-reviews of the debate in Hartford.
He said the Commission on Presidential Debates and its recommendation to exclude him favored the major parties, turning the Hartford debate into an entertainment event.
"If you have zip standing in the polls, and you are a Democrat or a Republican, you get to debate -- fascinating," he said. "But five Democrats and five Republicans decided, we don't want this, we want a nice tight, little theatrical event, which you saw last night."
In 1992, Mr. Perot took part in all three Presidential debates.
At another point, Mr. Perot gave Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole bad reviews, asserting that neither had tried to rebut the charges made by the other in a substantive way. "In 1996 we are still being manipulated by propaganda and negative ads that have nothing to do with the facts," he said. "And if you listened last night, it was confusing because they were both playing Ping-Pong in denying what the other said and not getting to the facts."
Several times during his speech, Mr. Perot urged the surgeons to take the lead in drafting a health care policy for the nation. Since neither party is trying to solve the nation's health care problems, he said, he suggested that the doctors raise $60 million for 30-minute infomercials and take their plan to their patients: the American people.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE VOTERS;
In Debate's Aftermath, Coffee and No Surprises

SERIES: AN AMERICAN PLACE: By and Large, Unimpressed

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Perhaps the first debate of this Presidential campaign will change the minds of some voters, but if that is the case, it was awfully hard to find any evidence of it here, whether you were looking at the oldest newsstand downtown or the just-opened Borders in The Strip, a suburban shopping complex so new, trucks are still busy spraying the dirt green.
"I'd call it a draw," said Jack Baker, a lawyer who stopped to pick up his daily newspaper at the News Depot downtown near the courthouse and who is undecided about how he will vote this time. "It was what I expected going in." 
 "A wash," said Johnny Miller, a Kent State University professor and Clinton supporter who was at the 30,000-square-foot Borders in suburban Jackson to pick up a copy of "Nordstrom Way: The Inside Story of America's Number One Customer Service Company." "If you need to call it something, call it a wash."
"Neither stuck out," said Pat Hassig, a retired nurse from North Canton shopping at Borders who favors Bob Dole.
On the plus side, people seemed grateful for the civility of the debate. "I was surprised by how polite they were to each other," said Cathy Kelty, who holds two part-time jobs. Several remarked about appreciating Mr. Dole's humor. "It was a side I'd never seen before," said Charles Mailat, a retired teacher. "And I enjoyed the way Clinton accepted the jokes."
On the minus side, people seemed a little shellshocked by all the numbers, the dates, the quotations and counter-quotations that were amassed on each side and then hurtled back and forth. Tom Cwynar, who made his usual Monday morning stop at the News Depot to pick up The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette to get some good Steelers stories, felt like he was being punted back and forth the whole 90-minute debate. "You see a lot of half-truths, half the facts to prove your point and then leave the other half out," he said. "I'll put you down for the N.R.A. and I'll put you down for the drug stuff."
"Everything they said was so ridiculously filled with numbers," said Tia Weber, who was reading at the Borders bistro, which offers 13 coffee selections. "I thought Bob Dole tried to pack so much in when he spoke about economics, he sounded confused. He was so busy punching out numbers I felt sorry for him."
Part of the reason for the muted reaction may be that people tuned in expecting to see some big surprise from Mr. Dole because he is trailing so in the polls. Instead they saw a man who came across simply as intelligent, prepared and funny.
Though Ohio still seems within reach for Mr. Dole -- he is trailing by 8 percentage points in the latest statewide University of Cincinnati poll released just before the debate -- there is a fatalism creeping into the voices of even the Republican faithful here.
"The only way Clinton's going to lose," said Ms. Weber, "is if Chelsea's caught smoking crack. My father's such a Republican, he's going to kill me for saying that."
When asked for her reaction to the debate, Darlene Stermer, a professional astrologer inspecting the selection at Borders, said, "Not much." She will vote for Mr. Dole, because she says, he has the better ideas. "Clinton is two-faced," she said, "but his chart is very good, it's highlighted for the coming election. He's going to win, astrologically speaking."
Despite all the facts and figures, a frustration mentioned by many was the absence of in-depth discussion of most issues and the proliferation of the sound bite. Martha Lottman, who is involved with Head Start and the Jewish community here, was disappointed to hear nothing new on welfare or health care.
William Friedman, a driver for the post office, had to be up at 2 this morning for work, but still wanted to see the debate. He said he was disappointed that there was no talk of the homeless or poor. "When I was driving by the mental health center at 5 this morning," he said, "there were two men waiting to get in who had no place to stay last night. There's homeless in Canton, Ohio."
To a great extent people seemed to take from the debate as confirmation of what they already felt. Allan White, a starter at the Bob-O-Link golf course, voted for George Bush in '92, but this time will be voting for Mr. Clinton, because, he says, the Democrats are more likely to protect people who face downsizing. ("Their constituents will kill them if they don't.")
"Did you see the shots of Clinton and Dole side by side?" he said. "Poor Dole, geriatric people have their rights, but I don't want him running the country." He was voting Clinton anyway, he says, but "I feel a little better about casting my vote now." And Leanne Barton, who watched a replay of the debate at 2 A.M. as she fed her 3-month-old Halie, said, "I've always liked Clinton, I'm for Clinton all the way, I thought he did great."
Sam Sliman, father of six, who owns the News Depot and holds two other jobs, did not see it that way. As he finished stacking the papers this morning for the 8 o'clock opening, Mr. Sliman, a Republican, said, "Bill Clinton's very smooth -- geez, he can deliver a speech on a dime. But you could see Bob Dole's integrity. I thought Bob Dole did better than I thought he would."
And Mr. Baker, the lawyer who is still undecided but usually votes Republican, is pretty sure what will happen over the next two weeks. "Clinton's done a good job moving to the middle," he said. "It makes it a difficult choice for someone with a Republican background like me. I'll keep watching and looking for signs from Mr. Dole and eventually I'll probably find enough things and I'll vote for him."
A few took into account the impossibly high standards voters hold for the Presidential candidates. Mr. Mailat, the teacher said, "They both seemed nervous at the beginning." And Robert Horowitz, the county prosecutor who comes in for his Akron Beacon-Journal every morning at the News Depot, noted, "I've seen both do better."
For years Lydia Goebeler, 85, and Mary Salvador, 83, have been coming into the News Depot, where there are only two kinds of coffee (with or without caffeine), but it is still just 50 cents a cup. Both are quite active (Ms. Salvador recently hurt her back putting in storm windows). They read all about the intense preparation the two candidates made for the Presidential debates, and they were ready to stay up Sunday night and watch.
"At the start I thought Clinton was winning," said Ms. Salvador.
"Oh yes," said Ms. Goebeler. "I did too."
"And then I fell asleep," said Ms. Salvador.
"I fell asleep, too," said Ms. Goebeler. "Right at the start."
"And the next thing I woke up," said Ms. Salvador, "and Bob Dole was saying 'God Bless America,' and it was over."
Both describe themselves as loyal Democrats who will vote for Mr. Clinton. "Dole is too old," said Ms. Salvador.
"He is," said Ms. Goebeler.
Living midway between Democratic Cleveland and Republican Columbus, the citizens of Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County have a history of voting for the winning Presidential candidate. This is the 28th article in a yearlong series that seeks to explore the forces shaping the political debate at the grass roots. (Previous articles are available to computer users on The New York Times on the Web, at http://www.nytimes.com/specials/canton.)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;
Clinton Shows That He, Too, Has Support Of Executives

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Oct. 7

 BODY:
Relaxed and folksy on the day after the first Presidential debate of the campaign, President Clinton today showcased his support from business executives and then barnstormed through New England to lure Northeastern Republican moderates to his side.
Mr. Clinton repeatedly stressed his fiscal policies and the economic growth of the past four years. "People tell me in Washington, 'Now don't go anywhere and talk about balancing the budget because it bores people now and it requires tough decisions,' " he said at a rally here in New Hampshire, which was battered by the recession of the early 1990's. "But it's important. Why? Because these declining deficits have meant as the Government borrows less money, it's easier for you to borrow money." 
 The President's post-debate campaign schedule almost seemed fashioned to taunt Bob Dole, as Mr. Clinton highlighted endorsements from business executives that served to undercut his Republican opponent's contention that the economy is stagnant, and campaigned in three states -- Connecticut, New Hampshire and Maine -- that have been Republican bastions in many previous Presidential races.
"I think part of today's message," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, is for Republicans in the more moderate wing of the party to "feel comfortable with Bill Clinton."
Mr. Clinton's first stop was in Stamford, Conn., where about 300 business executives turned out at the Stamford Center for the Arts to support the President. The Clinton campaign released the names of 2,591 business leaders who were endorsing him across the country.
Eli Segal, the head of the campaign's business outreach program, said that on the day after the debate "the President came to Stamford to show again that he is not a liberal, that he is a mainstream American, a mainstream President who has reached out to the business community."
Mr. Dole on Wednesday night had argued that the economy showed "the slowest growth in a century" and said "we've got stagnant wages; in fact, women's wages have dropped 2.2 percent. Men's wages haven't gone up, gone down." But today the chief executives applauded repeatedly as business leaders from their ranks spoke of low inflation, low interest rates and economic growth.
The speakers endorsing Mr. Clinton included George David, who is president and chief executive of United Technologies and who voted for George Bush in 1992; and William T. Esrey, the chairman and chief executive of Sprint, who introduced Mr. Clinton. The President's aides said Mr. Esrey is a Republican and one of the largest employers in Kansas, Mr. Dole's home state.
Mr. Esrey -- who has made contributions in this campaign of $1,000 each to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Dole and to Steve Forbes, who ran against Mr. Dole in the Republican primaries -- said that the Clinton campaign's feelers about an endorsement "produced a dialogue within my company which I'm sure has been echoed in boardrooms across America." He added, "What's driven that dialogue is the growing realization by corporate America that Democrat Bill Clinton has been good for American business."
Mr. Clinton told the business officials how gratified he was that they were willing to look at a Democrat. "This is a country with a strong private economy," Mr. Clinton said. "And if it doesn't work, then our aspirations for all the people we want to help can never, never, never be fulfilled by anything the government does. If there is not an effective partnership that is founded on a successful private economy, the rest of our endeavors are doomed to be thwarted."
In a long and rambling speech calling on business to help provide jobs for welfare recipients, Mr. Clinton did not mention his debate with Mr. Dole and brought it up only in passing in New Hampshire where he said, "I enjoyed that debate and I thank Senator Dole for joining me, and I believe that the American people got a pretty good feel for the differences between us."
But Mr. Clinton's aides asserted that the first of two nationally televised debates had gone their way, with Mr. Dole doing nothing to erode Mr. Clinton's large lead. They pointed both to their own instant poll conducted as the debate was taking place and several public polls.
"The fundamental nature of this race needed to be changed -- that's what we saw as the challenge for the Dole campaign," said Joe Lockhart, Mr. Clinton's campaign spokesman. "We essentially see the race this morning the way we saw it yesterday, a week ago, three months ago."
Mr. Clinton's advisers said that they would make no change in strategy as a result of the first debate, which traditionally is called the most crucial of the campaign season and the one with the most potential to change the dynamics of a race. Mr. McCurry called Mr. Clinton "quite happy with the outcome last night."
As the Presidential race moves into its final weeks, Mr. Clinton planned to campaign not only in traditional battleground states but to put time and money into states considered out of the Democrats' grasp in the past. Douglas Sosnik, the White House political director, cited Florida, Georgia, Virginia, Oklahoma and Arizona.
Connecticut, New Hampshire and Maine all voted for Mr. Clinton in 1992, but he won New Hampshire by only one percentage point and his victory in Maine was attributed in large part to the fact that it was Ross Perot's strongest state in 1992, giving him 30 percent of its vote.
Polls in September gave Mr. Clinton double-digit leads in all three states.

HEADLINE: Consumers' Borrowing Slows Sharply

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Consumer borrowing grew at a much slower pace than expected, the Federal Reserve said today.
Americans' consumer credit rose $3.3 billion in August to $1.167 trillion, down from July's revised increase of $7.3 billion. Previously, the Fed said July borrowing rose $7.7 billion. Analysts had expected an August increase of $7 billion. 
 The growth rate in August was 3.5 percent at an annual rate, the slowest pace since May 1993.
After a three-year borrowing binge that nearly doubled the borrowing total, the August slowdown suggests "consumers' debt burden is much too high and people can't keep up that pace of borrowing," said Kevin Flanagan, an economist with Dean Witter Reynolds in New York. He added, "Consumer spending could slow accordingly."
The borrowing slowdown may be linked to a new cautious attitude by lenders in response to an increase in bankruptcy filings by consumers and a surge in credit card delinquencies.
"This number is telling us a lot of the delinquent consumer credit out there is starting to bite," said Anthony Chan, chief economist with the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio. "We're moving to a slightly slower growth patch in the economy."
For retailers, the report may be a warning that consumer demand will prove disappointing for the second consecutive year during the holiday shopping season, analysts said. But other analysts said too much should not be read into one month's report.
"Consumers are still sufficiently confident to continue purchasing on credit," said Lynn Reaser, chief economist with Barnett Banks in Jacksonville, Fla.
Today's Fed report showed that credit card borrowings rose $2.8 billion in August, auto loans increased by $200 million and other types of personal loans rose by $400 billion.
The Fed report showed that auto loans inched up $200 million in August, at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent, sharply below July's $2 billion increase, when auto loans were growing at an annual rate of 6.7 percent.
Revolving, or credit card, debt in August also grew much more slowly, by $2.8 billion, at a 7.5 percent annual rate, only half the $5.6 billion July advance, when it was expanding at a 15.2 percent annual rate.
Other credit grew by $400 million, at a 1.3 percent annual rate, in August. The Fed's report does not track loans secured by real estate.

HEADLINE: Best Products to Shut 81 Stores and Let 4,500 Workers Go

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
The Best Products Company, the struggling Richmond-based catalogue-showroom retailer that sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month, announced yesterday that it would close 81 of its 169 stores and would dismiss 4,500 employees, or 45 percent of its work force.
The majority of the closings are planned in the West and Southwest, including 24 stores in California, 13 stores in Washington, 8 stores in Texas and 7 stores in Colorado. 
 Best sells products as diverse as jewelry, home furnishings, toys and electronics in 23 states. After the closings, to be completed in December, it will have 88 stores in 17 states. In addition, Best plans to close three of its four distribution centers -- in Denver, Seattle and Las Vegas, Nev. -- that employ about 75 people.
Analysts said Best had been unable to compete not only against mass merchants like Wal-Mart and Kmart, but also against high-end department stores.
"They sell low-quality merchandise in so-so retail locations that don't attract traffic," said Peter A. Chapman, president of Bankruptcy Creditors' Service Inc., a research consulting firm in Princeton, N.J.
Best emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for the first time in June 1994. It has posted losses for the last six quarters and last year had revenues of $1.49 billion. "Best was too highly leveraged after that, and in an economic setting where retail sales are lackluster, it's hard for Best to make interest payments," Mr. Chapman said.
Daniel H. Levy, Best's chief executive, said in a statement that it was more efficient to close a large number of stores now. "We believe it's in the best interests of the company and its associates to finalize closing plans now and remove questions about which locations will continue to operate," he said.
The plight of Best is familiar in a hypercompetitive environment where other troubled retailers have been squeezed not only by strong price competition but also by impatient creditors and lenders.
"Last year was one of the worst years we've seen since the Depression, as far as the retail environment is concerned," Donald T. Spindel, a retail analyst with A. G. Edwards & Sons, said.
Among last year's filings for bankruptcy protection were those of the Caldor Corporation, the Petrie Stores Corporation and Edison Brothers Stores Inc. The Jamesway Corporation asked for Chapter 11 protection in 1995, emerged and then was liquidated last spring. And Herman's Sporting Goods Inc., the sports retailer, filed for bankruptcy last April and then was liquidated.
"I think that the best Best strategy would be to liquidate all the stores over Christmas," Mr. Chapman said. "A well-run liquidation sale could do a bang-up job in recovering a lot of their inventory."
But Ross O. Richardson, a company spokesman, said that "in our opinion, the best way to improve the value of the company is to continue to reorganize it," adding that the company is trying to make the transition to specialty retailer.
The company said that each store had an average of about 25 full-time employees and 30 part-time workers, and that a total of 2,000 full-time and 2,500 part-time workers would be let go. The company employs about 5,500 people in operations not involving the stores to be closed.
On Sept. 3, Best received a bid of $68.7 million, or $2 a share, from Ocean Reef Management Inc., a Miami investment firm. But two weeks later, Ocean Reef withdrew its offer, saying Best needed more financial support than it had expected.
In late September, Best said it was delaying some vendor payments and filed for bankruptcy protection.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Loss at Advanced Micro Smaller Than Expected

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 7

 BODY:
Advanced Micro Devices Inc., which has been trying to revamp its Pentium-class processor unit and return to profitability, today reported a third-quarter loss that was narrower than expected.
The company reported a loss of $38.4 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with earnings of $42 million, or 30 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue fell 25 percent, to $456.9 million from $607 million. Wall Street had expected a loss of 37 cents, based on the average estimate of 21 analysts surveyed by IBES International Inc. 
 The results were reported after the stock market closed. But in after-hours trading, shares of Advanced Micro surged 87.5 cents to $15.75.
The third-quarter results reflected a restructuring charge of about $6 million after the company, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., dismissed 200 of its 15,200 employees because of weak demand.
Earnings for 1995 were restated to reflect the company's $623.2 million acquisition of Nexgen Inc., which it completed in January.
In the second quarter, Advanced Micro Devices had a loss of $34.7 million, or 26 cents a share, its first loss in more than five years, as the company struggled to introduce a chip that could compete with the Intel Corporation's industry-standard Pentium.
Advanced Micro said sales were improving in the unit that makes its Pentium-class chips, but not enough to make the business profitable yet.
"Over all, bookings improved significantly from the levels of the second quarter," but shipments are still outpacing new orders, W. J. Sanders 3d, the company's chairman, said in a statement.
Sales of telecommunications products and other businesses are also growing, Mr. Sanders said. Sales of the company's flash memory chips, which retain data when power is turned off, have also rebounded.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
Intel Cancels Meeting
By Bloomberg Business News
The Intel Corporation yesterday canceled its semiannual analyst meeting, citing a California ballot initiative that it said would make it easier for shareholders to sue companies.
Intel said it would not give any more forecasts because it was concerned that the initiative, Proposition 211, would increase "frivolous" shareholder lawsuits.
"We are trying to be pro-active and have ourselves protected if it does pass," the company's chief financial officer, Andy Bryant, said. The meeting with analysts had been scheduled for Nov. 1.
Intel, the world's largest chipmaker, said it would not include such statements at any meetings or in quarterly earnings announcements except as required by law.
The company usually gives some indication of orders being booked or the outlook for the following quarter. That information is used by analysts and investors as an indication of future demand and earnings for personal computers and chipmakers as well as software companies.
Intel is one of many Silicon Valley companies that have come out against the initiative. The American Electronics Association said last week that 47 percent of its public member companies would consider leaving California if the initiative passed on Nov. 5.
