HEADLINE: Federal Government Uses North's and Midwest's Dollars to Aid the South, Study Says

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Many states in the Northeast and the Middle West pay more in Federal taxes than they receive in Federal spending, while many Southern states are subsidized by the Federal Government, a new study shows.
Connecticut and New Jersey were the biggest "donor states" last year, and New York has consistently been among the large donors. 
 New Mexico, Virginia and Mississippi had the biggest surpluses, receiving far more in Federal outlays than they paid in Federal taxes.
The study, by researchers at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, said that Connecticut's tax payments to the Federal Government exceeded Federal spending in the state by an average of $2,099 for each resident last year. New Jersey had a deficit averaging $1,883 for each of its residents, while New York had an average deficit of $978 for each resident.
The report, issued by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, concludes that "the Federal Government is a major force in the geographic distribution of economic activity," though sometimes in ways that were not foreseen or intended.
The study measures the "balance of payments" for each state, defined as the difference between the Federal spending it receives and the taxes it pays.
Mr. Moynihan did the first such study 20 years ago to support his contention that New York had, in some ways, been treated unfairly. Since 1992, the body of the report has been prepared by Harvard researchers. The authors this year were Monica E. Friar, Herman B. Leonard and Jay H. Walder.
The latest study examines the flow of Federal money to and from all states and disavows any premise that states should get back precisely as much as they pay to the Federal Government. Indeed, the authors said, some redistribution of resources is inherent in the concept of America as a union of states in which people and commerce move freely across state borders.
The report made these points:
*"New Jersey, with high per capita incomes and Federal tax payments, receives relatively little in the way of Federal expenditures." The state is not a major center of military spending and, with a comparatively low poverty rate, gets a small share of Federal welfare spending.
*With income levels far exceeding the national average, "Connecticut residents consistently lead the nation in Federal taxes paid" per capita. "As a result, Connecticut contributes far more in taxes than it receives back in Federal spending."
*In the last decade, four New England states (Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Vermont) and three Western states (California, Hawaii and Washington) experienced significant changes for the worse in their balance of payments with the Federal Government.
*New York regularly ranks among the top states in Federal tax payments, "a direct result of high per capita income." But it is consistently below the national average in the amount of Federal spending it receives for each resident.
Speaker Newt Gingrich said last year that New York could not expect the Federal Government to subsidize its "culture of waste." But Mr. Moynihan said the new data showed that things were really the other way around: New York has been subsidizing Georgia and other Southern states for years.
Southern and Sunbelt states have a different perspective. Elizabeth G. Schneider, executive director of the Southern Governors' Association, said it was natural that the South should get a large portion of Federal spending because many Americans were choosing to retire there. In addition, she said, the region has a higher poverty rate than the rest of the country and has many military bases.
Debby K. Kilmer, director of the Washington office for the State of Florida, said that Southern states generally paid more in gasoline taxes than they received in Federal money for construction of highways. With the South and the West growing faster than Northeastern states, she said, it is proper that "dollars should follow the people."
The study finds that military spending, though cut in recent years, remains an important factor in determining the balance of payments for many states. Federal benefit programs have become more important, but payments to the elderly, not the poor, account for the bulk of this spending.
The net influx of Federal money accounted for more than 10 percent of per capita income in New Mexico, Mississippi and Virginia, the study said. Virginia, home to the Pentagon and many naval installations, attracted large amounts of military spending. New Mexico's nuclear weapons industries also attracted large sums of Federal money. Mississippi had a large surplus because, with low incomes and a high poverty rate, it generates a relatively small amount of taxes and receives large amounts of Federal aid.
Mr. Moynihan said, "New York does very well in a category of Federal spending that might best be described as disaster relief," which includes Medicaid and welfare payments for the poor. But he said the state had made "the worst possible use" of the money it has received for job programs, sending welfare recipients to school rather than to work.

(Source: "The Federal Budget and the States," Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Profit Taking Pushes Bond Prices Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices retreated yesterday as investors moved to consolidate recent gains, particularly those made on Friday following an employment report that showed unexpected weakness.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 16/32, to 99 18/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.78 percent, from 6.74 percent on Friday. 
 "Concerns that the market may have gotten a bit ahead of itself in recent weeks found expression in Monday's pullback," said Joel Marver, chief technical analyst at Technical Data in Boston.
Dealers and traders were also busy setting up yesterday in preparation for today's $10 billion Treasury auction of new 10-year notes, another factor that weighed on prices yesterday.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the new 10-year was being offered at a price to yield 6.50 percent, down 3 basis points from Friday, to see if that yield would generate enough investor interest. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Bond prices received a slight lift late in the afternoon from a Federal Reserve report that showed consumer credit grew $3.3 billion in August, a much slower pace of growth than had been expected. Economists were looking for an increase of $7 billion in August.
The report was the latest bit of evidence to suggest that economic growth was slowing, which should cause interest rates to remain stable.
Such a view of the economy appeared to be confirmed on Friday, when the September employment report showed an unexpected drop. Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, noted that the market understandably celebrated the weak September payroll report, but he worried whether the October data would be a repeat or reversal.
Still, he said, third-quarter growth has slowed from the too-hot pace of the second quarter and for the moment has taken the pressure off the Fed to raise short-term interest rates.
In bond futures trading, which affects the cash market for current issues, support for the December bond contract was seen at Friday's post-employment low price of around 111 4/32. Anything below that, traders said, was seen as spurring sales.
"Unless the market decays below a price of 109 29/32, we need to continue a buy strategy for a move to 116 to 122," Robin Mesch, chief fixed-income analyst at Thomson Research of Boston, said.
She added that the market could well be in a precarious pricing range, since it was from these levels that the market broke down in August to 105 7/32. "We are alert to what type of price action would herald that type of decline again," she said.
"A price of 109 28/32 is really like the point of no return," Ms. Mesch said. "But until then, we'll be looking to buy right to 110 20/32 this week." She agreed that the market was somewhat overbought, "but many a major upward move in the market has started from overbought levels."
The December contract closed at 111 6/32, down 17/32 from Friday.
The results of yesterday's $26 billion Treasury bill auction of three- and six-month bills were in line with market expectations. The average discount rate for a three-month bill was at 4.96 percent and the six- month, 5.07 percent, both down from the auction a week ago.
Dealers, who had been expecting decent demand, were a bit disappointed. But then, few expected the bills to be bid aggressively since market participants seem to be waiting for more economic data before making their next investment moves.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Where Was Character?

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Bob Dole entered Sunday's Presidential debate with two political handicaps. He emerged with three.
The first handicap was President Clinton. He achieved so large an October lead in the polls the way his critics thought he never could: by convincing enough Americans that he had looked after their economic and social interests and would continue to do exactly that in a second term. 
 Mr. Dole's second handicap is his own campaign. It was successful in only one goal: Say Dole and you think tax cuts.
The problem is that American voters believe that Mr. Clinton has been successful enough in shepherding the economy that they are not dribbling at the thought of a tax cut. Without how-to details from Mr. Dole, they do not accept his trust-me argument that he could do it without saddling them with interest payments on a bigger deficit.
The third handicap is a brand new one created by Mr. Dole and the geniuses who prepped him for the debate. Mr. Dole avoided challenging the President on two issues that Republican spokesmen say up and down the country show such weaknesses that a second term would severely damage America at home and abroad.
They are Whitewater and character. Mr. Dole failed to bring them up, except glancingly, and marginally.
All he said about Whitewater was that the President should announce that he would not grant a pardon to anybody convicted in the affair. That would be wrong for any President to say about any people still to face trial.
But pardon has not been the heart of Republican Whitewater charges, barely a toe. The allegations are that Mr. Clinton and his wife are guilty of something, that cover-up was going on in the White House, and even that the death of Vincent Foster, the Clintons' aide, was connected.
Those are charges of utmost seriousness. Any one of them could bring down a Presidency if true, and is villainous mischief if not. If Mr. Dole is too delicate or too uncertain to bring them up directly in nationally seen debate, continued Republican attacks about Whitewater will smell fraudulent.
Character: Mr. Dole brought it up obliquely by referring to drugs as something in the President's past, presumably using marijuana as a young man. But it is demeaning the issue to hang it on that.
At home character includes hiding files, misusing the White House against opponents and allowing Presidential aides to keep security clearances after they contemptuously evaded F.B.I. background checks.
In foreign policy the issue cuts even deeper.
Republican foreign policy experts accuse Mr. Clinton of squandering American prestige by refusing effective action to stall or punish Saddam Hussein for moving armed forces into Kurdish territory supposed to be within U.N. shelter. Mr. Dole said correctly that Saddam was stronger now than before his latest military adventure.
But there is a character issue involved in Mr. Clinton's conduct of foreign policy that Mr. Dole skipped over. That is the price of Mr. Clinton's inconstancy toward nations and movements he had promised to befriend, and its risks to the U.S.
The first to suffer from this unbecoming Presidential habit were Chinese Communist dissidents and Tibet, the victim of almost a half-century of Chinese occupation and oppression. Mr. Clinton hailed them one year and walked away from his official promises the next in submission to pressures from the Chinese Communist Government and the American lobby of businesses in the China trade. The failure of Mr. Clinton about Iraq, and the decision to walk away from the Kurds, was the latest inconstancy.
The debate was Mr. Dole's chance to point out that Mr. Clinton's character trait of inconstancy is a warning sign to all nations and peoples, that the word of American Presidents may amount to no more than a helicopter helping America's friends flee their own country. Mr. Dole missed it.
The debate will not decide the election, or many votes. For him or against him, Americans understand that if Mr. Clinton wins it will be because the country prefers his achievements, whatever his faults, to Mr. Dole's promises, whatever his virtues. Mr. Clinton has fought hard twice for the Presidency. He never got a free ride, not before Mr. Dole's generosity Sunday night.

HEADLINE: Dow Breaches 6,000 Before Falling 13.05

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average topped the 6,000-point level for the first time yesterday before ending lower on profit taking, but the Nasdaq index attained its first closing high in four months as technology stocks rallied.
The Dow index of 30 blue-chip stocks closed down 13.05 points at 5,979.81 following a brief run-up to 6,002.17. The broader-based Nasdaq composite index rose 3.31 points, to 1,250.87, eclipsing its June 5 high close of 1,249.15. That record was set before the summer's market swoon that hit technology stocks particularly hard. 
 Also in the broader market, declining issues barely led advancing ones, 1,230 to 1,145, on moderate volume of 381.9 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts said the Dow was due for a pause. It had set its 27th high close for the year on Friday at 5,992.86, as a weaker-than-expected report on September jobs lessened Wall Street's fears that the Federal Reserve would need to raise interest rates to slow the economy's growth.
"We're recovering from a little nosebleed after Friday's highs and some people are taking profits off the table," said Ken Ducey, head of trading at BT Brokerage. "People seem fairly convinced sometime this week we'll close above 6,000."
Other stock market gauges also set new milestones, with the Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks gaining 1.88 points, to 703.34, its fifth closing high in the last six trading sessions. The New York Stock Exchange composite index was at a new high, up 0.58 point, to 374.74.
William LeFevre, senior analyst at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum, was unfazed by the 6,000-point milestone.
"It's a bull market," he said. "Relax and enjoy it."
As for yesterday's trading, Peter Canelo, chief investment strategist at Dean Witter, said: "A couple of the Dow stocks got hurt, but oils are very strong and some tech stocks are doing well. The market is consolidating after a big move Friday."
The bulk of the Dow's losses came from Eastman Kodak, which fell 3 1/4, to 75 3/8. The company's chairman, George Fisher, said that it might be embroiled in a dispute over opening the Japanese film market for 18 more months.
Oil stocks were bolstered by news of a planned merger of the United States refining and marketing operations of three of the world's largest oil companies -- Texaco, Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Star Enterprise, a joint venture between Texaco and the state oil company of Saudi Arabia, Saudi Aramco.
Texaco rose7/8 a share, to 96 1/2, and Chevron rose 7/8, to 65 3/8, 52-week highs for both.
Technology stocks were buoyed by speculation that the group would report upbeat earnings for the latest quarter. On Nasdaq, the technology stocks that led the rally that finally reached a new record yesterday were mainly blue chips such as the Microsoft Corporation. Investors have bought these less volatile stocks since the market fall during the summer.
Among the winners yesterday: Intel rose 2 15/16 to 104 5/8; Microsoft was up 1 1/8 to 137 1/2; I.B.M. added 1 1/4, to 127 7/8; Hewlett-Packard was up 2 1/4, to 45 7/8, and Motorola was up 1 1/2, to 49 3/4.
Cheyenne Software climbed 7 45/64, to 30 5/64 after Computer Associates International, which gained 1 3/4, to 64 1/2, agreed to buy Cheyenne for $1.2 billion in cash.
Thomas & Betts, a maker of electrical equipment, agreed to buy Augat, a manufacturer of circuit connection products, in a stock deal valued at $550 million; Thomas & Betts lost 1 7/8, to 37 7/8, and Augat climbed 4 3/8, to 25 1/4.
Westell Technologies tumbled 12 3/8, to 34. Alcatel of France won a contract to supply modem technology to four regional Bell companies, a contract some had expected Westell to win.
Earthgrains surged 6, to 45, on unexpectedly strong earnings.

HEADLINE: Behind a Suburban Facade in Queens, A Teeming, Angry Urban Arithmetic

SERIES: BARELY FOUR WALLS: Housing's Hidden Crisis -- Third of Six Articles

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI with DEBORAH SONTAG 

 BODY:
By day, the neighborhood holds its secret close, presenting the same front it has for decades: tidy parallel lines of two- and three-story houses with tiny but verdant front lawns and a sliver of driveway space between them.
But come nightfall, when residents trickle home from work, the blocks around 90th Avenue and 102d Street in Richmond Hill, Queens, reveal the telltale cracks in their semisuburban facade. 
 Cars that do not fit in the driveways line the curbs, cluttering and narrowing the roads. People huddle on stoops, in numbers greater than one would expect from the size of the brick and wood-frame houses. Windows glow brightly in attics and even basements; the silhouettes of parents and children scuttle constantly through them.
All are clues to the existence of three or four apartments, and from a dozen to two dozen occupants, in houses legally designed for just one or two families.
"These look like nice private homes," said Simcha Waisman, president of the Richmond Hill Block Association. "But many of them aren't. You have to look closely. You have to look for the extra utility meters and the amount of garbage being put out. You wouldn't believe the number of people living in some of these places."
Throughout the city, the combination of stubborn poverty and a dwindling supply of affordable housing has led to a surge in illegal apartments, wedged into virtually any available nook or cranny. The problem is not confined to the most blighted neighborhoods, where it would barely be noticed.
But in Queens, an explosion of illegal conversions over the last decade has utterly transformed even the leafier reaches of a borough that once fancied itself the tranquil gateway to Long Island, but is increasingly becoming the chaotic terminus of New York City.
In the more urban parts of the borough, this phenomenon of illegal residences has produced squalid scenes to rival the most disturbing tableaux in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx: recent immigrants spread out on bare mattresses in the basements of large apartment buildings or crowded into jerry-rigged structures little better than shanties.
But the problem more often manifests itself in a different, subtler and ultimately more disruptive manner, creating thousands of illegal apartments and pockets of mild poverty on otherwise middle-class streets.
From Richmond Hill to the Rockaways, Jackson Heights to Jamaica, even in posher enclaves like Bayside and Forest Hills, desperate tenants and enterprising landlords have sliced one- or two-family houses into multiple apartments, most often converting attics and basements into makeshift flats. While the units are usually newer and more spacious than the subterranean cubicles that characterize illegal housing in the slums of other boroughs, they can present severe hazards for tenants and serious problems for the surrounding neighborhoods.
Because these apartments are not registered with the city, they are essentially unregulated. Landlords can violate basic city rules for safety and livability with impunity; illegal tenants rarely complain to the authorities because they do not want to be discovered. Many apartments do not have fire exits or adequate electrical wiring, a deadly combination.
Moreover, illegal conversions have whipped up a special degree of turmoil in Queens, straining city resources such as schools and hospitals and pitting newcomers against old-timers who are upset not only about more neighbors but also a changed complexion in the neighborhood, not only about double-parked cars on streets but also the smell of curry or the sound of merengue music wafting from kitchens.
"The mindset of hundreds of thousands of people is that they bought into the suburbs, and now it's becoming the city," said City Councilman Sheldon S. Leffler, who represents parts of Fresh Meadows, Bayside, Queens Village and Hollis.
What has happened in Queens represents an extraordinary collusion of landlords, tenants, real estate brokers and contractors, tacitly abetted by judges and city bureaucrats who are partly unwilling and partly unable to stop it. The surrender of city officials exemplifies the calculation they have made throughout all five boroughs: it is better to let tenants remain in illegal apartments than to evict them, because the city has no place else for them to go.
"We're betwixt and between," said Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens. Ms. Shulman said that if officials invoked enough laws, hired enough inspectors and mounted enough court battles, they might be able to make a dent in the problem. But, she added, "It would probably only increase the homeless population."
Ms. Shulman and other borough and city officials say it is impossible to quantify such a hidden phenomenon, and census numbers provide little or no help, because they overlook many of the recent immigrants who occupy the basements, attics and even garages of houses throughout the borough.
But the district managers of virtually every community board in Queens cite the illegal conversion of private homes as their primary problem, causing fire and health hazards, overcrowding schools and cluttering neighborhoods that were not supposed to be overrun with garbage pails and double-parked cars.
School officials notice more children listing the same address on enrollment forms. Postal workers notice more names on the different pieces of mail being delivered to each house. And residents notice contractors trudging in and out of their neighbors' yards as more and more homeowners cash in on the trend.
"The bottom line is that there is profit in it for the landlords, needs met for the tenants and there's no one to stop it, so the economics play out on their own," said John Brannen, a firefighter in South Jamaica, where illegal conversions are especially rampant. Firefighters there estimate that as many as 80 percent of the homes there have been unlawfully subdivided.
In Astoria, most home buyers want to look only at houses with finished basements that could be rented out immediately as separate apartments, according to Angelo Langdakis, a real estate agent there.
Asked if these apartments were illegal, Mr. Langdakis grew philosophical. "It's a very fine word -- illegal," he said. "It's like crossing the street in the middle of the street. That's illegal, because you're supposed to do it at the corner. But everybody does it anyway, so it almost becomes legal."
 
The Tenants
For the Desperate, Life Could Be Worse
Some of the tenants of these apartments are struggling, often jobless immigrants who, more than ever before, are bypassing Manhattan and Brooklyn to make Queens their first stop in America, and are creating a demand for cheap housing that far outpaces new construction in the borough.
Others are working-class New Yorkers who are earning anywhere from $15,000 to $30,000 a year but, because of the high price of living in New York City, cannot afford the security deposit or extra $150 a month it might cost to rent someplace safer and better. They remain in Queens, or are drawn there, because they deem it a better world than Manhattan, Brooklyn or the Bronx, where trees are scarcer, yards nonexistent and drugs and crime more prevalent.
At the most desperate end of the spectrum are those like the Polish men with bad teeth and no English who inhabit the garage behind a three-story apartment building on a dingy street in Maspeth.
The garage has been carved into a warren of a half-dozen cramped rooms with a shared kitchen. Up a narrow, twisting staircase lies a tiny, oddly shaped maze with uncovered openings leading to the outside. Its resident, a stooped and emaciated man who looks to be about 80, does his cooking on a hot plate and his sleeping on a rickety bed under a clothesline strung with underwear.
The men generally stay in the garage for six months to a year, paying about $250 a month in rent, until they can save up enough money from hourly, seasonal construction work to get a better place.
"You see them mostly at night," said Bonnie Rae, who lives in a house near the garage. "We call it the roach motel."
Gary Bryan Frasieur, by contrast, lives not in a glorified shed but in a charming two-story house in Flushing on a quiet street of robust shrubbery and brightly painted shingles. Hanging plants flank the front door.
But Mr. Frasieur uses an inconspicuous doorway off the driveway to get to his illegal cellar apartment. A cellar is distinct from a basement, because at least half of it lies below curb level, and for fire safety and health reasons, the city forbids cellar apartments under any circumstances.
In this one, the ceiling is only a couple of inches higher than six feet; some walls are nothing more than thin sheets of cheap paneling. There is no stove; Mr. Frasieur uses a hot plate to make most of his meals.
"If I save up some money, I can get a toaster oven," said Mr. Frasieur, 48, who has a history of mental illness and receives $554 a month from Supplemental Security Income. He said that this apartment, for $415 a month, was about as cheap as any place, and that despite its unreliable heating and history of flooding in heavy rains, losing it would devastate him.
"I'd be in the streets, down and simple," said Mr. Frasieur, a nervous man with pleading eyes. "So, if that were your situation, what would it matter if you had stains on the carpet? If you didn't have heat for most of the winter? You hear the steam rushing up the pipes to the first floor, but you get used to it. And, you know, the block is very nice."
The block where Gonzalo Campos lives in Jackson Heights is not as nice, and the evidence of illegal conversions is ludicrously obvious.
The two-family house across the street, for example, had a sign hanging in the window last summer that read "Rooms for Rent," and its owner, Gilberto Medina, freely admitted that he was renting out three cubicles in the basement for $70 a week apiece.
The house in which Mr. Campos lives, which the city considers a three-family home, has no fewer than five different bells beside its front door, including the one for Mr. Campos's cellar apartment, where he lives with his wife and two children.
Still, it is a clean, well-lighted place, with pristine wall-to-wall carpeting throughout its four rooms and a full-size kitchen with a stove and large refrigerator. Mr. Campos, 44, who immigrated from Mexico seven years ago and makes about $25,000 a year as a construction worker, said that this apartment, for $700 a month, was an improvement on the first-floor unit a few blocks away that he previously occupied for $750 a month.
"This is bigger," he said, with what sounded like genuine pride. "It's more private. I like it here. You try to do better for under $1,000 a month. This is the best you can do."
 
The Dangers
In Case of Fire, No Escape Route
But even the best such apartments are beset by a host of grave problems. The most urgent is the danger of fire.
The fact that many illegal apartments are in houses with outmoded wiring intended to meet perhaps a quarter of the demand being placed on it increases the chance of an electrical short sparking a blaze. And because apartments in basements and attics seldom have more than one exit, the risk of residents being unable to escape a fire rises.
"They're living within firetraps," said Lieutenant Brian Hickey, a firefighter who works with Mr. Brannen in South Jamaica. "And they're dying because of it."
Tenants of illegal homes often find themselves powerless to make demands of landlords, even for repairs to hazardous conditions. Unlike other tenants, they risk losing their apartments by calling attention to problems in them; if they end up in Housing Court, the illegality of their homes is exposed, and many judges feel duty-bound to evict them.
This gives their landlords enormous power over them. If the tenants withhold rent to try to force repairs, landlords can seek evictions without great fear of punishment for the illegal rental.
"Landlords are using judges to evict tenants they don't have a right to be renting to in the first place," said Jill Zuccardy, a lawyer with Queens Legal Services. "The judges never even consider reporting the landlords to the Buildings Department, and as far as I can tell they suffer no consequences. They just re-rent the illegal places within a matter of weeks."
A Housing Court judge, James R. Grayshaw, said he evicted tenants from basements and cellars because he was concerned about there being no way out in case of fire.
"There's a reason that the building codes were written as they were," he said in an interview. "To turn a blind eye to this kind of widespread fire hazard, to wink it off, is to ignore the lessons of history, starting long before the Triangle Shirtwaist factory fire." That 1911 fire, in a Manhattan garment factory where the exits had been locked, killed 146 people.
Judge Grayshaw said he told landlords that they would be in contempt of court if they re-rented the apartments and warned them that he might order housing inspectors to check on the properties. But when asked how many times he had actually dispatched these inspectors, he said, "Two to three."
 
The Economics
For Landlords, Essential Income
Many of the landlords in question are hardly callous slumlords trying to wring every dollar they can out of decrepit properties they rarely visit or barely maintain. They are often middle-class families renting out whole floors or single rooms in their own houses as a way of realizing their dream of homeownership.
In that sense, they are little different from the generations who preceded them in Queens, buying two-family homes because they needed the rental income from the apartment on the second floor to own the one on the first. But with the rise in home prices in the last few decades, today's buyers find they need rental income not just from one additional apartment, but from two or three.
That strategy is abetted by real estate agents who increasingly encourage buyers to consider the possibility of renting out basements when evaluating their financial fitness to buy a home. These same agents coach absentee landlords to maximize their profit from houses by subdividing them.
Random calls to 10 different real estate agents in Woodhaven, Ridgewood, Richmond Hill and Jamaica found that half of them quickly detailed and recommended subdivisions when asked if homes in the area made good investments. "Let's say you have a house that has three bedrooms upstairs," said an agent at a Century 21 office in Woodhaven. "You can get $300 a room. I saw one place where they had made five rooms. You should talk to a contractor."
The incentives for landlords not to register these conversions with the city are powerful. If they went through legal channels to create the third and fourth apartments in their one- and two-family homes, they might have to apply for zoning variances, a process with a highly dubious outcome and a price tag of several thousand dollars. Their renovations would be subject to the approval of the city, meaning that they would have to incur the additional expenses of doing electrical work and taking fire safety precautions that met city codes.
Moreover, they would subject themselves to significantly higher property taxes. The tax rates for residences of four units or more are between three and five times greater than those for dwellings with up to three units.
Indeed, by not identifying illegal apartments and adjusting landlords' tax rates accordingly, the city loses revenue that could be used, for example, to plump up the budgets of public schools that are overcrowded in part because of the occupants of those illegal apartments.
Corey Bearak, chief of staff for Councilman Leffler, said that citywide, "We're estimating it could be $1 billion of missed revenue on an annual basis." Approximately 40 percent of that uncollected revenue, he said, can be attributed to illegal conversions in Queens.
 
The Communities
Neighbors Sense A Sort of Anarchy
Scrunched down low in the driver's seat of his red truck, a baseball cap casting a shadow over his face, Mr. Waisman, the president of the Richmond Hill Block Association, cruised quietly down a shady corridor of regal houses. He pointed surreptitiously to one of them, a rambling white Victorian, then swerved quickly around the corner lest he be spotted.
"That's one, right there," he said of the structure, which was once a private home but was now an illegal boardinghouse for a dozen different families. "That's what I'm talking about."
Minutes later, Mr. Waisman cased a brick-faced, overgrown Cape Cod with a front yard paved for extra parking space and four visible utility meters. He said three or four families were living in this house, which was legally designed for two. One of his informers on the block had told him so.
Mr. Waisman belongs to a growing brigade of residents in Queens who have assumed responsibility themselves for sniffing out the illegal conversions in their midst.
Some, like him, patrol the streets, homing in on such giveaways as extra meters, asphalt yards and overstuffed garbage cans. Others peek out their windows or peer over their hedges and anonymously report their suspicions to neighborhood groups and city agencies with the hope that something -- anything -- will be done.
Their behavior, while almost comical at times, provides a measure of their despair over what they see as the deterioration of their cherished neighborhoods. Nowhere else in the city have illegal conversions provoked as desperate an outcry as in Queens, where urban tensions encroach on a quasi-suburban refuge.
"At one time, if you moved to Queens, you were moving to a better neighborhood," said Ezio Benini, 66, a retired Transit Authority superintendent who has lived in Elmhurst since 1970. "Now, it's the same as all the neighborhoods."
Longtime residents like Mr. Benini say they are seeing the first jagged lines of graffiti on street corners where it was previously unthinkable, hearing the crescendo of car radios and boom boxes at hours of the night when quiet was once a given, and feeling a sense of anarchy invade their world.
"The house that used to put out one can of garbage puts out four," said Maria Thomson, an officer with the Woodhaven Resident's Block Association. "The house that used to send two kids to school sends eight. A lot of times the illegal renters are undesirable people. This has created havoc with the quality of life in our community."
Some residents express their complaints in racial terms. "Most of these real estate brokers are Indian or Hispanic, and they don't care who they sell the house to, or under what conditions," said Benjamin Bohland, a retired police detective who has been living in Richmond Hill for four decades.
Of his new neighbors, Mr. Bohland added, "I've heard them say, 'We're here now. You don't like it -- move!' But why should we have to listen to what I call that mau-mau music during these 72-hour weddings?"
Regardless of its origin, residents' frustration is sharpened by their knowledge that there is little chance that the landlords who profit from illegal conversions will be caught, let alone be punished in a manner that might deter them from renting out illegal apartments again.
While both the Buildings Department and the Fire Department can inspect so-called multiple dwellings of three apartments or more at will, courts have held that one- and two-family homes are a "man's castle," so inspectors cannot enter properties listed that way as freely, even if they suspect that the residences have become de facto multiple dwellings.
Firefighters need someone to allow them in or a record of a specific complaint that the property is a fire hazard. The Buildings Department also must get someone to grant inspectors access -- which residents sometimes do, either because they do not understand the implications of the visit or are cowed by the credentials of the visitor -- or go through the laborious task of obtaining a court order, a process rarely undertaken.
And the odds of Buildings Department inspectors being invited in are undercut by their schedules: 8 A.M. to 4 P.M, only on weekdays, which greatly limits the chance that anyone will be home.
Even when the city successfully enters a house, finds an illegal apartment, orders it vacated and summons the landlord to a hearing, the landlord frequently defeats the whole process by ignoring the summons or paying the undaunting fine -- usually less than $1,000 -- and simply finding a new tenant to take the old one's place.
"They just start again with illegal conversions," said Joel A. Miele Sr., the former Commissioner of Buildings, in an interview months before he left his post in August. "And we are back to square one."

Photos: "Telltale Signs of Illegal Subdivision"
The illegal conversions that have cropped up throughout Queens are not always easy to spot. But a close inspection of many seemingly ordinary houses and apartment buildings reveals clues that these structures have been subdivided to accommodate additional families.
 
Buzzers and Mailboxes
These attached rowhouses in Corona are listed in city building and tax records as two-family homes. But the five buzzers for one and four mailboxes for the other suggest more than two apartments in each.
 
Basement Doors and Rental Signs
According to the Buildings Department, this home in Woodhaven should be occupied by two families. But a separate side entrance suggests a basement living space, and a call to the phone number listed on an the sign confirmed a third apartment in the basement.
 
Backyard Shanties
This three-story apartment building in Maspeth looks normal from the street. But behind it, a garage has been converted into a boarding house, with a shanty-like second level on top.
 
Extra Utility Meters
This rambling home on a leafy street in Richmond Hill is supposed to house two families. But local activists say the four meters are proof that it has been divided into as many as four apartments.
 
Converted Garages
These brick rowhouses in Elmhurst were designed for apartments on the first and second floors. But activists say the new entrances that have replaced garage doors flag basement apartments. (Photographs by Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)(pg. B6)

LENGTH: 1821 words

HEADLINE: Basic Research Is Losing Out As Companies Stress Results

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: MURRAY HILL, N.J.

 BODY:
When Greg E. Blonder joined Bell Laboratories in 1982 as a physicist just out of Harvard, no one said a word about products or selling. "They asked their usual job interview question," he said. " 'What would I work on if I had an empty room and an unlimited amount of money?' " He spent his time measuring the behavior of electrons at 1 degree above absolute zero, which is very cold. "Not many products exist in that situation," he conceded.
But now Dr. Blonder, whose two young sons often ask him where they can buy something he has invented, is making a transition from basic to more applied research characteristic of industry everywhere in America. At 41, he has traveled from quantum physics to consumer tastes, emerging as the improbable chief of "Customer Expectations Research," a novel undertaking for the august Bell Labs based in this suburb 30 miles west of New York. 
 "I am using what I know about science to invent to order," Dr. Blonder said. "I am working backward," he added, from what he used to do.
Corporations once spent big sums on basic research, the sort of open-ended inquiry that drew Dr. Blonder to physics and that can lead to innovations that spawn new industries and many thousands of well-paying jobs. A lot of basic research goes nowhere, of course, but AT&T, the owner of Bell Labs, knew that Dr. Blonder's fresh insights into electron behavior might someday make possible a momentous breakthrough, perhaps a new type of computer chip as revolutionary as the transistor, which came out of Bell Labs in 1947.
In the 1990's, though, corporate outlays for research and development have fallen significantly for the first time, with much of the decline coming out of basic research. The shift in emphasis to near-term development is paying off today as American companies excel at turning a generation of good ideas into profitable products. Yet many corporate executives have decided that basic research for tomorrow is simply too speculative. It should be done, they argue, by university scientists, paid mainly by government.
The problem is that in an era of deficit cutting, Federal financing for basic research has suffered, too. As a result, total spending on research in the United States -- basic or applied, whether federally or privately financed -- has stagnated in the 1990's, when adjusted for inflation, according to the National Science Foundation.
The last time the Government cut back on research -- in the 1970's when military spending fell sharply -- corporations held their own. But now industrial research has become a victim of downsizing, stiffer competition and the growing corporate view that the return from most research and development spending should come in three years or less.
"We are eating our seed corn," said Paul M. Romer, a Stanford University economist who argues that industry is still squeezing products from the aging cornucopia of breakthrough technologies that came during and after World War II. "If this continues, we will no longer be the nation that is on the cutting edge of new technologies, new products and new markets. For the moment, we still are, but that can't last."
The shift away from basic research shows up repeatedly in interviews with researchers, government officials and corporate executives like Dr. Edward M. Scolnick, the tall, courtly, Harvard-trained doctor and scientist who presides over research and development at Merck & Company, the huge pharmaceutical concern. "We haven't the resources to do that work," he said.
Merck, for example, plans to spend $1.5 billion this year on drug research, but very little of that will be devoted to finding the viruses and wayward enzymes that must first be identified before new drugs can be designed to attack them. Tenneco Inc.'s huge auto division spends heavily to develop new features for catalytic converters. But no Tenneco scientist is seeking the next generation of emissions control, perhaps some not-yet-dreamed-of technology. Even Microsoft, which has opened a basic research center -- mainly to seek new ways for people to interact with computers -- still invests nearly 99 percent of its $2 billion research and development budget on elaborations of existing software, or testing.
For now, the focus on immediate results pays dividends. A rash of new products -- another AIDS drug, a better catalytic converter, a new wrinkle on the Internet, a better A.T.M. machine -- are visible evidence of the success of corporate spending on applied research. There have been gains as well from "process R& D," the development of faster, more efficient, more sophisticated ways to manufacture.
By most estimates, 25 percent of corporate research and development spending is now going for process research, such as Tenneco's newly designed machinery for shaping metal pipes as if they were flexible plastic tubes. "We design catalytic converters now taking this new flexibility into account," said Tom Evans, president of Tenneco Automotive's Walker division.
But many experts worry that in 20 years or so a shortfall of new technology could shackle the economy, even though the stock market does not show much concern. "It doesn't reward basic research," said C. Richard Kramlich, managing partner of New Enterprise Associates, a venture capital firm. "It rewards only the products that come out of research soon."
Without the cold war, a prime engine for basic research, the Pentagon, has cut back. And neither Democrats nor Republicans, eyeing the deficit, have filled the gap with more civilian research. "President Clinton asked Congress for increases," said Mary L. Good, the Commerce Department's Under Secretary for Technology, "and if he had not asked, the cuts would have been greater."
Caught in these crosscurrents is Dr. Blonder, an energetic, optimistic man who decorates his office with the sunny crayon drawings of his sons, 10 and 7. The split-up this year of AT&T into three companies also cut up Bell Labs. And soon Dr. Blonder will leave Bell's old home here, with its landmark pyramid copper roof, and move to a building leased on Exxon's nearby campus, once a larger research center.
Left behind will be colleagues with whom Dr. Blonder once interacted daily who will now work for Lucent Technologies, the spinoff from AT&T's old equipment manufacturing arm. It keeps the Bell Labs name. "We had 20 projects going," Dr. Blonder said, "and four had to be abandoned because they relied on a synergy between our software and their hardware people."
More than anything, Dr. Blonder and his 40-member team are in a race to create a yet-to-be-designed, portable device that may someday instantly convert speech to text, or perhaps English to Japanese, and vice versa.
"How do people understand what they hear, how do computers understand grammar?" Dr. Blonder said. "And then you have to find out, in techniques that are a little fancier than focus groups, why they would want such a device. This is what basic research is for me now. When I joined Bell Labs we were at the tail of the more abstract decades."
The cutback in old-style basic research reflects a historic transition from a system that blossomed in the Eisenhower Administration, fathered by Vannevar Bush, the science czar then. Dr. Bush sought to encourage among scientists "the free play of intellects working on subjects of their own choice, in the manner dictated by their own curiosity." Such research was nurtured in huge corporate or Federal laboratories with heavy Government spending to keep ahead of the Soviet Union.
Nylon came out of this system. So did the silicon chip, the laser, cellular phones, color television, modern gene technology, fiber optics and other breakthroughs that eventually created new industries, which in turn helped to expand the national economy at a rapid pace. Much of the effort was concentrated in world famous laboratories at AT&T, I.B.M., Eastman Kodak, Xerox, General Electric, Du Pont and other giants that dominated their markets and could afford the costly, drawn-out research. That world has been turned upside down by deregulation and new competitors.
"We are moving now toward a more practical Japanese or German model," said Gavin Wright, a Stanford University economic historian. "That might not give us world leadership in technology in the future. But it is more realistic."
Indeed, in some ways the new approach is more efficient. The pharmaceutical industry, for instance, has found a way to make and test in a given week thousands of chemical compounds as potential prescription drugs, a far cry from the two or three a day that was the upper limit only a short time ago. That's the focus of scientists at Merck like Paula Fitzgerald, a biophysicist.
Occupying one of the many narrow offices off a long, gray corridor at Merck's laboratory in Rahway, N.J., Dr. Fitzgerald models the interaction of enzymes identified by university scientists and chemical compounds generated by Merck. She is seeking to determine what mixture might block a disease-causing enzyme. The enzyme and chemicals appear as blue, red and green filaments floating intricately in three-dimensional depth on her ink-black computer screen.
"You draw the compounds that you model and test from a computerized library," she said. "Before you had to actually mix the chemicals to see how a compound worked."
In the new emphasis on profitable products, research is being decentralized. The once mighty laboratories are losing their independence, forcing scientists who inhabit them to answer not just to profit-oriented operating units but even directly to customers. "It is very common to walk in the halls today and come across numerous outsiders," said Bernard S. Meyerson, a top executive at I.B.M.'s research center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., once renowned for its ivory tower approach. "We had much less of this in the early 1980's, when I arrived."
Corporations are also encouraging their scientists to monitor basic research by others, here and abroad, in lieu of attempting the research themselves. In this spirit, American companies have increased their research and development spending overseas threefold since 1980, the Commerce Department reports, while foreign companies operate 645 research offices in the United States, up from 250 in 1992.
A chunk of current research spending shows up in numerous cooperative arrangements. Some are among companies to avoid costly duplication. Others are between companies and university researchers, or the small start-up ventures often set up to commercialize some discovery made on campus.
Merck, like many other high-tech giants, has agreements with a dozen small companies. "As funds are cut back, people are finding ingenious ways to carry through basic research," said John Kozarich, Merck's director of biochemistry. "We might not notice the impact for a couple of decades."

Dow Flirts With 6,000, And Nasdaq Sets a Record
The Dow Jones industrial average topped the 6,000-point level for the first time before ending lower on profit-taking, but the Nasdaq index attained its first closing high in four months as technology stocks rallied.
The Dow index of 30 blue-chip stocks closed down 13.05 points, at 5,979.81, following a brief run-up to 6,002.17. The broader-based Nasdaq composite index rose 3.31 points, to 1,250.87, eclipsing its June 5 high close of 1,249.15, which occurred before technology stocks were beaten down this summer. HEADLINE: City Hall Sees Cable Battle By TV Titans

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
In an unusual venting of vitriol between two media giants, Time Warner and the News Corporation took their long-running feud to City Hall yesterday, lambasting each other before a panel that is reviewing whether Time Warner should be allowed to keep its valuable cable franchises in New York City.
The panel's meeting opened a new front in the campaign by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to get Time Warner to carry the new 24-hour news channel started by the News Corporation, which is controlled by Rupert Murdoch. Time Warner has declined to accept the channel, and last week, the company rejected a request by Mr. Giuliani to put the channel on one of five public-access cable stations operated by the city. 
 After Time Warner's refusal, Mr. Giuliani moved to use the panel, the Franchise Concession and Review Committee, to pressure the company to reverse its decision.
Executives from the two companies bickered through the meeting yesterday, all but calling one another liars. It was a series of charges and countercharges from men who rarely air grievances so publicly.
In their testimony, News Corporation executives contended that Time Warner was suffocating access to information in the city and said Ted Turner, the new vice chairman of Time Warner, had a vendetta against the News Corporation. Time Warner executives countered that the News Corporation was seeking special treatment for its channel, the Fox News Channel, arguing that the panel had no right to change the franchise agreements.
"Time Warner has extraordinary power in its New York City cable monopoly and does not hesitate to use that power to damage competitors and to damage the economy of this city," said Arthur M. Siskind, senior executive vice president and group general counsel for the News Corporation.
Richard Aurelio, president of Time Warner Cable of New York City, asked why the Giuliani administration was helping one company when more than 30 other cable programmers had been unable to get space on Time Warner's systems, which have 1.1 million subscribers in the city.
"What right does Fox have to leapfrog over all these other programs?" Mr. Aurelio said.
Mr. Giuliani repeated his reasoning yesterday for helping the News Corporation, which also owns The New York Post. He noted that the company had located the news channel's headquarters in Manhattan. If the channel is not shown in much of the city, it might fail, threatening hundreds of jobs, he said.
The review board had been scheduled to meet before the dispute erupted between the Giuliani administration and the two companies. By law, it must determine whether Time Warner's takeover of the Turner Broadcasting System, which will soon be completed, constitutes a change in ownership of the company that holds the cable franchises.
If the review board concludes that ownership has changed, in a vote that could come as early as tomorrow, then it can seek to rewrite the franchise agreements, which are up for renewal in 1998. That raises the possibility that the city could make the contracts less lucrative for Time Warner, or even take them away.
Four votes are controlled by the Mayor and one by City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi; one vote is shared by the five borough presidents. It takes five of the six votes to approve any action. The Mayor is leaning toward telling his representatives that there is a new owner, administration officials said.
Mr. Hevesi and four of the borough presidents said they had not yet taken a position. Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, said she thought that control of the franchises had changed, but said the city should not alter the franchise agreements.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
DOLE, FULL OF ZIP, GOES AFTER VOTERS FROM NEW JERSEY

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

 BODY:
With the first debate behind him, Bob Dole went back to the trail yesterday to seek new vigor for his campaign, rolling across New Jersey on his first bus tour and into Manhattan in a motorcade at rush hour.
At the same time, the campaign began broadcasting a set of new commercials that promote his tax-cut plan, use his wife to vouch for his trustworthiness and cast President Clinton as a tax-and-spend liberal. 
 "This is a great way to start the post-debate effort," Mr. Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee, said with enthusiasm at a high school rally in Toms River, in the first of four quick stops across the Garden State. "We've got 30 days to go. Don't believe the pundits, don't believe the polls. As Jack Kemp says, don't look up at the scoreboard -- the game is still on!"
Mr. Dole said he would win the election because he would be associated with the word "trust" while Mr. Clinton would be associated with the word "fear."
"When they think of Bill Clinton, I want them to think of the word fear," he said, referring to voters. "Fear."
As the Willie Nelson song, "On the Road Again," wailed in the background, Mr. Dole campaigned with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who advocated tax cuts, won an uphill election and then kept her word and cut taxes. Later this week, Mr. Dole will enlist the help of another of the Republican Party's most reliable sources of popularity, Colin L. Powell, for a campaign trip to the Midwest.
"There's something magic about riding around on a bus with Governor Whitman," Mr. Dole told a lunchtime crowd in the middle of a street in Red Bank yesterday afternoon in a speech that lasted less than five minutes. "She won."
As he breezed out of Milltown later in the day, Mr. Dole playfully took the microphone to the public address system outside his bus and regaled bystanders with a running commentary on the passing scene.
When he saw Clinton signs, he said: "Thanks for coming. You'll still get the tax cut." To someone selling anti-Dole T-shirts by the side of the road, he said, "Bet those shirts aren't selling well."
Dole aides tried to make the case that spending two days in New Jersey was a sign that Mr. Dole had secured the Republican base in other parts of the country and was now ready to fight for battleground states like this one, where he trails the President in polls by 10 to 15 points.
Mr. Clinton, meanwhile, spent the day invading traditional Republican strongholds. [Page A21.]
In Connecticut, Mr. Clinton showcased his support among corporate executives, many of them longtime Republicans, including the head of one of the biggest employers in Kansas, the Sprint long-distance telephone company. Then he traveled to New Hampshire and Maine in a schedule that seemed designed to taunt Mr. Dole and convey the impression that Mr. Clinton was feeling comfortable enough about his lead to go to states that are traditionally Republican and offer only marginal electoral prizes.
In addition to Mr. Dole's energetic return to the stump today, he unveiled a new series of commercials that followed two different political agendas: One reinforces the depiction of Mr. Clinton as an advocate of high taxes, and the other is aimed at women, who have been cool to Mr. Dole. Campaign aides said the advertisements would run in 17 states, including California, at least through the week.
In one advertisement, Elizabeth Dole, seated on a couch in a living room, says, "My husband has come out strongly to protect the victims of domestic violence and to make sure a man and woman who work at the same job get the same retirement benefits." She adds: "And when Bob Dole says he'll cut taxes 15 percent for families, you can count on it."
In a second advertisement, Mr. Clinton is portrayed as having raised taxes on Social Security, for upper-income people, and on gasoline. The announcer asserts that Mr. Clinton has proposed a total of 255 taxes and fees, declaring: "The real Bill Clinton. A real spend-and-tax liberal."
Clinton economic advisers criticized the advertisement tonight, saying Mr. Dole was counting a series of small, technical tax-law changes, many of which he had supported himself. "It's a bogus standard," said Gene Sperling, a White House economic adviser. "By that bogus standard, Bob Dole would have well over 1,000 tax increases. He's the Hank Aaron of tax increasers."
In addition, Mr. Dole will begin broadcasting a new round of radio advertisements aimed at particular groups of voters: radio listeners in farm states, particularly in the West, and listeners to Christian-oriented radio stations. The campaign's need to buy radio time in both markets is the latest indication of the difficulty Mr. Dole has encountered in trying to excite reliable Republican voters.
While Mr. Dole's senior advisers said they were pleased with his debate performance, they stopped short of asserting that it had altered the state of the race.
"This is going to be a steady building process for the next 30 days," Scott Reed, Mr. Dole's campaign chairman, said today. "There's not going to be an overnight shift."
Nor was Mr. Dole overly effusive. Asked how he had done in the debate, Mr. Dole told reporters as he emerged from his hotel this morning: "I don't know. We had a good time last night. I enjoyed it. Like Hartford. I'm going to work today."
Mr. Dole is behind in the polls at this point, Mr. Reed said, because the Democrats spent "millions of dollars to portray Dole as someone who is mean and out of touch."
Mr. Reed predicted that by the end of this week -- which is to include a bus trip across Ohio, where Mr. Dole will campaign with Mr. Powell, the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff -- Mr. Dole would have narrowed the gap in the polls. "By the end of he week, we'll be back in the high single digits, which will be a successful week for us," he said.
He added, "The Democrats' advertising has been very effective painting us into a corner, now we're going to beat our way out."
Mr. Reed said the campaign was focusing on states that would give Mr. Dole 320 electoral votes -- 270 are needed to win -- and that he had already locked up 200 of those votes from 17 states. But when pressed, Mr. Reed offered a list that totaled only 144 electoral votes.
The states that Mr. Reed said the campaign could count on were Alabama, Arizona, Idaho, Indiana, Kansas, Mississippi, Nebraska, Nevada, North Carolina, North Dakota, Oklahoma, South Carolina, South Dakota, Texas, Utah, Virginia and Wyoming. Mr. Reed's optimism, which he said was supported by campaign polling, is not supported by public polling in Arizona or Virginia. The other states are reliably Republican.
Having secured the Republican base, Mr. Reed said, the campaign is prepared to move on to battleground states like Ohio and New Jersey.
Greeting about 400 people briefly in a hotel ballroom in Manhattan before he attended a private fund-raising event, Mr. Dole ridiculed Mr. Clinton's debate performance.
"I thought I was back in the Congress last night, when I listened to President Clinton," Mr. Dole said. "You sound like a law clerk reading off all these things that he was responsible for, all these things that didn't pass the first two years when you had a Democratic Congress, all these things passed by the Republican Congress that he never heard of because he hadn't had an idea in four years! He said, 'These are mine! These are mine! These mine!' "

HEADLINE: Loan for Be-Bop Birth Site

 BODY:
State development officials said yesterday that they would provide the actor Robert De Niro and his partners with a $300,000 loan and other incentives to help resurrect Minton's Playhouse, the jazz club where be-bop was born, in Harlem.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the State Development Commission, said the low-interest loan would be financed through a fund for economically distressed areas. 
 Mr. De Niro teamed up with Drew Nieporent, who operates TriBeCa Grill and other restaurants, and Melba Wilson, a principal in Sylvia's Restaurant in Harlem, more than two years ago to reopen Minton's Playhouse at 118th Street and Seventh Avenue.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Prices Gain Sharply As Warehouse Stocks Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Copper prices rose sharply in New York yesterday after a report showed that available supplies in London Metal Exchange warehouses fell to the lowest level in 10 months.
The London exchange reported copper stocks in its warehouses around the world fell 8,625 metric tons since its last reporting on Friday. It was the 10th consecutive decline and took stocks down to 220,950 metric tons, the lowest level since Nov. 28, 1995. A metric ton is 2,204.62 pounds. 
 New supplies of copper have not been coming to market quickly because suppliers have been reluctant to sell with prices so low. But buying of copper cathodes, used to make wiring for automobiles and homes, is at its highest, said David Rinehimer, an analyst with Smith Barney.
"We're dealing with an extremely tight near-term supply situation reflecting the fact that the U.S. economy remains fairly strong," he said.
Copper prices have been erratic since the Sumitomo Corporation reported huge losses on copper trading in mid-June. To cover a $2.6 billion trading loss it attributed to unauthorized trading from its former chief dealer, Sumitomo announced that it was exiting the copper market and would sell its large supplies.
Some investors believe the company still has as much as 500,000 tons of copper that could be dumped on the market at any time. But those fears have eased as exchange supplies continued to show sharp withdrawals.
On the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, copper for December delivery rose 3.20 cents, to 91.65 cents a pound.
Crude and heating oil futures gained early on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid fears that the tropical storm Josephine would further disrupt production out of the Gulf of Mexico. Several offshore platforms were closed Sunday and Monday but were reopened yesterday, causing prices to fall back.
November crude oil rose 30 cents, to $25.54 a barrel, the highest settlement price since the start of the Persian Gulf war. November heating oil fell 0.30 cent, to 76.19 cents.

HEADLINE: I.R.A. Says It Set Bomb That Wounded 31 at Barracks in Ulster

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The Irish Republican Army acknowledged tonight that it had detonated the two bombs that wounded 21 soldiers and 10 civilians on Monday at the British Army's headquarters in the British province of Northern Ireland.
The attack, at Lisburn, 10 miles south of Belfast, was the first the I.R.A. has admitted to in Northern Ireland since Sept. 1, 1994, when it called a cease-fire. The overwhelmingly Roman Catholic guerrilla organization, dedicated to forcing Britain out of the predominantly Protestant province, had already broken its general cease-fire in February with attacks in England. 
 The admission, in a telephone call to the Irish national broadcasting network in Dublin, raised fears here and in Belfast of retaliation by Protestant paramilitary groups, which have observed their own cease-fire since Oct. 13, 1994. It may also mean that the peace talks that started in Belfast four months ago are now all but dead.
"Anything can happen," said David Ervine, leader of the Progressive Unionist Party, which has ties to the Protestant paramilitary Ulster Volunteer Force. "We have to batten down the hatches and prepare for the worst."
The worst would include a return to the sectarian guerrilla warfare that has killed more than 3,100 people since 1969.
Mr. Ervine and other Protestant leaders say they are trying to persuade the Protestant paramilitary groups not to retaliate. Protestant paramilitary leaders have warned that if the I.R.A. continues its violence, the Protestants will resume their own attacks, including forays into Dublin and other Irish cities.
On Monday, Prime Minister John Bruton of Ireland said the attack on the army base was an attempt to provoke Protestant retaliation. Today the Irish Government said it was increasing patrols along the border to intercept any Protestant guerrillas coming south.
Irish officials said the I.R.A. attack appeared to have been timed to coincide with an economic conference in Pittsburgh intended to bring American investment to the North and with the British Conservative Party conference in Bournemouth, England.
At the conference tonight, Prime Minister John Major of Britain said the attack, which came without the usual warning to the police, was "sickening."
He noted that Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political wing, had been insisting on meeting him to discuss peace, "and all this time he knew they planned to murder people in Lisburn."
The I.R.A. statement, made by a caller using a code word indicating its authenticity, said, "The target was personnel connected with the Thiepval barracks," that is, directed against soldiers.
"We regret any injuries caused to civilians," the caller added. "The resolution of the conflict demands an inclusive negotiated settlement."
The I.R.A. wants Sinn Fein to take part in the Belfast talks but the British and Irish Governments have excluded Sinn Fein until the I.R.A. restores its cease-fire.
At Lisburn, British officials are trying to find out how the high-security headquarters was penetrated and two car bombs placed near an administrative center and barracks. The base had not been attaked for more than 20 years and was considered a safe bastion.
Several I.R.A. operations in England have failed in recent months, and a huge cache of expolsives and weapons was seized two weeks ago by the police in London. But with the Lisburn bombing, the I.R.A. showed that in Northern Ireland it is still able to carry out terrorist attacks.

HEADLINE: The Downside of an Upturn

BYLINE: By James Grant; James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, is the author of "The Trouble With Prosperity: The Loss of Fear, the Rise of Speculation and the Risk to American Savings."

 BODY:
The United States economy, although growing too slowly to satisfy every registered voter, is a ball of fire compared with the economies of Western Europe and Japan. One vital source of this strength is the robust American capacity to fail.
Any economic system can cope with success. But capitalism excels at failure: recognizing it, cutting it short and, through the process of bankruptcy, forgiving it. 
 By forthrightly curing its 1980's-vintage debt troubles, the United States cleared the way for growth in the 1990's, at however slow a rate. The Japanese, by contrast, condemned their economy to stagnation by pretending that their boom-time banking problems could be made to disappear without the inconvenience of actually addressing them.
People in markets miscalculate, singly and in groups, both on the upside and downside. Overdoing it in a boom, they propagate white elephants -- driving prices too high in real estate, if that is the most favored type of investment, or in semiconductor plants, if that is what's hot. Making amends in the slump, they clear away the mistakes of the boom, salvaging and repricing them.
Wall Street today is in the overdoing-it phase. As the Dow Jones Industrial Average closes in on 6,000, the bull market is titanic in every particular: from the record number of investment clubs, to the record high cost of a dollar of dividend income, to the long lines of radio cars idling expectantly outside the front doors of the great investment banks at 2 A.M. With each new high in the Dow, fewer people fear what the ancients called a bear market. More and more believe that the cycles of markets have been displaced by one cycle, the smiling, upward one.
That this impossibility has become the short-odds betting favorite is proof of how far the bull market has gone and how thoroughly its critics (myself not least) have been flummoxed. There will always be cycles in markets and economies. They have to exist, if only because people conduct their market-related business in crowds. As individuals shopping at K mart, people prefer low prices to high. Operating en masse in Wall Street, they seem now to prefer high prices to low.
It is, in fact, the upside of the business expansion that helps to cause the downside. They are a matched set. The exuberance of the expansion produces investment that causes distortions in the economic architecture. Redesign is the necessary work of the downturn.
Decade by decade since the 1960's, the economy's growth rate has become fainter. Is it purely by accident that this loss of vitality has coincided with the Government's efforts to mitigate the business cycle, to protect the banking system and to manipulate the dollar exchange rate (exporting, as necessary, punitively high exchange rates to Japan and Western Europe)? Insofar as bear markets, bank runs, recessions and the like serve a useful purpose, their relative scarcity in modern life might not be an unalloyed blessing after all.
The relatively good performance of the American economy in recent years shows that our Government is less overprotective than some. In France, Credit Lyonnais, whose balance sheet constitutes a kind of museum of 1980's-era trouble, has just requested its third government bailout. "No one could ever even think of having the collapse of a bank like this," a European Union commissioner declared in explaining the unanimous decision to approve the requested subsidy. Like the Japanese, the French are still sorting out the mistakes of the last upturn, whereas the American savings and loan bailout was completed years ago.
Meanwhile, the United States has entered the champagne-and-cigar-smoke phase of a new upturn. There is nothing wrong with booms. They are the financial expression of innovation and derring-do. In the natural course of things, promoters will err on the side of excess. The greater the degree of financial subsidy in a particular up cycle (such as artificially low interest rates), the greater the tendency toward exaggeration.
Imagine an economy taking the form of a standard, boxy East Side Manhattan apartment building. Before the end of a long expansion (well-oiled with cheap money), our symbolic structure would acquire a penthouse, an airstrip, a rooftop farm, a full set of gargoyles and a television broadcasting tower. The vital work of removing these gauds (and auctioning them off in the open market for better, alternative use) would occupy the residents during the down times.
Japan is a case study in what happens when markets are not allowed to get on with the work of what a great economist has called "creative destruction." Overpriced, empty office buildings remain overpriced and empty; after bankruptcy, they do not become cheap and functional.
The American boom of the 1990's is distinctive for the near-universal conviction that the Fed is at the controls, clear-eyed and sure-handed. It is not, I think. But even if a central bank could temporarily create a financial condition resembling room temperature -- measuring out growth in noninflationary doses, neither too big nor too small -- it would be doing nobody a favor. By creating a false sense of security about contingent and unpredictable future events, it would be leading the innocent to believe that the down cycle had been scratched.
So believing, investors would put themselves needlessly at risk. As they are now.
A paradox of financial markets is that risk is most dangerous when it is least apparent and least dangerous when it is most apparent. Thus, one of the great all-time buying opportunities in modern history occurred in the spring of 1942, with capitalism at bay, the forces of Imperial Japan thrust directly at Los Angeles and common stocks given up for dead by their demoralized and heavily taxed owners.
It is hard not to draw invidious comparisons with 1996, a year when capitalism is triumphant (even in Mongolia), when lunchtime crowds file into the New York Stock Exchange to watch themselves getting richer and when some $15 billion or $20 billion a month seeks supposed safe haven in equity mutual funds.
Booms foment error because, in the heat of the up cycle, error is so financeable. Thus, in the junk bond market this season, certain wireless telecommunications companies have been able to borrow even before they achieve the conventional preliminary milestone of generating a little revenue.
Indeed, one seasoned bond buyer has publicly resolved to invest in no deal in which the Wall Street underwriter's payment is higher than the revenues of the borrowing company over the preceding 12 months. Revenues, not cash flow, not net profits. "The scary thing?" the investor asks, rhetorically, of his screening test. "It screens out a lot."
No doubt some of these revenue-impaired debtors will succeed. That is not the real issue. The issue is whether the market is pricing securities for any but the perfect, fair-weather outcome. Up and down Wall Street, the answer would seem to be no.
In speculative markets, nothing is more certain than the progress of apparent perfection toward certain imperfection. When things can't possibly get any better, it logically follows, they can only get worse.

HEADLINE: Motorola Expects Chip Growth to Resume

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Motorola Inc. said today that it expects growth to resume in the semiconductor industry next year, a prediction bolstered later in the day by the release of an industry report indicating a stronger-than-expected book-to-bill ratio.
The ratio, which compares the number of new orders with chips shipped, increased to 0.99 in September, as computer makers raised their orders 9 percent in the expectation of higher demand, the Semiconductor Industry Assocation said. A ratio of 0.99 means that for every $100 of chips sold, chip makers took in $99 in new orders. September's ratio rose from August's 0.93, which was revised upward from 0.90. 
 While growth appears to be returning to the industry, Motorola, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., also said that it expected to take a charge in its fourth quarter of "several tens of millions" of dollars against earnings -- still less than 10 cents a share -- to cover the expense of cutting jobs and other cost-saving measures.
The semiconductor and wireless communications giant made the projection in a conference call to analysts early this morning that followed the release on Monday of the company's report on third-quarter earnings. In that report, Motorola said its earnings for the quarter had fallen sharply.
Following the call, several analysts reduced their projected earnings for the current quarter and 1997.
Investors were uneasy with the news and sent Motorola's shares down $1, to $48.75, in heavy trading today on the New York Stock Exchange.
But many analysts viewed the news, especially the semiconductor projections, as cautiously optimistic. "It's good news they think the semiconductor market will grow next year," Todd Koffman, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, said.
During the conference call, Motorola said that while it expected an upturn in the industry next year, it did not expect growth to reach 10 percent, a level necessary to soak up excess capacity and force prices to rise.
During the call, Motorola officials stressed that earnings would be hurt in the next few quarters by its heavy investments in new technology, especially flat-panel displays and the Iridium satellite system for worldwide wireless communications.
Iridium may launch its first satellite as early as the end of this year but the entire 66-satellite network will not be up and generating commercial revenue before 1998 at the earliest. Motorola's share is 25 percent of what it said would be "hundreds of millions" of dollars in upfront costs.
In another technology bet that was disclosed on Monday in Tokyo and explained more fully today in Austin, Tex., Motorola and the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation of Japan said they planned to share technology to develop a new microchip that could handle both processing and memory functions that now required two or more semiconductors.
The two companies said that the new design could substantially reduce costs, save space and improve the reliability for designers of electronic products like peripheral devices used with desktop computers, personal digital assistants, portable phones and multimedia equipment. Designers would be able to specify the amount of memory they want instead of coupling processors and other types of microchips with separate memory chips that are sold in standard sizes.
