HEADLINE: Language Study Shifts Again: Chinese Is Up, Russian Down

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
In a dramatic shift in their choice of foreign languages to study, more and more American college students are taking Chinese and Arabic at the expense of French, German and Russian, according to a new study by the Modern Language Association of America.
"The foreign languages chosen for study by students have always fluctuated, and they have always reflected international developments," said Phyllis Franklin, executive director of the association. "During World Wars I and II, there was a definite movement away from the study of German. More recently, when postwar Japan seemed the model of efficiency and economic success, students began studying Japanese in great numbers, thinking that would be the ticket to a successful career." 
 The organization, which surveyed 2,700 two- and four-year colleges and universities, found that registrations in Chinese and Arabic were up 36 percent and 28 percent, respectively, over what they were five years ago, while those in Spanish had climbed by more than 13 percent.
Meanwhile, French, German and especially Russian have fallen off sharply, while registrations in Italian and Latin declined less dramatically. French and German are both down by 28 percent and Russian is down by 45 percent.
Largely unchanged are registrations in ancient Greek, Hebrew and Japanese, although Japanese is now the fourth most-studied language, up from fifth in 1990. Chinese became the sixth most-studied language, up from eighth.
Spanish continues to be the most popular foreign language among American students, with an enrollment of 606,286, nearly half of the nation's language enrollment of 1.1 million.
The survey found a substantially higher registration over the last five years among the less commonly studied languages. Three-quarters of this increase was accounted for by enrollments in Korean, Vietnamese and Hawaiian, plus American Sign Language, which the association included in its survey.
Although down since 1990 despite an overall rise in college enrollments, foreign language enrollments are still at higher levels than at any time in the 1960's, 1970's or 1980's.
Colleges and universities are struggling to cope with these changes in a variety of ways. At one extreme, officials at the State University of New York at Albany recently announced the elimination of its German program and its four tenured professors. Two years ago, Bennington College created a stir when it abolished its traditional language departments and replaced them with a language center that serves both the college and neighboring communities and is staffed by non-tenure-track teachers.
More commonly, educational administrators are allowing French, German and Russian departments to shrink by attrition. And, wary of building inflexible departments with tenured professors teaching languages that few want to learn, they are employing adjunct professors in non-tenure-track positions.
Asked whether American students could be expected to become fluent in unfamiliar languages, like Chinese and Arabic, Yuann-Yuann Meng, an instructor in Chinese at Columbia University, insisted that a hard-working student who studied Chinese over a period of three years "could become just as proficient as if he or she had studied Spanish for that many years."
"Chinese grammar is very simple," she said.
An Arabic scholar, Prof. Dilworth Parkinson of Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, said that Arabic was not nearly so easy for Americans who do not come from Arabic-speaking families. "Arabic is so strange and difficult to many American students -- nothing looks familiar and there's an elaborate vocabulary -- that unless they can travel and find a way to become fluent, just enrolling in a university program will not be enough."
Ms. Franklin said some language choices had obvious explanations. "The changing demographics of the United States figure into this," she said. "We have an influx of immigrants who speak Chinese, Arabic or Spanish and so their children want to learn or improve their ability in the family language. We call these the heritage learners.
"Another explanation has to do with economics," she said. "Students see the increasing number of people who speak Spanish in the country and that attracts them to study Spanish as a way of getting a job or doing business with the Spanish-speaking population. These students see that they won't have to travel outside the United States to use their language skill."
Ms. Franklin also cautioned against "simplistic" interpretations of the survey findings.
"People don't sit around deciding which countries are likely to succeed in the years ahead and then study their languages," she said. "That's too much cause-and-effect. In actual practice, the choice of a language to study is less formal."
She said she was gratified by the finding that Americans are still actively interested in studying foreign languages.
"Only a few years ago," she said, "many people thought that English would become the international language and that Americans would not have to learn languages other than English. Well, English has become an international language, but even so there's a general awareness today that we are in a global economy and that that necessitates the study of foreign languages. We see that as a good thing."

HEADLINE: For 2d Day, Dow Tops 6,000 Then Retreats

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average made another short-lived move above 6,000 yesterday as stocks, particularly technology shares, fell on some profit taking in advance of the quarterly flood of earnings reports.
The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 13.04 to close at 5,966.77, having quickly surrendered an early 30-point gain that had lifted the blue-chip average just above 6,010. On Monday, the Dow pierced the 6,000-mark for the first time, but pulled back within minutes. 
 Broader market measures slipped from record levels as interest rates rose slightly in bond trading, providing stock investors with an excuse to secure more profits on the market's monthlong push into record territory.
The bond market's weakness after a series of strong sessions "is not that big a deal, but it was ideal for a stock market that has done extremely well and was looking for an excuse to sell," said Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist at Everen Securities in Chicago. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 7/32, pushing its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, up to 6.80 percent, from 6.78 percent on Monday.
Many investors want to see if the impending barrage of third-quarter earnings reports will justify the gains in the stock and bond markets. They are also awaiting Friday's and next week's readings on producer and consumer prices in September, hoping for further confirmation of the recently upbeat inflation and interest rate outlook.
The biggest losses among stocks came in the technology-laden Nasdaq market, which on Monday had closed at a new high for the first time in four months.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 10.72, to 1,240.15, as bellwether technology issues, the dominant force behind the Nasdaq's rebound from July's selloff, suffered some heavy profit taking. Intel fell 3, to 101 5/8, and Microsoft fell 2 1/8, to 135 3/8.
Declining issues outnumbered advancers by nearly a 7-to-5 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 435.1 million shares, up from Monday's pace.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.70 points, to 700.64, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.23 points, to 373.51.
Monday evening's third-quarter reports from the chip makers Motorola and Advanced Micro Devices offered a less-than-encouraging peek at the computer sector. But analysts said the scarcity of warnings of disappointing earnings expectations bodes well for the quarter's results from technology companies and the broad market.
"We haven't had that many negative announcements, and that's what's impressed me," said Peter Anderson, chief investment officer at the IDS Advisory Group in Minneapolis.
Motorola reported an expected 58 percent drop in third-quarter earnings, cautioning that troubles in its semiconductor and cellular equipment businesses might continue. Advanced Micro meanwhile, reported a loss of more than $38 million as sales fell.
In active trading, Motorola shares fell 1, to 48 3/4, but Advanced Micro Devices, whose loss was actually smaller than analysts were expecting, rose 3/8, to 16 1/8.
Dole Food lost 2 1/8, to 37 5/8, after its chief financial officer left the company. The executive's departure follows a forecast last week that Dole's third-quarter results would be at the low end of analysts' forecasts.
 Expeditors International, a transportation and logistics company, surged 4 3/4, to 40, after forecasting it would top analysts' third-quarter earnings estimates by 25 percent.
 McDermott International fell 2 1/2, at 19 1/2. The energy services company is cutting its dividend and trying to sell noncore operations in the face of deepening losses. McDermott also said late Monday that it expects to report a second-quarter loss that is larger than the first quarter's $9.9 million, or 18 cents a share.

HEADLINE: Croatia Chief Seeks to Muzzle A Radio That Aided His Rise

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Oct. 8

 BODY:
A retired Croatian general, critical of President Franjo Tudjman's drive to turn this small country into a military power in the Balkans, took to the airwaves today to spell out what he said was the folly of such a course.
"We don't have the human, material or economic resources to be a regional military power," said the general, Antun Tus. "Our future should be in alliances, not in exhausting ourselves to build up our armed forces." 
 The broadcast was made over Radio 101, the last independent radio station in Croatia. It highlighted the fight by the dwindling number of news organizations in the Balkans to broadcast views contrary to those of the ruling parties that govern the six republics in the former Yugoslavia.
But Radio 101, which often gave air time to Mr. Tudjman when he was a dissident challenging the Communist authorities, may soon be silenced by the man who used its studios as a platform to build his political career. And its demise, many contend, would effectively end any hope for independent news media.
"There is very little diversity now in the Croatian press," said Marvin L. Stone, a former editor in chief of U.S. News and World Report and a visiting fellow at Zagreb University. "The Government has either tamed, taken over or closed nearly all independent media. As far as Eastern Europe goes, only Serbia is in the same league as Croatia. President Tudjman is always parading, talking or smiling on the state-run television. There is no room for the opposition."
New restrictive press laws, including a decision by officials at the Interior Ministry to limit the visas of foreign correspondents to three months, have been passed recently despite requests by Croatia's European and American allies to end a Government crackdown on the press. A new press law promulgated this month, intended to bolster Croatia's bid to join the Council of Europe, gives the Government the power to force newspapers to run corrections or clarifications and sets the qualifications for chief editors.
There are troubling signs that Radio 101, which for 13 years braved the intolerance of Communist and nationalist politicians alike, will be turned over to Tudjman supporters when its license expires in November. The Government commission that is deciding who will be awarded the frequency now used by the radio station has been busy the last few weeks handing out radio frequencies to party loyalists.
The station, with a 32 percent share of the Zagreb audience, according to independent telephone surveys, dwarfs that of any other radio station in the city. It can be heard by nearly a quarter of Croatia's 4.7 million people. And its listeners say that losing the station would recall the days of a dictatorship many hoped had ended when Croatia declared its independence five years ago.
"The radio is a symbol," said Nenad Vukadinovic, a lawyer. "It has given a voice, and hope, to those of us who yearn to see this country become a European democracy."
The governing political party, the Croatian Democratic Union, controls all television and radio, along with three of the four national newspapers. The three independent newspapers are all currently fighting several Government-backed lawsuits, any one of which, if successful, would throw them into bankruptcy. The suits were filed shortly after a new law was passed this year making it illegal to criticize the President or other top Government officials. Government tax inspectors have also been searching newsrooms and combing the newspapers' record books looking for irregularities.
The radio station, which broadcasts out of a cramped two-story building in downtown Zagreb, pumps out round-the-clock programming that includes popular call-in shows and rock music, although the 800-watt transmitter strains to reach the outskirts of the city. Reporters, editors and announcers often get their pay two or three months late.
Natasha Babic, a 30-year-old producer, stood recently in the door of a small studio, equipped with antiquated reel-to-reel tape players and old sound-mixers and turntables.
"The tactics used by the Communists to try to silence us are about the same used by Tudjman's Government," she said. "And this is because, in many cases, we are still dealing with the same people."

HEADLINE: Cable Interference

 BODY:
Part of the obligation of any top official in New York is to help businesses create new jobs. But Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, Gov. George Pataki and Attorney General Dennis Vacco have exercised poor judgment by demanding that Time Warner cable television allow the New York-based Fox News Channel to be shown to local television viewers. Since the Fox News Channel is owned by Rupert Murdoch, a political supporter of all three men, their actions involve a conflict of interest. Beyond that, Mr. Giuliani's threat to revoke Time Warner's license and Mr. Vacco's launching of an antitrust investigation are improper government interventions promoting one commercial programmer over another on cable television.
If the optimistic predictions of a few years ago had proved accurate, New Yorkers might have had 500 cable channels to choose from by now, with plenty of room for Mr. Murdoch's new 24-hour news operation. But technology has not moved that swiftly, and the 1.1 million city subscribers to Time Warner Cable receive only 75 channels, with 5 set aside for city-sponsored public service and educational programs. Time Warner Cable argues that there is simply not enough room for all the worthy companies that want to get on the air. 
 The current dispute arose when Time Warner promised the Federal Trade Commission to add one news channel in return for approval of its merger with the Cable News Network, owned by Ted Turner. Despite a strong bid by Fox, Time Warner chose a rival news unit owned by NBC and the Microsoft Corporation. In the media world, Mr. Murdoch and Mr. Turner are like Godzilla and King Kong. Time Warner says it had sound business reasons for awarding a channel to MSNBC, but Mr. Murdoch charged foul play based on his conservative views. Enter the politicians, who until now have never displayed much interest in cable programming. The Mayor wants to turn one of the city's public access channels over to Mr. Murdoch. That would probably violate the Federal ban on commercial use of the public-access channels. Time Warner declined to go along, no doubt reluctant to make room for another competitor to CNN.
Mr. Giuliani says he is only acting in the city's economic interest, noting that Fox News was awarded tax relief and other economic incentives only in June to start up its news service in the city, adding 1,400 new jobs to its operations. But the tax deal was not contingent on the Fox News Channel's being carried in the city, and in any case other cable companies that would like to get on Time Warner's service have never been surveyed on how many jobs they could bring to the table.
Under Federal law, any city that awards a franchise to a cable company is not permitted to take its content into account. But by threatening Time Warner that it might not renew its franchise, the city seems to be doing just that. Mr. Giuliani argues that the franchise renewal was prompted by Time Warner's acquisition of CNN a year ago, which changes the nature of corporate control. But that issue did not prompt a City Hall challenge in years past, when Time Warner was involved in other big takeovers.
As a powerful monopoly, Time Warner has a responsibility not to behave in a predatory way toward its competitors. But Mr. Murdoch is not some sort of innocent who needs a protector. He has ruthlessly used his news organizations in the United States and overseas to further his political agenda, and in New York City has used his newspaper The New York Post to help politicians he likes, including the Mayor, Governor and Attorney General. The conflict in this situation is clear and unseemly. These three have no business using their powers to force Mr. Murdoch on the air.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Slow Auction Causes a Slip In Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices slipped yesterday after an auction of new 10-year Treasury notes failed to encourage buying.
"The market expected the 10-year note auction to come in stronger and when it came in weaker than expected, it did not sit well with traders," said Larry Berman, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 7/32, to 99 11/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.80 percent, from 6.78 percent on Monday.
Bond prices received some support from two weekly retail sales reports. The Mitsubishi Bank-Schroder Wertheim report for the week ended Oct. 5 showed a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in sales from the previous week. A survey by LJR Redbook Research, formerly Johnson Redbook, showed that sales fell four-tenths of 1 percent, as expected. The reports confirmed a view that the economy was slowing and that the Federal Reserve would hold interest rates steady.
Prices were also bolstered by comments by two Federal Reserve officials that were interpreted as being bullish for the market.
The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, WilliamJ. McDonough, told the Reuters news service after addressing the Bank Administration Institute in Washington that he believed the Federal Reserve should set a target for the core Consumer Price Index, which excludes energy and food prices. His comments echoed remarks he made in March, analysts said, noting that the core numbers have been stable this year.
Also in Washington, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., told a group of economists that he saw signs of lower growth in recent reports on retail sales and jobs.
But prices were undermined by concern about how much demand dealers would see for the $10 billion auction of new 10-year Treasury notes.
Still, Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said the results of the sale were decent, noting that the average yield at auction of 6.502 percent was close to expectations of 6.50 percent.
For investors, the 10-year note is essentially a bet that the market will continue to rally higher than its recent range, analysts said. But the looming prospect of Friday's producer price and retail sales data, as well as next week's consumer price report, provided some resistance to making such a bet.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Growth Expected in Chips, As Book-to-Bill Ratio Rises
Motorola said that it expected growth to resume in the semiconductor industry next year, a prediction bolstered by the release of an industry report indicating a stronger-than-expected book-to-bill ratio. The ratio, which compares the number of new orders with chips shipped, rose to 0.99 in September, as computer makers increased their orders in the expectation of higher demand.
While growth appears to be returning to the industry, Motorola also said that it expected to take a charge this quarter to cover the expense of cutting jobs and other cost-saving measures. [Page D2.]
 
Stocks Fall Ahead of Earnings
The Dow Jones industrial average made another short-lived move above 6,000 as stocks fell on profit taking in advance of quarterly earnings reports. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 13.04, to 5,966.77, having surrendered an early 30-point gain. [D8.]
 
Treasury prices slipped after an auction of new 10-year Treasury notes failed to encourage buying. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.80 percent, from 6.78 percent on Monday. [D15.]
 
German Companies to Negotiate
Germany's biggest manufacturing companies, which infuriated unions in the last two weeks with plans to slash sick pay, have decided to talk instead of fight. [D5.]
 
Sony Names Managers for Studio
Sony announced a new management team headed, as expected, by John Calley, the president of United Artists, to run its studios. Sony also named Jeff Sagansky as co-president and Masayuki Nozoe as executive vice president. [D7.]
 
Wal-Mart Sales Rise 5.6 Percent
Wal-Mart Stores said that sales at stores open at least a year rose a better-than-expected 5.6 percent in September. [D2.]
 
S.E.C. to Force New Disclosure
The S.E.C. is preparing to force disclosure of the ways companies are using -- and misusing -- a rule meant to make it easier for American companies to sell securities overseas. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D8]
 
Firm Faces N.A.S.D. Charges
A N.A.S.D. panel has filed an administrative complaint against Sterling Foster & Company, contending that the brokerage firm defrauded investors. [D8.]
 
Selling a Cadillac to BMW Owners
Cadillac and its ad agency, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, are trying to convince baby boomers who like driving small, performance-oriented luxury sedans that a Cadillac is really their dream car. To catch the eyes of younger buyers, Cadillac has created an irreverent mascot for the campaign, a red duck. Advertising. [D7.]
 
Blockbuster Announces 2 Deals
Blockbuster Entertainment said it had agreed to buy Xtra-vision, a video chain in Ireland, and that it had acquired a minority interest in PC Upgrades, a Cincinnati retailer. [D7.]
 
New York Pressures Time Warner
New York's Governor and Attorney General have joined Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in trying to help the News Corporation gain access for its new 24-hour news channel on Time Warner cable systems in New York City. The disclosure came as the News Corporation said it would file suit against Time Warner, contending that its rival had violated Federal anti-trust law by rejecting its channel. [B1.]
 
Oxford to Add Alternative Medicine
Oxford Health Plans said it would add alternative-medicine coverage to some of its health plans. [A11.]

HEADLINE: Struggling to Duplicate a Success;
Levi Strauss Hopes to Match Performance of Dockers

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Last December, after production had already begun on Levi Strauss & Company's new Slates men's dress pants and only months before the shipping deadline, the company halted production to change the fabric of half the product line, increasing the wool content by 10 percent.
The company says it made the switch only after finding it could use better fabric without increasing the price of the pants. A competitor, Alan Burks, senior vice president for marketing at the Haggar Clothing Company of Dallas, says Levi Strauss was simply scurrying after realizing that Slates looked too much like its unsuccessful Dress Dockers. 
 Whatever the rationale, the switch meant a scramble. Workers were leaving for Christmas, retailers had placed orders based on the original fabric and factories needed fabric to keep up production levels. Patterns no longer met specifications, and dye colors were off.
"Delivering the news was not a pleasant moment," recalled Rita Trumbo, merchandising manager. "I had a room of about 15 people who had put their hearts into the production start of Slates, and this was the last straw. I'm sure there were a lot of hallway conversations and bathroom conversations that were not flattering."
A decade ago, Levi Strauss stunned the clothing world by creating Dockers, casual pants that became a billion-dollar brand. But the company, perceived as one of the world's great merchants, is finding it is not so easy to duplicate that success.
It discontinued Dress Dockers last May after seven years, amid criticism that consumers were confused about the differences between Dockers and Dress Dockers. Sales of the line never exceeded $25 million, estimated Harry Bernard of Colton Bernard Inc., an industry consultant and analyst based in San Francisco. Levi Strauss officials declined to disclose any financial information about Dress Dockers or the cost of developing Slates.
Now, Levi Strauss is having another try. Last August it introduced Slates into 1,500 stores and -- correcting what it saw as an oversight in the introduction of Dress Dockers -- backed the new line with a $20 million marketing budget. Levi Strauss created a new division solely for Slates -- only the third brand introduced in the company's 140-year history -- and hired more than 100 people full time to design and market the pants, which sell for $50 to $80 retail.
Levi Strauss, a privately held company with $6.7 billion in sales last year, estimates that Slates, as was the case with Dockers, will have $1 billion in sales worldwide in a decade (though inflation has made that a more attainable goal). Slates, the company says, will finally establish Levi Strauss as a market leader in the $1.9 billion men's dress pants market in the United States, a category that is being reconfigured by the new trend toward casual attire.
Jann Westfall, president of the Slates division, insists that Dress Dockers were a success and that Slates is a totally new line -- with a different fit, higher quality and wider distribution -- that will "awaken a sleeping giant of a category that we think has enormous potential." Indeed, in its marketing, Levi Strauss seeks to position Slates somewhere between dress and casual pants, equal to either role.
Haggar -- which this month is introducing a segment-straddling product of its own, called the Ultimate Pant -- says Levi Strauss's rollout has been fraught with missteps and, combined with the earlier Dress Docker episode, simply shows that Levi Strauss does not understand the dress pants market.
"I guess we'll see if the consumer is as dumb as they think they are," Mr. Burks said.
Others say Levi Strauss -- with its 18 months of dithering over details from buttonhole sizes to belt-loop widths and its cover-all-bases approach to Slates -- is showing it is not just a jeans manufacturer. While Levi's jeans and Dockers khakis are facing more competition from private-label brands, Levi Strauss is using its deep pockets and marketing muscle to open new niches.
"Levi is a great brand, but they are in a business where their products have been easily duplicated," said Douglas A. Christopher, a retailing analyst with Crowell Weedon, a brokerage firm in Los Angeles.
Competitors predict that success will not come easy for Slates because of the growing complexity of the dress pants market, already dominated by companies like Haggar, Farah Inc., based in El Paso, and Banana Republic, based in San Francisco, a unit of Gap Inc.
"The changing workplace environment for men is making it difficult to figure out what the heck they want to wear," said Peter Simon of NPD Group, an apparel research firm in Port Washington, L.I.
Indeed, the story of how Levi Strauss introduced Slates illustrates an almost comical level of confusion about what this new line should be. Not to mention high anxiety.
Consider the nits that were picked just to come up with the Slates name. The division's marketing group spent four months sifting through 10,000 possibilities looking for a name that it could trademark globally and that could be pronounced in most major languages. It wanted a name that was somewhat masculine and formal -- and something that ended in the letter s, because the company's two other brand names, Levi's and Dockers, end in s.
"What we were looking for was an empty vessel, a word that really had no meaning that we could then fill with meaning," said Nancy Friedman, Slates marketing director.
After selecting Slates, the executives set in motion a plan for concealing the name for several months leading up to the product's debut; just picking the brand's code name -- "Steps" -- took another month.
Among other quirky tests, the marketing team inserted the Slates name into mock news articles to gauge how it would look in print. But the exercise proved unnecessary once the executives learned that Microsoft was publishing an on-line magazine called Slate. Levi Strauss concluded it could only trademark the name against use by other apparel makers; it was too late to choose another one.
Attention turned to picking a logo, leading to another three or four months of haggling. Four freelance designers came up with dozens of possibilities, including a chiseled rock. "It was an easy way to remember the name, but we didn't really want the name to have to do with stone so men would think we only had gray pants," Ms. Friedman said. "Men are really literal."
The company finally chose a sleek interwoven letter S configuration and, after several more months of debate, decided it should go on the inside waistband above the zipper -- so that it would be the last thing a man sees as he puts on his pants.
The merchandising team, meanwhile, was poring over fabric swatches and buttons.
"In our research, we asked men what they expected in a dress pant, what they perceived as a dress pant," said John Sun, Slates senior designer. "We got a range from cotton khaki pants to suit pants and everything in between."
Men were asked to bring their favorite dress pants to a focus group. In many instances, the pants were so ill fitting that "men were pulling the waist below their stomachs," Mr. Sun noted.
So the designers chose to rely on their expertise, and the general comments of focus group participants. They gave Slates pockets that were deeper than the standard, reinforced the waistline and added nontraditional waist sizes like 35 inches.
Next the sales and marketing group needed a way to make Slates stand out in stores that traditionally displayed men's dress pants in warehouse fashion.
"We actually hung out in department stores and observed customers shopping," recalled David Ludd, retail marketing manager. The exercise, he said, confirmed that men generally become overwhelmed in clothing stores and head immediately for the center of the room, which is often so packed with product that moving around becomes a challenge.
With that in mind, the company hired an architectural firm that specializes in designing luxury hotels to create a roomy, circular display.
Then there were the hangers. Executives spent about a month trying to create a new hanger, something that would display the product in a unique fashion. One possibility required too much effort to assemble; another hid the logo; a third crumpled the pants. So Slates pants are in stores on hangers similar to those used by the competition.
With a product to show off, Ms. Friedman turned her attention to proposed commercials for Slates, spending a week reviewing a two-second shot in one spot. In the spot, entitled "Tango," a man in a pair of Slates dances around a grand restaurant with a waitress. Ms. Friedman was uncomfortable with a shot of the woman's leg hoisted in the air as the couple danced.
"I just didn't know if I liked seeing the sole of her shoe in my face," she said. With some prodding, Ms. Friedman voted to let the foot stay.
Only time will tell if attention to such details will help fulfill Levi Strauss's vision for Slates -- or if the experience simply represented a Keystone Cops development program that supports Haggar's contention that Levi Strauss doesn't know what it's doing in this market.
Paul Fitzpatrick, executive vice president and general merchandise manager for men's and children's apparel at Macy's, said Slates had exceeded Levi Strauss's initial sales estimates, although he declined to give specific numbers.
He said Macy's chose to carry the line because the company knew Levi Strauss would support Slates with extensive marketing. Asked how consumers could differentiate among Slates and Dress Dockers and competitors' brands, Mr. Fitzpatrick declined comment.
Al Preziosi, merchandise manager for men's clothing at J. C. Penney, said consumers would notice that Slates was better made than Dress Dockers and offered more of an assortment.
Perhaps, but what is certain is that the heat has been turned up a notch for all of the players in the industry. "It is going to be an intensified marketing battle now to see who is going to dominate that market," said Norman Karr of Jeanswear Communications. "One of the ways the competition is going to become obvious is in price wars. I think it will boil down to staying power."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: Campaign Trail;
THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

 BODY:

Your Dollars at Work
Taxpayers have ponied up almost $210 million to finance this year's primary and general-election races for the White House. Private donors and political parties have tossed in millions upon millions more. Most of it is spent on television ads, salaries and the other nuts and bolts of a national political campaign.
Some of the nickel-and-dime items, on the other hand, can be revealing. 
 Take the backstage expenses that go toward making a speech site worthy of a few seconds on network television. Bob Dole's expense reports suggest a preference for the big, sometimes costly splash. There is a $5,000 bill for fireworks. And a $6,700 tab for an August event in which the Dole campaign bought 10,000 biodegradable latex balloons and 100,000 feet of colored streamers, all for a speech in Pittsburgh by Jack Kemp.
The streamers "shot like giant party poppers" over Mr. Kemp, while the balloons rose from a giant football behind the stage, said Greg Crossey, one of the owners of The Balloon Company in suburban Pittsburgh. "Great visuals," he said.
Bill Clinton, on the other hand, went to San Francisco one weekend this summer. His campaign's expense reports show that the "decoration/paraphernalia/visibility" for the event were provided by Bill Graham Presents, a name that will resonate with children of the 60's like the President. Before his death, Mr. Graham was the world's foremost rock-concert promoter and made San Francisco a locus for stars like Janis Joplin, Bob Dylan and the Grateful Dead. The campaign paid $375.
Or perhaps a campaign is what it eats. According to the August expense reports, the Dole campaign regularly turned to restaurants like Bella Luna in San Diego and businesses like Jack Fackrell Catering in Redding, Calif., to lay out a spread at its political events.
The Clinton campaign usually shopped for food at Kroger's or at places like the Bi-Lo Food Store in Chattanooga, Tenn.
The Natural Law Party and its candidate, John Hagelin, are running on a platform based on the teachings of the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, the onetime guru to the Beatles. To no one's surprise, they largely patronized Thai and Indian restaurants.
And Ross Perot's Reform Party? The campaign seldom served food. And when it did, it was usually pizza.

Battle Fatigue
Sometimes, usually at the end of the campaign day, President Clinton becomes so caught up in his oratory that he seems to enter a different political dimension. Last week it was in Boston, where he compared the issues at stake in his re-election campaign to the fateful decisions made by the Founding Fathers.
This week it was in Portland, Me., where he disavowed the Founding Fathers altogether.
Mr. Clinton often winds his stemwinders down with a land-of-opportunity aphorism, this one in a Seattle speech: "If you want to be an American, what you have to do is believe in the Declaration of Independence, the Bill of Rights and the Constitution and show up and behave yourself and do right, and you're part of our country."
Fair enough. Now here's how it came out of his mouth in Portland earlier this week, in a 9 P.M. speech to an airport rally: "In this country, it doesn't matter if you believe in the Constitution and the Bill of Rights and you're willing to show up tomorrow and be a good citizen, everybody can have a place in America."
Reporters demanded to know whether Mr. Clinton had decided to abrogate the Constitution. They relented after White House aides threatened to brief them on the Constitution that night for an entire hour.

Bridge to Clinton's Page
At the end of Sunday's Presidential debate, Bob Dole showed he was, too, a 21st-century politician by capping his closing statement with his campaign's Internet address: www.dolekemp96.org. Trouble is, he left out the last "dot," after "96," rendering the address unusable.
Some net surfers who tried other variations of the address found this message: "Pssst . . . The past is over. Click below to make the right choice for the future." Following that instruction led them -- voila! -- to the official home page of the Clinton-Gore campaign.
Dirty Clinton cybertricks? Not exactly. The Internet addresses "www.dole-kemp.org" and "www.dole-kemp.com" belong to Internet Online, a Bethesda, Md., company that provides a bevy of web-related services. Michael Mann, president of the company, said it registered the addresses last month, "mostly because it only costs $100."
The company hoped to sell them or the company's services to the Dole campaign or to some other entrepreneur. When the campaign turned it down, it added the link to the Clinton campaign as a practical joke.
By Tuesday, the Clinton link was gone, replaced by an advertisement for Mr. Mann's Internet services. But there is always the potential for a few more hijinks: "We registered 'www.clinton-gore.com' a long time ago," Mr. Mann said.

Nonscience Marches On
"This is not rocket science. There is 'x' number of people on welfare who never seem to get off, but who are physically and mentally able to work." -- President Clinton in Connecticut on Monday, exercising the middle-of-the-road strategy that drives his campaign.
"This is not rocket science. This is a tax cut." -- Bob Dole in New Jersey that same day, exercising the economic strategy that drives his campaign. MICHAEL WINES

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Help for Lace Embroiderers

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: HOBOKEN

 BODY:
Northern New Jersey's 120-year-old, $300-million-a-year lace and embroidery industry is experiencing tough times. According to state commerce officials, the embroiderers -- 400 mostly family-run shops in North Bergen and Union City and nearby towns, employing 4,000 people -- have seen sales drop 20 percent over 15 years because of cheaper foreign competition. 
 Yesterday, the State Division of Economic Development announced a nine-point plan to revive the industry, with the help of Federal agencies and private organizations. The plan calls for bridge loans from local banks to ease embroiderers' cash flow problems, marketing advice from the government and technical help to upgrade outdated machinery. TERRY PRISTIN

LENGTH: 1163 words

HEADLINE: Fringe Benefits From Oil Give Alaska a Big Payday

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: PALMER, Alaska, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Politically conservative it may be, but Alaska is the only state in the nation where redistribution of wealth is written into the state Constitution. The Last Frontier State pays people to live here, and never before will so much have been paid to so many.
This week 543,000 Alaskans -- from single-toothed toddlers to urban-phobic homesteaders -- will each receive a check for $1,130.68, their annual share of the oil wealth that has transformed this state since the 1970's. 
 Some will blow it in one night. About a third of the people will bank it. Some 30,000 people will never see it; creditors have first claim on what, for some families, is their only reliable source of income. Thousands of others will sign their Permanent Fund dividend check over to an airline in return for round-trip tickets to places that have more than three hours of daylight in December.
Anyone who can prove a year's worth of residency in the year before the payout is entitled to a dividend. College students who go out of state, but return on a regular basis, are eligible. Any baby born up to the last day of the qualifying year will get a check. A family of four will receive $4,522.72 this year.
For merchants, the fund is a godsend. Stores peg their biggest sales to the dividend payout. Travel agencies do a booming business. Sales of snowmobiles perk up considerably. Bars are full, but that has never been a problem in Alaska.
Even as they make plans to spend this year's check, however, spme Alaskans are questioning whether the state should find some other way to use the fund, rather than give the money away.
What started as oil in Prudhoe Bay, an arm of the Beaufort Sea off northern Alaska, can end up in a little town like Palmer as literally music in the air.
"The Permanent Fund paid for these bagpipes," said Chris Behnke, a 13-year-old freshman at Palmer High School. He stood outside in the shadow of the great spine of the Alaskan Range, his fingers freezing, sending notes to the sky on his vintage instrument. His $990 check last year was just enough to pay for the bagpipes.
"The only income I get is from the fund," Chris said. "Most kids put it into Nintendo. This was my dream. The only problem is, it is not compatible with any other instrument, so I have to practice alone."
Palmer started as a socialist experiment in the 1930's, when several hundred Dust Bowl families from the Midwest were given land to farm here in the Matanuska Valley 40 miles northeast of Anchorage. Most of the farms are long gone, but October never fails to bring a harvest from the Permanent Fund.
"I might do a little traveling on this year's check," said John Schreiber, 81, a Palmer pioneer.
Addicted as they are to oil money, which pays for 85 percent of the state government, many Alaskans now think their annual dividend checks can continue indefinitely even if the North Slope oil wells run dry.
That is because this year's windfall, the biggest payout in the 20 years since the Permanent Fund was established, was earned primarily from things that had nothing to do with oil. Alaskans, as shareholders in what is essentially a state-run mutual fund, own things like an industrial complex in Orlando, Fla., and an office building in Washington, D.C.
The fund, which was established as a rainy-day reserve for the time when the oil companies leave, has grown to $20 billion in principal. Half the earnings from an average year are given back in the dividends. The principal is not touched.
In the year ended June 30 the fund earned $1.8 billion, and slightly more than half of those profits were from the stock market. From an array of outside investments, the fund made six times as much as it took in from oil money. This heralds a day, many Alaskans say, when the state will be free of its dependency on oil, but will remain hooked on the fringe benefits that started beneath the Arctic ice.
"It provides stability, it provides hope for the future and it gives everyone a sense of accomplishment that we turned a nonrenewable resource into a renewable one," said Jim Kelly, a spokesman for the Alaska Permanent Fund, the quasi-public agency that manages the money.
To people outside of Alaska, which has no state income tax or sales tax, the idea that a government agency pays people for simply living in the state seems like a fantasy. Alaska is often compared to Saudi Arabia, without the heat.
"People in the Lower 48 ask me what I do for a living," said Mike McGee, who runs the dividend operation at the Permanent Fund. "I get a big kick out of saying, 'I'm giving away money to people.' "
But on this, the fund's 20th anniversary, a debate is raging among some Alaskans over whether the state should do something else with the money.
"We should use the fund to buy influence as all the other special interests do," Charles M. Springer wrote in a forum in The Anchorage Daily News. He says lobbyists are far more effective than legislators, and could be put to work for Alaska by lobbying for more oil drilling.
Others fear that this tax-free, dividend-rich state is becoming too much of a good thing. "If Alaska becomes so utopian in providing free money and low or no taxes, we might have to pay people to stay away," wrote Jack F. Burton.
That seems unlikely. The cost of living in Alaska is still higher than in almost any other state. Winters are long, dark and cold. Population growth is steady, but not spectacular.
The economy rises and falls on the price of oil, although tourism and fishing are fast-growing industries. The dividend check has become so entrenched that most people see it as simply a right of residency. When the checks are sent out on Wednesday -- most of them deposited directly into bank accounts -- it will be the largest single transfer of wealth of any day in Alaska.
Jack Roberts and Nathan Hocker, fishing in the twilight of an October evening, said they planned to use the money to go on vacation and to bring relatives up from "outside," as the Lower 48 -- the 48 contiguous states -- are sometimes called here.
Michelle Brosnan, divorced with two children, plans to pay some bills. "We give up a lot by living in Alaska," she said. "I don't count on the check. But when it comes, it's a windfall."
Ms. Brosnan does not think the bonus will last much longer, no matter how well the fund has done in the stock market. "The whole Alaskan economy is built on things that we can't sustain," she said. "Why should we think this is any different?"
Some merchants say it would be tough to make it through the year without the dividend check.
"We have a lot of people who come into the store, eyeballing some special gift, and then telling me they'll be back soon as the check lands," said Eric Berwald, who owns North Star Gifts in Palmer.
"People come up in the summer and say, 'You mean they actually pay you to live here?' he continued. "Yeah, they do. But come back in December and you'll see why."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1020 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: POLITICAL MEMO;
On Volatile Social and Cultural Issues, Silence

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The contours of the final weeks of the Presidential campaign seemed clear when this race began a year ago: The Republican candidate would use divisive social issues -- chiefly, affirmative action, immigration and welfare -- to drive President Clinton to the left and ultimately off the edge of the electoral map.
But for all of the hopes Republicans once attached to these three subjects that served them so well in the 1994 Congressional and gubernatorial elections, they have essentially vanished from sight as Bob Dole moves into the last weeks of his Presidential campaign. So have the less prominent but equally volatile social issues of abortion and homosexuals in the military. 
 They did not come up in the course of 90 minutes of debate between Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton on Sunday evening. None are featured in Mr. Dole's television advertisements, and they are rarely, if ever, mentioned in his speeches these days. Nor are there plans, at least for now, Mr. Dole's aides said today, to invoke them in speeches or advertisements in the weeks ahead.
Indeed, Mr. Dole's electoral strategy has become notable as much for what it is not, as for what it is. It is principally about his economic plan to cut taxes 15 percent and, if today's remarks in New Jersey were any indication, sharp attacks on Mr. Clinton's ethics and character. It is not about the kind of issues that Republican strategists and candidates once calculated would bring down a sitting President.
"The whole medley of social and cultural issues utterly disappeared Sunday night," William Kristol, the editor of a conservative publication, The Weekly Standard, said today. "And what's ironic are that those are the issues on which you could make a real case that Clinton is a liberal -- and stayed to the left."
That Mr. Dole has not been able to turn these issues to his advantage is a comment on Mr. Clinton's success in defusing them by embracing them, with welfare being the most obvious example.
But it also suggests just how much Mr. Dole's fellow Republicans in the House let the air out of his tires by compromising with Mr. Clinton on matters like immigration restrictions, before adjourning for their own campaigns.
The campaign's public statements to the contrary, it suggests that Mr. Dole may well have given up on California, a state where tough stands on immigration and affirmative action have proved to be electoral winners, as Gov. Pete Wilson demonstrated in his come-from-behind victory in 1994. And it shows the price that Mr. Dole is paying for aligning himself with two Republicans whose views on social issues are often close to the center of the Republican Party (and, some conservatives might argue, to those of Mr. Dole himself): Jack Kemp, his running-mate, and Gen. Colin L. Powell, who will travel with Mr. Dole again on Thursday in Ohio.
Mr. Kemp and Mr. Powell have been among the party's defenders of the kind of affirmative action programs that Mr. Dole had introduced legislation to abolish as he prepared to run for President. At the time, he was contemplating a field of Republican Presidential hopefuls including Governor Wilson, who endorsed similar moves in California.
For many conservatives, Mr. Dole's performance on Sunday resurrected long-standing concerns about whether Mr. Dole is indeed the true conservative he declared himself to be this past winter as he sought the party's nomination from a generally conservative primary electorate. His choice of subjects on Sunday, and on the campaign trail beforehand, only seemed to confirm their greatest fear -- that he had cast aside social issues, even Mr. Clinton's veto of legislation that bans some forms of late-term abortions.
"That's an issue that strikes home with an awful lot of people," said Lyn Nofziger, a former aide to President Ronald Reagan, who was among those surprised that Mr. Dole never raised it in the Presidential debate. (He mentions it only intermittently while campaigning.)
Why this has happened is the subject of discussion among conservatives, who are beginning to raise questions with which Mr. Dole and his campaign strategists will have to deal with should he not win this election after failing to heed the conservatives' advice. On the morning after the debate, several conservatives sent memorandums to the campaign, asking why Mr. Dole insisted on relying so heavily on economic arguments when the public perception of the economy was so cheery.
"I think the tax cut and the fiscal message is a winning message -- but only if it's complemented with a morals and values message," said Ralph Reed, the executive director of the Christian Coalition. He said Mr. Dole needed "to take some of the cultural wedge issues and use them as a magnet to draw traditional voters."
Part of what is going on is the result of a struggle in Mr. Dole's campaign, among those who believe that his tax cut plan will win out in the end. But Mr. Reed was among several suggesting that the number of people who will switch their vote in this economy is, in truth, minimal.
To a limited extent, Mr. Dole's inability to use these issues reflects forces beyond his control. Mr. Dole, in his announcement speech, said affirmative action was "another Federal policy out of control," and his aides welcomed an anti-affirmative action referendum initiative in California as a way to sharpen their differences with Mr. Clinton.
Since then, Mr. Dole has avoided advertising that position, in part because opposition to affirmative action worries the very constituency with which he most needs to improve his standing: women.
"Quite frankly there are concerns about fostering a debate in a broad sense on an issue that can be divisive," Mr. Dole's communications director, John Buckley, said today.
It is that cautiousness that has bothered Mr. Dole's conservative critics from the start. "The problem is that Dole is spooked on these social and cultural issues," Mr. Kristol said. "He is not comfortable making the case about them. But these are in fact that issues that accounted for the Republican victory in 1994."
